title: 'Just grateful no one was home' - Resident reflects on Wednesday evening house fire
author: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com
content:
'Just grateful no one was home' - Resident reflects on Wednesday evening house fire

 October 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 516
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Clara Dorsey was sitting in a red beach chair with neighbors, family and friends on the curb in front of the melted yellow siding and charred timbers of her home on Thursday, Oct. 26.Red caution tape blew in the breeze and even the metal house number, 21, is seared.The evening before, a structure fire tore through the duplex where Dorsey has rented her apartment for 20 years."I am just glad it wasn't in the night time," she said."We were sitting on the porch, and I left for a few minutes. When I came back it was all on fire." According to the fire marshal, there were no injuries or fatalities reported in the blaze, but all of the residents' belongings were lost.Dorsey's beloved terrier, Peanut, has been missing since the event. She said she thought about looking for the remains in the charred rubble, but she is pretty sure there is nothing left.The fire, which broke out at 21 South West Street in Easton shortly after 5:30 p.m. on Wednesday, drew the attention of passersby, who alerted emergency officials to the blaze."It was some of them from the American Legion (which is next door) that were sitting there playing cards. They looked out the window," Dorsey said.The fire marshal estimates that $50,000 worth of damage was done to the building.They could not determine the smoke alarm status, and there was no sprinkler action."The building consisted of two apartments with the fire originating in the kitchen area of the downstairs apartment," the fire marshal wrote in a report about the incident."The families in both apartments were displaced due to the fire." Investigations into the preliminary cause of the blaze are still ongoing.Dorsey said her next step is to find a new place to live.She said she is being taken care of and has a place to sleep in the meantime."If everybody could say a prayer and thanks to everybody.This is different than yesterday when it happened.It was chaotic," Dorsey said.60 emergency personnel responded to the fire, according to the fire marshal's report, representing five volunteer fire departments, along with law enforcement and EMS personnel.Dorsey said in the aftermath of the event, she leans on gratitude that no one was hurt. She is also grateful she had renter's insurance."I've got to wait for the insurance adjuster to call me.They want to come and take pictures," she said.A GoFundMe has been established by Dorsey's grandson, De'Andre Dorsey.In the description on the page, De'Andre wrote "Unfortunately my grandma's house caught on fire today (10/25), and she lost everything. Her dog, Peanut, who was by her side for 14 years, clothes, family photos, important letters and documents, several sentimental items, and, unfortunately, her savings were in her house." He continued, "My grandmother has given her heart to the community of Easton, and today she is in desperate need of yours." More details can be found at https://www.gofundme.com/f/7u4cy-my-grandma. 
 
 Caption: TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRA
 
The fire is said to have originated in the kitchen of the duplex's downstairs unit. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a residential fire incident, emphasizing emergency response, safety implications, and community impact. While it includes local elements, the core focus is on the public safety aspect of the fire event.

title: Beach town bans smoking, eating cannabis - Pot now prohibited on public property and in meeting places in Chesapeake Beach
author: Marty Madden; mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Beach town bans smoking, eating cannabis - Pot now prohibited on public property and in meeting places in Chesapeake Beach

 October 31, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Marty Madden; mmadden@somdnews.com | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 414
 Words 

 Read News Document

 With no comment from the public during a hearing or remarks from the town council during an Oct. 19 monthly meeting, the town ofChes-apeake Beach unanimously passed an ordinance addressing legal cannabis.The new law prohibits the smoking or ingesting of cannabis in several public areas, including town hall, Veterans Park, Bayfront Park, Kellam's Field, boardwalk and town pocket parks. Additionally, the ban includes public areas at local businesses.The ordinance was discussed during the mayor and council's September work session, with it then being introduced during that month's council meeting.Acting upon Maryland voters' approval by referendum of the legalization of recreational marijuana for adults 21 or older, the Maryland General Assembly passed the accompanying Cannabis Reform Act earlier this year."Because I'm a nerd, I probably read that 100-page bill 20 or 30 times," Chesapeake Beach Mayor Patrick "Irish" Mahoney declared during the September work session.After familiarizing himself with the new law, Mahoney told the council he has testified before a state Senate committee and worked with other mayors through the Maryland Municipal League to find ways to comply without ceding total control."Just common sense," Councilwoman Valerie Beaudin said of the ordinance draft. "It falls along the lines ofwhat's already in place" for smoking and vaping tobacco and drinking alcohol.Councilman Charlie Fink said he wanted assurances the ordinance wouldn't result in people "being stopped and frisked.""If you have it in your pocket, that's fine,"Todd Pounds, town attorney, stated.During that same work session the mayor and council discussed a second cannabis-related ordinance affecting the legal sale of the substance within the town limits.Mahoney noted that unlike many other states, Maryland lawmakers declined to consider a "local opt out" for state jurisdictions that don't wish to have cannabis sales within their confines."You're trying to create a wholesome environment," Mahoney said of a prohibition on cannabis sales.The mayor added that the way the state is planning to tax the newly legalized product and distribute receipts to jurisdictions would mean the town would receive "basically nothing."A public hearing on the latter ordinance proposal did not happen at the October meeting.When asked late last week why there was no hearing for the other proposed ordinance, Mahoney told Southern Maryland News that he learned at a Maryland Municipal League meeting recently that the state legislature is planning to revisit the law next session to clear up some of its ambiguous aspects. 
 
 Caption: TOWN OF CHESAPEAKE BEACH PHOTO
 
Patrick "Irish" Mahoney is the mayor of Chesapeake Beach. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: School bus crash sends 11 to hospital
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
School bus crash sends 11 to hospital

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1A | Section: News 
 
 425
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Eleven patients were transported to the hospital following a crash between a SUV and a Caroline County school bus near the intersection of Matthewstown Road and Three Bridge Branch Road just before 8 a.m.Monday morning.According to a preliminary investigation by Maryland State Police, a Kia Sportage failed to stop at a stop sign at a four-way intersection and crashed into the side of the bus.The school bus rolled over.According to a statement from Caroline County Public Schools, the bus was transporting high school students involved in the Navy Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps program to Easton High School. Nine students and the bus driver were transported to area hospitals. All parents of children on the bus were notified.The juvenile driver of the Kia Sportage, whose identity is being withheld by police at this time, was transported to an area hospital for treatment of injuries.In an email sent to parents Monday morning, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said the driver was an Easton High School student.Police said the cause of the crash is under investigation. Charges may be filed pending the outcome of the investigation.Fog blanketed the area around the time of the crash. Neither Talbot County Public Schools nor Caroline County Public Schools issued a fog delay earlier in the morning.Troopers from the Maryland State Police Easton Barrack, Commercial Vehicle Enforcement Division and crash team responded to the scene to assist.All lanes on Matthewstown Road at Three Bridge Branch Road were closed for several hours during the investigation.Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and Caroline County Sheriff's Office also responded to the scene to assist. 
 
 Caption: TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
A school bus lays on its side in the roadway following a Monday morning crash involving this SUV.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT

TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
A member of Maryland State Police inspects the bottom of the bus that turned over at the intersection of Route 328 and Three Bridge Branch Road on Monday, Oct. 30. The rear and roof escape hatches are open.

Although the bus crash occurred at the intersection of Route 328 and Three Bridge Branch Road, side roads were blocked off. They closed off Route 328 at Black Dog Alley. title: Preston man pleads guilty to attempted murder - CRIME
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Preston man pleads guilty to attempted murder - CRIME

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 2A | Section: News 
 
 405
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - A Preston man pleaded guilty Monday to attempted murder in connection to the February 2022 stabbing of a young woman.After waiving his right to a jury trial two weeks ago, Mark William Thompkins, 25, pleaded guilty to attempted second-degree murder during a hearing in Caroline County Circuit Court.The plea reached Monday comes over a year and a half after the stabbing of a then 25-year-old woman near Holly Park Drive and Gilpin Point Road in Preston shortly before 3 p.m. on Feb. 17, 2022.According to Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin, trash collection workers near the scene first saw the woman sitting in the driver's seat of her vehicle with a man, later identified as Thompkins, seated behind her. Thompkins began striking the woman with his fists, then brandished a knife to stab her neck.The woman ran from her vehicle and collapsed in the front yard of a nearby house. Thompkins cradled her while holding the knife to his own throat, Franklin said.A witness attempted to help the victim but Thompkins threatened them, pointing the knife at them and yelling for them to get back.Multiple law enforcement agencies, including the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, Maryland State Police and Maryland Natural Resources Police, responded to the stabbing.Franklin said Thompkins punctured his own neck with a knife while running to the woods, evading officers.After 15 minutes and the use of multiple non-lethal methods, including a taser, to diffuse the situation, a state trooper was able to knock the knife out of Thompkins' hand to detain him, police said.Both Thompkins and the woman were flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore for treatment of their injuries.Following his arrest, a judge found Thompkins incompetent to stand trial in April 2022.He was committed to the Maryland Department of Health until August of this year, then transferred back to a local detention center upon being found competent, according to court filings.In court Monday, Franklin said he will recommend a 30-year sentence with all but 15 years of active incarceration suspended, followed by five years of supervised probation and special mental health conditions.State sentencing guidelines recommend five to 10 years, said Jesse Hicks, Thompkins' attorney. The plea is not binding, meaning a judge has the ability to impose a higher or lower sentence than what is recommended.Sentencing will be deferred until Feb. 1, 2024. 
 
 Caption: PHOTO BY MIKE DETMER
 
Police on scene in Preston for a reported stabbing Thursday, Feb. 17, 2022. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'We made a big impact' - Greensboro PD's Trams promoted, Chief Paugh joins Sheriff's Office
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
'We made a big impact' - Greensboro PD's Trams promoted, Chief Paugh joins Sheriff's Office

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 3B | Section: News 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO - While one Greensboro police officer was promoted Monday morning, Oct. 30, the chief announced his departure to join the Caroline County Sheriff's Office.But the focus was on Greensboro Police Chief George Paugh's promotion of Officer Lenox Trams to the rank of lieutenant, pinning his bars on his collar during an informal ceremony at the Town Meeting Hall on Main Street."Well, I'm very humbled," Trams said. "I was recruited here to make a difference and reinstate the love for law enforcement, so I've been trying to do that for seven months, and I'm going to continue to do that. It's a great little town." "I'm going to stay and watch this thing grow, and continue to give excellent service to the citizens and the town," Trams said."We're very proud to have you, and you're doing a fantastic job," Town manager Tammy Kelledes said.Several town employees attended the ceremony. Paugh thanked them and said, "I want to thank you guys for taking your time out of your busy Monday to join Lenox on his special day. It's been a long time coming." "Even though it's been a short period of time in Greensboro, you definitely made an impact in the community," he told Trams."I'm always stopped and told about how well you're doing and how you interact with the community, and that's huge. And that's who you are. You're Mr. Community Policeman," Paugh said."You've done some amazing things, and you're worthy of the rank." Trams joined the Greensboro Police Department with Paugh seven months ago.Most of their law enforcement careers were spent with the Easton Police Department.Trams, 48, was a police officer in Easton for 22 years, completing his career there as a school resource officer at Easton Middle School.Paugh, 50, a 26-year veteran of the Easton Police Department, is leaving soon to join the Caroline County Sheriff's Office as commander of criminal investigations and a lieutenant, the same rank he attained with the EPD.In only seven months, Paugh said, "We made a big impact." "We completely redid all the cars - the technology in them. Everything is up to date," he said. "We got a new CAD (computer-aided dispatch) system, new body cameras, new in-car cameras, all new computer systems" - all updates the department "very, very much" needed.

title: St. Michaels peeping Tom sentenced to 3 years
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
St. Michaels peeping Tom sentenced to 3 years

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 276
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The St.Michaels man previously convicted of being a peeping Tom was sentenced Oct. 18 to just over three years in jail.Talbot District Court Judge Karen Ketterman sentenced Diego Albarado Lopez, 31, to three years and 90 days of active incarceration after finding him guilty of stalking, harassment and trespassing as a peeping Tom.The charges stemmed from an incident captured on surveillance footage at a home on Jefferson Avenue in St. Michaels just after midnight on April 12.The home's residents contacted police several days later after seeing a man they identified as Lopez on their property during a review of previous surveillance footage.The footage showed the man walking toward the residents' bedroom window and holding his hands near his groin area, according to charging documents.The residents recognized Lopez from his March 2022 attempt to burglarize their home.Police said he was caught in the act by one of the residents, who detained Lopez until deputies arrived and arrested him.Lopez was previously convicted of being a peeping Tom and trespassing in May 2022 for following women home and peering in windows.He was sentenced to 4.5 months in jail and three years of supervised probation. Ketterman previously ordered Lopez to not have contact with any victims and to not enter or be found near several specific locations in St.Michaels.Lopez received about six months of credit for time already served in connection to the April charges. Following his release from jail, he will be placed on three years of supervised probation.Lopez will also be required to submit to a mental health evaluation and complete mental health and alcohol treatment.

title: Multiple arrests made after fights at Easton football game
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Multiple arrests made after fights at Easton football game

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 427
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Three teenagers were arrested following fights at the football game between Easton and Cambridge-South Dorchester high schools last week, and more arrests and charges are pending, police said.Just under seven minutes remained in the third quarter of the Friday, Oct. 27, game when play was suddenly stopped around 8 p.m. due to altercations in the stadium away from the playing field.In a news release, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office said several altercations between students erupted. No motive for the fights was identified by law enforcement.The two schools have a long-standing athletic rivalry. Prior to Friday night, no incidents or similar altercations had occurred between the two recently.Fans were instructed to leave the stadium by school administrators and local law enforcement officers, while the respective coaching staff led their teams off the field.In an email statement Wednesday, Talbot County Public Schools said the safety of students and staff is always the highest priority."We are grateful for the support of local law enforcement, and the quick and decisive action taken by the Easton High administration in addressing the situation for the best interests of all concerned," said Debbie Gardner, TCPS' director of communications Easton High School's athletic director Kurisha Hoffman said in a text Saturday night that the schools agreed to rule the game a "no contest," meaning it doesn't count for either team.Police said three arrests have been made so far, clarifying an earlier news release that said five juveniles were arrested.A 17-year-old Easton boy was charged with refusing to comply with a police order, obstructing and hindering, disorderly conduct and resisting arrest.A 13-year-old Cambridge boy and a 15-year-old Trappe boy were both charged with assault and disorderly conduct.All three teens were charged by referral to the Department of Juvenile Services and released to their parents.Police said the arrests of two adults, a man and a woman, were still pending as of Wednesday afternoon.Two additional juvenile girls have been identified and also will be charged, police said.As of 12:30 p.m. Wednesday, police said one female connected to the altercations has yet to be identified as a juvenile or adult.Investigators and school resource officers, along with the Talbot and Dorchester counties' boards of education, will review videos in an attempt to identify other involved juveniles, who could possibly face criminal charges, police said.If anyone has information, they are requested to contact the Talbot County Sheriff's Office at 410-822-1020, by email at sheriff@talbotcountymd.gov, on Facebook at Talbot County Sheriff's Office or online at talbotsheriff.org.Star Democrat Sports Editor William Haufe contributed to this article. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Jury finds Tilghman man guilty of child sexual abuse
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Jury finds Tilghman man guilty of child sexual abuse

 November 3, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 732
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - After roughly five hours of deliberation Thursday, a Talbot County jury found a Tilghman man guilty on all but one count relating to the sexual abuse of a child earlier this year.The jury found Eric L. Werner guilty of 16 counts, including sexual abuse of a minor, third-and fourth-degree sex offenses, second-degree assault and displaying obscene matter to a minor.However, the jury did not convict Werner on one count of sexual abuse of a minor.The verdict comes after a four-day jury trial in Talbot County Circuit Court.The child's mother, whom the Star Democrat is not naming to protect the victim's privacy, expressed gratitude for the guilty verdict."Justice has been served today," she said in an email. "We can't thank the Talbot County Sheriff's (Office), and the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office enough for their dedication to this case and the support that they've given my daughter and our family these past 8 months." She continued: "I'd also like to express how important it is that parents, and guardians educate themselves and their children on the statistics and signs of sexual abuse and grooming. Empower your kids to speak up if someone is hurting them, being inappropriate with them, or making them feel uncomfortable. If your child discloses abuse to you, believe them, support them, and report the abuse to authorities or a mandatory reporter." "What happened to my daughter was horrible, but it could have been a lot worse if she had not spoken up when she did.She will carry this trauma with her for the rest of her life, but we all hope that because she spoke up, it will help encourage another child to do the same and stop their abuse." Defense attorney Philip Cronan said he was disappointed in the verdict, but would see what comes next with sentencing, which is yet to be scheduled.Detectives from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office began investigating Werner, 61, in February after learning of multiple child sexual abuse incidents that occurred at a home in Tilghman that month.Police investigation revealed that Werner sexually assaulted a preteen girl through inappropriately touching her on three different occasions in February.Werner showed the child pornographic videos, which the child remembered in detail during the trial. Police testified to a specific adult website appearing in Werner's phone's search history.In closing arguments Thursday, Talbot County Deputy State's Attorney Chelsea Endzel highlighted the testimony and evidence presented during the trial as concrete proof that Werner established an inappropriate relationship with the child, grooming her, she said.Numerous text messages between the two, plus the child testifying to Werner initiating sexual conversations with her, further illustrated the inappropriate relationship, Endzel said.Later, Werner, asking the child to delete messages, indicated that he continued to coax the child into becoming comfortable with sexual contact, she added.Endzel also pointed to recordings of calls Werner made to his wife while in the county jail as additional corroboration for his guilt. During one call, Werner said the truth would get him "into some trouble." And during another, he attempted to discredit her, telling his wife they needed to give a reason why she would lie, Endzel said.Countering the prosecution, Cronan acknowledged that the allegations against Werner would bother any juror, but questioned what the prosecution presented as facts.A point of contention between both attorneys Thursday morning was whether or not Werner had permanent or temporary care or custody or responsibility for the supervision of the child - criteria that needed to be met to move forward with the sexual abuse of a minor charges.Though Talbot Circuit Judge Stephen H. Kehoe ruled that the prosecution had provided evidence demonstrating that Werner had temporary responsibility for the child during the incidents, Cronan still questioned if there was a change in responsibility between adults during his closing arguments.Cronan also questioned the consistency of the child's statements made to police compared to what she testified to on the witness stand, urging the jurors to find Werner not guilty if they only thought he "probably" or "maybe" touched the child inappropriately.In her final remarks to the jurors, Endzel said the child had no incentive to lie. She turned attention back to Werner, again highlighting his request for the child to delete text messages and pointing to the jail calls attempting to discredit her story."If that's not consciousness of guilt, I don't know what is," she said. 
 
 Caption: ERIC WERNER 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal trial involving child sexual abuse, focusing on the legal proceedings, jury verdict, and implications for community safety. While local government and national news could be tangentially related, the core subject aligns most directly with public safety due to its focus on criminal justice and community protection.

title: Man sentenced for Easton Bank of America robbery
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Man sentenced for Easton Bank of America robbery

 November 3, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 394
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - A Federalsburg man was sentenced Friday, Oct. 27, to eight years in prison for robbing the Bank of America in downtown Easton in April.Presiding Senior Judge C. Carey Deeley, Jr. sentenced Todd Holtzman, 57, to 15 years in prison and suspended all but eight years of active incarceration after he pleaded guilty to robbery.The case against Holtzman stemmed from his role in robbery reported shortly after 12:30 p.m. on Monday, April 17.Police said a man, later identified as Holtzman, entered the Bank of America from its rear entrance on Goldsborough Street and confronted a teller, demanding bills in certain denominations.The teller told police that the man put a black grocery bag under the sneeze guard at the counter and asked for money without dye packs or alarms, according to charging documents. The teller also told police that the man said he would not hurt her.After the teller gave the man the money, the man exited the bank from the same entrance on Goldsborough Street.The total amount stolen was $3,210, police said in charging documents.Holtzman will have to pay Bank of America the full stolen amount as restitution.Video surveillance reviewed later showed Holtzman discarding the hoodie and sunglasses in the area of 25 N. Harrison Street, police said.A K-9 team from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office tracked him to the area of the Walmart on Elliott Road near the bus stop, but did not find him.A Delmarva Community Transit bus driver told police they recalled picking up the man from Walmart about 45 minutes after the robbery and dropping him off in Cambridge 30 minutes later.In the same hearing in Talbot County Circuit Court, Holtzman also pleaded guilty to fourth-degree burglary in connection to an incident at Walgreens about a week before the bank robbery. He received a three-year sentence, all of which was suspended, according to court filings.Following his release from prison, Holtzman will be placed on five years of supervised probation. He is barred from entering the Bank of America and Walgreens.

title: Cambridge man charged with armed carjacking, robbery

Cambridge man charged with armed carjacking, robbery

 November 3, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 CAMBRIDGE - A Cambridge man was arrested Oct. 27 on 36 charges, including armed carjacking, armed robbery, assault, use of a firearm, reckless endangerment and theft.Kevin McClain, 53, was arrested in the 700 block of Race Street on Oct. 27. Police said McClain had an active Dorchester County District Court arrest warrant.Charges stem from an Oct. 3 incident where the Cambridge Police Department said officers responded to the 400 block of Caribbean Avenue around 1:40 a.m. regarding an armed robbery.Police said officers contacted the victim, who reported that after leaving their residence with a friend, another male subject came from the side of the residence, approaching the victim and knocking them to the ground.Police said the victim reported that the teen pulled out a handgun pointing and threatening to shoot them as he went through the victim's pockets, taking their wallet and vehicle keys. The victim then observed the friend he had met with, and the other male suspect get into the vehicle and leave the area.An investigation determined the suspect with the gun was a 17-year-old boy from Cambridge, police said. The teen was arrested and and charged as an adult.Police said that upon further investigation, McClain was identified as the "friend" of the victim.After being processed by CPD and having an initial appearance before a court commissioner, McClain was transported to the Dorchester County Department of Corrections on no bond.

title: Cambridge man sentenced to five years for reckless endangerment
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge man sentenced to five years for reckless endangerment

 November 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 532
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - A Cambridge man was sentenced Monday to five years in prison for reckless endangerment and illegal possession of a firearm in connection to last year's fatal Fourth of July shooting in the town.Emphasizing the tragic nature of the shooting, Circuit Judge Karen Dean handed down a sentence consistent with the prosecutor's recommendation to Dominic Savage, 34: five years of incarceration for illegal possession of a regulated firearm and five years, all suspended, for reckless endangerment."The level of gun violence in this town is astonishing," said Dean, who splits time between courts in Dorchester and Wicomico counties.Officers from the Cambridge Police Department responded to the 1000 block of Cosby Avenue just before 9 p.m. on July 4, 2022, for a reported shooting. There, police found 24-year-old Tyuane Johnson of Cambridge with a gunshot wound to the right side of his head.Over 30 spent shell casings were observed by police in various areas around the scene.Police attempted lifesaving measures while waiting for paramedics.Johnson was transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Dorchester, where he was pronounced dead.Autopsy results from the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner ruled Johnson's death a homicide from a gunshot wound.According to Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard, police identified Savage in surveillance video of the shooting.L eonard said Savage fired a gun in the area, then fled toward a home on Greenwood Avenue.Savage was already prohibited from owning a firearm due to a previous conviction.During the shooting, Savage also sustained a gunshot wound to his left foot and left a trail of blood from the scene to Greenwood Avenue.In recommending the maximum penalty on the firearm charge, Leonard said Johnson's family was still not satisfied.In the months after the shooting, nearly a dozen men were arrested and charged in connection to Johnson's death and the chaotic scene that unfolded that night, including Savage.Charges against two of the men were eventually dismissed; others received time served sentences after pleading guilty to lesser charges. Three men were handed sentences ranging from 18 months to five years, to be served in state prisons.In September, Deondray Stanford, 23, of Cambridge, was sentenced to 10 years in prison for manslaughter, the most significant punishment in the case.But to the family, no plea would ever fill the hole left by Johnson's death, Leonard said.Defense attorney Andrea Jaskulsky agreed that Johnson's death was a tragedy, but asserted that Savage was the intended target of the fatal shooting. Other men charged in connection to the shooting were upset with Savage for not intimidating a witness in a different court case, she said.It was "impossible" to tell what was going on from the surveillance video, Jaskulsky added.Savage spoke briefly, saying that he was only walking out of his front door and didn't intend to hurt anyone.Both Savage and Jaskulsky asked the judge for consideration for a work-release program, which was opposed by Leonard and denied by Dean, though Dean said she would recommend work programs for him.Savage will receive credit for the 16 months already served in the county jail since his arrest last July.He will also be required to submit to mental health and substance abuse evaluations. 
 
 Caption: FILE PHOTO 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Outdoor fire spreads, ignites structure near Easton

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 EASTON - An outdoor fire spread quickly thanks to dry pine needles behind a manufactured home in the 10000 block of Hailem School Road Wednesday evening.The fire happened around 4 p.m., and no one was hurt, according to emergency officials at the scene. The home was significantly damaged after the fire spread, eventually igniting the structure.A resident was comforted by friends outside of the structure as firefighters from Easton and Cordova sprayed water and cut aluminum siding to assess and address the extent of the fire's spread.The residents had been burning trash in a simple brick pit to the side of the home before the blaze began to spread. The fire melted around 75 feet of the fence behind the home.Firefighters worked together to contain the blaze by 5 p.m.Hailem School Road was closed to traffic by local law enforcement.

title: Anton Black's family settles with state medical examiner
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Anton Black's family settles with state medical examiner

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 773
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS - A $235,000 settlement approved by the Board of Public Works resolved all claims in a federal lawsuit brought against the state medical examiner by the family of 19-year-old Anton Black, who died in Greensboro in 2018 after being restrained by police.The settlement, which includes a $100,000 payment to Black's family and $135,000 toward attorneys' fees, was approved without discussion during Wednesday's Board of Public Works meeting.The settlement also "makes necessary changes to the Maryland Office of the Chief Medical Examiner's process for autopsies conducted on people killed in law enforcement custody and requires notification to families about the results and their rights to challenge the results," according to a news release from the American Civil Liberties Union.Reforms to the state medical examiner's office include the adoption of a policy addressing how medical examiners handle deaths in custody, which includes those involving law enforcement restraint, according to the ACLU.The policy also incorporates and models guidelines from the National Association of Medical Examiners for determining how such deaths are investigated and how examiners determine causation.The ACLU said the reforms will instill more transparency, impartiality and "independence from improper law enforcement influence." The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner must also provide families with information on their rights to seek correction of an autopsy report and the procedures to seek that correction.In a statement, Richard Potter, the founder of the Coalition for Justice for Anton Black, called the settlement an "excellent first step," adding that community members must stay vigilant to ensure it's effective and increases accountability from within."I hope that with this settlement agencies will begin to recognize their own wrongdoings, catch them and change them before they cause harm," he said in the statement. "What is needed is a sense of shared ownership that can only come through trust and mutual accountability, with police confronting their own biases about mental illness, committing to de-escalation, and truly serving a diverse community." Black died on his mother's front steps on Sept. 15, 2018, after being chased, tased and restrained by three white police officers and a white civilian.That day, Black and a 12-year-old family friend were walking around Greensboro together when Black began pulling and dragging the child, who was calling out for help, garnering attention from onlookers that led to a call to police.The chase ended outside Black's home, where Greensboro Police Officer Thomas Webster IV, offduty Ridgely Police Chief Gary Manos, Centreville Police Officer Dennis Lannon and a civilian attempted to restrain Black, pressing his body against a wooden handicap ramp for six minutes while attempting to handcuff and shackle him.Black later became unresponsive, but continued breathing and had a pulse.Officers rolled Black on his side, then shifted him to a sitting position.After no further response, officers removed the handcuffs and began CPR. Black was later transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center in Easton, where he was pronounced dead that evening.The medical examiner ruled that Black's death was an accident caused by a heart condition, with bipolar disorder as a contributing cause.Unanswered questions surrounding Black's death and excessive use of force spurred the litigation. The family filed a wrongful death lawsuit against multiple police officers, towns and the state medical examiner involved in the case in December 2020.No one was charged in connection to Black's death.In August 2022, the family and coalition reached a settlement that required police departments in Greensboro, Ridgely and Centreville to overhaul use of force policies and the enhancement of resources for police confronting mental health emergencies; officer training in de-escalation, intervention and implicit bias; hiring transparency; and public complaint reporting.The settlement also included a $5 million payment to Black's family from the police and municipal defendants.Black's death caused his family and the coalition to become deeply involved in Maryland's campaign for police reform and accountability.Efforts by the family and the Coalition led to the passage of Anton's Law in 2021, which makes police discipline records available to the community under Maryland's Public Information Act.Sonia Kumar, a senior staff attorney with the ACLU of Maryland, said the "hardfought" settlement is about ensuring the medical examiner is truthful about what happens when people, particularly Black people, are killed by police or corrections officials."We can't prevent such deaths if we aren't honest about what caused them, and this settlement is a crucial step towards that goal in future cases," she said in a statement. "We hope this settlement will make a real, positive impact, but it is truly just the beginning of the reckoning needed to address decades of misrepresentations so we can bring justice to families still waiting for the government to tell the truth." 
 
 Caption: ANTON BLACK 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a legal settlement involving law enforcement actions, medical examiner reforms, and police accountability, which directly relates to public safety. While race and diversity issues are mentioned, the core subject is the interaction between law enforcement and medical systems, making Public Safety the top priority.

title: Easton Fire Department equipped for grain bin rescues
author: Contributed
content:
Easton Fire Department equipped for grain bin rescues

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 205
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Grain bins play a pivotal role in agriculture, offering secure storage and protection for large amounts of grain before sale or processing.However, these structures can present serious hazards.Thanks to the nominations of Marylanders, 10 fire departments have won grain bin rescue equipment through Nationwide's Grain Bin Safety advocacy campaign, including the Easton Volunteer Fire Department."Maryland Farm Bureau is committed to the safety of our state's food producers," said Parker Welch, Executive Director of MDFB. "We are thrilled to team up with our partners at Nationwide to equip our courageous first responders with the training and resources necessary to prevent these tragedies." According to the 2022 Summary of U.S. Agricultural Confined Space-Related Injuries and Fatalities, more than 300 grain entrapments have been recorded in the past decade.In 2021, at least 29 grain entrapments were reported, resulting in 11 fatalities.Every February, MDFB celebrates National Grain Bin Safety Week to bring awareness to the dangers that grain bins can pose when safety measures are not enforced."Thanks to the Maryland Farm Bureau and Nationwide Insurance for providing us with the specialized equipment and training needed to perform safe and efficient grain bin rescues," said the Easton Volunteer Fire Department in a Facebook post.

title: Accessible AED added in Downtown Easton
author: Contributed
content:
Accessible AED added in Downtown Easton

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 389
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The first 24-hour publicly accessible automatic external defibrillator (AED) for downtown Easton is now operational, thanks to the collaboration of Talbot CARES and Bluepoint Hospitality.Talbot CARES, a program spearheaded by Talbot Paramedic Foundation, Team Trace and Talbot Emergency Services (DES), aims to provide publicly accessible defibrillators and additional emergency equipment around the county.Located on Washington Street adjacent to Doc's Downtown Grille, the newly placed station will ensure citizens have access to potentially life-saving equipment in case of an emergency, no matter what time it is.The station contains an AED device and other medical supplies, including a Stop the Bleed tourniquet kit and opioid overdose kits."We are incredibly proud of this station.It's the first time we've been able to place a station that is accessible 24 hours a day, outside of a public park or recreation area," said Rachael Cox, special programs paramedic for DES."By placing it in a prominent location downtown, we are hoping that this important resource will be utilized in emergencies by the surrounding community." Talbot Paramedic Foundation sponsored the AED. Bluepoint Hospitality sponsored the construction and installation of the cabinet and will ensure the station has access to constant power.Talbot Emergency Services will keep the station stocked and perform routine check-ups on the AED device."One of our priorities is for visitors and residents to feel safe downtown." said Michael Smith, head of security at Bluepoint Hospitality. "As part of this initiative, many Bluepoint staffers were certified in CPR, First Aid, AED and Stop the Bleed this year. We hope other downtown businesses join in on the efforts. The more staff that is certified, the better we can serve individuals with life-saving techniques before the professionals arrive." A nationally recognized model for placing public access AEDs, Talbot CARES has placed over 200 automatic external defibrillators (AEDs) in businesses, recreation facilities and parks, government buildings and more in Talbot County.To learn more about the program, contact Talbot Paramedic Foundation at talbotparamedic.org. Talbot County Emergency Services offers training sessions for local businesses and organizations, to learn more about available programming, reach out to Rachael Cox at rcox@talbotdes.org. 
 
 Caption: TALBOT COUNTY
 
Wayne Dyott, President of Talbot Paramedic Foundation discusses the AED system with Julia Foxwell, Director of Community Engagement at Bluepoint Hospitality. The Talbot CARE Station is located adjacent to Doc's Downtown Grille on Washington Street.

title: UM Shore glows green for veterans
author: Contributed

UM Shore glows green for veterans

 November 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 The University of Maryland Medical System honored veterans this week by joining Operation Green Light, a national initiative that shines a light on the needs and issues of those who have served.Operation Green Light invites anchor institutions and landmarks across the nation to illuminate their buildings in green, the color of hope and well-being, to show their support and appreciation for veterans and to raise awareness of the resources available to them.This is the second year that UMMS is participating in Operation Green Light, and once again, all 11 of its hospitals, including it's Mid-Shore locations, are glowing green.The green lights will remain on throug Veterans Day on Nov. 11."We express our deepest gratitude and respect to all the brave individuals who have served and sacrificed for our country. It is our honor to illuminate our hospitals in green this week as a symbol of our appreciation and support for our veterans," said Mohan Suntha, MD, MBA, president and CEO of UMMS."We are also proud to count many veterans among our team members, who bring their skills, values and dedication to providing quality health care to our communities." He continued, "UMMS also works closely with the military at our flagship hospital, the University of Maryland Medical Center in Baltimore, in programs focused on advancing and improving surgery techniques that can save lives on the battlefield and beyond. We salute our veterans and thank them for their service and courage."

title: Serving, protecting for 250 years - The Caroline County Sheriff's Office celebrates its sesquicentennial
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Serving, protecting for 250 years - The Caroline County Sheriff's Office celebrates its sesquicentennial

 November 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 1A | Section: News 
 
 979
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - To mark the 250th anniversary of the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, a new badge has been struck, containing symbols of its history dating to colonial Maryland.But the badge itself is a symbol of the long line of sheriffs who have held the office since 1773, when Thomas Hughlett of Greensboro was appointed by the British governor after the county was formed from parts of Dorchester and Queen Anne's counties.Bookending the long blue line is Sheriff Donnie Baker, who, like Hughlett, is also a Greensboro native. He's the county's 77th sheriff.Caroline County Deputy Lt. Jacob Andrew is the unofficial historian of the sheriff's office. And because he's the fifth generation of the Andrew family to serve the office during the past century, he's well-qualified for the job."Jake was just teaching me something," Baker said. "I didn't know that the first sheriff was buried up there (in Greensboro)." According to Andrew's research, Hughlett was a plantation owner appointed to a one-year term by the governor to be in charge of weights and scales because he was deemed trustworthy.Ironically, the next year he became captain of the Caroline County Militia Fifth Company, which encompassed Greensboro, Goldsboro and Bridgetown during the American Revolution.Hughlett later became a judge. He is buried in a crypt in a tiny, privately-owned graveyard in a Greensboro subdivision, the site of the Hughlett family farm.During the Civil War, John Wilson Saulsbury served a two-year term from 1861 to 1863 and was required to swear allegiance to the Union.Andrew said Sheriff James Temple, who served from 1923 to 1926 "was actually a pretty cool guy." A veteran of the Spanish-American War, Temple was known as the walking sheriff."He had the first Buick in Caroline County. He always told everybody that," Andrew said. However, "he hated driving it.So, if he had to go serve a warrant on somebody, he'd walk from Denton to Ridgely, lock them up and walk them back." "The original sheriff's office was pretty much a shed on the courthouse green, and it was very easy to break out of," Andrew said. The lynching on the green of Federalsburg blacksmith Marshall Price following accusations of murder in 1895 prompted the government to build a new jail across Gay Street on the Choptank River, where it stands today.In 1921, William Curtis Andrew, Jacob Andrew's great-great grandfather, became sheriff and served a two-year term. His son, William E. Andrew served from 1938 to 1946 and, following a four-year term by Saulsbury Sparks, served again from 1950 to 1961, dying of a heart attack in his office.William's son Louis C. Andrew served from 1961 to 1994, retiring when he was 70. His son, then-Deputy Charles Andrew, served as acting sheriff until Phil Brown was elected sheriff the following year.Back then, the sheriff and his family lived in the center section of what is now the Caroline County jail. Two wings were added to the large brick structure, but Charles Andrew remembers when the original section was home."I got to know a lot of inmates," he said.He recalls the night his "mother had a fit" when a naked woman was brought in by the state police."They had to come in the front door and walk down the hall which separated the living room and dining room directly back to that one-room office" at the back of the house, he said."I would have been seven or eight" years old, Charles Andrew said. "So, she made my father go to the commissioners, and that's when they put stairs on the side of the building to come in the outside door." "Back then, when my father started, he was only making $2,600 a year," he said. "They had to supply their own vehicle. The only thing the county gave them was a radio that went into their own private car." That center section of the current jail is called the Andrew Building today.Until 1994, both the sheriff's office and jail were under the jurisdiction of the sheriff, according to Charles Andrew. When Brown became sheriff, the county Department of Corrections was formed as a separate agency, and Charles Andrew served as the superintendent for 13 years, after serving in the sheriff's office for 20 years.Charles's son Jacob, now the fifth generation to serve in the sheriff's office, serves the county with almost 50 fellow deputies. After serving in the Air Force, Jacob Andrew joined the sheriff's office and has been on the job for 19 years. "I love it. I love my job," he said.The commemorative badge symbolizes not only his family's history of serving county citizens in the sheriff's office, but a long legacy of the office's commitment to public safety stretching back to the nation's founding.At the five points of the badge's star are a Revolutionary War soldier, the Caroline County Circuit Court building, the original courthouse before the renovations, the original sheriff's office on Gay Street, and the current office, completed in 2021 on Double Hills Road."One of the things that former Sheriff Randy Bounds wanted to do was have a wall of sheriff's (pictures)," Baker said."So I told him that Jake is going to fulfill that dream of his." The sheriff's office is seeking memorabilia from the public for a future museum or showcase. If you have any artifacts, photos or clippings you'd like to share, contact Lt. Jacob Andrew at 410-479-4124 or jandrew@carolinemd.org. 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Sheriff Donnie Baker commissioned this commemorative badge for the 250th anniversary of the Caroline County Sheriff's Office
 
COURTESY OF CCSO
 
Joining current Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker, center, are former Sheriff Phil Brown, left, and Sheriff Randy Bounds.
 
COURTESY OF CCSO
 
H. Saulsbury Sparks served as Caroline County Sheriff from 1934 to 1938, and again from 1942 to 1946. Note the handcuffs on his desktop.
 
COURTESY OF CCSO
 
Charles Andrew, left, served as acting sheriff and was a deputy for 20 years with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the history and legacy of the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, emphasizing its role in public safety over 250 years. While it touches on local government and historical aspects, the core theme aligns most directly with Public Safety as the sheriff's office is a law enforcement entity responsible for community safety.

title: Republicans pledge to 'restore balance' with public safety agenda
author: Steph Quinn; Capital News Service
content:
Republicans pledge to 'restore balance' with public safety agenda

 November 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Steph Quinn; Capital News Service | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 642
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS - Senate and House Republicans vowed Tuesday to redress what House Minority Leader Jason Buckel (R-Allegany) called Maryland's "soft on crime policies" with a 2024 public safety agenda that would intensify punishment for adults accused of gun-related and violent crimes and reverse reforms to the youth legal system passed by the General Assembly in 2022."The crime we're seeing in our communities is not anecdotal, nor media manufactured," said Senate Minority Leader Stephen Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil and Caroline). "It is real. The violence is real. And we are pleading with our Democrat colleagues to join us in making it their priority as well." The package would increase penalties for gun theft and violent firearms offenses, authorize law enforcement to search vehicles based on the smell of cannabis alone and limit eligibility for bail or reduced sentences for those charged with or convicted of violent crimes.One proposal would make theft of a firearm a felony - a measure Republicans have sponsored without success since 2018.Another would increase prison time and maximum fines for crimes committed with illegal firearms and would remove the "drug dealer loophole" whereby drug dealers receive a lighter sentence for possessing weapons than others committing similarly weighted offenses.A measure would eliminate reduced prison time for good behavior for those convicted of first-or second-degree murder, cap such reductions for other crimes of violence and prohibit bail for those accused of a crime of violence while facing pending violent crime charges.House and Senate Democratic leaders could not be reached to comment on the likelihood that the proposals in the package will clear Democratic majorities in both chambers.The youth justice proposal would require under-13 youth to appear before a juvenile court upon arrest for crimes involving firearms and broaden the juvenile court's jurisdiction to include youth on their third arrest for nonviolent crimes, including auto thefts. It would also allow police to interrogate youth with parental consent alone, rather than requiring that a young person first consult with an attorney.The proposal would allow law enforcement to skirt the Child in Need of Supervision process, which provides a pathway for police or citizens to enlist help from the Department of Juvenile Services in connecting youth of any age with services.Del. Jesse Pippy (R-Frederick) said current law, including the CINS process, has neither held "offenders that happen to be juveniles" accountable nor connected them with services."The argument we're hearing from on the street is (that) law enforcement doesn't know what to do with these kids," Pippy said."So they're not going anywhere.They're not getting any services. No one's talking with them. No one's following up with them." DJS data shows that most CINS cases end in referrals to services rather than in court, but also that law enforcement are using the process infrequently in much of the state.Though Pippy said he's open to programs to educate police officers on the CINS process, which dates to 1969 in Maryland law, he and others said that CINS is not sufficient.Buckel said youth involved in escalating and violent crimes "need more than what theChild In Need of Supervision system can provide." Pointing to closures of DJS residential facilities in western Maryland, Buckel suggested committed placement in DJS residential facilities could give youth "opportunities to succeed." "They're not draconian prisons," he said. "They're getting classes.They're getting education." But advocates of youth legal reform have pointed to research showing that youth incarceration increases the likelihood of recidivism and called for long-term investment in resource-starved communities.Senate Minority Whip Justin Ready (R-Frederick and Carroll) stressed a need for balance in comments after the press conference, saying, "I think we need to provide more accountability and more services that are truly effective." 
 
 Caption: CAPITOL NEWS SERVICE
 
Maryland Senate Minority Leader Stephen Hershey introduces the 2024 public safety agenda of the Joint Republican Caucus in Annapolis on Nov. 14. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Republican legislative proposals to strengthen public safety measures, including criminal justice reforms, firearm regulations, and youth justice system changes. While local government actions are mentioned, the core theme centers on public safety policies and crime prevention strategies.

title: Students evacuated for bomb threat at Easton Middle School
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Students evacuated for bomb threat at Easton Middle School

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 280
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Students and staff at Easton Middle School were evacuated Wednesday morning after the school administration received a bomb threat.According to a news release from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, front desk staff at the middle school received a bomb threat via telephone around 9:25 a.m.Wednesday.The caller said there were numerous explosive devices throughout the building that would detonate at a specified time, police said.Police said all identified calls were made from a New Jersey area code.School officials followed emergency policies and safely evacuated students and staff to St. Marks Methodist Church in Easton.Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office responded to the school and began investigating. Bomb detecting K-9 teams also responded to the building to complete a scan.Similar threats were made to schools across the state, including schools in Frederick, Carroll, Charles and Wicomico counties, police said.Students and staff were allowed to return to the building when the K-9 scan was completed.Police said there are no identified subjects and investigation is ongoing.Anyone with information is asked to contact the Talbot County Sheriff's Office at 410-822-1020, by email at sheriff@talbotcountymd.gov, on Facebook at Talbot County Sheriff or online at talbotsheriff.org. 
 
 Caption: TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT

title: Vehicle fire spreads to Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Vehicle fire spreads to Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge

 November 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 189
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TAYLORS ISLAND - A vehicle fire on Taylors Island resulted in a wildland fire, which encroached onto the Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge.According to a report from the Office of the State Fire Marshal, around one acre of land was burned in the fire that occurred in the early hours ofNov. 12.The one-alarm fire was controlled in 40 minutes by 10 firefighters. The Taylors Island Volunteer Fire Company was the primary responding fire department.According to the report, the fire started on the side console of a boat parked on a wooded lot off Smithville Road. The fire then spread to two other boats on the lot before becoming a wildland fire.The preliminary cause of the fire is still under investigation.There were no reported injuries or deaths. An estimated loss of $50,000 was reported.The Office of the State Fire Marshal said it was notified of the fire several hours after the fire was put out. State and federal forestry services are assisting, according to the report. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF THE STATE FIRE MARSHAL A vehicle fire in a wooded lot off Smithville Road on Taylors Island resulted in a wildland fire Nov. 12.

title: Dangerous minds - Israel-Hamas war, Musk comments, police surveillance spark new social media fights
author: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor
content:
Dangerous minds - Israel-Hamas war, Musk comments, police surveillance spark new social media fights

 November 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1895
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Holy Land war between Israel and Hamas is birthing increased police and government surveillance of social media, prompting calls for more Americans to report "hate crimes" and proposals to require all social media accounts to have public name verifications amid concerns about increases in antisemitism and terrorism threats.There are also pushes to deport some anti-war, pro-Palestinian foreign college students deemed supportive of U.S. designated terror groups and expel and ban Palestinian refugees from entering the country.The efforts are born out of security concerns stemming from U.S. support for Israel's war against Hamas in Gaza after the Oct. 7 terror attacks. But they are also sparking concerns about stunting or intimating dissent, privacy and other free speech protections.There is also a new social media battle over Twitter/X owner Elon Musk's support for a social media post that talked about anti-white sentiments among "Jewish communities." A number of major media and technology advertisers, who also compete with social media platforms and some of Musk's technology ventures, have paused advertising on X. That includes Disney (which owns ABC and ESPN), Apple, Paramount Global (which owns CBS and Comedy, IBM, Comcast/NBC Universal (which owns NBC and MSNBC) and Warner Bros/Discovery (which owns CNN).Musk said he agreed with a post from a Twitter who said "Jewish communities have been pushing the exact kind of dialectical hatred against whites that they claim to want people to stop using against them." "You said the actual truth," Musk said in a reply Nov. 15, latter adding that his concurrence was geared toward progressive activist groups and the Anti-Defamation League.The Biden administration condemned Musk's statement Friday. "We condemn this abhorrent promotion of antisemitic and racist hate in the strongest terms," the U.S. administration said in statement drawing parallels to the beliefs of the Robert Bowers, who faces the death penalty after the Tree of Life Synagogue shooting in Pittsburgh left 11 congregants dead.The ADL on Nov. 16 also criticized Musk. "it is indisputably dangerous to use one's influence to validate and promote antisemitic theories, said ADL CEO Jonathan Greenblalt, who on Friday then praised Musk for his condemnation of pro-Palestinian and pro-Hamas phrases 'from the river to the sea' and 'decolonization.' Musk said Saturday some of the critics are dangerously using the episode to squelch free speech and that. he plans on suing progressive activists he claims inaccurately showed neo-Nazi and antisemitic posts next to Twitter/X advertisers' promotions."I am sticking to my principles. As for any fake advocacy groups who seek to suppress free speech, they should remember that karma is real," Musk said on his social media platform.EXPELLING FOREIGN COLLEGE STUDENTSThere is a GOP push to expel foreign college students deemed to be supporting Hamas, Hezbollah and other groups on the U.S. government's list of terrorist groups.A group of 21 GOP attorneys general - including Ashley Moody of Florida and Austin Knudsen of Montana - want the federal government to "vigorously renew vetting of foreign students' and deport those deemed to have endorsed or provided "material support to foreign terrorist organizations." "It is possible that renewed vetting of foreign students already admitted to the United States may reveal activity that renders them ineligible to hold a student visa and liable to deportation," Knudsen, Moody and their cohorts wrote in a letter Nov. 8 to U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken and the U.S.Department of Education.Free speech and civil liberties advocates say the reactions to anti-Israel war protests (some of which have seen antisemitic rhetoric) can bleed into censorship as well as quieting and punishing voices of dissent."Free speech means protecting speech you don't like. Sometimes it even means protecting speech you find abhorrent and hateful," said U.S. Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Kentucky, after voting against censure measure aimed at U.S. Rep. Rashida Tlaib, D-Michigan, over her anti-Israel rhetoric and use of a pro-Hamas slogan.BANNING PALESTINIAN REFUGEESA group of congressional Republicans - including U.S. Reps. Andy Thomas, who represents the Eastern Shore, along with U.S. Reps. Ryan Zinke of Montana and Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia and U.S. Sen. Steve Daines of Montana, are also leading efforts to keep Palestinian refugees from the war out of the U.S. Zinke, Harris and Greene also wants to kick out Palestinians who entered the country on or after Oct. 1 in the aftermath of the Hamas' Oct. 7 terror attacks inside Israel that sparked the war in Gaza.They say said he does not trust the Biden administration or Palestinian authorities to adequately screen potential refugees.Critics say the proposal is xenophobic.Similar sentiments related to refugees and college students have been echoed by 2024 GOP presidential candidates such as former president Donald Trump and Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, who has suspended pro-Palestinian students' groups in his home state deemed extremist and favored restrictions on public library and school curricula content deemed inappropriate or offensive.While conservatives press universities, who have sometimes aggressively banned right-wing voices from their campuses, to condemn and crackdown on pro-Palestinian student protesters, the American Civil Liberties Union wants them to uphold free speech principles."It is precisely in times of heightened crisis and fear that university leaders must remain steadfast in their commitment to free speech, open debate, and peaceful dissent on campus.These principles are the bedrock of academic freedom at all universities," the ACLU said in a statement."The First Amendment protects all people who live in this country, whether they're here as citizens, foreign nationals, or visitors," the civil liberties group said.ENCOURAGING MORE HATE CRIME REPORTINGDaines and a bipartisan senators including U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen, D-Maryland, have also recently written to FBI Director Christopher Wray and the U.S. Department of Homeland Security asking for more investigative and enforcement resources to be dedicated to addressing antisemitism.The Anti-Defamation League reports a 300% increase in anti-Jewish threats, vandalism and violence since the start of the war, which has seen more than 1,400 Israelis and more than 11,000 Gazans killed.In a separate letter, U.S. Sen Jon Tester, D-Montana, also said FBI and DHS efforts should also be focused on white supremacists echoing past and current Biden administration efforts to go after alt-right groups.The Biden White House, which has put a focus on going after right-wing groups since taking office in 2021, has also launched a new task force to go after "Islamophobia" during the war.On Tuesday, the FBI said it added Oregon to a nationwide effort aimed at encouraging getting more Americans to report "hate incidents' ' with billboards posted in Eugene, Medford and Corvallis as well as digital signs at Portland International Airport.Similar hate crime billboards have been put up across the country, including last month in North Carolina, along with ads on public transit systems, social media platforms and local media outlets.Last month, the U.S. Department of Justice and FBI released new data showing there was a 7.3% increase in reported hate crimes in 2022 (11,634 cases versus 10,840) in 2021.There were more than 6,500 racially motivated incidents - 52% of them aimed at Blacks - and more than 2,000 cases related to religion - with 55% targeting Jews, according to DOJ.SOCIAL MEDIA SURVEILLANCE, FORCED VERIFICATIONSA state law in Montana backed by Knudsen and GOP Gov.Greg Gianforte banning Chinese-owned social media app TikTok is also one of the central fronts in efforts to restrict social media platforms and content.Montana lawmakers worry about TikTok's data security and ties to the Chinese government.The ban is being mirrored in other states.The Montana prohibition is being challenged by TikTok and free speech advocates in court.But there are also other efforts to increase government regulations and scrutiny and law enforcement surveillance of social media.New York Gov. Kathy Hochul said Nov. 13 that state police have ramped up social media surveillance and will reach out more to individuals and groups posting hate speech online."We're very focused on the data we're collecting from surveillance efforts. What's being said on social media platforms.And we have launched an effort to be able to counter some of the negativity. and reach out to people when we see hate speech being spoken about on online platforms," Hochul said. "Our media analysis, our social media analysis unit, has ramped up its monitoring of sites to catch incitement to violence; direct threats to others." The New York governor said the rise in extremist and violent threats after the start of the war in the Middle East "poses a clear and present danger." But the idea of more aggressive police surveillance of social media posts raises some concerns.Gerard Kassar, chairman of the New York Conservative Party, said police social media monitoring is potentially "chilling to the core"."Law enforcement authorities can and should monitor legitimate terrorism suspects online, but spying on everyday citizens is unconstitutional and wrong," Kassar said.Republican presidential candidate and former South Carolina governor and U.S. ambassador Nikki Haley wants to require all social media accounts be verified by name thus eliminating anonymous online speech on major platforms."Every person on social media should be verified by their name," said Haley, who is increasingly being promoted as an establishment and neoconservative 2024 alternative to former president Donald Trump."First of all, it's a national security threat. When you do that, all of a sudden people have to stand by what they say. And it gets rid of the Russian bots, the Iranian bots and the Chinese bots. And then you're going to get some civility when people know their name is next to what they say, and they know their pastor and their family members are going to see it," Haley told Fox News.Haley also backs a TikTok ban pointing to the recent viral traffic of a letter criticizing Israel and the U.S. from Osama Bin Laden.Harris told Fox News Nov. 16 that Congress could soon take some actions related to TikTok and the issue will come down to speech versus national security, citing the platform's Chinese ownership.The verification push sparked a backlash from free speech advocates, particularly on the right who have already been upset over social media bans and content restrictions over coronavirus vaccines and challenges to the 2020 election results.They say it will eliminate anonymous dissent and speech."Nikki Haley is 'openly' pushing for the government to use private tech companies to censor speech. This is a flagrant violation of the Constitution and straight out of the Democrats' playbook.Any politician who thinks it's OK for the government to use the private sector as its censorship bureau shouldn't be allowed anywhere near the White House," said Vivek Ramaswamy, who has frequently sparred with Haley over TikTok and other issues. 
 
 Caption: ASSOCIATED PRESS
 
Twitter/X, Tesla and SpaceX's CEO Elon Musk gestures during an in-conversation event with Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak in London, Thursday, Nov. 2, 2023.
 
ASSOCIATED PRESS
 
Republican presidential candidates former U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis and businessman Vivek Ramaswamy pose for a photo before the start of a presidential primary debate Nov. 8 in Miami. Haley has called for all social media accounts to be verified by name and DeSantis wants pro-Palestinian foreign college students who support Hamas deported.
 
ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Juvenile crime, reform are top issues for Talbot County police
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Juvenile crime, reform are top issues for Talbot County police

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 615
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Talbot County is seeing increases in juvenile crime, along with upticks in petty thefts and some violent crimes, according to the county's top law enforcement officials.Updates on local crime trends from each law enforcement agency in the county dominated discussion at Talbot County's latest Police Accountability Board meeting on Tuesday, Nov. 14.Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble reported a 19% increase in calls for service and a 13% increase in reported crime handled by the sheriff's office, including some small increases in assaults and drug charges. Crimes relating to fraud of older residents are likely the biggest financial loss in the county, he added.Gamble identified juvenile crimes in schools as a particular issue for the sheriff's office, which has uniformed officers serving in most of the public schools.Recently implemented state juvenile justice reform laws have barred police from charging anyone under 13 with most crimes.Gamble said Easton High School and Easton Middle School are where police see most of the incidents involving children, and over 30% of this year's reported incidents involve children under 13."We have 12-year-olds that are punching other kids in the face time and time again in the schools, or assaulting other kids, and there's no services for them," he said.Police Accountability Board members acknowledged the concerns, asking what officers can do to better handle issues with youth under 13 and if police can work with the schools.Gamble said the school system doesn't have leverage to handle discipline other than resorting to suspensions.Looking forward, Gamble hopes to see movement within state leadership in Annapolis during the upcoming General Assembly session to push legislation to tackle issues with the juvenile reform laws.Outside of juvenile crime, those at the meeting discussed several recent local incidents.In Easton, two homicides occurred within town limits in the last few months - one on Blake Street in early August and a second at the Sidetracked Saloon in late September.Several thefts and robberies have also occurred in town, said Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey. Those include a series of burglaries at vape stores where individuals are seeking Delta-8 THC cartridges, a non-regulated and legal psychoactive substance with effects similar to recreational cannabis.Another issue of great concern to Easton residents is crime on the Rails to Trails pathways throughout town, Lowrey said, citing a serious assault on the trails in the summer.To alleviate those concerns, the town's police department is increasing patrols on the trails and issuing more citations, Lowrey said. Those efforts include repopulating the department's bike unit, which is down due to lower staffing levels.In St. Michaels, Police Chief Jeffrey Oswald didn't note any specific crime trends, though he did mention two car thefts, which are "extremely unusual" for the town, he said. The town's tourist season is coming to a close, which means St. Michaels will have a lower population and more shops closed up for the winter.The small St. Michaels Police Department is down a few officers, though two new officers are starting soon, Oswald said. The department was also able to secure higher starting salaries and increases for current officers."Things are looking up. It's just going to be a little while," he said.Oxford Police Chief Eric Kellner did not report any major issues, adding that Oxford is a "very safe little town." The town's three-member police department was fully staffed until a few weeks ago, but Oxford's town commissioners recently agreed to increase the department to four full-time officers, Kellner said. The town is now looking to hire one additional officer. 
 
 Caption: NATALIE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Members of the Talbot County Police Accountability Board, seated to the right, listen to the county's top law enforcement officials during a Nov. 14 meeting. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
