title: Felony Charges Upheld Against Unionville Shooting Suspect
author: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub. Com
content:
Felony Charges Upheld Against Unionville Shooting Suspect

 November 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub. Com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 510
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - A Talbot County judge upheld felony charges against the Prince George's County man arrested in connection to an August shooting in Unionville.During a preliminary hearing Tuesday, Talbot District Court Judge Karen Ketterman determined there was sufficient probable cause to forward multiple felony charges against Stewart Orlando Ray to the county's circuit court.Ray, 37, was extradited from Washington, D.C. to Talbot County in late October on warrants charging him with attempted murder, assault, reckless endangerment and firearm offenses related to the Aug. 6 shooting of a 39-year-old man.Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office responded to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton around 9 p.m. Aug. 6 for a report of a shooting victim.The man told police he was driving near Unionville when he noticed another car following him at a high rate of speed. The car, which the victim identified as belonging to Ray, passed him and pulled off to the side of the road near a stop sign, police said.As the victim passed Ray's vehicle, a man shot at him multiple times, striking both the victim and his car, the victim told police. The victim was struck in the hand and drove himself to the hospital for treatment, police said.The victim's girlfriend, who was previously with Ray, said Ray had previously made threats against the victim's life, a detective from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office said Tuesday.Police said Ray fled the area in his car, failed to stop for a stop sign at the intersection of Unionville Road and Bruffs Island Road, left the roadway and struck a parked vehicle, disabling his own car.In court, the detective testified that Ray's phone was plotting in the area of the shooting that night.Ray then fled on foot into the nearby woods, prompting a 24-hour manhunt beginning in the early morning hours. Police later learned that Ray's girlfriend picked him up in the area several hours later.The detective testified to Ray's girlfriend, telling police Ray admitted to the shooting and that Ray had a handgun with him when she picked him up.A U.S. Marshals task force located Ray in Alexandria, Virginia on Aug. 8. Police said Ray was shot when the task force attempted to apprehend him.He was taken to a local hospital with life-threatening injuries.A .40 caliber handgun was recovered in the car Ray was using in Alexandria, the detective said. While ballistics testing is still in progress, several .40 caliber casings were recovered from the shooting site in Talbot County.The detective also said Ray texted the victim's girlfriend, whom Ray has a daughter with, to tell his daughter that he was sorry and he loved her.Prosecutor Joyce Jones pointed to the threats and the victim saying a man parked and waited to shoot at him and his vehicle as substantial steps to attempt to murder the victim.Defense attorney Kisha Petticolas said it was "curious" that no one identified Ray as the man who shot at the victim, saying that without an identification, all other evidence was circumstantial.Ray will remain held without bond pending further court hearings. 
 
 Caption: Ray

 CAMBRIDGE - The Frederick C. Malkus Bridge across the Choptank River on U.S. Route 50 was closed Monday morning after two eastbound tractor-trailers collided, littering the bridge with contents from one of the trailers.According to Maryland State Police, troopers from the Easton barrack responded to the bridge shortly before 7:30 a.m. Monday for a report of a disabled tractor-trailer.A preliminary investigation indicated the tractor-trailer was traveling east on the bridge when it became disabled. For unknown reasons, a second tractor-trailer struck the rear of the first tractor-trailer, police said.One person was transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Cambridge for treatment of their injuries.The bridge was closed in both directions for about two hours while crews cleaned up the debris and removed the two trucks.The westbound lanes of the bridge reopened around 9:30 a.m. Traffic was moving in both directions by 10 a.m.The cause of the crash remains under investigation.

title: Easton woman gets probation for evidence tampering in shooting case
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Easton woman gets probation for evidence tampering in shooting case

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 488
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - An Easton woman was given two years of unsupervised probation Wednesday, Nov. 22, after she was found guilty of tampering with evidence related to a fatal shooting in Easton.During a trial last week in Talbot County District Court, presiding District Judge Joseph Riley found Dana L. Wilson, 59, guilty of tampering with evidence connected to the man charged with murder in the shooting. She was given a one-year sentence, all of which was suspended, according to court documents.The charges against Wilson stemmed from her actions in the minutes following the fatal Aug. 7 shooting.Police responded to the area of 104 Blake Street around 7 p.m. that day for a report of a person who had been shot and was laying in the grass.Officers arriving on scene rendered aid to the man, later identified as 55-year-old Ty A. Brooks, until paramedics arrived. Brooks died from his injuries at the scene, police said.Police said earlier on Aug. 7, Brooks argued with individuals who were near and operating a Range Rover, which was parked in the 100 block of Blake Street.Brooks left the area and returned later, operating an ATV.Brooks confronted the same individuals with a shotgun, police said.Police said after the group exchanged words, a man seated in the driver's seat of the Range Rover fired shots through the front passenger seat window and struck Brooks' side, causing him to fall from the ATV.The man in the driver's seat was identified by police as Daseir Cornish, 22, of Denton. Cornish is charged with second-degree murder, assault, manslaughter and related charges in connection to Brooks' death.According to charging documents filed in Wilson's case, surveillance footage showed Cornish exiting the car after the shooting and dropping an object from his lap onto the sidewalk on Blake Street, police wrote.Six minutes later, the footage showed a woman, later identified as Wilson, emerging from the tree line between Blake Street and Glenwood Avenue. Wilson bent down to pick up an item on the sidewalk, which appeared to be the same item Cornish dropped, police said.During an interview with police, Wilson said she received a call from Cornish - her grandson - asking her to pick up the cell phone he dropped on Blake Street.The number Cornish called Wilson from was later identified as a number belonging to Raheem Green, 28, of Cambridge, police said. Green is charged with acting as an accessory after the fact of murder for allegedly helping Cornish flee from the scene and discard evidence.Wilson said she placed Cornish's phone in a bag on a bench behind a home on Glenwood Avenue.One of Cornish's friends picked up the phone, Wilson told police.In charging documents, police asserted Cornish's phone would have been evidence in the homicide investigation.The cases against Cornish and Green are still pending. Cornish is scheduled for a trial Feb. 26 to March 1. Green is set for a trial March 11 to March 15, according to online court records. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Man found guilty in death of infant son - Baltimore man sentenced to 35 years by Caroline County judge
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Man found guilty in death of infant son - Baltimore man sentenced to 35 years by Caroline County judge

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 465
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - A Baltimore man was sentenced Wednesday to 35 years in prison after a judge found him guilty of murder in the death of his infant son.Agreeing with joint recommendations from the prosecution and the defense, Caroline Circuit Judge Heather Price handed Sean Casey Pierce the lengthy sentence: 40 years, with all but 25 years suspended, for a second-degree murder charge and 25 years, with all but 10 years suspended, for first-degree assault.The sentences will be served consecutively.Pierce, 50, entered Alford pleas to the two felony charges during Wednesday's court hearing.An Alford plea does not require a defendant to admit guilt, but acknowledges that there was enough evidence for a conviction had the case gone to trial.The sentence comes nearly 18 months after the death of 8-week-old Chance Pierce on May 30, 2022.The case against Pierce stemmed from a 911 call reporting an infant experiencing a medical emergency.Officers from the Federalsburg Police Department responded to a camper on Buena Vista Avenue with emergency medical services personnel for the report.Police said the infant had a weak pulse and was cool to the touch upon their arrival.The child was taken to Nanticoke Memorial Hospital in Seaford before being transported to Nemours Children's Hospital in Wilmington, where he was declared deceased.Pierce told police that he was sleeping in a trailer with Chance and his other young son when he was awoken by the infant choking and vomiting.Pierce and another adult male on the property thought the child was suffering from heat stroke and attempted to cool him off using water and ice pops.However, a medical examiner ruled the child's cause of death as closedhead trauma caused by a blunt force injury.The medical examiner also found the child had several partially healed rib fractures, indicating prior abuse, said Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin.Pierce was unable to explain his son's injuries, Franklin added. The child's mother said Chance was healthy and had no prior issues.The child's mother was not present in court Wednesday and did not wish to be there, Franklin said."This has been a nightmare for her," he said, adding that he didn't want the child's mother to relive the death of her son.Defense attorney Dana Boston agreed with the prosecution's recommended sentence, calling it and the plea agreement fair."Thirty-five years in prison for a 50-year-old man is not a slap on the wrist," he said.Pierce spoke briefly in court Wednesday, acknowledging the difficulty of the case and some guilt he held, but he ultimately denied criminal involvement in his son's death."I didn't murder my son," he said.As part of the plea agreement, Pierce is not allowed to contact the child's mother.When released from prison, Pierce will be placed on five years of supervised probation. 
 
 Caption: SEAN CASEY PIERCE 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton man gets five years for narcotics charges
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com

Easton man gets five years for narcotics charges

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 EASTON - An Easton man was sentenced Wednesday, Nov. 22, to five years in prison for possession with the intent to distribute narcotics.During a plea hearing, Talbot County Circuit Judge Stephen Kehoe found Jaurice K. Henry, 27, guilty of two drug charges, handing down two 15-year sentences and suspending all but five years of each in a binding agreement. The two fiveyear terms will be served concurrently, according to court documents.Henry's release will be followed by three years of supervised probation.The charges against Henry stemmed from the Easton Police Department's investigation into a fatal overdose late last year.Police were dispatched to the Econo Lodge on Dec. 5, 2022, for an overdose victim.Officers began and continued resuscitation efforts until they were relieved by Talbot County paramedics.The victim was transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton, where he was later pronounced dead.Detectives with EPD's Criminal Investigations Division conducted the death investigation. After several months, Henry and Iyana Wilson, 27, were identified as the individuals who sold a cocaine and fentanyl mix to the victim, police said.Two cases involving alleged drug possession and distribution remain pending against Wilson.In September, Wilson entered an Alford plea to possession with intent to distribute narcotics in one case. She is set to be sentenced Dec. 15 in Talbot County Circuit Court.A second case charges Wilson with manufacturing narcotics, conspiring with Henry to manufacture drugs, possession of drug paraphernalia and obstructing justice.She is also alleged to have altered physical evidence relevant to a criminal proceeding and to have possessed contraband in a place of confinement by having narcotics inside her body while at the Easton Police Department, according to charging documents.The second case against Wilson is set for a status conference on Dec. 1.

title: Cambridge police department names PROTECT coordinator
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge police department names PROTECT coordinator

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 433
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - The Cambridge Police Department is adding a civilian position to its ranks.Lamont Goodson was announced as CPD's PROTECT coordinator, a new role that will be funded by the Governor's Office of Crime Control and Prevention.At a Cambridge City Council meeting on Monday, CPD Police Chief Justin Todd said PROTECT stands for Public Resources Organizing to End Crime Together.According to City Council meeting documents, Goodson's tasks will include ensuring the department is using all existing crime prevention programs, working with CPD on grants offered through the state, coordinating community and youth programs and coordinating engagement with CPD in the high-crime area micro-zones.The state PROTECT program was established to maximize resources to "combat neighborhood decline throughout the state" and to "support comprehensive strategies to reduce crime and fear" in communities experiencing high crime.Todd said Cambridge was one of 10 cities that the Governor's office recognized as a high-crime microzone for violent crimes. He said securing a PROTECT coordinator has been a "trying process.""This has been going on for quite some time," Todd said. "Salisbury hired their PROTECT coordinator a couple months ago."A Cambridge-South Dorchester High School graduate, Goodson was born and raised in Cambridge.After college, he served in the United States Army for eight years.Goodson served as a police officer in Howard County for four years after that, before getting hired as a special agent by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. After 21 years with the FBI, Goodson has retired to Cambridge.Todd said CPD is looking forward to seeing the positive outcomes that come out of the creation of this position. He said Goodson wants to do a lot of good in Cambridge."He's going to be getting out, doing a lot of community work," Todd said. "Building that trust and relationships in the community."Goodson will be working out of CPD's substation at 618 Pine Street."However, he will be out at the Altair apartment complex, from the Pine Street area through to the Greenwood Avenue area, where our high crime areas are," Todd said.At the end of the meeting Monday, Commission President Lajan Cephas said hiring Goodson was a "no-brainer.""It seems as if that position was created for Lamont," she said."He's so excited about being back at home and what he wants to bring back to Cambridge to try to unify the community and the. 
 
 Caption: Lamont Goodson (right) reads with Terry Groce at an event at the Packing House in Cambridge on June 29. Goodson will be the Cambridge Police Departments's PRO TEC T coordinator, a new role that will be funded by the Governor's Office of Crime Control and Prevention.

title: Cambridge man found not guilty of assault, mistrial on one charge
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge man found not guilty of assault, mistrial on one charge

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 489
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - After more than three hours of deliberation, a jury found Jonathan Diaz-Santiago, 36, of Cambridge, not guilty of first-and second-degree assault. The jury could not come to an agreement on a reckless endangerment charge, resulting in a mistrial on that count.Thursday, Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard said the state had not yet made a decision on whether they will retry the reckless endangerment charge.The charges stemmed from a report made by two of Diaz-Santiago's family members that Santiago attempted to hit, choke and stab his stepfather, Jose Sierra, during an argument on Decoursey Bridge Road in Cambridge on May 6.Diaz-Santiago was originally charged with attempted first-and second-degree murder, as well.Leonard said it was a prosecutorial choice, based on the evidence in the case, to drop those charges before the trial.During opening statements of the trial, Leonard said that a family fishing expedition on May 6 ended in violence and bloodshed. She said Sierra was "battered, bruised and in need of medical treatment," following the altercation.Worse than the physical injuries, Leonard said, are the long term effects Sierra is facing from the incident.Defense Attorney Michelle Moodispaw, from the Dorchester County Public Defender's Office, said that the state's case was based around the victim's claims."Because he said so," Moodispaw said in her opening statement, adding that law enforcement didn't talk with others in the area in which the fight took place.Moodispaw said that the case was not simple and straightforward, and said the jury would have just as many questions at the end of the trial as they did at the beginning of the trial.Moodispaw said Sierra was drinking that day, angry with Diaz-Santiago, and said Sierra hit Diaz-Santiago with a liquor bottle "several times."According to police, following the incident, Sierra reported that Diaz-Santiago grabbed his throat, attempting to choke him, while on the fishing trip. Diaz-Santiago then allegedly attempted to hit Sierra in the head with a tire iron, but Sierra was able to block the hit, police said.The two men then got into their vehicle, with Sierra seated in the driver's seat and Diaz-Santiago in the backseat. According to charging documents, the victim told police that Diaz-Santiago put a knife to his throat and verbally threatened him.Sierra told police he exited the car and was followed by Diaz-Santiago, who then attempted to stab him in the upper chest area. Sierra was able to block the attack, but was cut on his left wrist, police said.The officer who took the report observed multiple signs of injury on Sierra, including bruise marks around his neck and shoulder, blood coming out of his right ear and bruises and cuts on his arms.Leonard said she could not give any comment on the trial due to pending litigation.As of Thursday afternoon, Diaz-Santiago is being held without bond. A status conference is set for Friday morning.

title: Inspector general launches probe into selected FBI headquarters site
content:
Inspector general launches probe into selected FBI headquarters site

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 337
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - A federal watchdog will investigate how the Biden administration chose a site for a new FBI headquarters following a contentious competition marked by allegations of conflict of interest.The Inspector General for the General Services Administration is probing the decision to locate the facility in Greenbelt, Maryland, over a site in Virginia., according to a letter released Thursday by Virginia lawmakers.The new building would replace the FBI's crumbling headquarters in nearby Washington, D.C.Virginia's senators and representatives said in a joint statement that there was "overwhelming evidence" suggesting the process was influenced by politics and called on the GSA to pause anything related to the relocation until the review is complete.The acting inspector general said that his office would immediately begin evaluating the GSA's process and procedures for selecting the site and share a copy of any report that results, according to a letter sent to Democratic Sen. Mark Warner of Virginia."We applaud the inspector general for moving quickly and encourage him to move forward to complete a careful and thorough review," Virginia's delegation said in a joint statement.The agency said it welcomes the review and pointed out that it had already released decision-making materials and a legal review of concerns raised by the director of the FBI."We carefully followed the requirements and process, and stand behind GSA's final site selection decision," an agency spokesperson said in a statement.The review comes after FBI Director Christopher Wray told staff in an internal message earlier this month that he was concerned about a "potential conflict of interest" in a GSA executive choosing a site owned by a previous employer.Wray said his objections were about the process rather than the site itself.GSA, which manages the government's real estate portfolio, denied any conflict.The agency said the site about 13 miles northeast of Washington was the cheapest one with the best access to public transit.Maryland and Virginia have long been vying to land the FBI's heasquarters.Maryland's leaders applauded the Greenbelt choice, saying was "never about politics" and the new facility would meet a "dire, longstanding need." 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton department announces first Community Police Academy
content:
Easton department announces first Community Police Academy

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 437
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Easton Police Department announced its first Community Police Academy.The goal of this program, the department said in a press release, is to educate the public about the Easton Police Department and to increase the rapport between community members and police officers.The Community Police Academy will take place from 6 to 9 p.m. on the following eleven evenings: Jan. 17, Jan. 24, Jan. 31, Feb. 7, Feb. 15, Feb. 21, Feb. 28, March 6, March 13, March 20 and March 27.Most of the classes will meet at the Easton Police Department on 106 W.Dover St. in Easton. To "graduate," attendees may not miss more than two classes.The class curriculum will be different each week.Students will become familiar with the different functions in the police department and experience the decisions that officers must make in different situations, according to the release."We hope the graduates of the Community Police Academy complete the program with a better understanding of the Easton Police Department and will encourage others to participate in this rewarding program," EPD wrote in a release. "We invite Easton residents to apply and learn more about their Easton Police Department. If you are interested in attending, please contact the Easton Police Department. Class size is limited, so don't wait."Questions about this program can be directed to: EPDCareers@eastonmd.gov. Applications can be filled out at: eastonmd.gov/604/Community-Police-AcademyQUALIFICATIONSEligible applicants must meet the following criteria:. Resident of the Town of Easton. At least 18 years of age. Willing to sign a waiver of liability, consent to criminal history check form, and a limited confidentiality agreement form.An applicant may be disqualified from participating for any of the following reasons, including but not limited to:. Outstanding warrants of any type.· Having a conviction or being under indictment for, or currently charged with any violent felony offense.· Having a history of/or conviction for any sexual or family violence related offense.· Cannot be a suspect of any criminal case, regardless of the case outcome within the past three years.· Association with any person or organization which advocates hatred, prejudice or oppression of any person or group or which disseminates such material.· Association with any organization, association, movement, or group which advocates the commission of acts of force or violence to deny others their rights under the Constitution of the United States or which seeks to alter the form of government of the United States by unconstitutional means.· Has a pending lawsuit against the Department.Any other indications of criminal history, criminal involvement and/or previous law enforcement involvement will be evaluated on a case-by-case basis and considered in the application process. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Fire Knocks Out St. Michaels Pump Station - Second Pump Station Has 'Plenty Of Capacity' To Serve Town
author: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub. Com
content:
Fire Knocks Out St. Michaels Pump Station - Second Pump Station Has 'Plenty Of Capacity' To Serve Town

 December 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub. Com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 269
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS - A fire at the St. Michaels water pump station on E. Marengo Street late Sunday night caused "substantial damage" to the facility, according to the town.Firefighters responded to the blaze shortly before 11:30 p.m.Sunday night after being alerted by a St. Michaels firefighter who lives nearby, according to a Facebook post from the St. Michaels Fire Department.Three local fire departments and a paramedic unit arrived to the fire coming through the roof. The fire was quickly knocked down, according to the St. Michaels Fire Department.The Maryland State Fire Marshal said it took 31 firefighters almost an hour and a half to control the blaze.The Maryland Department of the Environment also responded to the scene due to the presence of treatment chemicals.The cause of the fire is under investigation by the Maryland State Fire Marshal.The state fire marshal estimated $200,000 in damage to the brick structure and a $150,000 loss in contents.According to a news release sent by the town, the pump station is not operational and will need major repairs to be brought back online.The town said its second pump station has "plenty of capacity" to meet water demand for the winter and spring.Town officials are working with state and local officials, engineers and other agencies to develop a plan to expedite repairs to the facility.Anyone with information regarding the fire is asked to contact the Upper Eastern Regional Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal at 410-822-7609. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF ST. MICHAELS FIRE DEPARTMENT
 
Flames shoot through the roof of the St. Michaels pump station on Marengo Street Sunday, Dec. 3.

title: Man Arrested In Connection With Shooting, Escape At Hospital
author: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub. Com
content:
Man Arrested In Connection With Shooting, Escape At Hospital

 December 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub. Com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 321
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - A Glen Burnie man was arrested Tuesday in connection with a shooting that allowed a patient to escape from the Eastern Shore Hospital Center via a broken window in August.Following a joint investigation with the Cambridge Police Department and the Rockville Police Department, officers arrested Israel Labastida, Jr., 19, and searched his Glen Burnie home Tuesday. Several items were seized from Labastida's home, including a loaded 9mm handgun, police said.Labastida is charged with conspiracy to escape, numerous counts of first-and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment, firearm charges and malicious destruction of property over $1,000.Charges are still pending in Rockville for items seized from Labastida's residence, police said.The charges against Labastida stem from his alleged involvement with the patient's escape from the psychiatric facility.Officers from the Cambridge Police Department responded to the facility in the 5200 block of Woods Road just after 5:30 p.m. Aug. 1 for a shooting incident.Security officers on scene at the hospital told police that an unknown person in a black vehicle approached the building and shot several times into a glass window. The unknown person then kicked the broken window out, which allowed a hospital patient to escape with the unknown person in the black vehicle, police said.Police said no injuries were reported at the scene.Detectives from CPD's criminal investigation also responded to the scene and recovered several spent shell casings, police said.The patient who escaped was identified as Darrin Lee Jeter, 19, of Rockville.Police said Jeter had been committed to the hospital center for assault on law enforcement officers in Montgomery County.Detectives continued the investigation through contacting law enforcement in Montgomery County, where Jeter was later located.Jeter was charged with first-degree escape and is being held without bond. His case remains pending in Dorchester County Circuit Court.Labastida was ordered held without bond during an initial appearance Tuesday. A bail review is set for Wednesday in Glen Burnie District Court in Anne Arundel County. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal incident involving police, a hospital shooting, and an escape, which directly relates to public safety concerns. While it also involves law enforcement collaboration (Local Government), the primary focus is on the safety and security implications of the crime.

title: 'Being Proactive, Not Reactive' - Caroline County Problem-Solving Court Awarded $200K To Improve, Continue Work
author: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub. Com
content:
'Being Proactive, Not Reactive' - Caroline County Problem-Solving Court Awarded $200K To Improve, Continue Work

 December 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub. Com | Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 729
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - The Caroline County Problem-Solving Court recently was awarded more than $200,000 to continue its mission to help individuals who are in the criminal justice system to overcome their addictions, reunite with their families and make positive contributions to their communities.The grant, funded from the Federal Bureau of Justice Assistance through the Maryland Office of Problem-Solving Courts, funds a two-year pilot program that became effective Oct. 1.Caroline County Circuit Court Judge Heather Price explained the problem-solving court to the Caroline County Commissioners Oct. 10.Calling it "a really amazing program to be a part of," Price also explained the purpose of the $206,138 grant.Problem-solving courts, sometimes called adult treatment or adult drug courts, use a team approach, calling on professionals in the community - the state's attorney, mental health professionals, parole and probation and corrections, law enforcement, among others - to help people who are already in the criminal justice system.Problem-solving courts are in 23 of 24 jurisdictions in Maryland.The crimes committed by those involved are mostly nonviolent and primarily driven by substance use disorders, Price said."If you have crime and an addiction, it affects first responders, it affects EMA (and) police, it affects the health department it affects the justice system, it affects corrections," the person's family and children in school, Price said. "There's not an angle in this county that it doesn't affect, and most importantly, it affects the community as a whole."The team approach begins when the decision is made to accept a person in the problem-solving court, which then becomes a "post-conviction, post-sentencing part of (their) probation," Price said."You have to successfully enroll in and complete problem-solving court, which is no easy task," she said. "It takes at least a year, oftentimes longer, and it involves a multidisciplinary approach, so it's not just treatment for substance use disorder. It's required mental health treatment, and it's all these other factors." Four participants graduated in November 2022 and two in January 2023."I'm passionate about it because you can actually see when somebody gets it, and it's remarkable the impact it has on a community," she said. Seven participants currently are enrolled in the program.Commission Vice President Larry Porter said he's attended a graduation ceremony of those who successfully completed the program. "I think it's a great program. I've seen it work," he said. Price encouraged the commissioners and interested people to attend the graduation ceremonies.Statistics supplied to the commissioners by Michelle Bethke, Problem-Solving Court Coordinator for the Caroline County Circuit Court, document the success of the program in Maryland.Adult Treatment Courts statewide demonstrated a "9% reduction in rearrests over two years compared to individuals going through business-as-usual court processing," according to research commissioned by the Maryland Judiciary. Individuals spent 23 fewer days in jail. Two-thirds of ATCs showed improvements in rearrests over time.The Caroline County team is improving its performance, Bethke said. Compliance with best practices has increased from 60% to 89% during the past 18 months the team has revamped the program. "We still have a lot on our to-do list to make more improvements," she said."It costs money to run the program," Price said. However, "it saves money in the long run to the community without a question, and seeing people that go on and have jobs and reunite with families, mothers that haven't seen children in years, it's a really amazing program to be a part of."According to a December 2022 report issued by NPC Research to the Maryland Administrative Office of the Courts, the "average statewide cost to administer an ATC was $27,134 per participant, and the largest spending category was substance use disorder treatment." Maryland saved an average of $14,352 per participant in reduced criminal justice and societal cost outcomes over two years.Price said Caroline County's PSC is one of four in the state that received the grant to implement a universal risk screening pilot program with high-risk, high-need individuals, and "increase the diversity, expand the program, decrease the time of when a person is charged to when they are admitted into the program and, of course, connect individuals to community resources sooner," Bethke said."I think it's just great," Commissioner Frank Bartz said. "I mean, you guys are being proactive, not reactive here, and (the program) is data-driven." 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Caroline County Circuit Court Judge Heather Price explains the mission of the Problem Solv-ing Court to the Caroline County Commissioners Oct. 10. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a problem-solving court program aimed at reducing recidivism through rehabilitation, which directly relates to public safety. It discusses crime prevention, community impact, and collaboration with law enforcement and corrections, aligning with Public Safety. While Local Government is tangentially relevant, the core emphasis is on criminal justice outcomes and community safety.

title: Eight indicted in Eastern Shore drug trafficking operation
content:
Eight indicted in Eastern Shore drug trafficking operation

 December 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 249
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Following a yearlong investigation, eight men were indicted in connection with a drug trafficking operation in Talbot County, state police announced Tuesday.The indictments come after the Talbot County Drug Task Force and Homeland Security Investigations began a covert investigation in spring 2022.Maryland State Police joined more than two dozen local, state and federal law enforcement agencies in dismantling the sale and distribution of illegal drugs, including cocaine and heroin, throughout Talbot, Dorchester, Caroline and Queen Anne's counties.Police identified the alleged kingpin as Sherman Nathaniel Greene Jr., 42, of Cambridge.Green is charged with importing large quantities of illegal drugs, which co-conspirators assisted Greene in selling and distributing, police said.Greene was indicted in both Talbot and Dorchester counties. He is being held without bond in the Dorchester County Detention Center.Others indicted in connection with the drug trafficking operation include Anthony Brinkley, 61, of Greensboro; David T. Carter Jr., 51, of Chester; Angelo D. Faulk, 50, of Easton; Kevin Greene, 56, of Easton; Clifton L. Morton Sr., 49, of St. Michaels; Wayne H. Spence Jr., 49, of Cambridge; and Kelvin P. Smothers, 64, of Preston.Police said the seven other men were released on bail.Police served multiple search and seizure warrants on residences and vehicles in Talbot, Dorchester, Caroline and Queen Anne's counties.The warrants yielded more than 1,300 grams of suspected cocaine, along with suspected heroin/fentanyl, two rifles and seven vehicles that were used to transport the drugs, according to a state police news release. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Emergency Services launches 'Season's Safety' campaign
content:
Emergency Services launches 'Season's Safety' campaign

 December 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 7 | Section: News 
 
 487
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Talbot County Department of Emergency Services launched a new public awareness campaign coined "Season's Safety." The initiative aims at enhancing public awareness of winter hazards and safety measures, especially around the season of giving."The holidays are a wonderful time to get together with friends and family, but with colder weather and holiday specific activities, there are several hazards to be aware of that may cause injuries, and potentially (loss of) lives each year," said Brian LeCates, director of Emergency Services. "We hope that this campaign will help keep safety on people's minds throughout their holiday celebrations."From home decorating and hot cocoa by the fire, to shopping for gifts and baking cookies, Emergency Services would like to remind citizens of the following safety tips: DECORATE SAFELYKeep potentially poisonous plants, like mistletoe, holly berries and amaryllis, away from pets and children.Avoid placing breakable ornaments or ones with small detachable parts within the reach of small children.Use only indoor lights indoors and outside lights outdoors, and choose the right ladder for the task of hanging lights.For a full list of holiday decoration tips, visit the U.S.Consumer Product Safety Commission publication at cpsc.gov/s3fs-public/611.pdf.WATCH OUT FOR FIRE-STARTERSPick decorations that are flame resistant or flame retardant.Keep lit candles away from children, pets and other decorations.Replace string lights that show signs of wear or have broken cords or bulbs; never tack wiring directly.Place trees at least three feet away from fireplaces, radiators, and other sources of heat and water live trees regularly so they don't dry out.Place a screen in front of your fireplace Blow out candles and turn off electronic decorations before you go to bed.For more information on winter holiday fire tips, visit the National Protection Association at nfpa.org/Education-and-Research/Home-Fire-Safety/Winter-holidays.SHOP SAFELY ONLINEWhen shopping online, have a general idea of how much an item should cost.Sometimes prices are too good to be true.Don't access bank records or online shop when on public wifi. Instead, use a VPN or mobile hotspot.Only buy items from vendors you can verify.Keep an eye on your bank statements and flag any suspicious activity.For the full shopping online toolkit, visit the National Cybersecurity Alliance tips at staysafeonline.org/resources/safe-online-holiday-shopping/.SAY NO TO RAW DOUGHBaking is a great way to celebrate special occasions.When making cookies, brownies, cakes or bread, you might be tempted to taste a bite before it's fully baked. But you can get sick after eating or tasting raw (unbaked) dough or batter.Don't let children handle raw dough, including play clay and dough for crafts.Wash your hands, bowls, utensils, and countertops after handling raw flour, eggs or dough.For more food safety tips, visit cdc.gov/foodsafety/communication/holidays.html.The "Season's Safety" Campaign will run on Talbot County Emergency Services Facebook page during the month of December.The campaign also includes tips on porch pirate prevention, winter weather safety for pets, fireplace safety and more. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a public awareness campaign by emergency services about winter safety hazards, including fire prevention, holiday decorations, and online shopping safety. While local government activities are mentioned, the core theme is public safety education.

title: Trial Begins For Cambridge Man Charged In Fatal Shooting
author: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub.Com
content:
Trial Begins For Cambridge Man Charged In Fatal Shooting

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub.Com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 528
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Testimony began Tuesday in the jury trial for a Cambridge man charged in the shooting death of a 24-year-old man last December.Tramelle Williams, 23, is charged with firstand second-degree murder, armed robbery and firearms offenses in the fatal shooting of Taijay Brian Daniels on Pleasant Street just after 7 p.m.
Dec. 8, 2022.
Wearing a Space Jam jacket and walking down Race Street that night, Daniels was just a normal 24-year-old. He had no idea he was about to be killed "execution-style," said Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard, who is prosecuting the case with Senior Assistant State's Attorney Ella Disharoon.
Williams, wearing a mask, approached Daniels with a gun, shooting him in the back. Then, he shot again, striking Daniels in the head twice before taking Daniels' belongings and leaving.
Although a Cambridge resident on his way home that night found Daniels' body lying facedown on Pleasant Street within minutes of the shooting, and police and emergency medical services personnel performed CPR, Daniels was pronounced deceased at the scene.
Daniels' death was ruled a homicide by multiple gunshot wounds, two of which were "rapidly fatal," a state medical examiner testified Tuesday afternoon.
"He didn't stand a chance," Leonard said during her opening statement.
However, Williams didn't count on surveillance cameras from local businesses capturing the shooting, she said.
Williams also didn't count on police arresting him while he was wearing the same backpack from the night of the shooting, or police finding Daniels' phone in his pocket, Leonard added.
Williams was arrested the next evening following a foot pursuit on Lincoln Terrace. After he attempted to flee, a Cambridge police officer fired, shooting Williams in the leg.
But to defense attorneys Michelle Moodispaw and Stephanie DeLang, evidence shown by prosecutors would not prove Williams guilty.
Video surveillance and forensics presented by prosecutors have limited value, Moodispaw said, urging the jury to consider evidence that wasn't being shown.
The only thing to be presented was "maybes and possibilities," she said.
By the end of the day Tuesday, seven witnesses had testified, including Daniels' mother, police officers, crime scene technicians and the medical examiner.
Additional law enforcement witnesses and forensic analysts are expected to testify Wednesday. A verdict is anticipated Friday.
This week's trial is not the only pending case against Williams.
Williams is also accused in a second fatal shooting in Cambridge, which occurred roughly three hours after Daniels was shot.
Around 10 p.m. Dec. 8, 2022, police responded to the 700 block of High Street for a second gunshot victim, who was identified as Lory Eugene Fields, 69, of Cambridge.
Fields was found lying in a yard with a gunshot wound to his head. He was declared deceased at the scene.
Williams is facing additional murder and robbery charges in connection to Fields' death.
Though the shootings happened within hours of each other and all charges appear to be grouped together in Maryland Judiciary court records, Williams is set to stand for a second trial related to Fields' death in mid-January. 
 
 Caption: FILE PHOTO

 Pleasant Street near the intersection with Race Street in Cambridge is the scene of the first fatal shooting that occurred Thursday evening, Dec. 8, 2022.

 FILE PHOTO

 Tire tracks line Pleasant Street in Cambridge where a fatal shooting occurred Thursday evening, Dec. 8, 2022.

title: Police Team With Talbot Optimist Club For Shop With A Cop
author: Contributed
content:
Police Team With Talbot Optimist Club For Shop With A Cop

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 523
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Easton Police Department, the Oxford Police Department and the Talbot County Sheriff 's Office came together Saturday, Dec. 9, for the Talbot Optimist Club's Shop with a Cop event.The event sees police officers pairing with local youths to assist them on a shopping spree to provide holiday gifts for the youths and their families.
Debbie Henckel, event organizer and member of the Talbot Optimist Club, has been working the event for over a decade.
"It's all about the kids, the smiles on their faces, and them being able to have something to give to their families," Henckel said.
The children participating came to the Elks Lodge off Dutchmans Lane, where they were greeted and paired with their chaperoning officers.
After they were welcomed by the officers, the children ventured out to the squad cars to head over to the Easton Walmart.
The squad cars left the Elks Lodge in an impressive fashion, lined up and utilizing lights and sirens similar to a parade procession.
Once they were at Walmart, officers helped the children use their budget and shopping lists to acquire presents for their families. Many of the children involved utilized their entire budget to purchase gifts for their families instead of themselves.
Fortunately, their kindness did not go unnoticed and was rewarded. The chaperoning officers found it in their hearts to give them a little extra so everyone left with a gift of their own.
In addition to the officers chipping in, there were a few shoppers passing by who also donated their own funds to the cause.
"This is a good place we live in," Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said. "I've seen these kids looking out for their families instead of themselves, our officers reaching into their own wallets to make sure no one is left out, and even just some local townspeople going out of their way to do the same. It is really moving, and I'm proud to see it all." After the shopping was completed, the group returned to the Elks Lodge to get wrapping.
Tape, wrapping paper, bags and scissors were all deployed simultaneously as the officers, and their companions took all the gifts and did their best to make everything look beautiful enough to go under the tree.
Once completed, the officers and children enjoyed pizza and snacks together, before wrapping up the day by playing a spirited soccer match on the lawn outside.
In all her years organizing the event, Henckel said she always sees familiar faces among the officers.
"You see a lot of returning officers and you know that's because they care. It's nice to see their eagerness to be here with the kids," she said in a news release. "They really make a difference to these kids, and around our community."
Henckel thanked the Elks Lodge for donating the space, the Easton Walmart for making the event possible and the three police departments for joining forces.
" To have their support over the years means more than you know," she said. 
 
 Caption: GREG MUELLER/TOWN OF EASTON

 Officer Cordero Proctor of the Easton Police Department does some holiday shopping alongside his partner at Walmart in Easton for the Talbot Optimist's Shop with a Cop event. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton Man Gets 18 Years For Enticing Child For Sexual Activity
content:
Easton Man Gets 18 Years For Enticing Child For Sexual Activity

 December 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: B2 | Section: News 
 
 553
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE - An Easton man was sentenced Wednesday to 18 years in federal prison for attempted coercion and enticement of a minor to engage in illicit sexual activity.U.S. District Judge George L. Russell III handed down the prison term to Samuel Charles Hardeman, 55. His prison term will be followed by lifetime supervised release.
Hardeman had a previous federal conviction in a 2002 case in the Northern District of Georgia for use of a computer to entice a child to engage in sexual activity, for which he was sentenced to 174 months in prison.
Upon his release from prison, Hardeman must continue to register as a sex offender in the places where he resides, where he is an employee and where he is a student, under the Sex Offender Registration and Notification Act, per the judge's order.
The sentence was announced by United States Attorney for the District of Maryland Erek L. Barron, Acting Special Agent in Charge R. Joseph Rothrock of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Baltimore Field Office and Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble.
According to the guilty plea, from Dec. 11, 2022, through Dec. 26, 2022, Hardeman engaged in conversations with an undercover law enforcement officer who purported to have a 10-year-old daughter.
During the conversations, Hardeman expressed how he wanted to have sex with the 10-year-old, sent a video containing child pornography to the undercover officer and made plans to drive to New York, where the undercover officer purportedly lived, to have sex with the 10-year-old.
Hardeman communicated with the undercover officer by phone via video call, text and through the use of encrypted messaging platforms.
The Maryland U.S.
Attorney's Office said the conversations occurred while Hardeman was on the sex offender registration for a previous federal sex offense conviction.
During a call on Dec. 26, 2022, Hardeman expressed hesitation about traveling to New York to visit the undercover officer and her daughter. The officer did not hear from Hardeman after that time.
On March 14, 2023, a federal search warrant was executed at Hardeman's residence, where several electronic devices were seized.
A forensic examination of one of the phones revealed the encrypted messaging account which Hardeman used to communicate with the undercover officer, a text message thread between Hardeman and the officer, photos sent to Hardeman by the officer at Hardeman's request, the photos and videos that Hardeman sent to the officer and dozens of images and videos depicting minors engaged in sexually explicit conduct.
Forensic examinations of several other devices and Hardeman's cloud storage account recovered additional images of child sex abuse material, including bestiality.
This case was brought as part of Project Safe Childhood, a nationwide initiative launched in May 2006 by the Department of Justice to combat the growing epidemic of child sexual exploitation and abuse.
Led by the United States Attorney's Offices and the Criminal Division's Child Exploitation and Obscenity Section, Project Safe Childhood marshals federal, state, and local resources to locate, apprehend, and prosecute individuals who sexually exploit children and to identify and rescue victims.
For more information about Project Safe Childhood, visit justice.gov/psc. For more information about Internet safety education, visit justice. gov/psc and click on the "Resources" tab on the left of the page.
Barron commended the FBI and the Talbot County Sheriff 's Office for their work in the investigation.
Barron thanked Assistant U.S. Attorneys Spencer Todd and Paul E. Budlow, who prosecuted the federal case. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a federal criminal conviction for child enticement and sexual exploitation, involving law enforcement actions and sex offender registration. This falls under Public Safety due to its focus on criminal justice and community safety. title: St. Michaels Issues Update On Marengo Street Pump Station Fire
author: Town Of St. Michaels
content:
St. Michaels Issues Update On Marengo Street Pump Station Fire

 December 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Town Of St. Michaels | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 420
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Dec. 3, one of two of the Town of St. Michaels' water treatment plants experienced a major fire, making the facility inoperable. The cause of the fire is still being investigated by the State Fire Marshal but does not appear to be arson-related.Fortunately, the Town has plenty of water capacity to serve the community in the coming months when demand is low during winter and early spring.
Nonetheless, with only a single, operable water treatment plant online, there is some potential of temporary domestic water service interruptions.
Please be assured that Town staff has quickly implemented precautionary and proactive measures to minimize any interruptions in water service to our community. To this end, we have implemented the following measures over the past several days: ¡ Hosted a meeting with Talbot County Emergency Services and other agencies to alert them of the issue.
¡ Coordinated with Town engineers and water treatment equipment suppliers to review all treatment processes in the current operable water plant along with securing back-up equipment if a mechanical failure were to occur.
¡ Worked with St. Michaels Fire Department to establish protocols for the use of alternative water sources if a major fire were to occur.
¡ As lead time for replacement of pump and electronic equipment for the Marengo Station is many months out, the Town is coordinating efforts with our engineers in the development of a temporary water treatment system to be located at the Marengo site creating critical water system redundancy and capacity that will be needed in the coming months.
Engineers have also started to order replacement equipment for the Marengo site.
¡ Costs associated with this fire will be paid for by the Town's insurance carrier minimizing any use of local tax dollars.
With recent emergency planning efforts well underway, the Town is in a much better position than last week. Although there is no mandatory water conservation order at this time, we would appreciate any efforts from the community to voluntarily conserve water in the coming months.
We are optimistic this will be resolved without interruptions in water service. Please be rest-assured that the Town Commission and staff are working diligently to resolve this issue as quickly as possible.
We will keep the community informed with future Constant Contact communications and through updates to our website at www.stmichaelsmd.gov.
If you should have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to contact Town Administrator Rob Straebel at 410-745-9535. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF ST. MICHAELS FIRE DEPARTMENT

 Flames shoot through the roof of the St. Michaels pump station on Marengo Street Sunday, Dec. 3.

title: Complicated Crossroads
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
Complicated Crossroads

 December 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1754
 Words 

 Read News Document

 After high-profile mass shootings, calls to focus on mental health - including passing more red flag gun confiscation laws and expanding involuntary commitment statutes - have become as frequent as pushes for increased gun control."It's about mental health." has become a common refrain after shootings.
The mental health component of America's longstanding debate over guns and its crossroads with high-profile mass and school shootings is dotted with misperceptions and misunderstandings of the issue, what's already on the books and how red flag and commitment laws are and are not being used to help those in crisis from hurting themselves and others.
There are also civil liberties and constitutional questions regarding allowing the government and/or police to put someone in a mental hospital or take away their guns.
POLICE, 911 CALLS
One of the biggest challenges is that mental health action and interventions often start after an emergency 911 call to police when a crisis situation is already happening.
It's often a police officer rushing to a scene who is the first to deal with someone threatening or already harming themselves or others.
"The de facto response is still law enforcement," said Lisa Dailey, executive director of the Treatment Advocacy Center, a Virginia-based group focused on civil commitment laws and other mental health issues.
She said the mental health system and approaches have to change that dynamic.
"They are not being implemented to get people the care that they need in the right time frame," Dailey said.
Despite the talk of increasing mental health resources and putting a dent in long-held societal and family stigmas, Jack McDevitt, a professor of practice emeritus in criminology and criminal justice at Northeastern University in Boston, said a 911 call is still frequently the entry point to law enforcement and other agencies response to a person going through a mental health crisis and potentially harming themselves or others.
Sometimes those police officers have no background information on a person's mental state or history of mental illness.
McDevitt, who has helped Massachusetts lawmakers with gun policy proposals, said it is important for 911 operators to be able to get information and mental health histories from callers. But that is not always easy in stressful and sometimes violent situations when emergency calls occur.
He sees merits in having counselors and social workers respond to some mental health calls and wellness checks that do not involve violence - with police sometimes in a support role.
That may help diffuse situations.
"They aren't the ones knocking on the door," said McDevitt, referring to programs in Florida, Wisconsin, Wyoming and other states.
'PATCHWORK SYSTEM'
All U.S. states have some form of involuntary or civil commitment laws that allow for temporary or short-term placements in inpatient mental health settings, including hospitals, when a person shows serious signs of committing suicide or harming or killing others.
The landscape for those state laws is mixed with some states allowing for court-order holds and commitments related to substance abuse, according to a report by the Treatment Advocacy Center. five states - including Florida, California, New York, Wisconsin and Wyoming - allow for 72-hour holds.
Another seven states (such as Georgia and Texas) and the District of Columbia have 48-hour limits on the time someone can be involuntarily committed.
Eight states - including Maryland (30 hours), Delaware (24 hours) and Montana (the next business day) - have shorter time limits, according to TAC.
Some state laws allow for family members to petition for commitments and there are situations where judges can impose holds related to substance abuse and self-harm.
For example, judges in Colorado can impose 180-days holds for substance abuse treatment.
"Our system is very patchwork," Dailey said.
Dailey said states need to look at how to better match mental health policies, including commitment laws, to the needs of patients. She said proper mental health treatment programs can take six months - not the 72-hour holds on the books in most states.
DISINCENTIVES AND DIFFICULTIES
That varied and piecemeal approach isn't just related to varying state laws related to commitments and gun confiscation.
Mental health systems across the country are challenged by lack of inpatient facility capacity and a system where treatment, housing, employment and substance abuse services can be siloed.
"It's still really difficult to navigate the system," said Dailey, pointing to the lack of a central agency, information or support source for patients and their families.
That can leave individuals dealing with severe mental illness such as schizophrenia, bipolar and borderline personality disorders to navigate various bureaucracies while trying to overcome stigmas and fears of past and contemporary mistreatment of the "mentally ill." "Individuals have often had very bad experiences at inpatient or law enforcement settings," Dailey said.
Stigmas toward mental health continue including hospitalizations for patients worried about reactions from their families, friends and employers.
There are pushes in New York and some other states to allow for longer mandated hospitalizations and to make it easier for police and courts to involuntarily commit seriously mentally ill persons, including homeless people, after a series of high-profile assaults.
Some bioethicists and mental health professionals argue that inpatient hospitalizations are not always the best treatment path for some patients.
Civil libertarians worry expanding forced hospitalizations can lead to discriminatory treatment by courts and police of some classes of patients. There is plenty of history in the U.S. and other countries of political, religious and ethnic minorities as well as women being disproportionately "put away" by government authorities and mental health practitioners.
"Involuntary hospitalization is a serious deprivation of liberty that can be justified only in the narrow circumstance where there is mental illness and an imminent physical danger to the person to be committed or to others, evidenced by observed behavior, and where there is no less restrictive alternative. In such cases, strong procedural safeguards must be in place throughout to ensure that the due process rights of the individual are protected," said the New York Civil Liberties Union in response to state and local efforts to expand civil commitments.
But even if police and courts are more aggressive in pursuing forced hospitalizations, many states and regions lack the number of mental inpatient beds needed to accommodate such a push.
Police officers have to go through a number of legal and bureaucratic hoops to gain temporary and short-term holds.
"It'a big challenge," said Dailey, noting that officers can spend several hours going through the inpatient mental health process.
Some states require specific staffing to transport an individual to a mental health hospital or another inpatient facility. And even then, police will find facilities completely full.
"It's much easier to bring them in and book them," she said.
BY THE NUMBERS
The U.S. has seen a contemporary decline in the number of mental hospitals and institutionalized patients.
In 1955, when state mental asylums and short and long-term commitments were more common there were more than 500,000 beds nationally, according to the American Psychiatric Association.
In 1963, there were 800,000 mentally ill developmentally disabled persons kept in institutional settings - often at overcrowded and toxic mental hospitals, according to the Kennedy administration which pushed for systematic changes away from asylums.
As many as 1.5 million people were treated annually at those sanatoriums in the early 1960s.
A study last year by the National Association of State Mental Health Program Directors Research Institute Inc. showed there were still close to 471,500 patients at government-run, private and other mental hospitals in 1970.
That number stands at just 121,300 in 2020, the most recent data available.
Moves toward de-institutionalization and U.S. health care business models focused away from inpatient settings have driven that trend.
RED FLAG LAWS
Shootings in Maine in October that killed 18 people and injured 13 and at the University of Nevada Las Vegas Dec. 6 that killed three persons have sparked new looks at mental health approaches and red flag gun laws - especially after details of the New England killings by U.S. Army firearms instructor Robert Card emerged.
Twenty-one states have so-called red flag laws on the books allowing for court and law enforcement to temporarily seize guns from individuals deemed likely to harm others or themselves.
Those states include Nevada, Washington, Oregon, California, Florida, Maryland, Delaware, Illinois and New York, according to Everytown for Gun Safety, which supports increased gun control laws.
"Red flag laws are a tool law enforcement and others can use when somebody is clearly at high risk of doing something with a firearm, but they can't be arrested because no crime has been committed and they don't appear to need a mental health hold or qualify for one," said Amy Barnhorst, a psychiatrist at University of California, Davis, Health and a violence prevention expert in an analysis of the issue earlier this year.
Maine's gun confiscation law requires an extra step of those states of having the individual question go through a mental health evaluation.
McDevitt said most of the time gun confiscations are done in response to concerns about potential suicide attempts and firearms are usually returned to their owners.
It can save some people from hurting themselves," said McDevitt, citing research showing for the laws can help reduce suicides.
There were 26,933 suicides committed with firearms in 2022 compared to with 19,592 homicides, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control.
Suicides by firearms made up 56.9% of all gun deaths and 54.4% of all suicides last year, according to CDC figures. McDevitt said owners often get guns back after anywhere between 30 days and six months depending on the state statute.
Pushes for additional red flags in other states face resistance from gun rights advocates. The National Rifle Association's Institute for Legislative Action worries red flag gun laws could be used by the government to take guns from critics and political opponents.
'RARELY USED'
Despite their increased advocacy, McDevitt said gun confiscation proceedings are rare.
"There aren't thousands and thousands of these things. They are pretty rarely used," he said.
A 2022 analysis by the Associated Press said red flag laws have been little used due to lack of awareness and resistance from some sheriff 's offices and police departments to such policies on Second Amendment grounds.
Part of that also stems from families being reluctant to broach the issue, McDevitt said.
"That's a very difficult conversation to have.
Most people don't want to do that," he said. 
 
 Caption: Bellevue Hospital in New York City is the oldest public hospital in the U.S. and is probably the country's most notable mental hospital via frequent references in movies and books as well as on television shows.

 Twenty-one U.S. states have implemented red flag laws that allow guns to be confiscated from individuals deemed mentally ill and a danger to themselves or others. Firearms account for the majority of suicides in the U.S. and more people take their own lives with guns than commit homicides with firearms. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the intersection of mental health policies, gun control laws, and public safety measures, including red flag laws, involuntary commitment statutes, and law enforcement responses to mental health crises. While mental health is a component, the primary emphasis is on societal safety frameworks, legal interventions, and public policy debates, aligning most closely with 'Public Safety.'

title: Cambridge man killed in Bradley Avenue shooting
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com

Cambridge man killed in Bradley Avenue shooting

 December 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 CAMBRIDGE - A Cambridge man was fatally shot Monday morning on Bradley Avenue, police said.Officers from the Cambridge Police Department responded to the 600 block of Bradley Avenue shortly before 8 a.m. Monday for a report of a shooting.
There, police found 36-year-old Taron Jones suffering from at least one apparent gunshot wound.
Jones was declared dead at the scene by Dorchester County emergency medical services personnel.
The Maryland State Police Homicide Unit was asked to take over the lead of the investigation into the case. The Cambridge Police Department is assisting state police in its investigation.
Homicide detectives consulted with the Dorchester County State's Attorney's Office. Detectives identified a person of interest in this case and said there is no threat to the public at this time.
The case remains under investigation.

title: Fire in Wye Mills leaves employee with burn injuries
author: Staff Report
content:
Fire in Wye Mills leaves employee with burn injuries

 December 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Report | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 216
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYEMILLS - An accidental structure fire at Nagel Farm Service's Wye Mills location left one employee with burn injuries to the face and hands.The fire, which originated on an interior side of the commercial structure adjacent to the grain elevators, was discovered by a neighbor Monday morning.
According to a news release from the Office of the State Fire Marshal, it took 50 firefighters one hour to control the one alarm fire at 14209 Old Wye Mills Road.
The Queen Anne-Hillsboro Volunteer Fire Company was the primary responding fire department.
The fire resulted in an estimated loss of $150,000, the news release said. The property is owned by Mountaire Farms, which in November made the announcement they would purchase not only the Wye Mills grain elevator, but also the Preston and Cordova locations. According to that press release from Mountaire officials, Nagel's Farm Service retained their trucking, hardware and crop insurance businesses.
The preliminary investigation into the fire has ruled the cause as accidental.

 An accidental structure fire at Nagel Farm Service's Wye Mills Location was discovered by a neighbor on the morning of Dec. 18. According to a news release from the Office of the State Fire Marshal, one employee was left with burn injuries to the face and hands.

title: Shop with a Cop brings smiles, connections
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Shop with a Cop brings smiles, connections

 December 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 450
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Jurnee Cannon, 8, led the way down the narrow toy isles of the Cambridge Walmart on Dec. 14 with Officer Malik Shirley following close behind."You drive better than I do," Shirley said to Cannon as she turned into another aisle and gazed up at the bright display of different dolls.
A moment before, Shirley had taken a toy off the top shelf for Cannon to put in her cart. It was a moment she remembered on the ride back to her house later that evening.
"He helped me get my doll that was on the top shelf," she said to explain why she liked Shirley.
At 4 p.m. that Thursday, Cannon's name was the first of two that was pulled from a red bucket at the Cambridge Police Department on Washington Street. Cannon and Nevaeh Moran, 6, were the two lucky children of the day to get the opportunity to "Shop with a Cop." For five years now, the department has been taking children out to Walmart to purchase items for themselves or for family members for the holidays.
"We normally partner up with the Dorchester County Board of Education and they pick the names," Captain Antoine Patton, who started the program, said.
"However, we realized that we were leaving a lot of our community out, so we decided to open it up to the entire community." This year, CPD is drawing two names every evening for 12 days, concluding on Christmas Eve.
Paul Davis Restoration is sponsoring the entire program this year.
"There may or may not be some special kids added toward the end," Patton said. "Wink, wink." Each drawing is broadcasted on Facebook Live. After names are picked, Patton calls the families to let them know their child has won. Then, a small group leaves the station to pick the children up from their homes and take them to Walmart. Each child then gets to spend $100 on "anything of their choosing." The program helps strengthen the department's relationship with the community, particularly with children in the community, Patton said.
"It gives us an opportunity to interact with children and families," he said. "Letting them know that we do a lot of positive things and give them a positive interaction with the police department instead of coming to the house when something's wrong." Patton remembers one night where they pulled up and a little girl "was smiling from ear to ear." "She was like, 'Yes! The police are here!'" Patton said. "She knew we were coming to take her Christmas shopping." 
 
 Caption: MAGGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT

 Jurnee Cannon, 8, shops for toys at the Walmart in Cambridge Dec. 14. Cannon was selected to take part in the Cambridge Police Department's Shop with a Cop program. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Cambridge Police Department's community engagement initiative, highlighting police-community relations and positive interactions. While local government aspects are present, the core theme aligns with public safety efforts to build trust and community connections.

title: Caroline Shop with a Cop event raises over $18K
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Caroline Shop with a Cop event raises over $18K

 December 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: A3 | Section: News 
 
 310
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - The Caroline County Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 118 raised over $18,000 for its Shop with a Cop program, and 26 children in the county benefited from the generosity of supporters.The fundraiser made it possible for the kids to accompany law enforcement officers Sunday, Dec. 10, and shop for themselves and others on their Christmas list at Walmart in Denton.
Most of the funds were raised through the Caroline County Sheriff's Office's "No Shave November" campaign, deemed "a huge success," according to its Facebook page. The deputies bought into the fundraiser with their own and solicited donations. They each paid $30 to grow a beard from Nov. 1 to Dec. 4.
Participating deputies raised a total of $18,115.00 for the Shop with a Cop program.
The top contributors were Capt. Rodney Helmer with $7,755, Corporal Amber Hafer with $4,785 and Detective Brent Beck with $1,390 in donations.
All Caroline County local law enforcement agencies participated, as well as the Maryland State Police and Department of Natural Resources Police.
The children wrapped presents with them at the Sheriff's Office on Double Hills Road in Denton following their shopping trip.
About 15 high school students helped out, earning service learning hours.
There was even a visit from Santa and the Grinch.
The event, formerly hosted by the disbanded Caroline County Optimist Club, was taken over by the local FOP lodge in 2022, who pulled together that event in eight days.
If you would like to donate to Shop with a Cop for next year, please reach out to Cpl. Hafer at 410-479-2515 extension 5980. 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT

 Over $18,000 was raised for Shop with a Cop to help 26 children in need make Christmas merrier for themselves and loved ones Dec. 10. From left are Caroline County Sheriff's officers Chief Deputy Capt. Rodney Helmer, Sheriff Donnie Baker, Cpl. Amber Hafer and DFC Logan Wolf, president of FOP Lodge 118.
