title: Seaford woman found guilty of embezzlement
content:
Seaford woman found guilty of embezzlement

 December 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A2 | Section: News 
 
 291
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - After two days of a three-day jury trial, Karen Knauer, 55, of Seaford, Delaware, entered an Alford plea Oct. 12 to one count of embezzling $36,245.30 from Bell Creek Equipment LLC, of Preston, Maryland, State's Attorney Sloane R. Franklin announced.An Alford plea allows a person to maintain their innocence but acknowledge the State had enough evidence to obtain a conviction.
Knauer was employed by Bell Creek Equipment as a bookkeeper and was responsible for accounts payable, receivable and depositing monies received.
Between Feb. 2017 and May 2018, Knauer failed to make a number of cash and check deposits.
She also wrote checks to herself from the business and changed the business checking account registry to hide her embezzlement.
"Knauer was in a position of trust, and she broke that trust and almost bankrupted a local family business for her own personal gain," Franklin said.
"I want to thank Salisbury University for the use of its resources.
I want to personally thank Professor David Weber, and his students, Micah J. Weber (SU '23; UB School of Law '26), Kaylynn Boswell (SU '23; U.S. Department of the Navy), Camryn Pepper (SU '24), Selena Sandbank (SU '24), and Mitchell Adams (SU '24) for conducting a through forensic accounting of Bell Creek Equipment's accounting records to help discover the embezzlement by Knauer." "Financial crimes are difficult to prosecute, but having the resources that Salisbury University provided and people like Professor Weber and his students, contributed greatly to the outcome of the case," Franklin said.
On Dec. 13, Judge Heather L. Price, sentenced Knauer to three years, suspended all but six months, ordered restitution in the amount of $36,245.30, and placed her on probation for three years.
The case was prosecuted by Franklin on behalf of the citizens of Caroline County. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a criminal embezzlement case involving a business, which impacts community trust and economic stability. While 'Business/Economy' is relevant due to the financial aspects, 'Public Safety' better captures the legal prosecution and societal implications of the crime.

title: Queen Anne man faces assault, firearm charges
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne man faces assault, firearm charges

 December 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 366
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEEN ANNE - A Queen Anne man is facing multiple charges in connection to two assaults earlier this year, police said.Travis N. Lynch, 33, is charged with first-and second-degree assault and reckless endangerment stemming from incidents in September and October.
He also is charged with illegal possession of a firearm and handgun offenses following the execution of a search warrant, police said.
Investigators with the Talbot County Sheriff's Office responded to the University of Maryland Shore Emergency Center at Queenstown on Friday, Dec. 22, and interviewed a woman who said she was the victim of two separate assaults in the 13000 block of Cannery Road in Queen Anne.
The investigators learned the first incident occurred in September or October. Lynch grabbed the victim after she caught him performing a sex act while watching her in the bathroom, police said.
A second incident occurred in October. The victim told police they were sitting in a vehicle parked in the driveway with another person. Lynch accosted them with a pistol while they were sitting in the driveway, police said.
Investigators obtained an arrest warrant for Lynch on Dec. 22. Police surveilled the Cannery Road address and saw a vehicle believed to be owned by Lynch leave the home.
Deputies with the Talbot County Sheriff's Office pulled the vehicle over for a traffic stop and identified Lynch as the front seat passenger. Police arrested Lynch and took him to Talbot County's central booking facility, where he was ordered held without bond during an initial appearance with a district court commissioner.
Lynch was ordered to remain held without bond during a Dec. 26 bail review, according to online court records.
The investigation continued after Lynch was arrested, police said.
Detectives searched the Cannery Road home and recovered pistol ammunition in a bag connected to Lynch, police said.
Police said detectives searched the vehicle Lynch was in when he was arrested and located a loaded pistol secreted under a trim panel in the front seat passenger area.
The Talbot County Sheriff's Office was assisted by the Easton Police Department's Crisis Response Unit, the Talbot County Drug Task Force and the Maryland State Police Gun Center.
Anyone with information regarding the incident is asked to contact the Talbot County Sheriff's Office at 410-822-1020. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Kyleigh remembered - Community rallies around family of girl killed in Christmas morning fire
author: Carl Hamilton; cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Kyleigh remembered - Community rallies around family of girl killed in Christmas morning fire

 January 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton; cahamilton@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1547
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ELKTON - Tom and Nancy Minor stood in front of the charred remains of a townhouse at 317 Willow Drive in Winding Brook Village near Elkton on Wednesday and remembered 10-year-old Kyleigh Nicole Treadway."Kyleigh was so sweet. She was a most vivacious girl, always smiling.
She loved to give hugs and loved animals. She loved our cats and always asked about them whenever she saw us," Nancy, 67, rattled off, needing little time to gather her thoughts to describe Kyleigh when asked about her.
Her 66-year-old husband, Tom, interjected, "Nothing seemed to faze her. Kyleigh always seemed to be upbeat, like nothing was impossible." Nancy started to speak again, but paused for a few seconds before recalling the last time she saw and interacted with Kyleigh - on a morning maybe a week or so earlier.
Chaperoned by her grandmother, Kyleigh was waiting for the school bus to arrive and take her to Cecil Manor Elementary School.
Nancy, who lives three doors down from 317 Willow Drive, happened to be outside.
"It was right before school was out for Christmas break. She was telling me about all of her animals," Nancy said. (The list of beloved pets in Kyleigh's home included two dogs, a cat, three ferrets and two rats, according to a family friend.)
When the school bus arrived, Kyleigh said her goodbyes - in a way that beautifully reflected her bubbly personality - and then she boarded.
"She said, 'I love you' and hugged her grandmom. Then she hugged me, too, and said, 'I love you'," Nancy said, prompting Tom to marvel, "I don't think she encountered anyone she didn't love." On Christmas morning, in stark and sobering contrast to the wonder and joy that the holiday holds for children, Kyleigh died in a swift-moving blaze that ripped through her family's two-story townhouse at 317 Willow Drive.
Singerly Volunteer Fire Company of Elkton and other area volunteer fire companies rushed to that neighborhood, northeast of Elkton, at approximately 7:30 a.m. Monday after receiving a dispatch regarding a dwelling fire at 317 Willow Drive, reported Master Deputy State Fire Marshal Oliver J. Alkire, an agency detective and spokesman.
"Upon arrival, firefighters found the family standing outside their home, stating a young girl was still inside. Firefighters heroically entered the home and located the child. However, she was later pronounced deceased on the scene," Alkire said, before emphasizing on Wednesday, "Investigators later learned that after family discovered the fire, they made several attempts to save Kyleigh during the fast-moving fire; however, they were unable to due to thick smoke and intense heat." The medical examiner attributed Kyleigh's death to "thermal injuries and smoke inhalation," Alkire reported.
The spokesman updated, "Deputy state fire marshals continue investigating the exact origin and cause (of the fire). While the fire remains under investigation, they have not recovered evidence that it was an intentionally set fire, nor do they believe or suspect that this was an intentionally set fire, and continue to explore all possible accidental causes." In addition to killing Kyleigh - despite heroic efforts by fire responders to rescue the girl - the blaze displaced 17 residents, including her five surviving family members, fire officials said.
The other 12 displaced residents lived in adjacent townhouses, fire officials added. Most of the pets at 317 Willow Drive, where Kyleigh lived, reportedly were lost in the blaze.
The fire displaced three adults and three children who lived at 319 Willow Drive, fire officials said. In addition, the fire displaced two adults and four children at 315 Willow Drive, fire officials added. The American Red Cross is assisting the 17 displaced residents, including Kyleigh's surviving relatives, the spokesman reported.
News of the fatal Christmas morning fire sparked an outpouring of community support for Kyleigh's survivors.
As Tom and Nancy - a retired couple that has owned and lived in their Willow Drive townhouse since 1993 - were speaking with the Cecil Whig on Wednesday afternoon, a woman pulled up in a sport utility vehicle and parked it.
The woman got out of the vehicle and purposefully walked over to a small patch of grass in front of the gutted remains of 317 Willow Drive, where a few people already had placed decorations and stuffed animals to show support, including at least one teddy bear. A strand of yellow "Do Not Cross" emergency scene tape was lying on the ground directly behind a teddy bear. Also nearby were two small, wooden crosses, one of which read, "Grow in grace." There were three candles in tall, slim glasses - similar to ones that might be found inside a church - on the nearby sidewalk. Only one candle was burning, however, the purple one. The blue and orange candles had burned out. The woman who had arrived in the SUV unsuccessfully attempted to relight the other two candles amid a steady rain.
"I did not know Kyleigh and I do not know her family, but I just wanted to come here today," said the woman, a Rising Sun resident who identified herself only as Kathi.
Teary-eyed, Kathi explained that she was experiencing sorrow after learning about the devastating blaze that killed Kyleigh and that she felt compelled to come to the place where it happened.
She placed a small teddy bear, one clad in a soldier uniform reminiscent of "The Nutcracker," in the lap of a bigger teddy bear already on the ground in front of the burnt shell of a townhouse. The woman also left a snowman decoration.
The tragedy spurred Cecil County resident Theresa Retz into action, too.
On Tuesday, one day after the fatal fire, she started a GoFundMe page to benefit Kyleigh's surviving family, which does not have insurance, and she did so with the permission of Kyleigh's mother - Theresa Moats - according to Retz, who works with Moats at Terumo Medical Corporation in Elkton.
"We work together, but we are also good friends," Retz explained.
"I only met Kyleigh a couple of times. But I can say Kyleigh made everyone smile. Her personality brightened a room, and she was the life of the party." On Monday, a few hours after losing Kyleigh in the house fire, Moats reached out to Retz from an area hospital, where medical staff was observing her and the other surviving family members.
"I found out late that morning. She messaged me from a friend's Facebook account because her laptop had burned up along with everything else inside the house. She told me her house burned down and Kyleigh did not make it," Retz said, noting that she sensed Moats was emotionally discombobulated.
"She wanted to know how to get up with the (Terumo) supervisor to let the company know that her badge and scrubs burned in the fire.
That's how I knew her head was nowhere in the right place. I let her know that it's OK and don't worry about that right now." They communicated electronically with each other throughout the day, after Moats and the surviving family members had moved from the hospital to an area hotel that American Red Cross volunteers had arranged for their lodging, at least for the next few days, according to Retz.
The friends had their emotional first face-toface meeting on Tuesday, one day after the fire, when Retz went to the hotel serving as temporary lodging for Kyleigh's surviving family members.
"There was a lot of crying," Retz said.
That day, Retz set up the GoFundMe page to benefit Moats; her fiance, Kevin; Moats' 13-yearold son, Ethan; her 20-year-old son, Jordan; and Moats' mother - the grandmother whom Kyleigh hugged at the bus stop on that morning earlier this month, a heartwarming scene witnessed by neighbor Nancy Minor, who also was embraced by the girl before she departed.
"Anyone who ever interacted with Kyleigh would have a hard time forgetting her," Minor said, after recalling that scene at the bus stop.
As of Thursday afternoon, the GoFundMe page had generated $17,414 in donations for Kyleigh's surviving family members. Also helping with the donations collection is Beth Edwards.
A section on the GoFundMe page reads, "Theresa Moats and her family are wonderful people who have suffered a devastating loss on Christmas Day Funds will be used for Kyleigh's funeral, supporting the family, paying for their current hotel room, as well as helping to secure permanent housing. The family did not have insurance." "People have been awesome.
In addition to (monetary) donations, there has been an avalanche of donated clothing," Retz said.
The list of items needed the most, aside from money, includes cell phones with chargers (T-Mobile network); restaurant gift cards; gasoline gift cards; Walmart and grocery store gift cards; and "any type of special Christmas gift." When asked about Moats' emotional condition, Retz explained, "She's holding up the best she can. She has to be strong, particularly for Ethan, who is now her youngest child." 
 
 Caption: CARL HAMILTON/CECIL WHIG

 Teddy Bears and candles left by people in the community dot the ground in front of a townhouse at 317 Willow Drive near Elkton, where a blaze killed 10-year-old Kyleigh Nicole Treadway on Christmas morning.

 PHOTO COURTESY OF THERESA RETZ

 This photo shows 10-year-old Kyleigh Nicole Treadway, who died in a fire inside her Willow Drive townhouse near Elkton on Christmas morning.

 CECIL WHIG FILE PHOTO

 This photo shows the gutted remains of Willow Drive townhouses, after a Christmas morning blaze killed 10-year-old Kyleigh Nicole Treadway and displaced 17 residents, including her five surviving family members.

title: Car crashes into house, sends infant to hospital
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Car crashes into house, sends infant to hospital

 January 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 270
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PRESTON - A car crashed into a Preston home Sunday morning, sending a 4-month-old baby who was inside the home to the hospital.Troopers from the Maryland State Police Barrack in Easton responded to the 200 block of Main Street in Preston shortly after 9:30 a.m. Sunday for a report of a vehicle that crashed into a residence.
According to a preliminary investigation, a Honda, operated by Christopher Fisher, 19, of Hurlock, was traveling northbound on Main Street when he lost control of the vehicle for unknown reasons, police said.
The Honda entered into the southbound lanes of traffic, crossing over a sidewalk and onto a gravel driveway before striking the home.
A 4-month-old baby who was inside the home at the time of the crash was flown by Maryland State Police Aviation Command to Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore for treatment of their injuries.
No other injuries were reported at the scene.
The crash caused significant damage to the front wall of the home.
The fire department stabilized the damaged wall to remove the car, then Cambridge-based company Perez Home Improvement LLC framed a temporary wall for the home. The company then called Cook's Electric LLC, a Dorchester County-based electrical contractor, who ensured power was restored and that all appliances were functioning.
The Maryland State Police Crash Team is leading the investigation. Once their investigation is complete, the team's findings will be submitted to the Caroline County State's Attorney's Office, which will decide whether charges will be filed in the case.
The cause of the crash remains under investigation. 
 
 Caption: A Honda crashed into the front wall of a home on Main Street in Preston Sunday, Dec. 31. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Family displaced in Henderson house fire
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Family displaced in Henderson house fire

 January 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 179
 Words 

 Read News Document

 HENDERSON - An early New Year's Day house fire displaced a Henderson family, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal.Fifty firefighters, primarily from the Goldsboro Volunteer Fire Department, responded to a fire in a onestory home at 27105 River Bridge Road in Henderson shortly after 6 a.m. Monday.
It took firefighters about an hour to control the blaze, which was discovered by a neighbor. The residents were not home at the time of the fire.
It's unknown if smoke alarms were present.
The fire originated in the interior of the home, but its cause remains under investigation, the state fire marshal said in a news release.
A family dog also died as a result of the fire.
The fire marshal estimated about $200,000 in damages - a $150,000 loss to the structure and a $50,000 loss in contents.
Anyone with information in reference to this fire is asked to call the Office of the State Fire Marshal's Upper Eastern Regional Office at 410-822-7609.

title: Cambridge, Queen Anne's County receive MDOT grants
content:
Cambridge, Queen Anne's County receive MDOT grants

 January 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 536
 Words 

 Read News Document

 HANOVER - The Maryland Department of Transportation congratulated 17 counties and municipalities in Maryland for their selection to receive more than $28 million in Fiscal Year 2023 Safe Streets and Roads for All grants.Awarded by the U.S. Department of Transportation, these grants are an important step toward meeting Maryland's goal of Vision Zero - the elimination of all traffic fatalities and severe injuries on Maryland roadways by 2030.
"In order to create the transportation system that Marylanders deserve, we must work with our citizens, our local officials and our Congressional delegation with unity and focus to deliver safe, equitable access across the state for everyone, whether they drive, ride, or walk," Gov.
Wes Moore said. "These grants help us achieve that goal and help fulfill our mission to lift every community."
The grants will be used for implementation, planning and demonstration projects to improve safety and help prevent deaths and serious injuries on the region's roadways.
MDOT worked in collaboration with local municipalities to advocate for the grant funding.
"The Maryland Department of Transportation is proud to have worked closely with our federal delegation to support our local partners' efforts to receive more than $28 million in funding to boost safety for those who bike, walk and drive on our roads," Maryland Transportation Secretary Paul Wiedefeld said. " The Maryland Department of Transportation looks forward to working with local leaders throughout the state to put this money to use to reduce roadway fatalities and ensure our streets are safer for all Marylanders."
The City of Mount Rainier is the largest implementation grant recipient in the state, receiving more than $9.7 million. Funds will be used for traffic calming measures, bicycle network improvements, sidewalk enhancements and pedestrian safety measures near Mount Rainier Elementary School.
The Town of Brentwood received $160,000 to develop a Vision Zero Action Plan.
"As a historically disadvantaged community, we're grateful for this federal investment and support of our county and state partners so that we can deliver safety for our residents, businesses and visitors," Brentwood Mayor Rocio Treminio-Lopez said. "While a small town, we have urban issues that need collaborative approaches to solve."
Baltimore County received $3.5 million to put toward developing a Vision Zero Action Plan.
"Investing in our roadways not only improves vital infrastructure, but prioritizes the safety and wellbeing of our residents and communities," Baltimore County Executive Johnny Olszewski said. "We are grateful to our federal and state partners for their help with the critical planning projects supported with this grant - and for helping to ensure Baltimore County's roads are safe for years to come."
Queen Anne's County received a grant of $280,000 to develop a comprehensive multimodal safety plan.
"This federal grant will help our local, state and federal partners combine knowledge and resources to create a comprehensive highway safety plan that will improve safety for our citizens and everyone traveling though Queen Anne's county," Queen Anne's County Commissioner Jim Moran said.
The City of Cambridge received a grant of $320,000 for research on ways to reorganize its streets to make them safer and more pedestrian-friendly.
"We have a number of streets and intersections that are really quite dangerous, especially to pedestrians," Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout said. "We're grateful for the funding. It's the kind of thing small communities need." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Maryland counties receiving federal grants for road safety improvements, including traffic calming measures, pedestrian safety projects, and Vision Zero initiatives. While local governments are involved, the primary emphasis is on public safety outcomes rather than general governance or economic factors.

title: New patrolman to join EPD
content:
New patrolman to join EPD

 January 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 203
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Monday, Dec. 18, 2023, Easton Police Department welcomed Patrolman Christopher Mueller to the force following his graduation from Wor-Wic Community College's Eastern Shore Criminal Justice Academy.The graduation ceremony was held at the Roland E. Powell Convention Center in Ocean City.
The academy has a six-month curriculum that trains officers on many aspects of police operations and has testing requirements for physical fitness, academics and marksmanship with a pistol.
During the ceremony, Mueller received additional awards for excellence in pistol marksmanship and academics.
Prior to starting with the Easton Police Department, Mueller served as a service technician II for ADT Commercial. Following his graduation, Mueller must successfully complete a threemonth field training program with Easton Police Department to satisfy the requirements for full certification as a Maryland law enforcement officer.
After the graduation ceremony, Deputy Chief Gregory Wright congratulated Mueller on a job well done. Deputy Chief Wright said, "We're excited to have Patrolman Mueller join our team. He's going to have a positive impact on our community." 
 
 Caption: From left: Deputy Chief Gregory Wright, Patrolman Christopher Mueller, and Easton Town Manager Don Richardson pose in front of an EPD cruiser after the Police Academy graduation held at the Roland E. Powell Convention Center in Ocean City

title: Work begins on Airport Modernization project
author: Staff Report
content:
Work begins on Airport Modernization project

 January 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Report | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 189
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Work has begun on what will be a years-long modernization and improvement project at the Easton Airport.Last week, crews began constructing a security and containment fence, designating areas that will soon see the project's impacts.
"The purpose of the fencing is to define the construction area and maintain security for aircraft operations throughout the implementation of the Airfield Modernization Program," said a release from the airport. "The fence will be 10 feet tall and include a mesh screen." The Airfield Modernization Project, when complete, will include shifting runway 4/22 1,900 feet southwest of its current location and the creation of 1,000 foot safety areas on either end of the runway, among other things.
Once the fence is completed, significant work is expected to begin on the project in February, according to an update from the most recent Easton Airport Advisory Board meeting on Dec. 20, 2023.

 Safety fencing goes up around the airport near the Talbot County Business Center. Soon it will have fabric put up to keep car drivers from getting distracted. According to Micah Risher, the airport manager, they can put up 30 poles a day.

title: A worthy New Year's resolution - Provide support to an abused or neglected child
author: Casa Of The Mid Shore
content:
A worthy New Year's resolution - Provide support to an abused or neglected child

 January 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Casa Of The Mid Shore | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 309
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's the first week of 2024, and many of us are excited to pursue new goals.We may have a renewed sense of purpose that beginnings can bring. While New Year's resolutions often focus on self-improvement, a sense of purpose can also involve helping others.
This year, why not resolve to help improve the life of a local child who is under court protection because of abuse or neglect?
You can bring this resolution to life by becoming a volunteer Court Appointed Special Advocate. Or you can help by making a financial contribution to CASA of the Mid-Shore.
CASA of the Mid-Shore is a nonprofit organization whose mission is to provide volunteer Court Appointed Special Advocates to all children under court protection in Talbot, Dorchester, Queen Anne's or Kent Counties due to maltreatment.
CASA volunteers receive in-depth training, enabling them to advocate in court and in the community for the needs and rights of children in foster care. CASA volunteers come from all walks of life and professions and share a common mission: they care about the future of vulnerable children in our communities.
"Volunteers fulfill their responsibilities by spending time with the child, as well as talking with everyone involved in the child's life. This might include parents and relatives, foster parents, teachers, medical professionals, attorneys, case workers and others. They use the information they gather to assist judges and other professionals in making important decisions to meet each child's needs, with the goal of obtaining a safe, permanent home for these children," said Robin Davenport, executive director of CASA of the Mid-Shore.
Start this New Year with a resolution to learn about how you can make a positive difference in the life of a local abused or neglected child.
CASA of the Mid-Shore is accepting applications for Spring Pre-Service Training.
Learn more about becoming a CASA volunteer by calling 410-822-2688 ext. 6 or visit casamidshore.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Trams takes helm as Greensboro police chief
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Trams takes helm as Greensboro police chief

 January 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 326
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — Mayor David Spencer administered the oath of office to new Greensboro Police Chief Lenox Trams shortly after 6 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 4, at the Greensboro Community Center and Fire Hall.Trams was named chief on Dec. 11. Also taking the oath of office was Greensboro Police Sgt. Jake Smith. The ceremony and meet and greet preceded the town's first meeting of 2024.
Trams, 48, has a 25-year career in law enforcement. He joined the GPD in March 2023. "(Chief Paugh) did a lot of work to get us up to standards," Trams told attendees, adding he would continue that trend.
Trams said he wants to fill out the department with three more officers. "We want the best officers who can do the job that the town deserves," he said.
Several of Trams' former colleagues from the Easton Police Department were on hand to applaud Trams' swearing-in, including Spencer, who was EPD police chief before retiring in Dec. 2022; Oxford Police Chief Eric Kellner, Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker; and former Greensboro Police Chief Lt. George Paugh, who hired Trams to the GPD and moved on in November 2023 to become commander of the criminal investigation division in the Caroline County Sheriff's Office.
Several of Trams' family members attended, and Trams' law enforcement colleagues shared their thoughts.
Upon joining the EPD, Sgt. Al Orrison said Trams offered him his trademark strong handshake and "took me under his wing. My kids actually call him Uncle Lenox. I love this man."
Orrison said Trams had not become cynical after so many years in law enforcement.
"When you get to that 15-, 20-year mark, you become very cynical, and it's hard to have compassion all the time," he said. "But Lenox Trams always has compassion for everyone. He treats everybody fairly, and he's just an incredible human being."
EPD Sgt. David Trevino said Trams has "endless energy" and "never stops giving to people" through mentoring and volunteer work.
"The town of Greensboro is very fortunate," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot Police Accountability Board releases inaugural report
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Talbot Police Accountability Board releases inaugural report

 January 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 749
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Police Accountability Board's first year was marked by challenges in adjusting to citizen oversight in policing, but "reluctant confidence" from law enforcement is believed to be growing, the board said in its inaugural report.The annual report, submitted to the Talbot County Council on Dec. 20, 2023, outlined the board's yearlong struggle in establishing a rapport with the county's four law enforcement agencies, which voiced concerns with the state-mandated legislation that created the board and a committee to review complaints of police misconduct.
Trends in call volume, arrests, struggles with recruitment and retention, use of force and police-community relations within each of the county's law enforcement agencies were analyzed in the report.
The board also asked the County Council to consider a number of recommendations to improve police accountability in Talbot County.
However, the board said most of the concerns from local police agencies centered on the Administrative Charging Committee, which is tasked with determining if officers should face administrative charges following a police agency's own investigation into the allegations. The committee also recommends appropriate discipline.
The committee is composed of five county residents and is helmed by Mitchell Ettinger, who also serves as the chairman of the Police Accountability Board.
Gaining the confidence of the county's law enforcement agencies proved to be the Administrative Charging Committee's great challenge last year, the report said.
Police questioned the wisdom of citizen oversight, the breadth of the committee's role and a lack of experience in law enforcement, which could translate to a gap in understanding the tasks and competing interests police officers face daily, according to the report.
In 2023, 15 complaints were submitted to the Administrative Charging Committee for review: 10 from the Sheriff's Office and five from the Easton Police Department.
Twelve complaints resulted in officer exonerations or were ruled as unfounded charges. Three complaints ended with varying disciplinary actions — two of which involved disagreements on recommended dispositions between the Administrative Charging Committee and the officers' respective agencies, the report said.
In one case, a Sheriff's Office deputy was administratively charged for undue use of force. According to the report, the deputy deployed pepper spray in an attempt to stop a juvenile who was improperly operating a mini-bike on the road.
The Administrative Charging Committee found it was unreasonable for the deputy to do so and imposed charges. The committee recommended two days' loss of pay, which the deputy accepted, according to the report.
The Sheriff's Office also revised its policy to clarify that deploying pepper spray on a moving motorist is inappropriate.
Use of force reports were a particular focus of the Police Accountability Board in 2023, according to its report. Law enforcement agencies now submit those reports quarterly.
The board's report said given the extensive interaction between police and the public, it was "remarkable" that officers only resorted to use of force on 10 occasions — six times by the sheriff's office, three times by the Easton Police Department and once by the St. Michaels Police Department.
Another case was heard against an Easton officer for unbecoming conduct off-duty, along with administrative failures to report conduct and a subpoena to testify. The allegations in that case were sustained, with the committee recommending two days' loss of pay or leave and a letter of reprimand.
The committee heard a third complaint against a sheriff's office deputy for speeding, which the deputy acknowledged. The deputy received a letter of reprimand.
Despite a year of building relationships, some distrust still lingers between the Administrative Charging Committee and local law enforcement.
"...The LEAs most certainly will maintain that they did not (and do not) need citizen oversight to exercise proper review and disposition of citizen complaints," the report said.
Though work remains to be done, the board believes the Administrative Charging Committee has established credibility with police through its "well-reasoned and supported" opinions on each of the complaints.
Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey acknowledged the lack of consensus between law enforcement and the committee on some case dispositions, but he said there was space for those disagreements.
"I think that we all want to be going in the same direction, and that is to have professional law enforcement in Talbot County," he said. "I've never gotten a sense from either entity, the PAB or the ACC, that they're looking to do in law enforcement like has been the narrative nationally for a few years of some groups — not all groups."
"We understand that it's important to have a rule of law in our community, and we just want it to be done well," Lowrey continued. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on police accountability, use of force, and community relations, which directly relate to public safety. While it involves local government structures, the core content centers on law enforcement oversight and public safety initiatives.

title: Federalsburg carport fire causes estimated $125K in damage

Federalsburg carport fire causes estimated $125K in damage

 FEDERALSBURG — A fire that originated in an attached carport caused an estimated $125,000 in damages to a Federalsburg home Friday, Jan. 5.Forty firefighters, primarily from the Denton Volunteer Fire Company, responded to the blaze at 26955 Iron Gate Road shortly before 2 p.m. Friday.

title: Queenstown man charged in Centreville shooting
author: Staff Writer
content:
Queenstown man charged in Centreville shooting

 January 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Crime 
 
 201
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Police have charged a 17-year-old male as an adult in connection with a weapons discharge incident Nov. 22 in the 100 block of Little Kidwell Avenue in Centreville.According to a statement released by the Centreville Police Department, a warrant was served on the young man at a Del Rhodes, Queenstown residence on Jan. 3 without incidence.
He was charged with attempted second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment, possession of a regulated firearm under the age of 21, and use of a firearm during a felony or violent crime.
During a search of the residence, a handgun was seized as evidence.
Police Chief Robert Hobbs confirmed the suspect and victim were related. The victim, an adult male, sustained only superficial injuries from the incident. He was taken to the hospital and released the same evening, Hobbs said.
The man charged is being held pending trial. His name is not yet being released as investigation surrounding this incident continues.
Members of the Maryland State Police, Centreville Police Department, Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff, US Marshals Service, Queen Anne's County Narcotics Task Force, Maryland State Police Crime Lab as well as the Queen Anne's County State's Attorney's Office are continuing the investigation.

title: Eastern Shore legislators prioritizing health care, public safety this session
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Eastern Shore legislators prioritizing health care, public safety this session

 January 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: General Assembly 
 
 909
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — As the 446th session of the Maryland General Assembly kicks off, Eastern Shore legislators are focused on health care, public safety and the implications of the budget shortfall.Sen. Johnny Mautz, Sen. Stephen Hershey and Del. Tom Hutchinson all said the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's new regional medical center in Easton is a top priority for Eastern Shore legislators this session.
"Making sure all the pieces are in place for that project to move forward," Mautz said. "It's long overdue to be replaced and upgraded."
Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said there are multiple hurdles to achieving this, including state regulatory approvals and other "loose ends." He said the University of Maryland Medical System has made it clear that a new medical center in Easton is also their top priority.
"Which is a huge help," Mautz said. "However, making sure that everything else is in place ... it's a huge undertaking."
Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) said that in creating an Aging & Wellness Center in Kent County and a freestanding medical facility in Dorchester County, the "spokes" are being put in place when it comes to health care on the Eastern Shore.
"But now we need the hub," he said. "And so what we are advocating for down here in Annapolis — and I've spoken with the governor about it — is we need to finalize that final piece on how we deliver health care services in the Mid-Shore region."
Hutchinson (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), who is on the Maryland House Health and Government Operations Committee, said he is sponsoring a number of bills that will make sure health care facilities have additional resources. He said he also plans to support bills related to better access to mental health care on the Shore.
Del. Chris Adams (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), who is the chair of the Eastern Shore Delegation, called public safety a "top-line issue" for this session.
On the Eastern Shore, Adams said that it has become more difficult to hire and retain law enforcement officers.
"I think it's because we've made this career path so difficult and so unclear about what the role is and what the responsibilities are," he said, adding that the job of law enforcers are to serve and protect.
In 2022, state legislators passed bills to limit what charges children under the age of 13 face. Adams said this legislation is a piece of this public safety issue.
"(Juvenile justice) has been an incremental step that has been, shall I say, just anti-police," he said.
Mautz said there are different approaches to amending the juvenile justice legislation. He said one approach is to look at enforcement and another is to look at services that can prevent children from engaging in criminal activity.
"You can have all the services in the world, but if you don't have the deterring enforcement, the services aren't going to do any good," he said. "You've got to have both, and you really need to start with enforcement. I mean there's got to be a rule of law."
Hutchinson, who said he thinks the existing juvenile reform laws need to be modified, has spearheaded a group of different stakeholders in Dorchester and Wicomico counties to discuss the the juvenile reform laws and its effects.
"I got to the point that I invited the Secretary of Juvenile Services to come, where we could express our frustrations," he said.
Hutchinson said it will be interesting to see what the pushback will be on these laws. He said that some members of the General Assembly feel that the laws haven't been in place for long enough to amend them.
"Me, along with many, many other members of the delegation, completely disagree with that," he said. "We need to address it now."
When it comes to finances, the state is facing a projected $761 million budget shortfall for FY2025.
Adams said he fears that tax increases are coming. He said that in his nearly 10 years as a legislator, this might be the first year he votes against the budget.
Hershey said dealing with the budget is a priority this session.
"We're going to have to find some ways that we can cut spending and pass a budget that doesn't include increasing taxes," he said.
Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) said the legislature needs to be careful how it spends money.
"I like to prioritize the necessities first," he said. "If you've got extra money after your primary duties are taken care of, then you can address some of that."
Jacobs said he has concerns with funding for the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a statewide plan to increase public education funding, improve student outcomes and improve the quality of public education.
He said meeting the Blueprint requirements will be especially hard on his home county, Kent County, adding that a one-size-fits-all approach is not going to work.
"I am not at all in favor of one-size-fits-all anything," he said. "Because we are so diverse in this state."
Jacobs said that counties should not have to face raising taxes "to a ridiculous level" or cutting services in order to fund the Blueprint.
"And some of that is potentially on the line right now," he said. "That's what's very concerning."
Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico) said she understands that some jurisdictions are struggling to fund the Blueprint.
"I know what that looks like," she said. "Because they can't get any more property taxes out of the citizens, because in areas such as Crisfield, they don't have anymore property to sell. It's flooded. So, it's a struggle." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Eastern Shore legislators prioritizing public safety measures, including law enforcement challenges and juvenile justice reforms, alongside health care initiatives. While health care is a significant component, the repeated emphasis on public safety policies and legislative actions related to law enforcement and juvenile justice makes 'Public Safety' the primary topic.

title: Number of Cambridge homicides down in 2023
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Number of Cambridge homicides down in 2023

 January 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 743
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — There were less than half as many homicides in Cambridge in 2023 compared to the year before.In 2022, Cambridge saw seven homicides. In 2023, it saw three.
Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd, who was sworn in as chief in January of 2023, called the difference progress. He credits the decrease in homicides to a few different things — namely, how the department polices and its partnerships with other agencies.
One of the police department's top priorities last year was community-oriented policing. For Todd, that meant being a part of the community that the department services.
He said getting out into neighborhoods and creating programs like neighborhood watches can help build relationships and trust in communities and, hopefully, reduce crime.
Along with prioritizing community policing, Todd said that the department has tried to be proactive in addressing gun violence and aggressive assaults. He said CPD is now taking an average of one gun off the street each week, "well more than double" the average in 2022.
Todd also stressed the importance of working with other agencies and working with the community. He said that being a part of the Dorchester County Task Force, getting support from Cambridge City Council and focusing on community-oriented policing has all made a difference.
"I think a lot of people have come to the table in the last year," he said.
Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout said this decrease in the number of homicides in Cambridge is a significant one.
"Every shooting that we can stop is a step in the right direction," he said.
Rideout said he thinks CPD's community policing efforts are part of the reason for that success.
"It's just started, but I think they're building a trust within the community that just did not exist before now," he said.
Lieutenant Kyle Clark with Maryland State Police's Homicide Unit said that although he can't say for certain why the number of homicides has gone down in Cambridge, he can say that there has been a focus on collaboration between agencies.
"We do concentrate on a lot of collaborative efforts with other units within the State Police and also allied agencies," he said, specifying the use of task forces, gang units and gun units. "And those are all tools that we use to combat the crime in any city."
Clark said that he would estimate about 50% of the homicides in the last two years in Cambridge have been gang-related. He said that in addressing gang violence, MSP, along with other agencies at all levels, do "everything and anything" to combat the gang violence.
Todd said CPD is working to identify gang members and groups that are "constantly harassing" residents in different Cambridge neighborhoods. He said they have worked with the different agencies within the Dorchester County Task Force as well as federal agencies to identify who is bringing in handguns and where they are coming from.
"The partnership's been great with the Task Force and Maryland State Police," he said. "The Homicide Unit with Maryland State Police — they handle all of our homicides. So we work hand in hand together. And that's what it's going to take."
Todd said he has noticed gun violence and homicide rates begin to fall throughout the country.
Specific data on other crime rates in Cambridge should be released to the public in the next couple of weeks, Todd said.
Rideout said early intervention is important when it comes to crime prevention. Rideout was recently at a meeting about a flag football initiative by CPD and the Maryland Department of Juvenile Services.
"It was really an exciting possibility of where we can really start focusing, not only on the crime itself, but on the prevention and early intervention," he said.
Rideout added that engaging children in education and outside activities, such as programming at the YMCA or Boys and Girls Club, can have a positive effect.
Going into 2024, CPD's goals include continuing to build its manpower, focusing on data-driven technology and "patrolling with a purpose."
Todd said "patrolling with a purpose" means putting officers in the areas where crimes are occurring on the specific days and at the specific times they have been occurring.
He said that residents can also expect to see more data from CPD in the new year, including heat maps of where crimes are occurring.
Regarding homicides, Rideout said the downward trend is good, but added that the work doesn't stop here.
"What we have to do is continue working on it and engage the community in working on it to hopefully keep these numbers down," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on homicide statistics, police strategies, community-oriented policing, and crime prevention efforts in Cambridge, directly relating to public safety initiatives. While local government entities are mentioned, the core content centers on safety and crime reduction rather than general governance.

title: Wind, rain and flood hit the Shore
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Wind, rain and flood hit the Shore

 January 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 219
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A windy winter storm closed the Bay Bridge for six hours Tuesday night and brought widespread coastal flooding to the Eastern Shore.The surge covered docks and left a parked car by the tennis courts in Oxford stranded.
A coastal flood advisory for Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's, Talbot and Caroline Counties continued through Wednesday.
Many homes lost electricity on Tuesday night and had to resort to candles and flashlights. Many lost cell phone coverage for the night. Telecom workers donned their rain gear to fix the cut lines by dawn.
Oxford had orange danger road cones up near Pope's Tavern next to the tennis courts Tuesday morning, where water poured across the street into Town Creek. But the area was still passable by car.
Town Manager Cheryl Lewis was on the scene and recommended those driving through get the undercarriage of their cars cleaned to avoid the negative effects of driving through salty water.
The water was clearing over Oxford Road and underneath in the drainage system.
St. Michaels also saw significant flooding.
The National Weather Service is predicting some more windy rainy days on Friday and Saturday. As far as the marine forecast, storm force winds are likely Friday night and gale force winds are likely Saturday through Saturday night. Dangerous seas will come up 8 to 12 feet Friday night and Saturday.

title: Second trial begins for Cambridge man charged in fatal shooting
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Second trial begins for Cambridge man charged in fatal shooting

 January 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 492
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Dec. 8, 2022, was a routine night for Lory Eugene Fields. Heading out of his home on High Street in Cambridge, he was only set to be gone for a few hours before returning.But that night, what was a consistent routine for Fields was permanently disrupted, said Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard, who is prosecuting a case involving Fields' death with Senior Assistant State's Attorney Ella Disharoon.
Around 10 p.m., officers from the Cambridge Police Department found Fields, 69, laying in the front yard of his own home. He had been shot once in the head at close range and robbed of the keys to his Chrysler 300, Leonard said.
Though the keys were missing, the car wasn't; it remained parked in front of the home at 718 High Street. And 24 hours later, police found the person believed to be responsible for Fields' death sitting right in the driver's seat.
That return to the scene was how police caught Tramelle Williams, Leonard said.
Williams, 23, was arrested that evening following a foot pursuit on nearby Lincoln Terrace. After he attempted to flee, a Cambridge police officer fired, shooting Williams in the leg.
After being taken to a hospital for treatment of his injuries, Williams was charged with first- and second-degree murder, assault, armed robbery and a firearms offense in connection to Fields' death.
To Leonard, testimony from Maryland State Police homicide investigators, officers involved in Williams' arrest, a medical examiner and crime scene and ballistics analysts would put the picture together, rendering a guilty verdict from the jury.
But to defense attorneys Michelle Moodispaw and Stephanie DeLang, a lack of witnesses, coupled with the limitations of DNA and ballistic evidence, would paint a different image — one in which Williams would be found not guilty.
In her opening statement to the jury Tuesday, Moodispaw emphasized the lack of testimony from witnesses.
No one saw the shooting. There was no video surveillance that captured the shooting either, only audio that seemed to be consistent gunfire from a city camera on a different street, police would testify.
And although a 9mm gun was found by Williams when he fell, crime scene processing of the gun and Fields' car keys only showed that Williams couldn't be excluded as a contributor to the DNA evidence, she said.
"The question about what happened on Dec. 8, 2022, will remain unanswered," Moodispaw said.
The shooting on High Street wasn't the only one police responded to that night. Just three hours earlier, 24-year-old Taijay Brian Daniels was found dead from multiple gunshot wounds on Pleasant Street.
Williams was also charged in connection to Daniels' death. In December, a jury found Williams guilty of first- and second-degree murder, assault, armed robbery and multiple firearms offenses in the fatal shooting.
Multiple witnesses testified at the outset of Williams' trial Tuesday, including Fields' daughter and significant other and law enforcement officers who responded to the scene.
Additional law enforcement witnesses and forensic analysts are expected to testify. A verdict is anticipated Friday. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal trial involving a fatal shooting and subsequent legal proceedings, which directly relates to public safety concerns. While it involves local law enforcement and judicial processes, the core focus is on a violent crime and its implications for community safety.

title: Moore calls for accountability, rehabilitation
author: KIERSTEN HACKER Capital News Service
content:
Moore calls for accountability, rehabilitation

 January 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KIERSTEN HACKER Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 487
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Gov. Wes Moore said he expects "robust debates" about juvenile justice in coming weeks — and that his administration will be an "active participant" trying to balance rehabilitation with cracking down on crime."The hallmark of what I hope to see in any juvenile justice legislation that's going to make it to my desk can be summarized in one word: accountability," the governor said. "I believe in rehabilitation, but I will not tolerate lawlessness."
Moore's comments came Tuesday, a day before the opening of the 2024 Maryland General Assembly, in a press conference devoted to his legislative priorities regarding public safety. He said he plans to press for three measures aimed at promoting victim's compensation, expanding apprenticeships in law enforcement jobs and preventing firearm violence.
But he also mused aloud on the issue of juvenile justice, at a time when state Republican officials are calling for passage of tougher crime policies — and specifically for reversing recent reforms to the youth legal system. House Republican Leader Jason Buckel, R-Allegany, recently vowed to toughen up what he called Maryland's "soft-on-crime policies."
Moore said Tuesday he will demand accountability for young offenders who are repeatedly violating the law, or who use a handgun to threaten the safety of others.
While Moore acknowledged the coming debate over juvenile crime this session, he stressed the importance of supporting communities and the advocates working at the grassroots level to prevent violence.
He said he supports lengthening probation for juveniles found guilty of certain crimes to allow for more time for rehabilitation programs. He also backs moving more crimes related to illegal guns from misdemeanors to felonies.
"It takes a village to raise a child, and it will take a village to build safer communities," Moore said.
The legislative criminal justice proposals Moore announced do not address the treatment of juveniles, but rather focus on other things.
He proposed establishing a firearm prevention center based on recommendations from the Safer States Initiative launched by Vice President Kamala Harris.
The statewide office would work in partnership with the White House, taking an "all of government" approach to effective prevention and intervention policies or programs, according to Rob Wilcox, deputy director of Biden's Office of Gun Violence Prevention. Maryland would be the first state to establish such a center, said Wilcox, who spoke at Moore's press conference.
"It's a critical step to focus investments and drive the strategies that we know will save lives," Wilcox said.
According to Moore, 75% of homicides in Maryland are committed with a gun. He said he considers it not only a public safety issue but a public health issue. He pledged to get illegal guns "off of our streets."
To help wage that fight, Moore hopes to recruit more people into law enforcement and public safety with a bill to promote apprenticeships.
"We need officers who reflect the diversity of our great state," Secretary of Labor Portia Wu said, "and we need them to come from the neighborhoods they serve." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Investigation continues after children die in Perryville home
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Investigation continues after children die in Perryville home

 January 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 264
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PERRYVILLE — An investigation into the "circumstances surrounding the suspicious deaths" of two children — a boy, 10, and a girl, 14 — continued on Tuesday night after the siblings were found unresponsive inside their Perryville home earlier that day, according to the Maryland State Police.Troopers assigned to the agency's North East Barrack responded to the residence in the 600 block of Cole Street at approximately 1:20 p.m. Tuesday to assist Perryville Police Department officers with what law enforcement officials described as the "cardiac arrest of two juveniles," police reported.
Paramedics were "attempting emergency medical care" on the children when troopers arrived, police said. Paramedics later pronounced the boy and the teenaged girl dead at the scene, police added.
Their bodies were transported to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner in Baltimore, where autopsies will be performed to determine the "cause and manner" of their deaths, according to police.
"The preliminary investigation indicates the sister of the juveniles came home and found both children unconscious inside the home. Investigators determined the two juveniles were brother and sister living in the house with their mother," an MSP spokesperson outlined, before noting, "There was no indication of violence in the area surrounding the location where the juveniles were found."
Investigators with MSP's Criminal Enforcement Division responded to the scene to lead the investigation, police said. Agents with Cecil County Child Protective Services also responded to the residence, police added.
"A search warrant was obtained for the house. Crime scene technicians from the Maryland State Police processed the area and a search of the premises was conducted," the spokesperson reported.

title: Former Cecil County deputy gets one year in misconduct case
author: CARL HAMILTON cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Former Cecil County deputy gets one year in misconduct case

 January 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CARL HAMILTON cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 1088
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CECIL COUNTY — A former Cecil County Sheriff's Office deputy who took and sent sexually explicit photos and videos of himself and two women, including one picture that he took of his genitals — while on duty, in uniform and inside agency headquarters — received a one-year jail term on Wednesday, according to the Maryland Office of the State Prosecutor.Visiting Retired Kent County Circuit Court Judge Paul M. Bowman imposed a five-year sentence on the defendant — Elkton resident Kyle Logan Thomas, 28 — for misconduct in office and then suspended four years of the penalty, prosecutors said. Bowman also imposed a suspended one-year sentence on Thomas for visual surveillance with prurient intent, prosecutors added.
In addition, the judge ordered Thomas to serve three years of supervised probation after completing his one-year jail term, prosecutors reported.
"The defendant's conduct is best described as depraved, sadistic, and vicious," Bowman reportedly remarked from the bench while sentencing Thomas.
The sentence imposed by Bowman matched a recommendation made by Assistant State Prosecutor Abigail E. Ticse, who handled the criminal case with Deputy State Prosecutor Sarah R. David.
After Wednesday's sentencing, Maryland State Prosecutor Charlton T. Howard III said, "I am proud of our office's efforts to build a strong case against a law enforcement officer who was sworn to protect and serve, not to abuse and traumatize, the residents of Cecil County. We appreciate the Court's sentence and believe that it demonstrates to the residents of Cecil County and the entire State of Maryland that real consequences await people who commit crimes such as these, especially by those that hold positions of public trust."
Thomas had pleaded guilty to those two charges in October, as part of a plea deal in which prosecutors agreed to dismiss nine related charges against him, according to court records and Cecil Whig archives.
In August, two months earlier, Thomas was charged with misconduct in office, witness retaliation, visual surveillance with prurient intent, revenge porn, and distribution of obscene material. Thomas was not arrested, but rather was served charging papers.
Thomas had worked as a sworn Cecil County deputy for approximately two and a half years — from February 2021 until July 18, 2023 when the agency "separated Deputy Kyle Thomas from employment" amid an internal investigation into the allegations made against him, according to Capt. Michael Holmes, a CCSO spokesman. Thomas had been on suspension, per protocol, during his last nine months with the sheriff's office after the agency received a citizen complaint on Oct. 28, 2022 regarding his purported off-duty and on-duty misconduct, he noted.
As part of an overview in the charging document, prosecutors explained, "Thomas, who was married, frequently utilized Snapchat to communicate and exchange photos and videos with other users because the communications or other exchanges typically disappear."
Thomas had a romantic relationship with a woman, who ended that relationship in August 2021, prosecutors reported.
"Throughout their relationship, Thomas shared photographs and videos with Victim I, primarily via Snapchat, depicting Thomas engaged in sexual acts," according to prosecutors.
At approximately 12:20 p.m. on June 16, 2021 — while on duty amid a shift that went from 7:45 a.m. to 7 p.m. that day — Thomas shared a video with VICTIM I using the "My Eyes Only" album on Snapchat and the image "depicted Thomas in his CCSO uniform, in the CCSO building, holding, touching his exposed penis," prosecutors reported.
The woman attempted to end her relationship with Thomas several times and, in response, according to court records, Thomas "made verbal threats" to her.
In August 2021, VICTIM I attempted to cease all contact with Thomas, prosecutors reported. After an interaction between VICTIM 1 and Thomas in October 2022, VICTIM I and others made complaints about Thomas to the CCSO, which spurred the internal investigation that resulted in agency officials suspending Thomas, according to prosecutors.
In late October 2022, Thomas learned that CCSO was investigating him and that VICTIM I had been interviewed by agency investigators and that "a copy of the video that he shared with VICTIM I on Snapchat had been provided to the CCSO," according to prosecutors.
In response, Thomas contacted VICTIM I several times at her place of employment — a doctor's office — on two days in November 2022 and requested to make a complaint against her, prompting her to obtain a final peace order against him, prosecutors said.
Prosecutors reported that Thomas went to a Cecil County District Court commissioner and requested that VICTIM 1 be charged with sharing the "video of Thomas in his uniform exposing his penis to her husband and Thomas' employer, the CCSO." VICTIM I had provided that video to CCSO in October 2022 while making her formal complaint against Thomas.
The Cecil County State's Attorney's Office, however, dismissed the charges that Thomas had filed against VICTIM I, prosecutors reported. The MOSP criminal information filed against Thomas accused Thomas of taking retaliatory action against VICTIM I.
Prosecutors reported that Thomas became "engaged in a sexual relationship" with a second woman in 2019 and that she ended their relationship in May, some four years later.
They further reported that, throughout their relationship, Thomas took videos and photos of himself and the woman engaged in sexual acts and that he took those images without her consent.
The woman tried to end their relationship several times and, in response, Thomas sent videos of himself and the woman engaged in sexual acts to her, prosecutors said. Thomas also threatened to send videos of the woman engaged in sexual acts to other individuals or post the videos online, prosecutors added.
In July 2022, VICTIM 2 told Thomas to delete the photos and videos that he had on his phone, according to prosecutors. But Thomas told VICTIM 2 that he couldn't because he was anxious to post them on social media someday "maybe when you get pregnant or married," prosecutors reported.
From April 2022 through January, Thomas sent dozens of videos of himself and VICTIM 2 engaged in sexual acts to other Snapchat users without VICTIM 2's consent or knowledge, according to prosecutors. Thomas asked random Snapchat users to watch the videos, prosecutors said. Thomas also paid several Snapchat users to watch the videos," prosecutors added.
When the Cecil County Sheriff's Office suspended Thomas on Oct. 28, 2022, agency officials served him a non-contact order forbidding Thomas from interacting with several specified people involved in the administrative investigation, including the second woman, prosecutors reported. Thomas refused to sign the non-contact order, according to prosecutors.
Thomas contacted the second woman "in person, through text messages and on social media applications, including Snapchat" from Nov. 12, 2022 through May 4, 2023, prosecutors reported. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a former law enforcement officer's criminal misconduct involving explicit content distribution and abuse of position, leading to legal consequences. While involving a local government employee, the core focus is on public safety concerns related to law enforcement integrity and criminal behavior.

title: Cambridge man found guilty of murder in second fatal shooting
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Cambridge man found guilty of murder in second fatal shooting

 January 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 417
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Dorchester County jury found a Cambridge man guilty Thursday of all counts in a fatal December 2022 shooting, marking the second killing the man was convicted of in the last month.The jury found Tramelle Williams, 23, guilty of first- and second-degree murder, assault, armed robbery and a firearms offense in connection to the death of Lory Fields.
Fields, 69, left his home on High Street on the evening of Dec. 8, 2022, heading out for a few hours before returning.
But what was a routine evening for Fields turned into tragedy.
Around 10 p.m., officers from the Cambridge Police Department found Fields laying in the front yard of his own home. He had been shot once in the head at close range and robbed of the keys to his Chrysler 300, Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard said at the outset of the trial Tuesday.
Though the keys were missing, the car wasn't. It remained parked in front of the home at 718 High Street.
The shooting on High Street wasn't the only one police responded to that night. Just three hours earlier, 24-year-old Taijay Brian Daniels was found dead from multiple gunshot wounds on Pleasant Street, one of which was fired at close range.
Twenty-four hours later, police saw the person believed to be responsible for the shooting around Fields' car.
Police approached Williams, but he attempted to flee.
A foot pursuit ensued on nearby Lincoln Terrace. Williams reportedly brandished a handgun, police said.
After he attempted to flee, a Cambridge police officer fired, shooting Williams in the leg. A handgun was found by Williams where he fell.
Fields' car keys and Daniels' phone were also recovered from Williams that night, police testified.
Williams was transported to TidalHealth Peninsula Regional in Salisbury for treatment of non-life-threatening injuries.
He was charged with first-degree murder in connection to both fatal shootings. In December, a jury convicted Williams of all counts related to Daniels' death.
Surveillance footage and forensic evidence linked Williams to the two killings.
A presentence investigation was ordered by Dorchester Circuit Judge William Jones, who presided over both trials. No sentencing date has been set yet.
Williams faces a maximum of life in prison without the possibility of parole for each first-degree murder conviction.
In a press release posted to Facebook, Leonard thanked the juries for their time and deliberations in the cases.
"While the senseless killings ... cannot be undone, it is the State's hope that these verdicts will give the families and loved ones of the victims a small sense of peace moving forward," the post stated.

title: Former Cambridge planning and zoning director indicted in Annapolis hit-and-run
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Former Cambridge planning and zoning director indicted in Annapolis hit-and-run

 January 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 305
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Former City of Cambridge Planning and Zoning Director John Steven Kaii-Ziegler was indicted Jan. 12 in Anne Arundel County in connection to a fatal hit-and-run last January.Kaii-Ziegler, 64, of Annapolis, is facing a number of charges, including negligent manslaughter, criminally negligent manslaughter, leaving the scene of an accident involving a death, driving under the influence of alcohol, driving while impaired, reckless driving and negligent driving, according to a news release from the Annapolis Police Department.
The charges stemmed from the fatal accident, which occurred shortly after 10 p.m. Jan. 24, 2023, on Hilltop Lane in Annapolis.
City police officers arriving on scene discovered that the victim, identified as 74-year-old Zarko Peruza, was struck and killed while riding his bicycle on Hilltop Lane.
Peruza was struck by an unidentified vehicle that left the scene, police said.
Police developed Kaii-Ziegler as a suspect with help from concerned citizens who reported a suspicious vehicle parked in their neighborhood the next morning, according to the news release.
Kaii-Ziegler turned himself in to the Annapolis Police Department on Thursday, Jan. 18, police said. He is currently being held without bond at the Jennifer Road Detention Center in Annapolis.
Kaii-Ziegler resigned from his position with the City of Cambridge on Tuesday, Jan. 16, according to City Manager Tom Carroll.
"I'd like to thank the lead investigators on this case, Ofc. First Class Bruce Ko and Lt. Kevin Krauss," Annapolis Police Chief Ed Jackson said. "This is another example of the Annapolis Police Department's commitment to working hard to ensure the family of the victim receives closure."
"We are committed as a department to hold reckless and dangerous drivers accountable for their actions," he said. "We are asking all motorists coming to Annapolis to drive to survive. We want other drivers and pedestrians and cyclists to be safe as they travel the streets of our fair city."

title: Worried by spikes in youth crime, Maryland lawmakers close in on new fixes to the system
author: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service
content:
Worried by spikes in youth crime, Maryland lawmakers close in on new fixes to the system

 January 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 602
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Almost two years after passing landmark youth justice reform, Maryland lawmakers are scrutinizing its impact on young offenders — and questioning whether they've done enough to make things better.The 2022 reforms were meant to help more young offenders avoid incarceration and get on the path to rehabilitation. But with spikes in auto thefts, carjackings and handgun violations by youth around the state, lawmakers on both sides of the political aisle are thinking about refining and updating the reforms this year.
Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City) said there is an agreement taking shape among lawmakers who want to smooth the process for referring young people for rehabilitative services. State agencies have the resources to help kids and families, Ferguson said, but a lack of cooperation sometimes gets in the way.
He said one thing in need of improvement is the Child in Need of Supervision process, which lets law enforcement refer young people to Juvenile Services for assessment and programs when they get into trouble.
"What happened over the last few years is that the CINS process never led to actual conversations (or) collaborations amongst agencies that have various resources to surround the child with those supports," Ferguson said this week.
In their quest to change the law, lawmakers are motivated both by complaints from constituents and by a sense that youth crime is on the rise. While youth violent crime arrests fell 16.5% overall between fiscal years 2022 and 2023, according to a Juvenile Services report last year, carjackings increased by 85.4% and handgun violations rose almost 220%. Auto theft grew 64.6%, doubling between 2022 and 2023.
Some Republicans blame the reform itself, and some prosecutors are joining them in raising concerns about the law. Among other changes, the 2022 reforms set 13 as the minimum age for a young person to be sent to juvenile court — except in cases of violent crime, where the minimum age is 10 — and prohibited police from interrogating youth without letting the child consult an attorney.
But Democrats are more interested in refining the system, and they're engaged in discussions that could produce a more sweeping set of improvements in the coming days.
Gov. Wes Moore's office is also involved in talks and expects that like-minded lawmakers may introduce legislation aimed at making improvements to the current law.
Sen. Jill Carter (D-Baltimore City), one of several lawmakers concerned about juvenile justice this session, said she wants to see police and prosecutors work together to use the tools the legislature has already given them.
"I think that the most effective thing that could happen is that law enforcement and prosecutors could work within the law, stop resisting it and work more collaboratively, and if they come up with suggestions, they should be data-driven," Carter said.
Several lawmakers defended the 2022 reforms in a press conference with the Maryland Youth Justice Coalition this week, and urged law enforcement and state's attorneys to use the tools it set up.
Del. Charlotte Crutchfield (D-Montgomery) said that the reform legislation is "still in its infancy."
"We know that there are things that need to be put in place to ensure that it continues and that our youth are well taken care of under this legislation," Crutchfield said.
Prosecutors say it's not that simple. Juvenile Services officers sometimes see six or seven complaints regarding the same young person before prosecutors are notified, Montgomery County State's Attorney John McCarthy said during a recent Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee.
"Let us, as state's attorneys, have what we had before," McCarthy said, "the ability to have those matters referred to us so that we may put a second additional set of eyes on it." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Maryland lawmakers addressing rising youth crime rates and reviewing juvenile justice reforms, directly relating to public safety concerns. While local government actions are mentioned, the core issue is crime prevention and public safety policy.
