title: Democrats say no big changes to cannabis law
author: ANGELIQUE GINGRAS Capital News Service
content:
Democrats say no big changes to cannabis law

 January 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANGELIQUE GINGRAS Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 445
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Republicans are pushing to repeal a controversial Maryland law that prohibits police from pulling over and searching drivers simply because they smell of marijuana, but Democratic leaders say they aren't interested in dramatic changes to the state's cannabis legislation this year.Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City) says Democrats are only considering what they refer to as "improvements" to Maryland's cannabis law, following its legalization for adult use last year.
"I think we're going to have a cannabis bill this year that sort of does some — I don't want to call it cleanup — but adjustments to the system that we passed last year," Ferguson said. "I don't think you'll see major changes to the program, but implementation adjustments."
In 2023, the Maryland General Assembly passed the new "odor" law hoping to prevent unwarranted search and seizure against people of color, according to members of Maryland's Legislative Black Caucus, who were proponents of the bill. With Democrats controlling both chambers of the General Assembly, their opposition to repeal makes it unlikely.
But critics of the law — Republicans in particular — say the law is making it harder for police to do their jobs.
"The irony is, if we see someone chugging a beer, police can pull them over," said Sen. William Folden (R-Frederick), a police officer who serves in the legislature. He says the law potentially takes away probable cause for police when "there is a crime occurring, just because you're saying, well, you're not allowed to use your nose anymore."
After voters approved a ballot referendum legalizing cannabis for adult use, the General Assembly passed legislation in 2023 setting up licensing and taxation as well as other rules.
Those laws were meant to address "the harms of the past when it comes to criminalization of cannabis," Del. Jheanelle Wilkins (D-Montgomery), chair of the Black Caucus and sponsor of the odor law, told Capital News Service.
Maryland's odor law isn't uncommon. In fact, several states that have legalized cannabis have said its smell doesn't warrant a police search of a vehicle, or they're considering such a provision.
"The public clearly wanted marijuana legalized, fine," said Sen. Jack Bailey (R-Calvert, St. Mary's), "but we shouldn't do away with the requirements."
But top Democrats said they are only considering small alterations, including adjustments to the duties and makeup of the Maryland Cannabis Administration and related authorities.
"It was hugely complicated, lots of moving pieces for the cannabis bill last year," Ferguson said. "And as we've been implementing, there's little things that have to be worked through."
Wilkins says the goal of Democrats and the Black Caucus is "working closely with the administration to make sure that our intentions of the bill are carried out." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Maryland's cannabis law and its implications for law enforcement practices, specifically regarding vehicle searches based on marijuana odor. title: Delaware man extradited on carjacking, shooting charges
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Delaware man extradited on carjacking, shooting charges

 January 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Crime 
 
 263
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Police extradited a Delaware man on Monday in connection to a carjacking and shooting in Easton last July.Tehron D. West, 39, is charged with attempted second-degree murder, first-degree assault, second-degree assault, reckless endangerment, firearm use in a violent crime, motor vehicle theft, illegal possession of a firearm, firearm possession with a felony conviction, intoxicated endangerment and theft between $100 and $1,500.
West was later released to the custody of the Talbot County Detention Center, according to police.
On July 16, at approximately 12:10 a.m., Easton police officers were dispatched to Lynbrook Court in Easton in reference to a reported carjacking. As officers were responding, an update was provided by dispatch that shots were fired at the scene.
As officers arrived, they met a female victim.They noticed that her vehicle had two bullet holes on the driver side door, just below the window.
The victim told officers that she was having an argument with West. West had been drinking, and the victim was preventing him from driving away intoxicated. West got into the victim's vehicle, pulled a handgun out and shot at least twice at the victim while she was sitting in her second vehicle.
He was served with an arrest warrant for attempted second-degree murder on Jan. 22. Police said he shot bullet holes in his girlfriend's car before fleeing in the victim's car. She was not injured.
At approximately 3:14 a.m. the same day, officers were notified that the Virginia State Police had stopped West in Accomack County, Virginia, operating the stolen vehicle. West was taken into custody without incident, according to the police report.

title: 40 vehicle crash closes Bay Bridge for nearly six hours
author: Staff Writer
content:
40 vehicle crash closes Bay Bridge for nearly six hours

 January 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Emergency Notice 
 
 260
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — A multi-vehicle incident on the westbound span of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge had travel shut down for several hours Saturday morning. Numerous patients were transported, some with serious injuries. No fatalities were reported.Although yet to be determined, heavy fog is believed to be a factor in the mass casualty incident. Maryland Transportation Police dispatch received initial calls at 8 a.m. Saturday morning.
Investigators with the MDTA Police Collision Reconstruction Unit preliminarily believe 23 vehicles were involved in a chain-reaction crash on the westbound span. Additionally, investigators believe approximately 20 additional vehicles were involved in a series of secondary crashes.
According to Sgt. Brady McCormick with the Transportation Authority, two patients were transported to local hospitals with serious injuries. Eleven additional patients were also transported to local hospitals. None of the injuries are believed to be life-threatening, McCormick said.
Around 10 a.m., Director of Emergency Services for Queen Anne's County Scott Haas said he was still waiting for updated information from the scene. Multiple units from both Queen Anne's County EMS and fire and Anne Arundel County Fire Department responded and patients were being transported to several different hospitals, Haas said.
Two-way traffic on the eastbound span was suspended and officials directed alternating eastbound and westbound traffic every 20-30 minutes until conditions improve. All lanes were reopened at 2 p.m. Saturday afternoon, with delays still expected from the earlier closure.
Requests for comment from the Kent Island Volunteer Fire Department, the responding station from Queen Anne's County, were deferred to the Maryland Transportation Authority.
This story will be updated as information is made available. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

author: Natalie Jones

Cambridge house fire sends two to hospital

 CAMBRIDGE — A house fire in Cambridge Friday morning sent two residents to nearby hospitals with non-life-threatening injuries, the state fire marshal said.Fifty-five firefighters, primarily from the city's Rescue Fire Company, responded to a fire in a two-story, wood frame and masonry home at 2124 Silver Goose Road in Cambridge shortly before 10:30 a.m. Friday.

The preliminary cause was accidental — combustibles were too close to a heater.

author: Staff Writer
content:
Police seeking information in Bay Bridge crash

 January 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Words

 ANNAPOLIS — Maryland Transportation Authority Police officers are continuing to investigate a serious crash that occurred on the westbound span of the Bay Bridge on Saturday, Jan. 27.Investigators with the MDTA Police Collision Reconstruction Unit are completing a full reconstruction of the 23-vehicle crash.
According to officials, at this point in the investigation, Collision Reconstruction Unit investigators believe a blue 2018 Honda Civic sedan was being driven at high speeds and erratically prior to the crash and may have contributed to the crash.
Anyone who witnessed this blue Honda Civic traveling on westbound US-50 near the Bay Bridge between approximately 7:30 and 7:45 a.m. on Jan. 27 is asked to call the MDTA Police at 443-454-8703.
Police said the reconstruction is a detailed process that typically takes months to complete as investigators analyze evidence such as interviews, physical evidence, medical records and more. Additional information will be released as it becomes available. Any potential charges related to the crash are pending the conclusion of the investigation.

title: Police release name of woman killed by arrow in Conowingo
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Police release name of woman killed by arrow in Conowingo

 January 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 337
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CONOWINGO — A Conowingo woman was shot and killed by an arrow fired from a crossbow on Wednesday.Investigators said 45-year-old Judy Elizabeth Gee died in the Conowingo residence where the fatal incident occurred, according to the Cecil County Sheriff's Office.
Also in the update released by the agency on Friday morning, Lt. Michael Zack, a sheriff's spokesman, reported, "This matter is still being investigated by detectives with the Cecil County Sheriff's Office, in conjunction with the State's Attorney's Office for Cecil County. An autopsy is currently being performed in Pennsylvania, where the victim was pronounced dead."
In addition, Zack said that no arrests had been made as of Friday in the ongoing homicide investigation, before adding, "However, all interested parties have been identified."
Sheriff's deputies and paramedics rushed to the scene in the 700 block of Bell Manor Road at approximately 4:40 p.m. Wednesday, after receiving a dispatch regarding a woman who had been struck in the back with an arrow, police said. Deputies and paramedics rendered medical aid at the scene, before an ambulance crew drove Gee to Lancaster General Hospital in Lancaster, Pa., where she died from her wound despite "life-saving measures attempted by medical staff," police added.
"The arrow was fired from a crossbow, which belonged to an occupant of the residence. The individual who fired the weapon was located at the residence and (was) transported to the Cecil County Sheriff's Office for further investigative efforts," said Zack, who declined to release the name of the person who purportedly shot the arrow that killed Gee because of the ongoing homicide investigation.
Detectives have been consulting with the Cecil County States Attorney's Office about the crossbow incident that resulted in Gee's death and, as of Friday, the homicide investigation remained active, Zack reported.
CCSO officials are asking anyone with additional information that might help in this investigation to call Detective Jonathan Eldreth at 410-392-2126 or email him at Jonathan.Eldreth@cecilsheriffmd.gov. In addition, anyone who wishes to remain anonymous and has information can contact the Cecil County Sheriff's Office tipline at 410-392-2180. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a fatal crossbow incident investigated by law enforcement, focusing on public safety concerns, criminal investigation procedures, and community safety implications. title: McDaniel man found not guilty of sex offense; mistrial ruled on assault
author: Natalie Jones
content:
McDaniel man found not guilty of sex offense; mistrial ruled on assault

 January 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 425
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Following a three-day trial ending Friday, Jan. 19, a Talbot County jury found a McDaniel man not guilty of a sex offense. However, jurors were unable to reach a verdict on a related assault charge, resulting in a mistrial on that count.Six witnesses testified in the trial for Charles M. Kling, 53, who was facing two charges — a fourth-degree sex offense and second-degree assault — in connection to an alleged incident involving a female employee at a business in St. Michaels on June 19, 2023.
According to police, Kling was charged after he allegedly entered the business where the woman was employed, lured her away and touched her inappropriately.
Jurors deliberated for over three hours on Jan. 19 before returning a unanimous acquittal on the sex offense charge, according to Christine DuFour, one of Kling's attorneys.
The jury foreman told Talbot County Circuit Judge Stephen Kehoe, who presided over the case, that the jurors were deadlocked 11-1 on the assault charge, DuFour said.
According to one juror, who spoke to DuFour in the presence of other attorneys and a bailiff, the majority was in favor of a not guilty finding on the assault charge, she added.
Though a mistrial was declared, the prosecution does have the option to retry Kling for the assault charge.
Deputy State's Attorney Chelsea Endzel, who prosecuted the case, was unable to comment.
Andrew Jezic, one of Kling's attorneys, said if the state chooses to retry the case, he expects a full acquittal.
Police previously noted that Kling was a Tier III sex offender — a lifetime registry in Maryland.
The registration followed Kling's release from prison after serving time for a first-degree rape conviction in Anne Arundel County in 2004, according to court records.
Kling was sentenced to 25 years of active incarceration in that case, though he was released in spring 2020 and placed on supervised probation due to housing issues stemming from the pandemic.
If the prosecution does retry the case for the assault charge, the jury will not be able to consider Kling's prior conviction due to the acquittal on the sex offense, Jezic said.
Though Kling was released from custody in Talbot County following the acquittal, he remains held in Anne Arundel County due to a pending violation of probation in the 2004 case.
In a bail review Tuesday, an Anne Arundel judge approved Kling's release to house arrest, DuFour said, but he has not yet been released.
He is set to appear in court for a status conference in Talbot County on Feb. 16 and violation of probation hearing in Anne Arundel County in March. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal trial involving sex offense and assault charges, which directly relates to public safety concerns. title: Pennsylvania man arrested for indecent exposure in Ridgely
author: Natalie Jones

Pennsylvania man arrested for indecent exposure in Ridgely

 January 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 361

 RIDGELY — A Pennsylvania man was arrested Wednesday, Jan. 24, for allegedly indecently exposing himself to a mother and her 6-year-old daughter.Lane J. Findley, 26, is charged with two counts of indecent exposure and one count of disorderly conduct in connection to an incident along Peaviner Road in Ridgely.
Deputies from the Caroline County Sheriff's Office responded to the 23000 block of Peaviner Road shortly after 11 a.m. Jan. 24 for the reported indecent exposure.
The victim told police she was driving down Peaviner Road when she saw a truck driver waving to get her attention. According to charging documents, the woman said she saw the man turn around and pull his pants down, exposing his buttocks from atop a tanker trailer.
The woman said her 6-year-old daughter also witnessed the indecent exposure.
Police said the woman showed deputies a cell phone photo of a man, which "clearly" showed a man exposing himself, according to charging documents.
Further down Peaviner Road, deputies found two tractor-trailers and a man, identified as Findley, matching the description the woman had given to police.
Findley told police he waved to a vehicle while standing on top of a tractor-trailer tanker. According to charging documents, Findley said he bent over facing away from the passing vehicle, exposing his bare back to the car, and that he did not show his buttocks.
Police also spoke with Findley's coworker, who said he was not near the tractor-trailer during the incident, but did hear Findley yelling to a stopped vehicle.
The coworker told police that he told Findley to "leave it alone" due to ongoing community issues of manure being dumped in Caroline County, charging documents said.
Court documents filed for Findley's initial appearance before a District Court commissioner indicate that he is employed by Hartland Farms in Quarryville, Pennsylvania.
Hartland Holdings LLC owns a significant amount of land in Caroline County, including a property on River Road near Greensboro, which has a dissolved air floatation pit and has been the subject of recent outcry from local residents.
Findley was released the same day on a $5,000 unsecured personal bond, according to court records.
He is set to appear for a trial in Caroline County District Court on March 21.

While not explicitly labeled as 'Crime' in the topics, Public Safety (4) is the closest match given the law enforcement involvement and community safety implications.

title: Trappe woman found guilty of criminally negligent manslaughter by vehicle
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Trappe woman found guilty of criminally negligent manslaughter by vehicle

 January 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 787
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A Trappe woman who fatally injured an 84-year-old woman in a crash at the intersection of U.S. Route 50 and the southern end of the Easton Parkway nearly three years ago was sentenced Monday to 45 days in jail.Brittnee Ewing, 24, pleaded guilty to one count of criminally negligent manslaughter by vehicle — a misdemeanor charge — in connection to the fatal Easton crash, which occurred in the afternoon hours of April 8, 2021.
"These are the hearings where I feel the most powerless," said Talbot County Circuit Judge Stephen Kehoe, who presided in court Monday.
Though no specific disposition was recommended by prosecutor Jennifer Wilson and defense attorney Stephanie Shipley advocated for a probation before judgment and no active incarceration, Kehoe handed Ewing a three-year sentence, suspending all but 45 days.
The case against Ewing stemmed from a multi-agency investigation into the crash.
Ewing, the driver of a Ford Escape, was traveling eastbound on Route 50 toward its intersection with the parkway at a high rate of speed — 85 mph prior to the crash, 79 mph at the time of the collision, Wilson said.
Vicki Harvey, 63, of Easton, was driving a Ford C-Max Hybrid that day. Jo Ann Wright, 84, of Easton, was her passenger.
Harvey and Wright were crossing over eastbound Route 50 from westbound Route 50 at the light to turn onto the parkway, traveling roughly 25 mph heading toward the parkway, when they were struck by Ewing's car.
Wright was seriously injured in the crash, Wilson said. She was flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore. Harvey was taken to the hospital in Easton with minor injuries.
Wright suffered "devastating trauma" to her head, along with multiple fractures and bruises all over her body, Wilson said. She died at the trauma center on April 9, 2021.
Wilson said Ewing's car was "completely destroyed" in the crash. Ewing, who was also seriously injured in the crash, was flown with her 1-year-old son to Johns Hopkins in Baltimore for treatment.
A witness who was driving westbound on Route 50 at the time of the crash told police that the C-Max Hybrid had a green light. According to the witness, Ewing did not slow or brake, Wilson said.
In a later interview with police, Ewing said she remembered picking up her son before the crash, though she said she wasn't in a hurry, Wilson said. She did not remember the crash.
Speaking in court, Wright's daughters, Julia George and Janine Conway, recounted the painful memories surrounding their mother's death.
Both women said Wright was internally decapitated, meaning her spinal cord separated from her skull. The family decided to remove her from life support.
George recalled how her mother would outstretch her arms when scared, voicing a fearful suspicion that her mother's broken wrists from the crash were from that movement.
"Her death was one of pain," George said, remembering Wright gasping for breath. A tear rolled down the side of her face around the time of her death.
Conway remembered rounding up her family together to take a photo with Wright on Easter, just days before the crash. She recalled urging her brother to get up for the photo, saying they wouldn't know if it would be the last picture they took with Wright.
"And it was," she said, her voice catching.
Conway and George asked the judge to hold Ewing responsible for her actions that day.
"The accident didn't kill my mother, the choices Ms. Ewing made killed my mother," Conway said.
Shipley acknowledged the family's pain and desire to hold Ewing responsible, saying Ewing did suffer physically and mentally from her split-second decision at that yellow light.
Ewing had undergone multiple surgeries following the crash, she said. The 24-year-old mother of one was unable to walk for months afterward.
The crash was out of character for Ewing, Shipley said — she had never even been pulled over before. Her life was one of service and hard work, she added.
"She lives with, every day, the thought that she killed someone else," Shipley said.
With tears in her eyes, Ewing apologized multiple times for her actions that day, saying she took full responsibility for the tragedy.
"I will carry this with me for the rest of my life, as I should," she said, looking back toward Wright's family members seated in the courtroom. "I am so sorry."
Kehoe said he truly believed her, but given what happened, consequences were still needed.
Despite Shipley's pleas for a delay in Ewing reporting to the county detention center to serve her term, Kehoe denied the requests. Ewing was taken into custody after the hearing.
Court records indicate Shipley filed a motion Tuesday afternoon requesting the court grant Ewing emergency release or home detention due to potentially life-threatening health issues. No decision was made as of press time. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal conviction for vehicular manslaughter, focusing on a traffic accident with fatal consequences. While 'Crime' is not an explicit topic, 'Public Safety' best captures the legal and community safety implications of the case. The legal proceedings and sentencing reflect broader public safety concerns, making it the most accurate classification.

title: Democratic lawmakers plan to crack down on youth crime in the coming weeks
author: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service
content:
Democratic lawmakers plan to crack down on youth crime in the coming weeks

 February 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service | Section: General Assembly 
 
 587
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Children as young as 10 could potentially go to court for auto thefts and handgun violations, under one proposal key Democratic lawmakers detailed on Wednesday and plan to push for in the legislature in coming weeks.The lawmakers propose giving Juvenile Services officers the option to route a young person's case to court if the child is 10 to 13 years of age and accused of these or other crimes — adding them to the list of serious offenses that already can land a young person before a judge.
The proposals are meant to promote collaboration and make the system work more smoothly, Democratic officials said, but youth advocates worry that they will lead to higher incarceration rates, especially of youth of color.
"Right now, juvenile offenders and the services and accountability they need are separated by an abundance of confusion," said House Speaker Adrienne Jones, D-Baltimore County. "Egos, political agendas and arguments over process have filled the gaps."
There must be "accountability for adults in the system, who are charged with administering the system," said Senate President Bill Ferguson, D-Baltimore City. "We must ensure that all parts are working to their highest potential."
Jones and Ferguson joined Democratic Gov. Wes Moore on Wednesday for a public announcement of the proposals, alongside the lawmakers who crafted them.
The raft of changes, if enacted, would toughen a reform law the state legislature passed in 2022. Among other things, that reform barred police from charging young people under 13 except when they are accused of the most serious crimes.
The newly unveiled legislative package would expand that list of serious crimes and lengthen the maximum probation period that can be ordered by a judge. It would also expand the reporting responsibilities of a state agency charged with oversight of the youth justice system.
The announcement on Wednesday gave shape to Democrats' response to pleas for accountability amid spikes in certain youth offenses in recent years. While youth violent crime arrests fell 16.5% overall between fiscal years 2020 and 2023, according to a Juvenile Services report last year, carjackings increased by 85.4% and handgun violations rose almost 220%.
After weeks of talks with law enforcement and advocates, the set of proposals represents a general agreement among Democrats, who control both chambers of the legislature and also hold the governor's office.
But advocates in the Maryland Youth Justice Coalition predicted in a written statement that the "legislation introduced today will see thousands more kids incarcerated every year, particularly Black and brown children, and (exacerbate) the already serious racial disparities in Maryland's juvenile justice system."
As the minority party, Republicans have said in recent months that the reform law leaves Marylanders less safe and also prevents young people from getting the services they need. GOP lawmakers in Annapolis have their own ideas for change, including a measure that would prohibit young people who have committed sexual offenses from attending school in person.
But one key Republican on Wednesday said the Democrats' plan shows they are taking "first steps" in addressing flaws in the youth justice system. House Minority Leader Jason Buckel, R-Allegany, said he appreciates that Moore has put his weight behind the issue of youth crime.
"For him to be able to step in and say, 'Hey, I'm a Democrat. I'm from Baltimore City, but I'm going to step up and say too much is too much and this is a reasonable way to deal with this' — it's incredibly helpful," Buckel said.
Buckel said he also hopes Moore will be able to persuade fellow Democrats to consider other tough ideas, too. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on legislative proposals to address youth crime and juvenile justice reforms, which directly relate to public safety. While local government actions are involved, the core issue is crime prevention and justice system accountability. Racial disparities are mentioned but as a secondary concern.

title: CPD investigating reported armed robbery
author: Staff Writer
content:
CPD investigating reported armed robbery

 January 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 199
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Cambridge Police Department is requesting assistance from the community for any information related to an armed robbery that occurred on the evening of Jan. 20.The incident took place at the Citgo at 220 Sunburst Highway, according to a news release from CPD.
According to the release, a man entered the restroom of the gas station. Upon exiting the restroom, he was reported to have walked behind the counter, pulled out a large knife and demanded money from the register.
Police said the suspect was turned over an undisclosed amount of money before he ran out of the store through the parking lot. He was reported to have run toward Roslyn Avenue and turned left toward Crusader Road, according to the report.
Police said patrol and K9 units attempted to track the suspect.
Police said the suspect was described as an African American man with a slim build, about 5'8" in height. At the time of the robbery, he was reported to be wearing a grey knit-style hat, black face mask, black jacket, dark colored pants and gloves.
The incident is being investigated by CPD's Criminal Investigations Division. Anyone with information can contact CPD at 410-228-3333. All calls can remain anonymous.

title: Sewage overflows in Cambridge, city prioritizing improvements
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Sewage overflows in Cambridge, city prioritizing improvements

 January 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 779
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Harford County resident Jayne Ash saw more than she expected on Jan. 13 when she brought a group of people to Cambridge to look at birds.The end of Oakley Street, near the Choptank River, was flooded that day, Ash said.
"And the overflow was not draining," she said.
The group began to notice a white residue on the sidewalks, which seemed to have been left by the water, now below the curb but still flooding the street.
"The longer we stood there and the longer we looked, we just realized that this was just really nasty sewage water," Ash said, adding that she saw what looked like human feces floating in the water.
As the group was leaving the area, Ash said she could see a leak "coming out of the street," bubbling up six to eight inches.
The entire experience worried Ash.
"We figured we probably shouldn't be walking in the water," she said. "So we were kind of tiptoeing around the edges of where we normally would have gone."
Ash said the city should have roped off the area, posted signs and pumped up the flooded water to transport it elsewhere.
"It's just so many things that they could have done, but I guess they weren't keeping aware of it," she said.
According to the Code of Maryland Regulations, the owner or operator of any sewer system is required to report any overflow — defined as a loss of wastewater or discharge from a sewer system — to the Maryland Department of the Environment and local health department. This report must be made no later than 24 hours after the owner or operator becomes aware of the overflow.
COMAR also states that unless advised otherwise by the state or local health department, the owner or operator of the sewer system must notify the public no later than 24 hours after they become aware of the overflow if it enters shellfish harvesting waters, drinking water sources, waters used as public beaches or waters used for public recreation.
They must also notify the public if the state or local health department has reason to believe the overflow is a public health risk
The public must be notified via a public service announcement or paid advertising in a daily newspaper, radio station, or television station. According to COMAR, if appropriate, the public should be notified of larger overflows with potential environmental or health impacts through posted signage, as well as through the media.
On Jan. 17, the city submitted a telephone report to MDE. In a letter attached to the report, signed by Cambridge City Engineer Carl "Bucky" Jackson, Jackson said that high tides caused the sewage overflow event on Jan. 13.
According to the report, the city was informed of the overflow by MDE on Jan. 17 following a complaint from a resident. No personnel from the city observed the overflow.
Jackson said in the report that based on the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Cambridge tide gauge, the overflow is estimated to have begun at 8 a.m. and stopped around 11:59 p.m on Jan. 13.
Jackson wrote that discharge from the overflow wasn't observed, but paper products were discovered around around the manhole where the overflow occurred. Once notified, the street and storm drains were cleaned and disinfected.
In an interview, Jackson said signage notifying residents and visitors of the overflow were placed at the location of the event within four hours of the city learning about it.
Jackson said it was surprising that high tide was the sole cause of this incident. He said that, usually, the cause is a mix of high tide and heavy rains.
Water and sewer infrastructure improvements are one of the city's priorities this year.
Cambridge City Council has set out a $20 million capital program over the next five years for water and sewer infrastructure. The city has budgeted $8 million for fiscal year 2024.
During a meeting between Cambridge City Council, city staff and local state legislators last Monday, Jan. 22, City Manager Tom Carroll said Cambridge annually gets fined for violating the Clean Water Act.
"We are focused on fixing the sewer issues and reducing or eliminating overflows," he said at the meeting.
Earlier this month, the City Council awarded a contract bid to replace the West End sewer, located in the lowest lying area of the city at Water Street and Hambrooks Boulevard.
"Routinely, we have elicit discharges when we have wet weather events," Carroll said. "We have sewage overflows. And we're hoping that this project will fix that."
Jackson said the West End sewer replacement will benefit Oakley Street near the river.
Carroll said there are three other major sewer projects planned that are in "various stages of design" as well as a water booster station to accommodate new development. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on sewage overflows posing health risks, public notification requirements, and city infrastructure improvements. While local government actions are mentioned, the core issue revolves around public health and safety concerns from the overflow, making 'Public Safety' the top priority.

title: CPD annual report shows reduction in some major offenses
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
CPD annual report shows reduction in some major offenses

 February 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 540
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — There were fewer burglaries, homicides and assaults in Cambridge in 2023 compared to 2022.According to the Cambridge Police Department's 2023 year-end report, robberies and rape offenses were the two major offenses that Cambridge saw more of in 2023 than the year before it, increasing around 30% each.
The report states that homicides were down from seven in 2022 to two in 2023. Although there were three total homicides in 2023, Police Chief Justin Todd said the Dec. 18 fatal shooting of Taron Jones has been ruled justified, meaning that the person that shot Jones is not considered criminally liable and will not be charged with the murder.
Burglaries were down 42%. Aggravated assaults were down 8.8%. Simple assaults were down 10%.
"The overwhelming amount of support that the Cambridge Police Department has received, along with the countless number of community leaders that have dedicated their time to assist in community engagement, shows that working together, we can flourish and continue to improve," the report says.
CPD seized 53 illegally-possessed guns in 2023, according to the report. The majority of them, or 38, were pistols. Seven revolvers, six shotguns and two rifles were also seized.
When it came to shots fired in 2023, CPD reported that it received 256 ShotSpotter alerts as well as 74 shots fired calls. ShotSpotter is a gunshot detection system that has sensors that can detect and locate illegal gunfire incidents and alert law enforcement.
According to the report, the Criminal Investigations Division, which is made up of three detectives and an evidence technician, cleared 163 of its assigned 214 cases, or 76.2%.
In 2023, the department swore in eight new officers, making the total number of sworn officers 34, with two additional officers in the academy.
Although this is two officers more than 2022's staffing rate, CPD still has fewer officers than it had in 2018, when there were 44 sworn officers on the force.
The department had one more civilian employee in 2023 than in 2022. This year, that number has increased one more, making the total number of civilian employees six.
In the summer, the department established the Office of Professional Standards. This new unit has been tasked with managing department policies and procedures, collecting data that can be used for better staffing officers and increasing transparency to the community.
At the end of 2023, the unit conducted a staffing survey to be completed in 2024. The results of this project will include a recommendation to Todd and City Manager Tom Carroll for approval.
Community-oriented policing was a focus for the department in 2023. According to the report, CPD's Community Policing Unit hosted over 50 events over the year, including National Night Out and Shop with a Cop.
Going into 2024, community policing will stay a focus. According to the report, the goal of the department in 2024 is to continue to reduce crimes while increasing residents' quality of life.
The department has several specific initiatives it plans to implement this year, including "Patrolling with a Purpose" and initiating a Proactive Criminal Enforcement Unit in order to address areas identified as "problem areas" in Cambridge.
The department also plans to implement a drone program that can be used in missing persons, active shooters and barricaded suspects cases; increase cooperation with allied agencies and continue recruiting officers. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on crime statistics, police department activities, and safety initiatives in Cambridge, directly relating to public safety. While local government aspects are mentioned, the primary emphasis is on crime reduction and law enforcement efforts.

title: GVFD honors Risley, Haddaway, and Thomas for years of service
author: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com
content:
GVFD honors Risley, Haddaway, and Thomas for years of service

 February 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 463
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEENSTOWN — Saturday evening, Jan. 27, the Grasonville Volunteer Fire Department hosted their 65th annual Installation of Officers and Awards for 2023 to its members. The program took place at the Bay Country Moose Lodge in Queenstown.Fire department President Matt Coursey welcomed everyone, firefighter J.T. Clarke provided the opening prayer for the event. Twenty-five different local businesses and organizations were recognized for their contributions and support to GVFD in 2023.
One of those, the Kent Island American Legion, Post 278, in Stevensville, presented checks totaling $9,500 to the fire department at the banquet.
Fire Chief Jason Anthony, Sr., gave a summary report of events for the fire department for 2023. A few of the highlights included three major donations of $10,000 each from the Didonato family, the Narrows Restaurant (the Hardesty family), and the Rob and Fran Marsh family to the building fund towards the new fire house to be built.
Anthony added, "The fire department responded to 834 emergency calls in 2023. August was the busiest month with 103 calls."
In June, the Queen Anne's County Planning and Zoning approved the plans for the new fire house. In October, Fire Prevention Month activities were held at Grasonville Elementary, Little Lambs Schools and Grasonville Head Start, to impress upon young children the importance of fire safety.
Major service awards were then presented. For years of service, Cory Holm was awarded his 10-year pin. Keith Thomas received his Life Membership recognition, receiving a plaque, his 20-year pin, and his 20-year membership card. "Skippy" Haddaway received a special commendation from Governor Wes Moore, presented by Queen Anne's Commissioner Phil Dumenil, for his 45-years of active service to the fire department.
Topping the years of service awards, former longtime Fire Chief Pete Risley also received a commendation from the governor for his 55-years of active membership. Both Haddaway and Risley were presented unique plaques for their fire department service, and standing ovations from those who were attending.
The Rookie of the Year award was presented to four young firefighters who are recent graduates of the fire department's Cadet program, Jason Anthony, Jr., Caleb Bargerstock, Colby Bargerstock, and L.T. Blake, Jr.
EMS Provider of the Year Denise Ornduff, who was also to Top EMS Responder, responded to 211 emergency calls in 2023. Firefighter of the Year was presented to Dave Bell, Chief's Award to Mike Mattison and President's Award to Skippy Haddaway.
The Top Five Fire Suppression Responders for 2023 were: Jimmy Hurlock, Jr. (311 calls), Pete Risley (292 calls), Steve McCombs (275 calls), Dave Bell (266) and Jason Anthony, Sr. (265).
Six members of the fire department received "Medals of Honor" for their roles in saving the life of a heart attack victim in March, 2023. Those members were Captain Matt Coursey and firefighters Pete Risley, Skippy Haddaway, Tom Sheahan, Michael Balsoma and Cory Holm. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details an event hosted by a volunteer fire department recognizing members' service, highlighting emergency response statistics, fire safety initiatives, and community partnerships. These elements directly relate to public safety operations and community emergency services.

title: Preston man sentenced to 15 years for stabbing
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Preston man sentenced to 15 years for stabbing

 February 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 415
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — A Preston man was sentenced Thursday to 15 years in prison for the February 2022 stabbing of a then 25-year-old woman.Agreeing with a recommendation from the prosecution, Caroline County Circuit Judge Heather Price handed Mark William Thompkins a 30-year sentence with all but 15 years suspended. He will receive credit for 714 days, or nearly two years, already served, according to court records.
Thompkins, 26, pleaded guilty last October to one count of attempted second-degree murder.
Price also referred Thompkins to the Patuxent Institution, a treatment-oriented, maximum security correctional facility.
"I believe that it was an appropriate sentence," said Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin, who prosecuted the case. "Unfortunately, the mental health system is broken and failed both the victim and Mr. Thompkins."
Thompkins' defense attorney, Jesse Hicks, could not be reached for comment.
Thursday's sentence comes nearly two years after the young woman was stabbed near Holly Park Drive and Gilpin Point Road in Preston shortly before 3 p.m. on Feb. 17, 2022.
During the Oct. 30 plea hearing, Franklin said trash collection workers near the scene first saw the woman sitting in the driver's seat of her vehicle with a man, later identified as Thompkins, seated behind her.
Thompkins began striking the woman with his fists, then brandished a knife to stab her neck.
The woman ran from her vehicle and collapsed in the front yard of a nearby house. Thompkins cradled her while holding the knife to his own throat, Franklin said.
A witness attempted to help the victim, but Thompkins threatened them, pointing the knife at them and yelling for them to get back.
Multiple law enforcement agencies, including the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, Maryland State Police and Maryland Natural Resources Police, responded to the stabbing.
Franklin said Thompkins punctured his own neck with a knife while running to the woods to evade officers.
After 15 minutes and the use of multiple non-lethal methods, including a taser, a state trooper was able to knock the knife out of Thompkins' hand to detain him, police said.
Both Thompkins and the woman were flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore for treatment of their injuries.
After his arrest, a judge found Thompkins incompetent to stand trial in April 2022. He was committed to the Maryland Department of Health until August 2023, then transferred back to a local detention center upon being found competent, according to court filings.
Following his release, Thompkins will be placed on five years of supervised probation. He will also be required to complete mental health treatment. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal sentencing for a violent stabbing, focusing on law enforcement response, judicial proceedings, and community safety implications. While local government and national news could marginally apply, public safety directly addresses the crime and its societal impact.

 Read News Document

 DENTON — A Preston man was sentenced Thursday to 15 years in prison for the February 2022 stabbing of a then 25-year-old woman.Agreeing with a recommendation from the prosecution, Caroline County Circuit Judge Heather Price handed Mark William Thompkins a 30-year sentence with all but 15 years suspended. He will receive credit for 714 days, or nearly two years, already served, according to court records.
Thompkins, 26, pleaded guilty last October to one count of attempted second-degree murder.
Price also referred Thompkins to the Patuxent Institution, a treatment-oriented, maximum security correctional facility.
"I believe that it was an appropriate sentence," said Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin, who prosecuted the case. "Unfortunately, the mental health system is broken and failed both the victim and Mr. Thompkins."
Thompkins' defense attorney, Jesse Hicks, could not be reached for comment.
Thursday's sentence comes nearly two years after the young woman was stabbed near Holly Park Drive and Gilpin Point Road in Preston shortly before 3 p.m. on Feb. 17, 2022.
During the Oct. 30 plea hearing, Franklin said trash collection workers near the scene first saw the woman sitting in the driver's seat of her vehicle with a man, later identified as Thompkins, seated behind her.
Thompkins began striking the woman with his fists, then brandished a knife to stab her neck.
The woman ran from her vehicle and collapsed in the front yard of a nearby house. Thompkins cradled her while holding the knife to his own throat, Franklin said.
A witness attempted to help the victim, but Thompkins threatened them, pointing the knife at them and yelling for them to get back.
Multiple law enforcement agencies, including the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, Maryland State Police and Maryland Natural Resources Police, responded to the stabbing.
Franklin said Thompkins punctured his own neck with a knife while running to the woods to evade officers.
After 15 minutes and the use of multiple non-lethal methods, including a taser, a state trooper was able to knock the knife out of Thompkins' hand to detain him, police said.
Both Thompkins and the woman were flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore for treatment of their injuries.
After his arrest, a judge found Thompkins incompetent to stand trial in April 2022. He was committed to the Maryland Department of Health until August 2023, then transferred back to a local detention center upon being found competent, according to court filings.
Following his release, Thompkins will be placed on five years of supervised probation. He will also be required to complete mental health treatment.

title: Violent Firearms Offender Act back before lawmakers a fifth time
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Violent Firearms Offender Act back before lawmakers a fifth time

 February 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 872
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — For the fifth legislative session in a row, the proposed Violent Firearms Offender Act is back in front of Maryland lawmakers for consideration and hopes of passage through both chambers.Senate Bill 28 and Senate Bill 179, two separate bills both known as the Violent Firearms Offender Act of 2024, are being brought forward in an effort to address gun violence across the state.
Both bills include the same provisions, including altering a number of firearms-related offenses, expanding the definition of a crime of violence and specifying that a violation of parole or probation involving a firearm is not a technical offense.
It would also require the state Commissioner of Correction to provide incarcerated individuals with a reentry kit prior to their release.
More specifically, the bill would make the use of a firearm in the commission of a violent crime a felony — a crime that's currently a misdemeanor. The bill would also make the use of an assault weapon, machine gun or magazine with a capacity of more than 10 rounds a felony.
Current state law also does not classify the use of a firearm while possessing drugs with the intent to distribute them as a crime of violence. If passed, the bill would remove that exception.
Additionally, current law says if a person who is prohibited from having a firearm due to previous felony convictions, for example, is caught with one, that person can be charged with illegal possession of a firearm — a misdemeanor crime with a maximum sentence of five years.
The bill would increase the maximum penalty from five years to 10 years in prison for a second offense.
State lawmakers have previously heard and voted in favor of similar versions of the Violent Firearms Offenders Act, though it hasn't been able to move forward to becoming law.
In the 2020 and 2021 General Assembly sessions, the legislation passed the Senate, but failed to advance further in the House of Delegates. And in 2022 and 2023, the legislation failed to advance past the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee.
However, SB 28, the Senate Republican Caucus version of the bill introduced this session by Sen. William Folden (R-Frederick), adds a new provision: imposing a penalty on a person who sells or loans a regulated firearm to someone else knowing that the firearm would be used to commit a crime or cause harm.
If the bill with that provision is approved, a person who violates that law would be guilty of a felony and could face a maximum of 10 years in prison.
At a Jan. 25 Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee hearing, Folden and SB 179 sponsor Sen. Ron Watson (D-Prince George's) testified to the need to finally pass the legislation.
Watson, who's served in the Senate since summer 2021, focused on the fact that the bill has been presented multiple times without passage, and to the committee, the legislation wasn't new.
"But I have to ask the committee, are we ready now to take action?" Watson asked. "Because the state of Maryland is watching, and everything we've done over the last several years with respect to guns and trying to hold folks accountable, it is clear that crime is continuing to rise, particularly among our juveniles and the gun use."
Folden, acknowledging that the two bills have "the exact same posture," asked if Watson would support his bill's new provision adding punishment to selling or transferring a firearm to someone who commits a crime.
Watson said in talking with attorneys about trying to punish the person who sold a firearm, it would be difficult to prove what the intent of a purchaser would be.
Folden countered, saying it would be difficult, but not impossible, considering the number of people who communicate via digital platforms.
"Because if there's ever been a time (when) the opportunity exists to prove that there was the intent, it's now, with the environment we live in with the electronic devices," he said.
Watson said he would be amenable to the provision if the committee agreed.
"But we have to do something," he said, with Folden agreeing. "Standing still is not an option."
The currently proposed Violent Firearms Offender Act has the support of Shore lawmakers, too.
Sen. Steve Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline), a co-sponsor of SB 28 who has supported similar versions of the legislation since 2020, noted the emphasis that's being placed on public safety this session by Republicans, Democrats and Gov. Wes Moore.
"The feeling in Annapolis is that we need to do something about public safety and violent crime," he said, also pointing to the spread of crime across the state.
Though he's not on the Judicial Proceeding Committee that determines which version of the bill, if either, will move forward, Hershey said the Senate Republican Caucus would be "pleased" to see either bill moved out of the committee and on to the Senate and House floors.
The Violent Firearms Offender Act is one of five pieces of legislation the Joint Republican Caucus is proposing this session as part of its public safety agenda.
Other bills proposed as part of the agenda include the Gun Theft Felony Act of 2024 (SB 39/HB 304), the Safe Communities Act of 2024 (SB 44/HB 310), the Drug-Free Roadways Act of 2024 (SB 396/HB 320) and the Juvenile Justice Restoration Act of 2024 (SB 52/HB 319). 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While it involves state legislation (Local Government), the core subject is crime prevention and public safety.

title: GVFD honors Risley, Haddaway, and Thomas for years of service
author: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com
content:
GVFD honors Risley, Haddaway, and Thomas for years of service

 February 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 463
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEENSTOWN — Saturday evening, Jan. 27, the Grasonville Volunteer Fire Department hosted their 65th annual Installation of Officers and Awards for 2023 to its members. The program took place at the Bay Country Moose Lodge in Queenstown.Fire department President Matt Coursey welcomed everyone, firefighter J.T. Clarke provided the opening prayer for the event. Twenty-five different local businesses and organizations were recognized for their contributions and support to GVFD in 2023.
One of those, the Kent Island American Legion, Post 278, in Stevensville, presented checks totaling $9,500 to the fire department at the banquet.
Fire Chief Jason Anthony, Sr., gave a summary report of events for the fire department for 2023. A few of the highlights included three major donations of $10,000 each from the Didonato family, the Narrows Restaurant (the Hardesty family), and the Rob and Fran Marsh family to the building fund towards the new fire house to be built.
Anthony added, "The fire department responded to 834 emergency calls in 2023. August was the busiest month with 103 calls."
In June, the Queen Anne's County Planning and Zoning approved the plans for the new fire house. In October, Fire Prevention Month activities were held at Grasonville Elementary, Little Lambs Schools and Grasonville Head Start, to impress upon young children the importance of fire safety.
Major service awards were then presented. For years of service, Cory Holm was awarded his 10-year pin. Keith Thomas received his Life Membership recognition, receiving a plaque, his 20-year pin, and his 20-year membership card. "Skippy" Haddaway received a special commendation from Governor Wes Moore, presented by Queen Anne's Commissioner Phil Dumenil, for his 45-years of active service to the fire department.
Topping the years of service awards, former longtime Fire Chief Pete Risley also received a commendation from the governor for his 55-years of active membership. Both Haddaway and Risley were presented unique plaques for their fire department service, and standing ovations from those who were attending.
The Rookie of the Year award was presented to four young firefighters who are recent graduates of the fire department's Cadet program, Jason Anthony, Jr., Caleb Bargerstock, Colby Bargerstock, and L.T. Blake, Jr.
EMS Provider of the Year Denise Ornduff, who was also to Top EMS Responder, responded to 211 emergency calls in 2023. Firefighter of the Year was presented to Dave Bell, Chief's Award to Mike Mattison and President's Award to Skippy Haddaway.
The Top Five Fire Suppression Responders for 2023 were: Jimmy Hurlock, Jr. (311 calls), Pete Risley (292 calls), Steve McCombs (275 calls), Dave Bell (266) and Jason Anthony, Sr. (265).
Six members of the fire department received "Medals of Honor" for their roles in saving the life of a heart attack victim in March, 2023. Those members were Captain Matt Coursey and firefighters Pete Risley, Skippy Haddaway, Tom Sheahan, Michael Balsoma and Cory Holm. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details an event hosted by a volunteer fire department recognizing members' service, highlighting emergency response statistics, fire safety initiatives, and community partnerships. title: Residents displaced in 2-house fire
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
Residents displaced in 2-house fire

 February 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 346
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Of all the things in her home that Leona Demdy, 87, lost to a fire Saturday afternoon, she said her photographs are what she will miss the most.A lifelong resident of Easton, Demdy had collected photos of friends, family and neighbors. She said the snapshots were proudly displayed on her walls.
"I cried, cried, cried," Demdy said as she watched firefighters extinguish the last remaining embers at 17 South Locust Lane, many of her belongings strewn across the front yard of the early 20th century house. "I had everybody's picture on the wall. My walls were just full of pictures."
Demdy's home of 27 years was one of two houses that caught fire a little before 3 p.m. Saturday. It was the second house fire that Demdy had experienced in her life. Her home a few streets over had been lost to a fire three decades prior.
Firefighters were dispatched to the blaze at 3:07 p.m., by which time, neighbors said, flames were spreading quickly between the two structures.
Both Demby, who lived alone, and the family who lived next door were able to make it out of the houses, and emergency officials on the scene said that no serious injuries were reported.
It took firefighters a little more than two hours to control the blaze. Responding fire departments began to gather their equipment and leave the scene a little before 5:30 p.m.
Seven local fire departments responded to the fire — the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, the Cordova Volunteer Fire Company, the St. Michaels Fire Department, the Preston Volunteer Fire Company, the Oxford Fire Company, the Queen Anne-Hillsboro Volunteer Fire Company and the Trappe Volunteer Fire Company, along with local EMS and law enforcement personnel.
The state fire marshal is conducting an investigation into the fire and its causes, the results of which will be available at a later date.
Though exact damages are yet to be determined by the fire marshal, both houses sustained significant damage, and all residents of the structures were displaced.
Demdy said she would be staying with a relative near Salisbury, and arrangements were made for her neighbors. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a house fire involving multiple fire departments, emergency response, and community displacement, directly relating to public safety concerns.  DENTON — Denton Police Chief George Bacorn thanked Cpl. Christopher McMullen with a Chief's Citation for going above and beyond his normal course of duties recently.The presentation took place during the Denton Town Council meeting Thursday, Feb. 1.
According to Bacorn, McMullen was on duty and responded to a "check welfare call for a homeless gentleman who was disabled and had no place to go."
"Cpl. McMullen took it upon himself to find lodging for this gentleman at the hotel for the evening, provided some guidance on resources where he could get some help and just made sure he was safe for the night and had an idea of the direction he's going," Bacorn said.
"He took money out of his own pocket that night to get it done," Bacorn said. "So I just want to thank him for the work he does — the kind of work he does all the time — and we really appreciate you."

title: Ridgely man indicted on rape, sex offense charges
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Ridgely man indicted on rape, sex offense charges

 February 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 203
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — A 26-year-old Ridgely man was indicted Jan. 18 in Caroline County in connection to an alleged sexual assault in 2012.Rhett Ritter is facing second-degree rape; second-, third- and fourth-degree sex offenses and second-degree assault charges related to the incident.
According to the indictment, the charges stem from a situation involving another minor, which is alleged to have occurred in January 2012 in Ridgely.
Ritter was arrested Monday. He was initially ordered held without bond.
At a bail review Tuesday afternoon, Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin said he wasn't opposed to supervised release, saying he didn't think Ritter was a danger to himself or the alleged victim.
Ritter's defense attorney Chris Jennings advocated for release without supervision, pointing out Ritter's lack of criminal history and unlikelihood of being a flight risk or danger to the community.
Ritter is a founding member and the CEO of Purple Peake CBD in Denton.
Ritter also would have been 14 years old at the time of the incident, Jennings added.
Mentioning Ritter's strong ties to the community and employment status, Caroline County Circuit Judge Heather Price ruled to release him on a $10,000 unsecured bond.
Ritter is set to appear for a scheduling conference in Caroline County Circuit Court on Feb. 21.

title: Cambridge man sentenced for injuring ex-girlfriend
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Cambridge man sentenced for injuring ex-girlfriend

 February 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Crime 
 
 198
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — A Caroline County jury found Dontre Smith of Cambridge guilty of second degree assault Dec. 19, 2023, State's Attorney Sloane R. Franklin announced in a Feb. 2 press release.The case arose from an incident on Aug. 22, 2022, when Smith was attempting to find his ex-girlfriend and saw her vehicle traveling westbound on Preston Road outside of Federalsburg.
Smith immediately steered his vehicle into the oncoming traffic lane, causing the victim to go onto the shoulder, and then Smith followed her onto the shoulder. The victim then steered her vehicle back into the travel lane to avoid a collision, only to have Smith steer his vehicle into the travel lane and intentionally strike her vehicle head-on with his vehicle, causing her to suffer injuries.
On Jan. 30, the Judge Heather Price sentenced Smith to 10 years in the Department of Corrections.
"I would like to thank the Maryland State Police for its investigation into this matter," Franklin stated. "I hope that this sends a message to the public that domestic violence, even when relationships are over, will not be tolerated."
The case was prosecuted by Assistant State's Attorney Ryan J. Kief on behalf of the citizens of Caroline County.

title: Moke to be raffled for fire department
author: EVELYN MURPHY Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Moke to be raffled for fire department

 February 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: EVELYN MURPHY Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Life 
 
 193
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Preston Automotive Group has donated a new Moke to the St. Michaels Fire Department to raffle off to the community.A ticket for the raffle can be purchased for $10, or six tickets can be purchased for $50. Tickets must be purchased before July 6 by contacting a St. Michaels Fire Department member or emailing treasurer@stmichaelsfd.org.
For the St. Michaels Fire Department volunteers to continue their services, they must maintain their facility and equipment. The proceeds of the Moke raffle will contribute towards a new cascade system that will provide breathing air at fire scenes.
"The raffle is a way for us to raise funds for things that aren't paid for by the state or county," said St. Michaels Fire Department Treasurer Jessica Kastel.
With spring around the corner, there is no better time to gear up for Moke driving. Their compact size and open-body design welcome both light off-road adventures and leisurely rides.
PAG has been Delmarva's go-to, family-owned automotive dealership group for decades. Though PAG boasts 26 automotive locations across Maryland, Delaware, and Virginia and features 23 brands, its community remains a top priority.
For more information on PAG's charitable efforts, visit prestoncares.com.

title: Cambridge man charged with reckless driving, firearm and drug possession
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge man charged with reckless driving, firearm and drug possession

 February 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 244
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man was arrested on a slew of charges, including negligent and reckless driving, firearm possession and drug possession, on Feb. 4.According to a news release from the Cambridge Police Department, officers attempted to conduct a traffic stop at Park Lane and Leonards Lane for a stop sign violation on Oakley Street and Greenwood Avenue.
Police said the vehicle did not stop and attempted to flee from officers "at a high rate of speed." Police later identified the driver as 33-year-old Robert Michael Haines Jr., 33.
According to the news release, Haines drove down Leonards Lane toward Washington Street before turning onto Zachary Drive and then onto Alex Way. Haines continued driving to Foxtail Drive and back to Zachary drive.
Police said Haines then lost control of the vehicle, crashing into several parked cars.
Police said Haines attempted to flee from officers on foot before being apprehended in the 700 block of Foxtail Drive.
After securing the vehicle, officers found a loaded handgun on the floor of Haine's vehicle, police said.
After searching the vehicle, police said they found a large amount of money and controlled dangerous substances, including seven pills of MDMA, 27 unknown pills, about 60 grams methamphetamine, about 57 grams of crack cocaine and about 40 grams of cannabis.
Police said that through further investigation, it was discovered that Haines is prohibited from possessing a firearm due to previous felony convictions.
Haines was turned over to the Dorchester County Department of Corrections on no bond.

title: Officer fights to deter drivers like one who harmed him
author: LYDIA HURLEY Capital News Service
content:
Officer fights to deter drivers like one who harmed him

 February 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LYDIA HURLEY Capital News Service | Section: General Assembly 
 
 740
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Less than four months after losing his legs in an attempt to stop a reckless highway driver, a Montgomery County police officer is at the forefront of a movement to crack down on negligent driving in Maryland.Sgt. Patrick Kepp plans to testify on two bills in the state capital of Annapolis this session — traveling from Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, where he is still in active recovery from last October's incident.
"When I was brought into the conversation about new laws being created, right away, I knew it was something I wanted to do," Kepp said.
Rehabilitation is his first priority, he said, but treatment won't get in the way of his new mission. "I will be there in Annapolis to make sure these bills happen," Kepp said.
Kepp announced his plans this week in a press briefing alongside Montgomery County Executive Marc Elrich and Montgomery County lawmakers who are taking up the cause with him. Kepp's story has inspired them to craft new legislation that would punish repeat offenders of reckless driving.
"I'm going to call it the Sergeant Pat Kepp Bill on Reckless Driving," said Delegate Greg Wims (D-Montgomery), calling Kepp a "hero."
Reckless driving isn't a new phenomenon in Maryland. Outraged by stories of dangerous driving on the Beltway or the Ocean City Expressway, Maryland lawmakers in years past have proposed legislation meant to stop these behaviors. This session, two other bills, separate from Kepp's, are making their way through the legislature, specifically aimed at ending the deadly game of drag racing or "exhibition driving."
But Kepp's bill is a personal one, inspired by an officer who patrolled the sponsoring lawmakers' home district. Elrich visited Kepp while he was in recovery to propose the idea of working together on this set of bills, the officer said.
The two bills have not been filed, but the sponsors say they share common goals. The bills would change existing criminal law to widen the definition of what constitutes reckless and negligent driving and increase penalties for those crimes, the sponsors said.
One penalty they will propose is requiring offenders to appear in court for their offenses. "It's way too easy for a driver to just pay a fine and get back on the road and do what they were doing before," Elrich explained.
Sgt. Kepp, who worked as an officer in the alcohol initiative unit, says these bills will "give a little more teeth to some of our laws." Additionally, he hopes the law will address the "overall frustration" with the difficulty enforcing existing reckless driving laws. The penalties aren't tough enough, he said, and the fines aren't a good enough deterrent.
In the early morning hours of last Oct. 18, Kepp had just finished his shift when he heard a radio report of a speeding driver on Interstate 270. He joined other officers in an attempt to stop the driver. While Kepp was standing outside of his car, the driver struck him and left him critically injured, as Elrich recounted in the press briefing.
The Montgomery County Police officers on duty that night knew the driver "had a history of speeding and taunting police into chasing him," Elrich said. Police say the driver targeted and intentionally hit Kepp, Elrich said, and he is now being charged.
Both of Kepp's legs were amputated due to the injuries he sustained that night. Now he said he spends every day — from 9:45 a.m. to 2:15 p.m. — at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center undergoing rehabilitation. He joined the Zoom call for Elrich's press briefing from the medical center, wearing a blue dry-fit shirt and a short military-style haircut.
It has been four months since the accident, and Kepp said he has had a dozen surgeries since.
Still, he wants to speak on behalf of legislation that "will strengthen our laws and make our roadways safer," Kepp said.
The aim of the bills is "not for everybody to be thrown in jail, have huge fines, or lose their licenses," Kepp said, but rather to end reckless driving, especially by repeat offenders.
Elrich said he hopes the law will stop people from "ignoring lights and sirens from law enforcement, breaking the rules of the road … and performing car tricks like drifting, peeling out, and doing donuts in the middle of a road."
"All it takes is a moment's loss of control over that vehicle," Elrich said. "Instead of being entertaining, it would take little to transform it into a deadly incident."
