title: State lawmakers hope to protect judges’ privacy
author: TYRAH BURRIS Capital News Service
content:
State lawmakers hope to protect judges’ privacy

 February 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TYRAH BURRIS Capital News Service | Section: General Assembly 
 
 629
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Just a few months after a Maryland judge was killed in front of his home, state lawmakers are considering a measure that would remove personal information from the internet to provide more safety for judges.The Judge Andrew F. Wilkinson Judicial Security Act is named after the judge, who was shot and killed in his driveway in October 2023 by a man he'd ruled against in a custody dispute.
Sponsors hope the proposed change would provide more safety to judges and their families.
"The threats that happen to the members of the judiciary, they happen all the time," said Del. Luke Clippinger (D-Baltimore City), House sponsor. "It's a very challenging job to begin with, but a particularly challenging job when you add on the threats that they face and their families face."
Wilkinson isn't the only judge whose life was put in danger. All cross the country, state legislatures are looking to beef up protections for judges. In 2022, Congress passed the Daniel Anderl Judicial Security and Privacy Act, in honor of the son of New Jersey Federal judge Esther Salas. Salas was targeted by a lawyer who found her address and personal information online. Her son was gunned down in their family home. That law allows federal judges to remove personal information from federal government websites, according to a statement on the United States Courts website.
During the 2024 legislative session, the Maryland General Assembly is trying to do something similar. The bill would protect the privacy of judges by removing or prohibiting personal information from being published on the internet or any form of social media. The bill passed in the Senate and now moves on to the House.
Watchdog and advocacy groups in other states that have considered similar legislation have raised concerns about the possibility of withholding too much information about elected and appointed officials, who ultimately answer to the public. In a committee hearing, Sen. Charles Sydnor III (D-Baltimore) expressed concerns that the effort could be too broad.
"While I understand there was a specific concern about people posting and immediately wanting to be able to act, that was just one circumstance, and I just thought it was too broad," Sydnor said in an interview with Capital News Service.
After Wilkinson was killed, Jason DeLoach, the president of the Maryland State Bar Association, said he began working with others to put the bill together.
"When Judge Wilkinson was tragically murdered, I looked his wife in the eye at his service and I told her that the MSBA would be actively involved in making sure that we improve judicial security and doing everything we can to prevent this type of thing from happening again," he said during an interview with CNS.
As an attorney, DeLoach said he thinks that it's important to trust that a case will be resolved based on the facts and evidence of the case.
"We don't want the judge to have to think about anything other than the facts and the evidence," he said. "When judges are being threatened, or there's a potential for violence, that may persuade them on how they're going to rule."
Shortly before he died, Wilkinson ruled against his shooter in a divorce case granting the man's ex-wife custody of their children. Police suspect that was the motive for the shooting later that night.
Stephanie Wilkinson, the wife of Judge Wilkinson, said in her testimony before lawmakers that the gunman ambushed Wilkinson while he stepped outside to take a walk.
"I am devastated that I lost my husband, but my heart is beyond repair that my children have lost their father," she said. "Please help make things right by supporting this bill. By doing so you will assure my children, and the children Drew saved that day in this domestic case, that he did not die in vain." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on legislative efforts to protect judges' privacy and safety following a murder, directly relating to public safety concerns. While it involves local government actions, the core issue is judicial security and threat mitigation, making 'Public Safety' the top priority.

title: Maryland Democrats close in on refined juvenile justice bill
author: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service
content:
Maryland Democrats close in on refined juvenile justice bill

 February 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service | Section: General Assembly 
 
 789
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Democratic leaders are "very close" to agreement on adjustments to their controversial juvenile justice bill, including changes to the list of crimes that should qualify children ages 10 through 12 for delinquency jurisdiction, a key lawmaker said Thursday.Sen. Will Smith (D-Montgomery) said discussions on the bill are "still an iterative process," but that the bill's architects plan to limit under-13 jurisdiction to regulated firearms violations and third-degree sex offenses. An earlier version of the bill included auto thefts, among other crimes.
In addition, Smith said, leaders are also looking at changes to improve the process for referring young people to rehabilitation services, through what is known as the "Child in Need of Supervision" petition.
"It's to hold the entire system accountable and to ensure that youth get the support and the treatment that they need," Smith told Capital News Service in an interview Thursday afternoon.
Democratic leaders have been negotiating behind the scenes as they try to reconcile their initial proposal, introduced in January, with testimony and data pouring in from prosecutors, public defenders, victims and youth advocates.
Now, after months of briefings and hours of testimony in House and Senate committees, they are closing in on an amended bill that will present their refined plan for holding young people, as well as adults in government, accountable for youth rehabilitation.
Whatever they may ultimately pass will be an update to the Juvenile Justice Reform Act, approved by Maryland lawmakers in 2022 to protect the rights of children and improve their chances at turning their lives around.
Currently, lawmakers are negotiating a "more prescriptive and clear" Child in Need of Supervision process, which would unfold in court and create a paper trail rather than being handled informally by the Juvenile Services department.
"We're trying to make sure that there's an actual more formalized, universal application of CINS across the state," Smith said.
Another change they are considering has to do with what happens when a young person fails to show up for two or more rehabilitation treatment appointments.
"You can have probation extended if you miss treatment," Smith said, "but you cannot be incarcerated."
In addition, he said, public defenders pointed out that many young people under 13 aren't competent to stand trial, and they aren't getting rehabilitation services during the time when they are working to gain that competency.
"There are no services provided while that process is happening," he said. "And this whole thing is about getting kids and families services and supports."
The lawmakers have also been looking at data in their deliberations, especially about which crimes have spiked among young offenders, Smith said. That data is guiding decisions about expanded jurisdiction and other matters.
In addition to data, hearings in February brought emotional testimony into the spotlight.
Some lawmakers questioned whether the January proposal went too far to reverse the reform measures — and whether it was overly influenced by media accounts and public perception that youth crime is out of control.
"During the hearing, I kept asking, where's the data?" said Sen. Charles Sydnor (D-Baltimore County). "At times, we've allowed the media to drive our policy, and we're supposed to be data-driven. So show me the data."
Children under 13 accounted for less than 3.5% of all Juvenile Services intakes during the latest fiscal year for offenses the January proposal wanted to add, including deadly weapon, handgun, motor vehicle theft and misdemeanor sex offenses. That's down from 6.5% the year before reforms went into effect, according to a racial equity impact note released Tuesday by the Department of Legislative Services.
"Everyone agrees that auto thefts are up for adults and juveniles," said Sen. Jill Carter (D-Baltimore City). "But the issue is that kids 12 and under doing it is miniscule."
Amid assertions that the bill would worsen racial inequality in Maryland's juvenile justice system, some witnesses speaking in support of the January bill have pointed out that youth crime also victimizes communities of color.
Baltimore Deputy District Public Defender Alycia Capozello said in one recent hearing that the original proposal would disproportionately punish "little boys of color who historically have been adultified."
Gordon Pack, who spent almost 43 years in prison after being tried as an adult when he was 15, said he thinks lawmakers should build up the state's offerings of rehabilitative services and treatments before putting more kids into formal involvement with the juvenile justice system.
"All they're trying to do is equip law enforcement with another tool to address things, and they want to think that law enforcement will take the best tool in that situation," Pack said. "And this is how we're supposed to think. If you're a legislator, you're supposed to think like that."
Still, Pack said he thought lawmakers were moving too fast with the initial version of the bill.
"I think," he said, "they've got to be cautious." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on legislative efforts to revise juvenile justice policies, including crime jurisdiction limits, rehabilitation processes, and accountability measures. These directly relate to public safety frameworks and criminal justice system reforms. While involving local government processes, the core content centers on safety and justice policies rather than administrative governance or education.

title: CPR training for 911 calls could expand statewide
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
CPR training for 911 calls could expand statewide

 February 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 367
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Tony Rose, the chief of 911 for Charles County, was given unanimous permission from the Charles County commissioners on Feb. 28 to go to Annapolis and testify on behalf of House Bill 1092.House Bill 1092 would require the Maryland 911 Board to establish training standards for public safety answering point personnel concerning telecommunications CPR and alter the purposes of the 911 Trust Fund to include funding the costs of certain telecommunications CPR training.
"When an out-of-hospital cardiac emergency occurs, you have about 600 seconds —10 minutes — to make a difference to save a life before irreversible brain death occurs," Rose said.
In 2019, Rose learned of a new program to help change the way education is delivered to 911 call center operators.
Rose jumped on the opportunity and immediately brought in a specialist to evaluate current telecommunications personnel.
"It was all over the board," Rose said referring to answers about the last time 911 operators had given over-the-phone CPR. "Some had it done it yesterday, some had never done it."
The new program requires a virtual training scenario every three months, according to Rose. During the training, operators are subject to challenging scenarios to help provide CPR instructions more proficiently.
"The results have been phenomenal," Rose said. "We have doubled, and in some cases tripled, the number of survivors of out-of-hospital cardiac arrest in Charles County. They're walking out of a hospital after they've stopped breathing."
"We also reported that we had improved the application of bystander CPR from 27% to 43%, improved bystander application of an AED from 23.5% to 28.6% and saw the number of survivors that were discharged from the hospital increase from five to eleven," a written testimony Rose provided to the board said.
"It reminds me of an incident when I used to coach soccer," Commissioner Ralph E. Patterson II (D) said. "We had a cardiac arrest incident."
Patterson recalled how the operator he talked to was calm and helped guide those present through the situation, underscoring the importance of legislation like House Bill 1092.
"Currently, Charles County is the only jurisdiction that participates in this program," Rose said. "This bill would make it mandatory for 911 centers to provide, not necessarily this particular program, but one similar to it." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on CPR training for 911 operators to improve emergency response, directly relating to public safety initiatives. While health aspects are involved, the core topic is emergency service protocols and legislation, aligning most closely with Public Safety.

title: Man pleads guilty to manslaughter and possession of a handgun
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Man pleads guilty to manslaughter and possession of a handgun

 February 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 529
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Monday morning, Daseir Cornish, 22, of Denton, pleaded guilty to counts of manslaughter and possession of a handgun in the death of TY Brooks.Judge David Densford sentenced Cornish to 13 years in prison for manslaughter, with five years suspended. Cornish was given an active sentence of 10 years in prison and will have to serve half of that due to it being a violent offense. He was also given five years of supervised probation upon his release.
"This is a tragedy all the way around," Densford said. "The Cornish family is grieving because there's some sort of prison, but the end of that sentence was 'but they can visit him in the Talbot County Detention Center. We have to go to a cemetery.' That's obvious to everyone."
Before the sentencing, family members of Brooks and Cornish gave statements to the judge for consideration. Brooks' family described him as a caring and spiritual man. They said that Brooks would mentor the youth around him and provide his best guidance.
Tyniqua Fooks, Brooks' daughter, said he was a wonderful man and a fantastic grandfather to her two-year-old daughter. Fooks said that Brooks made a promise to her that he would be there for all the special moments in his granddaughter's life.
"Unfortunately, that promise was taken away from my father," Fooks said. "She will no longer be able to see her grandfather… He won't be at any of those special moments in her life. It has been hard for me to describe them and move on."
Cornish's family described Cornish as a kind, shy, loving, but, most importantly, a protective young man to the people around him and the animals he loved.
"We are here today due to unfortunate circumstances, and I offer my most sincere apologies to all who have been affected," Sara Ringold, Cornish's mother, said. "This has not been easy to grasp by any means. I hope that my son is not defined by this moment because this is not who he is."
The charges stem from an incident that occurred Aug. 7, when Easton Police responded at about 7 p.m. to the area of 104 Blake Street in reference to someone who had just been shot and was lying in the grass. They rendered aid until paramedics arrived, but Brooks succumbed to his injuries at the scene.
According to statements, Brooks argued with individuals operating a 2018 Land Rover Range Rover parked in the 100 Block of Blake Street. Brooks left the area in a vehicle, police said, and later returned operating an ATV. He confronted the same individuals with a shotgun and a fanny pack with additional shells, police said.
After exchanging, Cornish, who was seated in the driver seat of the Range Rover, fired shots through the front passenger seat window and struck Brooks, police said. Brooks fell off the ATV as the Range Rover fled the scene. Cornish disposed of the Range Rover in a parking lot and abandoned the weapon in a river.
Attorney Molly Fox told the judge that Cornish came to her in August when a warrant went out for his arrest to review his options, and he decided to turn himself into the police. Cornish had no prior arrests. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal case involving manslaughter and firearm possession, which directly relates to public safety concerns. While it includes local court proceedings, the core focus is on a violent crime and its legal consequences, making 'Public Safety' the most appropriate category.

title: Pizza manager charged with selling cocaine to employees, customers
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Pizza manager charged with selling cocaine to employees, customers

 February 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 536
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The manager of Grotto Pizza in Delaware is accused of selling cocaine to employees and customers inside and outside of the restaurant and bar on Main Street in Newark, according to court records.Michael Gordon-Somers, 40, of Elkton, Maryland., was arrested Feb. 23 and charged with possession of cocaine with intent to deliver, drug dealing, possession of drug paraphernalia and driving on a revoked license. He was released on his own recognizance.
The investigation began in October when a tipster reported to Newark Police that he had witnessed Gordon-Somers engaging in hand-to-hand drug transactions inside the restaurant, which is a popular nightlife destination among University of Delaware students. He also alleged that Gordon-Somers used drugs to take sexual advantage of young male staffers, according to court records.
It's not clear if police investigated at the time, as the narrative provided in court documents doesn't pick back up until December, when plainclothes officers in the Street Crimes Unit encountered Gordon-Somers during an unrelated drug investigation.
The unit was working with a cooperating witness, who had arranged to purchase cocaine from a drug dealer. The witness learned that the dealer had to go to Main Street to pick up cocaine from a supplier.
Officers watched as the dealer pulled into the City of Newark's Lot 2, a public parking lot on the north side of Main Street, across the street from Grotto Pizza. The lot is partially reserved for employees of downtown businesses, who can purchase monthly parking permits there.
Gordon-Somers arrived on foot, and he and the dealer both got into Gordon-Somers' SUV, which was already parked in Lot 2. Police observed Gordon-Somers hand something to the dealer, according to court records.
Police then scoured surveillance footage from Lot 2 and found footage of an earlier incident in which Gordon-Somers and another Grotto employee got into Gordon-Somer's SUV. Gordon-Somers handed the employee something from the center console, and the employee could be seen snorting a substance two separate times. After wiping his noise, the employee and Gordon-Somers walked back to Grotto Pizza, court documents indicate.
Officers continued to monitor surveillance footage throughout January and February. On Valentine's Day, the cameras captured footage of Gordon-Somers getting into his vehicle in Lot 2 shortly before noon. Another man got into the passenger seat and they conducted a hand-to-hand drug transaction, court documents allege.
Police obtained a search warrant for Gordon-Somers's vehicle and pulled him over Feb. 23 as he drove on Elkton Road. Inside the vehicle, police found 23 grams of cocaine, packaged in 15 baggies. Officers also determined that Gordon-Somers' Maryland driver's license had been revoked.
According to court records, Gordon-Somers told police he had been selling cocaine for two years and specifically admitted to at least four drug sales in Lot 2 and Lot 1, which is located behind Grotto Pizza. He also admitted snorting cocaine inside his vehicle.
According to Gordon-Somers' LinkedIn profile, he has worked for Grotto Pizza since 2012. A 2020 post on the restaurant's Facebook page hailed Gordon-Somers as an "all-star" employee who started as a dishwasher and worked his way up to become general manager.
"Michael has been suspended from employment and is not permitted on the property pending the outcome of his trial," Grotto Pizza President Jeffrey Gosnear said in a statement.

title: Crumpton VFD honors volunteers for 2023 service

Crumpton VFD honors volunteers for 2023 service

 Following tradition of volunteer fire company's across the county, Crumpton President Eric Meredith welcomed members and their guests to the annual awards banquet and installation of officers on Feb. 24.Among the many members recognized for their tireless dedication to the all volunteer department were Daphine Thomas receiving the President's Award and Beverly Emore and Patricia Trossbach receiving the Outstanding Achievement Award.
Presented only for the second time was the Milestone Award, received by David Skinner. This award was created in 2022 and is given to the member who has made the most significant contributions in overall service to the fire department over many years.
Justin Skinner was awarded 2023 Firefighter of the Year. He responded to a total of 172 fire and emergency medical services calls during the past year.
Scott Ferwalt was also recognized for his nearly 20 years service performing as Santa for the Crumpton Volunteer Fire Department.
Following the invocation offered by Pastor Dave Patterson, dinner was served by Port Side Grill Catering of Easton. Meredith then presented the annual report for service to the community for 2023, which included 200 fire related emergency calls and 238 EMS emergency calls, totaling 438 emergency calls for the year.
Queen Anne's County Fire and EMS Commission President Bill Faust administered the oath of office to the 2024 Administrative, Fire Suppression and EMS officers.
Fire Chief Wade presented years of service recognitions to members Eric Meredith who received his 20-year Life Membership Award, Tricia Hunter for 35 years and David Skinner for 45 years.
Members were also recognized for their service hours and responses in 2023.
Top Overall Points earned (Non-Operational) went to: Kathie King with 174 points, Daphine Thomas with 160, and Dawn Piposzar with 141.
Top EMS Responders for 2023: 102 EMS calls, Justin Skinner; 80 calls, Chris Tingen and Dawn Piposzar, 78.

title: Following lockdown, lawmakers express worry over Capitol’s emergency alert system
author: ANGELIQUE GINGRAS Capital News Service
content:
Following lockdown, lawmakers express worry over Capitol’s emergency alert system

 March 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANGELIQUE GINGRAS Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 449
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — A day after a threat to the state capitol prompted a near two-hour lockdown, lawmakers applauded the quick work of law enforcement, but raised concerns about efficient communication.Sen. Antonio Hayes (D-Baltimore City) said he was voting in a Finance Committee meeting when a member of the press texted him about a security threat to the State House. A few minutes later, a state trooper in the room notified committee members to shelter in place, before they were escorted out of the building.
"I wish I would have gotten a text message internally before I got one externally, but I think just given the series of events, it is what it is," Hayes said.
The incident occurred around 5 p.m. Thursday when an anonymous call was made to the Annapolis City Police Department threatening to target the state capitol. After nearly two hours of lockdown, the Maryland Capitol Police determined there was no evidence of a potential threat.
The Senate and House of Delegates convened Friday, each opening their floor sessions with a standing ovation for the law enforcement officers who sprang into action.
"Yesterday was certainly a very scary moment for many, a very intense moment, but a moment when our first responders did everything that they were supposed to do and kept everyone safe, followed protocol and really responded to a very intense situation appropriately," Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore County) told reporters Friday.
Capital News Service reached out to a spokesperson for the Department of General Services, which oversees the Maryland Capitol Police, who provided no comment on the communication efforts by law enforcement.
"The one thing you can't have happen is, you don't want to over alert or over alarm the people you're trying to protect," said Sen. Will Folden (R-Frederick), who also serves as an active duty police officer in the city of Frederick. "It's a necessary element to only provide absolutely necessary information to not create panic."
The incident occurred just days after the General Assembly signed a contract with Motorola to incorporate a text message alert system for state officials in the State House complex, according to Ferguson. That system is still being built, he said, and was not in use at the time of the threat.
"Within the structure we have right now, (state troopers) did an amazing job. I think we all would like a world in which we had a text service to keep us informed." said Sen. Sarah Elfreth (D-Anne Arundel).
Hayes added, "I didn't even realize that we were in the middle of negotiating a text messaging contract, which I think would have been helpful."
While it isn't clear when the alert system will be up and running, lawmakers expressed gratitude for police efforts yesterday. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a security threat to the Maryland state capitol, emergency response protocols, and legislative discussions about improving communication systems. These elements directly relate to public safety concerns involving law enforcement, emergency alerts, and threat mitigation. title: Future without fear
author: Staff Writer
content:
Future without fear

 March 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 236
 Words 

 Read News Document

 This letter expresses my own commentary of the op-ed piece titled "Why Can't We Solve America's Gun Problem?"I agree our nation is currently suffering from the struggle for gun control. As a member of this nation's youth, I live in fear. Although possession of a firearm is meant to protect, it has proven repeatedly that it can be used to harm or even end lives. The nation has seen this recently, such as the shooting at the Chief's Super Bowl parade or the Parkland shooting six years prior.
I expect this double-edged sword will continue to be a hot-seat issue for this nation's politics for a long time. As said in the op-ed piece, politicians are not concerned about the idea of gun control, but rather how they can sway voters toward their campaigns. These politicians prevent our nation from solving this major issue for all people in this country by rejecting proposed policies that would help the cause, such as universal background checks.
Ultimately, if we were to get past these politicians and their negligence, we could create a future for Americans to live without fear of being a victim to gun violence. This initiative does not need to be immediate. Realistically, it will be a gradual process that I may not even see in my lifetime, but I am hopeful that one day the fear that many hold for gun violence ceases.
CLYDE FORMILLEZA JR.
Newark, Delaware

title: Background checks needed
author: Staff Writer
content:
Background checks needed

 March 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 203
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I agree with the opinions in the article, "Why we cannot solve America's gun problem." The shooting in Kansas City shows that there is an issue in our country. Juveniles carrying guns and firing upon a parade of innocent civilians should show that this is a crucial conversation to have.I agree that in Missouri there needs to be better gun safety laws such as background checks and permits to carry. A requirement to lock up firearms countrywide is essential in a household because juveniles like this can get guns from family members.
I agree that it is an issue that one party has made an agreement with the National Rifle Association, and they have their bias toward it. Opposing criminal background checks does not seem safe or smart in any capacity. Some lawmakers change and alter their ideals purposefully to receive votes. I do not think guns should be completely outlawed and banned. I think everyone should have the right to own a firearm barring obvious constraints such as mental illness or a criminal record.
However, there absolutely needs to be background checks across the country and ensuring that guns in the house are locked up and out of reach from children.
JOSEPH MURPHY
Newark, Delaware

title: Rider trial postponed; bench warrant issued
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Rider trial postponed; bench warrant issued

 March 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 476
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Although the trial was set to begin Monday morning, Fred "Trey" Rider III will not be tried for arson, malicious destruction of property, reckless endangerment and other charges this week.Rider is accused of setting his house afire in November 2022.
At a status hearing Monday morning, Judge Thomas G. Ross stated that Rider had been voluntarily admitted to Johns Hopkins Hospital and issued a bench warrant for Rider's failure to appear in court that morning.
A tentative trial date has been scheduled for Aug. 19 at 9 a.m., according to the Maryland Electronic Courts website.
According to court documents, the bench warrant can be executed once Rider has been released from Johns Hopkins Hospital.
The $20,000 unsecured bond that Rider had been released on in February 2023 also was revoked Monday.
Rider's attorney Stephanie Shipley filed a motion Friday to postpone the trial, according to court documents. In the motion, it states that Rider had been admitted to Johns Hopkins Hospital "on an emergency basis for acute medical issues, with further transfer planned to an inpatient facility in the State of Maryland."
On the same day, the State's Attorney's Office issued its position on the defendant's motion to postpone the trial. According to court documents, the state's consent to the postponement was contingent upon "further appropriate medical documentation."
Shipley presented an updated letter from Johns Hopkins Hospital at the status hearing Monday morning.
The 15 charges Rider faces stem from a Nov. 24, 2022, incident where firefighters responded to a fire at Rider's home at 27930 Peach Orchard Road in Easton.
Deputy State Fire Marshal Shayne McKinney, who investigated the fire and authored the incident narrative, wrote in charging documents that a Talbot County deputy responding to the scene informed him Rider had possibly attempted suicide that evening based on evidence found within the home. Rider had attempted suicide in the past as well, according to the deputy.
According to court documents, a person connected to Rider told officials he had called Rider several times that evening, adding that Rider had clearly indicated to him that he was attempting suicide and wanted to be left alone. Charging documents indicated that Rider told the person that he lit the house on fire during their conversation.
Rider was located a short distance away from the home and transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton for emergency care.
Through investigation, officials identified the fire as an act of human intervention with an open flame, classifying the cause of fire as incendiary.
According to court documents, Rider's reckless conduct in igniting the house on fire "clearly" put emergency services personnel, specifically more than 45 firefighters who responded, in danger as they suppressed the fire.
Rider was arrested in February 2023 and released on a $20,000 unsecured bond.
In April 2023, Rider entered a plea of not criminally responsible by reason of insanity, according to documents filed in court. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Lawmakers work toward juvenile justice solution
author: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service
content:
Lawmakers work toward juvenile justice solution

 March 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 994
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Lawmakers are moving toward consensus on changes to Maryland's juvenile justice system, discussing how to address crime by children ages 10 to 12 and get them into rehabilitation programs that can help.The House and Senate have each passed their own version in this effort, and lawmakers are now turning to the task of agreeing on a shared solution.
The main point of contention between the two bills now is whether kids who are being shielded from prosecution should go to programs without Department of Juvenile Services involvement or, instead, go into a Juvenile Services process that would play out in court.
"I think that what it comes down to is both sides want to find some way prior to the child being put directly into DJS, of having a stop on the way before that happens," said Del. Luke Clippinger (D-Baltimore City), co-sponsor of the House bill.
Sen. Will Smith (D-Montgomery), co-sponsor in the Senate, said that in discussions to agree on a single bill, lawmakers will "do whatever makes sense to ensure that, obviously, our youth have the supports to succeed and public safety is upheld."
But as the measures advance, they also differ on the crimes that would trigger mandatory rehabilitation.
The House bill would give kids accused of auto theft or firearms violations for the first time a chance to avoid court by participating in a so-called "diversion program" chosen by the arresting officer. Such a program is meant to offer services and divert a child from entering the juvenile justice system.
The Senate bill would send kids accused of auto theft for the first time to court through an existing DJS procedure, known as the "Child in Need of Supervision" process.
In current law, when law enforcement or a member of the public reports someone as a Child in Need of Supervision, a DJS intake officer can decide whether to refer the young person to services or file a "CINS petition" in court. A CINS petition asks the judge to assess the case and decide on an appropriate intervention.
The amended Senate bill would require the filing of a petition in court, but only in cases of children under 13 accused of auto theft for the first time.
While a judge could choose from a range of options in such cases — such as community-based services, a substance abuse rehabilitation program or an out-of-home placement — incarceration would not be on the table. And if a child did not complete the rehabilitation, the judge could recall them to court.
Lawmakers are also working to address lapses of communication between police and DJS with their bills.
Both bills would require police to file a written report with DJS when they refer a young person to services or take them into custody. The CINS petition required in the Senate bill would also create a written record that would go into a child's case history.
Smith said that by requiring an intake officer to send children before a judge, the Senate bill will allow children "to have the ability to get services and support, but there will be a level of accountability there."
Both bills would specify that if a child repeats the same offense a second time, they could be sent to court with the possibility of incarceration.
Clippinger said he's "happy to hear more from the Senate" but that creating a separate CINS process for children ages 10 to 12 accused of auto theft could create confusion.
"The special kind of CINS, at least how it is described to me, sounds an awful lot like just putting kids at the Department of Juvenile Services," Clippinger said. CINS "has been administered disparately" by DJS, he added.
Even with these changes, the amended bills have failed to win the approval of some youth advocates and public defenders.
"Only one diversion for a kid who's 10, 11 or 12 is not going to solve the problem of whether they're competent to stand trial," said Kimber Watts, attorney in the Forensic Mental Health Division at the Maryland Office of the Public Defender.
When a young person is charged with a crime, they undergo a process to determine whether they are "competent" to understand the court proceedings. During this process, they can only receive services to help them attain competency.
In cases when children are ruled incompetent, Watts said, "then we're high and dry, and we can't get them whatever it is they need."
Both versions of the bill moved through their chambers with largely favorable votes, with support from Democrats and Republicans.
Sen. William Folden (R-Frederick) said that while the Senate bill wasn't "as far-reaching as we would like to have had," it would help hold kids accountable for their rehabilitation.
"That's an important component, being able to have that recall authority of the judge to say that their sentencing and their guidelines have some teeth," Folden said.
Neither bill would change a 2022 law that bars police from interrogating minors before they have consulted with an attorney.
"There are parents that want law enforcement to be in contact with their child and say, 'Listen, you're going down a bad path. Don't do this. This is why,'" said Folden. "That type of candid dialogue is now gone because the officer can't talk (with the young person) even with parental consent."
The House and Senate both amended their bills to move up the work of the proposed Commission on Juvenile Justice Reform and Emerging Best Practices from October to July. The House bill would push back the implementation date of its other measures to January to give some jurisdictions time to stand up diversion programs, while the rest of the Senate bill would go into effect Oct. 1.
Del. Cheryl Pasteur (D-Baltimore County) said she decided to vote for the bill because the House had "ameliorated" penalties for 10- to 12-year-olds. She urged her colleagues to use the commission to prioritize prevention of youth crime.
"We have commissions, and sometimes the seats don't get filled. We don't take them seriously," Pasteur said. "This time, we need to take it seriously." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on legislative efforts to reform Maryland's juvenile justice system, addressing crime prevention, rehabilitation programs, and accountability measures for minors. These topics directly relate to public safety concerns, as the reforms aim to balance youth intervention with community safety. While Local Government is tangentially relevant due to the legislative process, the core subject is public safety policy.

title: Off-duty Prince George's officer faces attempted murder charge
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Off-duty Prince George's officer faces attempted murder charge

 March 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 450
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A Prince George's County police officer was arrested and charged with attempted murder and first-degree assault after firing his service weapon at a man in Charles County while off-duty.On Feb. 23, the Charles County Sheriff's Office responded to the area of Crain Highway and Budds Creek Road in Newburg for reports of shots being fired at a moving vehicle, charging documents say.
Charles County emergency communications received ongoing updates from the caller, who said that he was following the shooter in his vehicle on Budds Creek Road. A detective was able to locate both of the vehicles, and they came to a stop on Ryceville Road in Mechanicsville.
The alleged shooter, David Hardester, 42, of Mechanicsville, cooperated with responding officers and was detained after a felony stop was conducted, according to charging documents.
The document says an officer asked Hardester where he was coming from and he said, "Down there at the Aqualand neighborhood. I was just going to talk with him."
Hardester was asked how he knew the man he allegedly shot at, to which he told officers that his wife knew him, the document says.
Officers talked to the other man who said Hardester was going to meet him at his house and that he was expecting a fight with him because Hardester was aware that the man was talking to his estranged wife, according to charging documents.
The man told officers that he believed they would have a fist fight and "get it over with as men," charging documents say.
The two met in a parking area by the man's residence and began arguing when the man began to walk away. When his back was turned, he heard a loud gunshot, felt a "whiz" allegedly from a bullet go past him and ran from Hardester, the document says.
Upon taking Hardester into custody, police allegedly located live ammunition and Hardester's 9 mm handgun, which was later determined to be his service weapon.
According to the charging documents, Hardester's driver's door had damage consistent with a gunshot entering the door panel from inside the truck and exiting out the door.
Officers were able to obtain video footage that was consistent with the victim's story.
Hardester's estranged wife came to the scene at Ryceville Road and informed officers that before the alleged shooting Hardester had assaulted her at her home in St. Mary's County after finding out about her new relationship, charging documents say.
Hardester informed her that he was going to go to the man's house and allegedly grabbed her, slammed her into a wall and left the residence. Hardester's estranged wife took the opportunity to warn the man that Hardester was coming, the document says.
Currently, Hardester is suspended without pay, according to the Prince George's County Police Department. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cambridge man handed two life sentences without parole
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge man handed two life sentences without parole

 March 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 648
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Tramelle Williams, 23, of Cambridge was handed two consecutive life sentences without the possibility of parole for the December 2022 murders of 24-year-old Taijay Daniels and 69-year-old Lory Fields.Before handing over the sentence on Monday, Dorchester County Administrative Judge William Jones called surveillance footage of Daniels' death "possibly in the top five, if not No. 2 most difficult thing I've had to see."
Williams also was handed a consecutive 20-year sentence for robbery charges and two additional consecutive 20-year sentences with mandatory minimums of five years for firearms charges.
Williams was tried separately for the murders of Daniels and Fields. He was found guilty on all counts — which included first- and second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, robbery and firearms charges — in both trials.
A motion for a new trial for the death of Fields, filed by Williams' defense in late January, was denied at the sentencing hearing Monday.
According to court documents, Williams' defense argued there was insufficient evidence to support that a robbery had occurred and that Williams had intended to kill or harm Fields. His defense included in the motion that evidence related to Daniels' death was "unintentionally admitted and sent back" to the jury in the trial for the death of Fields.
According to court documents, in response, the state said the motion for a new trial should be denied because the evidence "clearly supported a conviction on all counts," and said none of the jurors had knowledge of the Daniels case.
"'Taijay Daniels' would be nothing more than a 'John Doe' to the seated jurors," the state's response to the motion says.
At the sentencing hearing, Jones denied the request for a new trial. He said there was sufficient evidence to prove that Williams was responsible for the death of Fields.
Jones said there was an extensive voir dire to make sure no jurors in the Fields trial knew anything about the Daniels case. He said that when the document related to Daniels' death was given to the jury on the Fields case, the jury was told to disregard it.
"And they did," he said.
Before the sentencing was handed over on Monday, Williams was given the opportunity to speak. He said he was sorry to the families of Daniels and Fields, and maintained his innocence. Williams said he thought he could benefit from going to a psychiatric hospital.
The events that resulted in the deaths of Daniels and Fields took place on Dec. 8, 2022. That day, the Cambridge Police Department responded to two shootings in the span of a few hours.
During the trial for Daniels' death, Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard said Daniels was found dead from multiple gunshot wounds on Pleasant Street, one of which was fired at close range.
Surveillance footage shown in court showed Daniels' last minutes walking past a corner market, followed by Williams shortly after. A video from an apartment complex on Pleasant Street showed a man identified as Williams approaching Daniels with a gun. Daniels dropped his phone as Williams extended his arm, shooting him in the back.
Then, Williams shot again, striking Daniels in the head twice before taking his belongings and leaving.
During the trial for Fields' death, Leonard said Cambridge police had found Fields lying in his front yard. He had been shot once in the head at close range and robbed of the keys to his Chrysler 300, she said.
Police testified that Fields' car keys and Daniels' phone were recovered from Williams the night he was arrested.
At the sentencing hearing, members of both Daniels' and Fields' families spoke.
Daniels' mother, Barbara Gabbin called her son a giver, adding that he was "full of love."
"Taijay was my world," she said.
Fields' daughter Lauren Davis wrote a letter to her deceased father, which she read at the sentencing.
"I have been so lost without you," she said, later adding that she would give anything for just one more day, one more second with him. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal trial involving multiple murders and life sentences, which directly relates to public safety concerns. While 'Local Government' and 'Local Life' are tangentially related, the core focus on crime and judicial outcomes aligns most closely with 'Public Safety.'

title: CPD juvenile crime report shows juvenile referrals, vehicle thefts are up
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
CPD juvenile crime report shows juvenile referrals, vehicle thefts are up

 March 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 631
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The number of juvenile referrals made by the Cambridge Police Department has increased since 2021, according to a CPD report that looks at juvenile crime from 2021 to 2023.Juvenile referrals are incident reports, written by the police department, that are sent to the Maryland Department of Juvenile Services. According to the report, CPD issued 114 juvenile referrals in 2023. The year before, in 2022, 111 juvenile referrals were issued.
In 2021, 63 juvenile referrals were issued.
Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd said that with juvenile referrals, instead of arresting a child and bringing them back to the police department to be charged, the Department of Juvenile Services steps in.
"Say two children get involved in an assault," Todd said. "They fight each other, there's no serious injuries. We do juvenile referrals and send them to Juvenile Services so Juvenile Services can do their part by following up with the child and the parents, instead of (CPD) actually going through an arrest practice with them."
Todd said a change in juvenile laws has contributed to this rise in referrals.
Under the Maryland Juvenile Justice Reform Act of 2022, children under the age of 13 can only be charged with crimes of violence, which include murder, robbery, carjacking and first-degree assault, among other offenses considered violent.
In its report, CPD states that this act has also made it so that most children are released by police to a parent or guardian unless they are arrested on a warrant or writ issued by the court, or they have a violation involving a firearm or crime of violence.
"So instead of charging a child, we just send a report on over to the Juvenile Services and let it be handled at that level, since it's not a crime of violence," Todd said about the referrals.
The CPD report also shows that the number of juvenile warrant arrests recorded in Cambridge has decreased 80%, from 25 to five, between 2022 and 2023.
Todd noted this change is significant and said it could possibly be attributed to the change in laws as well.
"It's simply because we're not receiving the court orders or the warrants to go and file paperwork against juveniles," he said.
Other than the referrals, Todd said there isn't a huge difference in the data over three years. He said the area where CPD is seeing a big difference is stolen vehicle cases involving youth.
From 2021 to 2023, the number of motor vehicle thefts has gone up from 15 to 102. The CPD report states that for 15 reports of vehicle theft in 2021, 10 cases involved juvenile suspects.
For the 102 reports of vehicle theft in 2023, 29 cases involved juvenile suspects.
In the report, CPD said that in 2023, all of the juvenile offenders caught and charged with vehicle theft were immediately released due to changes in state law.
"Through investigation and statistical analysis, we have determined that the overwhelming suspect profiles for these crimes are male juveniles under the age of 16," the report said. "But we have detained suspects as young as 11 for stealing vehicles in Cambridge."
According to the report, there is one 12-year-old that has been arrested for vehicle theft 11 times in the past three years.
As the number of vehicle thefts have increased in Cambridge, Todd said the current juvenile laws have affected what police can do when the suspect is a child.
"We can't interview that juvenile after we arrested him because of the new juvenile laws," he said. "... We can't go and do an interrogation or anything without first asking — not even permission from the parents — we have to have (the child) obtain a lawyer."
Todd said it's unlikely a lawyer would have the child speak with the police in this instance.
"So that's where our juvenile laws really are starting to affect us," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on juvenile crime statistics, police department reports, and legal changes affecting law enforcement's handling of juvenile cases, all directly related to public safety concerns. While local government operations are mentioned, the core content revolves around crime trends and public safety implications.

title: Stevensville man charged with sexual solicitation of minor
author: Staff Writer
content:
Stevensville man charged with sexual solicitation of minor

 March 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 185
 Words 

 Read News Document

title: Jury acquits woman who stabbed two women in neighborhood fight
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Jury acquits woman who stabbed two women in neighborhood fight

 March 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1193
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A woman maintained that she stabbed two women in self-defense during a dispute that turned physical on the street of a neighborhood near North East in August and a Cecil County Circuit Court jury apparently believed her or concluded that prosecutors fell short of proving otherwise, acquitting the defendant of attempted second-degree murder, first-degree assault and all other charges on Thursday.Jurors deliberated approximately two hours at the conclusion of a three-day-long trial before finding the defendant — Lacey N. Siple, 31 — not guilty across the board. Assistant State's Attorney Ellis Rollins prosecuted the case. Siple was represented by Assistant Public Defender Denise Winston. Cecil County Circuit Court Judge William W. Davis Jr. presided at trial.
Testimony showed that an ongoing dispute between Siple and other people in the Cedar Hill neighborhood, including the two women who suffered stab wounds, cropped up a few times over several days. The disharmony purportedly related to one of Siple's children shooting other kids in the neighborhood with a toy gun that is typically used to fire gel balls. The dispute came to a head in the unit block of Cedar Hill Circle at approximately 9:30 p.m. of Aug. 30 when, according to state witnesses, Siple and the two women got into an argument that turned physical.
Testifying as state witnesses, the two woman who suffered stab wounds admitted to macing Siple during the altercation — but qualified that they did so after she became aggressive, lunging at them.
One woman testified that Siple stabbed her near the shoulder, causing blood to squirt out from the gash, and then stabbed her in the back as she retreated. She suffered a total of four stab wounds, according to state testimony.
The other woman suffered knife wounds, including on her arm and hand. Ambulance crews drove the wounded women to a Delaware hospital for treatment. One law enforcement officer testified that first responders applied a tourniquet to the arm of one of women because her wound was so severe. The ground was covered in blood where the incident occurred and there was at least one blood trial leading to a nearby residence, according to testimony.
Siple testified on her own behalf, giving an account that was similar to another defense witness, a female friend of hers..
They testified that the two women who suffered stab wounds were part of a mob that descended upon them on the street in front of Siple's residence and threatened them, as they were walking to Siple's home to pick up pizza that Siple had forgotten. Siple testified that she had forgotten the pizza because moments earlier, before the mob showed up, four masked men got out of of vehicle and ran toward her children while making threats, prompting them to run into their friend's residence, where they had planned to eat dinner. Siple's friend testified that she volunteered to accompany Siple back to her place to retrieve the forgotten pizza, because it was clear that Siple was terrified.
Siple testified that a man punched her in the face, as the mob behind him started closing in. "I thought I was going to die. I thought they would stomp me," Siple testified.
After Siple had been pepper-sprayed by one of the women, Siple grabbed her knife and started flailing her arms blindly, Siple told jurors. "I was just trying to get home, trying to get home with my kids. I didn't mean to hurt anybody," Siple sobbed on the witness stand, maintaining that she didn't realize that she had stabbed anyone.
Her friend testified that she pulled out her own pepper-spray container and squirted it toward the mob surrounding Siple, causing people to back away and giving her an opening to grab Siple and lead her away. During her testimony, that woman emphasized a few times that the events were frenzied and unfolded swiftly. Once home, Siple tossed the blood-covered knife on her couch, which is where investigators later confiscated the weapon, and dead-bolted the door, according to defense testimony. She did not unlock that door until police arrived.
During his cross examination, Rollins asked Siple why she didn't call police when the four masked men chased and threatened her and her children. He also asked why she didn't do likewise when the mob descended upon her. Siple explained that if she were viewed as a "snitch" in that neighborhood it would put her life and the lives of her four children in jeopardy. In addition, she testified that she was wise enough not to pull out a cell phone in front of a group of aggressors, revealing that she even possessed one, because someone simply would snatch it from her.
Rollins reminded the jury during his closing argument on Wednesday afternoon that Siple had been convicted of theft, which is a crime that involves deceit and, therefore, is one of the convictions that can be used to impeach the credibility of a trial witness. "There was no mob," Rollins asserted.
The prosecutor told jurors that Siple was the "initial aggressor" and spurred an altercation with the two women, whom he opined were forthright in their testimonies. After that altercation with the two women grew into a "more significant fight," Siple grabbed a knife she had in her waistband and lunged toward them with the weapon, according the scenario proffered by Rollins during his closing argument.
"She (Siple) was the aggressor. She started it and she was going to end it," Rollins told jurors before contending, "She raised it to a deadly force level. She upped the ante. She brought a knife to a fistfight."
Along those lines, Rollins maintained that the cuts on hands of one of the women who testified for the state were "defensive wounds" and also told jurors that the women pepper-sprayed Siple to fend her off.
In addition, Rollins told jurors that the women didn't suffer only cuts, but also puncture wounds — calling into question Siple's account of waving the knife blindly. "She didn't just slash the victims; she stabbed them," Rollins stressed.
But Winston emphasized in her closing argument, "My client acted in self-defense."
Winston reminded jurors of where the Aug. 30 confrontation between Siple and the neighbors occurred, as well as the ones that happened during the days leading up to it. "Every time there was an interaction, it happened outside of her house. They went to her; she didn't come to them," Winston told jurors.
Addressing the one woman's stab wound to her back, in context of the state's assertion that she was trying to retreat, Winston told jurors, "If you're twisting and turning, you can get stabbed all over the place."
Winston also told jurors to recall the police body-cam audio that, according to the defense lawyer, captured the terror in Siple's voice when, unbeknownst to her, responding law enforcement officers knocked on her door after the incident. 'She screamed, 'Who is that?'," Winston said. Then that recording reflects a calmness in Siple's voice when she learns that it is police officers knocking on her door, according to Winston. "She says, 'OK, OK, let me unlock the door'," Winston told the jurors.
Summarizing toward the end of closing argument, Winston commented, "They brought the fight to her. She just wanted to go home." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal trial involving a neighborhood altercation, self-defense claims, and legal proceedings, which directly relates to public safety concerns. While local government or national news could marginally apply, the core focus on crime and community safety aligns most strongly with 'Public Safety.'

title: Victim’s dad asks for law he thinks could’ve saved her
author: Tyrah Burris Capital News Service
content:
Victim’s dad asks for law he thinks could’ve saved her

 March 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tyrah Burris Capital News Service | Section: Crime 
 
 407
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A few months after the murder of his daughter in Baltimore, Frank LaPere is asking lawmakers this session to change the law he blames for her death.The man charged with killing tech CEO Pava LaPere might have been in prison at the time of the killing, serving time for a previous charge, but he had been released early under special provisions for good behavior.
"No other victim should fall prey to repeat violent sexual offenders," LaPere's father told lawmakers in a recent committee hearing. "We cannot allow the system that failed Pava to continue."
The bill he is pushing for would prohibit people incarcerated for first-degree rape or first-degree sexual offense from receiving what are known as "diminution credits," reducing the length of incarceration for behavior like attending classes or therapy.
The defendant in LaPere's killing was released early from prison with diminution credits, according to news accounts. He is scheduled to go to trial this summer.
Diminution credits are "an incentive tool used behind the wall to maintain order, encourage good behavior and offer opportunities to learn and develop the skills needed to return to the community," said Marguerite Lanaux, the district public defender of Baltimore City.
Del. Jackie Addison, D-Baltimore City, said that, as a mother and grandmother, she hopes to see the measure passed this legislative session.
"I have three daughters and a granddaughter and I would never want that to happen to anyone, not just my family but anyone," Addison, a co-sponsor of the bill, said in an interview with Capital News Service. "I just pray that it does get passed because it is a very important bill, and we need the bill."
But some public defenders say that taking away diminution credits won't incentivize inmates to do the work while they are still incarcerated to prepare them for the real world, and it won't make communities safer because they will be released anyway.
An alternative option, they say, would be providing better programs for sexual offenders in Division of Corrections facilities.
The measure would "make the DOC a more traumatizing place so across the board it will have a negative effect on all incarcerated people and our communities when they are released," said Gabriel Ellenberger, of the public defender's office, during a committee hearing.
The proposed measure is named after Pava LaPere, who was the CEO of a tech startup company called EcoMap Technologies.
"While she is physically gone from this world her vision and dreams will still live on," LaPere said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on legislative efforts to address prison release policies for violent offenders, aiming to prevent future crimes and protect communities. This directly relates to public safety concerns, with secondary ties to local government actions and broader legislative processes.

title: Sewer line broken in Federalsburg
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Sewer line broken in Federalsburg

 March 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: News 
 
 205
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — A sewer line was broken near the Dart Container Factory in Federalsburg Industrial Park on Wednesday.Workers were on the scene working to repair the break, laying pipe and pumping the liquid through a long tube to a man hole on Reliance Road.
"A sewer line was hit by a contractor working in the area. Dart is the only business that is affected," said Federalsburg Town Manager Kristy Marshall in an email Wednesday afternoon. "Details are still being worked out regarding repairs, but no other businesses or residences are affected. There is no damage to pumps or wells or water towers."
Federalsburg has experienced several outages related to water and sewer since the beginning of the year.
On Feb. 20, a downed tree behind Holland Drive uprooted a main water line, causing a "massive leak," town officials said at the time, leading to complaints from residents about lacking water pressure.
A month earlier, the town experienced a water shutdown that lasted from Jan. 26 to Jan. 30 after a power outage at the water and sewage plant caused the town's water pumps to fail, depleting water in the system and leaving air in the lines.
Dart Container had no further comment on the March 7 sewer line break.

 CENTREVILLE — No direct action on the town's part is planned at this time regarding the dilapidated mill located adjacent to Mill Stream Park on Route 213, running through Centreville."We are in continued conversations with the owner on addressing any issues at the property," Town Council President Ashley Kaiser said.
The mill is privately owned by Charles Geschwilm of Easton. Geschwilm has been very cooperative with the council, and has been very open to discussion and communication and regularly meeting with town officials, Kaiser said.
Council member Jeff Kiel said the owner of the mill had a structural engineer review the structure who stated it was structurally sound, but noted, "metal is falling off the building."
With fears lessened the structure will fall into the roadway, the owner is now working to have a contractor repair the metal of the building to prevent exposure to the elements and maintain structural integrity.
The mill owner has been doing some repair himself and is currently seeking professionals for roof work, according to Kaiser, who said the town will work to identify contractors and to assist as it can.

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man has been arrested on assault, reckless endangerment and theft charges.Tavonte Mijay Ennals, 22, was arrested on an arrest warrant March 3, according to a news release from the Cambridge Police Department.

Police said the victim reported Ennals had bitten them and burned them with a cigarette.
According to the news release, Cambridge officers observed signs of injury consistent with the victim's report.
Ennals was charged with first- and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment and theft less than $100.
Upon arrest, Ennals was transported to CPD for processing and an initial court appearance and then turned over to the Dorchester County Department of Corrections on no bond.

title: Cambridge police investigating armed carjacking

 CAMBRIDGE — The Cambridge Police Department is investigating an armed carjacking that was reported on March 6.According to a news release from CPD, a silver 2016 Ford Focus with Maryland license plate number 14296CL was last observed on security cameras traveling south on Leonards Lane toward Washington Street. Police are looking for two male suspects involved in the incident.
The incident occurred in the 500 block of Greenwood Avenue, police said.
According to the news release, the victim of the carjacking told police they had been asked to pick up a friend and drive them home. Police said the victim reportedly picked up that friend on Teal Lane and picked up another man on Foxtail Drive.
Police said the victim was then told to give both men a ride to the 500 block of Greenwood Avenue, where the men reportedly threatened the victim in the parking lot of an apartment complex. Police said the one suspect reportedly pulled out a gun and handed it the other suspect in front seat, who pointed it at the victim and threatened to shoot them.
The other suspect exited the vehicle and went to the drivers side of the car and punched the victim, according to the news release.
Police said the victim reported that after a struggle, they fled on foot and ran to Willis Street, where they requested help from a FedEx driver.
According to the news release, the suspect picked up on Teal Lane was described as a 6-foot tall African American man with a skinny build, short dreadlocks and chin hair. Police said he reportedly appeared to be around 18-years-old. He was reported wearing a red sweatshirt and black sweatpants.
The suspect picked up on Foxtail Drive was described as a 5 foot 9 inch or 5 foot 10 inch African American man with a buzzcut and beard. Police said he was reported wearing yellow sweatpants, a yellow t-shirt and a black puffy jacket.
Police said this investigation is active, and the department is requesting assistance from the community with any information related to the incident. CPD's Criminal Investigations Division can be reached at 410-228-3333. All callers can remain anonymous.
Police said that if someone sees the vehicle, they should not approach it and call 911 or their local law enforcement agency.

The operator of a Jeep, identified as Christopher McMullen, 31, of Federalsburg, and a passenger, as well as the operator of a GMC, were transported by ambulance to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton for treatment of their injuries.

title: Ridgely suspends entire police department
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Ridgely suspends entire police department

 March 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 251
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Commissioners of Ridgely suspended the entire Ridgely Police Department with pay, effective immediately, pending an investigation by the Office of the Maryland State Prosecutor, according to a Wednesday release from the town.The commissioners are developing a temporary agreement with the Caroline County Sheriff's Department to guarantee uninterrupted public safety services for the Ridgely residents, the release said.
According to the Ridgely Police Department website, six officers are employed by the department.
The Commissioners of Ridgely met in closed session Monday evening to discuss matters of personnel and "to consult with staff, consultants, or other individuals about pending or potential litigation," according to an agenda for the meeting posted to the town's website.
Sheriff Donnie Baker said the Caroline County Sheriff's Department is ready to continue to provide services to the town of Ridgely.
"We cover the town when their police is off the clock," Baker said. "We provide them with back up. We're familiar with the citizens."
A statement from the Sheriff's Office read, "Given the recent events involving the Ridgely Police Department, the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, in collaboration with the Caroline County Commissioners and the Commissioners of the Town of Ridgely, are committed to providing continuous police services to the town's citizens, ensuring their safety remains a top priority. Together with the Maryland State Police, the Sheriff's Office will guarantee seamless and uninterrupted police coverage within the town limits of Ridgely."
Residents are asked to continue to dial 410-479-2515 for non-emergencies and 911 for emergencies.
This report will be updated as information becomes available.

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A Cambridge man pleaded guilty Monday to altering evidence in an August 2023 fatal shooting in Easton.Raheem Green, 28, was handed a suspended 18-month sentence with credit for time served and three years of probation — the first year supervised — after entering an Alford plea Monday morning.
An Alford plea allows a person to maintain their innocence while acknowledging the state had enough evidence to obtain a conviction.
The Aug. 7 shooting took place in the 100 block of Blake Street and resulted in the death of Ty Brooks, 55, of Easton.
In late February, 22-year-old Deseir Cornish, of Denton, pleaded guilty to manslaughter and possession of a handgun in the death of Brooks. Cornish was sentenced to 10 years in prison and five years of supervised probation upon his release.
Green had initially been charged with acting as an accessory after the fact of murder for allegedly helping Cornish flee from the scene and discard evidence. The charge was amended to altering physical evidence.
At the plea hearing Monday, Talbot County Circuit Judge Broughton Earnest read the conditions of the plea agreement. He said that per the agreement, the state and defense would agree to dropping an additional charge of accessory after the fact, and Green would receive a fully suspended sentence with a 25-day credit for time served and probation.
At the hearing, Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale detailed what happened the day Brooks was found unresponsive in the grass with three gunshot wounds.
Coale said Brooks had gotten into an argument with a group of young men around a white Range Rover parked on Blake Street that day. He said Brooks left Blake Street and returned with a shotgun, operating an ATV. When Brooks approached the passenger side front window of the Range Rover on the ATV and held up the shotgun, Cornish shot Brooks with a handgun.
Coale said Green was outside the driver's side of the Range Rover at the time and got into a Hyundai to leave the area. He said Cornish, who was in the Range Rover with other individuals, followed Green.
Green told police that he drove to a gas station. At the gas station Cornish asked to use Green's cellphone. After Cornish returned the cellphone to Green, a passenger in the Range Rover told Green where to meet them so they could abandon the Range Rover.
Upon abandoning the vehicle, Green gave the individuals that had been in the Range Rover a ride, Coale said.
After Coale spoke, Green's attorney, Stephanie Shipley, said Green was not a part of the group of young men, adding that Green is in his late 20s. She said Green left the scene in his car when he heard gunshots, and the Range Rover followed him without him telling them to do so.
Shipley later said Green was simply "in the wrong place at the wrong time," and the only mistake he made was lending Cornish his cell phone and giving the individuals in the Range Rover — including Cornish — a ride. She said Green didn't know Brooks had been killed when he gave them the ride.
After accepting the plea, Earnest said that although he did not want to ignore the emotional trauma Brooks' family has faced, he didn't think Green was directly involved in the shooting and accepted the sentencing recommendations made by the State's Attorney's Office and the defense. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal case involving a fatal shooting and legal proceedings related to evidence alteration, directly tying to public safety concerns. While local government and national news could marginally apply, public safety most accurately reflects the crime-focused content.

title: Rider discharged from hospital, to receive treatment before return to detention center
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Rider discharged from hospital, to receive treatment before return to detention center

 March 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 405
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — After being admitted to Johns Hopkins Hospital a few weeks ago, Fred "Trey" Rider III has been discharged, and a judge has granted his request to be transferred to Avenues Recovery Center at Eastern Shore, an alcohol and drug rehabilitation facility in Cambridge, for 60 days.Rider is accused of setting his house on fire in November 2022.
Through investigation, officials identified the fire as an act of human intervention with an open flame, classifying the cause of fire as incendiary. According to court documents, Rider's reckless conduct in igniting the house on fire "clearly" put emergency services personnel, specifically more than 45 firefighters who responded, in danger as they suppressed the fire.
Rider faces 15 charges for this, including arson, malicious destruction of property and reckless endangerment.
A trial for the case was set to begin March 4, but at a status hearing that morning, Judge Thomas G. Ross stated that Rider had been voluntarily admitted to Johns Hopkins and issued a bench warrant for Rider's failure to appear in court that morning.
According to court documents, Rider was discharged from Johns Hopkins Hospital and placed in the custody of Deputy Fire Marshal Shayne McKinney on Monday.
In court documents, Rider's attorney Stephanie Shipley wrote that Rider and his counsel did not know he was being discharged immediately Monday morning following an endoscopy procedure and recovery from anesthesia.
Following the discharge, Rider, through his defense, requested to be released to Avenues Recovery Center for inpatient treatment "pursuant to the active referral from Johns Hopkins Hospital Psychiatric Department."
According to court documents filed by Rider's defense, Rider's social worker Joseph Antonetti advised over the phone that Rider had obtained long-term placement in Avenues Recovery Center for 60 days.
At a bail review and status hearing on Tuesday, according to court documents, Ross granted Rider a bed-to-bed transfer to Avenues Recovery Center from the Talbot County Detention Center.
The conditions of this transfer, outlined in court documents, are that Rider must be fitted with a GPS tracking device, cannot leave Avenues Recovery Center for any reason and must return to the detention center upon completion of the 60-day inpatient program.
Included in the conditions of this transfer, Rider cannot be given access to internet or any social media accounts. He cannot have contact with any state witnesses, other than his parents, Peggy Rider and Fred Rider Jr.
A hearing for Rider's case is set for April 3. The trial is set to begin Aug. 19. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
