title: Two Cambridge residents charged with abuse in girl's death
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Two Cambridge residents charged with abuse in girl's death

 March 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 285
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Two Cambridge residents have been arrested and charged with first-degree child abuse resulting in death and neglect of a minor.David Allen Insley, 53, and Mandy Leigh Insley, 47, were arrested Feb. 21 following an incident that occurred in June 2023.
According to a news release from the Cambridge Police Department, on June 26, 2023, officers, along with Dorchester County Emergency Medical Services, responded to the 100 block of Mako Drive following a report of a medical emergency.
Police said when officers arrived, they observed family members of a 14-year-old girl attempting lifesaving measures on the girl. Dorchester County EMS confirmed the girl had died.
Police said because of the living conditions officers observed at the home, the Criminal Investigations Division of CPD assisted with the investigation, along with the assistance of Child Protective Services, Cambridge Code Enforcement and Dorchester County Animal Control.
According to the news release, Cambridge Code Enforcement condemned the house.
Police said the Criminal Investigations Division consulted with the Dorchester County State's Attorney's Office for the investigation, resulting in the investigation being submitted to a grand jury where an indictment was issued for David and Mandy Insleys' arrests on Feb. 20.
A trial is scheduled for July 16.
Both David and Mandy Insley have been released before the trial under level five supervision. This means that the Insleys are under house arrest with a curfew and GPS restrictions. This level of supervision entails weekly meetings with a case manager and random drug testing.
An additional requirement to their pre-trial releases is that they cannot have pets or minors in their home.
According to court documents, a notice of a pretrial violation was filed in early March based on information obtained that the Insleys had dogs in their home.

 EASTON — An 18-wheel sewage truck crashed through a guardrail on the right lane heading east on U.S. Route 50 near Hiner's Lane on Monday morning. According to an official on the scene, "at least no one died."The accident closed the eastbound lanes.
The truck veered off the passenger lane, through the guard rail and slid over 100 yards into a wooded ravine. The path of the truck tore through a front yard, leaving pieces of the guard rail and fragments of the truck.
Easton firefighters and State Patrol officers responded. The Department of the Environment had a blue emergency response team truck at the site of the accident.
Eastbound traffic was detoured off Route 50 to Longwoods Road and met back up with the highway near Easton Airport.
There was no odor of sewage at the site.

title: Arson-sniffing K-9 retires from fire marshal's office
author: Staff Writer
content:
Arson-sniffing K-9 retires from fire marshal's office

 March 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 358
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For over seven years, Senior Deputy State Fire Marshal Melissa Decker and her partner, K-9 Sky, have assisted fire investigators across Maryland and beyond in finding trace amounts of flammable liquids to help build cases against arsonists or to rule out their use so investigators can focus on other potential reasons for a fire.Sky is hanging up her badge, and the beloved accelerant detection canine officially retired last week.
Trained by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, K-9 Sky started in the "Puppy Behind Bars" program, where she lived with and was socialized by inmates who provided basic training to service dogs. The ATF procured Sky and assigned her to the accelerant detection program. Together, Decker and Sky graduated from Class No. 117 in December 2016.
Sky has worked alongside firefighters and investigators, responding to countless calls, assisting in investigations, and meeting what Decker estimates are thousands of people while working community and school events and public demonstrations across Maryland.
Decker and Sky traveled regularly to the Federal Law Enforcement Training Center in Glyco, Georgia, where they assisted in training ATF agents during their academy.
Known for their keen sense of smell and unwavering commitment to their work, accelerant detection canines like Sky have been instrumental in identifying accelerants such as gasoline, lighter fluid, kerosene and even odorless solvents used in arson cases. Sky is a food-reward canine and has been fed with Decker's hand tens of thousands of times. On Friday, Sky celebrated with a bowl of food, her first since joining the program.
"As Sky enters retirement, everyone at the Office of the State Fire Marshal expresses our gratitude for Sky and Decker's commitment to keeping Maryland safe," said Chief Deputy and Acting State Fire Marshal Jason M. Mowbray. "We wish Sky a well-deserved restful retirement filled with treats, belly rubs and endless playtime."
Although she is now retired, Sky will soon have company. Starting this week, Decker will travel to the ATF Canine Training Center in Front Royal, Virginia, for six weeks to work with a new partner. When the pair graduate, they will return to Maryland and be one of only 71 teams in the United States. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on an arson-sniffing K-9 dog's retirement after years of service in fire investigations, highlighting its role in public safety through arson detection and community safety efforts. title: Easton council approves 7 vehicles for Easton police
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Easton council approves 7 vehicles for Easton police

 March 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 347
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Monday evening, the Easton Town Council voted to provide additional financial assistance to the Easton Police Department.On the agenda, the council modified Ordinance 810, a budget modification ordinance to allocate over $1.69 million from the American Rescue Plan Act.
The council had initially allocated funds to the Doverbrook affordable housing project, the North Harrison Street stormwater project, the North Hazel Street stormwater project and finally, the purchase of four police vehicles.
The remaining funds from the American Rescue Plan Act were about $240,885.
Before voting to approve Ordinance 810, Councilmember David Montgomery said he would like to modify the funds for the police department. Montgomery suggested that the remaining funds should be allocated to assist the Easton Police Department with purchasing the rest of the department's police vehicles.
Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey originally requested financial assistance for eight vehicles, but the council approved the purchase of four police vehicles.
Montgomery offered an amendment to increase the allocation of police vehicles from four to seven, using the remainder of the funds from the American Rescue Plan Act.
"I would like to see us fully fund the police vehicles that are needed, according to Chief Laurie, rather than leaving money on the table at this point," Montgomery said. "I think that's a clear need. It's a public service safety, which should be our highest priority."
Councilmember Maureen Curry supported the modification of additional financial support. The council estimated that each police vehicle would cost approximately $80,000. The council agreed to increase the funds from the original $320,000 to $560,000, an increase of $240,000.
The council unanimously approved both the amendment and the modified Ordinance 810.
Other News
The council unanimously approved Resolution 623, authorizing a lease agreement between the town of Easton and the state of Maryland for a district court facility.
The council approved Resolution 618, authorizing a lease agreement between the town of Easton and the state of Maryland for a Maryland Veterans Affairs Office. The council unanimously approved the resolution.
The public hearing for Ordinance 809 regulating cannabis uses was continued to the next meeting to allow for updates from the state legislature. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cambridge murder trial postponed until July
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge murder trial postponed until July

 March 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 796
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A trial for a Cambridge teen charged in the 2021 fatal shooting of Ja'Len Woolford has been postponed until July.Although a trial for Key'Marion Ennals, 18, was supposed to begin Monday morning, it was pushed to the week of July 22.
Ennals faces first- and second-degree murder, assault and firearm charges in connection to the Nov. 18, 2021, shooting death of Woolford, along with additional assault and reckless endangerment charges relating to four other victims.
Daeveon Johnson, 18, of Cambridge, was also charged in the shooting and entered an Alford plea to first-degree murder in November 2022. In his initial interview with police, Johnson admitted to carrying a .40 caliber firearm. An autopsy revealed that Woolford died from a single gunshot wound from a .40 caliber firearm.
Last Thursday, Ennals' defense filed an emergency motion requesting to dismiss the case or provide alternative relief. Monday morning, instead of bringing a jury into the courtroom, a motion hearing was held.
According to court documents, along with the dismissal request, Ennals' attorneys Larry Greenberg and Brice Litus also asked that the prosecutor, Jonathon Church of the Prince George's County State's Attorney's Office, be disqualified from the case.
Church assumed the case in October after the Dorchester County State's Attorney's Office was disqualified from the case.
In the motion filed last week, Ennals' defense asked that if the court does not grant these requests, the trial be postponed.
In a motion filed Thursday and a supplement to the motion filed Friday, Ennals' defense said the state has two audio recordings of witness statements that the defense was unaware of until Thursday afternoon. One of those statements, they said, implicates a suspect that is not Ennals.
The defense also said it was not provided certain data related to the case from a DNA anaylst, including "hundreds of pages of documents," until Friday.
Ennals' defense said it discovered the audio recordings and other documents that had been uploaded to a Google Drive in the previous three weeks "by happenstance," without the state's disclosure of the additional evidence.
The defense said multiple files it received last week would not open. The files that were accessible, the defense attorneys said, appear to contain exculpatory or impeachment evidence. Exculpatory evidence is evidence that is favorable to the defendant or could exonerate the defendant.
"Trial is scheduled to begin in two days in a murder trial and we are still receiving new evidence," Greenberg and Litus wrote in the supplemental motion.
In response, Church said the defense had been aware of the recordings for a year and never mentioned or requested them, according to court documents. He said the state did not receive a request for the complete DNA file until March 11, and the state doesn't intend to introduce any DNA evidence in the case.
At the motion hearing Monday, Greenberg he was "disheartened" by the situation. He said he had a conversation with Church on Friday where Church admitted to not turning over the additional evidence.
Church said he had offered to meet with Ennals' defense in mid-November, which he said would have resolved "99%" of these issues.
Judge Thomas G. Ross said he wouldn't grant the motion to dismiss, but would postpone the trial and charge it to the state. Ross also required the state to file all evidence and provide a complete list of the evidence produced.
BACKGROUND OF THE CASE
This is not the first time Ennals' defense has filed a motion to dismiss this case.
In September, Greenberg filed a motion to dismiss the case due to the lack of a speedy trial along with a motion to disqualify Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard and the Dorchester County State's Attorney's Office from the case.
That same month, less than two weeks before a trial for Ennals was set to begin in, according to Greenberg and documented in court papers, Leonard told Greenberg she met with Daeveon Johnson — also charged in the shooting — to prepare for the trial and learned that two other people were involved.
According to previous Star Democrat reporting, in a Sept. 27 hearing, Greenberg asserted that the information shared in the interview was exculpatory. Not disclosing exculpatory information to defense attorneys is a violation of the Brady rule, which requires prosecutors to turn over information that could exonerate a defendant.
At the hearing, 1st Judicial Circuit Administrative Judge S. James Sarbanes granted the motion to disqualify Leonard and the Dorchester County State's Attorney's Office from prosecuting Ennals. Sarbanes said he was "troubled" by recent happenings in the case against Ennals, particularly relating to evidence disclosures and the perception and appearance of fairness.
In February Greenberg and Litus filed two separate motions to dismiss the case. Reasons they listed for why the case should be dismissed included lack of a speedy trial, Brady violations and ex-parte communications between the state and the court. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a murder trial postponement involving criminal charges, legal proceedings, and public safety implications. While it has local context, the core subject relates to public safety due to the nature of the crime and legal system involvement.

title: Caroline commissioners discuss plan for public safety after Ridgely police suspension
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Caroline commissioners discuss plan for public safety after Ridgely police suspension

 March 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 216
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Tuesday morning, the Commissioners of Caroline County shared its plan to maintain a safety system in Ridgely after the recent suspension of the Ridgely Police Department.According to a press release from the town, on March 13, the commissioners of Ridgely suspended the entire Ridgely police department with pay, effective immediately, pending an investigation by the Office of the Maryland State Prosecutor.
No reason for the investigation was immediately indicated.
According to the Ridgely Police Department website, six officers are employed by the department.
At their March 19 morning, the county commissioners shared their plan for a temporary agreement with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office to provide public safety services for the citizens of Ridgely.
The commission explained that the Caroline County Sheriff's Office and the Maryland State Police would divide responsibilities for providing law enforcement to the town.
The sheriff's office will work one five-hour shift a day for seven days a week.
The Caroline County Sheriff's Office will lead half of 911 dispatch calls for the town, and every other call will go to the Maryland State Police.
The commissioners also agreed that Sheriff Donald Baker will secure warrants and firearms for the Ridgely police department. Baker will secure the front door of the Ridgely Police Department.
Caroline County's Police Accountability Board has a pending a case involving the Ridgely Police Department.

title: Mother of girl killed in Christmas Day fire facing 23 charges
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Mother of girl killed in Christmas Day fire facing 23 charges

 March 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1674
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ELKTON — The mother of a 10-year-old girl who was killed in a townhouse fire near Elkton on Christmas morning faces multiple charges — including involuntary manslaughter, child neglect and reckless endangerment — after investigators concluded that hoarding, overloaded electrical outlets and a lack of smoke detectors inside the dwelling were factors in the deadly blaze, according to Cecil County District Court records.For the same alleged reasons, the mother's live-in boyfriend is facing the same 23 criminal charges that have been filed against her, police reported.
Maryland State Police investigators arrested the suspects — Theresa Ann Moats, 40, and Kevin Neal Summerfield, 41, now both of New Castle, Del. — on Friday, March 15, and charged each of them with involuntary manslaughter, neglect of a minor, reckless endangerment and 20 counts of animal cruelty, court records show.
A portion of the charging documents filed against Moats and Summerfield focus on horrid living conditions discovered inside their Willow Drive townhouse where, according to Moats' own admission, as many as 35 pets, mostly dogs and cats, were kept at the same time.
In addition, court records allege that a "vast majority of the floor was covered in caked animal feces" and that the odor of animal urine and feces was pungent throughout the dwelling when Cecil County Department of Animal Services agents responded to that townhouse on Dec. 20 — five days before the fatal fire — after receiving a complaint.
Moats and Summerfield remained in the Cecil County Detention Center on no bond Wednesday night, two days after their bail review hearings, according to court records, which indicate that Cecil County District Court Judge Clara E. Campbell presided over that proceeding. Preliminary hearings for Moats and Summerfield have been set for April 10, court records show.
Moats' daughter — Kyleigh Nicole Treadway — perished in the swift-moving, two-alarm blaze that broke out inside 317 Willow Dr. in the Winding Brook neighborhood, northeast of Elkton, shortly before 7:30 a.m. on Dec. 25, 2023. Kyleigh was trapped inside that burning townhouse after her mother (Moats), her grandmother, her two older brothers and her mother's boyfriend (Summerfield) had escaped.
Court records indicate a woman believed to be Kyleigh's mother approached Capt. William Ryan of Singerly Volunteer Fire Company during the fire and told him that "her baby was right inside the front door."
"Due to the magnitude and intensity of the fire, Ryan and other firefighters were unable to immediately enter the residence to recover the child. When it was safe to enter the residence, Captain Ryan pushed inside the residence and located the deceased child. The child was located near the front door of the residence," according to court records.
An autopsy revealed that Kyleigh's cause of death was listed as smoke inhalation and thermal injuries that included burns covering much of her body, according to police.
Including Kyleigh's five surviving family members, the blaze displaced 17 residents in the three adjacent townhouses damaged by the fire.
POSSIBLE CAUSES
Detectives with the Maryland Office of the State Fire Marshal determined that the blaze that killed Kyleigh started accidentally on the first floor inside an 8'-by-8' room, which was an addition at the rear of the townhouse, and that the cause is either an electric "overload situation based on the multiple operating appliances" or "improperly discarded smoking materials," court records show.
During their investigation, MOSFM investigators discovered multiple electrical power cords connected to one another, which were then all connected to a power strip. The extension cords were wound through the rest of the residence, including around and behind appliances and into the townhouse's backyard.
During her interview with MSP investigators, Moats mentioned the electrical power cords in the backroom where the fire started, police said. Moats said she tried to extinguish the flames after her son woke her up in her second-floor bedroom to alert her about the blaze, police added.
"Theresa observed the 'orange fire' and attempted to put it out using water. Her efforts were in vain. Theresa explained that the backroom was filled with boxes of clothing and miscellaneous items. Among these items was an electrical power cord that was connected to an outside grill. She stated the grill was inoperable. Theresa Moats stated 'this all could have been preventable and that she misses her daughter.' She felt bad and felt it was her fault," according to the charging document.
As for the possibility of improperly discarded smoking materials causing the blaze, investigators noted that they found "several empty Newport cigarette containers and cigarette-style lighters" in that backroom, court records show.
In recorded interviews with MSP investigators, the adults who lived in that Willow Drive townhouse told detectives that smoke detectors had been installed one year before the fire and that they were operational, police said.
However, fire investigators reported that they were unable to locate the remains of any smoke detectors within the townhouse. They further reported that the lack of smoke detectors likely caused a delay in the evacuation of the residence.
In addition, MOSFM detectives reported that they documented "residential hoarding conditions" inside the Willow Court townhouse during their investigation. Specifically, the detectives cited an "overabundance of combustibles and clothing" in the living room, in the dining/kitchen area and in the rear backroom where the fire started, noting that they removed large trash bags of clothing from there and that a connecting storage closet also was filled with combustibles, court records show.
Court records further state that the poor conditions of the home, the amount of 'hoarding', as well as the widespread animal waste and overabundance of trash and other combustibles — combined with the lack of smoke detection — likely delayed and hampered the home's evacuation.
ANIMAL SERVICES INVESTIGATION
Charging documents indicate that two Cecil County Department of Animal Services officers went to 317 Willow Dr. on Dec. 20 — five days before the fatal fire there — and impounded 18 animals — 14 dogs and four cats — that showed signs of neglect and abuse, after receiving a call regarding "multiple canines of various ages located within the residence," court records show.
The officers heard "excessive barking" when they knocked on the door, which continued when Summerfield let them inside the dwelling, police said. Once inside, police added, the officers "detected the smell of animal urine and feces."
Court records allege that the officers observed eight pit bull mixed puppies of "average health and slightly underweight" crated without food and water. Officers also saw eight adult canines of mixed breeds and several cats of various ages inside the townhouse, court records show.
The officers further reported that a vast majority of the floor was covered in caked animal waste. Officers informed Moats and Summerfield that their animals could not remain in such conditions, resulting in several animals being surrendered to the officers. Officers reported that the surrendered puppies immediately ran to empty water bowls and attempted to drink after they were uncrated.
"When the officers arrived at the animal shelter, two emaciated puppies were found to be very dehydrated and needed subcutaneous fluids. All puppies ate and drank ravenously. Two crates of puppies each drank an entire bucket of water," according to the charging documents.
During interviews with police, Summerfield, Moats and Moats' mother admitted that not all of the pets had been vaccinated; that the dogs urinated and defecated inside the townhouse "all the time;" and that the cats would "urinate and defecate everywhere and it would get on Kyleigh's clothes," court records show. Summerfield acknowledged to investigators that the "pet situation" was "ridiculous" and excessive, police reported.
After they impounded the 18 animals from that Willow Drive townhouse, the Animal Services officers "planned to make a report to Child Protective Services, as the children in the home were subjected to poor living conditions," according to the charging documents.
SIGNS AT SCHOOL
On Jan. 11, some 17 days after the fatal fire, an MSP investigator and a Cecil County Department of Social Services supervisor went to Cecil Manor Elementary School in Elk Mills, where Kyleigh had been a fourth-grade student, and interviewed her teachers, guidance and school nurse — all of whom cited signs of possible child neglect, court records show.
According to the charging document, school officials were concerned over Kyleigh's hygiene, reporting that her hair and clothes would often emanate smells of animal waste. School officials also noted that other students in her class would avoid Kyleigh due to the smell of her clothes.
The school nurse routinely washed Kyleigh's clothes and washed and brushed the girl's hair on multiple occasions because it was "matted, itchy and foul-smelling," police said. Staff members replaced Kyleigh's backpack twice because cats at her residence urinated and vomited on top of her previous backpacks, police added.
"Kyleigh's hygiene issues were described as 'terrible' and they needed to be addressed 3-4 times per day. Kyleigh stated to teachers that she had a 'ton' of pets and that she loved them," court records allege.
Court records allege that school staff attempted to contact Moats by email and by phone, but there was "absolutely no involvement to address concern brought forth by the school," including the concerns that Kyleigh was "disoriented during school and not mentally present," that she never completed homework assignments, and that she was academically performing at a level several years behind her peers.
School staff members alleged that Moats "showed a lack of care for Kyleigh," according to the charging documents, which also indicate that "daily communication logs were sent home and they were never signed or acknowledged by Kyleigh's guardians."
School officials told investigators that referrals were made to the Department of Social Services after Kyleigh moved with her family from Delaware and started attending Cecil Manor Elementary School and that the school provided a "vast amount of support to Kyleigh and her family."
In one section of the charging documents, it reads, "Prior to Christmas 2023, the school counselor visited Kyleigh's residence to drop off food and presents. The occupants (guardians) were unable to open the front door fully. Without stepping inside the residence, the school counselor could smell animal urine and feces emanating from the inside. Animal feces were observed on the floor of the residence when the door was ajar."

title: Firefighter injured in Cambridge fire
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Firefighter injured in Cambridge fire

 March 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 160
 Words

 CAMBRIDGE — A firefighter was transported to TidalHealth in Salisbury March 22 for non-life-threatening burns sustained battling a structure fire at a three-story single family house on Travers Street.According to a news release from the Office of the State Fire Marshal, Friday's two-alarm fire took 50 firefighters an hour to control. The fire, which resulted in an estimated loss of $400,000, was discovered by a neighbor.
Rescue Fire Company was the primary responding fire department.
According to a news release from Rescue Fire Company, 15 fire companies were on the scene to control the blaze. The news release said a second firefighter received minor injuries while on the scene, but refused care.
The fire originated in the utility room on the first floor of the house, the Office of the State Fire Marshal said. The cause of the fire is still under investigation.
No arrests have been made, and no other injuries were reported, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal.

title: Eclipse 2024: Extra police, even National Guard troops being deployed amid alerts, government warnings
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Eclipse 2024: Extra police, even National Guard troops being deployed amid alerts, government warnings

 March 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: Eclipse 
 
 1068
 Words 

 Read News Document

 More police will be deployed, some National Guard troops are being activated and put at the ready and emergency orders along with aviation alerts have been issued for the total solar eclipse set to sweep across the U.S. on Monday, April 8.The eclipse will be visible across the continental U.S. with a swath of the country — from Texas to New England — experiencing as much as four minutes of daytime darkness with the moon blocking the sun.
Eclipse day and the weekend leading up to are expected to be one of the busiest travel periods in U.S. history.
That is prompting concerns about traffic congestion and how the events and expected high usage rates will impact internet and other communications connections including electronic transactions and payment systems.
Gasoline supplies could be impacted in prime viewing regions.
TROOPS ACTIVATED
The Oklahoma National Guard is activating troops from a civil support unit to assist local government agencies during the eclipse. That includes members of a hazardous materials team.
The Oklahoma guard said March 18 it received a request for resources from the McCurtain County Emergency Management agency.
The state is in the path of totality where the moon will completely shield the sun on April 8.
Oklahoma officials expect as many 100,000 visitors to McCurtain County in the southeastern part of the state. The county, which has a population of approximately 31,000 people, is part of the sprawling Choctaw Nation Indian territory. The tribe is hosting a number of eclipse events.
"McCurtain County Emergency Management requested our support because they expect up to 100,000 additional people visiting their communities to watch the eclipse," said Lt. Col. Jabonn Flurry, an Oklahoma National Guard commander. "This influx of visitors has the potential to overtax local resources and thanks to the training and experience our Guardsmen have working alongside local agencies all across Oklahoma, the (Civil Support Team) is uniquely qualified to support our fellow Oklahomans."
Other states are deploying more state police and have National Guard troops and resources at the ready for the eclipse.
"The New York National Guard is prepared to provide troops and two of our Naval Militia patrol boats if required," said Eric Durr, public affairs director of the New York State Division of Military and Naval Affairs.
Durr said the Empire State's homeland security agency has not yet tasked the Guard with any eclipse-related deployments.
The eclipse's totality path will go through upstate New York including Rochester, Buffalo and Niagara Falls.
The New York State Police is implementing emergency plans and will deploy more troopers statewide for the eclipse, the agency announced Monday, March 25.
In Arkansas, the state's National Guard was part of pre-eclipse training exercises March 13 with state emergency managers and police. Arkansas' emergency control center will be activated April 6 through April 10.
The state expects as many as 1.5 million visitors for the eclipse and another 500,000 Arkansans traveling to areas of totality.
POLICE PRESENCE
Local police, state highway patrols and other law enforcement and emergency agencies across the country are planning for increased patrols, staffing and deployments for the celestial event.
"We will have additional staffing working the day of the eclipse in order to have more resources available since there will be additional people in the city," said Stan Reno, chief of police in Carbondale, Illinois, in the southern part of the state.
Reno does not expect additional state resources.
In Texas, which is viewed as a prime eclipse viewing spot in the U.S. because of its comparatively clearer skies than other totality locations, police, emergency and transportation managers are preparing for a deluge of visitors and in-state travelers to view the events.
More than 1 million people could visit the state, according to the Texas Department of Transportation.
"The public should expect a police presence on our roadways and across the city, the day of the event," said Jennifer Pryor, a public information officer with the Dallas Police Department.
"While the department is working to keep our roadways and streets safe during the eclipse, the public should be prepared for increased traffic and delays. Traffic may impact all areas of DFW (Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport), not just the city of Dallas. Plan extra time for your travels," she said.
Sgt. Tyler Ross, a spokesperson for the Ohio Highway Patrol, said there will be more police out for the eclipse and like other police warns motorists not to stop on the side of highways to view the astronomical event.
"Leading up to, during and after the eclipse, our troopers will be highly visible, enforcing all traffic laws and ready to assist, ensuring traffic flows smoothly and everyone enjoys this rare event safely," Ross said. "Remember, stopping on the side of roads or exit ramps for viewing is prohibited and unsafe."
The eclipse will be the largest such event in the U.S. since 1806. There will not be another total solar eclipse in the U.S. until 2044.
Social media buzz about the eclipse is on the rise including its technological, public safety, natural, spiritual and metaphysical impacts.
EMERGENCY ALERTS
A number of governments in Texas, Ohio and other states in the totality path have issued special and emergency orders related to the eclipse.
A special eclipse order issued by March 13 Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine's order instructs state agencies, including police, to prepare for the event and for those traveling for it to make sure to carry cash, cell phone chargers, blankets and other items.
Bell County, Texas, which expects 400,000 visitors for the eclipse (doubling its population) has declared a state of emergency for the event, urging residents to stock up on fuel, drug prescriptions and groceries before the influx of tourists and potential impacts.
Other emergency and tourism agencies are recommending having cash on hand, fueling up on gas and stocking up on food and other staples before the April event in case of disruptions. Protective eyewear is also required to view the eclipse.
The Federal Aviation Administration has issued a special alert for airlines and general aviation pilots for the April 8 eclipse.
That includes warnings of increased aviation traffic — especially in the prime path — and that there could be flight restrictions or changes ordered by the U.S. military or security agencies.
That could especially impact air travel and airports in areas such as Dallas, Houston, Little Rock, Arkansas; Indianapolis, Cleveland, Buffalo and Burlington, Vermont, according to the FAA.
"There may be a higher traffic volume than normal anticipated at airports along the path of the eclipse. Traffic should anticipate delays during peak traffic periods," the FAA said in its alert. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on government and law enforcement preparations for the solar eclipse, including police deployments, National Guard activations, emergency orders, and public safety warnings. While local government agencies are involved, the primary emphasis is on safety measures, traffic management, and emergency response rather than governance itself.

title: Dundalk residents view crumpled bridge with shock, dismay
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dundalk residents view crumpled bridge with shock, dismay

 March 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 667
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DUNDALK — A few hours after Teresita Santana and her family drove across the Francis Scott Key Bridge, they felt their house shake."As if something had exploded," Santana said.
Santana and her family, including her children and mother, got back to their home in Dundalk late Monday night after a trip to Washington, D.C., to get their passports and see the cherry blossoms. It was only a few hours after they crossed the Key Bridge on their way home that the bridge collapsed.
A container ship slammed into the iconic bridge just before 1:30 a.m. Tuesday. Within seconds, the bridge crumpled into the chilly waters of the Patapsco River at the entrance to the Baltimore Harbor.
In the hours that followed, authorities began search and rescue efforts for survivors of the collapse. Radar indicated that vehicles had been discovered at the bottom of the river, which is about 50 feet deep.
By Tuesday evening, officials said that six construction workers who had been repairing potholes on the bridge at the time of the collapse had been presumed dead. Two construction workers were rescued in the efforts.
Tuesday morning, Santana looked out on the now collapsed bridge from a hill on Dundalk Avenue, across the street from the Logan Village Shopping Center.
"It was scary because it could have been us," Santana said.
Santana wasn't the only one looking at what's left of the I-695 bridge. People filtered in and out Tuesday morning to see it for themselves. "Shock" was a word repeated often.
"Shock and dismay," were the words Judy Corkhum used to describe the emotions of residents she had talked to.
"Nobody in a million years thought we would wake up this morning to something like that," said Corkhum, who also viewed the collapsed bridge from off Dundalk Avenue. "It brings back emotions from 9/11. ... You saw that and the first thing you think is, 'Oh my god. The people. The workers.'"
Corkhum, who recently moved to Baltimore from Dundalk, said she heard about the bridge collapse via a text from a neighbor at 4 a.m. Tuesday. She said her friend's son, a truck driver, "literally just got over the bridge before it happened."
"She said, 'I was having a heart attack this morning thinking he was out on the road last night,'" Corkhum said.
Corkhum said her friend went into surgery this morning, so she was happy to know her son was OK.
Anthony Meeks, a Dundalk native, said he heard about the collapse as soon as he woke up.
"The Key Bridge is a very iconic piece of Dundalk," he said. "It's something that everybody who's from Dundalk or this city even has at one point in their life crossed."
Meeks remembers being scared to cross the bridge when he was younger. These days, he crosses it every two weeks.
"It (will) make me go out of my way to find a different path to get to where I need to go," he said about the collapse. "It could make my trips be a lot longer."
Meeks called the incident an eye opener.
"Because it's like you don't really expect these kinds of tragedies and stuff to happen and occur in your neighborhood," he said.
Dundalk-Patapsco Neck Historical Society President Jean Walker said this is the first time Dundalk has experienced a large disaster like this.
Historical Society Vice President Joe Stadler called the event "unbelievable."
"It takes a while to fathom it," he said.
For both Walker and Stadler, the bridge has been a big part of Dundalk. They said the founder of the Historical Society, Ben Womer, was "instrumental" in getting the bridge named after Francis Scott Key, the author of the national anthem.
"It's the backdrop for everything around here," Stadler said about the bridge.
Standing on the hill, looking at the wreckage of the bridge, Corkhum said she had to make the trip from her new home in Baltimore to see what had happened with her own eyes.
"I'm so used to seeing that pretty view out there every day," she said. "It's going to be horrible seeing that (there's) no view anymore." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a bridge collapse caused by a container ship, describing its immediate impact on residents, search and rescue efforts, and community reactions. This aligns with 'Public Safety' due to the focus on a sudden disaster, human safety, and emergency response. While 'Local Government' and 'National News' are plausible, the core narrative centers on public safety concerns rather than governance or broader national implications.

title: Biden administration ready to release federal funds for Baltimore bridge
author: YESENIA MONTENEGRO Capital News Service
content:
Biden administration ready to release federal funds for Baltimore bridge

 March 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: YESENIA MONTENEGRO Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 935
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is prepared to provide federal funding to cover costs following the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore, Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg said Wednesday in a White House press briefing."We are committed to delivering every federal resource needed to help Maryland get back to normal and we're going to work with them every step of the way to rebuild this bridge," Buttigieg said.
While there is no estimate on the cost of rebuilding yet, there are provisions in place that allow funds to be released while the estimate is being determined. The Maryland Department of Transportation has released an emergency relief funding request, which will be processed immediately to start the funding process, Buttigieg said.
The infrastructure law authorized funding of the emergency relief account, which will most likely be used in this situation. According to Buttigieg, about $950 million is available. However, this money is used for other projects as well, so it is likely that Congress will be asked to authorize additional funding.
"That shouldn't be a barrier to the immediate next few days beginning to get the ball rolling," he said.
President Joe Biden met earlier in the Oval Office with Buttigieg and U.S. Coast Guard Vice Admiral Peter Gautier. The president also spoke by phone with Maryland Gov. Wes Moore and Lt. Gen. Scott Spellmon, chief of engineers and commander of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers.
"The people of Baltimore can count on us to stick with them at every step of the way until the port is reopened and Francis Scott Key Bridge is rebuilt," Biden said in a post on X. "We're not leaving until it's done."
Buttigieg said officials did not have an estimate yet of costs to replace the bridge. He also declined to estimate how long it will take to reopen the Port of Baltimore.
Any private party found accountable for the accident will be held responsible, Buttigieg said. However, Biden's goal is not to have that process interfere with Maryland getting the financial help it needs, he said.
Buttigieg said it was "possible if not likely" the administration will ask Congress for additional money to refill the emergency relief account.
He said he hopes that some Republicans will work with Biden and Democrats to provide that funding. He also reminded members of Congress on the fence about supporting federal funding to remember that "today this is happening in Baltimore, tomorrow it could be your district."
"Infrastructure is, or at least ought to be, a bipartisan priority," the secretary said. "I know that partisanship has gotten in the way of some important functions and expenditures, but I would also note that the infrastructure package that was passed is known as the bipartisan infrastructure law for a reason."
"I think in a situation like this where you have a national emergency where it's gonna attract a lot of attention, I think it's gonna get through rather quickly," John Dedie, a political science professor at the Community College of Baltimore County told Capital News Service. "There are gonna be some people that may grumble in the House a little bit, but I think that under the circumstances people are gonna realize economically something has to be done to build this thing."
Buttigieg said the Department of Transportation will focus on reopening the port, dealing with supply chain implications until the port reopens, rebuilding the bridge and dealing with surface transportation implications until the bridge can be rebuilt.
"The products that are now stuck behind the blocked channel are one piece of it, and that affects global markets everywhere," Maryland Sen. Sarah Elfreth, a Democrat who currently serves on the state's Budget and Taxation Committee, told CNS. "Not to mention what can't come into the port for the time it takes to clear the channel."
About 8,000 jobs are directly affected and between $100 million-$200 million worth of cargo moves in and out of the port every day, according to Buttigieg.
"Rebuilding will not be quick, or easy or cheap, but we will get it done," he said.
The accident investigation is led by the National Transportation Safety Board. The Coast Guard will also be providing investigators with its Marine Board of Investigation, which is one of the highest levels of investigation within the Coast Guard, Gautier said during the press conference.
The greatest immediate challenge, the vice admiral said, is going to be the removal of the bridge trusses now draped across the bow of the cargo ship. The bow of the vessel Dali currently is sitting on the bottom of the Patapsco River but there are no signs that the hull is leaking.
"What we do know is a bridge like this one, completed in the 1970s, was simply not made to withstand a direct impact on a critical support pier, from a vessel that weighs about 200 million pounds," Buttigieg said.
Although there is no timeline yet, Buttigieg expects that the clearing of the channel will happen on a much quicker timeline than the reconstruction of the bridge. The Army Corps of Engineers is beginning the underwater surveys to understand the possible challenges the debris presents, Gautier said.
The State of Maryland is simultaneously conducting body recovery operations in and around the same area as the debris assessment, Gautier said. Six highway workers who were on the bridge at the time of the accident are missing and presumed dead.
Biden plans to visit Baltimore as soon as possible, White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said. The Biden administration will work with local officials to ensure that a presidential visit would not disrupt the efforts at the scene.
Capital News Service Washington Bureau reporter Torrence Banks contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on federal funding for bridge reconstruction after a collapse, emphasizing public safety concerns, emergency response, and infrastructure repair. While economic impacts are mentioned, the primary context is public safety and federal disaster relief efforts.

title: Caroline County Sheriff's Office details plans for Ridgely
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Caroline County Sheriff's Office details plans for Ridgely

 CAROLINE COUNTY — On Friday, the Caroline County Sheriff's Office released a statement on Facebook updating the public on the collaborative agreement reached between the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, the Town of Ridgely and the County Commissioners.The agreement underscores the safety and welfare of Ridgely's residents and businesses after the temporary suspension of the municipal police department earlier this month.
The sheriff's office emphasized five key points of the agreement in their statement.
Increased Patrols: More officers on duty for faster responses and proactive policing, including an additional 35 hours per week beyond regular patrol hours.
Prompt Emergency Response: Deputies available for emergencies.
Community Engagement: Actively involving residents and businesses to foster trust.
Oversight and Accountability: Regular evaluations to assess performance.
Transparent Communication: Keeping residents informed about law enforcement activities.
This agreement takes effect on April 1, 2024

title: A massive disaster stuns Dundalk residents
author: JIM JOHNSON
content:
A massive disaster stuns Dundalk residents

 March 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JIM JOHNSON | Section: Columns 
 
 648
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I was in Dundalk the morning the Francis Scott Key Bridge collapsed. APG Chesapeake owns the newspaper in Dundalk on the east side of the bridge. Star Democrat reporter Maggie Trovato and I traveled to help the newspaper with its coverage of the disaster.Two observations.
First, people in Dundalk had stunned looks on their faces that day. The bridge was iconic, a fixture on the city skyline. In an instant, it was gone. The shock was palpable, easily seen in the vacant stares of people who realized their lives would change but without yet fully understanding how.
Second, the scale of the disaster was massive. Photos cannot capture the size of the bridge structure nor the size of the ship that brought the bridge down. Seeing it from Dundalk, you begin to comprehend the challenging job ahead to simply clear the debris and reopen Baltimore Harbor.
Kudos to the Commissioners of St. Michaels for apologizing after approving a permit for a Makers Market to host a vendor event at Muskrat Park. City code prohibits the use of the park for for-profit ventures. Another code prohibits the use of tents on the park's lawns.
"We apologize that it was an oversight previously," Commission President David Breimhurst said. "And I can tell you that the staff is well aware of what the issue was. These permits will be thoroughly vetted in the future before they come to us."
Yes, someone should have known about the ordinances that limit the use of the park. Yet the commission should be applauded for trying to find a solution to help artists and crafters to move to a more desirable location, an event that brings hundreds of visitors to St. Michaels each year.
At the commission's March 13 meeting, Trish Payne and Mark Montoya, members of Talbot County's local art community, requested the use of the park every other Saturday or every second Sunday starting in April for a local art vendors event.
There was vocal opposition by members of the St. Michaels Business Association, who said that the vendor event could harm to local businesses.
After a heated discussion by members of the public, the commissioners approved the event on a trial run to begin in April to assess impacts to the local community.
That decision had to be reversed after the discovery of the city codes sections prohibiting the type of event Makers Market wishes to hold.
Too frequently these days government agencies dig their heels into the sand and refuse to budge, even when they are in the wrong. The apology from the commissioners was refreshing.
* * * * *
A sad anniversary passed on Friday. It's been one year since Russian authorities arrested Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, falsely accusing him of being a spy. Much of the time he has been held in a tiny cell, awaiting a trial that has not yet been set.
Gershkovich was doing his job, reporting on news, helping readers understand what is happening in the authoritarian-run Russia. His arrest and detention shows the importance of freedom of the press and the dangers that authoritarian governments bring to people's freedoms. Those freedoms are in jeopardy all over the world as authoritarian regimes rise.
It is important to remember the role that reporters perform in a free society. Journalism is not a crime.
* * * * *
In case you missed some of these, here are the top stories that appeared in the Star Democrat this week. You can read any of them you missed on StarDem.com.
Bridgerton Season 3: Teasers, Trailers, and the Tale So Far (From Limelight entertainment magazine).
Four suspects evade police in search south of Trappe.
Sailing leader and community trailblazer Diana Mautz dies.
Jymil Thompson resigns from Talbot County Board of Education.
Ship issued mayday before hitting Key Bridge.
Board of Education member Donna DiGiacomo resigns.
Denton dancer achieves mastery.
College students travel to every Easton in US.
Cambridge is 1 of 6 picked for National Parks Service Chesapeake Gateways pilot.

While it includes local government actions (permit approvals) and community impacts, the primary focus is on the disaster's scale, safety implications, and emergency response.

title: Calvert County middle schoolers in Calvert County face hate crime charges
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Calvert County middle schoolers in Calvert County face hate crime charges

 April 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 344
 Words 

 Read News Document

 According to the Calvert County State's Attorney's Office, three 13-year-old students at Plum Point Middle School in Huntingtown have been charged as juveniles with harassment and violations of Maryland's hate crimes statutes. The state's attorney's office released the information Friday afternoon.According to charging documents filed by the Maryland State Police, the students displayed swastikas, made Nazi salutes and directed offensive comments to a classmate because of the classmate's religious beliefs.
The state's attorney's office press release stated the behavior began last December and "continued over several months despite repeated requests to stop."
The matter was reported to the state police, who investigated and filed the charges against the juveniles. The press release does not report the names or genders of the charged students.
The charges will be forwarded to the Maryland Department of Juvenile Services for appropriate action. That entity has the discretion to refer the charges to the Calvert County Circuit Court for a hearing. The state's attorney's office then would be required to prove the allegations beyond a reasonable doubt.
"Calvert County Public Schools is committed to providing students and staff with an environment that is safe, welcoming and free from all forms of discrimination," Susan Johnson, chief academic officer and spokesperson for the school system, said in a statement released Monday. "The civil rights of all individuals will be protected. All complaints are investigated promptly. Upon completion of an investigation, students and school personnel may be subject to disciplinary action or consequences for discriminatory behaviors."
Calvert County State's Attorney Robert Harvey (R) issued a statement last Friday.
"Maryland was founded on the principle of religious toleration," Harvey said in the statement. "It is frankly astonishing that nearly 400 years later some people continue to persecute others based upon their religion. I call upon parents, educators and community and faith leaders to make sure that our children know that religious persecution has no place in our society."
On Tuesday, Commissioner President Earl F. "Buddy" Hance (R) stated, "We will not tolerate hate speech. That's not who we are. I hope they [juveniles] get the counseling that they need." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on hate crime charges against students, involving harassment and discrimination based on religion, which directly relates to public safety concerns. title: Man arrested in kidnapping, murder of woman in Cambridge
author: Staff Writer
content:
Man arrested in kidnapping, murder of woman in Cambridge

 April 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 151
 Words

 CAMBRIDGE – Maryland State Police arrested a man who has been indicted for the kidnapping and murder of a woman earlier this year in Dorchester County.The suspect, Kenneth Stefan Bradley, 40, of Cambridge, was indicted on March 29, on charges of first-degree murder, second-degree murder, first-degree assault, second-degree assault, kidnapping, false imprisonment and reckless endangerment. He is being held without bail at the Dorchester County Detention Center.
According to a preliminary investigation, the victim, Tiyavauna Britt, 31, was last seen at work on Feb. 7 in Delaware and her vehicle was located in the Easton area. Her body has not yet been recovered.
Britt and Bradley were known to each other prior to her disappearance.
The Maryland State Police Homicide Unit is leading the investigation, with assistance from Easton Police and Cambridge Police. Anyone having knowledge of Britt's whereabouts are asked to contact Sergeant Scott Sears at 443-783-7230.
The investigation into this case continues.

title: Cambridge man charged with kidnap and murder of woman
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge man charged with kidnap and murder of woman

 April 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 257
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man has been charged with murder, assault, kidnapping, false imprisonment and reckless endangerment for the kidnapping and murder of 31-year-old Tiyavauna Britt.According to a news release from the Maryland State Police, Kenneth Stefan Bradley, 40, was indicted on these charges on March 29. Bradley is being held without bail at the Dorchester County Detention Center.
Bradley was arrested in connection to Britt's disappearance Feb. 19 in Anne Arundel County, according to previous Star Democrat reporting.
Police said Britt's body has not yet been found. According to the police's preliminary investigation, Britt was last seen in Delaware at work on Feb. 7. Her vehicle was was found unoccupied in the Dollar Tree parking lot in Easton, according to previous Star Democrat reporting. The car was found unlocked with Britt's belongings inside, including her phone and wallet.
According to February charging documents, Britt's mother told police she had attempted to contact her daughter several times between Jan. 31 and Feb. 13, but had not been able to reach her. Several other family members were unable to make contact with Britt, her mother told police.
According to February charging documents, Britt's mother believed her daughter was with her ex-boyfriend, identified as Bradley. The mother feared for her daughter's safety, citing previous domestic violence history between the two.
The investigation, which is ongoing, is being led by the Maryland State Police Homicide Unit with assistance from the Easton and Cambridge police departments.
Maryland State Police asks that anyone with knowledge of Britt's whereabouts contact Maryland State Police Sergeant Scott Sears at 443-783-7230.

title: Easton man convicted of child abuse, assault
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Easton man convicted of child abuse, assault

 April 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 325
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An Easton man was convicted of first-degree child abuse and related charges Thursday.According to a news release from Talbot County State's Attorney's Office, Earl Andrew Kautz, 31, was found guilty on all charges, which include two counts of first-degree child abuse, one count of second-degree child abuse, two counts of second-degree assault and one count of reckless endangerment.
The charges stem from the abuse of a one-year-old boy and the assault of a 13-year-old girl, both of whom lived with Kautz at the time of the incidents.
According to the news release, the trial included testimony of the 13 year old and her mother, and expert medical testimony by the medical director of Pediatric Urgent Care Services at Johns Hopkins Hospital.
Evidence used in the trial include a May 2023 interview with the 13-year-old that was conducted by Talbot County Department of Social Services, according to the news release.
After the interview, the 1-year-old boy — who was 18 months old at the time — was taken to Johns Hopkins Hospital for a skeletal survey that revealed healing fractures in both of his tibias. A second survey taken two weeks later showed the same thing. According to the news release, the fractures were "deemed highly indicative of non-accidental injury" by Johns Hopkins medical staff.
According to the news release, witnesses at trial testified they had observed Kautz shaking the 1-year-old boy on multiple occasions in 2022. Witnesses also testified to observing bruises on the child's body when he was returned from visitations with Kautz.
"These cases involve children who are too young to testify or to speak on their own behalf and are therefore difficult to prosecute," Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale said in the news release. "We are extremely grateful to the investigators at the Talbot County Department of Social Services, Easton Police Department and to the doctors at Johns Hopkins who came together to achieve justice in this case."
Kautz's sentencing is scheduled for June 10.

While the case involves legal proceedings (Local Government) and medical evidence (Health), the primary focus is on protecting individuals from harm, aligning most closely with Public Safety.

title: Effects from New Jersey earthquake felt across Mid-Shore
author: Staff Writer
content:
Effects from New Jersey earthquake felt across Mid-Shore

 April 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 341
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — From Glen Burnie to Chestertown, trembles were felt from this morning's 4.7 magnitude earthquake. Officials from the U.S. Geological Survey said residents across the Northeast reported rumbling in a region where people are unaccustomed to feeling the ground move.The agency reported a quake at 10:23 a.m. with a preliminary magnitude of 4.8, centered near Lebanon, New Jersey, or about 45 miles west of New York City and 50 miles north of Philadelphia. USGS figures indicated that the quake might have been felt by more than 42 million people.
Across social media, users from Crumpton, Centreville, Worton, Ridgely, Wye Mills and Easton felt the quake. In Chester, one woman reported small vibration, less than 10 seconds. Melonie Mattison of Kent Island said she was sitting at here dining table when the chair wobbled.
For most though, unless they were sitting still it was an easy to miss experience here on the Shore. As Justin Davis quipped, "I felt more trembles when a tractor trailer passes by."
The shaking stirred memories of the Aug. 23, 2011, earthquake that jolted tens of millions of people from Georgia to Canada. Registering magnitude 5.8, it was the strongest quake to hit the East Coast since World War II. The epicenter was in Virginia.
That earthquake left cracks in the Washington Monument, spurred the evacuation of the White House and Capitol and rattled New Yorkers three weeks before the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terror attacks.
Earthquakes are less common on this side of the U.S. because the East Coast does not lie on a boundary of tectonic plates. But East Coast quakes can still pack a punch — its rocks are better at spreading earthquake energy across far distances.
"If we had the same magnitude quake in California, it probably wouldn't be felt nearly as far away," said U.S.G.S. geophysicist Paul Caruso.
The White House said in a statement that President Joe Biden had been briefed on the earthquake and was "in touch with federal, state, and local officials as we learn more."
The Associated Press contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on an earthquake's impact on communities, including public reactions and historical context, which relates to public safety concerns. While not explicitly about safety protocols, the event's effects on residents align with the broader 'Public Safety' category. 'Environment' is a secondary fit due to the geological nature of the event, but the focus is on societal impact rather than ecological effects.

title: For All Seasons hosting Human Trafficking speaker series at Avalon
author: Staff Writer
content:
For All Seasons hosting Human Trafficking speaker series at Avalon

 April 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 239
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Regional behavioral and mental health nonprofit For All Seasons will host a Speaker Series event at the Avalon Theatre focusing on human trafficking awareness.The free event — "Connecting Our Community to Stop Human Trafficking" — will be held on Tuesday, April 16, from 6:30 p.m. to 8 p.m. at the Atheatre in Easton.
For All Seasons CEO Beth Anne Dorman will moderate the discussion with expert panelists Thomas Stack, anti-human trafficking and sexual assault response manager for the city of Baltimore; Heather Amador, deputy director of victim services policy and programs at the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy; and Susan Ahlstrom, human trafficking regional navigator at For All Seasons.
"Human trafficking is a complex problem that requires a coordinated response from community members, local and state leaders, businesses, nonprofits, government officials, and law enforcement. Awareness and collaboration are key to fighting this form of modern-day slavery. The panel discussion will cover human trafficking, its presence in our community, how to recognize the red flags, the resources available to survivors, and state initiatives to end trafficking," according to the announcement.
Ahlstrom "is working to help mitigate the upward trend in Human Trafficking by expanding For All Seasons Rape Crisis Center's outreach; strengthening the medical, legal, social service, and mental health collaboration to support survivors in the Mid-Shore region," according to For All Seasons.
To register for the free educational event, "Connecting Our Community to Stop Human Trafficking," visit https://HumanTraffickingItsHere.eventbrite.com.
For more: ForAllSeasonsInc.org.

title: Bill seeks to provide online protection for children
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Bill seeks to provide online protection for children

 April 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 367
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland legislators are heading a nation-leading effort to protect children and their data online.The Maryland Kids Code — a bill sent to the governor's desk after unanimous votes from the House and Senate on its third reading — seeks to afford protections to children from all online products they are likely to access.
The bill states that entities that develop and provide online services and products that children are reasonably likely to access shall ensure the best interests of children when designing, developing and providing those products.
Currently, 75% of the top social media platforms use AI to recommend children's profiles to strangers, according to the Maryland Kids Code Coalition's website. One in three of the top 100 free apps on the Google Play store have banner ads, including ads for adult content, the website says.
According to the Pew Research Center, in 2022, 97% of American teenagers aged 13–17 used the internet every day, with 46% responding they used the internet almost constantly.
Del. C. T. Wilson (D-Charles) was one of the sponsors of the bill.
"Tonight's vote is a landmark moment for Maryland kids and families working toward a better, safer online world," said Todd Minor Sr. and Mia Minor, parent advocates from Accokeek who founded the Matthew E. Minor Awareness Foundation. "We've worked hard for this moment, and we're super proud our legislators had the courage and determination to stand up to the Big Tech lobbyists in the hope that other families will never have to suffer pain like ours has endured."
The Matthew E. Minor Awareness Foundation was created after Matthew Minor died at 12 years old as a result of the "choking/black-out" challenge that had been circulating on social media and other internet platforms.
"Today's vote shows support for the Kids Code model's safety-by-design and privacy-by-default principles that transcends political divides, reflecting growing public recognition of the urgent need for smart, effective policy solutions to protect kids online," Maryland Kids Code Coalition spokeswoman Marisa Shea of St. Mary's County said.
The bill has wide-reaching support, with organizations like the Digital Harbor Foundation, the Free State PTA, the Maryland Association of School Health Nurses, the Maryland Coalition of Families and the Maryland State Education Association testifying in favor of it. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on legislative efforts to protect children's online safety and data, which directly relates to public safety concerns. While education and health topics are tangentially related, the core issue involves safeguarding minors from online risks, aligning most closely with public safety.

title: Police nab theft suspects who allegedly stole $8K in perfume from Ulta store
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Police nab theft suspects who allegedly stole $8K in perfume from Ulta store

 April 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 471
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Five out-of-state individuals — four men and a woman — have been charged with felony theft following an alleged theft of nearly $8,000 worth of merchandise from Ulta Beauty in Prince Frederick.The incident occurred on April 4 at approximately 4:37 p.m., according to the Calvert County Sheriff's Office. Deputies responded to the store when a call went out that a theft had occurred.
According to a sheriff's office report, "Two males and one female entered the store and placed numerous colognes and perfumes into bags and fled the store. After fleeing the store, witnesses observed all three suspects enter a gray Mercury Montego that fled northbound on Route 4."
According to court documents filed by Deputy Antonio Tavares, Deputy Justin MacWilliams located the Mercury traveling northbound on Route 4, which then turned onto Route 2.
MacWilliams "initiated a traffic stop in the area of Pushaw Station Road in Sunderland. During the traffic stop, five occupants were located in the suspect vehicle along with numerous bags of perfumes and colognes in plain view. The total value of the stolen items was approximately $7,694 dollars."
In addition to the merchandise that was allegedly stolen from the Prince Frederick store, Tavares reported in charging papers that several cellphones were also confiscated.
The five arrested are identified as Yeiner Jose Rodriguez Barcelo, 27, of Bronx, N.Y., Yoncar Alberto Rainoso, 21, of Manhattan, N.Y., Estefani Andrea Urbano-Zapata, 21, of Cape Girardea, Mo., Raimil Marquez Jimenez, 25, of Washington, D.C., and Adony Josue Carana, 27, of Manhattan N.Y.
A sheriff's office press release stated that further investigation revealed Rodriguez-Barcelo was wanted on an open warrant from Pennsylvania for felony retail theft related to thefts at Ulta stores in Pennsylvania.
Court records show Carana, who was also listed with the alias Carrano, has been released after posting $10,000 bond. As of Monday, the other four remained at the Calvert detention center on a no-bond status.
A district court hearing on the charges the five are facing is scheduled for June 3. Language interpreters have been requested for four of the five defendants, court records show.
The Prince Frederick Ulta has been the scene of similar thefts over the last three years. Other Ulta stores regionally and nationally have been targets of alleged thieves. Several national news outlets have reported allegations of a possible retail theft ring in the state of California. The alleged perpetrators there stole $8 million in cosmetics from several chains, including Ulta, and then sold the products on Amazon.
It is not known at this time if the five arrested in Calvert last week are part of a larger theft ring.
Calvert County Sheriff Ricky Cox (R) issued a note of thanks in an agency press release to "the witnesses on scene that went above and beyond to promptly call 911 and provide details of the suspects and suspects' vehicle. Your efforts are greatly appreciated." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
