title: Workshop encourages becoming an informed weather spotter
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Workshop encourages becoming an informed weather spotter

 April 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 696
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For Warning Coordinator Meteorologist for the National Weather Service, Sarah Johnson, discussing weather's not just typical small talk.She deals in tornados, hail, high winds and severe storms all the time. As Marylanders escape winter weather, hopefully, there's a pause in the storm seasons.
June is considered the beginning of hurricane season and Johnson mentioned some things to stay alert to on the Eastern Shore.
At the Kent County Public Library on March 21, she introduced her audience to their program: SKYWARN.
She's looking for more and more people to become a spotter, who look out for the basics of thunderstorm development, storm structure and severe weather features, then report the information accurately.
"The main mission of the spotter is to be aware of the rapidly changing conditions of the weather," Johnson replied.
And it's sorely needed too.
Johnson said last year they reported the second most severe thunderstorms.
The third most for tornado warnings.
And the fourth most in flash flood warnings.
Unperturbed by the smaller audience in attendance, she was concise and enthusiastic while walking through the process of what to look out for.
For instance, people tend to be on high alert when they get something on their phone saying "tornado warning." Not so much when they get a "severe thunderstorm warning."
"That's a mistake to think one's worse than the other," Johnson commented.
Especially when water can be more harmful than wind in most cases, she said.
"When we look at the fatalities, 75% in the United States are due to water in some way; 50% of those are those are due to storm surge; 25% freshwater heavy rain flooding. Keep that in mind. Don't think, 'Oh, it's just a tropical storm.' No, you still need to pay attention and see what the hazards are."
Severe storms should not be treated much differently than a tornado.
She then pointed out the difference between a storm watch and a storm warning. A watch means to keep an eye on the weather pattern.
A warning means, don't just watch — get prepared.
A severe storm warning means, gather up some candles for light, or buy extra gas for the back-up generator and do things that will prepare your family and yourself for a potential hazard.
As hurricanes emerge from the North Atlantic ocean and the Gulf of Mexico, Johnson reminded her audience how to categorize them and what that exactly means.
Hurricanes, big or small, she indicated, can create problems, such as tornados.
The uninformed, she added, might hear about a category 1 hurricane and think it's not much of a problem. They'll see it as a little rain and wind. Very minimal damage.
The savvy spotter though, will see that even a category 1 hurricane can create big problems, such as a tornado. The spotter will know category 1, simply describes the wind of the hurricane. Nothing else. It does not highlight the possibility of it creating tornados or other adverse weather conditions.
And those who think tornados are only a threat in Kansas are in for a rude awakening.
Tornados hit everywhere, Johnson pointed out. Even in our backyard.
She said Hurricane Ida was a remnant tropical system that produced a lot of tornados in 2020.
Hurricane Isaias was a destructive Category 1 hurricane, producing the longest tracked tornado in Delaware history.
Tornados in Cecil County and Southern Delaware — resulted in fatalities last year.
"That's why we need you all," she said, encouraging her audience to report their observations to their nearest national weather station.
To become a spotter, adults are invited to complete the SKYWARN training.
Those who finish the course join a volunteer program with between 350,000 and 400,000 trained severe weather spotters.
Individuals affiliated with hospitals, schools, churches and nursing homes or who have a responsibility for protecting others are encouraged to become a spotter.
"There can be no finer reward than to know that your efforts have given your family and neighbors the precious gift of time—minutes that can help save lives," as stated by the NWS.
And as the movie "Twisters," the sequel to the original from 1996, comes out in theaters shortly, Johnson jokes that she's preparing to field a lot more questions about tornados.
She discouraged the crowd on becoming storm chasers like sensationalist Hollywood actors and actresses, but rather to become informed citizens who save lives. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on weather safety initiatives, severe weather preparedness, and community education about storm warnings. While environmental factors are mentioned, the primary emphasis is on public safety measures, volunteer programs, and hazard mitigation efforts led by the National Weather Service.

title: Caroline County residents show support for child abuse prevention with pinwheels
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Caroline County residents show support for child abuse prevention with pinwheels

 April 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 606
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Four years since the first Pinwheels for Prevention planting ceremony in Caroline County, the number of shiny blue and silver pinwheels twirling in the breeze has grown.For the event, hosted by CASA of Caroline every year, the pinwheels are placed on lawns and in gardens throughout the county to spread awareness of child abuse and promote its prevention. CASA of Caroline Executive Director Amy Horne said the blue in the pinwheels represents the color of bruises, and the pinwheels themselves "represent the whimsical, carefree childhood that all kids deserve."
At the annual planting ceremony on Fourth Street in Denton on April 10, Horne said participation has grown throughout the county in the past four years.
"My gosh, go up to the Town of Ridgely," she said in an interview. "They have an amazing display."
CASA of Caroline is a nonprofit organization that advocates for and helps find homes for abused and neglected children.
On the nonprofit's website, there is a virtual garden that shows where many of the pinwheels have been planted this year. Horn said hundreds of pinwheels have been planted.
In the 20 years the organization has been around, it has advocated for more than 100 children in the county, Horne said.
"People may think (that because) we're a close-knit county, that it doesn't happen here, but it does," she said about child abuse. "With the tremendous outpouring of support — as you can see here, and that we receive all over the county — it's obvious that Caroline County is really committed to being a safe place for children and families."
CASA of Caroline Board President Keith Johnson talked about the different agencies and organizations that are involved when children experience abuse.
"We have representatives from Denton Police Department and the (Caroline County) Sheriff's Office here," he said. "A lot of times, those cases start with their work. But as those children progress, they go to social service and then our advocates, which serve each one of those children."
Caroline County Circuit Court Judge Heather Price said in an interview that CASA reports offer an important perspective to judges.
"They give me a different angle than what the attorneys representing the parents would say or the attorneys representing the department," she said. "Here you have the voice of the child that's speaking through an advocate."
Before attendees of the ceremony fanned out to plant pinwheels, citations and awards were handed out. Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) presented CASA of Caroline with a citation in recognition of the Pinwheels for Prevention campaign.
Del. Jeff Ghrist (R-36, Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline), who was also in attendance at the event, talked about the importance of the services CASA of Caroline offers children.
"In order to be able to connect them with that one person that they can trust, it takes a community to do that," he said. "It takes CASA to do that."
At the event, CASA of Caroline awarded the Caroline Career and Technology Center for the having highest participation across Caroline County Public Schools in coloring pinwheels to inspire hope from children experiencing abuse. Horn said 40% of CCTC students colored pinwheels. She said they will receive a Kona Ice party as their prize.
Career center Principal Courtney Handte said it means a lot to her and the center's staff that their students showed support for National Child Abuse Prevention Month, which is April.
"It's important for all students to know what is out there and available to them, and that they are not alone," Handte said. "Caroline County is a small community, but we are mighty. And we will surround them with the support and love that they need during challenging times." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on child abuse prevention efforts in Caroline County, highlighting community awareness campaigns, nonprofit initiatives, and collaborations with local authorities. While related to health and education, the primary emphasis is on safeguarding children and promoting community safety, aligning most directly with Public Safety.

title: Housing secretary visits His Hope Ministries
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Housing secretary visits His Hope Ministries

 April 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 668
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Maryland Secretary of Housing and Community Development Jake Day, came to His Hope Ministries in Denton Tuesday to learn about the nonprofit's vision for the future.The organization, which provides services and shelter to those experiencing homelessness, wants to develop a new building and move to Market Street.
They toured bunk rooms at 409 Aldersgate Drive, where neat piles of clothes, toothbrushes, laundry detergent and ear buds lie. The shelter welcomes guests from September through the end of April, with accommodations for families, single men and women, and youths.
"They are seeking to grow because the demand is high," Day said. "Part of that is that there just are not enough housing units, particularly affordable housing units in the Mid-Shore. We have underbuilt for the last 15 years. The consequence is that people are unhoused."
Executive Director Stefanie Johnson showed Day some architectural plans for a new facility she would like to build to expand His Hope's services.
"I did show him our design so far. We have an idea in mind for land, but so far, it is not available from the town yet. We have our Senior Haven, which is a three bedroom one bath home. It has three seniors in it. Seniors or disabled — it is transitional so they can stay there for up to three years," said Johnson.
There is a vacant lot next to this senior home where His Hope hopes to build their expanded facility.
One of the barriers to completing the project is its cost. Some of the visit was talking about money.
Day said he believes the best fiscal options for His Hope to complete the project is through the Community Development Block Grant from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. The state has $7.5 million to fund CDBG annually, he said.
"Probably for the Eastern Shore it is CDBG money. It gets to the end user when it is ready to be executed and spent for construction and design. This federal money has to serve the low income population," Day said.
The other option Day mentioned is Sowing Empowerment and Economic Development Inc., a nonprofit organization providing food, education, and training while promoting self-sufficiency and empowerment directly to low-to-moderate-income families.
"I believe both predevelopment and development costs are eligible. SEED is the institutional version of this. For the town, all it has to be is a community development goal that they're interested in. Helping unsheltered homeless be sheltered has positive health outcomes. A hospital and a shelter would go hand and glove," Day said.
Andrew Breeding, treasurer for His Hope Ministries, called their hoped-for property the Market Street Property. The land is owned by the Town of Denton and used to be a Southern States facility.
"The challenge is putting a homeless shelter literally anywhere," said Breeding.
Johnson said some local politicians are hesitant about the idea of building a shelter in town. Day said that representatives from his office, including him, could come and testify to the town council on behalf of His Hope's story.
Day asked some pressing questions about how His Hope Ministries and the community interact.
"What's that look like between you and other organizations in the community?" he asked.
Johnson responded, "It is impeccable. When we closed (for the warmer months), we called and said, 'Hey, do you have room for our families? Talbot Interfaith in Easton, and in Cambridge the Salvation Army, we are all on speed dial. Even the Christian Shelter in Salisbury. This community is so giving."
Day also toured the office and youth drop-in center of His Hope Ministries on 105 Gay Street, housed in a spacious Victorian house with a broad porch. The inside is inviting and colorful. There is room for classes on financial literacy, and there are many positive affirmations on the walls.
Amidst a big black board filled with affirmations, Day was invited to grab some chalk and add his. He wrote, "A mistake will not define you. Get back up and keep going."
This report has been updated from earlier versions to correct the name of His Hope's treasurer. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on housing insecurity and homelessness, which are critical public safety issues. While local government and health aspects are mentioned, the core theme revolves around community safety, shelter availability, and systemic housing challenges.

title: Experts discuss Mid-Shore impacts of human trafficking
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Experts discuss Mid-Shore impacts of human trafficking

 April 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 751
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Around 180 people attended the For All Seasons presentation on human trafficking on Tuesday night at the Avalon Theatre, where a panel of experts painted a picture of a changing landscape for trafficking crimes.With the increasing use of social media, traffickers find and groom their victims at home, a more methodical trust-gaining method than before the advent of the internet, they said.
According to Thomas Stack, anti-human trafficking and sexual assault response manager for Mayor's Neighborhood Office of Safety and Engagement for the City of Baltimore, because young people's lives are so transparent online, traffickers can target individuals who are alone, mad at their parents and not doing well in school. Low self esteem is the target, he said.
"It is all about getting the word out there. Human trafficking has been around a long time, but the awareness has probably only been around for the last 20 years," Stack said. "Maryland has a toxic mixture of both poverty and wealth. The poverty is a major risk factor for exploitation and the wealth is the buyers of sex, the people who are willing to purchase people for their pleasure."
Maryland is also geographically vulnerable to trafficking, the experts said.
"We are two hours from Philly, three hours from New York, we have a lot of sporting events, we have two major cities, and we have airports and casinos, everything a trafficker wants," Stack said. "Like we have the Preakness coming up. There will be a lot of males who have traveled here. The traffickers know that and will bring their victims of sex trafficking to service those males."
The speakers made it clear that human trafficking happens in the Mid-Shore community.
"There was a 15-year-old trafficked in Denton, so it is here," Stack said.
By becoming more aware of the problem, they said, community members can identify victims and reach out.
Heather Amador, deputy director of victim services policy and programs for the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy, was one of the speakers. She said members of the community can look for signs of trafficking, like bruises, new tattoos and new suggestive clothing.
Red flags can also appear online, Stack said, like if a teenager has multiple Facebook profiles with some that have nothing to do with their family or friends.
"Human trafficking is here. People don't want to believe that their neighbors are capable of such things," Amador said. "A lot of human trafficking victims don't even identify as a victim. They see themselves as voluntarily engaging in it. They don't see the coercion that goes along with it. They are deceived to go down this path or forced into addiction. They think they are helping someone else out."
Amador had one victim in her office who simply said she needed to make money. She was a runaway and had nowhere to go, Amador said, and she needed housing.
Amador came across a case where a child had to perform a sex act to get lunch money in her lunch account and emphasized that that is trafficking too.
For All Seasons offers a host of services around human trafficking, from trainings, to getting the word out, to psychological services, to addiction services.
Beth Anne Dorman, CEO and president of For All Seasons, says it takes a village to combat trafficking.
"Our anti-human trafficking efforts focused on a team-based approach," she said. "We collaborate with law enforcement, first responders, Department of Social Services, child advocacy centers, school administrators, teachers and the hospital, officials from the towns and counties we serve."
Then she introduced a video of Maryland Comptroller Brooke Lierman, who created and helped pass legislation to make the Maryland Regional Navigator program when she was a legislator. This program supports survivors of trafficking. For All Seasons is a participant.
"Maryland recorded 118 cases of human trafficking involving 173 victims. This figure includes sex and labor exploitation. Child sex trafficking is also a concern. Since 2012 over 500 children have been identified by Child Protective Services as reportedly being trafficked in Maryland. This remains vastly under reported," Lierman said in the video.
She said she was committed to ensuring access to services for every survivor of sex trafficking in Maryland. She highlighted For All Seasons as "essential to the safety and wellness of our communities."
The night ended with a call to action for the audience.
"It is a hidden crime so we all have to be alert," said Susan Ahlstrom, regional navigator at For All Seasons. "We all have to be vigilant."
For more information on human trafficking and available resources, visit missingkids.org, polaris.com and netsmartz.com 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on human trafficking discussions, expert panels, and community awareness efforts, which directly relate to public safety concerns. While health aspects (e.g., victim care) and local government collaborations are mentioned, the core theme centers on crime prevention and community safety.

title: Crime in Cambridge 'trending down,' police department says
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Crime in Cambridge 'trending down,' police department says

 April 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 521
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The number of reported crimes, ShotSpotter alerts and shots fired calls is down in the first quarter of this year compared to last year in Cambridge, according to a quarterly report from the Cambridge Police Department.Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd said he thinks this shows that crime in Cambridge is "trending down."
"A lot of credit goes to our officers that are out doing what we're asking of them to do as an administration," he said about these decreases. "And that's patrol with a purpose, be in our high-crime areas."
Todd also attributes the lowering of these stats to the department's work in getting guns off the street. He said that last year the department averaged getting one illegal firearm off the street per week in Cambridge alone.
"We know there's more out there, and we know there's still crime," Todd said. "But we're making progress."
According to the CPD report, in the first quarter of 2024, CPD submitted 200 crime incidents committed within its jurisdiction to the National Incident-Based Reporting System, a national reporting system for crimes used by police departments. That is compared to 247 incidents submitted in the first quarter of 2023.
This year, the majority of those incidents have been assaults.
The CPD report also states there was a 33.3% decrease in ShotSpotter alerts for the first quarter of 2024 compared to the first quarter of 2023. ShotSpotter is a gunshot detection system that has sensors that can detect and locate illegal gunfire incidents and alert law enforcement.
The CPD report states there was a 40.9% decrease in shots fire calls compared to the first quarter of 2023.
The first quarter of this year, there were 46 Shot Spotter alerts and 13 shots fired calls in Cambridge, according to the report. There was one shooting in that time.
Todd confirmed that shooting was on March 1 in the 800 block of Phillips Street. According to previous Dorchester Star reporting, police found several spent shell casings from multiple calibers of handguns on the scene. Isaiah David Foster, 23, of Cambridge was arrested on firearm possession charges, as well as resisting arrest and obstructing and hindering, following the incident.
According to the CPD report, calls for service increased 9.1% in the first quarter of 2024 compared to the first quarter of 2023. Todd said this is a good thing because it shows that officers are out in the community doing their jobs.
Compared to 171 adult arrests, there were eight juvenile arrests and 34 juvenile referrals in the first quarter of 2024.
Although Todd said he didn't have those numbers for this time last year, when it comes to juvenile crime, he thinks Cambridge is "stagnant."
"I think there's a lot of work to do with juvenile reform," he said. "We have to put more emphasis on figuring out why these kids are out committing these crimes and getting in touch with families by working through social services and Juvenile Services."
Todd said that the department will have a better understanding of the state of crime in Cambridge come summer.
"When the kids get out of school, that'll be a big factor of just how good we're doing crime-wise," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on crime statistics, police department reports, and safety initiatives in Cambridge, directly relating to public safety efforts. While local government and community life are tangentially related, the core content centers on crime reduction and law enforcement actions.

title: After deadly work zone crashes, a push for change
author: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service
content:
After deadly work zone crashes, a push for change

 April 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 631
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — After a pair of deadly work zone incidents cast attention on the dangers of road work, Maryland Gov. Wes Moore enacted a set of protections for workers and their families that his administration describes as "a moral imperative."Hours after the state's legislature adjourned, a bill increasing fines for work zone speed violations and another covering educational costs for families of fallen workers were among the first measures from the 2024 session that Moore signed into law.
At a bill signing ceremony, Lt. Gov. Aruna Miller, a former transportation engineer, invoked two fatal crashes that inspired the new legislation. In March 2023, six highway workers died when a car careened into a work zone on Interstate 695. Nearly a year later, six construction workers repairing potholes atop the Francis Scott Key Bridge were killed when a container ship struck the bridge, causing it to collapse.
"The men and women in the construction industry place themselves in harm's way every day on the frontline of service," Miller said. "We saw it happen on March 22, 2023. And we saw it happen again on March 26, 2024. It's a moral imperative that we protect workers who provide critical service, public service for all of us."
Among the measures to receive Moore's signature was the Maryland Road Worker Protection Act, which Miller championed throughout the legislative session and touted Tuesday, during an event overlooking the site of the I-695 crash to mark National Work Zone Awareness Week.
Effective June 1, the new law permits the installation of multiple speed cameras within a single work zone and raises the fine for speed camera violations to $80. The current penalty in Maryland is $40, among the lowest such fines in the country.
Beginning January 2025, fines shift to a tiered system ranging from $60 to $500 depending on the driver's speed. Fines will double if workers are present at the time of the violation.
The new law is part of a larger effort to change driver behavior in work zones by strengthening enforcement methods and increasing education. Distracted driving, aggressive driving and speeding are the leading causes of work zone crashes, according to the State Highway Administration.
"Most crashes are not accidents," State Highway Administrator William Pines told Capital News Service. "In reality, they're very preventable. The majority of crashes that occur happen because of behaviors with drivers. So if we want to stop the root cause of most crashes, we've got to deal with driver behavior."
But the law offers no safety solutions for incidents like the collapse of the Key Bridge, which was unrelated to driver behavior. Maryland Transportation Secretary Paul Wiedefeld told Capital News Service on Tuesday that officials may consider structural solutions to bolster bridge safety but are awaiting the results of an investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board before making any specific policy proposals.
Instead, lawmakers responded to the bridge collapse by recognizing the toll that work zone crashes leave on workers' families.
In the final hours of the legislative session, the General Assembly passed the Protecting Opportunities and Regional Trade (PORT) Act, primarily aimed at providing emergency aid to workers and businesses affected by the closure of the Port of Baltimore.
Moore's administration offered a successful amendment to the bill creating the Fallen Transportation Workers Scholarship Program, providing tuition assistance for five years of full-time study or eight-years of part-time study to children and spouses of workers who have died on the job since 2022.
"What happened on the bridge is horrifically traumatic, and I think one of the things that we wanted to do is protect others who are in a similarly dangerous situation," said Maryland Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City), who co-sponsored the PORT Act.
"Certainly, we wish there were no one participating in that fund, but sadly, we know how dangerous this work is," he continued. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on legislative actions to improve worker safety in road work zones, including new laws, enforcement measures, and support for families of victims. These directly relate to public safety initiatives. While local government is involved, the core issue is worker and public safety rather than general governance.

title: Tilghman man sentenced for child porn distribution, animal cruelty
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Tilghman man sentenced for child porn distribution, animal cruelty

 April 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 346
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A Tilghman man was sentenced to 33 years with 10 years suspended for three counts of distribution of child pornography and one count of aggravated animal cruelty on Tuesday.Parker Greer Michael Matta, 21, was arrested by the Talbot County Sheriff's Office in March 2023 after detectives found evidence of child pornography on his electronic devices while executing a search warrant, police said.
The Sheriff's Office's Criminal Investigations Division received a tip from the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children involving Matta in March, according to previous Star Democrat reporting.
With assistance from the Howard County Police Department, the Sheriff's Office learned that Matta sent an image containing child pornography to another person via a social media platform in December 2022.
After reviewing the file, an investigator with the Talbot County Sheriff's office was able to identify an image depicting sexual abuse against a young female child between the ages of toddler and 5 years-old.
On March 31, 2023, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office executed a search warrant on Matta's residence, and found several electronic devices where images and videos of child pornography were located by investigators.
Additionally, investigators located several images depicting child sexual abuse that Matta shared to a group chatroom named "~Pxdo Paradise~" on an internet-based messaging and sharing application.
Also discovered in the investigation was a video wherein Matta sexually abused a labrador retriever at the Tilghman residence, leading to the defendant's conviction for aggravated animal cruelty.
Matta pled guilty to the distribution of child pornography charge on Nov. 29, according to court documents. In February, Matta's sentencing was postponed so that he could receive a psycho-sexual evaluation before being sentenced.
At the sentencing, Deputy State's Attorney Chelsea Endzel recommended the maximum sentence of 33 years with 10 years suspended, or 23 years to serve in prison.
"We are very happy with the outcome of this difficult case as it honors the trauma and harm suffered by the child victims in cases involving possession and distribution of Child Sexual Abuse Material and the threat that individuals who have a sexual interest in children pose to society," Endzel said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal conviction for child pornography distribution and animal cruelty, which directly relates to public safety concerns. While 'Public Safety' is the closest match, 'Local Government' could also apply due to law enforcement involvement, but the primary focus is on the criminal justice outcome rather than governmental operations.

title: VAMSA seeks donation of 25 acres for veterans care site
author: DOUG BISHOP Special to the Star Democrat
content:
VAMSA seeks donation of 25 acres for veterans care site

 April 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 651
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Two years into a successful start of VAMSA, the Veteran and Military Support Alliance organization, retired U.S. Army veteran Joe Candella, who serves as president of VAMSA, and retired U.S. Air Force Medical Administrator Eric Johnson, Jr., VAMSA executive director, explained their vision for veterans care, going forward.VAMSA seeks to make sure all local veterans receive the benefits they've earned in service to our nation.
"Through statistics provided, 30% of all veterans don't receive any benefits from the Veterans Administration they're entitled to. That is shameful," Candella said.
May will mark the first anniversary of the VAMSA's resource center, located in office space located at Bay Bridge Marina, 337 Pier One Road, Suite 101, Stevensville, provided free by owner and veteran Walt Petrie.
The resource center provides a place where military veterans who are experiencing any type of concerns obtaining their VA benefits or services they may need can find immediate help.
The center also provides a 24/7 hotline, 1-844-MIL-VETS, for any veteran suffering from PTSD and immediate assistance for suicide prevention, which several years ago was considered an epidemic among military veterans.
Johnson said, "There's been a slight decline in the suicide rate going down the past two-years, when veterans were dying on average of one every hour. However, those still dying in this way is unacceptable, and the need for help for veterans suffering is still urgent."
"This resource center is for all veterans and their families," Johnson said, "The VA benefits veterans earned also cover family members. We want to help their families too."
Both Candella and Johnson are pleased with the quick coming together of VAMSA and what its been able to accomplish thus far. The resource center is what Candella called "Phase 1 of what we want to do for veterans. Phase 2 would be to have a small community where veterans could live and have the resources right there within the same property."
They're looking ahead to complete that vision of veterans care.
Candella explained, "There are those in Queen Anne's County who own large farms/acres that they might be able to afford to donate to help create such a small community for veterans. We have an architect working on a drawing/design for such a community of tiny small homes, starting at 300 to 500 square feet for one veteran to reside. For two people to reside, the home would be slightly bigger. We're thinking we'd have 25 to possibly 50 tiny homes within the 25-acres, a center for services veterans need, an exercise room, and a swimming pool. This community would be veteran centered for their needs."
Johnson referred to the community as, "Operation Thank You for Your Service."
"Fellowship is so important for veterans," Johnson said. "All of them lived by a moral code — 'I'll die for you, you'll die for me,' if it came to that. Those in combat learned to live by that code."
Candella said, "As soon as we get the resource center staffed full-time, we'll be ready to move forward with the living community, and I'm expecting with the support we've received thus far, that will be in a matter of a few months" Since the interview, the center is now staffed full-time. He added, "There are communities like the one I've described already in existence in Brunswick, Georgia, and in Alabama. Those communities for veterans were put together by local people wanting to assist veterans in need."
Also serving on the VAMSA board of directors, Dr. Sushma Jani, professional psychiatrist, of Centreville, who wrote the clinical practice guidelines for both the Department of Defense and Veterans Administration.
Johnson said, "We're blessed to have such people working with us. Many of us believe that the mission of their project to care for veterans has been divinely inspired. Everything that has happened thus far has been the answer to many peoples prayers."
Anyone who would be interested in helping with the donation of 23-acres for a veterans community can email executive.director@vamsa.us. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on VAMSA's efforts to support veterans through a resource center, mental health services, and community development. While 'Health' relates to PTSD and suicide prevention, the primary emphasis is on public safety initiatives for veterans. 'Local Government' is less fitting as VAMSA is a non-profit, not a governmental entity.

title: Police: Two teen girls carjacked, assaulted 74-year-old woman
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Police: Two teen girls carjacked, assaulted 74-year-old woman

 April 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 434
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Two females suspects, ages 16 and 18, are in custody after they allegedly assaulted and carjacked a 74-year-old woman in Perryville on Wednesday, April 24 — while she was doing them a favor, according to police.Investigators arrested the suspects after locating them and the stolen vehicle in York, Pennsylvania, on Thursday morning — about 12 hours after the carjacking, which occurred at approximately 7 p.m. Wednesday on Honaker Street near Keesey Lane, reported Chief Robert Nitz of the Perryville Police Department.
The suspects are awaiting extradition back to Cecil County, where both have been charged as adults with numerous criminal offenses, according to Nitz. (Juveniles who are at least 16 and are accused of committing certain serious crimes, including carjacking, automatically are charged as adults.)
Because officials cannot serve the two suspects with the charging documents until after extradition, Nitz declined to release their names on Thursday.
Police reported that the suspects approached the elderly woman in the Royal Farms parking lot in the 5400 block of West Pulaski Highway (Route 40) and asked her for a short ride in her Nissan Altima.
The victim obliged and started driving toward downtown Perryville, as the suspects had requested, police said. Then one of the suspects asked her to turn onto Honaker Street, and she did, police added.
"When they got to the end of Honaker Street, the suspect in the front seat asked her to stop and then both suspects demanded that she exit the vehicle. When she did, the two suspects assaulted the woman. They threw her to the ground and drove away in her car," Nitz outlined, before noting that PPD officers rushed to the scene at 7:06 p.m. after the incident was reported.
Paramedics reportedly gave the victim medical attention.
In addition to searching for the stolen vehicle and the suspects in Perryville and the surrounding area, officers broadcasted a be-on-the-lookout (BOLO) over the police radio, Nitz reported. In addition, investigators entered information about the stolen vehicle and the carjacking incident into two national crime databases, which proved to be beneficial in the investigation, according to Nitz.
Police located the stolen Nissan in York, Pa. while handling an incident that involved 10 suspects, including the two females who allegedly committed the carjacking in Perryville, Nitz reported.
Authorities in York contacted PPD early Thursday morning after matching the Nissan they had recovered to the stolen one that PPD investigators had entered in the national databases, according to Nitz.
Police in York charged the two suspects with possession of stolen property in that jurisdiction, Nitz said. PPD investigators filed numerous criminal charges, including carjacking, against the two suspects in Cecil County, he added. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal incident involving carjacking and assault, which directly relates to public safety. While 'Crime' is a close subtopic, it's not explicitly listed in the topics. 'Local Government' is relevant due to police involvement but is secondary to the primary focus on the criminal act itself.

title: After two deadly work zone crashes, Maryland officials press for change
author: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service
content:
After two deadly work zone crashes, Maryland officials press for change

 April 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1103
 Words 

 Read News Document

 After a pair of deadly work zone incidents cast attention on the dangers of road work, Maryland Gov. Wes Moore enacted a set of protections for workers and their families that his administration describes as "a moral imperative."Hours after the state's legislature adjourned, a bill increasing fines for work zone speed violations and another covering educational costs for families of fallen workers were among the first measures from the 2024 session that Moore signed into law.
At a bill signing ceremony, Lt. Gov. Aruna Miller, a former transportation engineer, invoked two fatal crashes that inspired the new legislation. In March 2023, six highway workers died when a car careened into a work zone on Interstate 695. Nearly a year later, six construction workers repairing potholes atop the Francis Scott Key Bridge were killed when a container ship struck the bridge, causing it to collapse.
"The men and women in the construction industry place themselves in harm's way every day on the frontline of service," Miller said. "We saw it happen on March 22, 2023. And we saw it happen again on March 26, 2024. It's a moral imperative that we protect workers who provide critical service, public service for all of us."
Among the measures to receive Moore's signature was the Maryland Road Worker Protection Act, which Miller championed throughout the legislative session and touted Tuesday, during an event overlooking the site of the I-695 crash to mark National Work Zone Awareness Week.
Effective June 1, the new law permits the installation of multiple speed cameras within a single work zone and raises the fine for speed camera violations to $80. The current penalty in Maryland is $40, among the lowest such fines in the country.
Beginning January 2025, fines shift to a tiered system ranging from $60 to $500 depending on the driver's speed. Fines will double if workers are present at the time of the violation.
While the law is viewed as a direct response to the I-695 crash, officials said it also acknowledges the dangers that road workers experience every day. In 2023, there were 1,287 work zone crashes across Maryland, an average of 3.5 per day.
Steven Cook, a field maintenance technician with the Maryland Department of Transportation who attended Tuesday's event, said highway work requires constant vigilance. He has witnessed drivers who ignore signs, take out traffic cones and slip into work zones. "It happens more often than what people really think about and notice," Cook told Capital News Service.
"You always got to have your head on a swivel with being out here on the highway … We're sitting ducks when we're out here on the job," Cook added.
The new law is part of a larger effort to change driver behavior in work zones by strengthening enforcement methods and increasing education. Distracted driving, aggressive driving and speeding are the leading causes of work zone crashes, according to the State Highway Administration.
"Most crashes are not accidents," State Highway Administrator William Pines told Capital News Service. "In reality, they're very preventable. The majority of crashes that occur happen because of behaviors with drivers. So if we want to stop the root cause of most crashes, we've got to deal with driver behavior."
But the law offers no safety solutions for incidents like the collapse of the Key Bridge, which was unrelated to driver behavior. Maryland Transportation Secretary Paul Wiedefeld told Capital News Service on Tuesday that officials may consider structural solutions to bolster bridge safety but are awaiting the results of an investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board before making any specific policy proposals.
Instead, lawmakers responded to the bridge collapse by recognizing the toll that work zone crashes leave on workers' families.
In the final hours of the legislative session, the General Assembly passed the Protecting Opportunities and Regional Trade (PORT) Act, primarily aimed at providing emergency aid to workers and businesses affected by the closure of the Port of Baltimore. Moore's administration offered a successful amendment to the bill creating the Fallen Transportation Workers Scholarship Program, providing tuition assistance for five years of full-time study or eight-years of part-time study to children and spouses of workers who have died on the job since 2022.
"What happened on the bridge is horrifically traumatic, and I think one of the things that we wanted to do is protect others who are in a similarly dangerous situation," said Maryland Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore city), who co-sponsored the PORT Act.
"Certainly, we wish there were no one participating in that fund, but sadly, we know how dangerous this work is," he continued.
The scholarship reflected efforts by the state's Latino Caucus, which met with members of Moore's administration in the days after the bridge collapse and sought financial support for families of the victims. The six men who died were all immigrant construction workers from Latin America. Three of the workers killed in the I-695 crash were also of Latino origin.
"When someone passes, particularly as the breadwinner or primary breadwinner of their family, it trickles down," said Del. Ashanti Martinez (D-Prince George's), chair of the Latino Caucus. "It's not just about their immediate family, but those that they support in the community or back home."
Del. Deni Taveras (D-Prince George's), a member of the caucus' executive board, said she was pleased to see the scholarship included in the PORT Act but expressed concern about how families would meet immediate needs for rent, food and clothing.
"Something is definitely better than nothing," Taveras said. "I'm happy that they can have a secure future for themselves through access to college."
Another executive board member, Del. Joe Vogel (D-Montgomery), said he hopes the state will continue to acknowledge the workers' sacrifices and support their families' needs over the long term.
"I want the families to feel like the lives lost were not in vain and that the state appreciates and recognizes the immense value of those six individuals," Vogel said.
Beyond the legislative remedies, state officials have called the two work zone tragedies an opportunity for awareness. They've said the workers' deaths, as well as countless other close calls that happen each day, are a reminder that road workers take on labor that is essential and difficult but also overlooked. And that many are sacrificing their lives to do so.
"Our work zones are filled with mothers, fathers, sisters, brothers, close friends and your neighbors," Pines said, standing atop an overpass for Tuesday's National Work Zone Awareness Week event as cars and trucks zipped underneath. "They're building a better, safer, world-class highway system to provide access and opportunity to every single user. The highway is their office. Protecting them must be a priority for us."
Angelique Gingras contributed reporting for this story. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Maryland's legislative response to work zone safety, including new laws to protect road workers through increased fines and scholarship programs. While local government actions are mentioned, the core theme revolves around public safety measures to prevent accidents and protect workers.

title: Legal gray areas hinder police watchdogs
author: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service
content:
Legal gray areas hinder police watchdogs

 April 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1464
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Three years after state lawmakers celebrated the passage of the Maryland Police Accountability Act, the rollout of the new police oversight systems has proven slow, inconsistent and rife with disagreements about how to implement the new oversight process — challenges that frustrate critics and administrators alike.But the Maryland General Assembly has shown little appetite for revisiting the law, leaving many of the unresolved questions about the new police oversight systems in the hands of local governments.
A Capital News Service investigation revealed that roughly a quarter of Maryland jurisdictions did not get their police oversight systems up and running before the July 2022 deadlines set by state lawmakers. The new oversight bodies in Baltimore City, along with Dorchester, Cecil and Kent Counties, did not meet until 2023.
Even in jurisdictions that did meet the deadline, some administrators have struggled to navigate ambiguities in the law. In one county, three people who submitted misconduct complaints later had to defend themselves in court against counter-accusations that they had submitted false reports and wasted police resources.
The 2021 Maryland Police Accountability Act outlined a three-tiered police oversight system that theoretically overhauled the state's long-standing rules for police misconduct investigations and gave civilian bodies the authority to receive misconduct complaints, review police internal investigations and issue discipline. The reforms were the most prominent contribution by Maryland lawmakers to a wave of police oversight reforms nationwide in the wake of the murder of George Floyd by a Minneapolis police officer a year earlier.
Maryland House Majority Leader David Moon, D-Montgomery County, was a member of the Maryland General Assembly's police reform and accountability work group and a leading voice of support for the Police Accountability Act in 2021. He says state lawmakers generally expect local governments to be proactive in making the new police oversight systems work, though he doesn't always endorse that approach.
"If there are real issues, of course, the state can step in for clarification, but we are essentially still in the early stages of allowing the implementation to flow through local governments," Moon said.
Police Accountability Boards, or PABs, form the foundation of the new system. The boards are responsible for receiving civilian complaints and passing them to the appropriate law enforcement agency for an internal investigation.
State lawmakers set an unenforced timeline for the creation of new county-level police oversight agencies: each jurisdiction, including Baltimore City, would establish a PAB by July 2022, and each PAB would release an annual report on its activities that year.
But a half-dozen counties struggled to stand up their PABs and to refer complaints for investigation before that deadline, generally because of administrative barriers, a shortage of volunteers, or simply the scale of the task.
Moon says that state lawmakers anticipated those setbacks, but opted to set a shorter timeline to establish the new oversight bodies rather than stalling the process on behalf of smaller jurisdictions. "We ultimately decided to force the implementation process along, even if there were delays and hiccups," he said.
In many counties, a lack of outreach and preparation meant that positions on the boards "often went to people who were already in the loop," said Yanet Amanuel, the Director of Public Policy for the ACLU of Maryland.
Those delays have come with consequences. Joshua Harris, the chair of Baltimore City's PAB, says administrative red tape pushed back the board's first meeting to February of last year, during which the city's Office of Equity and Civil Rights accepted more than 300 complaints on the board's behalf; the city did not form its ACC until July 2023.
"[By the time of its first meeting], our ACC already had a backlog of cases," Harris said. "If cases are not reviewed within a year and a day [after they are submitted], whatever the police department's integrity bureau decides is basically final. That could mean there are problematic officers that remain on the streets."
Harris adds that the committee also continues to receive cases for review with little time to spare before the 366-day deadline, forcing them to rush their review or risk leaving the discipline to the discretion of the police department.
Meanwhile, county attorneys and PAB administrators elsewhere in the state have raised concerns that the rules for reviewing police misconduct and issuing discipline are riddled with ambiguities.
The Worcester County State's Attorney's Office's decision to bring criminal charges against three people whose police misconduct complaints were deemed to be unfounded offers a prime example.
"The law does not currently provide protections for people who file complaints," says Amanuel of the ACLU.
Worcester County has charged three people — including the first person to submit a complaint through the county's PAB in 2022 — with filing a false report after submitting complaints about Ocean City police officers.
The Ocean City District Court has yet to side with the State's Attorney's Office on the matter; judges dismissed all three cases, arguing that while the complaints themselves were unfounded, they did not rise to the level of criminality.
"I have never seen a case where police bring a criminal charge against a person that wanted to be heard on their view of police conduct," said Judge Richard Collins, who presided over the first trial, during his closing remarks. "I believe that it would have the effect of telling people, 'don't complain against the police because they might decide to make a criminal investigation of your differing opinions as to the conduct of these officers."
Messiah Burrell, a Pennsylvania resident and the second person to face charges after filing a misconduct report in Worcester County, believes his experience calls into question the value of the new oversight system itself.
"I might have known what I was getting into," he said. "I never got to talk to anyone on that [Police Accountability] Board. I only spoke with Ocean City Police."
The Worcester County State's Attorney's Office did not respond to inquiries about the cases.
Worcester County Attorney Roscoe Leslie, however, identified other glaring ambiguities in the Maryland Police Accountability Act, including the definition of "police misconduct" itself.
The law defines misconduct as "depriving persons of rights protected by the Constitution, violation of criminal statute and violation of law enforcement agency standards or policies."
"The way that it's written leaves it open to the interpretation that you need all three — depriving persons of constitutional rights, violating criminal statutes and violating agency policy — to constitute misconduct," Leslie argues. "I haven't taken that interpretation, but it's still possible." The Prince George's County PAB raised similar concerns, and the Maryland Attorney General's office stepped in last April to clarify that counties should use the broader definition of police misconduct.
Lawmakers in Annapolis considered one proposed change to the new police oversight system this year: a bill introduced by Baltimore delegate Malcolm Ruff (D-41) that would have granted the boards subpoena powers to conduct investigations concurrently with law enforcement agencies' internal reviews.
Jim Gormley, a former member of Howard County's PAB and a founder of the Howard County Police Accountability Task Force, argues that granting subpoena power would encourage boards to take a more active role in police oversight. At the moment, he said, most boards serve as a "mail box," in part because of uncertainty about the extent of their role in recommending reforms.
"The state law says the PABs should work to 'improve matters of policing,'" Gormley said. "What does working to improve policing actually mean? It doesn't mean nothing, but until we have a statutory mandate to take an active role, we're going to have a lack of clarity, lack of energy, and lack of drive towards accountability."
Law enforcement advocates, however, countered that the ACCs already have subpoena power — whether or not they use it — and that adding another investigative step would over-complicate an already convoluted process.
"Across the state, we're talking about hundreds of cases," Maryland Fraternal Order of Police President Clyde Boatwright told the Maryland House Judiciary Committee. "We still have found the one case that says the internal investigation should have been done differently. How many bites on the apple do we need to have?"
Ruff's bill ultimately failed to advance beyond the state's Judiciary Committee, ending consideration of changes to Maryland's police accountability system this year.
Without an appetite in the General Assembly for revisiting the Maryland Police Accountability Act — or, in some counties, confidence to expand upon the state law independent of the General Assembly — Howard County's Gormley says that those seeking to improve the new system are "a little bit stuck."
But Moon maintains that state lawmakers designed the Maryland Police Accountability Act to leave much of the decision-making to the state's 23 counties and Baltimore City.
During the drafting of the bill, "I think everybody accepted that a lot of the decisions would be made locally," Moon said. "We were standing up a framework, and local governments would have to fill in the gaps."
Tommy Tucker contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on challenges in implementing police oversight systems under Maryland's Police Accountability Act, including legal ambiguities, administrative delays, and conflicts between state law and local implementation. While local governments are involved, the core subject is police accountability and oversight, which directly falls under Public Safety. Other topics like Education or Health are irrelevant here.

title: Second man arrested for March incident in Trappe
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Second man arrested for March incident in Trappe

 May 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — Two men have been arrested for an incident that took place on Howell Point Road on March 23 in Trappe.Flamond D. Woolford, 18, of Cambridge, was arrested Monday by the Talbot County Sheriff's Office Criminal Investigations Division and charged with home invasion, kidnapping, first-degree assault, armed robbery, reckless endangerment, use of a firearm in a violent crime, conspiracy to commit the crimes and other related charges.
On Thursday, Talbot County Sheriff's Office Criminal Investigations Division arrested Yahjay N. Greene, 22, of Easton, for his alleged involvement in the incident and charged with the same charges as Woolford.
Police said investigators identified Greene as being involved in the incident. They contacted the United States Marshal's Capital Area Regional Fugitive Task Force for help with locating Greene.
Upon investigation, Greene was located and arrested without incident in Sykesville on Thursday, police said. He was transported to Talbot County Central Booking Facility and had an initial appearance before a district court commissioner.
He is being held at the Talbot County Detention Center without bond.
Police said investigators identified Woolford as being involved in the incident and obtained an arrest warrant for him. According to the news release, Maryland State Police stopped a vehicle on eastbound Route 50 in Queen Anne's County that Woolford was a passenger in. After the trooper determined Woolford was wanted by the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, Woolford was arrested without incident, police said.
Woolford was taken to the Talbot County Central Booking Facility for an initial appearance before a district court commissioner.
On March 23, residents south of Trappe were told to shelter in place while police searched for four people suspected in gunshots being fired.
Despite an hourslong search, the suspects in the incident were not found. Police were hindered by a steady downpour throughout the morning.
Deputies responding to the shots fired call found a lone subject walking on Howell Point Road. The individual reported being forced into the vehicle in an apparent armed robbery attempt.
As deputies and troopers spoke with the individual, a vehicle approached, stopped and then put the car in reverse and attempted to flee when a deputy ordered the occupants to show their hands. The car drove into a ditch, and four people got out and fled into the surrounding woods, according to a report from the sheriff's office.
Deputies — with assistance from Maryland State Police, Natural Resources Police, Dorchester County Sheriff's Office and police from Easton and Cambridge — conducted "exhaustive searches" in the area with about 30 officers and police dogs.
"The rain made things a mess, but nothing that couldn't be worked through," sheriff's Lt. Steve Hall said.
The Sheriff's Office said it was assisted by Maryland State Police and the Cambridge Police Department for this investigation, which is ongoing. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details criminal arrests, police investigations, and a violent incident involving multiple law enforcement agencies, directly aligning with Public Safety. While 'Local Government' and 'Crime' are related, the primary focus on law enforcement actions and public safety concerns makes 'Public Safety' the best fit.

title: Friday apartment fire caused by discarded smoking material
author: Staff Writer
content:
Friday apartment fire caused by discarded smoking material

 May 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 209
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Discarded smoking material caused an accidental apartment fire at The Meadows of Cambridge Apartments on Friday.According to a news release from the Office of the State Fire Marshal, the fire, which started on the second floor of a wood-framed balcony at 5238 Primrose Court, was discovered by a neighboring tenant. The discarded smoking material was from a third-floor balcony, the release stated.
It took 20 firefighters 35 minutes to control the one alarm fire.
The fire activated sprinklers on the second- and third-floor balconies. The Office of the State Fire Marshal said the activated sprinklers contained the fire and kept it from spreading into the apartments. The office said an alarm pull station was also activated by a tenant of the third-floor apartment above where the fire started.
"Residential fire sprinklers are proven to save lives, prevent injuries and protect property and valuables," Acting State Fire Marshal Jason M. Mowbray said. "This is yet another example of how the presence of an automatic fire sprinkler system protected occupants and prevented substantial fire damage to residential property."
There were no injuries or deaths reported from the fire, which caused an estimated loss of $5,500, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal.
Rescue Fire Company was the primary responding fire department. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a residential fire incident, emphasizing fire safety measures, emergency response, and the role of fire sprinklers in preventing casualties. This directly relates to Public Safety as it involves community risk management, fire prevention, and emergency services. High Street house fire under investigation

 CAMBRIDGE — The cause of a fire that started in the exterior of a two-story, single-family home in the 400 block of High Street is under investigation.According to a news release from the Office of the State Fire Marshal, the one-alarm fire, which occurred on April 29, was discovered by a neighbor.
