title: UPDATED: Pilot confirmed dead in Tred Avon River plane crash
author: VERONICA FERNANDEZ-ALVARADO valvarado@chespub.com
content:
UPDATED: Pilot confirmed dead in Tred Avon River plane crash

 July 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: VERONICA FERNANDEZ-ALVARADO valvarado@chespub.com | Section: Breaking 
 
 418
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Officials with the Maryland State Police confirmed the pilot of a small aircraft that crashed into the Tred Avon River near Easton Tuesday morning was killed in the incident.Robert Eugene Merlini, 56, of Annapolis was identified as the victim of the crash by MSP Tuesday evening.
The Merlini called in an engine failure before crashing into the river at around 9:30 a.m., the Federal Aviation Administration said in a statement to The Star Democrat. The pilot was the only person on board.
Merlini was doing work with the Maryland Advanced Development Laboratory's University Research Foundation, according to officials at the scene.
"It's a sad day for not only the aviation community, but for the scientific community," said David Abrams, the communication director for the Maryland Department of the Environment.
The FAA said the aircraft is a twin-engine Cessna 402. The plane was 30 years old, according to MSP.
According to David Heidhausen, president at the University Research Foundation, the plane was used for advanced research and development. Heidhausen said the projects included enhanced flight vision systems, cameras in the nose and helmet-mounted displays.
Heidhausen said Merlini was not developing research but relocating the plane in a "ferry flight" when he crashed.
According to a preliminary investigation, the aircraft took off shortly before 9 a.m. from Tipton Airport at Fort Meade before crashing into the Tred Avon River, MSP said. Police believe the pilot was headed toward the Easton Airport when the crash occurred.
The Easton air traffic control tower reported the incident to the emergency dispatch center, as did witnesses who observed the crash.
The FAA said it will work with the National Transportation Safety Board to conduct an investigation.
Merlini's identity was released following the notification of his next of kin. Merlini was recovered from the water and transported to the shore, where EMS personnel declared him deceased at the scene. He will be transported to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner for autopsy.
Liz Underhill, who lives along the Tred Avon, received a call from a neighbor who had seen the plane in the water. Underhill got in her boat and attempted to assess the situation. She saw the plane in the water, but no one was out of the plane.
There were numerous other people in boats trying to help.
Among the agencies on the scene were the Coast Guard, Talbot County Sheriff, Maryland State Police, Maryland Natural Resources Police, Easton Volunteer Fire Department, St. Michaels Volunteer Fire Department, Anne Arundel County Fire Department and Talbot County Emergency Services.
Konner Metz contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Pilot dies in plane crash near Easton

 EASTON — Officials with the Maryland State Police confirmed the pilot of a small aircraft that crashed into the Tred Avon River near Easton Tuesday morning was killed in the incident.Robert Eugene Merlini, 56, of Annapolis was identified as the victim of the crash by MSP Tuesday evening.

According to David Heidhausen, president at the University Research Foundation, the plane was used for advanced research and development. Heidhausen said the projects included enhanced flight vision systems, cameras in the nose and helmet-mounted displays.
Heidhausen said Merlini was not developing research but relocating the plane in a "ferry flight" when he crashed.
According to a preliminary investigation, the aircraft took off shortly before 9 a.m. from Tipton Airport at Fort Meade before crashing into the Tred Avon River, MSP said. Police believe the pilot was headed toward the Easton Airport when the crash occurred.
The Easton air traffic control tower reported the incident to the emergency dispatch center, as did witnesses who observed the crash.
The FAA said it will work with the National Transportation Safety Board to conduct an investigation.
Merlini's identity was released following the notification of his next of kin. Merlini was recovered from the water and transported to the shore, where EMS personnel declared him deceased at the scene. He will be transported to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner for autopsy.
Liz Underhill, who lives along the Tred Avon, received a call from a neighbor who had seen the plane in the water. Underhill got in her boat and attempted to assess the situation. She saw the plane in the water, but no one was out of the plane.
There were numerous other people in boats trying to help.
Among the agencies on the scene were the Coast Guard, Talbot County Sheriff, Maryland State Police, Maryland Natural Resources Police, Easton Volunteer Fire Department, St. Michaels Volunteer Fire Department, Anne Arundel County Fire Department and Talbot County Emergency Services.
Konner Metz contributed to this report.

While it has local elements, the primary focus is on the safety incident and its implications, aligning most strongly with 'Public Safety.' 'National News' is a secondary consideration due to federal agency involvement, and 'Local Life' reflects the regional context.

title: Easton traffic dashboard gives residents detailed look at crash trends
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Easton traffic dashboard gives residents detailed look at crash trends

 July 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 537
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Residents can now easily access traffic statistics online thanks to a new traffic dashboard released by the town last week.The Easton Interactive Traffic Dashboard allows users to view up-to-date vehicle, pedestrian and bicycle data from 2018 to the present.
It includes maps, charts and filters that allow users to see crash information based on time of day, where the crash took place and the weather circumstances. Residents can find specific information on categories such as drunk driving, Route 50 and distracted driving incidents.
Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said it will be a valuable resource for the community to better understand where an alarming number of accidents or traffic citations may happen.
"We are focusing on making transportation safety in Easton better," Lowrey said. "We're trying to take a methodical approach, a thoughtful approach to it. … Here is a resource, here's a transparent resource to see what is going on in the town where you live."
Ron Engle, a former town council member, helped spearhead the project, along with the Washington College Geographic Information Systems Program and the Maryland Highway Safety Office. Engle has a background in law enforcement and with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
Sean Lynn, the GIS program manager at Washington College, presented the tool to the Easton Town Council on Monday.
"Hopefully it allows the folks here in the town to be able to get the information quickly," Lynn said.
Ever since the pandemic in 2020, Lowrey said it's been hard to recruit officers. With limited human resources but a need to improve traffic safety, Lowrey began to think about solutions from an "engineering" standpoint.
"An officer sitting at a location, the impact ends soon after the officer leaves," he said. "Engineering (and) other means are more of a 24-hour solution."
Lowrey added that it'll help not just residents, but his team of officers as well. The department will be better-equipped to answer questions such as, "How many of these are left turn-related? How many of these are red light-related?," Lowrey said.
The dashboard is a step in completing a Strategic Highway Safety Plan for the town. Engle, Lowrey and Mayor Megan Cook have been working to develop the plan.
Lowrey said a Strategic Highway Safety Plan will open up the ability for the town to acquire grant funding. He pointed to Salisbury as a local jurisdiction that has embraced the state's "Vision Zero' initiative that was passed by the state legislature in 2019.
"Behind it is the notion that you try to reduce fatalities and serious injury accidents down to zero," Lowrey said. "It's a pretty big goal, a really difficult one."
According to Lowrey, a plan outline for Easton will be completed in about a month. Engle told council members on Monday that a lack of data was perhaps the "biggest problem" for the town in terms of developing a highway safety plan.
Engle said the dashboard will be a "strong compliment" to developing the plan in line with the Vision Zero initiative.
"I would hope by fall that we're at a place where we can present a finalized plan before the council with a pretty good idea that they're going to approve it," Lowrey said.
The interactive traffic dashboard can be accessed by visiting https://eastonmd.gov/196/Police and clicking on the dashboard image. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Easton's traffic dashboard as a tool to improve transportation safety, reduce accidents, and support the town's Strategic Highway Safety Plan. While it involves local government initiatives, the primary purpose aligns with public safety goals, particularly in addressing traffic-related risks and community safety.

title: Chester man charged in murder of father
author: Staff Writer

Chester man charged in murder of father

 July 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 CHESTER — A Chester man has been arrested in connection with the murder of his father. The Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff's Criminal Investigation Unit arrested Drew Bernard Meyer, 32, of Chester, charging him with first degree murder in the death of his father, Wayne Michael Meyer, 65, also of Chester.According to police reports, on May 17, deputies were dispatched to Auckland Way in Chester, for a report of a cardiac arrest. Upon arrival, deputies found Wayne Meyer deceased under "suspicious circumstances."
The Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff's Criminal Investigation Unit assumed the investigation and identified Drew Meyer as the primary suspect in the isolated event. A short time later he was apprehended by an allied police agency.
Meyer is being held without bond pending his preliminary hearing on Aug. 7.
In a statement released to the public, Sheriff Gary Hofmann said, "Our thoughts are with the Meyer family during this incredibly difficult time. We are committed to protecting the privacy of the family as they navigate this tragic event. This was an isolated domestic situation, and we appreciate the public's trust in our investigators to bring this case to a swift conclusion. We are grateful that Drew Meyer will now be processed through the criminal justice system, ensuring that justice is served."
Anyone with additional information about the case is asked to contact DFC Armington of the Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff at 410-758-0770 ext. 1938 or carmington@qac.org. The Anonymous Tip Line can also be reached at 410-758-6666.

title: Investigators looking into fatal crash in Easton
author: Staff Writer
content:
Investigators looking into fatal crash in Easton

 July 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Crime 
 
 259
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE — The Independent Investigations Division of the Maryland Office of the Attorney General is investigating a fatal crash following an attempted traffic stop and pursuit that occurred in Easton Monday evening.The preliminary investigation revealed that just after 7 p.m., deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, in marked police cruisers, encountered a car in the area of westbound Route 50 and Dutchmans Lane, where they attempted to initiate a traffic stop.
The driver of the car did not stop and continued to drive on Route 50. The deputies pursued the vehicle for several minutes.
Officers from the Easton Police Department assisted during the pursuit, which ended several minutes later when the car being pursued crashed into a tree in the 8300 block of Black Dog Alley.
Four people were in the vehicle at the time of the crash, according to the investigation. Officers rendered aid to all occupants and EMS arrived on scene and began rendering medical aid.
The driver, a juvenile male, and the front seat passenger, an adult woman, were transported to a local hospital for treatment of serious injuries. The adult woman was later pronounced dead at the hospital, the attorney general's office said.
The two rear passengers, a juvenile male and an adult woman, were transported to an area hospital for treatment of serious injuries. The involved officers were equipped with body-worn cameras.
The Independent Investigations Division, with assistance from the Maryland State Police Crash Team, is investigating the circumstances leading up to the crash.
Anyone with information about this investigation is asked to contact 410-576-7070 or email at IID@oag.state.md.us.

title: UPDATED: Traffic moving again after hazmat incident St. Michaels Road
author: Tom McCall
content:
UPDATED: Traffic moving again after hazmat incident St. Michaels Road

 July 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: News 
 
 307
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Cars were backed up for miles along St. Michaels Road Wednesday morning as emergency crews responded to a hazmat incident.The incident, which occurred shortly before 9 a.m. at the intersection of St. Michaels Road and Aveley Farm Road stalled traffic for upwards of three hours Wednesday morning, according to Talbot County emergency officials.
The Maryland Department of the Environment confirmed the incident involved a chemical spill, which created a vapor cloud across the road.
Easton Volunteer Fire Department chief Sonny Jones, who was on site, said the incident occurred when a one-gallon container of muriatic acid in a pool company's van tipped over. When this acid touched the metal of the van, a toxic vapor cloud arose.
"He was treated on site and transported to the hospital," Jones said of the driver.
"With a vapor cloud going across the road, we can't drive traffic through it, so we had to shut the road down until the situation was mitigated," Jones said.
Cars were lined up almost all the way from St. Michaels to Easton because of the spill. People on their way to the Bay Hundred area were standing outside of their parked cars wondering what was going on.
An alternate way to and from St. Michaels, the Oxford Ferry, reported wait times of more than two hours Wednesday morning, Jones said.
Hazmat teams were called in from Anne Arundel and Salisbury fire departments to assist with cleanup efforts. The Easton, St. Michaels, Oxford, Trappe and Tilghman volunteer fire departments also responded to the incident.
"The Department of Emergency Services has a drone. It was invaluable because we were able to provide photographic information to the hazardous materials team as to what they were going to encounter before their personnel even suited up and be ready to mitigate the hazard," Jones said.
Traffic started moving through the intersection again around 12:30 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Seven charged with theft of LGBTQ items

 CHESTERTOWN — Three out-of-state men were charged by the Chestertown Police Department for the theft of Pride flags and other rainbow-themed items taken from the Emmanuel Church on Cross Street during the weekend of the Juneteenth celebration, June 15-16.In all, nine victims of theft were identified. The crimes occurred on Cross Street, Cannon Street, Greenwood Avenue, Water Street and High Street in Chestertown. The loss to the victims is estimated by police at approximately $1,400.
According to police, through investigation, a suspect vehicle was identified and using that information, seven suspects were identified. After additional evidence and information was collected, each suspect was charged for their involvement in these crimes, three adults and four juveniles.
Hearings are scheduled for Aug. 16 in the District Court of Kent County.
The three adult males were charged with 40 counts, all misdemeanors: multiple counts of theft; malicious destruction of property; contributing to the condition of a child; burglary, fourth-degree theft; and a hate crime.
Chief Ron Dixon said they referred the four male youths, aged 16 and 17, to the Department of Juvenile Services.
Adults charged were Mahlon Luke Fisher, 20, of Newburg; Jason Duane Smucker, 19, of Lykens; and John Caleb Stoltzfus, 18, of Gratz. Their summons was issued July 17.
The investigation was headed up by Pfc. Meera Srinivasan.
Dixon said there isn't need for the community to be on high alert, just to be aware of their surroundings, and assist police when necessary.
"This appears to be a crime of opportunity, but it was certainly directed at the LGTBQ community, which generated the hate crime charges," he said. "With the suspects all being from out of the area, there should be no cause for alarm with this group, but we ask that everyone stay vigilant and aware of their surroundings. Extra eyes and ears are a huge asset to the police."

title: Easton air traffic tower celebrates one million operations
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Easton air traffic tower celebrates one million operations

 July 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 724
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In its 17th year, the Easton air traffic control tower reached a monumental mark: one million operations.A Cessna Skyhawk piloted by Preston Hull and flight instructor Nyck Shirkey tallied the milestone number when it flew out of the airport Saturday afternoon.
The aircraft is owned by Michele Anstatt, who was the first pilot to receive service when the tower opened in 2007.
The milestone is less about the number and more about the tower's impact on the Easton community, Easton Airport Manager Micah Risher said.
"Having the air traffic control tower be the veil that increases safety, it's huge," said Risher, who delivered the tower's first transmission on Nov. 14, 2007. "It multiplies everything we do. Safety is our highest priority. Every decision we make has to be viewed through the lens of safety."
On Wednesday, air traffic controllers Jacob Hacker and Lars Hugle manned the tower with less than 600 operations to go until the millionth. Risher said the two work "in tandem," with one responsible for aircraft coming in and the other controlling what happens on the ground below.
Scott Stiefel, the airport's air traffic manager, said the tower's biggest challenge is communication with pilots. Many of the pilots that come through Easton Airport are trainees or not used to flying into an airport with a control tower.
"They're used to working at airports without an active control tower, so the procedures are entirely different," Stiefel said. "And they're just not used to having someone issue instructions and then complying."
The work of those in the tower boosts the local economy, Risher added. "You have a safe airport, people want to fly here, businesses want to relocate here, jets will come here," he said.
The tower, which is open from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. every day, is one of 264 towers under the Federal Aviation Administration Contract Tower Program. It means the tower is a federal operation, with its employees contracted from the Midwest Air Traffic Control Service.
'EVERYTHING HAS CHANGED'Constructing the FAA-approved tower in 2007 took the vision of Mike Henry, the airport's manager from 2003 to 2018. Risher said Henry led the airport's "lightning quick" construction of the tower with the FAA, which was the fastest ever seen in the contract tower program.
Risher noted that changes in the Easton Airport's usual traffic count stemmed from industry changes after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
"There was something that was called an air defense identification zone that was put around D.C., a lot of restricted airspace," Risher said. "That ended about 10 miles north of Easton, which meant all of a sudden, planes started coming to Easton instead of the other airports closer to D.C."
National figures such as then-Vice President Dick Cheney and then-Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld were flying into the airport. Henry recognized the need to adjust and build an air traffic tower.
At its outset, the Easton tower was analog-based. Almost 17 years later, Risher says "everything has changed," with computers providing radar and weather data that improves the tower's ability to provide information and help flights depart and arrive safely.
A dearth of air traffic control employees is another area of change, one that Stiefel sees as particularly challenging. Stiefel, who has been an air traffic controller since 1976 and managing the Easton tower since 2018, said the air traffic control industry is "losing people left and right."
"Until we figure out some way to get more people interested and trained, we're going to be short handed," Stiefel said. "And that's across the board, that's every air traffic control facility in the country."
Despite state-of-the-art technology and a changing workforce, a lot has remained, Risher said. As Hacker picked up a pair of binoculars to locate an aircraft preparing for landing, Risher pointed out the process of the job isn't much different.
"If you see how Jacob is doing his job right now, this is the same way we did it in 1950," Risher said. "This is literally, grab the binoculars, look out the window, see the aircraft, track them on paper flight progress strips."
It's become a balance of "traditional methods of control," and enhanced data tools to complete the job more effectively, Risher said.
"These guys do an amazing job day in and day out to keep the airport safe and keep the community safe," Risher said. "There's things they do all the time that people don't even realize." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Easton air traffic control tower's role in ensuring aviation safety, emphasizing safety protocols, community impact, and operational milestones. While local government and economic factors are mentioned, the core theme revolves around public safety through air traffic management.

title: Police investigating 'sabotage' of Greensboro's water system
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Police investigating 'sabotage' of Greensboro's water system

 July 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 328
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — The Town of Greensboro said it has discovered "deliberate sabotage" of its water system after higher than normal chlorine levels this weekend."After examining the tower wells, it was discovered that one of the chlorine regulators had been tampered with," the town wrote in a release on Monday. The release stated the Caroline County Sheriff's Office is conducting a criminal investigation.
The discovery follows resident concerns about the smell and drinkability of the town's water. On Saturday, Greensboro's public works department contacted its water and wastewater contractor, Susquehanna Operational Services, to test chlorine levels.
Resident Jose Miranda said "the smell is still really strong." He said there's no discoloration of the water, but that the chlorine smell is obvious.
In the release, the town stated that the chlorine levels were as high as 2.2 milligrams per liter over the weekend. Typical readings are around 0.56 milligrams per liter.
That mark dropped to 1.0 milligrams per liter on Monday, the town said. The Environmental Protection Agency's standard is that anything above the 4.0 milligram per level mark is not healthy to drink and could pose long-term health effects such as eye irritation and stomach problems.
On Sunday, a Facebook post by the town told residents the water is safe to drink and within Maryland Department of the Environment regulations. Multiple residents, though, commented that the chlorine-like smell and taste were still noticeable.
On July 19, the town issued a boil water notice, advising residents to boil water before drinking due to high chlorine levels.
Resident Chris Mason said the water quality issue has been recurring in the last few weeks. He said poor drinking water will especially effect those without refrigerator filters and mothers who need it for baby formula.
Town Manager Tammy Kelledes said the town changed its locks to prevent further tampering with the regulators.
Residents who would like their water tested can call 410-482-6222 or email greensboro@greensboromd.com. Anyone with information regarding the criminal investigation can call the Caroline County Sheriff's Office at 410-479-2515. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Preliminary investigation revels more details of fatal plane crash
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Preliminary investigation revels more details of fatal plane crash

 July 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 480
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A preliminary investigation report on the July 16 fatal plane crash into the Tred Avon River near Easton has been released by the National Transportation Safety Board, revealing new details of the accident.The NTSB's investigation revealed the purpose of the flight was to reposition the airplane to Easton Airport to conduct future atmospheric testing flights. The Federal Aviation Administration said the 30-year-old aircraft was a twin-engine Cessna 402.
Robert Eugene Merlini, 56, of Annapolis was identified as the victim and pilot of the crash by Maryland State Police on July 16.
According to the preliminary investigation, two days before the accident, ground engine runs were performed by maintenance personnel at the conclusion of an annual inspection.
Following the ground engine runs, Merlini stated to his manager that 12 gallons of fuel remained in each main fuel tank. Merlini said he was going to add 20 more gallons to each main fuel tank so he did not have to switch tanks during the upcoming flight.
Airport security video showed the pilot added 20 gallons of fuel to each auxiliary fuel tank, rather than the main fuel tanks. The airplane was not flown between that fueling and the flight resulting in the accident.
The aircraft took off shortly before 9 a.m. July 16 from Tipton Airport at Fort Meade before crashing into the Tred Avon River.
According to the preliminary investigation, at about 9:28 a.m., Merlini contacted the Easton Airport air traffic control tower and reported a "pretty significant engine problem."
The controller instructed the pilot to enter a right base leg, the transitional part of the traffic pattern between the downwind leg and the final approach leg when landing, for Runway 15.
About a minute later, the pilot reported the airplane was at 2,400 feel above sea level and setting up for a right base leg, with a "pretty bad right engine." About 30 seconds later, the pilot declared an emergency and stated both engines were losing power.
The controller cleared the airplane to land on Runway 15 via an approach from any direction. However, the pilot replied that he was not going to reach the airport and was going to try to land in a field. The airplane subsequently impacted the Tred Avon River about four miles southwest of the Easton Airport.
According to the report, the left wing, including the left engine, separated about 1 foot outboard of the wing root and was not located.
Merlini's identity was released following the notification of his next of kin. Merlini was recovered from the water and transported to the shore, where EMS personnel declared him deceased at the scene. He was transported to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner for autopsy.
According to the report, Merlini's most recent FAA first-class medical certificate was issued on March 27, 2024. At that time, he reported a total flight experience of 4,100 hours, with no hours accrued during the preceding six months. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Sentence handed down in fatal 301 accident
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
Sentence handed down in fatal 301 accident

 August 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 593
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Grief and remorse filled the courtroom Friday morning as Queen Anne's County Circuit Court Judge Lynn Knight heard testimony from friends and family on both sides of the sentencing hearing of Yassin Alallaq, who earlier pleaded guilty to criminally negligent manslaughter.After careful consideration, Knight sentenced Alallaq to three years, the maximum penalty under law, suspending all but 16 months to be served in the county detention center.
Alallaq, of Arlington, Virginia, was 21 at the time of the fatal accident on Route 301 that claimed the life of Barbara South of Queenstown. The April 3, 2023, accident occurred shortly after 8 a.m. in the area of Rolling Bridge Road. South was en route to help care for her 2-year-old granddaughter and Alallaq, in his words, was rushing to get to school.
A student at Delaware State University, Alallaq was training as an aviation student with the goal of becoming a military pilot. He was an officer candidate for the U.S. Coast Guard.
According to the investigation reports, South was traveling northbound in a Subaru Outback on Route 301 in the second lane when Alallaq crossed the line separating lane 1 from lane 2, striking the driver side rear of the Outback with his Chevrolet Sonic traveling a recorded speed of about 96 mile per hour.
The Outback rolled three times before coming to rest, police said. South was transported to Shock Trauma Center, where she remained in a coma for two weeks before succumbing to her injuries. Alallaq was treated for superficial injuries. No other conditions, including drugs or alcohol contributed to the crash, according to the investigation.
South's family members spoke at length, sharing how she was "a good person who had a wide circle of family and friends who loved her."
Speaking through tears in a barely controlled voice, South's son Jonathan repeated how frequently he thinks "she should be here."
"There are no words to describe this loss," said Lance Richardson, state's attorney for Queen Anne's County.
"It is one of the most tragic cases I have seen in 30 years," he said.
In requesting the sentence, Richardson said, it was not lost on him the adversity the defendant had overcome, nor his character — to which many spoke on his behalf as being concerned, diligent, responsible and displaying a "high level of integrity."
Richardson requested 18 months of time to be served and 100 hours of community service. He said he took no joy in asking for incarceration but could not ignore the defendant had a history of traffic violations involving speed.
"There is no fair outcome to any involved," Richardson said.
Speaking to the court, Alallq professed a "heavy heart, deep remorse ... profound sadness and guilt" pledging his commitment to ensure his "actions honor the memory of Mrs. South." Without the court's direction, Alallq has booked speaking engagements talking to other youth about the finality of his actions.
Knight said she recognized no actions taken by the court could bring back the victim. However, it was her duty to consider "punishment, deterrence and rehabilitation," she said. As to rehabilitation, Knight gave credit to the young man for being on that path already and taking initiative on his own.
Knight's sentencing included 100 hours of community service for Alallq to continue efforts he had begun and five years supervised probation, in which she ordered drug and alcohol testing and mental health evaluation. Knight reasoned, though there was no history of substance abuse, individuals in such a situation may be inclined to turn to those as a resource, and she hoped to not see that as an unintended negative consequence. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a court case involving a fatal traffic accident and subsequent sentencing, focusing on legal proceedings, accountability, and the impact on public safety. While it includes local government elements (court system), the core theme revolves around safety implications of the accident and judicial response.

title: Following week of intense controversy, Maryland fire chief resigns
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Following week of intense controversy, Maryland fire chief resigns

 August 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 421
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Following a week of controversy, the chief of the Waldorf Volunteer Fire Department has resigned.In a statement published late on Aug. 2, it was revealed that Chief John Durrer announced his resignation the day prior, effective immediately.
A report leaked to the media earlier in the week written by the Charles County Volunteer and EMS Association's Significant Incident Response Team — which is comprised of a group of volunteer chiefs — detailed issues with the chain of command on the scene of a June 5 fire on Needlefish Court in Waldorf.
"At some point around the 20-minute duration check, Chief 3 relinquished command to Chief 12B. With the lack of after-action reports from any chief of Waldorf, it is not known why this occurred," the report reads. "In addition, Truck 1 was removed from the structure and was told to report to the Alpha Side for not following directions. Once again, without any reports from any chief of Waldorf it is not known why this occurred."
The report used inflammatory language, calling it a "miracle" that firefighters had not been seriously injured or died yet.
Southern Maryland News attempted to reach the Waldorf chief through phone calls to the firehouse earlier in the week but did not get a response.
"Out of respect for and commitment to the [Waldorf Volunteer Fire Department]'s mission, I have decided to resign as the chief of the [Waldorf department]. The men and women of the [Waldorf department] deserve to have absolute support of and focus on the fulfillment of their critical mission, which is to serve and protect the citizens of Charles County," Durrer stated in the release. "I am extremely proud of the dedicated [Waldorf department] members and thank them for the opportunity to serve."
James W. King, the president of the Waldorf Volunteer Fire Department, thanked Durrer for serving as chief over the past four years and as a volunteer firefighter for 47 years.
"Being the chief is an immense and difficult responsibility. I commend Chief Durrer for his service and for putting first the needs and mission of the [Waldorf Volunteer Fire Department]," King said in the release. "I want to assure the citizens of Charles County, that the [Waldorf department] will continue to operate and serve the community with the highest level of professionalism and integrity."
King said that the department will continue to review and monitor its performance and take steps that improve the effectiveness of their emergency response.
There will be a special election for a new chief within the next 30 days, according to the release. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a fire chief's resignation due to internal operational controversies within a local fire department, which directly relates to public safety management. While local government could be a secondary consideration, the core issue involves emergency response protocols and organizational accountability, aligning most closely with Public Safety.

title: 5-year-old dies after bounce castle swept away at Blue Crabs game
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
5-year-old dies after bounce castle swept away at Blue Crabs game

 August 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 501
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A 5-year-old child died after a bounce castle was swept away by a wind gust at the Aug. 2 Southern Maryland Blue Crabs game.It was revealed through online fundraising and memorial posts that the 5-year-old was Declan Hicks of La Plata.
"That day family, friends, and the world lost a dinosaur lover, ninja turtle fan, and crazy sock wearing (with boots!) 5-year-old, Declan Hicks," Tiffany Goudie, the organizer of a GoFundMe for Hicks' family, wrote on the page.
"Hicks was a part of the Blessed Lambs Preschool family for 3 years. He was a very special little boy who brought light and laughter to everyone who had the pleasure of knowing him," Gouldie said. "To know him was to love him. He was a great friend, and a fan favorite in his 4-year-old classroom, not just with other children but with his teachers."
Hicks was a member of the La Plata Blue Knights Football and Cheerleading Organization as a flag football player.
In a Facebook post by the organization, the Blue Knights said that they will be dedicating their upcoming season to Hicks, all flag football players and cheerleaders will wear a patch and all tackle football players will have his number on their helmets.
At 9:21 p.m. Aug. 2, Charles County 911 Public Safety Communications received a call from the Regency Furniture Stadium reporting that a moon bounce house became airborne due to a wind gust, while children were inside it.
At the time, the Southern Maryland Blue Crabs baseball team was playing a game, and the moon bounce was carried approximately 15 to 20 feet in the air, causing children to fall before it landed on the playing field, a release from Charles County government said.
Charles County EMS personnel, who were stationed at the stadium for the game, along with trainers from the baseball team and several volunteer first responders, swiftly began patient care within minutes of the incident.
One pediatric patient sustained life-threatening injuries and was transported by Maryland State Police Trooper 2 to Children's Hospital. This patient, the 5-year-old boy from La Plata, died at the hospital.
A second pediatric patient who sustained non-life-threatening injuries was also flown out by MSP Trooper 7.
"We extend our deepest empathy to the children and their families during this difficult time," Commission President Reuben B. Collins II (D) said. "We thank our EMS team and the Maryland State Police for their swift actions to ensure the children received immediate care."
Courtney Knichel, general manager of the Southern Maryland Blue Crabs said that "our entire organization shares our condolences with the family mourning the loss of a child, and concern for the child who was injured. Our thoughts and prayers are with them all."
The Southern Maryland Blue Crabs canceled Saturday's baseball game and all baseball activities for Aug. 3 and are offering counseling and support to families, players and fans who attended the game.
A spokesperson from the Charles County Sheriff's Office said that the agency is working with investigators from Maryland Occupational Safety and Health, who will lead the investigation. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a tragic accident involving a bounce castle being swept away by wind at a public event, leading to a child's death and involving emergency services. The primary focus is on the safety incident, emergency response, and investigation, aligning most closely with Public Safety. While Health (medical aspects) and Local Government (county involvement) are tangentially relevant, the core narrative revolves around public safety protocols and incident response.

title: Greensboro adds security measures, hears resident feedback after water system 'sabotage'
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Greensboro adds security measures, hears resident feedback after water system 'sabotage'

 August 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 549
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — Town employees discussed an apparent "sabotage" of Greensboro's water system and heard feedback from residents during a Thursday evening Town Council meeting.On July 29, the town announced that the its water and wastewater contract operator, Susquehanna Operational Services, conducted tests throughout town, finding higher than normal chlorine levels. It came after a bevy of complaints from concerned residents, who said the water had a chlorine-like taste and smell the weekend prior.
The town concluded that "one of the chlorine regulators had been tampered with" in the tower wells. In a press release, it was deemed "deliberate sabotage," and the town stated the Caroline County Sheriff's Office would conduct an investigation.
Brandon Cunningham, the town's public works supervisor, provided an update Thursday on security measures put in place in days since. Cunningham said "the locks have all been changed to all the well houses."
Keys were given to members of Susquehanna Operational Services, and himself and the town manager in case of emergency, he said.
He also said he's been in contact with SafeHouse, a security system company, to potentially procure security cameras and keypads. Cunningham said SafeHouse security measures, including adding cameras, would cost $15,865.54.
Councilmember Joe Noon said he'd "like a couple more bids" for the cameras and security additions. Carly Landolfi, assistant to the town attorney, told councilmembers they could vote on a "contingent" motion to purchase the SafeHouse services, depending on whether she finds the town must legally seek out other bids or not.
Mayor David Spencer said he's visited the wells and vouched for security services to be adopted as soon as possible.
"I really don't want to push this off," Spencer said. Councilmember Pete Breila made a motion to pass the "contingent" motion, which was seconded by Councilmember Bob Harrison.
PUBLIC COMMENTMultiple residents expressed concerns about the water quality and the town's response to councilmembers Thursday.
"The word sabotage, that's a pretty extensive word," resident Chris Mason said. "It means a lot, and it puts fear in the community."
Mason continued, questioning why the investigation is being conducted by Caroline County Sheriff's Office and not the Greensboro Police Department. He added that he wished the town had passed out water to residents during the days in which the chlorine-like taste and smell was apparent.
"Who has access to sabotage?" resident Melissa Knight asked. "Where'd that information come from? We're not getting any forthcoming information."
Knight said that "the entire bedroom (smelled) like chlorine" after flushing the toilet in her house last weekend. She also asked about the process of testing the chlorine levels.
George Smith, president of Susquehanna Operational Services, said his team tested multiple locations when notified by the town of the complaints. Smith and a Susquehanna employee confirmed there were readings of 2.2, 0.6 and 0.54 milligrams per liter. The Environmental Protection Agency's standard is that anything above the 4.0 milligram per liter mark is not healthy to drink and could pose long-term health effects such as eye irritation and stomach problems.
Smith declined to comment on the investigation since it's active. Spencer also declined.
"There's a lot that we'd all like to say," Spencer said. "But since there is an investigation ongoing, when that is concluded, then we will try to give you as much information as we possibly can."
The Caroline County Sheriff's Office declined to comment on the investigation for this article. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Greensboro's response to a water system sabotage, including security upgrades, investigations, and resident concerns. While local government procedures are discussed, the core issue revolves around public safety measures to protect critical infrastructure and community well-being.

title: Ridgely residents call for police department to be reinstated
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Ridgely residents call for police department to be reinstated

 August 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 665
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — Following tense public comment at Monday's Ridgely Town Meeting, residents are calling for the Ridgely Police Department and its officers to be reinstated after nearly five months of suspension.The Commissioners of Ridgely suspended the department in March, with pay, pending an investigation by the Maryland Office of the State Prosecutor. At Monday's meeting, residents raised that the department and its officers had been exonerated by investigators surfaced.
Multiple people asked for the department to be reinstated. Resident James Romph questioned the commissioners and town employees on the investigation.
"What is the update on the Ridgely Police Department investigation?" Romph asked.
"Sir, I'd love to answer that but I was told to keep my mouth shut," David Crist, the town's director of public works, responded.
"I'm going to answer it for you, for the public," Romph said. "The entire police department has been exonerated. The state has concluded their investigation and found no fault with the police department or the police chief, criminally or administratively. They're exonerated."
As of Tuesday, town employees and the Office of the State Prosecutor did not immediately respond to requests regarding the report and whether or not it cleared the department and its officers.
Romph claimed the commissioners had "known for over two weeks and didn't share that with you," speaking to the standing-room-only crowd, which included members of the police department.
"No we have not, we have not been notified," Commissioner John Hurley said. Crist backed the commissioners up, saying they hadn't been notified but confirming that he had been. Romph questioned why Crist did not inform the commissioners or the public.
"From my counsel, I was told this is a personnel matter, you cannot speak," Crist said. "I'm not a lawyer, I don't know law. But if the town attorney tells me to zip it, I'm zipping it."
Since the initial suspension, the town has not provided clear reasoning for the investigation. Nor has the Office of the State Prosecutor.
The town came to a temporary memorandum of understanding with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, agreeing that the Sheriff's Office and Maryland State Police would split duties to cover the suspended department.
In May, the town agreed to a new memorandum of understanding with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, this one providing a "long-term partnership" for fiscal year 2025. It included "a provision for maintaining 480 hours of coverage per month," per a town release, and took effect on July 1.
Caroline County Chief Deputy Rodney Helmer told The Star Democrat on Tuesday that the updated MOU is still in effect. As of Tuesday, the county had not heard from the town requesting to cease the MOU. Such a request would require 30 days of notice, Helmer said.
Residents have brought concerns about the county's law enforcement coverage compared to what town police provided. Resident and business owner Holly Justice says it hasn't been the same.
"When you deal with a big giant, you lose a lot of those small-town things," Justice said in an interview. "The county, they have a lot of area to cover, and although we have officers that they did dedicate to this territory, it's just not the same."
Justice created a petition Tuesday, asking the town to reinstate the officers. As of Tuesday evening, it had over 30 signatures.
"People's lives were jeopardized with this," Justice said. " … These people have families. My heart goes out to them. But I also understand the town's side, being told by their counsel that they can not speak about this matter.
"Instead of joining in with the brigade and yelling and fussing, I said, 'What's a better way to come at this? What's a better way to be heard and be seen?'"
Resident Lakia Harris-Pierce said she believes residents should be informed on the investigation's results. "They need to make the investigation public, we have the right to know," she said.
Town commissioners are meeting in closed session Wednesday afternoon to discuss personnel matters, according to an agenda posted to the town's website.
Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado and Tom McCall contributed reporting to this story. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on residents demanding the reinstatement of the Ridgely Police Department after an investigation, highlighting public safety concerns and community reactions. While local government procedures are mentioned, the core issue revolves around law enforcement and public safety.

title: Man sentenced to life without parole for 2023 murder of Jasmine Hicks
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Man sentenced to life without parole for 2023 murder of Jasmine Hicks

 August 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 579
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Aug. 6, Deanthony Lamont Warrick, 35, was sentenced to life without parole for the April 2023 murder of Jasmine Hicks.Hicks was stabbed to death in the overnight hours of April 12, 2023 after an argument with Warrick. She was 29 at the time.
A video captured by a security camera system on a nearby house was presented during the trial.
The video depicted Hicks and Warrick leaving a red Chrysler vehicle in the 2300 block of Woodberry Drive in Bryans Road, when Warrick realized that PCP, a handgun and an assault rifle were missing from the vehicle, according to testimony.
Warrick argued with Hicks and got progressively louder until Warrick grabbed a knife and repeatedly stabbed Hicks. Police said lacerations were found on her head, neck, hands and upper arms.
Hicks could be heard on tape, from across the street, saying, "You've already killed me. I'm already dead."
Warrick tried to move Hicks, who was still alive at the time, into his car. He gave up and fled the scene.
Hicks' family attended en masse for the sentencing, with Assistant State's Attorney Laura Caspar presenting the case to give Warrick life without parole.
Caspar told Judge William R. Greer that the State's Attorney's Office does not seek this sentence in every case, but that the murder of Jasmine Hicks was "vile, malicious and vengeful."
Warrick claimed at one point that Hicks had a gun and that the killing was in self-defense, but the footage from the camera that caught the murder showed otherwise.
"Where's my s—," Warrick could be heard screaming on the footage, looking for PCP and a firearm that Hicks' brother took in fear that he would use the firearm on his sister after he had pointed the firearm at a vehicle Hicks was in.
"There was no fear there," Caspar said. "There was no gun and he knew it."
After the argument escalated, Warrick stabbed Hicks a number of times before saying, "Don't make me kill you."
Hicks replied, "You already did."
Caspar could only speculate the horror that Hicks had to endure after Warrick left the scene of the murder, where Hicks was alive for another hour and a half.
Members of Hicks' family came forward to ask that Greer impose the maximum sentence.
Arthur Lancaster, Hicks' uncle, told the judge that Hicks was the type of person that would "brighten your day" and that she was a loving mother to her three children.
"Today, your honor, we are looking for closure," Lancaster said. "Deanthony Warrick is an atrocious, cruel, heinous, cold-blooded murderer."
Lancaster called Warrick a "wild animal" before saying, "Wild animals need to be caged."
Mary Lawson — Hicks' mother — fought tears to say, "She went too soon."
Lawson recalled how Hicks' children came home from school and were looking for their mother, but she had to tell them that she would not be there.
"I'll be there every time," Lawson said.
Andre Mahasa, Warrick's attorney, said that while he and Warrick respected the jury's verdict, they still believed that there was no premeditation in the murder and that it should have been second-degree murder at most.
Warrick had nothing to say to the judge after being informed of his right to speak.
During the sentencing, Greer dismissed Warrick's claim that Hicks had a firearm, saying that at some point during the stabbing, he had to realize that there was no gun.
Greer said that Warrick's actions after the attack showed a lack of empathy.
"Jasmine Hicks died alone in the night on the cold ground," Greer said before imposing a life sentence on Warrick. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal sentencing for a murder case, focusing on public safety concerns, legal proceedings, and community impact. While it involves local law enforcement and judicial processes, the core subject is the crime and its implications for public safety rather than government operations or national significance.

title: National Night Out connects cops with community
author: Tom McCall
content:
National Night Out connects cops with community

 August 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 576
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A crowd in Moton Park joined communities all over the country in celebrating the 40th annual National Night Out Tuesday.National Night Out connects different branches of law enforcement with the community. The goal is to prevent crime and have people know the officers and emergency services personnel who serve their area.
Megan Coxon, a sergeant with the Easton Police Department, has been a primary force in organizing the event.
"We are here for First Night Out, which is a nationwide event. It happens the first Tuesday in August. I probably know half the folks here just because we interact on a daily anyway," Coxon said. "It is like a mini reunion. We get to hang out for a night, and of course you get to meet new people. If I don't know you, I will come talk to you and if I have seen you before, we will reconnect."
She said she got a lot of help from Jill Garvey, an EPD management assistant, and Lorraine Gould, director of Easton Parks and Recreation.
Coxon pointed out the law enforcement representatives in attendance.
"We have at least ten from EPD. We have sheriff's office, fire marshall's office, Natural Resources Police, Talbot Sheriff's office and MSP. There are about 40 people," she said.
Over a smoking hot grill with about 50 burgers were members of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department.
"We are cooking some good burgers. We got some good hot dogs. We got a decent crowd of people, it is its a good time," Aiden Lowery, a firefighter and EMT said.
Mayor Megan Cook was also present, immersed in community.
"Talking to people? That is the best part of my job," Cook said. "The sense of community is what is important tonight. I think to see the police department as partners and to get them visible in the community so our neighbors know that they are a resource and they are there to help."
John Grothe of the state's fire marshal office had a full kevlar and ballistic shield bomb squad suit and special helmet on display. He is a bomb tech and said the suit weighs 100 pounds.
"In the event that there is a device or suspicious package, we try to stay as remote as possible. We try to utilize our bomb robot, but every once in a while, we have to put on the suit and go downrange in person. Night Out is a great opportunity to meet people and have them come up and touch the equipment. We get to explain what we do. It puts a face to the agency," Grothe said.
There were over 100 community members wandering around, getting food, visiting with friends and getting information from the community service booths.
Jessica Carter, who was sharing an shaved ice with her daughter, said the National Night Out event gives her family an opportunity to see what resources are available to them.
"We come every year. The resources. Giving back to the community. Some people may not know what resources are available to them. So it is good. I like the health department and Chesapeake Voyagers," Carter said.
Garvey said she has been working on this event for over a month. She had two massive sheet cakes from Cordova Bakery in her air conditioned vehicle.
"It falls into place. I have been planning these for 18 years. It is a free fun family event. The pool is open. Come out and enjoy. There is free food. It is a good community event," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While local government and community life aspects are present, the primary emphasis is on public safety initiatives involving police, fire, and emergency services.

title: State investigators continue investigation into fatal Easton police chase
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
State investigators continue investigation into fatal Easton police chase

 August 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 544
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Independent Investigations Division of the Maryland Office of the Attorney General is continuing its investigation into a police chase that ended in a fatality last month.In an interview with The Star Democrat, Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said his department "preliminarily" determined the county's deputies "complied" with state law and county policies on vehicle pursuits. But that determination "won't finalize" until the state investigation is complete, he said.
The state's preliminary investigation into the incident revealed that just after 7 p.m. on July 22, deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, in marked police cruisers, encountered a car in the area of westbound Route 50 and Dutchmans Lane, where they attempted to initiate a traffic stop.
According to the preliminary investigation, the front seat passenger, identified as 18-year old Yemaya Wilson, and the driver were transported to a local hospital for treatment of serious injuries. Wilson was later pronounced dead at the hospital.
The driver of the car, an unidentified juvenile male, did not stop and continued to drive on Route 50. The deputies pursued the vehicle for several minutes, with officers from the Easton Police Department assisting, before it crashed into a tree in the 8300 block of Black Dog Alley.
The two rear passengers, an unidentified juvenile male and adult woman, were transported to an area hospital for treatment of serious injuries.
Gamble said after the crash, police learned the vehicle had been stolen from Montgomery County.
The involved officers were equipped with body-worn cameras.
The attorney general's office identified the officers involved in the pursuit: Talbot County deputies Brittanie DiMichele, William Barnett and Owen Joseph, and Easton Police Department officer Nicholas Lange.
The Independent Investigations Division is continuing its investigation with assistance from the Maryland State Police Crash Team.
Both the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and Easton Police Department have standards for vehicle pursuits in their department policies, many of which are identical.
Written in both policies are factors to consider when initiating a police pursuit. These include the seriousness of the alleged crime, public safety, officers' familiarity with the area, weather or traffic patterns, if the suspect has been identified and if other people are in the vehicle that's being pursued.
Both departments' policies state that a pursuit should be halted when "present risks of continuing the pursuit reasonably appear to outweigh the risks resulting from the suspect's escape."
An administrative review by the Talbot County Sheriff's Office is underway, Gamble said. That review will not be completed until the state's investigation is complete. The three county deputies are still working, Gamble added.
In a statement to The Star Democrat, Attorney General Anthony Brown vouched for the creation state standards of police pursuits, which currently do not exist.
"I would like (to) see statewide standards for police-involved vehicle pursuits, but the rules should consider different population densities and take geography into account," Brown said in the statement. "The goal should be to make our communities safer for all, reduce fatalities and help law enforcement do their jobs effectively."
When asked about the potential of statewide standards, Gamble said "one size does not fit all," emphasizing that pursuits in populated areas like Baltimore City are different to pursuits in rural areas like Talbot County.
Gamble expressed concerns of such legislative efforts to create what he calls "one size fits all" statewide police policies. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a police pursuit leading to a fatality, investigation protocols, and debates over law enforcement policies. While involving local agencies, the core issue revolves around public safety concerns, police procedures, and community safety standards. The discussion about statewide pursuit policies also ties to broader public safety frameworks.

title: Police: Two men assaulted each other with fishing rod, fishing hook
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Police: Two men assaulted each other with fishing rod, fishing hook

 August 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 327
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RISING SUN — Two men are facing criminal charges after a fight in which fishing equipment was used as weapons — including a gaff hook that one of the combatants allegedly used to stab the other in the leg, sending him to the hospital in an ambulance, according to the Cecil County Sheriff's Office.The incident occurred at approximately 7:45 p.m. on Tuesday at a residence in the 200 block of Smith Road. near Rising Sun, police said. CCSO deputies rushed to that address after someone called 911 from that location and then hung up the phone, police added.
Investigators learned that two tenants — William Winford Abbott, 59, and Mark Alvin Vincent, 58, both of whom reside at 241 Smith Road — had gotten into a property dispute, police reported.
Abbott allegedly struck Vincent's back and side with a fishing pole, according to Lt. Michael Zack, a CCSO spokesman. Then Vincent allegedly hit Abbott in his right leg with a fishing gaff hook, puncturing Abbott's leg, Zack reported.
An ambulance crew drove Abbott to Christiana Hospital in Delaware, where he was treated for his non-life-threatening puncture wound to his leg, police said.
Arrested at the scene, Vincent is charged with first-degree assault, second-degree assault and reckless endangerment, court records show. First-degree assault is a felony that is punishable by up to 25 years in prison if convicted while second-degree assault and reckless endangerment are misdemeanors that carry maximum sentences of 10 years and five years respectively.
Vincent remained in the Cecil County Detention Center in lieu of $5,000 bond on Thursday, one day after a bail review hearing in which his no-bond status was reduced to that sum, according to court records, which indicate that Cecil County District Court Administrative Judge Bonnie G. Schneider presided over that proceeding.
Abbott, meanwhile, is charged with second-degree assault and reckless endangerment for his alleged role in the incident, court records show. Abbott was not arrested but, rather, was served a criminal summons, court records indicate. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Debby's remnants bring flooding to the Shore
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Debby's remnants bring flooding to the Shore

 August 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: News 
 
 278
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Flooding was prevalent as the remnants of Hurricane Debby hit the Eastern Shore Friday morning, with communities bracing for unusually high tides later that day."We've gotten a report on email from Emergency Management. It's been minor flooding so far," said Rescue Fire Company Chief Adam Pritchett Friday afternoon. "I believe the high tides are expected to be tonight of concern for Cambridge. But as of right now, it's been minor flooding so far."
The Town of Oxford warned residents that higher-than-expected tides could cause further flooding in the area Friday evening.
"Please be aware that the NOAA prediction for this evening's high tide has changed significantly and is now anticipated to be 4.5 feet, which could produce major flooding," the town said in an email to residents Friday afternoon. "By comparison, this morning's high tide that resulted in flooding throughout the town registered as a 3.9-foot tide at the Cambridge marker. With a 4.5-foot tide, the Causeway area will be impassable for a period of time."
Debby was downgraded to a tropical depression late Thursday afternoon, and was a post-tropical cyclone on Friday, the National Hurricane Center said. It made landfall early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida as a category 1 hurricane. Then, Debby made a second landfall early Thursday in South Carolina as a tropical storm.
Pritchett said his department was ready to help with any impacts from Friday evening's tides.
"We pretty much stay at a ready pace for things like this because it's becoming more normal all the time now with each storm that passes on," he said. "So we're kind of always ready for events like this. Have our equipment ready, checked out and so forth."

title: 22-year-old sentenced for week-long crime spree
author: Jesse Yeatman jyeatman@somdnews.com
content:
22-year-old sentenced for week-long crime spree

 August 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jesse Yeatman jyeatman@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 436
 Words 

 Read News Document

 An Anne Arundel County man was sentenced to 44 years in prison for multiple crimes committed in St. Mary's two years ago.State's Attorney Jaymi Sterling this week announced that Tyler Ray Marini Sater, 22, of Stoney Beach was sentenced to 59 years in prison, with 44 years of active incarceration, for multiple criminal convictions stemming from his week-long, one-man crime spree in late 2022.
On Dec. 13, 2022, Sater committed a robbery by knifepoint at the Cloud Smoke Shop in California, according to a release from the state's attorney's office.
Six days later, he committed an additional series of crimes at the Wildewood Shopping Center.
As a result, he was convicted of robbery, attempted armed carjacking, unlawful taking of a motor vehicle, attempted harm of a law enforcement animal, and rogue and vagabond.
While pending trial, Sater fled to Charles County. He was subsequently charged and convicted of second-degree escape.
"While the defendant was on supervised probation in several other counties for disturbingly similar crimes, he fled to our county and initiated a one-man crime spree. His deliberate actions victimized multiple community members, each suffering from the impact of his criminal conduct," Sterling (R) said in the release. "This sentence serves as a critical step toward safeguarding the public and ensuring that this Defendant can no longer target the citizens in our community."
During his arrest in 2022, Sater had been shot by Sgt. Timothy Wesner, a 10-year veteran of the agency, who fired his weapon, striking the suspect twice.
St. Mary's deputies responded to a Wawa gas station in California in regard to a vehicle theft on Dec. 19, 2022, according to a sheriff's office press release at the time.
Deputies located the stolen vehicle minutes later at a hotel in the 23400 block of Three Notch Road and the suspect fled on foot toward the Wildewood shopping center. Deputies pursued the Sater, who allegedly was armed with a knife, and attempted less lethal means by using a Taser on him multiple times. They also used a sheriff's office canine, the press release states.
Sater attempted to carjack an occupied vehicle at a restaurant, but the victim fled. Sater continued to flee through the shopping center and entered a separate vehicle which was running, but he was then shot by the deputy who fired three rounds, according to the release.
Sater was transported by helicopter to an area trauma center, the release states. No injuries to deputies were reported.
Judge Michael Stamm presided over the case. Senior Assistant State's Attorney Alena Mosier prosecuted the case.
Detective Warren Forinash, Detective Daniel Sidorowicz and Detective Taylore Nauman of the St. Mary's County Sheriff's Office were the lead investigators. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
