title: Delaware freshman killed by speeding motorcyclist on her first day of classes
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Delaware freshman killed by speeding motorcyclist on her first day of classes

 August 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 731
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sitting on a curb handcuffed, smelling of alcohol with his face bloodied and his right eye swollen, motorcyclist Brian Briddle claimed to have no memory of the high-speed crash that killed a University of Delaware freshman and injured four other pedestrians.But as he rode in an ambulance to Christiana Hospital, Briddle appeared to have one moment of clarity. "I screwed up," he told the police officer riding in the ambulance with him, according to court documents.
The court records released Friday provide the most complete picture yet of the crash that killed 18-year-old Noelia Gomez, of Clark, N.J. just hours after she attended her first day of college classes. Briddle was arrested Thursday – on his 27th birthday – and remains behind bars, charged with second-degree murder and a bevy of related offenses.
The incident began shortly before midnight Tuesday, Aug. 29, when a UD police officer saw Briddle riding a 2008 Yamaha motorcycle on Main Street near the intersection of South Chapel Street. He was riding in a "normal manner" but did not have a license plate on the motorcycle, court documents indicate.
The officer activated his emergency lights in an attempt to pull over the motorcycle. Briddle changed lanes, revved his engine and began speeding away as he passed the Haines Street intersection. The officer did not pursue the motorcycle for safety reasons and turned off his lights in the area of Haines Street.
Briddle continued down Main Street, driving at excessive speeds, making unsafe lane changes and blowing through red lights at Academy Street, South College Avenue and North College Avenue, according to court records, which indicate Briddle's reckless driving was captured on the officer's dash camera and by several surveillance cameras along Main Street.
"Main Street was full of vehicular traffic and pedestrians at the time of the incident," Master Cpl. Wayne Aston wrote in court documents. "Earlier that day was the first day of classes for the fall semester at the University of Delaware. There were vehicles parked along the roadway, vehicles traveling the roadway and vehicles stopped at red lights. There were many pedestrians walking along the adjacent sidewalks and crossing the roadway. The businesses along the roadway were still open as this occurred just before midnight, and the bars were beginning to let out."
Gomez was crossing Main Street in a crosswalk in front of Trabant University Center when Briddle's motorcycle hit her. Passersby attempted live-saving measures, but Gomez went into cardiac arrest and died at the scene.
Briddle fell off the motorcycle, which then hit a pole and four other pedestrians on a nearby sidewalk. One of the pedestrians was hospitalized for injuries, as was Briddle.
Both the officer that rode in the ambulance with Briddle and nurses at the hospital detected a faint smell of alcohol coming from Briddle, but officers were unable to perform field sobriety tests due to his injuries, court records indicate.
At the hospital, Briddle continued to insist he didn't remember the crash or the officer trying to pull him over.
"Briddle did state that he would have run from police because his motorcycle was not registered and he did not like the way that police officers treat motorcyclists," Aston wrote.
A records check showed that Briddle has a valid driver's license but does not have the required motorcycle endorsement. The motorcycle is not registered in Delaware. It was last registered by a previous owner in Virginia and was reported as having been sold.
Two days after the crash, Briddle was taken into custody at his home in the Aspen Run apartment complex near Bear. He was charged with second-degree murder, possession of a deadly weapon during the commission of a felony, disregarding a police officer's signal, driving a special vehicle without a special license, operation of an unregistered motor vehicle and three counts of failure to stop at a red light.
Traffic crashes rarely result in murder charges. However, Delaware law specifies that a person is guilty of second-degree murder if he causes the death of another person while engaged in a felony or while fleeing after committing a felony. Fleeing from the police is a Class G felony, thus triggering the murder charge against Briddle.
"Briddle drove, used and possessed a motor vehicle, a dangerous instrument used as a deadly weapon, during the commission of this felony," Aston wrote.
Briddle was jailed after failing to post $362,005 cash bail. If convicted, he would face 15 years to life in prison. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a fatal traffic accident involving reckless driving, police pursuit, and criminal charges, which directly relates to public safety concerns. While the victim was a student (education) and injuries occurred (health), the core issue revolves around road safety and law enforcement response.

title: Woman charged with 69 animal neglect counts after dogs rescued
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Woman charged with 69 animal neglect counts after dogs rescued

 September 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 410
 Words 

 Read News Document

 More details have emerged about a mass rescue of more than 70 dogs from a Calvert County residence this past May.On Aug. 27, 69 counts of animal neglect and one count of animal cruelty/hoarding were filed in district court against a 30-year-old Chesapeake Beach woman.
The defendant, identified in court documents as Marliana A. Zahedi-Mullis, was issued a court summons. A preliminary inquiry regarding the charges is scheduled for Oct. 7 in district court.
According to court papers filed by Calvert County Animal Control Officer H. Neel, four members of the division along with the county's director of animal services, a state's attorney's office investigator, a local sheriff's office deputy and staff members from the Linda L. Kelley Animal Shelter went to Zahedi-Mullis' residence on Breezy Point Road to investigate a report of possible animal cruelty and neglect.
Neel stated in court documents that staff from Calvert Well Pet Clinic in Huntingtown also assisted.
Neel documented what investigators saw when they examined the residence. Several different breeds of dogs of various ages were found, some confined to crates, many isolated in piles of excrement and pools of urine.
The investigation team seized 76 dogs, three cats and one guinea pig from the residence.
The rescue of dozens of dogs on May 8 prompted the five-day closure to the animal shelter off Route 231 in Prince Frederick. During the closure period, veterinarian care and health assessments were provided to the rescued dogs.
The added burden of having a larger than usual dog population this summer has resulted in rumors that were spread on social media and addressed by staff on Aug. 23.
"We want to address misinformation circulating online that more than 10 dogs will be euthanized today for shelter space at the Linda L. Kelley Animal Shelter," staff wrote on the facility's Facebook page that day. "This information is false. In May 2024, the shelter had to unexpectedly close its doors in response to a rescue operation involving more than 70 dogs. Many of the dogs saved from that rescue operation have been adopted to loving homes, sent to other rescues or are being fostered."
The statement continued, "We are unable to comment at this time on this ongoing cruelty case; we appreciate your understanding and patience as we work through this situation. If you're interested in visiting the shelter to support our efforts and make a positive impact, please consider volunteering. Reach out to the shelter at 410-535-7387 for more information on how you can get involved." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Police arrest Dorchester County man on rape, sexual assault charges
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Police arrest Dorchester County man on rape, sexual assault charges

 September 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 330
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Police arrested a man from Toddville on rape, sexual offense and assault charges on Monday morning, according to a press release.Jason Groff, 41, was arrested just after 11 a.m. Monday by the Cambridge Police Department. A release stated city police received assistance from the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office in locating Groff, who was actively being sought by authorities.
Police obtained information that Groff was heading to Cambridge from Toddville, which is just over 20 miles south of Cambridge. Police located him northwest of Toddville around the Lakesville area, the release stated.
Groff is being held without bond in the Dorchester County Department of Corrections. He's charged with two counts each of first-degree rape, second-degree rape, sex offense of the third degree and sex offense of the fourth degree. He is also charged with a count of second-degree assault and a count of false imprisonment.
The charges stem from an investigation by the Cambridge Police Department into an Aug. 13 incident.
According to the release, investigators began an investigation on Aug. 16, contacting a female victim in the hospital. She reported that after pulling into a gas station to inflate a tire, a man engaged in conversation with her.
The release stated the man and the female went to a Cambridge residence, where "the male subject was reported to making lewd comments and advancements on the female victim."
"The female repeatedly told the male subject 'No' and to 'Stop,'" the release states. "The male subject ended up reportedly overpowering the female victim and she ended up being raped."
Investigators gathered descriptions of the subject, and on Aug. 27, an officer matched the descriptions to a man identified as Groff. Detectives met with Groff for an interview on Aug. 28.
On Aug. 29, an arrest warrant was issued for Groff. The investigation revealed Groff was on probation with restrictions and is a registered sex offender.
The investigation is ongoing. Anyone with information regarding the incident is asked to contact the Cambridge Police Department's Criminal Investigations Division at 410-901-8457.

title: Body-worn camera footage from fatal officer-involved car crash released
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Body-worn camera footage from fatal officer-involved car crash released

 September 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 677
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE — On Wednesday, the Independent Investigations Division of the Maryland Office of the Attorney General released the body-worn camera footage from the fatal officer-involved vehicle pursuit that occurred on July 22 in Easton.The preliminary investigation revealed deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, in marked police cruisers, encountered a car in the area of westbound Route 50 and Dutchmans Lane, where they attempted to initiate a traffic stop. The car did not stop, and a pursuit ensued.
Body-worn camera footage was released from four officers: Talbot County Deputies Brittanie DiMichele, William Barnett and Owen Joseph, and Easton Police Department Officer Nicholas Lange.
DiMichele led the pursuit as Joseph drove a second county police vehicle with Barnett in the passenger's seat. The driver of the car being pursued did not stop and continued to drive on Route 50. Officers pursued the vehicle for several minutes, sometimes reaching speeds over 100 MPH.
"We looked at our policy and we looked at the body-worn camera footage," Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said in an interview. "We listened to the dispatch record of our deputies as well as the communication behind the deputies, and our deputies followed proper procedure and policies."
In the video, officers can be seen taking a left turn onto Black Dog Alley just before stopping and exiting to approach the crashed vehicle at the 8300 block at 7:14 p.m.
"Let me see your hands. Let me see your hands," DiMichele shouted. The armed deputies asked for the people in the car to put their hands out the window.
DiMichele approached the rear passenger door on the left side, slightly opening it as repeated asks for "help" can be heard from inside the car. The rear passenger pressed his hands on the window, as Barnett repeatedly asked the driver, a juvenile male, to stick his hands out the window.
"If you keep reaching, you're going to get shot if you pull something out, you understand me?" Barnett said.
Gamble said it is "totally appropriate" for the officers to draw their weapons while approaching the vehicle.
"For their safety, they drew their weapons, ordered the people out," Gamble said. "Once they realized the injuries and there was entrapment, then they holstered their weapons and tried to assist."
Barnett asked the driver if he had any weapons, then began to attempt to help the driver exit the car at 7:16 p.m.
"We're here to help you now, okay, I need you to climb out this window," Barnett said.
The two rear passengers, a juvenile male and an adult woman, exited the car with assistance from the officers.
Officers were unable to extract the adult woman from the front passenger seat. "She's just agonal," an officer said of her breathing. One officer noted she "definitely wasn't wearing a seatbelt." EMS arrived on the scene at 7:22 p.m., the video shows.
The driver and the front seat passenger were transported to a local hospital for treatment of serious injuries. The front seat passenger was later pronounced dead at the hospital, the attorney general's office said.
The decedent was previously identified as 18-year-old Yemaya Wilson.
The two rear passengers were transported to an area hospital for treatment of serious injuries.
In an August interview, Gamble said after the crash, police learned the vehicle had been stolen from Montgomery County.
"We suspect the criminal charges will be brought at some point in the case, against, at the very least, the driver of the stolen vehicle, if not more," Gamble said on Wednesday. "But that's going to be in the hands of the (Maryland) State Police and the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office."
The Independent Investigations Division will generally release body-worn camera and dashboard camera footage within 20 business days of an incident. The release of body-worn camera footage in this incident was delayed to allow additional time to conduct witness interviews, the Attorney General's Office said in a press release.
The Independent Investigations Division continues to investigate the circumstances of the fatal pursuit.
This report has been updated from an earlier version to include comment from the Talbot County Sheriff and more details about the event.{iframe title="YouTube video player" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/9msnyhxgddI?si=ryU7ae89GJOWvceC" frameborder="0" width="560" height="315"}{/iframe} 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a fatal officer-involved car pursuit and the subsequent release of body-worn camera footage, focusing on law enforcement procedures, public safety protocols, and the investigation into a critical incident involving police and civilian safety.

title: Dorchester County to replace camera system in EMS vehicles
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester County to replace camera system in EMS vehicles

 September 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 332
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Emergency Medical Services is replacing the video and tracking system in its vehicles.At a Dorchester County Council meeting on Sept. 3, the council voted to allow the department to proceed with replacing the current system. The new system, which is from software company Samsara, will save the county a little over $2,000.
Dorchester County EMS Division Chief Debbie Wheedleton said the cameras only show the front of the ambulance, including the driver and passenger as well as out the front window. The video footage is live streamed, she said.
The Samsara system not only notifies via email if there is a problem with a camera, but also if a crash is detected or if a driver isn't wearing their seatbelt or is texting and driving.
"It takes a picture and sends it to you," she said. "This old system will tell you they don't have a seatbelt on, but it doesn't have a picture. You don't know who's driving."
Council President Lenny Pfeffer said the new system sounds beneficial for the safety and security of the providers and the people they are taking care of in the back of the ambulance.
"And also help in the unfortunate event of a possible accident or something where we have data as well as visual to show whether or not we were at fault or what happened," he said. "So it sounds like this could be very useful to help minimize our risk involved with our employees."
Wheedleton also talked about the new system's maintenance alerts. She said that while the current system gives some maintenance information, the new system will send codes to let the department know what is wrong with a vehicle so that maintenance can be scheduled.
"Well that sounds like that could save us a lot of money too," Pfeffer said in response.
The new system will cost a little over $13,500 and come out of fiscal year 2025 operating budget funds. No further charges will be incurred, according to the request from EMS. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Elkton High School deploying weapons detection system for football games, sports events
author: Erik Halberg ehalberg@chespub.com
content:
Elkton High School deploying weapons detection system for football games, sports events

 September 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Erik Halberg ehalberg@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 429
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As part of efforts to keep students safe, attendees of Elkton High School football games this fall will have to pass through a weapon detection system before entering the stadium.According to Leitgeb, the system is designed primarily to scan for 'mass casualty style' weapons, including guns and large knives, and will allow attendees to keep their belongings on them so as to not slow down entrance to the stadium. School officials noted that EHS football games average roughly 1,200 attendees, and other fall sports games can bring in 300 to 400.
"We are introducing the CEIA OPENGATE weapons detection system to enhance the security measures and safety for our students, staff, and community alike," Elkton High School Principal Dr. James Leitgeb wrote in a letter to EHS parents and guardians. "This advanced security technology is a walk-through detection system designed to identify and prevent unauthorized or potentially harmful items from being brought onto our campus."
The new system is consistent with Elkton High School's strict policy banning weapons on school grounds for any reason.
Leitgeb noted that the system is portable, and the school plans to make use of it beyond the fall sports season.
"We are doing this for our fall events, and eventually we do plan on using [the system] for our indoor winter games," said Leitgeb.
The OPENGATE system is comprised of two upright detectors that will be placed at the entrance to the stadium, which will likely look familiar to those who have gone to a professional sports game or concert recently. CEIA, an Ohio-based metal detector manufacturer, touts that the system scans bags and backpacks automatically, allowing lines to proceed through the gates faster.
"This system is highly effective yet minimally intrusive, allowing students, staff, and visitors to enter school premises without significant delays or disruptions," Leitgeb said.
The implementation of the system is part of a partnership between EHS and Elkton Police Department. According to Leitgeb, EHS staff will man the gates and, in the event of any alerts from the system, EPD officers and the School Resource Officer will be on hand to help handle the situation.
"One of my highest priorities as principal is the safety of our students and guests," Leitgeb said. "This is true not only during the school day, but at night time events as well."
Leitgeb also noted that the purchase of the system is part of a grant-funded pilot program and, if successful, other schools in Cecil County will make use of similar systems.
The detection system was slated to make its debut at Elkton's home football opener on Sept. 6 at the school's stadium. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Down to one officer, Greensboro considers closing police department
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Down to one officer, Greensboro considers closing police department

 September 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 592
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — The future of the Greensboro Police Department is up in the air.Mayor David Spencer announced at Thursday evening's Greensboro Town Council meeting that the town will consider closing its police department, which is now down to one officer, Chief Lenox Trams.
Four options were provided to the mayor and commissioners by Town Manager Tammy Kelledes:
Continuing running its own police department.Working "in conjunction with" the Caroline County Sheriff's Office "to fill the spots (it doesn't) have now for (its) own officers."Entering into a "contractual agreement" with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office.Closing the police department, not entering into an agreement and turning "the town over to the sheriff's department and the Maryland State Police."
"The current public safety demands are too much for a one-person police department to handle," Spencer said. "In addition, the mayor and council must consider the increasing costs of retaining a police department and the struggles caused by a shortage of police officers and police applicants throughout the state."
"We will listen to all comments and suggestions and take all of those into consideration," he added. "We will not be making a decision tonight."
The mayor emphasized Thursday was just the beginning of a "fluid" and long-term process.
Greensboro has been receiving assistance from county police in recent weeks to reduce the burden on the town's only officer. Spencer said Greensboro has been paying a $75-per-hour rate for county deputies to cover the town, which will continue "in the meantime."
"When they come in here, they're staying here," Spencer said. "They're not patrolling the county, they're only patrolling the town."
A person recently hired by the town did not complete police academy training, Spencer said in response to a resident question.
Spencer said the town has asked Trams to continue going through officer applications on file in hopes that an applicant who is already certified can be brought on board. Otherwise, certification and training can take up to a full year.
"If you put somebody through the academy, it takes about a year," Trams said. "When you hire them after you do the background, for the nine months that they really aren't much good to you, you are paying their salary and their health insurance."
During his department update, Trams urged those with non-emergencies to call the county at 410-479-2515 since the Greensboro department is limited. "If (we're) working, they will certainly send us. If we're not working, then they will send the next agency that is in rotation," he said.
PUBLIC FEEDBACKAfter Spencer read the four options aloud, resident Paula Turner pushed for more details and asked for the town to host a special meeting.
"Of those options, where is the breakdown of cost, of savings?" Turner asked "If No. 4 is voted in, if that's what the town wants, show us how … (the) money that's budgeted will be allocated back into our town. I want numbers."
Kevin Parks spoke in support of the police department remaining. He referenced the struggle to attract police officers due to Maryland's repeal of the Law Enforcement Officers' Bill of Rights back in 2021.
"I don't want to see the police department closed up," Parks said. "The chief's doing the best he can. If you want to fuss about the police department, call your legislators and your senators for the state of Maryland and tell them to give them their bill of rights back."
Spencer said the town's budget has room for three officers. Public Works Supervisor Brandon Cunningham asked if the town would continue paying for county assistance if it hired a second officer only.
"Those decisions have not yet been made," Spencer said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Greensboro's consideration to close its police department due to insufficient staffing, highlighting public safety concerns. While local government processes are involved, the core issue revolves around law enforcement and community safety, making 'Public Safety' the primary topic.

title: Emergency call centers utilizing Convey911 for translation services
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Emergency call centers utilizing Convey911 for translation services

 September 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 665
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Public safety agencies up and down the Shore are reaping the benefits of a new translation service called Convey911.The service has been added to the arsenal of many emergency call centers, including in Talbot and Dorchester counties. With a network of around 10,000 on-demand human interpreters, the service runs 24/7 and can connect callers in just seconds.
Convey911 CEO Jeff Bruns said the service allows emergency call specialists to quickly bring an interpreter after detecting the language of the caller.
"The technology is listening to that person's voice, is making a determination around what language they speak, and is transcribing and translating their voice in real time, and putting it on the screen so the 911 call taker is able to read and understand what you're saying," Bruns said.
Over 180 languages are supported by Convey911's text translation services, Bruns said.
The service has around 110 languages on demand for human interpreters and around 120 using artificial intelligence.
Artificial intelligence helps at the beginning of a call, Bruns said, detecting the language spoken by the caller. But the service doesn't rely on AI.
"The call taker always has control," Bruns said. "They have the ability to hit a button and pull in a real, live human. But what we're doing in the background is understanding how accurately, or lack thereof, we're transcribing. And if we find that the accuracy is not within a certain level of expectation, for example 80% accuracy, then we're going to prompt the call taker on the screen (to bring in an interpreter)."
Holley Guschke, the chief of Talbot County's 911 communications division, said the department is fully trained on Convey911's services. It is the department's hope that the service will assist residents in Talbot and surrounding counties.
"When you do need to translate, it is important to be able to do that as quickly as possible in order to send police, fire or medical personnel," Guschke said.
"Working with Convey911 translation services will be invaluable to 911 operations by enabling clear and immediate communication with non-English speakers, reducing response times, and ensuring that all individuals receive the critical help they need during emergencies," said Brian LeCates, Talbot County's emergency services director, in an emailed statement.
In Dorchester County, Emergency Communications Chief Robbie Larimer says the county's call center receives one to two calls per day from non-English speakers. Partnering with Convey911 has helped the department quicken its translation times since June, he said.
"They've been very willing to work with us," Larimer said. He added that the company "embraces the understanding" of the need for public safety.
Larimer said Eastern Shore agencies embraced the service at the Maryland Association of Counties' conference last year. Convey911 was at the conference, and representatives from different counties took notice.
"We saw what they had to offer," Larimer said.
Bruns emphasized the service helps not just public safety agencies, but other departments as well. The Caroline County Health Department has been using the service since June.
Holly Trice, the health department's director of nursing, lauded the Convey911 service as an "everyday" tool to communicate with residents.
"Our previous platform did not have an interpreter immediately available, so there were times we would sit on the phone for 15 minutes or so trying to find an appropriate interpreter," Trice said. "We don't have that with Convey911. As soon as we initiate the call, we immediately assign an interpreter, and everyone has been extremely professional."
Bruns said feedback has been "exceptional" so far. He noted two "pain points" that the service addresses: quality of interpretation and the time it takes to get an interpreter on the line.
While Convey911 serves around 50 departments in around 14 states, its Maryland roots as a Baltimore-based company are important to Bruns.
"It's very important for us to ensure that we're doing everything we can to canvass Maryland, and really support Gov. (Wes) Moore's platform of leave no one behind," Bruns said. "We had a huge advocate in (Larimer) … in bringing all of the counties together so that we could do this as a group." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on emergency call centers and public safety agencies utilizing Convey911 translation services to improve communication during emergencies. While local government and health sectors are mentioned, the primary context is public safety operations, making it the best fit.

title: Political signs vandalized
author: Staff Writer
content:
Political signs vandalized

 September 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 330
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Talbot Republican Central Committee (TCRCC) has worked hard to promote our candidates, including the erection of a couple dozen large Trump, Andy Harris and Hogan signs around the county. In just a week we have had one large sign near Trappe stolen, replaced and stolen again, and last night (Saturday, Aug. 31) had two signs spray-painted on St Michaels Road just outside of St Michaels. These signs cost an average of $100 each plus $15 for lumber and sweat equity to dig post holes and erect the signs.Vandalism of political signs is against the law and is punishable by jail time and hefty fines. Complaints have been filed with the Sheriff's Office. Many signs are now monitored by trail cameras. If we catch the responsible parties, we will prosecute vigorously. TCRCC will pay a $500 reward to anyone whose testimony leads to conviction.
While spending two hours cleaning the paint off of the signs, I was cursed at twice … "F--k You" and "F--k Trump" by people driving by. (It was offset by some dozen or more friendly honks and thumbs-up, and two people who stopped to ask if they could help.)
This behavior is typical of people who have no respect for the Constitution, and specifically the First Amendment or of the election process in which we all express our opinions by peaceful, respectful means.
Sadly, the Democratic Party has encouraged behavior that stifles freedom of expression for several years (witness Obama's "get in their face" remarks), and seems to have little regard for the First Amendment (as shown by the pressuring of Facebook and Twitter by the Biden/Harris Administration to censor conservative thought).
If we are to have a democracy of, by and for the people, we must respect each other's right to think and say what we will. I hope that Democrats who are put off by this behavior will chastise their brethren for acting this way. It isn't pretty.
To be silent is to condone this behavior.
KENT ROBERTSON
Royal Oak 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the vandalism of political signs, which constitutes a criminal act affecting public safety. While it touches on political and legal aspects, the core issue is the unlawful destruction of property and threats to community safety, aligning most directly with 'Public Safety.'

title: Coming for the kids
author: Staff Writer
content:
Coming for the kids

 September 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 330
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I have had several persons of a liberal persuasion question me about Project 2025, which I had not even heard of until recently.I was informed by said liberal persons, with complete certainty on their part, that Project 2025 would be imposed on the USA if Trump were elected for a second term, which would mean the end of the republic, with the imposition of a fascist dictatorship.
After some research it became clear that Trump and his campaign have no connection with Project 2025. Project 2025 is a project of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank that only a Marxist would describe as "fascist" or "bourgeois." Project 2025 has as its goals such things as securing the border, making federal bureaucrats accountable to Congress, cutting government spending and other policies which I have heard both Democrats and Republicans defend.
More of a matter of concern is the Reproductive Freedom Amendment or Ballot Question No. 1 for Maryland voters in the upcoming November general election. All you have to do is think for a minute about why we would need such an amendment. What reproductive freedoms do Marylanders lack?
Under current Maryland laws, adults are free to reproduce with other consenting adults, except blood relatives. They are even free not to reproduce by engaging in same sex relationships, dignified by the laws of Maryland as marriage. Those who engage in reproductive activity are free, according to the law, to terminate a pregnancy any time before the moment of birth.
Minors once required the permission of a parent or guardian in most circumstances but under the new laws parents may lose their rights. If parents object to gender reassignment surgery, the state is already empowered to remove the child from the home. If the Question No. 1 passes, then legal action in favor of parents will be almost impossible as will be repealing the unjust laws. It already is happening in other states. So the news is: they are coming for the kids.
MARY-EILEEN RUSSELL
Claiborne

title: Assault at Easton High School sends student to hospital
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Assault at Easton High School sends student to hospital

 September 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 257
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Sheriff's Office is investigating the circumstances surrounding an assault that took place at Easton High School, located on the 700 block of Mecklenburg Avenue, on Sep. 10.At approximately 12:06 p.m., the deputy assigned as the school resource officer at Easton High School was alerted to an assault occurring inside of the school.
Deputies initiated an investigation into the circumstances surrounding the assault, in conjunction with the Easton High School administrative staff and the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office.
Pursuant to the investigation, two juveniles, who are students at the school, were identified and arrested in relation to the assault. Deputies were also able to identify two victims of the assault. One of the victims is an Easton High School staff member and the second victim is a juvenile student at the school.
The juvenile victim was transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton via the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services for treatment of non-life-threatening injuries.
The juvenile suspects were transported to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office for booking and processing. They were charged with first- and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment and several other charges relating to the incident.
The Talbot County Sheriff's Office will be contacting the Department of Juvenile Services to obtain a release disposition for both suspects.
Easton High School was placed on a brief lockdown during this event.
If anyone has information they are requested to contact the Talbot County Sheriff's Office at 410-822-1020, by email at sheriff@talbotcountymd.gov, on Facebook at Talbot County Sheriff or on our website at talbotsheriff.org.

title: Bradford House residents share concerns with community, management
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Bradford House residents share concerns with community, management

 September 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 656
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Bradford House Apartments residents, community members, and service providers gathered at Anchor Point on Monday afternoon to talk about unsafe conditions at the apartment complex on Race Street and what is needed to remedy the situation.The community conversation, which was facilitated by Mid Shore Mediation, was born out of a concern from Dorchester County District Court Judge Melvin Jews. Jews is presiding over multiple rent escrow cases filed against Bradford House residents by Millennia Housing Management, the Cleveland-based company that manages Bradford House.
Residents have expressed concerns about safety in the building.
In September 2023, the property — which offers multifamily, subsidized housing for low-income individuals who are elderly or have special needs — received a U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development inspection score of 30c*. The score indicated health and safety deficiencies and other problems identified with building systems, the building's exterior and individual apartments.
Wendy Schneider, alternative dispute resolution programs manager for Eastern Shore district courts, said Jews was concerned residents who don't have a case in court or who are not comfortable appearing in court weren't getting heard.
"And there also might have been people outside of those that were actually in the courtroom that might need to hear what's going on," Schneider said. "So that's why we came up with the idea of hosting this meeting. Just to give everyone an open and safe space to have conversation and just say whatever they feel comfortable saying without that pressure of court."
Representatives from Millennia, including the chief operating officer, regional manager and Bradford House property manager, listened in on the meeting virtually. At the end of the meeting, one representative said they appreciated the residents taking the time to voice their concerns.
During the conversation, residents talked about a variety of concerns from bed bug infestations, to frequent changes in management, to elevators not working, to a lack of security.
Residents Anna Walker and Stephanie Robinson talked about the in-unit call-for-aid systems, many of which were found inoperable during the September 2023 HUD inspection.
Walker said that she learned her call-for-aid chord didn't work in December when no one came to help her on the floor of her bathroom. Walker said she had to crawl down the hallway of the building to get a neighbor to call 911.
Robinson, who has epilepsy, recalled falling in the bathtub and having to yell for help "for the longest time." She said more than two pull chords are needed in each apartment.
Walker said her grandchildren can't visit her because of safety and security concerns, and she hasn't been able to get a home health care provider because no one wants to come to the Bradford House.
"The worst part is the isolation," she said.
Resident Jerome Jones, who is on dialysis, said he has also had a difficult time getting services because people don't want to come to the apartment complex.
Jones talked about being scared to bring furniture into his home because he doesn't want to draw bed bugs, which multiple residents at the meeting talked about experiencing.
La-Shon Foster, who is running for mayor of Cambridge, said during the conversation that these problems have existed for more than four years and residents aren't getting the help they need.
"The mediation is good," she said. "But if nothing is done to follow it in six months from now, we're right back at this table (and) it does no good."
Local psychiatrist Gene Bautista, who serves Bradford House residents, suggested that the Health Department open a station in the Bradford House and that everyone who serves the apartment receive sensitivity training.
"Just a little bit more sensitivity would go a long, long way," he said.
Resident Linda Johnson, who is a member of the apartment's tenant association, said she just wants management to respect residents, talk with residents and know what's happening on the property.
"At the end of the day, I'm just glad that we had this mediation, and I'm glad that Millennia finally heard us," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on residents' concerns about unsafe conditions in a housing complex, including safety deficiencies, health risks, and management issues. While local government and community mediation are mentioned, the core theme revolves around public safety threats to residents.

title: Cambridge man gets 25 years after taking plea deal in murder trial
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Cambridge man gets 25 years after taking plea deal in murder trial

 September 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 289
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge teen was sentenced to 25 years in prison on Sept. 6 in connection to the 2021 fatal shooting of Ja'Len Woolford.Daeveon Johnson, 19, faced a first-degree murder charge in the shooting that occurred on Nov. 18, 2021. Johnson entered an Alford plea for the charge in November 2022.
As part of the plea deal, Johnson will serve 25 years at the Patuxent Youthful Offenders Program. Once 50% of the sentence is served, Johnson will be eligible for parole.
Johnson's sentence will begin dating back to Jan. 4, 2022, the day he was arrested by Cambridge police. He will also serve five years probation.
The sentence orders Johnson to have no contact with Key'Marion Ennals. Ennals, 19, was found not guilty on 12 charges relation to the fatal shooting, including first-degree murder, at a trial this August.
Johnson's sentencing was delayed as part of his plea agreement, which included Johnson testifying during Ennals' trial last month.
In his initial interview with police, Johnson admitted to carrying a .40 caliber firearm. An autopsy revealed that Woolford died from a single gunshot wound from a .40 caliber firearm.
Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard provided a statement following the sentencing of Johnson.
"The State recommended a sentence of life imprisonment, suspending all but forty years of active incarceration," the statement read. "The Court heard heartfelt victim impact statements from three members of the victim's family, each expressing their choice to forgive Mr. Johnson, and each requesting the Court consider a lesser period of active incarceration for Mr. Johnson given his cooperation and remorse.
"The State continues to offer condolences to all family and loved ones impacted by the loss of Ja'Len Woolford, and thanks the Court for its mindful consideration of all circumstances at sentencing." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Everbridge becomes Kent's new emergency alert system
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Everbridge becomes Kent's new emergency alert system

 September 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 607
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Even at 3 a.m. from his home, with a tap of a button Emergency Preparedness Planner Brian Pearsall can send out an alert to a majority of Kent County residents.He hopes he never has to do that, but it's beneficial the option's there.
In the basement of the Kent County Sheriff's Office, where the Office of Emergency Services is housed, he demonstrates how efficient he can be in sending notifications with the department's new software, Everbridge.
On July 1, they made the switch from their old system Code Red, a commendable program in its own right.
Why the switch?
"It allows us to be more effective to the community with updated information regarding weather forecasts and gives us a larger environment to do that with their technology," Pearsall said.
Pearsall explained there are three levels of communication.
Everbridge is a TSP level 3 certification, designated Public Health, and receives restoration priority just under Federal government certifications. It is required to be backed up and restored in order to provide for public health.
He pointed out, Everbridge is used widely throughout the state right now making communicating between counties convenient.
"We can coordinate better as far as resource needs," Pearsall said.
Everbridge can target specific areas within the county as well.
In a simulation, a test, on his cell phone, Pearsall uses the map on the Everbridge application to send out a storm warning to just Kennedyville residents.
Narrowing it down even further, if needed, he could send notifications to just a specific housing community within Kennedyville.
These alerts are available to residents who have phones in a contract with Everbridge. But also residents can receive specific notifications by signing up to receive alerts at https://www.kentcounty.com/oes.
Those who sign up get alerts for weather conditions, tornados, flash floods, and even water line repairs and other infrastructure information.
So far, the new software has gone off without a hitch as they've sent out 10 alerts since the time of the interview in late August.
Along with other administrators, Director Pete Landon and Chief of Communications Brad Russum, Pearsall meets regularly over Zoom with the Everbridge team to increase their knowledge of technology which always seems to be adapting.
The emergency team is always looking to learn as much as they can to increase the public's awareness and safety.
Like for example, in a few months time they will be able to provide IPAUS, Integrated Public Alert and Warning System.
"When you receive an amber alert on your phone, you can't stop that from coming through. So soon I'll be able to provide this to our residents and visitors," Pearsall remarked.
In the case of an impending tornado for example, he can interrupt every phone in Kent County warning residents.
He's been taking FEMA courses online, and when the time comes, will take an exam for certification along with quarterly tests.
The team's also looking to expand public's awareness like the recent Maryland Mesonet Weather Station, set up at the back of the A.F. Whitsitt Center. It's one of 70 weather stations in the state in partnership with the University of Maryland, Maryland Department of Emergency Management, Maryland Environmental Service and Maryland Department of Health.
These stations are spaced about 10 miles apart and solar powered, measuring rainfall, snow, even the temperature of the top soil.
"It has all manner of capabilities and allows us to be more effective in predicting and forecasting weather events," Pearsall added.
Like the Everbridge program, the station provides opportunities to cooperate with various local, state and federal entities.
All these expansions are part of an effort, "To create a safer Kent County by getting the resources to the community, residents and visitors."
Pearsall noted, "We're doing everything we can to ensure the public is safe as possible." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Kent County's implementation of the Everbridge emergency alert system, which enhances public safety through weather alerts, emergency communication, and coordination with emergency services. While local government operations are mentioned, the primary emphasis is on safety measures and public alert systems.

title: Easton police officer found guilty of misconduct
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Easton police officer found guilty of misconduct

 September 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 662
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An Easton police officer was found guilty on Tuesday of misconduct in office. Sgt. Jason Dyott, 38, was convicted of two separate instances of engaging in physical sexual conduct with two different teenage girls while on duty.Judge C. Carey Deeley Jr. found Easton Police Department Dyott guilty on two counts of misconduct in office. Dyott — who had served as an Easton police officer since approximately June 2008 — was found guilty under three theories of misconduct: malfeasance, misfeasance and nonfeasance.
The charges stem from allegations that Dyott used his departmental cell phone to communicate in a sexual manner with several teenagers and students at local high schools and met up with them while on duty. Two teenage girls are mentioned in a charging document from the Office of the State Prosecutor.
During opening statements of the trial, Senior Assistant State Prosecutor Mary Setzer said that in the fall of 2022, Dyott engaged in physical acts with two teenage girls in separate instances. She said that on Nov. 11, Dyott picked up an 18-year-old from her friend's house in his police vehicle and had sex with her in the vehicle while on duty.
Setzer said that two days later, Dyott met with a 17-year-old in the Target parking lot while he was on duty and made out with her. According to the charging document, Dyott leveraged his position as a police officer to engage in this sexual relationship and sent her multiple photographs of him in his police uniform with sexually provocative language attached.
Dyott's defense attorney Shaun Owens said during opening statements that Dyott is not denying the relationships with the teenagers. Owens said the conduct was not criminal, however, and that he does not believe there is evidence to support that Dyott's actions constituted misconduct.
Owens said the state would need to prove that Dyott engaged in the acts because he was a police officer or because he had been afforded that privilege as a police officer. Owens said that in any profession, Dyott could have engaged in the exact same behavior.
During the trial, both of the then-teenagers mentioned in the charging document testified. The then-17-year-old said that when the investigation into Dyott began, Dyott told her to deny what happened, and he said they didn't do anything wrong because she was old enough to consent.
The then-18-year-old recounted the night she met up with Dyott. She said that while in the police vehicle, the police radio was on, and after she heard a badge number spoken over the radio, Dyott turned the radio down. She said that she and Dyott didn't have any conversations about Dyott's job during their interaction, and Dyott didn't respond to work during that time.
During closing arguments, Owens brought up that the radio call, which the then-18-year-old talked about during testimony. He said that it was not clear what the call was about, if it was for Dyott specifically or if it required Dyott's response.
Deputy State Prosecutor Sarah David said that in the two incidents, Dyott acted in his official capacity. Not only was he on duty, she said, but he was presenting himself to the public and to the teenage girls as an officer.
A sentencing hearing is set for Nov. 1.
According to a news release from the Office of the State Prosecutor, State Prosecutor Charlton T. Howard III said, "Law enforcement officers who abuse the power of their position, and betray the trust of the community, must be held accountable."
In an interview with the Star Democrat Wednesday, Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said Dyott is suspended with pay. He has been suspended with pay since the beginning stages of the investigation in 2023.
In 2014, Dyott was named the Easton's department's officer of the year.
According to a Wednesday press release, "upon this conviction, the Easton Police Department will now seek to impose the appropriate administrative penalties upon Mr. Dyott."
Lowery said he could not say at this time when those administrative penalties will be imposed.
This article may be updated. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a police officer's misconduct involving abuse of authority and sexual conduct with minors, directly relating to public safety and law enforcement accountability. While Local Government and Crime are relevant, Public Safety most accurately captures the core issue of trust in law enforcement and community safety.

title: Family seeks answers to St. Mary's man's death while in custody in Calvert jail
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Family seeks answers to St. Mary's man's death while in custody in Calvert jail

 September 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 504
 Words 

 Read News Document

 According to descriptions provided by his family, Angel Manuel Jimenez was always the life of the party. They described him as "a flirt, a charmer, always cracking jokes and tearing up the dance floor."Jimenez, a native of the Bronx, a resident of Great Mills and an electrician by trade, was 50 years old when he died on Dec. 4, 2023, while in custody at the Calvert County Detention Center in Barstow.
"What led him there is not important," Elena Jimenez, one of Angel's sisters, said of the fact her brother was in jail, adding the real question is, "What led up to his death?"
A certificate issued by the state department of health's division of vital records lists Jimenez's cause of death as "restraint complicated by hypertensive atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease." The document cites his manner of death as "homicide."
"He was just detained at the time," Elena Jimenez told Southern Maryland News. "No medical attention was given to him. He died at the detention center. What occurred during the last hours? We don't have anything. It's already been nine months and we don't have any answers."
According to documents on file in the Maryland Judiciary system, Jimenez was the defendant in an ongoing paternity case, which dated back to December 2008. He was served a warrant last Dec. 1, just days before his death.
On Aug. 16, after other local media outlets reported on the family's call for answers from authorities, the Calvert County Sheriff's Office, which oversees the detention center, issued a statement about the Jimenez case.
"As soon as we became aware of the incident, we immediately contacted the independent investigations division of the [state] attorney general's office," the sheriff's office statement reads. "However, they determined this case would not fall under their purview and declined to investigate it. Determined to ensure an impartial investigation, we reached out to the Maryland State Police, who agreed to handle the case from start to finish."
Southern Maryland News contacted the state police's Pikesville office headquarters, which advised to "contact the Calvert County State's Attorney's Office as they are handling all media inquiries for the Jimenez case."
"Our office is reviewing the entire case," Calvert County State's Attorney Robert H. Harvey Jr. (R) told Southern Maryland News. "We are going to be following up with the state medical examiner's office. We will then prepare a written report."
Harvey said he was hopeful the report would be completed by the end of September. He added that the case may or may not be reviewed by a grand jury.
The Jimenez family and members of the Calvert community received some surprising news during the Aug. 28 meeting of the county's police accountability board.
While reviewing the year-to-date complaints the panel has received, chairman Wilson H. Parran said the detention center and the correctional deputies are "not an area of responsibility" for the accountability board, adding that those officers "have their own bill of rights."
John Norris, county attorney who provided council to the board at the August meeting, explained that correctional deputies are "disciplined through their internal structure." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a death in custody at a detention center, involving law enforcement, medical examiner reports, and investigative procedures. While health aspects are mentioned, the primary context revolves around public safety concerns, legal accountability, and correctional facility operations.

title: Videos of Easton High School assault circulate online
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Videos of Easton High School assault circulate online

 September 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Crime 
 
 406
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Videos showing the Tuesday assault at Easton High School have been circulating online. The incident involved three students and one staff member and ended with a student being transported to a hospital for non-life-threatening injuries.According to a press release released by the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, the assault happened on Tuesday afternoon. The videos paint a picture of the incident, though no further official statement has been released by law enforcement on the assault.
In the videos, a group of students are circling around the three students involved in the assault. Seconds into the video, one student in a black hoodie moves toward a student in a red hoodie and assaults him. The student in red falls to the floor. Immediately following, an additional student in a gray hoodie proceeds to join in the assault.
In the video, a male staff member in a white shirt attempts to protect the student that is being assaulted and physically puts his body on top of the student, seemingly to act as a barrier between the students.
The other two students seemingly continue to assault the student in red and begin to also assault the staff member. Soon after, other staff members intervene and separate the students and defuse the situation. The incident lasted around 30 seconds.
Deputies were able to identify two victims of the assault, one was an Easton High School staff member and the second was a student of the school. No identities have been released, and the incident is currently under investigation.
The assault resulted in one student being transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton via Talbot County Department of Emergency Services to be treated for non-life-threatening injuries, police said.
The two other students in the video were identified and arrested in relation to the assault.
According to a statement from Debbie Gardner, director of communications for Talbot County Public Schools, the event is being evaluated and those involved will face appropriate disciplinary action.
"The safety of our students and staff is always our top priority. We are grateful for our partnership with the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and the presence of School Resource Officers in our schools," the statement said. "Deputy Horseman, along with several other Sheriff's deputies and members of the Easton High staff responded quickly to contain the incident. The students involved will face appropriate disciplinary action, and we are continuously evaluating safety measures to prevent or mitigate incidents of this nature." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: UPDATED: Social media post 'not a threat' to Easton schools, TCPS says
author: Tom McCall
content:
UPDATED: Social media post 'not a threat' to Easton schools, TCPS says

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: News 
 
 245
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Students in Talbot County Public Schools were put in a modified lockdown after a threatening social media post was made Friday morning. According to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, the threat originated outside of the United States and similar threats were made to schools in Easton, Pennsylvania.A message sent to families in the district later that morning stated that the Talbot County Sheriff's Office confirmed the incident was "not a threat to our schools or community."
"They are continuing to investigate and will notify us if any additional information is received," the message said. "Thank you for your support in keeping our students and staff safe."
"We got a notification from Easton, Pennsylvania that they got the same exact notice," said Talbot County Sheriff's Office Public Information Officer John Bollinger. "It is all over and it is Friday the 13th and somebody felt like having some fun. From what we can tell so far, the threat originated from out of the country."
An initial message sent to parents of TCPS students Friday morning said, "We have increased police presence at schools this morning as a precautionary measure."
"The kids aren't outside," Bollinger said. "There have been some very generic threats, nothing specific, so we are just going above and beyond."
"... They are not letting anyone out doing outside activities and limiting kids in the hallway," he said.
Easton Police Department is assisting the sheriff's office in investigating the situation and monitoring the school.
This report may be updated.

title: Man handed life sentence for Federalsburg murder
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Man handed life sentence for Federalsburg murder

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 549
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Quandre Winder, 27, was handed a life sentence on Wednesday for the September 2023 murder of 27-year-old Caryn Faye Brown in Federalsburg.Judge Brett Wilson handed Winder a life sentence with all but 50 years suspended for first-degree murder and a consecutive 20-year sentence for firearm use in a violent crime with eligibility for parole after five years.
Winder's incarceration will be followed by five years of supervised probation.
In July, Winder pleaded guilty to first-degree murder and using a firearm in a violent crime. Although Winder received 10 charges relating to Brown's death, the remaining eight charges — including manslaughter, assault and additional firearm charges — were abandoned by the state.
Shortly after midnight on Sept. 4, 2023, Brown was found dead in front of an apartment complex in the 700 block of Gardens Court in Federalsburg. Officers from the Federalsburg Police Department were called to the scene and found her lying in the grass with apparent gunshot wounds to the head and chest.
At a plea hearing on July 8, Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin said Winder, who had a handgun on him and had been arguing with Brown before she was killed, was seen shooting Brown multiple times. Franklin said the two were in a "volatile relationship," which Brown had ended due to domestic violence.
During the sentencing hearing on Wednesday, Franklin said the system had failed Brown, who had cases against Winder for domestic violence.
Brown's siblings, mother and eight-year-old son all provided statements at the sentencing hearing. Brown's son Dominic's statement read, "My mommy was a beautiful person, and you took her away from me."
Brown's mother, Nancy Geeslin, recounted the night she got the call that her daughter had been killed. She spoke about how Brown's death has affected each of Brown's children.
Brown's younger sister, Tyrah Banks, said she didn't know if Winder would every fully grasp what he did to their families.
"This will never not hurt," she said.
Banks said she has found peace in the fact that her sister can't be hurt again and peace in the fact that Brown lives on through her children.
Winder's attorney Dana Boston, who is with the Maryland Office of the Public Defender, said Winder committed a terrible act that shouldn't have happened. Boston said Winder had a rough upbringing and developed a drug addiction. He said Winder was on Percocet and Xanax the night of Brown's death.
Boston said Winder expressed "heartfelt remorse" for his actions and is dealing with the psychological repercussions of those actions.
Before handing down Winder's sentence, Wilson said it wasn't the system, but the nature of law that failed Brown. He said when it comes to domestic violence, peace orders are just pieces of paper.
"They're not bullet-proof vests," he said.
Wilson said Winder's criminal history, including firearm and assault charges, show a pattern of disregard for law, authority and others.
Wilson said he is sorry anybody has to grow up in imperfect conditions. But he said this "senseless" act should not have happened.
After the hearing, Jennifer Roberts, Brown's aunt, said in an interview with the Star Democrat that their family is happy to have closure after this has hung over their heads for a year. She said they have no choice but to be satisfied with the outcome, and they have to put their faith in the court system. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot County Sheriffs' Office investigating another threat, threat not specific to TCPS
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Talbot County Sheriffs' Office investigating another threat, threat not specific to TCPS

 September 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: News 
 
 319
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — After a threatening social media post on Friday was determined to not be a threat to Easton schools, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office is investigating another threat that has been circulating on social media.Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said Monday morning that the threat, which originated on Instagram, is not a specific threat to Talbot County Public Schools, but to the 410 area code. He said the threat is a photo of a "clearly" photoshopped Instagram message that includes the 410 area code.
"We're taking it very seriously, as we do every threat," Gamble said, adding that, through investigation, the Sheriff's Office doesn't think there is "any viable threat to the safety" of TCPS students.
According to a letter from the district addressed to TCPS families, the district is "closely monitoring the situation" and working with local authorities. The letter says that school operations will continue as normal.
Gamble said a criminal investigation by the Sheriff's Office is underway. He said all school resource officers in the district are aware of the threat, and extra deputies are patrolling.
On Friday, TCPS students were put in a modified lockdown following a threatening social media post made that morning. According to the Sheriff's Office, the threat originated outside of the United States and similar threats were made to schools in Easton, Pennsylvania.
Gamble said the Sheriff's officer is aware of jurisdictions in other states that "have had 40 or 50 of these types of threats."
"It's happening all over our country where, for whatever reason, somebody is trying to disrupt school operations and put our kids in fear," he said.
Gamble said that a few years back, the district experienced something similar where about half a dozen non-specific threats were made during the course of the school year. He said he would expect to see more of these threats this year.
"This just seems like the thing to do these days for some reason," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Child dies after Dundalk house fire
author: JOEL LEV-TOV jlev-tov@chespub.com
content:
Child dies after Dundalk house fire

 September 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JOEL LEV-TOV jlev-tov@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 353
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As neighbor Zack Richardson tells it, it was eerily quiet for such a dramatic night. Fire trucks lined Dunleer Road in the early hours of Wednesday, Sept. 4, but didn't turn on their sirens.Had he not gotten up to feed his newborn, he said, he would have missed the house fire across the street from him at 3220 Dunleer Road. The Baltimore County Fire Department ruled that an electrical malfunction caused the fire.
According to a fire department press release, fire engines arrived at the house at 3:44 a.m.
Owner Kevin Mars' 8-year-old son Nolan was hiding on the second floor of the house. Firefighters found and rescued him by 4 a.m., radio traffic indicates. Richardson said Nolan's body was "limp" as he was carried out of the burning house.
Nolan was taken to a local hospital. He died Sept. 9, according to a fire department press release. Only one pet survived, owner Kevin Mars said. Nine cats died in the blaze, according to the fire department.
Mars and four other children in the house escaped with minor injuries, the fire department said.
Despite the dramatic scene, few signs of tragedy remained just a few hours later. The only hints were charred grass, boarded up windows, small pieces of glass strewn around the outside of the house and the back of packaging for an oxygen mask. A faint smell of burning lingered if you got close enough. Even closer, burned wood was visible.
The birds in the tree next to the house kept chirping.
By Sept. 10, the oxygen mask packaging had been removed. In addition to a sign directing people to drop off packages at Richardson's house, a sign warning people that "any alteration or removal of items in this area" would be punished because an ongoing fire investigation was taking place.
Richardson, the neighbor, started a GoFundMe campaign to help the family. As of Tuesday, it had already raised over $23,000 out of the $30,000 goal. His wife set up a clothing drive for the family.
"The support has been amazing and unexpected but sometimes uncomfortable," Mars wrote in a text to the Eagle, "being we're usually quiet people." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Police charge suspect in connection with Easton High bomb threat
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Police charge suspect in connection with Easton High bomb threat

 September 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 385
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A 17-year-old suspect has been charged in connection with a bomb threat that forced an evacuation at Easton High School Monday.In a social media post on Facebook, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office announced detectives located the residence of a 17-year-old female and charged her with "making a threat of mass violence." Police say she is not enrolled in the Talbot County Public Schools system.
Students and staff were evacuated out of EHS on Monday afternoon after the threat was made just after 2 p.m. Police say a caller contacted the front desk and "advised that there was a bomb inside of the school and hung up."
"The caller re-contacted the front desk staff a few minutes later and asked when dismissal was," the Talbot County Sheriff's Office stated.
Police stated EHS staff immediately notified the school resource officer of the threat, leading to a quick evacuation from the building. The sheriff's office said all students and staff were safely evacuated as of Monday afternoon.
Deputies responded to the school, and bomb-detecting K-9 teams searched the building and surrounding property. Once cleared, staff returned to the school building.
"I am so grateful for the outstanding work our Talbot Deputies, Easton Police Officers, and our Talbot County Department of Emergency Services Dispatchers performed today to identify the caller of the bomb threat," Sheriff Joe Gamble said in a release.
"Within two hours the suspect was identified, located and charged," he said. "The teachers and staff at Easton High worked tirelessly with law enforcement to make sure everyone was safe. We are so fortunate to have such dedicated professionals in our community who work very hard to keep our children safe."
Deputies are working with the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office and "will be seeking additional charges if applicable," the sheriff's office said.
At Monday's Easton Town Council meeting, Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello thanked staff and first responders who handled the situation on Monday.
"I want to offer my sincere thanks to the teachers and the staff, and the first responders who attended the bomb threat today at Easton High School," Abbatiello said. "You all were professional in caring for our children and put them first. In this day and age, you cannot be too careful."
Anyone with information is asked to contact the Talbot County Sheriff's Office at 410-822-1020.
This report may be updated.
