title: Moore cancels back debt for thousands of parolees
author: STEVEN JACOBS JR. Capital News Service
content:
Moore cancels back debt for thousands of parolees

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEVEN JACOBS JR. Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 211
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Gov. Wes Moore is canceling outstanding debts owed to the state by those on parole and probation, calling it the "equitable and just" thing to do.The action will forgive the debt for more than 6,700 people who owe supervision fees as part of their parole or release arrangement with the Department of Public Safety and Correctional services.
"Marylanders who serve their time deserve a second chance without bearing the financial burden of recurring administrative fees," Moore said in a release. "This action will create paths to work, wages and wealth for Marylanders; grow our economy; and build a state that is more equitable and just."
The decision forgives more than $13 million in debt. It applies only to current parolees on active supervision, not to those whose debts are already in collection proceedings.
Individuals under court-ordered supervision — whether through parole, probation or release — pay monthly fees to the state. The rate ranges from $40 to $50 a month depending on the date the supervision began.
"The decision to waive parole and drug testing fees aligns with Gov. Moore's vision for a more supportive reintegration process," said Carolyn Scruggs, secretary of the correctional agency. "This decision eases financial burden, promotes successful reintegration and will ultimately help reduce recidivism among returning citizens." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Governor Moore's policy to cancel debts for parolees, administered by the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services. This directly relates to public safety systems and reintegration efforts. While economic impacts are mentioned, the core context is correctional policy and public safety administration.

title: Bus driver likely to face charges after abandoning students at the wrong stop
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Bus driver likely to face charges after abandoning students at the wrong stop

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 733
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A bus driver for Newark Charter School in Delaware is expected to face charges after 10 elementary school students were abandoned at the wrong bus stop.The incident happened Tuesday afternoon as Bus #28 was driving the students home for the day. School officials called police at approximately 4:15 p.m. to report the incident, according to Sgt. Joseph Conover, a spokesman for the Newark Police Department.
The driver made the students — ranging from kindergarten to fifth grade — get off the bus at a stop in Robscott Manor, which is not their normal stop, Conover said.
A parent waiting for her child at that stop realized that extra students exited the bus and called the school and police to report the incident.
School officials and officers from the Newark and New Castle County police departments all rushed to Robscott Manor, where they found the students safe.
"The cooperative efforts between Newark Charter School, the Newark Police Department and its law enforcement partners ensured the safe reunification of all of the students with their guardians," Conover said.
State troopers tracked down the bus and confirmed that there were no more students aboard.
Conover said Newark's school resource officers are still interviewing students and families but he expects the driver to be arrested and charged with multiple offenses.
Police are still trying to figure out exactly why the students were told to get out in Robscott Manor. The neighborhood is on the bus route, but some of those students live a significant distance away from where they were dropped off, Conover said.
The mother of one of the affected students told the Newark Post she was waiting for her child to come home and was tracking the bus via an app that parents have access to. She began to get concerned when the bus was late and she saw on the GPS tracking app that the bus was going in the wrong direction.
She then got a call from the parent who witnessed the kids get kicked off the bus, and she went to Robscott to pick up her child.
She started to piece together what happened by talking to her son.
"He said they were at a stop, and the bus driver said 'Everybody get off the bus. Get your stuff and get off,'" recounted the mother, who asked not to be identified out of concern for her child's safety.
Some of the children were confused and scared and refused to get off, she added. At the next stop on the same street, the driver again told them it's the last stop and they had to get off, and the remaining students eventually complied.
She said she told her son she was proud of him for helping his younger classmates.
"It's just a crazy thing, but I do feel like the kids really stuck together and they kind of took care of each other," she said. "I think that made a lot of the parents feel better."
She also praised school officials for reacting quickly to ensure the students were safe.
The mother said she has decided to let her child continue to ride the bus, but she will be more alert about knowing who is driving her child.
"You don't really think about who is it that's driving the bus," she said. "You don't really see them a whole lot. You just kind of let your kid get on, and there they are."
The incident has taught her to be more vigilant about talking to her child about what happens during bus rides.
"A big takeaway with all the parents is just to kind of watch out a little bit more and try to notice if things do seem strange and having your kid be able to tell you if things seem off," she said.
The driver, whose name has not yet been made public, is an employee of Advanced Student Transportation, the bus company Newark Charter has contracted with since the school opened 23 years ago.
"Yesterday's incident was unfortunate and we are tremendously disappointed that it occurred," Head of School Sam Golder wrote in a letter to parents. "The bus driver will no longer be driving for Newark Charter School."
Golder assured parents the school is fully cooperating with the police investigation.
"Student safety is, and will continue to be, our number one priority at Newark Charter School," he said. "I personally have three children of my own and I would not have tolerated yesterday's behavior, had my children been riding this bus." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a bus driver abandoning students at a wrong stop, leading to police involvement and concerns about child safety. While education institutions are involved, the core issue revolves around public safety risks and law enforcement response.

title: Police: Man, 63, took inappropriate photos of girls at volleyball games
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Police: Man, 63, took inappropriate photos of girls at volleyball games

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 840
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESAPEAKE CITY — A 63-year-old man is charged with disturbing school operation and disorderly conduct after he allegedly took numerous inappropriate photos and videos of girls playing volleyball matches inside the Bohemia Manor High School gymnasium, according to Cecil County District Court records.Investigators identified the suspect as Michael Cornell Griffin of Townsend, Del.
Maryland State Police Master Trooper Jason Proctor conducted an on-scene investigation during the incident, which occurred shortly before 8 p.m. on Thursday, and he was able to view the photographic content of the suspect's cell phone after Griffin had given verbal consent to do so, police reported.
"I reviewed the photo album and observed that it contained several photographs and videos of the junior varsity teams and varsity teams from both schools: Bohemia Manor High School and Perryville High School . . . The photographs observed in the photo album were of the buttock areas of the juvenile aged female players," Proctor summarized in his written statement of probable cause.
The investigator noted, "The uniform shorts that are worn by all the volleyball players are tight in nature; however, the photographs that were taken were zoomed in by Griffin revealing inappropriate detail, as certain curvature of the female players body parts could be clearly observed."
Court records indicate that the investigation leading to the two criminal charges against Griffin started after spectators noticed the suspect acting suspiciously in the bleachers during the volleyball game, police said. The initial complainant was a 41-year-old woman, court records show. (It is not clear if Griffin had direct ties to the volleyball competition, such as a relative who was one of the players.)
The complainants had seen the suspect "deliberately zoom in on the players' buttock areas" while he was taking digital photos with his cell phone, court records allege.
Griffin's alleged actions caused nearby parents and other spectators to ask him why he was taking pictures, creating a scene that diverted some of the spectators' attention away from the volleyball game, according to the charging document.
"This was actively causing disturbance within the stands," court records allege.
After spectators complained and pointed to the suspect, the trooper escorted Griffin from the gymnasium into the lobby, police said. Bohemia Manor Middle School Assistant Principal Stacy Rahnama was in the lobby and was present during the on-scene investigation, police added.
Proctor informed Griffin that he had been accused of taking inappropriate photos of female volleyball players, court records show. Griffin denied taking pictures of the players and started opening and closing the photo album on his phone, according to court records.
"It appeared as if he was trying to hide the photographs. Griffin appeared to be extremely nervous while speaking with me. I observed his right hand and fingers shake multiple times as he was scrolling through his phone," Proctor outlined in court records.
At that point, the trooper asked Griffin if he would be willing to show him the photos that he had taken and Griffin gave verbal consent, court records show. During that viewing of the photographic content of Griffin's cell phone, Proctor and Rahnama saw numerous inappropriate photos and videos of the female volleyball players, court records allege.
"While reviewing the photo albums, the initial complainant entered the lobby and made inquiries as to whether or not her daughter's photograph was on his phone and was making comments that she wanted the photographs deleted," according to the charging document.
Proctor then escorted Griffin out of the building and into the breezeway, where — with the suspect's consent — he and Rahnama deleted all of the questionable pictures and videos found in the phone's photo library and then from the phone's trash bin file, court records show.
"While this was taking place, a group of patrons had gathered in the lobby and were actively observing my interactions with Griffin. Another patron had to tell that group of people to remain inside and not to interfere, as they were making threats to assault Griffin due to his actions," according to the charging document, which indicates that the group obeyed and returned to the gymnasium.
After the deletion of the photos and videos, Rahnama requested that Griffin leave the school property, police said. The trooper then escorted Griffin to his 2014 Chrysler 200 that was parked in the school lot and ordered him to leave the premises, which Griffin did, police added.
At the end of his written statement of probable cause, Proctor summarized, "Griffin's direct actions of being visible while he was taking inappropriate and offensive photographs (by way of zooming in) caused direct disturbance within the stands of the sporting event which is also disruption of school activities."
Griffin was not arrested but, instead, was charged through a criminal summons that was issued on Monday, court records show. Griffin is charged with disturbing school operation, a misdemeanor that carries a maximum six-month penalty and a $2,500 fine if convicted; and disorderly conduct, which is punishable by up to 60 days in jail and a $500 fine if convicted, according to court records.
Griffin is scheduled to appear for a preliminary inquiry on Nov. 25, court records show. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal incident involving police investigation, charges of disturbing school operations, and disorderly conduct related to inappropriate photography at a school event. While the school setting connects to Education, the primary focus is on law enforcement response and public safety concerns.

title: Woman faces murder charge after allegedly running over man with SUV
author: Jesse Yeatman jyeatman@somdnews.com
content:
Woman faces murder charge after allegedly running over man with SUV

 October 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jesse Yeatman jyeatman@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 304
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A 50-year-old woman faces.a murder charge after she allegedly hit a man with a vehicle in Lexington Park Oct. 7.Maryland State Police homicide investigators arrested Simone Stewart, 50, of Lexington Park in connection with the death of Demeatrum Scarborough.
Stewart is charged with second-degree murder, first-degree assault, homicide by motor vehicle and driving under the influence. She is currently at the St. Mary's Detention Center awaiting an appearance before the court commissioner, according to a release from the state police sent Wednesday night.
Scarborough, 53, of Lexington Park was pronounced deceased Tuesday by hospital personnel at MedStar Washington Hospital.
"Police believe Stewart and Scarborough were involved in an ongoing relationship. Further investigation indicates they were involved in an alleged altercation at the time the incident occurred," according to the release.
Shortly before 1 p.m. on Monday, Oct. 7, troopers from the Leonardtown barrack responded to Spring Valley Drive and Valley Court in Lexington Park for the report of a pedestrian struck by a Chevrolet Suburban.
Upon arrival, troopers located Scarborough with apparent injuries. He was flown by Maryland State Police Aviation Command to MedStar Washington Hospital.
The preliminary investigation indicated Stewart was allegedly the driver of the Suburban at the time of the incident, according to the state police. Investigators from the Maryland State Police Homicide Unit are leading the investigation.
Based on additional information received, evidence collected and consultation with the St. Mary's County State's Attorney, Stewart was charged with the murder of Scarborough.
Assistance with the investigation is being provided by troopers from the Leonardtown barrack, regional investigators from the Maryland State Police Criminal Enforcement Division Central South, crime scene technicians from the Forensic Sciences Division and the St. Mary's County State's Attorney's Office.
The investigation is active and ongoing. Anyone with information relevant to this investigation can contact homicide investigators at the Maryland State Police Leonardtown Barrack at 301-475-8955.

While local government and community life could be tangentially related, the core focus on a criminal incident and safety risks makes 'Public Safety' the most accurate classification.

title: Thousands of troops, hundreds of out-of-state police in Florida after Hurricane Milton
author: Mike Sunnucks APG Newspapers
content:
Thousands of troops, hundreds of out-of-state police in Florida after Hurricane Milton

 October 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG Newspapers | Section: National 
 
 658
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Thousands of National Guard troops are being deployed and the Pentagon is also sending military personnel to Florida after Hurricane Milton slammed into the gulf coast and swept through much of the state causing significant damage from extreme winds, relentless rains and hundred-year floods.Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis has activated more than 6,500 National Guard troops and another 200 soldiers from the Florida State Guard (a state defense force that has been in place since World War II) to help with emergency and public safety responses to the hurricane.
DeSantis and state officials said the Milton response includes Blackhawk helicopters and drones.
Pentagon spokesman Maj. Gen. Pat Ryder said Thursday there are another 3,000 National Guard troops from 19 other states are also at the ready to help with search and rescue, relief and security efforts after the storm.
Ryder said the response includes 26 helicopters and more than 500 high-water vehicles are part of the response.
The Pentagon is also sending U.S. military assets to Florida as part of the Federal Emergency Management Agency's response to Milton — which knocked power to more than 3 million Florida households and resulted in wind damage and widespread flooding in southwest Florida, the Tampa Bay area, Orlando and other parts of the state.
FEMA has already been in the state after Hurricane Helene cause substantial storm surge damage along Florida's west coast.
"The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers has approximately 250 people supporting the response with temporary roof support, debris control, flood control, waterway clearance and more," Ryder said during a press briefing Thursday.
"U.S. Northern Command and U.S. Army North have also have active duty forces and capabilities postured and ready to support FEMA when requested, to include up to 60 high water vehicles from Fort Stewart, Georgia, up to 100 U.S. Marines from Camp Lejeune, North Carolina to provide support for urban search and rescue, search and rescue helicopters plus light and medium rotary wing airlift aircraft from the 3rd Infantry Division, as well as command and control support capabilities."
Those two military commands focus on domestic security.
Ryder said U.S. military bases in Florida and nearby southern states will serve as staging areas for Hurricane Milton responses. Tampa is home to MacDill Air Force Base and the U.S. Central Command (which runs U.S. military operations in the Middle East including the current Holy Land war zone involving Israel, Iran and its proxies Hamas and Hezbollah). Officials at Central Command have not responded to questions about the impact of Milton on operations and whether any commanders or assets were moved ahead of the Category 3 storm. Ryder also did not provide details when asked about the hurricane's impact on the Tampa-baed command Thursday.
Florida police agencies restricted access to beach areas after the storm surge damage of Hurricane Helene for safety and security reasons — in part, because of their concerns about looting and criminal activity. The Helene response has included National Guard troops patrolling beach areas.
They will likely do the same for areas after Milton which brought widespread flooding and wind damage to southwest Florida and Tampa Bay. Deployed troops will also be part of search and rescue and cleanup efforts in response to Milton, according to state officials.
While the Florida governor has promised as quick as possible access to their homes for Floridians who evacuated before Milton's arrival, some local officials are less keen on that approach.
A number of local police and fire departments pulled back on responses during Milton which brought intense winds and hours-long torrential rains Wednesday night and early Thursday morning.
DeSantis said 500 out-of-state police are coming to Florida to add to state law enforcement responses to Milton.
Local sheriffs, in particular, along with DeSantis and state officials have promised aggressive response to any post-hurricane looting or burglaries of wealthy homes or businesses impacted by Milton or Helene.
"We are going to come down hard on you," said DeSantis at a press briefing Wednesday before Milton's treacherous arrival. "We need to maintain law and order." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on emergency response efforts, military and law enforcement deployment, and public safety measures following Hurricane Milton. While there are elements of national coordination and local governance, the primary emphasis is on safety, security, and disaster response operations.

title: Talbot County nonprofit says heating cost 'crisis' looms amid gaps in funding
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot County nonprofit says heating cost 'crisis' looms amid gaps in funding

 October 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 441
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Representatives from the Neighborhood Service Center spoke during an Easton Town Council meeting Monday evening, requesting funding from the town for what's been deemed a potential heating cost "crisis" this winter.The nonprofit assists families in Talbot County with heating costs during cooler weather. Marilyn Neal, executive director of the Neighborhood Service Center, told council members that a "drastic change" in funding will limit the assistance provided by the organization to residents in the form of kerosene, heating oil, propane and electric.
"I fear we are going to have a crisis," Neal said. " … I'm worried that our seniors and some low-income individuals in Talbot County, as well as the town of Easton, may not be able to keep warm this winter, and it keeps me up at night."
Neal said the nonprofit provides financial assistance to local residents and is then reimbursed by the Maryland Energy Assistance Program, a state program under the Department of Housing and Community Development that is federally funded.
Cardeaner Robinson, the Maryland Energy Assistance Program director, said the number of customers for the energy assistance program statewide has doubled. She said Gov. Wes Moore "wanted to see more people use the program," which led to changes in eligibility requirements.
Increased eligibility and funding cuts for the Maryland Energy Assistance Program will impact how much financial assistance the Neighborhood Service Center can provide to county residents, Neal and Robinson said.
"It sounds like really, really bad policy making and planning on the part of the state," Ward 3 Councilmember David Montgomery said.
Neal said it happens "with every administration," but that she's "not seen a crisis as large" as what may come this winter.
Neal asked for "at least $50,000" from the town to aid the center's energy assistance efforts. Ward 4 Councilmember the Rev. Elmer Davis and Montgomery each asked for Neal to bring a breakdown of how many Easton residents are served by those efforts.
Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello asked that the council and town employees take a look at where the money may come from if the town contributes to the Neighborhood Service Center's program.
Following the presentation and questions from councilmembers, Council President Frank Gunsallus said the council will put follow-up questions together requesting further information and details from the Neighborhood Service Center.
"I don't see how our seniors living on a fixed income will be able to sustain," Neal said. "Normally, the subsidy would take them through the winter. Well this year, it won't fill their propane tanks up, it won't give them a full tank of kerosene.
"And the Neighborhood Service Center has expended 85% of our funding. … By December, all the funding will be gone." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a nonprofit's urgent request for funding to address a heating cost crisis affecting vulnerable residents, which directly relates to public safety concerns about health and well-being during cold weather. While 'Health' and 'Local Government' are relevant, 'Public Safety' best captures the immediate threat to residents' safety and survival.

title: Fire breaks out a Dollar General store
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Fire breaks out a Dollar General store

 October 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 346
 Words 

 Read News Document

 At the Worton Dollar General on Sunday, Oct. 6, a fire broke out due to what the Maryland Fire Marshal reported as an unspecified failure of a refrigerator unit.The Fire Marshal report further states, the fire at 10838 Worton Road was deemed accidental and caused an estimated loss of $100,000 in structure and $400,000 in contents. No one was injured and it took ten minutes to control with 18 firefighters on-site.
The primary responding company was Chestertown Volunteer Fire Department that later issued their press release.
According to their report, at 1:22 pm on Sunday, Oct. 6, Chestertown Volunteer Fire Company with multiple other companies, was dispatched for the Structure Fire at the Dollar General store in Worton.
A deputy from Kent County Sheriff's Office arrived first on the scene and used a fire extinguisher inside but due to the excessive smoke was forced out of the building.
First arriving was Command 6 with Chief John "Otis" Darling and Engine 68. According to reports, they laid a 5" Large Diameter Hose down that acted like an above-ground water and main supply hose.
They continued into the parking lot deploying a single 1-3/4 fire attack hose, entering the building. Officials knew which way to go from the deputy's instructions, and faced with heavy smoke, were able to do a quick "knock down."
The fire was controlled through those actions even though other precautionary measures were deployed. The report said that they had an additional supply line and Tower 6 was up on the roof, but no action needed to be taken.
With no fire, their efforts turned to clearing the building of smoke, taking more than 45 minutes.
Conducting an Origin and Cause investigation, a representative from the Maryland State's Fire Marshal's Office strongly believed the cause to be electrical. As a result Delmarva Power arrived on-site, however service was left on after determining it was safe.
Additionally, a representative from the Kent County Health Department arrived due to the the amount of food in the store. Their decision was to condemn and dispose of all food material.
The store is temporarily closed until further notice. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details an accidental fire at a retail store, emphasizing emergency response, property damage, and safety protocols. While business/economy aspects (financial loss) are mentioned, the primary focus is on public safety concerns, fire suppression efforts, and incident investigation.

title: Mid-Shore community, organizations provide hurricane relief
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Mid-Shore community, organizations provide hurricane relief

 October 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 476
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Mid-Shore community members and organizations have headed south in recent days to provide crucial assistance to communities impacted by Hurricane Helene and Hurricane Milton.Helene hit land as a Category 4 hurricane on Sept. 26, making its way through the Southeast and devastating communities. More than 200 deaths have been confirmed in six states.
Milton tore through Florida late Wednesday night, leaving millions without power and causing at least five confirmed deaths as of Thursday afternoon. It made landfall as a Category 3 hurricane.
Easton Town Council President Frank Gunsallus, who is active with Disaster Aid USA, a nonprofit that delivers disaster relief worldwide, has made two trips to North Carolina to assist Hurricane Helene victims.
This past weekend, Gunsallus drove down and delivered 20 cases of water, food, medicine, first aid supplies, diapers, hygiene products and more to Skyland United Methodist Church in Asheville, North Carolina.
He spent the weekend delivering aid and driving in Asheville and surrounding areas in western North Carolina. On Sunday, he drove through Swannanoa, North Carolina, among other ravaged towns.
"The devastation that I witnessed is moving," Gunsallus said at Monday's Easton Town Council meeting. "It doesn't really matter how well you think you have your life planned out. Sometimes the Earth just has plans of its own, and everything you know and love can just be gone. There are still people stranded, (who) cannot get out of their properties."
Gunsallus and Barc Upchurch, members of the Easton Rotary Club, drove down on Tuesday to the small community of Green Mountain, North Carolina. They took a generator to the Double Island Fire Department on behalf of the Rotary Club.
There, they also delivered an off-road, all-terrain vehicle to the local fire department, which was needed for search and rescue efforts. Gunsallus said the ATV was donated by Dave Wilson, president of Preston Automotive Group and Preston Powersports.
Gunsallus described the sights of devastation during his two trips, from houses and buildings destroyed to trees blocking roads and railroad tracks broken.
"I can't not do anything. … I've got to do something," Gunsallus said in an interview.
Donations to Disaster Aid USA can be made by visiting disasteraidusa.org or mailing a check. Checks can be mailed to: Disaster Aid USA 700 Port Street #538, Easton, MD 21601.
On Wednesday, 12 lineworkers and additional individuals from Delmarva Power arrived in St. Petersburg, Florida, to assist the electric company Duke Energy amid impacts from Hurricane Milton.
Candice Womer, senior communications specialist for Exelon, the parent company of Delmarva Power, said more crews will be heading down to Florida later this week.
"By the end of this week, Delmarva Power will have close to 50 field crews and additional personnel assisting Florida," Womer wrote.
Delmarva Power crews just wrapped up providing aid in Georgia following last month's Hurricane Helene. Womer said those crews and personnel departed Sept. 26, finished their work on Wednesday and will be heading home. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Turner gets life sentence for shootout with Calvert cops
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Turner gets life sentence for shootout with Calvert cops

 October 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 617
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A 23-year-old Prince George's County man who was convicted in June of attempting to kill a Calvert County deputy sheriff during an incident in December 2022 was given a life sentence Friday by a circuit court judge.In imposing Brandon Alexander Turner's sentence on 16 counts related to a high speed pursuit and shootout with deputies in a Huntingtown neighborhood, Judge Andrew Rappaport suspended all but 40 years of the life sentence for attempting to shoot and kill Deputy James Flynt.
Two counts of first-degree assault netted the defendant an additional 50 years with all but 18 year suspended, combined with 15 years with all but five years suspended for firearm possession with a crime of violence conviction. Those sentences will run consecutively, along with a three-year sentence for fleeing and eluding. Several other counts will run concurrently with the other charges.
Combined, Turner's sentence is for over 60 years and due to the violent nature of the crimes he must serve at least half of that time behind bars before becoming eligible for parole.
Calvert County State's Attorney Robert H. Harvey Jr. (R) called the sentence "fair and appropriate, given the magnitude of the crime."
During Friday's sentencing hearing, Flynt addressed the court, reading a prepared statement.
"Mr. Turner is a coward," Flynt said, adding that his fellow deputies responding to the shooting scene in the Walnut Creek subdivision saved his life with their quick actions.
"This would have been a murder trial," Flynt said, adding that the leg injuries he sustained in the shooting still hamper his ability today.
"My life is changed forever," Flynt said. "I've fought like hell to get back to full duty."
Noting that he has undergone about 10 surgeries due to his wounds, Flynt told the court he will be on medication for the rest of his life.
"I will never be able to run like I used to," Flynt said. The deputy asked Rappaport to impose the maximum sentence on Turner.
The other two deputies involved in the shootout also told the court their lives were changed by the incident.
Deputy Tyler Bowen also read a statement, calling the incident a "traumatic, stressful event."
In a letter read into the record during the hearing, Deputy Anthony Aranda stated the incident has impacted his career and personal life.
"The sole focus must be on public safety," Harvey said of the sentence, adding that Turner's "conduct was reprehensible. He has shown no remorse. He blames everyone else. He has been a disciplinary problem since his incarceration."
The defendant's attorney, Michelle Harewood, said her client suffers from a bipolar disorder for which he was not taking his medication.
Harewood asked that Turner be sent to Patuxent Institute in Jessup so that his behavioral health issues can be addressed.
"If he had kept on his medication we wouldn't be here today," Shelton Turner, the defendant's father, told the court. The elder Turner added that his family and church "prayed earnestly" for Flynt after the shooting incident.
"I hope you will find it in your heart to forgive me," Brandon Turner said in a written statement he read to the court prior to sentencing.
The Dec. 17, 2022, incident began in the Dunkirk area when the vehicle Turner and his wife were in was pulled over on the side of Route 4. Deputies had stopped and were about to search the vehicle when Turner fled. He led the deputies on a high-speed chase on Route 4 and several times fired a weapon out the driver's side window.
Flynt, operating a patrol vehicle, disabled Turner's Kia with a precision immobilization technique. That's when the defendant reportedly began shooting at the deputies, who returned fire.
"You could have stopped at any time but you chose not to," Rappaport told the defendant before the sentence was imposed. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal case involving a violent shootout with law enforcement, resulting in a life sentence. This directly relates to public safety concerns, as it involves police-citizen confrontations, criminal justice outcomes, and community safety implications. title: Delaware cocoa processing plant damaged by fire again
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Delaware cocoa processing plant damaged by fire again

 October 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 216
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A two-alarm fire damaged a cocoa processing plant near Glasgow Oct. 12, marking at least the fifth time in 10 years that the factory has caught fire.The latest incident happened shortly before 11 p.m. at United Cocoa Processors in the Pencader Corporate Center off Del. 896.
Firefighters arrived to find fire coming from the building. The flames were knocked down in approximately 40 minutes, and the situation was declared under control shortly after midnight.
The incident drew firefighters from 10 local fire departments as well as New Castle County paramedics. No one was injured.
The state fire marshal is investigating the cause of the fire.
Saturday's incident is at least the fifth fire there since 2015. In November 2023, two employees had to be rescued from the roof of the burning factory. There also was a fire there in July of that year, as well as in March 2021 and February 2015.
In 2020, the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration fined the company $53,000 for five safety violations, including exposing workers to slip and fall hazards, failing to maintain proper egress routes out of the roasting room and having machinery with rotating parts that were not fully enclosed or sufficiently guarded.
United Cocoa Processors turns raw cocoa beans into cocoa liquor, cocoa butter and cocoa powder to be shipped globally. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Queen Anne's County High School gets school security grant
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's County High School gets school security grant

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 308
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Queen Anne's County High School has recently been awarded $70,000 to pursue the hiring of the district's first School Security Employee (SSE), according to Joe Saboury, coordinator of school safety and security.As of August, the district received funding from the Maryland Center for School Safety School Resource Officer (SRO) Adequate Coverage Grant under the 2018 Maryland Safe to Learn Act, Saboury said.
This funding allows school districts to hire an employee to serve as a supplement to the SRO already in place, he said. Resource officers already serving the school district fall under the direction and budget of the county sheriff's office.
The statewide grant funding assists in supplementing law enforcement coverage for public schools with $10 to 15 million in FY26 and $20 million in FY27 and each year thereafter, he said.
As school security is considered a top state priority, a minimum three years of funding following this year is secured, according to Saboury.
"So really that's putting additional eyes and ears in our schools, which is a wonderful thing," he said.
As a member of the district, the SSE works more closely with school leaders on safety measures, often outside law enforcement scopes, and are more closely involved with student behavior, support and providing intervention to mitigate and prevent harm, he said.
As district employees, QACPS has the flexibility to utilize SSEs for after school sporting events or field trips Saboury said.
"It's a great resource that the school district has never had before," he said.
SSEs are held to the same standards and certification programs through the Maryland for School Safety Model training as SROs.
Training, uniforms, equipment and overtime are all budgeted into the grant with no cost the district, he said.
With the potential for increased funding down the road, Saboury was hopeful to be able to build the program and continually create a safe learning environment for students. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a school security grant and implementation of a School Security Employee (SSE) program, directly relating to public safety measures in educational institutions. While education is tangentially relevant, the primary emphasis is on safety protocols and law enforcement collaboration.

title: Millington homicide suspect arrested in Philadelphia
author: Staff Writer
content:
Millington homicide suspect arrested in Philadelphia

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 359
 Words 

 Read News Document

 MILLINGTON — Police have made an arrest in the Oct. 11 murder of a Millington man. According to the Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff, Brian Sykes, 48, also of Millington, was apprehended during a traffic stop in Philadelphia on Oct. 13, shortly before midnight.Deputies from the Sheriff's Office were dispatched to a residence on Pfalzgroff Road in Millington, just after 6 p.m. on Oct. 11, for a report of a medical emergency. Upon arrival, deputies discovered that 67-year-old David Teat of Millington had been involved in a serious altercation, which ultimately led to his death.
Police said through investigative efforts, including interviews with witnesses and family members, the suspect was identified as Sykes, the victim's stepson. Investigators quickly determined that Sykes had fled and was no longer in the area. The victim's vehicle was noted missing. Police issued a stolen vehicle alert and a person of interest alert. Law enforcement agencies in surrounding states were notified, and a regional search was initiated, police said.
Sykes was located during a traffic stop in North Philadelphia when a felony alert came back on the vehicle's tags. Sykes attempted to flee, striking multiple vehicles in the process, before being apprehended. Minor injuries were sustained as a result of these collisions. Sykes was held on multiple charges related to the incident in Philadelphia. The Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff sought and obtained an arrest warrant that Sykes will be extradited for the following charges: murder, first degree; murder, second degree; assault, first degree; assault, second degree; armed robbery; robbery and theft: $1,500 to under $25,000.
Sheriff Gary Hofmann said, "Our office is grateful for the critical support we received from law enforcement agencies in Delaware and Pennsylvania in the apprehension of this suspect. We are grateful that Brian Sykes will now face the judicial process. This is an important step towards justice for the victim and their family."
The investigation remains active. Anyone with additional information is encouraged to contact Detective First Class Sullivan at the Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff at 410-758-0770, ext. 1225, or via email at dsullivan@qac.org The Anonymous Tip Line also is available 24/7 at 410-758-6666.

title: Dorchester County may need to add to detention center
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Dorchester County may need to add to detention center

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 681
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County detention center is struggling to keep up with increases in the number of juveniles incarcerated and may ask for money to build a new wing to house the young offenders.During a Tuesday County Council meeting, council members decided to prioritize the topic for the upcoming Maryland General Assembly legislative session.
During a final discussion on priorities for the legislative session, Councilmember Mike Detmer, talked about what he described as his "juvenile crime concern."
In his comments, Detmer said juvenile crime in Dorchester County has been on the rise and the crimes being committed are more than simply jaywalking.
"It's absolutely insane that we have so many people that have had direct and directly affected by this, multiple people in this room directly affected by juvenile crime," Detmer said. "And it's unbelievable that in 2024 that we can be in a place of all the resources and all the talent we have that are wearing badges, that we can be in a place where we're held hostage by ostensibly well intentioned laws."
Detmer pleaded with council to put emphasis on juvenile crime for the Maryland General Assembly legislative session. He reminded the council of stories he shared on juvenile crime during previous meetings including children as young as 10 with guns and speeding cars on U.S. Route 50 and state Route 16 by underage drivers.
"There are kids that are still kids on paper," Detmer said. "(But) they're not acting like children."
Council President George Pfeffer, said the topic is on the list and there's no priority on the list created. Pfeffer described the topics on the list as "equally important to us" and said they will emphasize the importance of those topics once there is a legislator in front of them.
The list will be discussed with the local contingent of state delegates and senators.
Later on in the meeting Councilmember Ricky Travers, added that he agreed with Detmer and said he had issue with the way the juvenile justice system functions and said the system is "setting up a whole group of young kids for failure."
During public comment, detention center Warden Don Satterfield shared that over the last two months the detention center has had seven juveniles waiting for adult status.
Satterfield said because the state of Maryland has passed laws stating that juveniles must be housed separately by "vision and audio," those regulations have created a difficult barrier with the increase of juveniles being sent to adult detention centers.
Satterfield shared that the current detention center is almost 34 years old and is not designed to accommodate increased numbers of juveniles.
"Unfortunately, I'm going to be coming before you to add a wing (to the center)," Satterfield said. "That's where we are with this. We are already in violation of the law because of the audio part, and every other facility in the states is pretty much the same way. But this is where we are with the juvenile situation, and I don't see it concluding. And they are, quite frankly, they're a holy terror."
After hearing comment from Satterfield, Pfeffers suggested in addition to the rise in juvenile crime, that they discuss the restrictions placed on detention centers could possibly force the county to build another wing to the detention facility.
The council unanimously agreed to add the topics to the county's legislative priorities.
Dorchester is not the only county facing questions of outdated detention centers. Earlier this week, Caroline County commissioners discussed plans to join with Queen Anne's and Kent counties to build a new center, in part to deal with the increase in juvenile inmates.
In a March article in The Star Democrat, Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd talked about the growing challenge of juvenile crime in Dorchester County's largest city.
"Through investigation and statistical analysis, we have determined that the overwhelming suspect profiles for these crimes are male juveniles under the age of 16," according to a Cambridge police report. "But we have detained suspects as young as 11 for stealing vehicles in Cambridge."
According to the report, there is one 12-year-old who has been arrested for vehicle theft 11 times in the past three years. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Dorchester County's detention center challenges related to rising juvenile crime, legislative priorities for juvenile justice reforms, and facility capacity issues. These directly relate to public safety concerns. While local government actions are mentioned, the core issue revolves around public safety implications of juvenile justice system failures.

title: Eastern Shore fire companies aid areas affected by Hurricane Helene
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Eastern Shore fire companies aid areas affected by Hurricane Helene

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 591
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — Fire companies throughout the Eastern Shore have stepped up to assist with disaster areas affected by Hurricane Helene. Together they have donated fire and EMS equipment to first responders in need.When Hurricane Helene occurred, some of the members of the Oxford and Tilghman Fire Company felt the need to assist in any way possible. After watching several YouTube and Facebook videos circulating online showing the conditions in the affected areas, members of the fire company came up with the idea to assist first responders in Tennessee by donating some of their equipment.
Graham Norbury, chief of the Oxford Fire Company, said regardless of location, fire departments seek to help each other and anyone else in need.
"We do a lot of mutual aid to other departments in the area and elsewhere," Norbury said. "The Brotherhood of the Fire Services is pretty tight. When we see someone in need, then we want to be able to help any way we can."
According to Norbury, most volunteer fire companies replace equipment on a reasonably regular basis. The Oxford Fire Department had several pieces of equipment delivered to them in a short amount of time including a new ambulance and a new fire truck.
Norbury said they put word out through the Maryland State Firefighters Association that they wanted to help by donating equipment. News traveled fast, and Bill Killan, member from a fire department in Tennessee, contacted Norbury and helped coordinate a drop off with a fire department in Butler, Tennessee.
Tim Kearns, president of Oxford Fire Company, was one of the volunteers to deliver essential equipment to support disaster relief efforts. The drive to Tennessee was over 500 miles and was shared among four different drivers.
"It was important because the volunteer system works on mutual aid, so when someone is overwhelmed, we come to help," Kearns said. "And that's what we did, only they're just a little farther away than most."
Kearns said they made two stops to deliver equipment. The first was at an agricultural supply in Bristol, Virginia, which is on the border of Tennessee.
There they offloaded a skid brush unit, which is a pre-assembled piece of equipment that can fit into the back of a pickup truck and turn that pickup truck into a brush truck for fighting land fires and small house fires.
According to Kearns, the brush skid unit was the most valuable piece of equipment they gave because the roads in the area were so badly destroyed that any vehicle would have a difficult time navigating through.
With the brush skid unit the local fire department could use a heavy four-wheel drive pickup truck to help fight fires that occur.
The second stop was a campground called Faith Camp. Kearns said the camp was owned by Darren Clark, a member of the Elk Mills Poga Volunteer Fire Company, who had come from Florida to create the beautiful natural area.
Currently, Clark has been assisting people who have been displaced by the hurricane. Clark has designated his campground as a satellite fire station.
According to Kearns, everyone is trying to do their part, regardless of location. Contributing Maryland fire companies include Oxford, Tilghman, Cordova, Easton, Queen Anne Hillsboro, Suddlersville and Hollywood.
"It took a lot of folks to coordinate and manhandle the transfer of this equipment, from the paperwork, insurances, transfer of titles and tags, to all of the logistics here, there and in between," Kearns said. "Our Chief Engineer Stacy Dulin and Assistant Chief Engineers Mike Greenwak and Tom Bixler assured the equipment was capable of the 500-mile trip. Oxford Ferry loaned the heavy trailer." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on fire departments providing disaster relief and mutual aid during Hurricane Helene, emphasizing emergency response, equipment donations, and collaboration between agencies. This directly aligns with 'Public Safety' as the core theme, with secondary ties to local government coordination and environmental disaster impacts.

title: Greensboro Town Hall closed following asbestos discovery
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Greensboro Town Hall closed following asbestos discovery

 October 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 258
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — The Greensboro Town Hall is experiencing its second closure in three months, this time due to asbestos and mold found in the building.The town announced in a Facebook post on Oct. 17 that asbestos was found in a second floor office on Oct. 8. Town Manager Tammy Kelledes said in an interview that "ongoing" concerns of respiratory issues "prompted an air study."
After the initial closure, further testing confirmed asbestos and "multiple types of mold" are in the building, the town release stated.
"Laboratory results showed elevated levels of mold throughout the 2nd floor of the building and confirmed there was a risk of exposure and contamination," the town wrote.
Town employees moved out of the Town Hall building on Oct. 8 after the initial finding. They are working out of the town's meeting hall across the street.
In July, Greensboro's Town Hall was closed for more than two weeks due to a bat infestation, which cost the town around $12,000 in cleanup costs.
The town says an "abatement plan is being prepared" for the mold and asbestos. Kelledes said next steps are "to be determined," but that they may be "fairly extensive."
"We're functioning right now," Kelledes said. "It's hard to say what will come out of it. … As of right now, we are out of there and fine."
While Town Hall is closed, residents can go to the meeting hall at 111 S Main Street for assistance, which is located across the parking lot from Town Hall. They can also reach the town by calling 410-482-6222 or emailing greensboro@greensboromd.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: State Police arrest man in connection to 2021 homicide
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
State Police arrest man in connection to 2021 homicide

 October 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 329
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland State Police homicide investigators arrested a wanted fugitive in connection with a Trappe homicide that took place nearly three years ago.Ibarra Juarez, 32, is charged with first and second-degree murder, along with other related criminal charges in relation to the killing of Marta Merina, 33, on Christmas Eve in 2021.
That morning, police responded to the 2900 block of Howell Point Road for an apparent shooting. Upon their arrival, they found Merina outside of her home with a gunshot wound. According to prior reporting in the Star Democrat, Merina was located inside a vehicle with multiple bullet holes. She was pronounced dead on the scene.
Following an investigation by the Maryland State Police Homicide Unit and consultation with the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office, a felony arrest warrant was issued for Juarez a few days later.
Juarez was located by Mexican authorities for an unrelated crime in Oaxaca, Mexico on March 24, 2022. The U.S. Department of Justice's Office of International Affairs worked with Mexican prosecutors to request Juarez's provisional arrest in April 2022. Extradition was granted on Oct. 5, 2022, but was deferred pending completion of Juarez's sentence in Mexico.
Juarez was extradited to Maryland Tuesday and processed at the Maryland State Police Easton Barracks. He is currently being held at the Talbot County Detention Center without bond.
Investigators from the Maryland State Police Homicide Unit led the investigation. Assistance was provided by troopers from the Easton Barrack, the Maryland State Police Criminal Intelligence Section, crime scene technicians from the Forensic Sciences Division, troopers from the Maryland State Apprehension Team, Talbot County Sheriff's Office, Talbot County State's Attorney's Office, the Maryland Coordination and Analysis Center, Salisbury City Police Department and the Fruitland Police Department.
Federal law enforcement assistance was provided by the United States Marshals Service Baltimore Field Office and the Capital Area Regional Fugitive Task Force, and the United States Department of Justice's Office of International Affairs, who worked with law enforcement partners in Mexico to secure Juarez's arrest and extradition.

title: Mid-Shore sheriffs join in call for DJS secretary's resignation
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Mid-Shore sheriffs join in call for DJS secretary's resignation

 October 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 693
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sheriffs across the state of Maryland are calling for Gov. Wes Moore (D) to "immediately demand the resignation" of Vincent Schiraldi, secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services.The Dorchester, Talbot and Caroline County sheriffs, along with all but five other Maryland sheriffs, voted Monday to have the Maryland Sheriffs' Association send the governor a letter to this effect.
"Since Schiraldi's appointment in 2022, his extreme policies and lack of leadership as the Secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services, have directly made communities less safe in Maryland," the letter reads.
"Consistently in Maryland, juveniles have been charged with serious violent crimes," it later states, "only to be turned right back over to a parent or guardian, and back out on the streets to commit more crimes."
A statement from Moore's office noted that "over the past year," the governor has made a "concerted effort" to hold youth accountable and rehabilitate offenders. The statement highlighted a "26% decline in juvenile homicide arrests and 46% decline in non-fatal shootings of juveniles" statewide.
The statement did not directly respond to the Maryland Sheriffs' Association's request for Moore to call for Schiraldi's resignation.
"The governor is fully committed to working with local elected officials, law enforcement, the judiciary, and community leaders to improve public safety by holding youth accountable and rehabilitating them," it reads.
The Department of Juvenile Services did not immediately respond to a request for comment regarding the sheriffs' letter.
Schiraldi, who was officially appointed to the position by Moore in March 2023, has indicated in other media interviews that he has the governor's support and is planning to "stay in his job."
"Gov. Moore has been extremely supportive," Schiraldi told WBAL-TV on Friday afternoon. "He's gotten us additional funds this year — $17 million to make community safer by expanding programs — and I want those community members who are calling for my resignation to feel safe."
SHERIFFS WEIGH INThe Caroline, Dorchester and Talbot sheriffs said their votes to send the letter to Moore were prompted by negative impacts on local communities during Schiraldi's tenure as Department of Juvenile Services secretary.
Dorchester County Sheriff James Phillips said he "lost all respect" for Schiraldi following an in-person community meeting the secretary attended around a year ago.
"He had the audacity to tell us, … 'The data that I'm receiving doesn't support your claim of increased juvenile crime,'" Phillips recalled. "And our reply to that was, 'Well, obviously the numbers are going to go down because you're not allowing us to charge (them) anymore.'"
Phillips said in Dorchester County, "we're dealing with the same people, the same names, the same age kids."
"The law-abiding citizens are suffering because of their ignorance and stupidity in protecting these criminals," Phillips said. "And that's all they are. They might only be 15 or 16, but they're thugs."
Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble says there's "no accountability," noting that his office was recently involved in a vehicle chase in which a juvenile had an ankle monitor with batteries that hadn't been replaced for two months.
Gamble said the Mid-Shore has "good" juvenile services workers, "but they're being hampered by the secretary." He pointed to Talbot Teen Court, a first-time program for juvenile offenders of misdemeanor crimes, as more successful in rehabilitating youth compared to the state's services.
"They're getting more community service and stuff out of Teen Court than they would ever get out of DJS," Gamble said. "It's just a failed system. And it's being led by what the Sheriffs' Association believes is a bad pick by the governor."
Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker said recent justice reform — particularly Maryland's Child Interrogation Protection Act — has decreased the ability of police to hold juveniles accountable.
That act, enacted in 2022, restricts police from questioning a child without first talking to the parent or guardian's attorney or the Office of the Public Defender. Baker said it's a "shame when parental rights are superseded by the legislature."
Baker, who serves on the state's juvenile justice reform commission, believes the General Assembly has a "role to play" in improving juvenile reform moving forward.
"Juvenile reform needs to be a high priority to help take the steps needed for them to have accountability for when they step into adulthood," Baker said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on sheriffs' demands for the resignation of the DJS secretary due to concerns over juvenile justice policies impacting community safety. While local government officials are involved, the core issue revolves around public safety implications of juvenile justice reforms and law enforcement challenges.

title: Greensboro man enters Alford plea in sex abuse of a minor
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Greensboro man enters Alford plea in sex abuse of a minor

 October 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 320
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — A Greensboro man entered an Alford plea for sexual abuse of a minor and reckless endangerment at a pre-trial hearing last week in the Caroline County Circuit Court.On Oct. 23, Enemias Simeon Bautista Perez, 37, took the plea for two of 14 counts of criminal charges, which included first-degree rape and first-degree child abuse.
An Alford plea allows a person to maintain their innocence while acknowledging the state had enough evidence to obtain a conviction. The other 12 counts will not be prosecuted.
Perez's jury trial, which was scheduled to begin Oct. 28, is now canceled.
The counts that will not be prosecuted included first-degree rape of an 8-year-old child, along with incest, first-degree child abuse, first-degree assault and sexual solicitation of a minor, all allegedly occurring at his residence in Greensboro around March 30.
Originally, Perez faced up to 211 years in prison in Caroline County, along with life in prison for the first-degree rape charge. His guilty counts of sexual abuse of a minor and reckless endangerment carry maximum sentences of 30 and five years, respectively.
Perez's sentencing is scheduled for Dec. 13. Judge Sidney S. Campen requested a full pre-sentence investigation into Perez prior to that date.
Attorney Eduardo Gonzalez, who represents Perez, did not immediately respond to request for comment.
Charging documents indicated Perez as the 8-year-old child's parent. Since being charged, he's been held without bond at the Caroline County Detention Center.
Perez faces an addition 19 counts of criminal charges in Wicomico County, including first-degree rape, sexual abuse of a minor and second-degree assault. All 19 of those charges state the offenses occurred between August 2021 and April 2024 in Wicomico County, according to court records.
The Wicomico County charges total a potential 224 years in prison, along with life in prison for the first-degree rape charge.
A pre-trial conference for that case is scheduled for Nov. 25, with a potential jury trial set to begin Dec. 9 in Wicomico County.

title: Cambridge police, fire chiefs update City Council on departments
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge police, fire chiefs update City Council on departments

 October 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 541
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd and Rescue Fire Company Chief Brad Walters both gave updates on their departments at a Cambridge City Council meeting Oct. 28.During the meeting, Walters talked about the fire company's goals and objectives, and Todd talked about the police department's third quarter report, which breaks down data from July through September.
RESCUE FIRE COMPANYThe Rescue Fire Company Chiefs Office has nine goals for 2024 through 2026:
Provide an advanced, cost-effective and dependable fleet of apparatuses.Ensure a healthy and safe workplace.Provide an efficient and well-structured training program.Improve response management.Improve internal and external communications.Provide well-structured and accessible standard operating guidelines and procedures.Improve records management.Provide an efficient system for inventory and supplies.Improve recruitment and retention.
Objectives for the nine goals include developing a health and fitness program for members, developing a standard for response times and staff availability, developing mutual aid agreements with surrounding departments and developing an outreach program for recruitment.
Walters, who attended the council meeting virtually, said the fire company has always had goals and objectives in place.
"Now we're just finally putting them on paper, (putting) them out there," he said to the City Council.
CAMBRIDGE POLICE DEPARTMENTAfter Walters spoke, Todd filled the City Council in on the police department's third quarter report. He said the department has been keeping up with its reporting in an effort to be transparent and keep the public aware of what is happening in Cambridge.
Todd listed some reductions in crime and said he sees these reductions as a sign of progress. He said there is still "a lot of work ahead," but the department will keep working.
According to the report, compared to last year's third quarter, violent crime is down 31%, stolen vehicle reports are down 114%, simple assault complaints are down 16%, aggravated assault complaints are down 62% and ShotSpotter alerts are down 57%.
Todd said he believes the percentage of stolen vehicle reports decreased more than 100% this year because many of the vehicle thefts last year were committed by kids after videos came out showing how a person can easily break into Kias and Hyundais.
Todd said Kia and Hyundai has since fixed this issue. He said the Cambridge Police Department also identified many of those children, and a lot of them were given referrals to the Department of Juvenile Services.
"I believe that's the main reason you see that drop that significant," Todd said.
Todd also mentioned some increases in certain crimes. According to the report, sexual crime is up 122% and vandalism and malicious destruction of property complaints are up 27% compared to last year's third quarter.
Todd said the department will work to address these increases.
"We'll get to the point of figuring out why they are up and who is doing those crimes," he said.
After Todd spoke, multiple commissioners thanked him and his department for their efforts.
Commissioner Jameson Harrington said he was impressed with the results from ShotSpotter, a gunshot detection system. The ShotSpotter data within the report broke down the number of gunshot incidents and rounds fired it has detected, as well as the top locations for gunfire.
"I was very skeptical at first, and I've seen how it's been misused and mis-deployed in other cities, but it seems like it's working well here," Harrington said about the system. "So thank you." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
