title: State could improve juvenile justice system
author: STEPHEN RIDEOUT
content:
State could improve juvenile justice system

 January 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPHEN RIDEOUT | Section: Columns 
 
 759
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The first juvenile court was founded in 1899 in Chicago. Since then, the states have passed laws that created their own juvenile court systems. These are broad systems that function differently within each state. That impacts similar cases in different ways.So, in one state a child of a certain age automatically can be treated as an adult depending on the crime charged while in another state that same child would go through a hearing in the juvenile court to determine probable cause and if a judicial officer felt the case should remain in juvenile court or go to adult court for trial and treatment as an adult.
After I retired from the bench in 2004, I began consulting in states to help them improve how their systems worked for children and families with a focus on local collaboration efforts among courts, child welfare agencies, lawyers and service agencies to help improve outcomes.
From my experience as a judge in Virginia and my consulting work around the country, some states have confusing and sometimes counterproductive laws for the treatment of juveniles tried for delinquent offenses or crimes. Maryland is one of them.
To that end, what follows is an explanation of just one way that Maryland could improve its juvenile justice system. It is not, however, intended to say that the proposed legislation that the General Assembly is considering is the right answer. It is meant to offer an alternative that might work better for everyone.
In Virginia, where I was a juvenile and domestic relations district court judge, the decision for treating a youth as an adult was left to the juvenile court judge after he or she made a determination of probable cause that the child committed the offense, reviewed a report prepared by the juvenile justice agency on the child's background and court history and heard other evidence that the parties wanted to present.
The judge then decided if the evidence supported the removal of the case to adult court or not. No matter what the decision was, either the commonwealth attorney or the defense attorney could appeal that decision to the Circuit Court for a new hearing by a different judge.
The Virginia process worked well and efficiently, and those cases that were removed to Circuit Court were done with a more complete understanding of what happened and who may have done what. It also allowed the juvenile court judge to detain the youth in a juvenile detention facility where services were available rather than in an adult jail, where he or she should have been held separate from the adult population.
The concern that I have about the Maryland process is that the state's attorney can have limited information about the crime and alleged perpetrator and his or her background. The decision can be made based on public outrage that may not be founded on facts but rather, nowadays, on social media.
I recall cases that I heard that would have met the Maryland standard for trial as an adult that did not, in my opinion, warrant removal to Circuit Court. One involved a youth with no prior court involvement who was handed a gun while riding in a car with four other youth, one of whom was his cousin, who was sitting in the front seat of the car. The defendant was holding the gun when it discharged accidentally and killed his cousin.
In Maryland, given his age, from my understanding of Maryland law, it would have gone to Circuit Court for trial as an adult; and he would have been held in jail rather than a juvenile detention facility.
Another case involved what would have been a school yard fistfight. The commonwealth attorney sought to remove that case involving several youths to Circuit Court. While there was probable cause for the removal of most of them, there was no probable cause as to one and the cause of death was a blow to the back of deceased youth's head when his head hit on some steps after he was hit one time with a fist.
Some of the youth had prior records with the court and so their cases went to Circuit Court for trial as adults while I kept some in juvenile court and found no probable cause as to one youth. Appeals were allowed for all those cases for new determinations by our Circuit Court.
Despite opposition by state's attorneys to a change in the law, I would urge the members of the General Assembly to work to improve the current law by supporting reasonable changes such as the process in Virginia. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the structure and improvement of Maryland's juvenile justice system, emphasizing legal procedures, court processes, and legislative reforms. While not explicitly about public safety, the topic relates to justice system effectiveness, which impacts community safety. 'Local Government' is a close second as it involves state-level legal frameworks, but 'Public Safety' better captures the systemic reforms discussed.

title: Will state lawmakers regulate police drones?
author: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service
content:
Will state lawmakers regulate police drones?

 January 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 1052
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — On an afternoon in mid-January, a Montgomery County police drone tracked a shoplifting suspect as he made his way from a Wheaton CVS to the entrance of a nearby Metro station, where a patrol unit intercepted and arrested him.Police flight records show that the drone, piloted by officers at a command center in Rockville, then returned to its station on a nearby rooftop to await the next 911 call.
The drone is one of four operated by the Montgomery County Department of Police. The year-old drone response program is the first of its kind in Maryland, with drones stationed in Gaithersburg, Silver Spring and Wheaton. The drones have responded to nearly 2,000 calls since the program's launch, often reaching the scene before police officers get there.
"We hear the emergency as you're describing it, and we can just send the drone," said Commander Jason Cokinos, who leads the department's drone program. "We're cheating time."
Reactions to the program are mixed, with some observers enthusiastic about the flexibility it provides and others concerned about the technology's privacy implications. This year, Maryland lawmakers are considering regulating the use of drones for police responses before a more widespread adoption of the technology occurs.
Some Maryland lawmakers worry that current state law doesn't offer clear guidance on how or when law enforcement can use drones as the first or only responders to emergency calls.
The police are operating in a legal gray area, said Del. Robin Grammer Jr., a Republican representing Baltimore County and a member of Maryland's House Judiciary Committee.
"Now, it's reactive enforcement," Grammer said. "You can come back to this moment in time in a year, two years from now, and some jurisdiction's going to be sending out drones proactively. That's not the world I want to live in."
Montgomery County police say they reached out to community members and civil liberties groups to develop rules for their use of drones and the storage of aerial surveillance footage before implementing their program in November 2023.
But it wasn't until this month that the Maryland General Assembly began weighing whether to set state-level rules for more expansive drone programs. House lawmakers summoned police and a spokesperson for the American Civil Liberties Union to Annapolis last Wednesday to review Montgomery County's program.
In that meeting, Cokinos emphasized that his department has taken a narrow approach to aerial surveillance.
"We want to have the least amount of visual intrusion (on) anybody on the ground level that we can," Cokinos told lawmakers.
Police only dispatch the drones in response to emergency calls involving "safety issues," Cokinos said, and they do not send drones to calls without a suspect present. Those can range from assaults in progress to children playing hockey on potentially thin ice, according to the department's flight records.
Pilots do not point the drones' cameras downward nor begin recording until they reach the scene, he added, and the drones do not record audio or use facial recognition technology. Members of the public can view details of drone responses within 24 hours of a deployment.
Cokinos said that the drone's live feeds have helped officers avoid at least one confrontation with an armed suspect. He argued that the use of the drone helped to de-escalate a response that "very well could have resulted in an officer-involved shooting."
While the drones aren't a replacement for police officers, Cokinos said, the department has responded to nearly 300 emergency calls with drones alone since November 2023. If there's no need for a police officer, he said, they don't dispatch one.
More widespread adoption of the technology by law enforcement agencies appears to be just over the horizon.
As the prices of drones fall, other law enforcement agencies across the state will likely be able to launch their own programs for far less than the roughly $773,000 the Montgomery County Department of Police spent last year. The FAA could offer a less costly waiver to fly surveillance drones over large areas, potentially enabling smaller departments to launch their own programs. The Prince George's County Police Department is currently considering whether to launch its own first responder drone program.
But civil libertarians say Maryland lawmakers should get ahead of that trend.
Jay Stanley, a senior policy analyst with the ACLU's Speech, Privacy and Technology Project, warned lawmakers against allowing the use of surveillance drones to proliferate without guardrails.
Law enforcement agencies have used drones in less sophisticated ways for years, Stanley said, but so-called "Drone as First Responder" programs raise a much larger range of privacy and transparency concerns for civil liberties groups.
"When there's a brand new technology that's controversial … government agencies tend to be on their best behavior," Stanley said. But as the technology becomes more ubiquitous and scrutiny subsides, he added, "We could see it expand to routine patrols to cover an entire city."
Stanley also underscored that other law enforcement agencies may not adopt Montgomery County's transparency mechanisms and privacy protections.
"[As] this technology spreads to other counties in Maryland, and perhaps someday all counties in Maryland, are they all going to have these same protections?" he asked.
Even Montgomery County's program, he added, may still evolve in ways lawmakers do not anticipate.
Grammer, the Republican lawmaker, shares Stanley's concerns.
"These marginal benefits — I don't think they outweigh the costs of, frankly, living in a society where the state's surveilling you 24/7 in 10 different ways," Grammer said.
After the Baltimore Police Department launched a controversial aerial surveillance program to capture images of nearly the entire city in 2019, Grammer introduced legislation to require law enforcement to obtain warrants before using aerial surveillance to gather evidence in criminal investigations. Despite reintroducing the bill each year, Grammar hasn't managed to pass it.
Grammer told Capital News Service he approached fellow lawmakers for signatures on the latest iteration of his bill ahead of last Wednesday's hearing.
"I'm talking with people in the committee on both sides of the aisle that are uneasy about how we didn't take this unmanned aerial surveillance (and) put guardrails there," he told CNS.
Though the General Assembly has yet to act on the subject, Stanley says Maryland may actually be ahead of other state legislatures by taking an interest in the Montgomery County program.
"I'm not aware of any other state legislatures that have begun to really think through the questions that the DFR programs bring forth," he said.
So far, legislation has yet to materialize in Maryland's General Assembly. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the use of police drones for public safety operations and the legislative efforts to regulate their deployment. While local government actions are discussed, the core subject revolves around law enforcement technologies and their impact on public safety, making 'Public Safety' the primary topic.

title: Kent ham radio club tests emergency communications skills
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Kent ham radio club tests emergency communications skills

 January 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 557
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WORTON — As wildfire recovery begins in southern California and a lengthy reconstruction effort continues after Hurricane Helene devastated the Appalachian area, emergency preparation is getting attention.In Kent, that conversation and training is happening among amateur radio operators prepared for potential disasters on the Eastern Shore.
Starting at 3 p.m. Saturday, over 24 hours, the Kent Amateur Radio Society club set up satellite and radio equipment in the Kent County High School parking lot. Using emergency power from generators and solar panels, they communicated with 145 stations — 18 were amateur radio satellites.
With a refurbished school bus and a camper, they operated from five stations, classified as mobile, including the emergency trailer EMCOMM 1, which contained equipment from the school's ham radio classes taught by WKHS station manager Chris Singleton, a KARS member for 30 years.
EMCOMM 1 serves as backup when regular emergency dispatch fails.
This was part of the American Radio Relay League's Winter Field Day training exercise. Radio operators set up field operations in remote locations "with the aim to improve their preparedness for disasters, enhancing their operational abilities in adverse conditions."
For KARS members, ham radio is a lifelong passion, but disaster preparation remains the priority.
KARS President Chris Cote cited Hurricane Irma in September 2017, when 7.5 million homes lost electricity. Ham radio could become the only communication mode in such situations.
Inside Cote's bus, three stations operate off a 12-volt battery charging from a solar array — two radio with VHF/UHF capabilities and one satellite communications. They reached operators nationwide without external power all weekend.
The event reached young people when Singleton's KCHS broadcasting students operated the ham radio. Junior, Jordana Capp, in her second year of broadcasting, contacted Washington state over a Russian satellite connection.
Junior, Aidan Maxey, also in his second broadcasting year, made contact with New York. He plans to pursue media studies at Syracuse, impressed with ther program.
Senior, Alayna Brown, featured on Radio World's Jan. 1 cover, contacted Tennessee. Brown, already certified by the Society of Broadcast Engineers, was recently accepted to Belmont in Nashville, where she plans to work with multitrack recording systems, live stage and master tapes.
All three students became interested in ham radio certification after attending the ARRL School Round up on Oct. 21. Brown had communicated with Russia during that event.
Singleton celebrated his students' interest in this vital skill. He had worked for 15 years to engage youth in ham radio, noting that combining broadcasting skills, live audio, music production and SBE certification opens many career paths.
"They are amazed," Singleton said. "They don't get many opportunities to work with this very specialized equipment. It is a rare opportunity."
KARS members continue generating youth interest in ham radio by teaching them radio operating skills and attending the Winter Field Day Contest. They anticipate the ARRL School Club Roundup Contest Feb. 10-14 as well.
On Sunday, as Cote's drone photographed their stations, KARS member Bobby Kelley helped newest member Alberto Larotonda dismantle his homemade antenna built from a ski pole, copper pipes and a drywall mud bucket.
"My little setup just shows anybody can do this with enough imagination," said Larotonda, who joined two months ago.
Cote said while no one wants to think disasters like those in California or North Carolina will strike locally, testing equipment in harsh conditions benefits the county; ensuring first responders that it is battle-tested.
For more information about KARS, visit k3ars.org/kars/. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on emergency communications training by a ham radio club, emphasizing disaster preparedness, backup communication systems, and community resilience. While education aspects are present through student involvement, the primary context aligns with public safety and emergency response protocols.

title: Hoarding turned deadly: Mother takes plea deal in Christmas Day 2023 fire that killed her daughter
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Hoarding turned deadly: Mother takes plea deal in Christmas Day 2023 fire that killed her daughter

 January 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1125
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The mother of a 10-year-old girl who was killed in a townhouse fire near Elkton on Christmas Day 2023 is facing up to 10 years in prison, after accepting a plea deal in a criminal case in which prosecutors maintain that overloaded electrical outlets, hoarding conditions and a lack of smoke detectors contributed to the youngster's death.The defendant — Theresa Ann Moats, 41 — entered an Alford plea to involuntary manslaughter, the most serious charge in the case, on Jan. 24 during a Cecil County Circuit Court hearing.
In an Alford plea, the defendant maintains his or her innocence but, at the same time, he or she does not dispute the incriminating evidence possessed by the state.
Prosecutors agreed to drop 11 related charges against Moats, including reckless endangerment and neglect of a child, as part of the plea agreement reached by Assistant State's Attorney Gavin Patashnick and Moats' lawyers, Assistant Public Defenders Denise Winston and Emily Gillis.
Cecil County Circuit Court Judge William W. Davis Jr. accepted Moats' Alford plea and then, after Patashnick read aloud the prosecution's statement of facts, the judge found her guilty of involuntary manslaughter.
Also part of the plea deal, Davis will wait four months before sentencing Moats, who will remain on house arrest until then on an unsecured $50,000 bond posted in late May after she had spent approximately six weeks in jail on no bond.
Moats' daughter — Kyleigh Nicole Treadway — perished in the swift-moving, two-alarm blaze that started accidentally inside 317 Willow Dr. in the Winding Brook neighborhood, northeast of Elkton, shortly before 7:30 a.m. on Dec. 25, 2023.
Kyleigh, who had been sleeping in a second-floor bedroom, was trapped inside that burning townhouse after her mother, her grandmother, her two older brothers and her mother's boyfriend — Kevin Neal Summerfield, now 41 — had escaped.
As firefighters battled the blaze, Moats alerted Capt. William Ryan of Singerly Volunteer Fire Company that "her baby was right inside the front door." Firefighters tried to rescue Kyleigh, but the "magnitude and intensity of the fire" prevented them from entering the house. Kyleigh's body later was found near the front door.
Including Kyleigh's five surviving family members, the blaze displaced 17 residents in the three adjacent townhouses damaged by the fire.
In March, a Cecil County grand jury handed up indictments against Moats and Summerfield, charging them with involuntary manslaughter and numerous other offenses.
Summerfield's jury trial is set to start and Feb. 3 and is expected to last five days. Before taking the plea deal, Moats had been scheduled to tried along with Summerfield.
During her plea hearing on Friday, Moats stood behind the defense table and wiped tears from her eyes with tissue paper as Patashnick read aloud the prosecution's statement of fact.
The prosecutor reported that an "overload situation" existed in the dwelling's electrical system because multiple extension cords inside an 8'-by-8' first-floor addition at the rear of house had been connected to each other to bypass non-functioning outlets and to reach operational power sources. Court records show that cords were plugged into a power strip.
Along those lines, Patashnick noted that a freezer and refrigerator were plugged into electrical outlets that weren't designed to handle the power demand of such heavy-duty appliances.
One of the power cords drawing electricity from inside of the townhouse snaked out of the dwelling and was connected to a backyard grill, according to the prosecutor, who also reported that some cords ran behind appliances.
Exacerbating the overload situation, strewn clothing, trash and other combustible debris — including a coating of animal feces left by numerous pet dogs and cats — covered the electrical cords in the back room, according to the prosecutor.
Court records show that Moats admitted that as many as 35 pets — mostly dogs and cats — were kept inside the dwelling at one time.
The prosecutor told the judge that "an extensive amount of hoarding conditions" existed inside the 1,100-square-foot, two-story townhouse. He explained that boxes of clothing, bags of trash and other miscellaneous items cluttered the dwelling.
In addition to making it difficult to walk out of the townhouse or anywhere inside of the dwelling, the hoarding conditions worsened an already existing fire hazard created by the improper use of electrical cords and outlets.
The trash, pet feces, clothing and other combustible items "increased the magnitude and intensity of the fire" caused by the electrical overload, according to Patashnick.
Also a factor, the townhouse lacked smoke detectors.
The prosecutor reported that autopsy results indicated that Kyleigh had 0.3 grams of an antidepressant that aids sleep in her system and that her death was attributed to smoke inhalation and burns over 90 percent of her body.
Patashnick summarized that the involuntary manslaughter charge against Moats hinges on her neglect of the townhouse and of Kyleigh.
Court records indicate that two Cecil County Department of Animal Services officers went to 317 Willow Dr. on Dec. 20, 2023 — five days before the fatal fire there — and impounded 14 dogs and four cats that showed signs of neglect and abuse after receiving a complaint.
Officers heard "excessive barking" when they knocked on the door and, once inside the dwelling, they "detected the smell of animal urine and feces" and noticed that a vast majority of the floor was covered in caked animal waste, court records show.
After impounding the 18 animals, officers, "planned to make a report to Child Protective Services, as the children in the home were subjected to poor living conditions," according to court records.
Administrators at Cecil Manor Elementary School in Elk Mills, where Kyleigh was a fourth-grader, also noticed signs of possible neglect and made referrals to the Cecil County Department of Social Services after Kyleigh moved with her family from Delaware and started attending that school, court records show.
Those school officials reported to investigators that Kyleigh's hair and clothes emanated the smell of animal waste and that fellow students avoided the girl because of the pungent odor, according to court records.
The school nurse routinely washed Kyleigh's clothes and washed and brushed the girl's unkempt hair, investigators said. Staff members replaced Kyleigh's backpack twice because cats at her residence urinated and vomited on top of her previous backpacks, investigators added.
"Kyleigh's hygiene issues were described as 'terrible' and they needed to be addressed 3-4 times per day. Kyleigh stated to teachers that she had a 'ton' of pets and that she loved them," court records show.
School staff attempted to contact Moats by email and by phone, but there was "absolutely no involvement to address concern brought forth by the school," according to court records.
Court records also indicate that, in the wake of townhouse fire, Moats told investigators that "this all could have been preventable," and that she "felt bad and felt it was her fault."
In addition, according to those court records, Moats told investigators that she missed Kyleigh. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a fire caused by unsafe living conditions, electrical hazards, and neglect, leading to a child's death. This directly relates to public safety concerns involving fire prevention, housing standards, and community safety. While health neglect is mentioned, the primary context is the safety failure that led to the tragedy.

title: Caroline Police Accountability Board offers 2024 annual report
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline Police Accountability Board offers 2024 annual report

 January 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 244
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline County Police Accountability Board wrapped up an eventful year, presenting its finalized annual report for 2024 with the county commissioners on Tuesday.The board offered insight into complaints it received throughout last year, as well as grant information for 2025.
According to the annual report, the Police Accountability Board has received nine total complaints since Jan. 1, 2024.
The report said 25,275 calls for service came to Caroline County Sheriffs office, and six citizen complaints were received for the Sheriff's Office.
The nine complaints came from Federalsburg, Ridgley, Greensboro and Denton. According to the report, "the complaint topics alleged an officer's rude and discourteous behavior, a police chase, use of force, conduct unbecoming, and sexual assault."
Eight of nine complaints were closed and exonerated, with one complaint not being investigated by the Police Accountability Board because it involved a police chief, thus it was beyond the board's purview.
The county secured another Police Accountability, Community, and Transparency grant from the state to cover expenses for 2025. Costs covered by the $153,597 grant include expenses, citizen training, payroll for the board members and attorney fees.
In addition, the fund will go toward body cameras for officers, LAPro software renewal and Lexipol and Police One academy software.
"Thank you for your service on the board," Commission President Travis Breeding said. "I know at times its a thankless job, and we really appreciate the time you and your members from the ACC (Administrative Charging Committee) and the PAB put in." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Sandy Hill Elementary told to stay in place Thursday

 CAMBRIDGE — Students and staff at Sandy Hill Elementary School were told to stay in place Thursday after the school received a threat via email.Chris Dayton, executive assistant to the Dorchester County Public Schools superintendent, said Thursday afternoon that the stay in place order had been lifted after the school put it into affect in the early afternoon. She said it was put into effect for precautionary reasons after the school received an email threat that someone would shoot up the school.
Stay in place means that classes continue, but no one is allowed in or out of the school.

title: 'Heartbroken': Delaware figure skaters, coach among those killed in D.C. plane, Black Hawk crash
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
'Heartbroken': Delaware figure skaters, coach among those killed in D.C. plane, Black Hawk crash

 January 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 874
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A coach and two young figure skaters with ties to the University of Delaware were among the victims of the plane crash in Washington, D.C., Wednesday evening, UD officials confirmed."Our hearts go out to the families and friends of all of the victims of this horrific tragedy," UD president Dennis Assanis said in a statement.
One of the victims was identified as Alexandr "Sasha" Kirsanov, 46, a coach affiliated with UD's High Performance Training Center.
Also killed were Sean Kay and Angela Yang, who were young members of the UD Figure Skating Club.
"Kirsanov and the skaters trained at the University's High Performance Training Center, which uses UD ice rink facilities and has been the training home for many years of multiple world-class skating champions and competitors," Assanis said in a statement. "The figure skating community is tight-knit, and many of our students and coaches have trained and competed alongside those who were lost."
UD Athletic Director Chrissi Rawak said Kirsanov's "presence was felt deeply in our ice arenas."
"His dedication — and that of his skaters — forged meaningful connections throughout the UD family," Rawak said. "Coach Kirsanov's passion and commitment touched many lives, leaving a permanent mark on our campus."
Born in Russia, Kirsanov competed internationally in figure skating. After retiring, he became a national and international coach.
His wife, Natalya Gudin, who is also a skating coach, told ABC News that her husband was accompanying Kay and Yang on the trip while she stayed home with the other skaters.
"I lost everything," Gudin told ABC News. "I lost my husband, I lost my students, I lost my friends."
Kay and Yang were partners in pairs skating and in November, they won first place at a U.S. Figure Skating competition in Texas.
They were in Wichita, Kansas, this week to attend a national development camp held in conjunction with the U.S. Figure Skating Championships.
"It was a lot of fun watching all the skaters at Kansas," Yang wrote on Instagram, three days before the fatal plane crash. "I had a lot of fun sitting with my friends watching amazing skaters! I wish I could watch it all over again!"
The UD skaters were among at least 14 members of the national skating community who were returning from Wichita when the plane crashed. Several were from the Skating Club of Boston and other clubs on the East Coast.
"We are heartbroken to learn that figure skaters, along with their families, friends and coaches, are understood to be among those on board. Our thoughts are with everyone affected by this tragedy," U.S. Figure Skating said in a statement.
The crash happened late Wednesday when an American Airlines plane collided with a military helicopter while landing at Ronald Reagan National Airport near Washington, officials said. The plane carried 60 passengers and four crew. Three soldiers were aboard the helicopter.
There were no survivors.
"We are now at the point where we are switching from a rescue operation to a recovery operation," said John Donnelly, the fire chief in the nation's capital.
The plane was found upside-down in three sections in waist-deep water, and first responders were searching an area of the Potomac as far south as the Woodrow Wilson Bridge, roughly 3 miles south of the airport, Donnelly said. The helicopter wreckage was also found. Images from the river showed boats around the partly submerged wing and the mangled wreckage of the plane's fuselage.
The collision is the deadliest U.S. air crash since 2001.
There was no immediate word on the cause of the collision, but officials said flight conditions were clear as the jet arrived from Wichita, Kansas, with U.S. and Russian figure skaters and others aboard.
"On final approach into Reagan National, it collided with a military aircraft on an otherwise normal approach," American Airlines CEO Robert Isom said.
A top Army aviation official said the Black Hawk crew was "very experienced" and familiar with the congested flying that occurs daily around Washington.
"Both pilots had flown this specific route before, at night. This wasn't something new to either one of them," said Jonathan Koziol, chief of staff for Army aviation. "Even the crew chief in the back has been in the unit for a very long time, very familiar with the area, very familiar with the routing structure."
Delaware Gov. Matt Meyer called for a full investigation into the crash.
"Here in Delaware, we're mourning the loss of former University of Delaware Figure Skating coach Sasha Kirsanov, as well as two youth skaters and their family members who were aboard AA5342," Meyer said. "Lauren's and my thoughts are with the families today as they grapple with this new reality, and we encourage all Delawareans to keep them in your prayers."
Sen. Chris Coons also issued a statement of condolences.
"I'm devastated to hear the news that at least three Delawareans died during last night's air collision," Coons said. "Sasha Kirsanov, Sean Kay, and Angela Yang went to Wichita to pursue their passion for figure skating. It is a tragedy that none of them returned home to our state. Delaware is a state of neighbors, and tonight we hold all of our neighbors a little closer. My heart goes out to Sasha's wife Natalia, the University of Delaware Figure Skating Club, and every other Delawarean touched by the three of them."
This article contains information from the Associated Press. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a major aviation accident involving a plane and helicopter collision, resulting in multiple fatalities. While the victims include figure skaters (sports connection), the core focus is on the safety incident, its investigation, and impact on communities, aligning most directly with 'Public Safety.' 'National News' is a secondary fit due to the event's scale, but the tragedy's nature as a safety crisis is primary.

title: Cambridge sees reduction in crime in 2024 compared to previous year
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge sees reduction in crime in 2024 compared to previous year

 January 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 529
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The City of Cambridge saw a 14% reduction in crime in 2024.While presenting the Cambridge Police Department's 2024 year end report to the Cambridge City Council on Jan. 27, Police Chief Justin Todd called this accomplishment the "big one."
He said the department achieved many accomplishments in 2024.
"I have a lot of people to thank for that," he said. "Not only my officers and the staff, but also the city staff and the commissioners." Todd said it wouldn't have been possible without funding and the "numerous resources" the department was provided.
Along with reducing crime overall, Todd mentioned increasing the number of cameras around the city, creating better working relationships with the Dorchester County Board of Education and the Department of Juvenile Services and reaching a clearance rate of 69.6% in the department's Criminal Investigations Division.
Todd said the average clearance rate, which is the rate of crimes that are solved, is around 28% nationally. "So that just shows you what a good job they are doing," Todd said.
Todd also talked about the department's efforts to map crimes by where and when they occur. He said that informs how the department spends its time patrolling.
"We make sure that officers are in those areas as much as possible during that time," he said.
Todd listed the department's continued commitment to community-oriented policing as an accomplishment.
"These things, patrolling with purpose and community-oriented policing, will continue as we charge harder to fine-tune it and make it better," he said.
When it comes to specific crime stats for 2024, there were 30 aggravated assaults reported. Todd pointed out the "significant difference" from 2022 when there were 110 aggravated assaults reported in Cambridge. Compared to 2023, there was a 53% reduction in aggravated assaults in Cambridge in 2024.
According to the report, compared to 2023, burglaries and simple assaults were down 12% and 16%, respectively, in 2024.
Todd said that like 2023, there were two homicides in Cambridge in 2024. This number is a decrease from seven homicides in 2022.
Todd said one of the homicides in Cambridge this year was the result of gun violence and the other was a kidnapping in Easton that law enforcement officials believe resulted in a homicide in Cambridge.
The number of robberies as well as the number of rapes and sex offenses each increased by 12% in 2024 compared to the previous year. Todd said some of those rape and sex offenses investigations are still open.
RECRUITMENT AND RETENTIONDuring his presentation to the City Council, Todd also talked about the city's efforts to recruit and keep a full staff, which will continue into 2025.
"We're going to recruit, recruit, recruit good quality people that want to invest in the City of Cambridge and be here," he said.
Todd said the city has 36 sworn officers, including a civilian liaison officer. He said they were ready to put three people in the police academy but one didn't make the final interview and the other two determined it wasn't a good fit.
"So we're back at the drawing boards," he said.
Todd said the department has seven civilian employees.
"That has been significant in helping us do our daily work and customer service as we continue to move along," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on crime statistics, police department achievements, and community safety efforts in Cambridge, directly relating to Public Safety. While Local Government is tangentially relevant due to city council involvement, the core subject is crime reduction and public safety initiatives.

title: Two men sentenced for March incident on Howell Point Road in Trappe
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Two men sentenced for March incident on Howell Point Road in Trappe

 January 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 249
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Both men who were arrested and charged for an incident that took place on Howell Point Road in Trappe on March 23, 2024, have been sentenced.After entering an Alford plea on Oct. 11 for kidnapping and use of a firearm in a felony or violent crime, Yahjay Greene, 22, of Easton, was sentenced to a total of 25 years with 18 of those years suspended. Greene will also have to serve 18 months of supervised probation.
Flamond Woolford Jr., 19, of Cambridge, was sentenced to a total of seven years with three of those years suspended after pleading guilty on Dec. 11 to home invasion and possession of a handgun in a vehicle. Woolford will have to serve two years of supervised probation.
The charges stemmed from an incident that led to residents south of Trappe sheltering in place while police searched for four people suspected of firing gunshots.
Talbot County deputies responding to the shots fired call on March 23, 2024, found a lone subject walking on Howell Point Road. The individual reported being forced into the vehicle in an apparent armed robbery attempt.
As deputies and troopers spoke with the individual, a vehicle approached, stopped and put the car in reverse, attempting to flee when a deputy ordered the occupants to show their hands. The car drove into a ditch, and four people got out and fled into the surrounding woods, according to a report from the sheriff's office.
Both Greene and Woolford were later charged in the incident.

title: For All Seasons gives update on human trafficking in Talbot County
author: Konner Metz
content:
For All Seasons gives update on human trafficking in Talbot County

 January 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 421
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Representatives from For All Seasons say the problem of human trafficking in Talbot County is persisting, though they are seeing positive gains in awareness and detection.During a Talbot County Council meeting Tuesday, Lauren Weber, the nonprofit's vice president of strategy and development, provided an update to council members regarding human and labor trafficking.
"It is happening and it's happening here. That continues to be the case," Weber said. " … There's a complexity to human trafficking that it doesn't really know county boundaries."
Weber and Katie Theeke, vice president of marketing and communications, each said the organization has a special role given its wide reach. For All Seasons' presence in the five Mid-Shore counties — Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot — is critical to providing victims with essential services.
"We know that human trafficking knows no boundaries and that it affects people of different backgrounds, races, genders," Theeke said. "We have seen several cases come through our doors, and it comes from Talbot County. It comes from neighboring counties. We really aim to be the connector to get those people the help that they need."
Council Member Keasha Haythe asked if For All Seasons is seeing a decline in human trafficking numbers. Weber said it's a "double-edged sword."
"A year ago we sat in front of you and said, when we look at our rape crisis center data, a good fifth of what was coming in was having at least one indicator of human trafficking," Weber said. " … That persists."
The organization has noticed a shift in how many people are recognizing signs of human trafficking and making those reports, Weber says.
"The folks that are self-referring, we're seeing a decline," she said. "But we're seeing a real rapid incline in folks coming to us and saying, 'Hey, I know more and now I've seen something.'"
Weber said that since September, more than 120 people have taken For All Seasons' free, online anti-human trafficking course.
For All Seasons is an official regional navigator for the Mid-Shore area, Theeke said, meaning it works on task forces and serves youth and young adults that are victims of trafficking.
At the end of the discussion, council members thanked the For All Seasons representatives for their work and presented the organization with a proclamation Tuesday declaring January as National Human Trafficking Awareness Month.
"We know that even one victim is too many," council Vice President Pete Lesher said. "We appreciate all that you do both on prevention, but also to develop and take care of those who have been victims." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on human trafficking, a critical public safety issue, and details updates from a nonprofit organization presented to a local government body. While the context involves Local Government (county council meeting), the core subject is human trafficking, which directly aligns with Public Safety. title: Organizations on the Shore hosts count of people experiencing homelessness
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Organizations on the Shore hosts count of people experiencing homelessness

 January 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 599
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — From Queen Anne's County to Dorchester County many churches, libraries and senior centers assisted as various organizations hosted a point-in-time, a count of all experiencing unsheltered and sheltered homelessness.In Caroline County alone, approximately 142 people were reported to be in attendance on Wednesday. Jimmy Morris, continuum of care housing specialist for Mid-Shore Behavioral Health, said the count in Dorchester County recorded its highest ever number of people experiencing homelessness. Finalized numbers for the Mid-Shore will not be available for several weeks.
Morris said large efforts were made to reach this specific population, from media outreach to visiting encampments. He said this larger effort was made due to the growing population of homelessness on the Shore.
Over the last few years, the population of people experiencing homelessness has skyrocketed on the Eastern Shore, and organizations focused on assisting this population are working to have a proper count in order to better secure funds to provide resources.
Ashley Kessinger, continuum care manager at Mid-Shore Behavioral Health, said this winter the organization's shelters were filled with people trying to stay warm.
"It's been a crisis," Kessinger said. "Our shelters are completely full, and they stay full all the time. They're all working off of waitlists. They're all trying to find other ways so that people that come to them, don't have to turn them away. But they're just full and we don't have enough."
According to Kessinger, the results of the data gathered by each jurisdiction will be submitted to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development and can be used to secure grant funding.
Yvette Robinson, grant manager at Neighborhood Service Center, was distributing information at the Fredrick Douglas room of the Talbot County Free Library in Easton, one of the locations for the county Wednesday. Robinson said homelessness on the Eastern Shore looks different in comparison to homelessness in major cities. One of those contributing factors, she said, is resources.
"The numbers are growing, the resources are not," Robinson said. "We rely on community partners to try to collaborate so that we can see what's working, what may not be working …we're just trying to get the information out that there are variable resources."
According to Robinson, since Nov. 24, 2024, Neighborhood Service Center has given out 9,000 pounds of food and served over 600 families, a majority of which were homeless.
Kessinger said a contributing factor to the growing homeless population has been a lack of affordable housing on the shore. Many of the people served at Mid-Shore Behavioral Health either have no income or they receive funds from Social Security which can be about $900 a month.
A lack of affordable housing has made the issue worse but it is the mark of homelessness that will make it difficult to get landlords to consider working on affordable housing alternatives.
In her experience, there are some landlords that refuse to help customers that her organization works with because the customers have experienced homelessness. Kessinger said there is an assumption that the customers will be bad tenants or bad people in general.
For Kessinger, everyone deserves help and people shouldn't treat those experiencing homelessness differently because of their circumstance because it can happen to anyone at any time.
"People think homelessness looks a certain way and we have seen people from all walks of life and it does not look a certain way," Kessinger said. "There's a lot of stigma on the shore about homelessness and some people just don't want to see it. If they come across an encampment or something like that, they just want it to go away. …everyone deserves a chance to have a home." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on efforts to count and address homelessness in local communities, involving organizations, shelters, and resource allocation. While not explicitly about safety, homelessness intersects with public safety concerns like community well-being, resource distribution, and social stability. 'Local Government' is a secondary fit due to local initiatives, but 'Public Safety' better captures the broader societal impact and crisis management aspects.

title: Sheriff affirms federal immigration enforcement partnership

content:
Sheriff affirms federal immigration enforcement partnership

 February 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Words

 The Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office will continue cooperating with federal immigration authorities while maintaining fair treatment of all individuals, Sheriff Gary Hofmann said Wednesday."I have zero tolerance for crime within our community," Hofmann said. "Regardless of immigration status, if the offender is in violation of any state, local, or federal law, we will assist any partner in the apprehension."
The statement comes amid nationwide immigration enforcement operations by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).
Hofmann emphasized his department's ongoing collaboration with law enforcement at all levels.

The sheriff stressed that his office remains committed to equitable treatment during enforcement actions.
"Our office will always treat every person with dignity and respect during the process and will ensure that this process is fair and consistent with any person we may detain or arrest," Hofmann said.

title: Maryland man gets 8 years in crossbow killing of girlfriend
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Maryland man gets 8 years in crossbow killing of girlfriend

 February 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 790
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A man who fatally shot his live-in girlfriend with a crossbow arrow inside their Conowingo residence — maintaining that it was an accident — received an eight-year sentence on Tuesday, after a jury had convicted him of involuntary manslaughter but acquitted him of murder and assault two months earlier.Cecil County Circuit Court Administrative Judge Brenda A. Sexton imposed the eight-year sentence on 41-year-old Jeffrey Allen Lander, who also had been found guilty of reckless endangerment. At sentencing, however, that lesser charge merged into Lander's conviction for involuntary manslaughter, which carries a maximum 10-year penalty.
The victim — Judy Elizabeth Gee, 45 — was shot through the back inside the couple's residence in the 700 block of Bell Manor Road at approximately 4:40 p.m. on Jan. 14, 2024, causing heavy internal bleeding. An ambulance crew transported Gee to Lancaster General Hospital in Lancaster, Pa., where she died on an operating table at 7:13 p.m., about two and half hours later.
Sexton remarked from the bench Tuesday that Lander's "conduct was heinous," and she agreed with Assistant State's Attorney Robert Sentman's assessment that Lander exhibited a "lack of remorse or acceptance of responsibility for Gee's death," prosecutors summarized.
Sentman, who prosecuted Lander at trial, recommended a maximum 10-year sentence — exceeding state sentencing guidelines that set a penalty range of three to eight years of active incarceration for Lander. Those guidelines are based on a defendant's criminal record, the seriousness of the offense and other factors.
Lander's lawyer, Assistant Public Defender Jason Ricke, requested a sentence at the lower end of state sentencing guidelines.
Landers will serve his eight-year term in a Maryland Department of Corrections prison, and he received credit for approximately seven months that he spent in jail after his June arrest.
In November, at the conclusion of a three-day-long trial, jurors deliberated for approximately four hours before finding Lander guilty of involuntary manslaughter and reckless endangerment.
Involuntary manslaughter applies when the defendant unintentionally kills someone while acting with gross negligence, meaning the defendant should have known the risk of his or her actions. Other elements also can apply under the statute.
The jury, however, acquitted Lander of second-degree murder, first-degree assault and second-degree assault — criminal offenses that involve an intentional act, to varied degrees. Second-degree murder is punishable by up to 40 years in prison. First-degree assault and second-degree assault carry maximum sentences of 25 years and 10 years respectively.
At trial, Sentman maintained that Lander intentionally shot Gee because, during an argument moments earlier, Gee had informed Lander that she was ending their two-year relationship and that she was leaving him.
Aside from Gee, Lander was the only person present when the fatal shooting occurred — and he provided the narrative of the incident to investigators.
While police and paramedics were at the shooting scene, Gee was seated on a couch, with the arrow protruding out the entrance and exit wounds on her upper torso. She was barely conscious and was not alert. Gee wasn't capable of giving investigators her account of the incident.
The day of the fatal shooting started for Lander at about 4 p.m., with Gee jolting him awake and starting an argument with him. "She was kicking me in the knee. It was a rude awakening. I woke up angry," Lander told investigators.
Lander volunteered all of that information to investigators at the outset, after he had called 911. But in a police interview about two months later, Lander denied that he and Gee had been arguing directly before the fatal shooting.
The defense contended that Lander accidentally shot Gee with the arrow when he tripped over a cat seconds after removing his loaded crossbow from a wall rack in the living room while she was seated on a nearby couch, possibly leaning toward an end table to retrieve something.
Lander, who elected not to testify on his own behalf, told investigators that he thought the crossbow's safety was engaged and that he always stored his crossbow locked and loaded during hunting season.
In addition, Lander told investigators that he was preparing to go deer hunting that late afternoon, noting that there was about one hour of daylight left. Lander also told investigators that he liked going into the woods to decompress after confrontations with Gee.
Cecil County Sheriff's Office detectives testified that they believe Lander shot Gee in the "heat of the moment" amid the argument and that he immediately experienced regret and emotional aguish, prompting him to call 911.
Ricke, however, categorized the deadly shooting this way when addressing the jury in his opening statement: "It was a tragic accident — nothing more. It is not a murder. It is not a crime."
Police arrested and charged Lander on June 28, six months after the incident, at the conclusion of an investigation that included consulting with a crossbow expert.

title: Cleanup launched at former homeless camp in Maryland woods near I-95
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Cleanup launched at former homeless camp in Maryland woods near I-95

 February 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 594
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Nearly 30 contracted workers wearing hazmat suits and protective masks and gloves spent about 30 hours collecting garbage left at a former homeless encampment in the woods adjacent to the North East Station Shopping Center, marking the latest step in restricting the property.The cleanup started on Monday morning (Feb. 3) and continued through Thursday, with contractors filling scores of industrial-sized garbage bags by the end of each 7-hour workday. In addition to bottles, cans and other trash, workers gathered the remnants of campsites, including worn blankets, pillows and so forth. Numerous syringes reportedly were found while clearing the area.
Baltimore-based real estate developer Klein Enterprises, which acquired the 87,006-square-foot North East Station Shopping Center for $11.6 million in 2017, also owns approximately 40 acres of adjacent woods, and that company is paying for the cleanup of the homeless encampment that once occupied that area.
Problems associated with the homeless people living in those woods grew over time as the number of campers increased, according to North East Police Chief Stephen Yates, who noted that an NEPD patrol officer checked the area at the start of the cleanup project Monday morning to make sure that no homeless people were on the property.
"Drug overdoses were occurring more and more in those woods and so were medical emergencies in general. And it is not an easy area for paramedics and police officers to access," Yates said, before remarking, "The concern was for everyone's safety."
The police chief also reported that trash created by the homeless people started accumulating in the woods and that the number of complaints regarding malicious destruction of property and vandalism also increased, as the number of campsites grew.
In addition, according to Yates, his agency frequently received complaints about homeless people panhandling outside stores in the North East Station Shopping Center and disturbing patrons in other ways.
The situation reached its boiling point about a year ago, when garbage, rocks and other debris that the homeless people had dropped into an opening after removing a manhole cover clogged a sewer pipe — causing backed-up sewage to spill into the creek.
It reportedly cost Klein Enterprises thousands of dollars to repair the damaged pipe.
But much worse, the seeped sewage triggered a Maryland Department of Environment investigation. Because the environmental incident occurred on property owned by Klein Enterprises, the MDE levied an "astronomical fine" on the company, according to Yates.
And that was the catalyst for Klein Enterprises taking proper measures to get rid of the homeless people in the woods, Yates said.
Following eviction procedures, the company first posted "no trespassing" signs in and around the woods and then gave people in that makeshift homeless community notice that they must vacate the property within at least two months, Yates added, noting that circumstances later pushed that deadline back.
After the homeless people were gone, Klein Enterprises was free to embark on the next phase — cleanup of the former campground. Contractors started removing the garbage left behind by the banished homeless people on Monday morning and, as of late Thursday afternoon, it wasn't clear when the cleanup project will end.
Once the cleanup is completed, Klein Enterprises will erect a high fence around that entire wooded area, in an effort to keep people from entering the property, Yates said. It also will install security cameras in and around that wooded area, he added.
The Cecil Whig reached Klein Enterprises representatives Thursday and asked for more specific information for this story, including the sum of the MDE fine and the cost of the cleanup. As of deadline, however, the Whig had not received that information. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 6 to 8 inches of snow expected in Tuesday evening winter storm
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
6 to 8 inches of snow expected in Tuesday evening winter storm

 February 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 309
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The National Weather Service have declared a winter storm warning in Easton and other Mid-Shore towns from Tuesday at 1 p.m. to Wednesday at 7 a.m.The weather service expects Easton and Cambridge to get about six to eight inches of snow.
After the snow, temperatures are expected to rise into the 40s, with a wintry snow and rain mix until 4 p.m. and rain lasting until Wednesday evening.
Due to the incoming snow Talbot, Caroline and Dorchester counties have taken precautions to prepare roadways and winter weather crews.
Talbot County Emergency Services started planning with the National Weather services on Sunday.
"We also know that our local roads department, as well as our state highway partners, are working on pre-treating the roads now and then," Geneva Schaffle, Emergency Management Division chief for Talbot County, said. "We'll have crews working to clear the roads tomorrow through Wednesday."
Talbot County will be sharing alerts through Facebook and its alerts system.
Caroline County Emergency Services said it would have a meeting Monday to discuss its plans for the snow with the state and the National Weather Service.
County emergency officials encourages motorists to stay off the roads for all unessential travel Tuesday night and Wednesday morning while crews work to combat wintery conditions.
Dorchester County Emergency Services could not be reached for comment Monday.
Talbot County Public Schools will be operating on a half day early dismissal schedule on Tuesday, with students leaving campus at noon.
In case the winter storm weather leaks into Wednesday, Talbot County Public schools sent home devices with students on Monday to conduct a virtual learning day on Wednesday if needed.
Caroline and Dorchester County Public Schools will also be operating on half day early dismissal schedules Tuesday. Students in these districts will also return home at noon.
If any changes are made, the districts will update students and parents via social media and county websites.

title: "These allegations are despicable': In wake of crematorium scandal, morticians resign, board being reviewed
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
"These allegations are despicable': In wake of crematorium scandal, morticians resign, board being reviewed

 February 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 676
 Words 

 Read News Document

 After a scathing report about a White Plains crematorium began circulating in late January, the Maryland State Board of Morticians had several key figures resign after complaints arose of their inaction over the last several years.Brandon Wylie, Michele Kutta and Patrick Thompson, executive members and officers of the board, all resigned under pressure from Gov. Wes Moore (D).
Soon after their resignation, they were promptly removed from the Maryland Department of Health's website.
Heaven Bound Cremation Services LLC — located in a White Plains building with beauty salons, a pharmacy and a restaurant — had its license suspended last month after it was determined that "the public health, safety or welfare imperatively requires emergency action," the Maryland State Board of Morticians' report said.
Rosa and Brandon Williams, the two operators of the crematorium, were already on probation by the board for prior disciplinary action before the most recent report due to improper storage of human remains.
An August 2019 final order said that Rosa Williams had violated several statutory and regulatory provisions by "commingling cremains, disposing of cremated remains in a receptacle with bio-hazard waste, otherwise improperly storing cremated remains, and failing to send cremated remains to the agent of the decedent."
In January 2021, it was determined that Williams had failed to comply with the order, which set another two-year probationary term on her.
Then, in March last year, the Maryland State Board of Morticians' investigator conducted an inspection that revealed "human bodies in cardboard boxes stacked on top of each other with no support between the boxes, human bodies in ripped body bags with arms and legs hanging out of the body bags, human remains that were not being stored at temperatures below 40 degrees Fahrenheit and blood on the refrigeration unit and bodily fluids on the floor."
By January this year, not much had changed, according to the report.
It was determined that the cremation chamber was not operational and human bodies were "accumulating rather than being cremated in a timely manner."
Also found last month, the door to a refrigeration unit was blocked by an accumulation of boxes with bodies, dried blood and fluids were on the floors, bodies were stored in damaged bags, 18 bodies were stored in temperatures not below 40 degrees, "three visibly decomposing bodies," and one decomposing body that had been in the facility since the March 2024 inspection.
Moore commented on the report, saying, "Firstly, these allegations are despicable, and those responsible need to be held accountable. I know the board is independent, but they have failed these families and I share in their outrage, and I stand with them in demanding justice. There is an active investigation into this matter, and these families deserve better."
Soon after, he announced a review of the board.
Moore asked attorney Charles P. Scheeler to lead the review, which will involve a thorough assessment of the board's structure and operations and whether changes to law or regulations are warranted. Scheeler previously served as a federal prosecutor in the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of Maryland.
"The operational review of Maryland's health professional licensing boards is an important step in ensuring these entities are effectively fulfilling their responsibilities," said Del. Joseline Peña-Melnyk (D-Anne Arundel, Prince George's), who is the chair of the Health Government and Operations Committee. "Given their critical role in safeguarding public health and maintaining professional standards, it is essential that we fully understand any challenges they may be facing. I appreciate the administration's efforts in undertaking this review."
Southern Maryland News visited various businesses in the building, with multiple employees having no idea what was occurring right behind them. Most businesses within the building are front-facing, toward Crain Highway; the crematorium is in the back of the facility.
The Charles County Department of Health issued an abatement order to the crematorium, while the Maryland Department of Health condemned "in the strongest terms" the mistreatment of human remains.
Anyone who may have questions or need guidance regarding concerns for the remains of a loved one can contact the Maryland Department of Health Board of Morticians and Funeral Directors. Visit health.maryland.gov/bom/Pages/home.aspx for contact information. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a crematorium scandal involving systemic failures in handling human remains, leading to public health risks and government investigations. While 'Health' is related, the core issue revolves around public safety concerns, regulatory oversight, and government accountability, making 'Public Safety' the most precise category.

title: Bill could improve police awareness of unseen disabilities
author: SOfIA APPOLONIO Capital News Service
content:
Bill could improve police awareness of unseen disabilities

 February 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SOfIA APPOLONIO Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 466
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Lawmakers are considering a bill that would make it easier for first responders in Maryland to know when they're dealing with a person who has invisible disabilities.The measure would allow Maryland residents to request a notation on their driver's license or state ID card that identifies their unseen disability, such as autism or hearing impairment.
If adopted, the bill would mandate training for law enforcement on how to improve interactions with people who have hidden disabilities. It would also require the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration to work on awareness programs.
The changes are meant to help protect people with invisible disabilities during encounters with first responders — a special concern for parents of Black children who may be at higher risk during conflict with police.
"The reality of these encounters presents differently when your Black son transitions to adulthood and becomes a legally independent Black man," said bill co-sponsor Del. Kym Taylor, a Democrat representing Prince George's County, who said her son has a hidden disability. "There are no visible signs nor immediate indicators to help first responders understand potential reactions."
The bill, known as Eric's ID Law, is named for Maryland native Eric Blessed Carpenter Grantham, 20, a Black man who lives with autism.
Following the 2020 death of George Floyd — a Black man who died at the hands of Minneapolis police officers — Grantham and his mother Linda worried about Grantham potentially encountering police and failing to respond as expected because of his disability. The two met with Sen. William Smith Jr., a Democrat representing Montgomery County, Senate sponsor of the bill.
Grantham says that he designed special logos that easily identify hidden disabilities to law enforcement.
"Eric's ID Law was created to help save lives for people who cannot use their own voice," he said.
Prince George's County Sheriff John Carr said he supports the proposal, adding that increased resources to aid people with invisible disabilities during encounters with law enforcement are a "must."
"From a law enforcement perspective, we want you to know that we are here to serve you and we want this bill to pass," Carr said. "Any time that we're able to put a citizen at ease during a traffic stop, that is something that helps us interact and keep our community safe."
Similar initiatives exist in Maryland already, such as the MVA "blue card" that people can present to identify their disability. Additionally, the Ethan Saylor Alliance was established in 2015 to "provide increased training for law enforcement and other public service entities" to address situations with people with invisible disabilities.
Its formation follows the death of Saylor, a 26-year-old man with Down syndrome, following a police altercation at a Frederick movie theatre.
The passage of this law would mean Maryland joins 11 other states allowing people with disabilities to identify themselves on their identification cards. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton man pleads guilty to distributing child pornography
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Easton man pleads guilty to distributing child pornography

 February 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 303
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An Easton man pleaded guilty Wednesday to six counts of promoting and distributing child pornography.Darian Braun, 23, said he made the decision to plead guilty because he is guilty and it was in his best interest.
During the plea hearing, Talbot County Deputy State's Attorney Chelsea Endzel said said that in June of 2024, the Easton Police Department got a cyber tip from the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children about a person possessing child sexual abuse material. She said that through investigation, the person was identified as Braun.
Endzel described the content of the videos Braun pleaded guilty to distributing, which all included underage girls. Endzel said that when police executed a search and seizure warrant at Braun's residence, Braun told police that he knew he messed up.
After Endzel detailed the case, Braun's attorney Holland Brownley, who is with the Talbot County Public Defender's Office, said she had no additions or corrections to Endzel's summary.
Before entering into a plea agreement with the state, Braun had received 34 charges. Seventeen of those charges were for promoting and distributing child pornography, and the other 17 charges were for possessing child pornography.
As a part of the plea agreement, the state will enter nolle prosequi for the remaining 28 charges Braun did not plead guilty to, meaning the state will not prosecute for those charges.
The six counts Braun pleaded guilty to each carry a maximum sentence of 10 years and a maximum fine of $25,000.
Braun was not sentenced during the plea hearing, and a sentence hearing date has not yet been set.
The state recommends Braun receive a sentence of 25 years with all but six of those years suspended. The state also recommends Braun serve five years of supervised probation and be added to the sex offender registry as a tier II sex offender.

title: Greensboro Police Department adds Stg. Jeff Adams to staff
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Greensboro Police Department adds Stg. Jeff Adams to staff

 February 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 423
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — The Town of Greensboro announced on Feb. 12 that its police department hired Sgt. Jeff Adams as its newest member, ending a long stretch during which Police Chief Lenox Trams was the town's sole officer."Sgt. Adams brings 18 years of law enforcement experience and officially started on February 11," The Town of Greensboro said in a Facebook post. "He's currently completing his 80-hour FTO training, and we can't wait for you to meet him."
Trams has been the lone officer at Greensboro Police Department since September of 2024, and he is pleased to bring Adams on board.
"I've been there since March of 2023, and I've been trying to recruit only the highest best qualified officers, and it's been a struggle," Trams said. "So when I was down to myself I didn't give up, I kept recruiting and I actually had the applicant who kind of met our standards, so he applied, and then he went through the hiring process and a very extensive background investigation, and I just hired him."
Adams' 18 years of law enforcement experience was one of these reasons Trams hired him, the police chief said, but also Adams' 18 years of loyalty.
"Sergeant Adams has been at one agency for 18 years and that track record to me says a lot," Trams said. "He's very loyal to the agency, and he just doesn't bounce around. We also look at like other factors of his application, but I think off the face, just having him be loyal to his one agency for 18 years says a lot."
In September 2024, the town of Greensboro considered closing the police department because the public safety demands were too much for one officer to handle. The Caroline County Sheriff's Office would have taken over the policing duties for the town.
Trams believes with this hire the conversations of dissolving the police department have been "tabled." He hopes to continue to grow the staff at the Greensboro Police Department.
When Trams was by himself, Greensboro moved its offices into the police department's building, with the town's town hall experiencing maintenance concerns. But now there will be talks of moving the police department to another office since the plan will be to continue to grow the department, Trams said.
"I was by myself, so that was the best move at the time," Trams said. "But now that I'm going to build up the agency and hire quality officers, we all can't be in the same building, so there is some talking about putting the police department in another building."
