title: Multiple crashes at Easton intersection lead to resident concerns
author: Konner Metz
content:
Multiple crashes at Easton intersection lead to resident concerns

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 630
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A recent string of crashes at the intersection of Brookletts Avenue and South Aurora Street have ignited resident calls for traffic and safety improvements.Monday morning, residents Lydia Pinkney and Tony Ruffini stood on the sidewalk of Aurora Street, discussing their safety concerns for the residential area that is home to many families and children.
"You stand out here for about five, ten minutes, you'll see how fast people go," Ruffini said. "It's insane. They don't care, and they're always in a hurry."
According to the Easton Police Department, the intersection has seen three crashes this month, all due to driver error. There were only 13 in the last 11 years, police said.
Town engineers reviewed the traffic light, which was confirmed as operational. In a Facebook post, the police department encouraged drivers to be cautious and stated the intersection will be monitored.
"While this location is being monitored, officers have begun targeted traffic enforcement and will continue to do so at different hours of the day," the department wrote.
Pinkney said she's worried for the safety of her 9-year-old daughter and her dog when walking up and down Aurora Street near the intersection. She says a car has careened into her yard before, and many neighbors have had their parked cars damaged.
Pinkney believes part of the issue is drivers may be unaware it is a residential area.
"The speed limit's 25, and I know people are going more than 25," she said. "Our kids play out here. And what worries me about everything is if … someone's not paying attention or whatnot, them running the red light or just going way too fast and clipping me and my daughter."
Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh said the town is looking at what it can do with the intersection's traffic light in terms of safety and timing.
Easton's engineers recently adjusted the timing of the intersection's traffic light, hoping to lower the "chances of a collision if a driver attempts to beat a red light," the Easton Police Department announced Tuesday.
Discussion around safety on Brookletts Avenue has been recurring. This month, the town installed four-way stop signs at two other Brookletts intersections, South Harrison Street and Hanson Street. The intersections previously had two stop signs each.
Van Emburgh said thus far, feedback on the four-way stop signs has been positive. Resident Lisa Stone lives next to the intersections and said she's happy with the change.
"I have seen so many near accidents at the intersections, particularly Hanson and Brookletts," Stone said. " … I think that's a good improvement."
The town also added on-street parking lines to Brookletts Avenue, a measure that Van Emburgh said will improve safety on the wide, two-way street.
"The white lines give the drivers cues as to where they're supposed to be in the travel lanes," Van Emburgh said. "Because one of the things that we struggle with is when you have a road that can accommodate on-street parking, but no one's actually parking on it, it looks like a wide-open raceway."
For many neighbors, traffic and safety concerns only grow as developers revamp a nearby property formerly owned by Perdue AgriBusiness. Last week, Easton's Planning Commission approved the majority of a 123-unit proposal for the site along Brookletts Avenue.
Developers had Lenhart Traffic Consulting prepare a traffic impact study, which recommended project approval. Per Planning Commission documents, the study found redevelopment will have "minimal impact on the surrounding road network."
Ruffini said with the new development and an eventual increase in traffic, South Aurora Street "will be a main road before you know it."
Stone, meanwhile, is excited to see the redevelopment, given it includes commercial space and affordable housing. But she's keeping an eye on its impacts to driver and pedestrian safety.
"Hopefully it will just be an increase in traffic and not a decrease in safety," Stone said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on traffic safety concerns, police involvement, and community efforts to address crashes at a local intersection, directly aligning with Public Safety. Local Government is a secondary fit due to town engineering and police actions, while Local Life reflects resident impacts but is less central.

title: Former councilmember Engle leads way in creating Easton's new highway safety plan
author: Konner Metz
content:
Former councilmember Engle leads way in creating Easton's new highway safety plan

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 611
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Ron Engle has a robust resume of public service.The former National Highway Traffic Safety Administration senior manager and Virginia police officer developed an extensive portfolio in traffic policy and management over more than three decades.
Following retirement, Engle remained busy, serving on many local boards in Talbot County and winning a seat on the Easton Town Council in 2015.
So when Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey asked Engle in 2023 if he would give the town a hand in creating a Strategic Highway Safety Plan, it was a no-brainer.
"The chief grabbed me and said, 'I need help getting grants,'" Engle recalled. "And he said, 'And I know you know how to do it.'"
Though he lost his council seat two years ago, Engle has spearheaded the creation of a traffic safety plan for Easton during the last year.
Approved by the Town Council earlier this month, Easton's new Strategic Highway Safety Plan is expected to bring significant funding opportunities to the town for its transportation and safety efforts, town officials say.
It is 72 pages in length, detailing strategies and action plans for Easton to address vehicular, bicycle and pedestrian safety issues as the town grows. Not every city or town in the state has adopted a strategic plan aligning with the state's vision, Engle noted.
"My gut feeling is that with so few of these programs, we can do pretty well," he said.
The plan goes hand-in-hand with Maryland's Vision Zero law that was established in 2019, which aims to eliminate all vehicle-related deaths by 2030. Traditional approaches to highway safety assume crashes and injuries are inevitable, but Vision Zero lays out that traffic systems can accommodate for human error.
"What I mainly focused on was speeding, distracted driving, impaired driving, bicycling and pedestrians," Engle said, as well as sections dedicated to Route 50 safety and mature drivers, given Talbot County's older population.
In order to lay the groundwork, town leaders worked with Washington College's Geographic Information Systems Program to compile accident data dating back to 2018, culminating in the release of an interactive traffic dashboard.
While Easton doesn't have traffic fatalities often, the numbers depict problem areas in town where the most crashes occurred from 2018-2023, such as Dover Road and Aurora Street.
Engle said the data, combined with sleek and easy-to-read graphic designs and charts made by the town's communications specialist, Greg Mueller, helped the strategic plan come to life.
"It wasn't until I got the data," Engle said. "I would have never thought Dover Street had the most crashes. It just wouldn't occur to me."
Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh, one of the plan's main contributors, said it all boils down to making Easton safer. Clear deadlines for goals and improvements will keep the town's progress timely, he said.
"It will hold us accountable," Van Emburgh said.
Lowrey says the Strategic Highway Safety Plan is just one step in Easton's efforts to better safety for residents using all modes of transportation.
"It's an important first step, but it's part of a bigger process that the mayor's undertaking to help us address Easton as it is right now and how it will be in the future," Lowrey said.
Engle, who says he's "fascinated" by public service, has been inspired not just by his traffic safety background, but by local organizations and residents, too.
It's part of the reason he's continued to dedicate hours upon hours of his time to creating a better and safer Easton.
"It's a big bite for the town, because there's a lot of things in here they need to (do that) they may not have the money or may not have the resources (for)," Engle said of the highway safety plan. "But everything in here is something we should do." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the development of Easton's Strategic Highway Safety Plan, which aims to improve traffic safety through data-driven strategies, collaboration with local authorities, and alignment with state safety initiatives. While local government involvement is present, the core subject is traffic safety planning, making 'Public Safety' the primary topic.

title: Cambridge man sentenced for child abuse, assault
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge man sentenced for child abuse, assault

 February 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 387
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man has been sentenced to incarceration after being found guilty of charges that stem from an incident with his infant in April 2023.On Feb. 21, Marcus Peak, 28, was sentenced to 28 years of incarceration, with all but 15 of those years suspended, in the Dorchester County Circuit Court. Peak was also sentenced to serve five years of probation with the condition that he not have any unsupervised contact with minors.
In December, Dorchester County Circuit Court Judge William Jones found Peak guilty of of first- and second-degree assault, first- and second-degree child abuse, neglect of a minor and reckless endangerment.
The charges against Peak stem from an incident on April 21, 2023, when Cambridge Police officers responded to assist Dorchester County Emergency Medical Services with an infant who was unconscious and not breathing. EMS treated the infant and transported her to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Cambridge. The baby was then transported to Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore.
According to police, Peak told detectives he had just fed his daughter a bottle and placed her in a bassinet for a nap. He said the baby was asleep.
Peak said that when he returned to check on her later, he noticed the baby's head was tilted to the side with fluid coming from her nose and mouth. He said the baby's eyes were partially opened.
At that time, Peak denied any traumatic event that could have caused injury to his daughter.
Detectives were told Peak had lied and did not inform them the baby had fallen to the floor, striking her head. Peak allegedly then picked the baby up and shook her to wake her up, according to a report from the Cambridge Police Department.
During the trial in December, Dr. Eric Klotz, an emergency medicine physician who treated the child that day, said the child's injuries were consistent with a high mechanism of injury. He said it was one of the more severe head injuries he's seen in his career.
Dr. Joseph Scheller, a pediatric neurologist who was asked by Peak's defense to testify, said it is possible the child's injuries were caused by an accidental fall. He said short falls can sometimes cause serious injury.
According to Maryland court documents, Dorchester County Assistant Public Defender Michelle Moodispaw filed a notice to appeal the case on Tuesday. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Eastern Shore renters face challenges with affordable housing
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Eastern Shore renters face challenges with affordable housing

 March 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 1987
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Bradford House Apartments resident Linda Johnson doesn't carry mace on her keychain anymore.She doesn't feel the need to use a key or a cell phone instead of her finger to tap the buttons of the apartment's elevator.
After years of asking apartment management to address resident safety concerns, from mold and bug infestations to a lack of security, Johnson and other Bradford House residents finally feel safe.
"I feel better every day," said Johnson, who has lived at Bradford House on Race Street in Cambridge for nearly 25 years. "I'm not angry no more."
The complex — which offers multifamily, subsidized housing for low-income individuals who are elderly or have special needs — came under new management with a new principal owner in the fall, and residents started to see changes they had requested for years be made.
But as housing problems across the Eastern Shore persist, others have not been as lucky.
A SHORE PROBLEM
With a lack of affordable housing options on the Eastern Shore and a need for better enforcement over housing standards, renters living in poor conditions often feel stuck.
In the eyes of Larry Rooths, the head of the Public Safety and Intelligence Committee for the Eastern Shore branch of the Caucus of African American Leaders, the lack of affordable housing is a national issue.
"But it seems a lot worse down here because there's so little housing," he said, "and there's no infrastructure in place for emergency services, emergency shelters."
Rooths said he's noticed landlords don't feel like they have to do much for tenants because there aren't many other places those tenants can go.
"And then the residents feel like that also," he said. "They don't want to stir up too much trouble because they know if somebody comes in and shuts the building down, where are they going?"
Rooths sees a need for housing legislation with more enforcement power so landlords address the issues residents face. He said the Shore also needs more housing infrastructure.
"If you create a situation where there's enough housing, then the landlords lose control," he said. "...If you don't like the place you're living in, you get up and move. But if there's no place to move or you can't move to another apartment building close to where you work, then it gets difficult."
The caucus is working to get tenants to form groups, which Rooths said would help them know their rights and push elected officials to make change.
"Unless there's some change in legislation or there's some increased funding to create a bigger pool of housing, this problem is going to be the same," he said.
In October, the Tenant Safety Act of 2024 went into effect in Maryland. The act, which places responsibility on landlords to provide safe dwelling for tenants, guarantees tenants can form groups.
Shore Legal Access Executive Director Meredith Girard considers Bradford House's tenant association a critical piece of its success in getting new management.
"I think the tenant association was critical to really letting the management and the court know what the issues were and how widespread it was," Girard said. "And that prompted some really important changes so that now the building is managed by a new company."
Girard said rural counties don't always have enough resources to support a rental inspection and licensing system. She said it would be great if counties on the Eastern Shore could pool their resources to form a regional housing commission.
"Where you could set some basic standards for habitability to make sure that if you're renting a unit, that the oven works, that the heat works, that the plumbing works, that the roof isn't leaking," she said.
Girard acknowledged rural landlords may also be strapped for resources. She said in some cases, landlords might not have the resources to make needed repairs.
"Which then becomes this really problematic cycle," she said.
At Bradford House, previous management said the property had been neglected before they took over in 2022.
In an April 2024 statement to The Star Democrat, Millennia Housing Management, the previous management at the complex, said it had invested more than $300,000 into the maintenance and enhancement of the "severely distressed property."
Girard said that when problems in complexes are fixed, tenants are often scared to complain about the conditions because they don't have anywhere else to go.
"And they don't want to upset their landlords," she said. "But at the same time, they need landlords to fix the things that need to be fixed."
Maryland Legal Aid Advocacy Director for the Human Right to Housing Zafar Shah said further protections against evictions are needed so tenants aren't reluctant to use the Tenant Safety Act of 2024. He said the Maryland legislature is considering a good cause eviction bill "that would protect tenants from lease non-renewal without a good reason."
"This is the big priority for renters in Maryland," he said.
NO WHERE TO GO
De'Auntte Clark came to Cambridge for peace.
In 2016, her 14-year-old son was killed after being hit by a car in Anne Arundel County. Four years later, her husband died from COVID-19.
In September 2022, Clark brought her family to the Eastern Shore for a fresh start. But since moving here, Clark has found anything but the peace she was seeking.
"I'm so numb, I can't cry," she said.
With concerns about the safety of her apartment at Calvin Mowbray Park and Stephen Camper Park in Cambridge and nowhere else to go, Clark spent more than a month living out of a van with her family.
A few days after her family moved into the complex, Clark noticed what seemed like mold in the cabinets along one of the walls in the kitchen.
Maintenance came to clean the cabinets out, but as the weather outside got colder and she turned the heat on, Clark said she started to see black spots pop up on the walls.
In December 2023, Clark's son, Keith Dezurn — who has a medical history of severe, persistent asthma — was airlifted to the University of Maryland Children's Hospital because he was struggling to breathe. He stayed in intensive care for five days, Clark said, displaying symptoms consistent with mold exposure.
Clark said on the way to the hospital in Baltimore, she could barely see anything and was crying.
"I don't want to lose another child," she said.
Ed Cafasso, a spokesperson for the property that is managed by WinnResidential, said on Jan. 15 that the health and safety of residents is WinnResidential's number one priority.
"Any time a household reports a moisture-related issue, it is treated as an emergency and remediated immediately by a professional, licensed specialist," he said.
Cafasso said over the past year, there have been seven instances at the complex that required professional mold remediation. He said there were zero reported cases of mold at the 190-apartment community as of January.
Before Clark and her family could move into a new unit at the complex this past fall, the unit was condemned. Cambridge Assistant City Manager Brandon Hesson said that in condemning the unit, the city ordered mold and moisture testing be done.
An inspection report obtained by The Star Democrat from the city showed an early November analysis found aspergillus and penicillium spore counts in the unit that were "significantly higher than the baseline count and probably indicates a source of contamination."
The unit was later removed from the city's list of condemned properties after a report by Simple Mold Solutions, which was based on the analysis, found the numbers "indicated a normal fungal environment with no elevated concentrations of airborne mold spores." The report recommended the HVAC system be cleaned to prevent mold spores from circulating.
But Clark's son's health scare was enough to make her seek housing elsewhere. The search proved to be no easy feat.
Limited affordable housing options on the Eastern Shore and across the state have made it difficult for Clark to find somewhere new to settle.
Clark said she went to multiple shelters in Howard County, where her children are currently enrolled in school, but all of them were full. She said the places she did find that had space required she live in the county for six months, which she had not.
Moving from place to place hasn't been easy on Clark's kids. She said they are scared to go back to the complex.
"They don't want to go back there, and I don't know what to do," Clark told The Star Democrat while they were living out of a van. "But at the same time, I know we can't keep living like this."
In mid-December, Clark and her family were able to secure a hotel room after living out of a van for more than a month. On Valentine's Day, they moved into a townhouse on the western shore.
"It's much better," she said. "No mold."
ZOOMING IN ON THE PROBLEM
Clark's story isn't an uncommon one when it comes to tenants of affordable housing on the Eastern Shore.
Residential issues at affordable housing complexes in Cambridge have come to a head more than once in the last two years.
In an attempt to attack the bigger issue at the local level, Cambridge has beefed up its Code Enforcement Department and is working on projects intended to increase and improve the city's housing stock.
Hesson said although the issues at housing facilities are all unique, there are common themes among them.
"There have been failures by agencies at the local, state and federal level to hold up the standards we've set for housing providers here," he said. "It's not my place to point fingers, because it isn't going to fix anything. The city is part of that structure, and we're committed to being better."
Hesson said building "strong relationships" with the governing authorities for the different housing facilities has helped achieve "significant progress."
"We've been able to draw attention to where these systems and processes have fallen short, and residents are seeing some of the early results of those efforts," he said.
PROGRESS
For Linda Johnson, those results are clear.
On Feb. 13, Johnson moved into a new unit within Bradford House Apartments. The move is not just a win for Johnson, who has been a loud and consistent voice of the Bradford House community, but proof of a new era for the apartment complex and its residents.
For years Bradford House residents expressed concerns about the safety of the building. In September 2023, the property — which was then managed by Millennia — received a U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development inspection score that indicated health and safety deficiencies.
Three months later, Millennia received a debarment order from HUD, preventing the company from participating in any new business with the department.
In October, it was announced that Nuveen, an asset manager and subsidiary of financial planning firm TIAA, had been made principal owner of the apartment complex. Paths Management Services, a subsidiary of Nuveen, would manage the property.
Johnson's new digs, complete with a brand new, updated kitchen and laminate wood flooring, are a stark contrast from her previous unit.
When The Star Democrat visited some residents' homes last year, residents pointed out things like holes in ceilings, possible mold and problems with stoves. At that time, multiple residents had active rent escrow cases, where tenants pay their rent to a court, rather than to their landlord, until property issues are addressed.
The change at Bradford House isn't just visible in individual apartment units. The hallways have new flooring, the stairways are consistently clean, there is better lighting and new cameras and the community room has been renovated. Johnson said management is fixing the elevator that's been broken for more than a year.
"It's been wonderful," Johnson said. "I mean Paths came in here, they didn't talk, they worked."
Johnson is the president of the complex's tenant association, which was formed with guidance from Shore Legal Access.
"Just because we're low income people doesn't mean we have to live like that," she said.
Johnson said other renters going through housing issues should fight for what they believe in, adding that tenants have the right to withhold rent and form tenant associations.
"Your voice matters," she said.
Star Democrat reporter Konner Metz contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on housing safety issues like mold, security, and living conditions affecting residents, which directly relate to public safety. While local government actions and health impacts are mentioned, the core theme revolves around resident safety and systemic failures in housing standards.

title: Garage fire outside Denton causes significant damages
author: Konner Metz

Garage fire outside Denton causes significant damages

 Words

 DENTON — A garage fire Sunday morning caused an estimated $700,000 in damages, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal.Just before 11:30 a.m. Sunday, a fire broke out in a garage on Sennett Road near Hobbs, a community just southeast of Denton.
Firefighters from the Denton Volunteer Fire Company responded and controlled the blaze in around 40 minutes, per the fire marshal. No injuries were reported.

title: Court docs: Delaware middle school teacher spent months grooming student online with sexual messages
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Court docs: Delaware middle school teacher spent months grooming student online with sexual messages

 March 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 681
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Delaware court documents released Tuesday shed new light on how a Kirk Middle School teacher allegedly spent months grooming one of his students by sending her sexual messages and fantasies through an online chat application.Ultimately, the inappropriate behavior expanded to school grounds, where David DiFilippo would spend time alone with the 13-year-old girl in his classroom, making sexual comments to her and, on one occasion, touching her legs, court records allege.
DiFilippo's actions "are clearly and reasonably indicative of an adult grooming and enticing a minor for the purpose of sexual contact and/or a sexual experience," Detective Marc Conway, of the Delaware State Police, wrote in court documents, adding that DiFilippo was trying to build up trust with the girl to "ultimately entice and arouse her sexually."
DiFilippo's alleged behavior took place between September 2023 and February 2024, when DiFilippo was 43 and 44 years old.
During that six-month period, DiFilippo and the girl chatted nearly every day over Discord, a messaging app. The messages were "flirtatious and sexual in nature," and DiFilippo suggested sexual acts with the girl, made comments about her body and clothing and referred to her as "babe" and "baby," court records show.
He sent her several stories detailing explicit sexual fantasies involving her engaging in sexual intercourse, masturbation and oral sex. He would then ask the girl "if the writings were good enough that she could picture them in her mind and if reading them made her feel a certain way," court documents allege.
One story involved a teacher and a student having sexual relations on a school bus during a field trip, and DiFilippo then told the girl he was planing a field trip and asked if she would like to sit with him on the bus, court records indicate.
DiFilippo would delete the messages after the girl read them, but she kept screenshots of the messages on her phone.
DiFilippo's behavior eventually extended into in-person encounters, and he would allow the girl to skip class to hang out with him alone in his classroom during his planning period when he did not have a class to teach. Other times, she would stay in his classroom after class ended and the other students left.
On one occasion, DiFilippo told the girl he liked her "milky white thighs" and said seeing them made him feel "like an animal ready to attack his prey," court documents allege. Another time, he suggested they go into a closet to kiss, but the girl refused. On a different day, the girl brought DiFilippo an assortment of snack food and asked him which he liked best, to which he replied he liked "the snack in the dress," presumably referring to her.
Court records describe one incident in which DiFilippo's behavior turned physical. The girl was sitting on a counter near his desk, and DiFilippo allegedly knelt down and rubbed her legs. The girl told him to stop, which he did.
It's not clear why DiFilippo's behavior ended in February 2024. Court records indicate that the girl told her therapist about it in August 2024, sparking a police investigation.
The girl provided police with screenshots of DiFilippo's Discord messages, and detectives later subpoenaed Discord for a transcript of the messages sent from his account. Investigators interviewed the girl with help from the Child Advocacy Center in Wilmington.
DiFilippo turned himself in to police in February after the months-long investigation.
He was charged with sexual solicitation of a child, enticement for purposes of sexual conduct, dangerous crime against a minor, promoting sexual solicitation of a child, providing obscenity material to a child, sexual abuse of a child by a person of trust and offensive touching. He was released after posting $65,500 secured bond.
Police asked anyone with information or who may be a victim to contact Conway at 302-365-8411.
According to a brief biography posted on Kirk's website, DiFilippo taught in the gifted and talented program and has been a teacher for approximately 15 years. He wrote that his favorite part of the job is "forming strong bonds and relationships with my students."
A spokesperson for the Christina School District did not respond to a request for comment. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal case involving a teacher's sexual misconduct with a minor, including online grooming and physical abuse. While the perpetrator was an educator, the core issue revolves around criminal behavior threatening a minor's safety, making 'Public Safety' the most appropriate classification. The Education topic is secondary, as the story focuses on the crime rather than educational systems or policies.

title: Easton woman pleads guilty to assault of county correctional officer
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Easton woman pleads guilty to assault of county correctional officer

 March 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 180
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An Easton woman pleaded guilty to second-degree assault after being charged with assaulting a Talbot County correctional officer in January.According to Maryland court documents, Latoia Handy, 36, was sentenced to 36 months of supervised probation by Judge Karen R. Ketterman in the Maryland District Court for Talbot County Monday.
Handy was also sentenced to two years of incarceration with all of the incarceration term suspended except one day. She was given credit for time served for one day.
The charge stemmed from a Jan. 11 incident that occurred at the Talbot County Detention Center. According to court documents, Handy was accused of biting Cpl. Michelle Armstrong while getting escorted in the correctional building.
In a statement of charges, Armstrong wrote that "Handy had hit her (own) head against several walls in several different areas" after she claimed she had mental health problems. Armstrong wrote that multiple law enforcement officers moved Handy to a restraint chair so she wouldn't injure herself.
"I was putting her left wrist in the restraint strap when she bit me on my right inner forearm," Armstrong wrote.

title: UPDATE: Bay Bridge reopened to most traffic, wind restrictions in place
author: Staff Writer
content:
UPDATE: Bay Bridge reopened to most traffic, wind restrictions in place

 March 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 112
 Words 

 Read News Document

 UPDATE 2:40 P.M. — The bridge has been reopened to most traffic in both directions. Motorists should expect significant delays.Wind restrictions are in place for house trailers, empty box trailers and other vehicles vulnerable to high winds.
ORIGINAL REPORT —
With gusts of wind exceeding 55 miles per hour in the area, The Maryland Transportation Authority placed a temporary hold for all traffic on the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Wednesday afternoon.
It was not stated when the bridge closure would be lifted and if any wind restrictions would remain in place when the bridge reopens. Severe weather was expected to remain in the area until Wednesday evening.
This report will be updated as information becomes available.

title: A man of action
author: Staff Writer
content:
A man of action

 March 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 539
 Words 

 Read News Document

 You look at so many things in life that you hope you never see and wonder why no one seems to do anything about it. But then I remember Frank Gunsallus and how one person can truly make a difference. He's a fellow Easton Rotarian and friend, and all of us can learn a lot from him about courage, integrity, action and service to others.Heroes come along rarely, but when Frank Gunsallus and his wife, Iryna, traveled to Ukraine to get her parents out of the country at the beginning of the war there, he became one in short order. Instead of running home, the whole family stayed in Warsaw, Poland, to help Ukrainian refugees in Poland and Ukrainians stuck at home and facing the horrors of a merciless, dreadful war.
Frank secured three ambulances to save lives at the front. He made sure a mental health facility was secured in Warsaw to accommodate refugees who had seen and experienced far too much. Working with Rotary Clubs in Poland and Ukraine and with Disaster Aid USA, he delivered tents, water purification systems, lights, cell phone chargers and much-needed food and supplies to where they were needed most.
He delivered teddy bears made in our own Rotary District to refugee children, and they worked magic. He guided Rotarians from all over the world to refugee camps so they, too, could help.
Last fall, when Hurricane Helene slammed its way through the South, as a Rotary and community leader, Frank could not just sit comfortably at home here in Easton. He wrote:
"In the wake of Hurricane Helene, I felt a deep sense of responsibility to step up and offer help to our fellow countrymen in need during such a challenging time. Perhaps it was the summers I spent in those North Carolina hills as a child, visiting my grandparents, or the deep connection my family has to that land that stirred something within me. Or maybe it was simply the empathy I feel for others in times of crisis. After seeing heartbreaking videos of people suffering on social media, I knew I had to act."
With Rotary's help, he quickly gathered supplies and money and headed to Asheville, North Carolina. He witnessed incredible devastation and not only delivered the supplies where they were needed most, but also pitched in and helped those in need. By doing so, he discovered that many hurricane victims could not be reached because of the severe, unimaginable destruction. Exhausted, but determined, he returned to Easton and procured an ATV that could break into those unreachable areas.
He then went right back to North Carolina with the ATV and delivered it to emergency personnel who could immediately put it to work.
Like the firefighters and police who ran into—and not away from— the World Trade Center on 9/11, Frank Gunsallus ran into the teeth of trouble in Europe and in North Carolina. He is a true hero and public servant and sets a very high standard for the rest of us to follow. Frank will soon be the president of the Rotary Club of Easton and is the very definition of Rotary International's motto of "Service above Self" and its members' proven track record of being "People of Action."
GEORGE A. HATCHER JR. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article highlights Frank Gunsallus's humanitarian efforts during crises like the Ukraine war and Hurricane Helene, emphasizing his role in disaster relief, emergency aid distribution, and community service. While 'Local Life' is relevant due to his community involvement, 'Public Safety' best captures the focus on emergency response and safeguarding communities.

title: Man charged with impersonating police officer, falsifying records in Easton PD application
author: Konner Metz
content:
Man charged with impersonating police officer, falsifying records in Easton PD application

 March 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 399
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Police arrested a man Wednesday for allegedly impersonating a police officer and falsifying a number of documents in his application to join the Easton Police Department.Richard Browning, 30, of Fairfax, Virginia, was arrested by Easton police after allegedly falsifying military and law enforcement documents and his social security information.
Browning faces 23 total charges, the first 15 of which include perjury, forgery, impersonating a police officer, destroying public records and making false statements to police officers.
Following his arrest March 5, authorities searched Browning's vehicle and found a loaded handgun and a U.S. Marshals Service badge, according to court documents. He was later charged with eight additional counts, including illegal possession of a firearm and loaded handgun in a vehicle, among others.
Court documents state that Browning sent an application to the Easton Police Department Feb. 4. During applicant testing and extensive background investigations that followed, police found discrepancies in Browning's documents and application.
Lt. Milton Orellana, special operations commander for the Easton Police Department, received Browning's initial application and worked the investigation.
"I've been doing background investigations for 21 years, and never seen this before," Orellana told The Star Democrat.
Per court documents, Browning falsified documents claiming he had prior employment with the U.S. Marshals Service and U.S. Capitol Police.
Browning had a warrant out for his arrest in Florida on charges of larceny and grand theft, court records state, as well as criminal history in Texas and Washington, D.C.
During the interview process, Browning was "well-spoken, poised, and respectful" and did not struggle to answer questions, according to court records.
After a lengthy investigation, police brought Browning to the department Wednesday and arrested him. The 30-year-old admitted to the falsified documents and said he was in a "bad place in his life," per court records.
"Browning stated that he got the documents from a guy but would not identify the person," charging documents read. "Browning stated that he didn't want to talk anymore … ."
Police determined that the handgun found in Browning's vehicle was illegally carried. Browning was taken to the Talbot County Detention Center following his arrest. He's being held without bond for the initial 15 charges and held on $10,000 bond for the subsequent eight charges.
Orellana said it was a unique investigation, "especially since (Browning) presented all these documents to a law enforcement agency."
"We do a pretty intense and thorough background investigation," Orellana said. "We're going to catch something if it's fictitious." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a police investigation into criminal activities involving falsified documents and impersonation of law enforcement, directly relating to public safety concerns. While local government is tangentially relevant due to the police department's role, the primary focus is on criminal behavior and law enforcement actions.

title: On NTSB recommendations, FAA closes helicopter route near DC airport weeks after tragedy
author: MENNATALLA IBRAHIM Capital News Service
content:
On NTSB recommendations, FAA closes helicopter route near DC airport weeks after tragedy

 March 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MENNATALLA IBRAHIM Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 601
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — The National Transportation Safety Board issued urgent safety recommendations Tuesday, warning that helicopter flights near the Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport pose serious safety risks and one helicopter route should be closed during airport operations.Hours later, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy accepted the recommendations on behalf of the Federal Aviation Administration, promising long-term changes.
"Urgent recommendations require immediate action to prevent similar accidents or incidents when we issue them," NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy said at an NTSB media briefing Tuesday. "We believe a critical safety issue must be addressed without delay."
The recommendations were released alongside a preliminary investigative report on the Jan. 29 midair collision of an American Airlines jetliner and a military helicopter near Reagan National that killed 67 people.
The NTSB urged the FAA to ban helicopters from a four-mile stretch over the Potomac River when airport runway 15/33 is in use and to designate an alternative route when the area is closed, according to the published recommendations. The American jet was on final approach to runway 15/33 when the collision occurred.
Homendy said that there were warning signs before the January collision, citing data detailing more than 15,000 near-collisions between commercial aircraft and helicopters at Reagan National between October 2021 and December 2024. The majority occurred during plane landings and at night, according to the NTSB's report.
"We're in a situation where we're threading the needle, allowing helicopters to fly down the same airspace as landing aircraft," Duffy said. "And why this information wasn't studied and known before January 29 is an important question."
Following the crash, Duffy restricted helicopter traffic around the airport through the end of March. He said those restrictions will continue in accordance with NTSB recommendations. Duffy said he also spoke with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth about alternative military flight routes, with exceptions for presidential travel, life-saving operations and law enforcement.
The preliminary report does not identify any probable causes of the collision, as the NTSB is still in "the fact-finding phase" of its investigation, according to Homendy.
"We still have a lot of work to do in this investigation, so the report contains only the facts that we're able to validate and release at this time," Homendy said. "The easiest and quickest part of the investigation is determining what happened. The part that takes longer is the how and why."
Tuesday's NTSB media briefing was the fifth of its kind since the collision.
At a Feb. 14 briefing, Homendy told reporters that investigators believe that the helicopter crew was wearing night vision goggles that would have limited their peripheral vision. She also said that cockpit conversations suggest that the helicopter crew may not have heard key instructions from air traffic controllers and had inaccurate altitude readings in the moments before the crash.
Duffy criticized the air traffic control system as outdated, relying on 25- to 30-year-old technology, including floppy disks and plug-in headphones, at a separate press conference Tuesday. He pledged to propose a plan in the coming weeks that would revolutionize the "antiquated" technology, seeking congressional approval and funding.
"We're at a point where we can do this fast—three and a half to four years for a brand new air traffic control system. Gold plated. Envy of the world," he said. "It will greatly improve our safety…but it's also going to improve the efficiency that we have in American air travel, which I think will mean less delays, less cancellations, and again, better safety."
Despite concerns, Homendy reassured travelers.
"I just flew with my daughter out of DCA…aviation is incredibly safe," she said. "However, there are safety issues and areas where we need to improve to make sure that we are at zero." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on safety recommendations from the NTSB and FAA regarding helicopter routes near a major airport, following a tragic collision. This directly relates to public safety measures and aviation safety protocols. While it involves federal agencies and could tie to national news, the core emphasis is on safety improvements and risk mitigation.

title: Talbot County man charged for possessing, distributing child porn
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County man charged for possessing, distributing child porn

 March 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 181
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A Talbot County man has been charged with the possession and distribution of child pornography.Jordan Cabrera, 20, was arrested March 2, according to a news release from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office.
Cabrera, whose residence is listed under a Trappe address in court records, is charged with three separate child pornography counts: two counts of soliciting a minor to engage as a subject in child porn and one count of knowingly distributing child porn.
According to court records, the charges were filed by an ex-girlfriend of Cabrera's, who was underage at the time they dated from 2021 to 2023.
Cabrera allegedly obtained nude photos from the then-minor and distributed those photos on a messaging app called Telegram, court records state. The nude photos also surfaced on Instagram and Twitter, the ex-girlfriend alleged in charging documents.
She wrote they broke up in 2023, a month before she turned 18. She stated she was a minor in every nude photo and video, per court records.
Cabrera was initially held without bond before posting $1,500 bond March 3. A preliminary hearing is set for March 31. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Lawmakers battle between cracking down and easing up on prison sentences
author: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service
content:
Lawmakers battle between cracking down and easing up on prison sentences

 March 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 745
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Lawmakers are taking a hard look at prison sentences in Maryland this spring, but from two dramatically different points of view.One measure under consideration would help offenders reduce their sentences for demonstrating good behavior. The other would crack down on violent offenders seeking time off their sentences.
Democrat Del. Cheryl Pasteur is sponsoring the Maryland Second Look Act, which would allow offenders showcasing good behavior to petition the courts for time off after serving at least 20 years.
"They have done every single thing possible to be better folks, better than a lot of the folks that I work with here," Pasteur, who represents Baltimore County said, referring to incarcerated people who demonstrate good behavior. "When do we ever have to spend 20 years to be vetted? Never."
But Republican Sen. William Folden is the sponsor for Real Time for Violent Crimes, a bill that would restrict or prohibit violent offenders from receiving diminution credits, or time off due to good behavior. He disagrees with Pasteur.
"If you commit a violent crime and you prey on our communities, and you're that two percenters that are the worst of the worst, then you should get real time and not allow it to be watered down through dim credits and things of that," said Folden, who represents Frederick County.
Hearings for both bills have elicited contentious and emotional testimony, both from families of murder victims and from formerly incarcerated individuals. But after both bills died during last year's legislative session, proponents of each bill are pushing yet again for passage.
Supporters and opponents alike for the Real Time for Real Crimes Act gathered at a Tuesday bill hearing to provide their testimony. Kurt Wolfgang, the executive director of the Maryland Crime Victims Resource Center, said this bill is "long overdue."
"There are so many ways to already diminish a sentence in Maryland," Wolfgang said. "This is just one more hole in the bucket that needs to be plugged up by taking away or diminishing the use of diminution credits to release violent offenders."
Despite his efforts, Folden told CNS that there isn't a "big appetite" for his bill.
Still, there was some opposition to the Maryland Second Look Act in a nearly three-hour long hearing in February, with some detailing emotional stories of their loved ones who are victims of violence.
Theresa Darvish, whose son was murdered in 2021, opposed the bill. She said it is retroactive, and referred to the procedures in the bill as "rampant and ambiguous at best."
"My son will never return to his home," Darvish testified. "No murderer should be given a free ride home."
This is a sentiment was echoed by many including Folden, who said those accused of rape and murder specifically should not get a second look.
But the bill that could allow review of prison sentences over 20 years was also met with large amounts of support from activists and formerly incarcerated individuals.
Anthony Muhummad was just 15 when he was arrested for two homicide charges in Baltimore City. He served over 29 years and was released under the Juvenile Restoration Act, and was one of the first to testify in support of the bill.
"There are dozens of individuals who are still incarcerated throughout the Maryland prison system who have served 20, 30, 40 and yes, sometimes even 50 years of incarceration who are not juveniles, who have demonstrated their maturity and rehabilitation and we believe are worthy of a second opportunity," Muhummad said.
Muhummad detailed his community engagement since his release, including his current employment at the ACLU. He also spoke about the conversation he had with the families of the two victims in his case, both of whom were in favor of rehabilitation.
And Pasteur, who is a former educator in Baltimore City and Baltimore County schools, believes that all deserve the chance for reevaluation after 20 years, especially those who entered the prison system at a young age. Pasteur said two of her "very favorite" former students have been or are currently incarcerated.
"I am really an educator, not a politician," Pasteur said. "Having always been in schools where things are tough for a lot of the students I have seen students get themselves engaged and involved in things that they know they shouldn't have. So they are in my heart."
And ultimately, Pasteur has high hopes for the bill.
"It's about appreciating and recognizing that some folks under the most horrific circumstances have made themselves better," Pasteur said. "Much better than a whole lot of us on any given day." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on legislative debates about prison sentence policies, which directly relate to public safety concerns. While it involves state lawmakers (Local Government), the core content centers on criminal justice reforms and their implications for community safety, making 'Public Safety' the most precise classification.

title: Cambridge fire leaves homes with $750,000 in damages
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge fire leaves homes with $750,000 in damages

 March 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 265
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Just before 11:30 p.m. Thursday, Rescue Fire Company responded to reports of an explosion on the 400 block of Wood Duck Drive in Cambridge.The fire company then received multiple calls reporting that a townhouse was on fire and rapidly spreading. Upon arrival firefighters saw a townhome in flames and spreading to the two adjacent homes.
According to Fire Chief Brad Walters, all occupants had already exited the adjacent buildings, and the occupants of the main affected townhome were not home at the time, so nobody was injured in the fire.
Walters also stated that approximately 55 firemen were called to the fire. The firefighters got the fire under control at about 1 a.m.
According to the state fire marshal estimated damages to be at $750,000.
Cambridge Commissioner Shay Lewis-Sisco lives in the same development. She said heard a loud boom and then saw the home burst into flames.
"I heard a boom in the living room," Lewis-Sisco said. "Then we looked outside and the house within a matter of minutes, the house was engulfed in flames."
While everyone was OK, Lewis-Sisco said her heart goes out to the families affected by the fire.
"Representing the area, I think for me, my heart broke in the process of watching the other houses also the fire alone, my heart broke for just seeing itself," she said.
The fire marshal confirmed that there was a gas explosion in the townhome where the fire started, but the fire marshal's office is still investigating to determine what caused the gas explosion.
This story has been updated to include information about the potential cause of the fire. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Adams brings experience, potential K-9 to Greensboro Police Department
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Adams brings experience, potential K-9 to Greensboro Police Department

 March 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 446
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — Sgt. Jeff Adams chose the Greensboro Police Department as his next endeavor because of his great relationship with Police Chief Lenox Trams."I was looking at different agencies but I reached out the chief. Chief and I go back to 2005 or 2006," Adams said. "I didn't know if I wanted to come here or not. We just had a brief conversation, then I came and did an interview and instantly fell in love. Ever since talking to him and doing a ride along, I was pretty much sold."
Adams, originally from New Jersey, came to the Eastern Shore in 2004 after his career in the military. Adams served in the Navy and in the Army Reserve.
A friend talked to him about coming down to the Eastern Shore and pursing law enforcement as a career.
Adams started his career in law enforcement in dispatch at Easton Police Department for one year. Then Adams moved to the Federalsburg Police Department, where he served for the past 17 years.
While Adams and Trams' long relationship played a big part in his decision to pick Greensboro as his next stop, Adams' residence in Greensboro played a big part as well.
"I think the people here are very nice," Adams said. "They're genuine, and it just seem like a really good fit after we went for a ride along. Just the environment alone was was good enough."
Adams wants residents to know if they ever cross paths with him, he is a easy officer to work with.
"I'm easy going," Adams said. "So what you see is what you get. I think Chief can attest to that, but I'm just laid back, professional, polite and kind. Hopefully we'll be community-oriented. We're just trying to make our interactions are police-public friendly."
Adams brings a potential coworker with him to the department. His K-9 Mosley has been with him since 2017.
Mosley has experienced cancer, but Adams says she is still able to work as a K-9 dog.
"She's done everything," Adams said. "She's already certified in tracking and narcotics. Now we took off the tracking because she lost her leg to cancer in Halloween of 2023. She went through chemo, radiation, and she's she's still working. She's did awesome with the training last Wednesday, she nailed it."
While Mosley hasn't officially joined the force yet, Trams and Adams expect for her to be apart of the team very soon.
"We're really excited to be able to bring her on," Trams said. "We're going through our budget cycle, and we put the K-9 program in the budget so the Town Council has to approve it. Hopefully we'll get the thumps up and then she can start working because we need one." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a police officer joining a department and details his law enforcement background and K-9 unit, which directly relates to public safety. While there is mention of local government interactions, the core subject is law enforcement and community safety.

title: Easton man arrested after crashing, flipping car on Dover Street
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton man arrested after crashing, flipping car on Dover Street

 March 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 201
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A car flipped on its roof on Dover Street in Easton Sunday, leading to the arrest of the driver. No injuries were reported.Patrick J. Ward, 61, of Easton, was arrested after allegedly fleeing the scene, Easton police said. Ward didn't require medical treatment, according to police.
Just after 5 p.m. Sunday, authorities responded to the crash in front of the Avalon Theatre. Easton Police Department Deputy Chief Greg Wright said investigators determined Ward was traveling westbound on Dover Street in a Toyota Camry.
Wright said Ward "failed to maintain driving in the roadway" and hit the rear of a parked Tesla, which was unattended. The Camry then flipped, Wright said.
"Witnesses then described the driver to have gotten out of the vehicle and then fled on foot," Wright said.
Police say Ward was later located and arrested in the area of Brookletts Avenue. He's been charged with four separate traffic offenses for failing to remain at the scene and locate the owner of the unattended vehicle.
The wreck was an uncommon occurrence, Wright said.
"Anytime you get a vehicle (in) a car crash flipped over in a downtown where streets are relatively congested, slower speeds, it is unusual for it to happen," Wright said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cambridge man pleads guilty to assault, carrying handgun in shooting
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge man pleads guilty to assault, carrying handgun in shooting

 March 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 305
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man has pleaded guilty to two charges related to a shooting that took place at the Corner Market Exxon in Cambridge in July.Dykir Qualick Lee, 23, pleaded guilty during a hearing March 10 to first-degree assault and carrying a loaded handgun.
Dorchester County Circuit Court Judge William Jones handed down a sentence of 25 years for the first-degree assault charge and a consecutive sentence of three years for carrying a loaded handgun. All but 18 months of Lee's 25-year sentence were suspended. His entire three-year sentence was suspended.
After incarceration, Lee will have to serve five years of supervised probation.
Lee had previously been charged with 18 other charges related to the July incident, including attempted first- and second-degree murder. The state has entered nolle prosequi for those charges, meaning the state will not prosecute for them.
Lee's charges stem from a July 11 shooting. According to a news release from the Cambridge Police Department, officers responded to the Corner Market Exxon on Maryland Route 16 and Stone Boundary Road for a report of shots fired that day.
Police said that as officers were on their way to the scene, Cambridge Police learned a vehicle had left the area of the reported shooting and two victims had arrived at the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Cambridge. Police said both victims, a 19-year-old from Cambridge and a 20-year-old from Cambridge, were treated for non-life-threatening gunshot wounds.
Police said evidence was found at the scene of the shooting and at the hospital, where the vehicle — reportedly damaged in the shooting — was located. Through investigation by the police department's Criminal Investigations Division, Lee was identified as a suspect in the shooting.
With assistance from the U.S. Marshals Fugitive Task Force, the Cambridge Police Department located Lee at a home in Cambridge in August and arrested him.

title: Support and rapid response
author: Staff Writer
content:
Support and rapid response

 March 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 217
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On behalf of Double Island Volunteer Fire Department, I would like to thank Frank Gunsallus and Disaster Aid USA for their timely and unwavering support in the Helene Hurricane Relief efforts. Our area was devastated by the storm. Basic infrastructure services as of today, March 18, will still take based on estimates five months to one year to complete. Many are still homeless and struggling day to day.We are a small all volunteer fire department in western North Carolina. Limited budget resources handicap our ability to afford specialized equipment like all-terrain side-by-side vehicles.
Within 48 hours of making contact with Frank, a side-by-side vehicle was delivered to our station by Frank himself. Immediately we were able to access areas for rescue operations and ferry personnel and equipment to badly damaged locations. In some cases we had to build, cut and clear nonexistent roads and old logging roads. It took over five days to cut a path on existing roads just to get a side by side vehicle through.
Dozens of residents were transported for medical care using the machine Frank delivered to us.
It is the support and rapid response shown by Frank and Disaster Aid USA that gives hope and shores up faith in the greatness of the people of the United States of America.
DAN BUCHANAN
Green Mountain, N.C.

title: Students complete inaugural Talbot County Sheriff's Office police academy
author: Konner Metz
content:
Students complete inaugural Talbot County Sheriff's Office police academy

 March 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 481
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Students in grades 10 through 12 graduated from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office inaugural citizens police academy Tuesday night.In a 10-week course that met every Tuesday, officers provided students an inside look at the law enforcement field, teaching topics such as crisis response, bleeding emergencies and traffic stops.
Saints Peter & Paul sophomore Carson Tyree said the academy changed his perspective of police work.
"What stood out is how these guys work. It's not all fun and games," Tyree said. " … When they go into a situation, there's a lot of thinking behind it because they can't violate procedure. If they violate procedure, they can't be a police officer."
Junior Canin Parks said he took the academy to learn more about law enforcement since he is considering entering the field. His favorite week was the virtual reality simulator, during which students were posed with the virtual task of helping people in distress.
Jules Stepp, a Saints Peter & Paul junior, most enjoyed learning about Talbot County's crisis response unit, or SWAT team. Students were shown the inside of a SWAT van and learned about the materials and techniques used in situations that call for crisis response.
"It was like we were there with them," Stepp said. "We got to live vicariously through them."
Stepp said she recommends the academy to anyone interested. The academy made it clear the extreme level of detail that policing requires, she said.
"I was surprised how much detail went into every little thing, and how one little thing can cause a problem so they had to backtrack and think about what the consequences could be," she said. "And how they have to go through so many processes to get grants, peace orders, protective orders and all that type of stuff."
Following Tuesday's 10th and final class, Maj. Steve Elliott thanked the students and called them a "great group" for the first ever citizens police academy. Lt. J.R Dobson said it was a fun 10 weeks.
"I think from day one — when (Sheriff Joe Gamble) was giving you guys a lesson on when the first sheriff of Talbot County was — until now, I've seen you all loosen up," Dobson said.
Gamble thanked Lori Stepp, the grants administrator for the Sheriff's Office, for procuring a grant to make the police academy possible.
The Talbot County Sheriff's Office is now fielding applications for its second citizens police academy. This round is open to county residents 18 and older. Classes are held every Tuesday for 10 weeks beginning April 8. Applications are open until March 31.
Graduates of the inaugural Talbot County Sheriff's Office citizens police academy:
Yvonne Herrera Hernandez, North Caroline High School.
Ian Knopp, Saints Peter & Paul High School.
Eric Loredo, Easton High School.
Sofia Miller, St. Michaels Middle High School.
Canin Parks, Saints Peter & Paul High School.
Jules Stepp, Saints Peter & Paul High School.
Carson Tyree, Saints Peter & Paul High School.
Evelio Urdaneta Delgado, Easton High School.

title: Queen Anne's County man added to Animal Abuse Registry
author: Staff Writer
content:
Queen Anne's County man added to Animal Abuse Registry

 March 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Crime 
 
 226
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEENSTOWN — Troy Michael Sellman, 37, of Queenstown, has been added to the Queen Anne's County Animal Abuse Registry after pleading guilty to animal abuse charges, according to Queen Anne's County State's Attorney Lance Richardson.Sellman entered a guilty plea in Queen Anne's County District Court on Nov. 24, 2024, for failing to provide proper shelter for a Cane Corso dog, violating Maryland Criminal Law Article 10-604, Richardson said. The offense is punishable by up to 90 days in jail and/or a $1,000 fine.
In August 2024, county animal control officers responded to an anonymous tip about a dog in distress at Sellman's Thompson Avenue residence, Richardson reported. Officers found the Cane Corso tethered with a choker collar in direct sunlight without shelter or water. The dog was heavily panting in critical condition, with an external temperature of 121 degrees when the air temperature was 96 degrees.
According to Richardson, officers transported the animal to a nearby clinic where it was pronounced dead upon arrival.
Richardson said Sellman received a suspended jail sentence and supervised probation, as he was already incarcerated on unrelated charges. His probation conditions prohibit him from owning or possessing animals and require a mental health evaluation.
The Queen Anne's County Animal Abuse Registry, maintained by the county State's Attorney as mandated by County Ordinance 24-17, lists individuals convicted of animal abuse in county courts, Richardson noted.

title: Firefighters extinguish large barn blaze in Easton
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Firefighters extinguish large barn blaze in Easton

 March 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 373
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Dozens of firefighters from agencies throughout the Mid-Shore extinguished a large barn fire on Chapel Road Wednesday, a blaze which was caused by a controlled burn and took more than five hours to put out, according to officials.No injuries were reported, fire officials said, though the main barn structure was mostly destroyed.
The Easton Volunteer Fire Department was called at 10:33 a.m. Wednesday and arrived on the scene at 10:37 a.m., according to Captain Justin Jones. Most of the barn was engulfed in flames at that time, he said.
"On arrival, it was probably 75% involved," Jones said. "And with the wind conditions, spot fires were popping up all around the property. And with all the fuel load around the structure, I went ahead and hit the second (alarm) to get the manpower and equipment that I needed."
Jones said 76 personnel were on scene. It took around 200,000 gallons of water and hours of work for firefighters to handle the blaze, which was fully extinguished by 3:50 p.m.
Wood and mulch piles around the barn led to spot fires that presented a further challenge for fire crews. Excavators were brought to the scene to help pull apart the piles.
"The main challenge was getting all the piles of debris around the structure broken apart, soaked down anyway we could, and keeping all the fire in check," Jones said.
Officials say the barn and surrounding area is used by Economy Tree Service, a company based in Queenstown. Jones said personnel on the scene confirmed the fire began as a controlled burn by the tree service. It then spread, partly due to significant wind gusts and dry conditions.
Jones said he wasn't aware of any animal injuries. A cat that exited the barn structure during the fire was saved, he added.
The property is located at the 9000 block of Chapel Road, east of U.S. Route 50. It's at the site of the former Murdoch Gardens florist business and farm, according to officials.
Jones thanked the many fire departments from across the Mid-Shore that provided crucial assistance Wednesday.
"We couldn't do it without all the mutual aid from Caroline, Dorchester, the other stations in Talbot County and also Queen Anne's County," Jones said.
This report has been updated to include additional information. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Man surrenders to police after hours long standoff in Chestertown
author: STAFF REPORTS
content:
Man surrenders to police after hours long standoff in Chestertown

 March 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORTS | Section: Crime 
 
 309
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — A day-long law enforcement operation on Flatland Road ended peacefully Friday when a man experiencing a mental health crisis surrendered after firing multiple gunshots and prompting widespread community response.The incident began around 5:45 a.m. March 28, when Chestertown Police Department and Kent County Sheriff's Office responded to shots fired in the 100 block of Flatland Road. Witnesses, including neighbor Todd Hughes, reported hearing gunshots around 5 a.m., followed by someone knocking on a nearby door.
Police vehicles were first spotted in the area around 5:30 a.m., with tactical response escalating throughout the morning. At approximately 8:30 a.m., a SWAT-type vehicle with a large ram approached the house, officers repeatedly calling for the individual to come out, saying they wanted to "check on him" and were "not there to hurt him."
The extensive operation disrupted community activities. Shortly before 1 p.m., parents were notified that students on bus routes near Flatland Road and Hilltop Drive would need to be picked up from school due to safety concerns. Radcliffe Creek School, the closest school to the incident, advised keeping students indoors.
Residents in surrounding areas, including a trailer park near Sunny's Mart, were advised to stay inside.
Law enforcement personnel were observed in nearby woods, and a helicopter and drone were part of the operation.
At approximately 1:30 p.m., the subject voluntarily exited the residence and surrendered without incident. He was taken into custody and transported to a local medical facility for a mental health evaluation. Criminal charges are pending, Chestertown Police Chief Ron Dixon, lead agency on the incident, said.
Flatland Road remained closed throughout the day, with motorists advised to avoid the area. Authorities used the Everbridge alert system to notify nearby residents of the ongoing situation.
While initial police statements suggested no immediate public risk, neighbors expressed concerns about the incident's severity. The precise circumstances leading to the standoff remain under investigation.

title: Manager stole $31K from Family Dollar store
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Manager stole $31K from Family Dollar store

 March 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 374
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A judge ordered a woman to pay more than $30,000 in restitution after she pleaded guilty to a theft charge relating to her stealing from an Elkton-area Family Dollar store during a four-month period while working there as the general manager, according to Cecil County Circuit Court records.Cecil County Circuit Court Judge Cameron A. Brown imposed a three-year sentence on the defendant — Deta Marie O'Toole, 38, of Earleville — for theft of more than $25,000 and less than $100,000 on Monday and then suspended the penalty, court records show.
The judge then placed O'Toole on three years of supervised probation and ordered to pay the Family Dollar store in the unit block of Chestnut Drive $31,130, according to court records.
Earlier in the courtroom proceeding, O'Toole pleaded guilty to that felony theft offense as part of a plea bargain in which prosecutors agreed to dismiss related charges of embezzlement/misappropriation and theft scheme of more than $25,000 and less than $100,000, court records show.
Assistant State's Attorney Robert Sentman and O'Toole's lawyer, Assistant Public Defender Emily Gillis, negotiated the plea agreement.
The Cecil County State's Attorney's Office charged O'Toole by way of a criminal information that was filed against her in September, after an investigation conducted by Cecil County Sheriff's Office deputies, court records show.
O'Toole committed the thefts totaling $31,130 from Sept. 1, 2023 through Dec. 5, 2023, according to that charging document.
As general manager of the Family Dollar store on Chestnut Drive, making daily deposits of proceeds into the business' bank account was one of O'Toole's responsibilities, according to prosecutors. O'Toole, however, kept some of the cash for herself when making those bank deposits and, other times, kept all of the money for herself and failed to make any deposit, prosecutors reported.
Her Family Dollar superiors contacted authorities at an unspecified point in or after December 2023 when bank officials informed them that a deposit had not been made on a particular day and they, in turn, contacted CCSO — spurring the investigation that led to the charges against O'Toole, prosecutors said.
Also identified as a cause for that investigation, an anonymous tipster reported that O'Toole was stealing cash that was intended for bank deposits and that she also had stolen about $400 in store merchandise, prosecutors added.

title: Wind causes Grasonville house fire
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Wind causes Grasonville house fire

 April 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: News 
 
 236
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GRASONVILLE — A single-family home on Grasonville Cemetery Road was destroyed by fire Tuesday morning after wind knocked over a bucket containing wood stove embers.The fire occurred at approximately 8:21 a.m. on April 8 at a residence in the 300 block of Grasonville Cemetery Road. According to the Queen Anne's County Fire Marshal's report, the blaze caused an estimated $240,000 in structural damage and $100,000 in content loss.
The owner and sole occupant, Bert Olmstead, 73, told officials he had cleaned out his wood stove and placed the embers in a closed bucket on the front porch when wind blew it over. Olmstead was alerted by the smell of burning plastic and discovered the fire had already spread significantly before calling 911.
"And after that, the whole thing went up," Olmstead said. "I just got out as quickly as I could."
Olmstead reported losing "everything" in the fire, including his wallet and hearing aids. He is currently being assisted by family and friends while waiting to hear from his insurance company.
Forty-six firefighters from Grasonville Volunteer Fire Department and Kent Island Volunteer Fire Department responded to the one-alarm fire, which took one hour and 24 minutes to control. The fire originated on the front porch and has been ruled accidental due to the discarded wood stove ashes.
According to the Office of the State Fire Marshal, no injuries were reported and emergency responders cleared the scene by approximately 11 a.m.
