title: Community rallies to support food bank after federal cuts
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Community rallies to support food bank after federal cuts

 April 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 437
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Since news broke last week that federal cuts would deprive the Food Bank of Delaware of 19 truckloads of urgently needed food, the organization has seen a surge of new donors and an increase in visitors to its website looking for ways to help."We have gotten so much groundswell of support from people that maybe didn't even know about the Food Bank, but are learning about the Food Bank now and not wanting to see people in the State of Delaware go hungry," CEO Cathy Kanefsky said.
That community support was on full display Tuesday evening during an emergency food drive sponsored by Newark-area legislators. A steady stream of cars pulled up at the Food Bank's Glasgow warehouse to drop off food donations that were then unloaded by legislators and other volunteers.
Inside, 25 volunteers helped sort and pack food.
"Tonight has been so heartwarming to just stand here and watch all the legislators that have come out to support, and all the people that are coming with food," Kanefsky said.
Food banks across the country were left reeling last week when the Trump administration abruptly paused $500 million in funding for the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Emergency Food Assistance Program.
For the Food Bank of Delaware, from April to June alone, the canceled shipments equate to 750,000 pounds of food or 900,000 meals that would have directly benefited residents across the state.
State Rep. Eric Morrison, who has been a regular Food Bank volunteer for 20 years, organized Tuesday's food drive.
"When I learned that they are going to be losing about 50 percent of their food, everybody felt frustrated and I thought I have to do something. Somebody has to do something," Morrison said. "Tonight, we can bring in a lot of food, but we can also bring in awareness, which is really important."
One in seven Delawareans, including one in five children, are food insecure, he added.
"I think some people may have certain prejudices or misconceptions about who uses the Food Bank, but we're talking about your grandparents, your children, your next door neighbor with a disability. It's a lot of people," he said.
Morrison added that in Dover, there are ongoing discussions about how much the state will have to step in to make up for lost funding to the Food Bank and other programs affected by federal cuts.
"It's very hard right now, because with the federal administration, everything is just very day-by-day," he said. "Every day, we're waking up to something new."
Residents can visit fbd.org to learn how they can help the Food Bank.
"We're facing some interesting times, and we've all got to take care of each other," Morrison said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Point-in-time count shows Mid-Shore homelessness is up
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Point-in-time count shows Mid-Shore homelessness is up

 April 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 565
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A point-in-time count conducted in January showed a 50% rise in people experiencing homelessness on the Mid-Shore since last year, according to results released earlier this month.The count is an annual survey that measures homelessness across the U.S. This year, Mid Shore Behavioral Health's Continuum of Care team contributed by gathering data from individuals in encampments, shelters and temporary housing in Talbot, Kent, Dorchester, Caroline and Queen Anne's counties.
In addition to the 50% rise, the Mid-Shore saw a 400% rise in total unsheltered homelessness since 2024, according to the results of the count. Unsheltered homelessness involves a person living in a place not meant for habitation.
But Ashley Kessinger, continuum of care program manager, says these numbers might not accurately represent changes in homelessness on the Mid-Shore.
The number may be so high, she said, because of the difficulty of reaching people in the past due to the Shore's rural nature.
"That 400% increase, I think it has to do with the efforts that went into reaching more people (this year)," Kessinger said. "We live in a rural community, and it's different from the cities, where a lot of times people experiencing homelessness may be right on the sidewalk and in front of your stores."
According to the count, The total number of people experiencing homelessness on the Mid-Shore sits at 195, with 179 people in sheltered locations and 16 in unsheltered locations.
According to Jimmy Morris, continuum of care housing outreach specialist at Mid-Shore Behavioral Health, the count is important due to the rise of unsheltered individuals on the Shore.
"There's people that lost their homes because of medical conditions or job layoff, drug, alcohol, addiction or mental health," Morris said to the Star Democrat in January. "We are overwhelmed in these five counties."
While many issues can cause homelessness, Kessinger cites lack of affordable housing as one of the main factors.
"Housing is definitely a huge barrier that we have seen," Kessinger said. "We have funding that can place people in housing like security deposits, first month's rent and depending on the program, they can help with some additional months.
"But it has been really hard to find housing that can fit within the HUD fair market rent that we have to abide by."
Another factor Kessinger cites is transportation in Mid-Shore communities.
"Transportation may not be something that people think about right off the bat, but it's a huge need for the people that we work with," Kessinger said. "This rural community, it makes it very hard to go from one county to another. It's hard because it's so spread out, you need a vehicle, and vehicles are expensive."
Kessigner hopes that Continuum of Care can help improve homelessness in the area. Aid from the Department of Housing and Community Development with affordable housing for people experiencing homelessness will help as well, she said.
"So I know the DHCD has a really great initiative with creating more permanent housing," Kessinger said. "We have a permanent housing program, and they are basically expanding that in the state of Maryland.
"I know the governor's had a hand in that as well. I think that is a really great is a step in the right direction as far as helping to resolve a lot of the homelessness that we see on the shore. I think the emergency shelters are vital. They're very important, but what everyone needs is a safe home that they can actually afford." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While not explicitly about crime, homelessness intersects with public safety concerns. title: Fire, exacerbated by hoarding, rips through house killing two
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Fire, exacerbated by hoarding, rips through house killing two

 April 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 224
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A fire claimed the lives of two Charles County men on Thursday morning.Firefighters from Calvert, St. Mary's and Charles counties, as well as some units from Virginia, responded early April 17 to Brunswick Road in Faulkner for the report of a structure fire.
The fire was reported at 6:15 a.m. — the second of the morning for many local firefighters after a blaze devastated a La Plata home — was heavy, with smoke pouring from the structure.
Two homeowners were not accounted for, the Office of the State Fire Marshal said in a release.
Firefighters located Robert Bowling, 62, and Kim Dickens, 70, deceased in the remains of the home, the release said.
A tenant that resided on the first level of the home was able to escape uninjured, according to the fire marshal's office. Damages to the structure totaled $175,000 and another $75,000 was lost in contents.
Smoke alarms were found in the home, but it is unknown if they were working.
The bodies of the two deceased men have been transported to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner in Baltimore to determine the cause of death.
The Charles County Volunteer Fire and Emergency Medical Services Facebook page reported that there were severe hoarder conditions at the site, evidenced by photographs of items littered throughout the property.
An investigation remains ongoing to determine the exact cause of the fire.

title: Residents protest planned Royal Farms development, citing safety concerns
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Residents protest planned Royal Farms development, citing safety concerns

 April 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 328
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Bay Bridge Cove residents took to the streets in Stevensville to protest a potential Royal Farms development before a Queen Anne's County Planning and Zoning technical meeting April 16.On April 14 and 15 preceding the meeting, about a dozen residents each day from the 55-and-older community demonstrated outside their neighborhood to oppose the project, said coordinator Teresa Tamburrino.
Traffic in the area is "already contentious," she said.
A county Staff Technical Advisory Committee meeting brought together local and state agencies to discuss technical aspects of the development proposal, including representatives from the Departments of Public Works and Parks and Recreation and the State Highway Administration.
The applicant is proposing to combine three parcels at 336 Romancoke Road (Route 8) in Stevensville for a 5,154-square-foot convenience store, six gasoline fuel islands with 12 fueling positions, and a 1,248-square-foot car wash located at the rear of the convenience store.
The Queen Anne's County Planning Commission previously tabled a decision on the concept plan for another Royal Farms convenience store on Kent Island in December 2022.
The county received extensive public input regarding the project, according to Planning Director Amy Moredock. The room was packed with concerned citizens and surrounding business owners Wednesday.
Major concerns the board continued to address with the developers included traffic impact on Maryland Route 8, entrance and exit access, and architectural issues.
The proposal is not before the County Commissioners for a vote, and due to subsequent comments from the planning commission that must be addressed, the Royal Farms project is not expected to be placed on an agenda for some time, Moredock said.
Bay Bridge Cove residents and members of the Homeowners Association there plan to seek information about a potential county ordinance to prevent gas stations within 500 feet of a day care center, Tamburrino said.
Residents are also compiling data and crash statistics to prepare for the next meeting, according to Tamburrino.
More information and updates can be found on the Planning and Zoning Department section of the county website at qac.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: It takes a village: QA CARE Center goes blue in recognition of Child Abuse Awareness Month
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
It takes a village: QA CARE Center goes blue in recognition of Child Abuse Awareness Month

 April 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 275
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Highlighting April as Child Abuse Awareness Month, Queen Anne's County Child Advocacy and Resource Center welcomed community partners for an open house April 8.Formed in 2011, the CARE Center is a non-profit program formed through a partnership with the Queen Anne's County Department of Social Services, the State's Attorney Office, local law enforcement and mental health professionals.
A place to coordinate investigative, medical, mental health and legal services, the CARE Center provides a warm, child-friendly environment for collaborative services surrounding child abuse as well as providing family advocacy support for non-offending caregivers.
"It's important to celebrate the partnerships who work hard for the children in the community," said Child Advocacy Center advocate Carole Friend.
Using this collaborative multi-disciplinary approach, the CARE Center brings key professionals together under one roof to work on behalf of the best interests of the child.
The center brings all necessary officials to one place and children only have to tell their story once, Alex Sweetak, Center assistant director said.
The center is also home to wellness activities to support mindfulness and reduce anxieties, educational resources, and a family room where advocates like Friend, can meet with children in a safe, friendly environment.
From ages nine months to 17, the center works with schools to provide outreach and information and provides referrals to community agencies, she said. Even after the interviews, the Center continues to work with children and families as much as they need, according to Friend.
"It definitely makes a difference for the children in our community," said Friend.
Officials noted child advocacy has come a long way over the years and the Center stands at the forefront of allowing conversations and erasing stigma. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Caroline County animal abuse case moves to circuit court
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Caroline County animal abuse case moves to circuit court

 April 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 428
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — A Caroline County District Court case concerning a Talbot County woman charged with animal cruelty has been transferred to the Caroline County Circuit Court.Barbara Lemaire, 29, was charged in December on 34 counts of animal cruelty, including aggravated animal cruelty and failure to provide for the animals. The incident involved four dogs and five cats. One of the dogs was found dead, according to court documents.
Monday, Lemaire's case was transferred from the county's district court to its circuit court. A trial has been scheduled for July 21.
Federalsburg resident Anthony Sarro, 30, was also charged with 34 counts of animal cruelty for the incident. Sarro failed to appear in court Monday, and District Court Judge Joseph Riley issued a bench warrant for Sarro that day.
The charges stem from Caroline County Animal Control visits in early November.
According to charging documents, Caroline County Animal Control officer Diana Greenwood stated she first visited the Greensboro property Lemaire and Sarro were tenants of on Nov. 6. In her statement, Greenwood said Greensboro Police Chief Lenox Trams told her the property had not had electric or water for at least one month.
Once an eviction was performed a day later, Greenwood reportedly entered the property and observed piles of feces throughout the residence. She said she did not observe any available water source for the animals. She said there was only one litter box provided for the cats that hadn't been cleaned.
Greenwood said there was a small amount of dry food in a container, but noted animals often stop eating when they become dehydrated.
In her statement, Greenwood said two of the dogs were found in crates without food or water. She said one of the dogs appeared to be dead.
All of the animals were taken to the Caroline County Humane Society for processing. Greenwood stated the dogs drank water for multiple minutes during intake. She said two of the cats were dehydrated and she could feel their ribs.
Greenwood said that in contacting Lemaire and Sarro, Sarro reportedly told her he did not stay at the residence and the animals were the responsibility of his girlfriend, Lemaire.
Lemaire reportedly told Greenwood she was living in Talbot County and Sarro was staying at the Greenwood residence. Lemaire reportedly said she had been to the residence that morning and planned to re-home all of the pets the next day.
Greenwood said later that day, Lemaire was on the property and surrendered all the animals except one dog that she said belonged to Sarro. Greenwood said Sarro also arrived on the property but refused to speak with her. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on an animal cruelty case involving legal proceedings, court transfers, and animal welfare, which directly relates to public safety concerns. title: Caroline County police officer charged with second-degree assault
author: Konner Metz
content:
Caroline County police officer charged with second-degree assault

 April 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 273
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Caroline County Sheriff's Office Sgt. Keith Collison faces a second-degree assault charge from a domestic violence incident on Monday involving he and his former wife, according to court documents obtained by The Star Democrat.Court records allege that during an argument, Collison "positioned himself over top of her, face to face" on a bed. After attempting to "kick him off," she "choked Keith with two hands."
He then head-butted her, "resulting in a bloodied nose," court records state. He then allegedly flipped the mattress over, causing her to "roll out of the bed."
Charging documents state Collison advised officers that "he was the aggressor." Officers observed he had an abrasion on his neck and the woman had an injured nose stemming from the incident.
Collison was released on his own recognizance Tuesday. A trial date is set for June 9.
Sheriff Donnie Baker told The Star Democrat Wednesday that Collison has been suspended with pay pending the outcome of the criminal investigation. The Sheriff's Office is also conducting an administrative investigation.
Collison is one of three county officers assigned to patrol the town of Ridgely as part of a memorandum of understanding between Ridgely commissioners and county police. Ridgely has been without its own police department for more than a year, and the Sheriff's Office has filled that gap through an MOU since last July.
Baker said the Sheriff's Office will continue to fulfill the required hours of police coverage outlined in the MOU.
"To ensure no disruption of police services to the residents of Ridgely, the Sheriff's Office is fully committed to providing all agreed upon law enforcement services to the town," Baker wrote in a statement Thursday morning. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: St. Michaels approves three new police vehicles
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
St. Michaels approves three new police vehicles

 April 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 247

 ST. MICHAELS — The St. Michaels commissioners plan to invest $215,000 from this fiscal year and next fiscal year into three new police vehicles for the St. Michaels Police Department."These guys are always in need for updated equipment," Alfred Mercier, commissioners president, said.
The company that St. Michaels is buying the police vehicles through will allow the commissioners to pay for one vehicle with this year's fbudget and two in next year's budget. The town will receive all three vehicles up front.
"These are all coming out of speed camera funds that are held in a separate account, so unless there's going to be changes in the FY26 budget, this should be something that we can accomplish," Don Richardson, town manager, said.
While the budget for the vehicles is $215,000, the three vehicles will cost $146,820. The rest will be used for graphics, lights and equipment.
Jeffery Oswald, St. Michaels chief of police, credits the St. Michaels commissioners for their help getting the new vehicles.
"I would have to thank to the commissioners because they're always have the support on keeping our equipment up-to-date to match other agencies surrounding us," Oswald said. "We want to keep our emergency vehicles safe and well equipped so we can provide public safety to the town.
"Our fleet is aging, so having the cost and the liabilities of an aging fleet, so not only it will save us money on maintenance, it will provide a better look to attract officers with new equipment and new vehicles."

title: Indictment returned for man who allegedly killed girlfriend, buried her in forest
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Indictment returned for man who allegedly killed girlfriend, buried her in forest

 April 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 432
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A man charged with murdering his girlfriend is back in Charles County after being returned from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement custody.The state's attorney for Charles County advised that on Friday, April 25, a grand jury returned an indictment for Keycy Robinson Alexi Barrera-Rosa, 24, of Waldorf for the murder of Lesbia Mileth Ramirez Guerra.
The indictment charges Barrera-Rosa with first-degree murder, second-degree murder and making a false report, a release from the state's attorney's office said.
On April 2, Barrera-Rosa contacted the Charles County Sheriff's Office to report that his girlfriend, Guerra, was missing from their Waldorf residence. During the investigation, detectives reviewed video surveillance showing the victim entering their residence on March 31 but never exiting, the release said.
Witnesses reported that during the early morning hours of April 1 Barrera-Rosa and Guerra were allegedly in a violent argument.
During the afternoon of April 1, video surveillance allegedly captured Barrera-Rosa grabbing a large plastic bin from a shed in his backyard and carrying it to the back of the house, the state's attorney's office said.
Barrera-Rosa then drove his truck to the back of the house.
Cellular tower data records indicate that Barrera-Rosa traveled to Prince George's County to meet with his uncle, Rolvin Eduardo Barerra-Barerra, at a construction worksite, according to the release.
Further cellular records indicate that Barrera-Rosa and his uncle traveled to a secluded, densely wooded intersection in the area of Cedarville State Park.
Barerra-Barerra was interviewed by detectives and reported that on April 1 his nephew told him that he had killed his girlfriend by strangulation and asked for help with hiding the body, the release said.
He further stated that when Barrera-Rosa allegedly traveled to his work site in Prince George's County, the woman was already deceased and in a plastic bin in the back of Barrera-Rosa's vehicle.
The uncle, Barerra-Barerra, allegedly told detectives that he and Barrera-Rosa disposed of the Guerra's body by burying her in a wooded area near Cedarville State Park, the release said.
On April 18, Charles sheriff's officers located Guerra's body in a plastic bin buried at a location described by Barerra-Barerra and in proximity to where phone records indicated Barrera-Rosa and his uncle parked their vehicles on April 1.
On April 5, Barrera-Rosa was arrested and detained by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement for unrelated charges.
On April 22, he was transported by ICE agents and turned over to the Charles County Sheriff's Office. He is being held without bond at the Charles County Detention Center.
Barerra-Barerra has been charged as an accessory after the fact to murder in Prince George's County and is also being held without bond in that jurisdiction. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a murder case involving law enforcement investigation, legal charges, and criminal proceedings, which directly relates to public safety concerns. title: QA sheriff’s deputy struck by impaired driver during traffic stop
author: Staff Writer
content:
QA sheriff’s deputy struck by impaired driver during traffic stop

 April 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 245
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — A Queen Anne's County sheriff's deputy received minor injuries after his car was hit by another vehicle during a traffic stop on eastbound Route 50.Just after 11:15 p.m on Saturday, Deputy First Class Dustin Schulz was conducting a traffic stop on eastbound Route 50 near Romancoke Road when a vehicle, traveling at a high rate of speed, struck his patrol vehicle from behind.
According to police, the impact pushed the patrol vehicle about 10 feet forward, causing it to collide with the vehicle he had initially stopped. Both vehicles were rendered inoperable.
Sheriff's deputies investigated the crash, and emergency services responded to the scene. Schulz was taken to a local medical facility for evaluation and treatment of minor injuries.
Deputies contacted the driver of the striking vehicle, identified as Christopher Teta, 35, of Stevensville. During the interaction, deputies detected a strong odor of alcohol and observed signs of impairment. Teta agreed to perform standardized field sobriety tests, which he failed, and was arrested for driving while impaired. Teta later refused a breath test.
Sheriff Gary Hofmann said, "This serves as a stark reminder that impaired driving endangers everyone on the road, including law enforcement officers who are simply doing their jobs. This could have easily ended in unimaginable tragedy."
Teta was charged with: driving under the influence, driving while intoxicated, negligent driving, reckless driving, driving too fast for conditions, failure to obey a traffic control device and unsafe lane change.
A court date is pending for the charges. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Kent recognizes Child Abuse Prevention Month
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Kent recognizes Child Abuse Prevention Month

 May 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 244
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Kent County officials recognized the critical work of child advocacy agencies Tuesday, issuing a proclamation during Child Abuse Prevention Month that honors the local professionals helping more than 35 vulnerable children annually.The Kent County commissioners proclaimed April 25 as Child Abuse Prevention and Child Advocacy Appreciation Month during their April 22 meeting.
Department of Social Services Director Shelly Neal-Edwards accepted the proclamation alongside her multidisciplinary team and child advocacy center representatives.
Commissioner Albert Nickerson noted that the Child Advocacy Center in Kent County serves more than 35 of the county's "youngest and most vulnerable citizens" each year.
"Preventing child abuse is a community-wide responsibility," Nickerson said.
Neal-Edwards explained that effective child abuse prevention relies on partnerships among law enforcement, social services and health care officials, supporting Maryland laws that protect child victims' rights and provide essential services in public and private sectors.
She thanked the commissioners, emphasizing that everyone plays a vital role in connecting victims with resources for healing and justice.
"Child Abuse Prevention Month reminds us of the long-term devastating effects but also reminds us of the strength in the community to prevent the abuse," Neal-Edwards said.
The advocacy center planted blue pinwheels, the symbol of Child Abuse Prevention Month, in the Circuit Court courtyard. Neal-Edwards described them as representing "the carefree and joyful childhood that every child deserves."
"Let us stand together, advocate for those who have no voice and work toward a brighter future for every child in our community and our county," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: State Highway Administration to make repairs to Cambridge Creek drawbridge

State Highway Administration to make repairs to Cambridge Creek drawbridge

 May 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 CAMBRIDGE — The Maryland Department of Transportation State Highway Administration plans to temporarily close the Cambridge Creek drawbridge on Maryland Avenue for a week sometime this month for concrete repairs.Although the closure was supposed to begin the week of May 5, weather conditions caused the postponement of the work to the bridge.
Cambridge City Manager Glenn Steckman told The Star Democrat May 5 that the State Highway Administration is now considering closing the bridge the last week of May.
The closure will not impact marine and pedestrian traffic.
When crews close the bridge, the State Highway Administration's contractor, ANA General Contractors, an MDOT-certified Minority Business Enterprise, will use reflective barrels, temporary traffic signs and VMS boards to detour traffic around the project limits.
The State Highway Administration estimates the work will take a week to complete.
During the closure, motorists traveling west on Maryland Avenue will turn left on Dorchester Avenue, right on Cedar Street, right on Academy Street and back to Maryland Avenue. Motorists traveling east on Maryland Avenue will turn right on Academy Street, left on Cedar Street, left on Dorchester Avenue and proceed to Maryland Avenue.
Motorists may dial #77 on their mobile devices for roadside assistance.
For a list of all major State Highway Administration projects, go to Project Portal, or visit the homepage at roads.maryland.gov. For a look at real-time traffic conditions, go to md511.maryland.gov.

title: Atmosphere safer, more friendly
author: Staff Writer
content:
Atmosphere safer, more friendly

 May 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 217
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I actually used to live in Easton but had to move out in 2012 because of the crime. We lived in a relatively new area. But my brother was beaten half to death by a gang of teens when walking home from working at a restaurant.Later another gang of youths tried to lure my small daughter and her friends into their car by offering them candy.
My elderly mother was harassed and threatened by another group of boys while taking a walk in broad daylight. Another kid threw a sharp rock at our door which gouged it. Luckily no one was coming out of the door.
There were several other terrible things that happened, drug dealers hanging around, threats from teens who didn't even live in our neighborhood. Most of the people who lived in the neighborhood were fine; it was usually others from outside the neighborhood who liked to hang out there and cause trouble.
We moved to the country and never looked back. I have noticed, however, when I shop in Easton that the atmosphere is safer and more family-friendly since Frank Gunsallus has been Town Council president. The fact that Frank is endorsed by Sheriff Joe Gamble says a lot in his favor as someone who sees law and order as the key to prosperity.
MARY-EILEEN RUSSELL
Claiborne

title: Ramp closures to ease Kent Island traffic, impact commute times
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
STEVENSVILLE — Queen Anne's County is preparing to launch an expanded version of the U.S. 50/301 Ramp Management Program this summer in partnership with the Maryland State Highway Administration. The program, which will begin May 18, seeks to alleviate congestion on local roads and improve emergency vehicle access during peak summer traffic.
 The initiative, which will run weekends and Monday holidays from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. through Sept. 8, will close two westbound U.S. 50/301

title: Construction advances for first responder training campus
author: Konner Metz
content:
Construction advances for first responder training campus

 May 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 461
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Construction on the A. James Clark Emergency Services Training Campus is well underway — and project leaders even had the chance to show Gov. Wes Moore around the construction site last week.Brett Whitehead, president of Friends of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, has spearheaded fundraising efforts for the state-of-the-art training campus, which will be used by firefighters, police officers and EMS workers when it opens.
Whitehead said construction teams have made "unbelievable progress."
The 7,200-square-foot campus is located on Mistletoe Drive. Once complete, Easton Volunteer Fire Department Assistant Chief Daryl Caldwell said it will include a 4,200-square-foot classroom building, a burn building for search-and-rescue and active shooter simulations, and two pads for car fire and extrication training.
The burn building won't be damaged, project leaders say, since it's going to be a metal building with concrete floors and stairs. It will have movable walls to provide a variety of room configurations during trainings.
Caldwell said the training campus will keep on-duty first responders centrally located. The campus also will reduce long travel times that local first responders often incur when going to Salisbury or the western shore for necessary training.
Ground was broken in December on the project. As of Monday, significant work had been done to both the classroom and burn buildings. Whitehead said the goal of opening by the end of the year still remains.
"If weather holds up, permits get approved," he said.
Whitehead said more than $4 million has been raised, which leaves less than $1 million remaining of the project's $5 million fundraising goal.
As the name indicates, the A. James & Alice B. Clark Foundation was fundamental in fundraising efforts. Last September, the foundation donated $1 million to the training campus. Overall, the foundation has contributed $1.9 million to the project.
The project also has received $300,000 in state grant funding.
On April 29, Moore toured the training campus as part of a private visit in Easton.
Caldwell said Moore was "very attentive" and asked many questions. Caldwell, Whitehead and other members of the department, along with town leaders, were present for the governor's visit.
"Governor Moore's visit to the A. James Clark Emergency Services Training Campus site in Easton highlights his continued commitment to public safety, and ensuring Maryland is providing our law enforcement and first responder personnel with the best resources available," Moore's office said in a statement. "The governor is proud to work alongside so many local electeds and community leaders in supporting this project."
Whitehead believes the Easton training campus will be a model for future first responder training facilities where personnel can train separately or together.
"This is the only one of its kind in the Mid-Shore period," Whitehead said. "Where you have real-time training opportunities. You have all first responders training together. No other site does that in the Mid-Shore." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Vehicle break-in cases move to Talbot County Circuit Court
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Vehicle break-in cases move to Talbot County Circuit Court

 May 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 439
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Criminal cases for two Talbot County teens have moved to the Talbot County Circuit Court from the Talbot County District Court.Nihjay Greene, 18, of Trappe, and Aamad Turner, 19, of Easton, were charged at the end of 2024 for their alleged involvement in multiple vehicle break-ins and thefts that occurred at the end of December in the La Trappe Heights community in Trappe.
Greene was charged with six counts of fourth-degree burglary, six counts of rogue and vagabond, theft, malicious destruction of property, second-degree assault, resisting or interfering with arrest, and obstructing and hindering.
Turner was charged with six counts of fourth-degree burglary, six counts of rogue and vagabond, theft, malicious destruction of property and obstructing and hindering.
Monday, the state entered nolle prosequi for all of Greene and Turner's charges in the district court. This means the state will not prosecute for those charges.
In an interview Monday, Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale said the charges against Greene and Turner will be recharged in the Talbot County Circuit Court. Coale said this process is standard practice for more complex district court cases that move to the circuit court.
According to Maryland Court records, the charges against both Greene and Turner have been filed in the circuit court.
The charges stem from an incident on Dec. 30 where deputies responded to a report of an attempted vehicle break-in in the 3800 block of Seymour Drive in Trappe. According to a Jan. 3 news release from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, deputies determined after further investigation that three men wearing all black clothing and masks attempted to enter multiple vehicles, stealing various items.
Police said the same day, deputies were dispatched to Harrison Circle in Trappe, where a resident noticed three men dressed in black clothing and wearing masks looking into vehicles.
Police said the three men barricaded themselves in a residence in the 3900 block of Main Street and after a short time, deputies were able to make contact with them. Police identified the three men as Greene, Turner and a 16-year-old boy, who was not named by the sheriff's office.
In January, the Sheriff's Office said the 16-year-old was charged with the same offenses as Turner and referred to the Maryland Department of Juvenile Services, where he was released to a guardian.
The Sheriff's Office said Greene attempted to resist arrest and assaulted a deputy as he was being detained.
According to the news release, deputies found evidence during the investigation that also connected the three teens to vehicle break-ins that occurred in Easton earlier in 2024.
As of Monday afternoon, hearings or trials had yet to be set for Greene and Turner's circuit court cases. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Be responsible on the water
author: Staff Writer
content:
Be responsible on the water

 May 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 453
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Summer is a great time to enjoy local waters. Whether you're a boater, angler or water sports enthusiast on the Eastern Shore, please remember to be responsible around the water. May 17-23 is National Safe Boating Week. The Safe Boating Campaign, led by the National Safe Boating Council, offers these tips for practicing social distancing and safety while boating:Wear a life jacket. No matter what activity you have planned on the water, always remember to wear a life jacket every time you are on the water. Accidents on the water can happen much too fast to reach and put on a stowed life jacket.Make sure your life jacket is U.S. Coast Guard approved, appropriate for your water activity and fits properly. A life jacket that is too large or too small can cause different situational problems.Know state boating laws. Rules and laws can differ from state to state and violations can result in ticketing, fines or jail time.Take a boating safety course.Learn valuable tips that can help save your life in unexpected situations.Make sure your boat is prepared. There are many items that need to be checked and rechecked on any boat. Schedule a vessel safety check with your local U.S. Coast Guard Auxiliary or U.S. Power Squadrons before you hit the water. Every vessel safety check is conducted at no charge.Always file a float plan. File a float plan before you leave shore with someone you trust that includes details about the trip, boat, persons, towing or trailer vehicle, communication equipment, and emergency contacts.Check the weather, including the water temperature. Know the latest marine weather forecast prior to going out, and keep a regular check for changing conditions.Don't drink while you boat. Where the primary cause was known, alcohol was listed as a leading factor in boating-related deaths.Beware of carbon monoxide poisoning. Gasoline-powered engines on boats, including onboard generators, produce carbon monoxide (CO), a colorless and odorless gas that can poison or kill someone who breathes too much of it. Be sure to install and maintain a working CO detector, never block exhaust outlets, and always dock, beach or anchor at least 20 feet away from the nearest boat that is running a generator or engine.Keep in touch. Communication devices can be the most important piece of emergency equipment on board a vessel, especially in case of emergency. Be sure to have and know how to use at least two communication devices that work when wet, such as satellite phones, emergency position indicating radio beacons, VHF radios and personal locator beacons.
By following these tips, you can enjoy your boat, the water, sunshine and fresh air responsibly. For additional boating resources and tips, please visit SafeBoatingCampaign.com.
CAPT. BRETT M. SAUSE
USCG master licensed captain 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on boating safety guidelines, accident prevention, and responsible water activities, which directly align with Public Safety. While it mentions local waters and community engagement, the core message is about safety protocols rather than local events or environmental conservation.

title: Easton woman charged with placing swastikas on political signs
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton woman charged with placing swastikas on political signs

 May 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 564
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Friday, police charged an Easton woman for allegedly placing swastika stickers on political signs and town property ahead of Easton's recent election.Jennifer Cristaudo, 53, has been charged with 20 counts of using a hate symbol, three counts of malicious destruction of property and one count of defacing property in a race/religion crime. All counts are misdemeanors.
According to charging documents, Cristaudo allegedly placed six swastika stickers on political signs and 16 stickers with red lines through swastikas on town property, such as light poles and stop signs.
The six stickers placed on Gunsallus signs were all in "high-minority areas," according to charging documents prepared by Detective Cory Schuch.
"The placement of a hate symbol, such as a swastika on campaign signs in these areas is a clear indication that Cristaudo's motivation was to intimidate minority voters in the Town of Easton to not vote for Frank Gunsallus," charging documents stated.
Police say the placement of the stickers began in late March and continued through early May. The election was held May 6.
According to the Easton Police Department, on March 26, officers located three swastika stickers on Gunsallus signs. They reviewed surveillance video, which showed a woman driving a blue Subaru as the person placing the hate symbols.
On April 1, police discovered another defaced sign. April 28, officers found two more Gunsallus signs defaced near the Easton Amish Market.
Per charging documents, police later found 16 swastika stickers with red lines throughout town, with 10 reported on April 1 and 2, and six reported between April 30 and May 6.
According to court documents, a town official told police removing the stickers causes "permanent damage" to the signs, "rendering them unusable." The town's public works department estimated $21,000 in replacement costs.
In addition to video footage linking Cristaudo to the stickers, court documents state police found a "large roll of matching swastika stickers" in Cristaudo's residence.
Matching clothing and more stickers were found in her car, police said in charging documents.
During the campaign, Gunsallus and his then-opponent Don Abbatiello both spoke out against sign vandalism. Gunsallus told The Star Democrat in March that "these types of things shouldn't happen during a campaign."
"This act of hate has escalated the situation into a deeply troubling reality that demands our collective attention," Gunsallus wrote in a letter sent to The Star Democrat, local police and various local officials in March.
Rabbi Fred Scherlinder Dobb, interim rabbi for Temple B'Nai Israel and Satell Center for Jewish Life on the Eastern Shore, said he was "disappointed" but not "shocked" by the use of hate symbols.
"I would say Easton and Talbot County are mostly a wonderful refuge from some of that national division," he said. "But sadly, and maybe inevitably, pieces of that creep in."
Dobb said the placement of hate symbols is "utterly unacceptable" no matter the intent. "Full-on continental devastation and genocide — which is the ultimate Nazi legacy — needs to be reserved for issues far greater than Town Council," Dobb said.
Lt. Milton Orellana, special operations commander for the Easton Police Department, said Monday that the department had also received a report of a Ku Klux Klan hood being placed on a Gunsallus sign during the campaign. Police were not sure who was behind that incident.
Orellana said police are actively investigating both incidents. A preliminary hearing for Cristaudo is set for June 20.
Gunsallus declined to further comment on the situation, citing the ongoing investigation. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a criminal act involving hate symbols, which directly relates to public safety concerns. While race and diversity issues are mentioned, the primary context is the legal charges and community safety implications of the vandalism.

title: Chester man pleads guilty to father's murder
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Chester man pleads guilty to father's murder

 May 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 351
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTER — A Chester man pleaded guilty to second-degree murder Monday in the stabbing death of his father last year.Drew Bernard Meyer, 32, entered the plea in connection with the death of his father, Wayne Michael Meyer, 65, of Chester. The younger Meyer was initially charged with first-degree murder following his arrest last May.
According to police reports, Queen Anne's County deputies responded to a residence on Auckland Way in Chester at approximately 8:26 p.m. on May 17, 2024, for reports of a cardiac arrest. Upon arrival, deputies found the elder Meyer deceased under "suspicious circumstances."
"Deputies were familiar with the area due to a previous well-being check," Deputy State's Attorney Christine Dulla Rickard said during Monday's proceedings.
Further investigation revealed that Wayne Meyer had numerous laceration wounds consistent with sharp objects, prosecutors said.
The Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Criminal Investigation Unit led the investigation and identified the younger Meyer as the primary suspect.
The accused's brother provided Meyer's description and phone number, as well as information about a potential vehicle, claiming there had been an argument between Meyer and his father earlier that day, officials said.
Investigators noted that Auckland Way neighbors reported hearing yelling and screaming coming from the residence.
Through cooperation with other law enforcement agencies, authorities tracked the vehicle to Roanoke, Virginia, where Meyer was detained with bloody clothes and scratches on his hands, according to Dulla Rickard.
"Meyer had to be tracked from Roanoke, which brought logistical challenges," Queen Anne's County State's Attorney Lance Richardson said.
Maryland State Police crime scene investigators found male DNA consistent with Meyer's on knife handles in the kitchen. Blood was found throughout the house, including a dried shoe imprint, and cleanup efforts were identified through towels, Dulla Rickard said.
No signs of forced entry were found at the property, according to prosecutors.
The State is recommending 40 years, suspend all but 30 years to serve to be followed by probation. This recommendation is over the Maryland Sentencing guidelines which are 12 years to 20 years, according to Dulla Rickard.
Meyer's sentencing hearing is scheduled for July 21 at 1:30 p.m.
Queen Anne's County Circuit Court Judge Lynn Knight presided over Monday's hearing. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Anton Black's cause of death should be ruled homicide, audit finds
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
Anton Black's cause of death should be ruled homicide, audit finds

 May 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 674
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In 2018, the state medical examiner ruled that Anton Black's death at the hands of police in Greensboro was an accident. An audit report released by the state attorney general's office Thursday says the cause of death should have been ruled a homicide.The recommendation, one of dozens, comes after a four-year review of cases from between 2003 and 2019, during which time former Medical Examiner Dr. David Fowler was in office. The audit ultimately evaluated 87 cases, reclassifying the cause of death from accidental, unknown or natural to homicide in 36 of them.
"The audit also validated concerns that bias may have affected death investigations in Maryland," Attorney General Anthony Brown said in a letter to Marylanders included with the report. "Addressing those concerns benefits everyone in our system of justice — including the vast majority of law enforcement professionals who perform their duties with integrity and deserve clear, consistent standards."
The audit, led by Towson University psychology professor Jeff Kukucka, began in 2021 after Fowler's testimony in the trial of Minneapolis Police Officer Derek Chauvin sparked outcry. Chauvin, who was convicted of murder for the 2020 death of George Floyd, knelt on Floyd's neck for up to nine minutes during an arrest.
During his testimony, Fowler, who was called as an expert witness, said Floyd's death could be attributed to causes other than police restraint, including "excited delirium," a term used to describe agitation and aggression related to mental health or substance abuse that has been disavowed by leading medical authorities. Over 450 medical experts co-signed a letter to former Maryland Attorney General Brian Frosh and others condemning Fowler's testimony.
"This audit marks the beginning of a long conversation — one that must be handled with honesty, delicacy, resolve, and deep consideration," Gov. Wes Moore said in a letter included in the Thursday report. Moore went on to highlight reforms in the medical examiner's office that have been underway for several years.
The 2023 settlement of a case brought by the Coalition for Justice for Anton Black and Black's family demanded changes including a policy addressing how medical examiners handle deaths in custody, including those involving law enforcement restraint, according to the ACLU of Maryland.
The policy incorporates and models guidelines from the National Association of Medical Examiners for determining how such deaths are investigated and how examiners determine causation.
On Sept. 15, 2018, Black, 19, and a 12-year-old family friend were walking around Greensboro when Black began pulling and dragging the child, who called out for help, garnering attention from onlookers that led to a 911 call.
A chase that ensued ended outside Black's home, where Greensboro Police Officer Thomas Webster IV, off-duty Ridgely Police Chief Gary Manos, Centreville Police Officer Dennis Lannon and a civilian pinned Black against a wooden handicap ramp for six minutes while handcuffing and shackling him.
Black, who had severe bipolar depression, stopped breathing and became unresponsive after being handcuffed and shackled. He was taken to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center in Easton, where he was pronounced dead that evening.
Fowler ruled Black's cause of death was a sudden cardiac event. A later examination by a Johns Hopkins University cardiologist determined asphyxiation was the cause. No one was charged in the incident.
For those who have advocated for change in the way in-custody deaths are handled by the state since Black's death, the report released Thursday marked a potential turning point.
"This 70-page independent report vindicates what family members and communities — mostly Black and Brown Marylanders — have been saying for decades: the truth. That the entire system has been complicit in making police-involved deaths seem inevitable," said ACLU of Maryland senior staff attorney Sonia Kumar, who led the team that litigated the 2023 settlement, in a statement Friday.
An executive order issued by Moore Thursday called for the attorney general and the state's attorney's office to examine whether any cases should be reopened for investigation as a result of the report's findings. The executive order also established a task force to examine the handling of in-custody deaths.
Star Democrat reporter Lily Tierney contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on an audit of police-involved deaths, systemic bias in medical examiner rulings, and policy reforms related to law enforcement accountability. While race and diversity issues are mentioned, the core subject revolves around public safety reforms, police procedures, and justice system accountability.

title: Mother gets six years for Christmas Day fire that killed daughter, 10
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Mother gets six years for Christmas Day fire that killed daughter, 10

 May 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1001
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The mother of a 10-year-old girl who was killed in a townhouse fire near Elkton on Christmas Day 2023 has received a six-year prison term for involuntary manslaughter — an offense relating to overloaded electrical outlets, hoarding conditions and a lack of smoke detectors that contributed to the youngster's death.Cecil County Circuit Court Judge William W. Davis Jr. imposed a maximum 10-year sentence on the defendant — Theresa Ann Moats, 41 — during a May 12 courtroom proceeding and then suspended four years of the penalty.
"It was totally preventable. I'm not doubting that you love your daughter, but the care wasn't there," Davis told Moats after remarking, "This is the exact definition of a difficult case. You have the tragic loss of a young person and there his zero intention for this to happen. It's the nature of the charge."
Moats' daughter — Kyleigh Nicole Treadway — perished in the swift-moving, two-alarm blaze that started accidentally inside 317 Willow Dr. in the Winding Brook neighborhood, northeast of Elkton, shortly before 7:30 a.m. on Dec. 25, 2023.
Kyleigh, who had been sleeping in a second-floor bedroom, was trapped inside that burning townhouse after her mother, her grandmother, her two older brothers and her mother's boyfriend — Kevin Neal Summerfield, now 42 — had escaped.
Investigators reported that as many as 35 pets, mostly dogs and cats, lived inside the townhouse with the family and that the floor was coated in animal feces, saturated with urine and covered with trash, clothing and other combustibles.
Those unsanitary conditions and the hoarding situation made walking passage difficult. Those extreme conditions also exacerbated the overloaded electrical outlets marked by long runs of extension cords powering everything, including heavy-duty appliances like the refrigerator and freezer.
The investigation also revealed that Kyleigh's hair and clothing emanated the smell of animal waste every morning she arrived at Cecil Manor Elementary School in Elk Mills, where she was a fourth-grader, and that fellow students avoided her because of the pungent unpleasant odor.
In addition, the investigation revealed that the school nurse routinely washed Kyleigh's clothes and washed and brushed the girl's unkempt hair and that attempts to interact with Moats about the situation were futile.
The evidence of neglect prompted school officials to make referrals to the Cecil County Department of Social Services, after Kyleigh moved with her family from Delaware and started attending that school, court records show.
"It was the saddest fact pattern I've ever read," Davis commented from the bench Monday before sentencing Moats. "Her existence seemed to be miserable and her demise was miserable. It does make me want to cry."
Moats will serve her six-year term in a Maryland Department of Corrections prison. She was taken into custody inside the courtroom directly after sentencing. The judge gave Moats credit for 424 days that she already served, initially as a pre-trial jail inmate and later on house arrest on a $50,000 unsecured bond.
She tearfully addressed the judge moments before sentencing.
"Living without my daughter has been like a mental prison. I miss her. I can't hug her. I can't play games with her. Life is dull. She was the shining star of the family. Kyleigh was everything to me . . . I can't look at her picture. I wish she was here," Moats said.
In addition to the six-year prison term, Davis ordered Moats to serve five years of supervised probation once released. The judge ordered her to submit to any mental health treatment and counseling deemed necessary.
Assistant State's Attorney Gavin Patashnick sought the full 10 years of incarceration for Moats, whom he accused of minimizing her gross negligence. The judge agreed with Patashnick's assessment of Moats' mindset.
"The defendant flatly refuses to accept any responsibility . . . The house was in shambles . . . Kyleigh didn't have any friends. No one would touch her. Her only friends were teachers. This child was essentially forgotten," Pataschnick told the judge.
The prosecutor remarked that Kyleigh "died horribly" because of the squalid dwelling conditions that caused the blaze and then fueled it. The state medical examiner attributed Kyleigh's death to smoke inhalation and burns over 90 percent of her body.
"She did not die peacefully. She had soot in her mouth, smoke in her lungs. She burned. She was breathing in gases," Patashnick outlined.
As for his recommendation of the maximum 10-year sentence, Patashnick told the judge, "I'm here to stand up for this girl."
Moats' lawyer, Assistant Public Defender Emily Gillis, recommended that the judge sentence her client to time served, approximately 16 months. Gillis categorized the townhouse fire that killed Kyleigh as a "tragic accident" and reported that Moats has been suffering — and will continue to suffer — from the loss of her daughter.
"She lives with that. Parents aren't suppose to bury their children," Gillis told Davis.
Court records indicate that two Cecil County Department of Animal Services officers went to 317 Willow Dr. on Dec. 20, 2023 — five days before the fatal fire there — and impounded 14 dogs and four cats that showed signs of neglect and abuse after receiving a complaint.
After impounding the 18 animals, officers, "planned to make a report to Child Protective Services, as the children in the home were subjected to poor living conditions," according to court records.
At Monday's sentencing, Gillis questioned why Social Services did not remove Kyleigh and her minor sibling from the dwelling at that point and arrange for foster care or a similar program.
"There was no shelter plan, no safety plan . . . The Department of Social Services failed. They (social services) would have had Kyleigh with them if they had done their job properly," Gillis asserted.
In January, as part of a plea deal, Moats entered an Alford plea to involuntary manslaughter, the most serious charge in the case. In an Alford plea, the defendant maintains his or her innocence but, at the same time, he or she does not dispute the incriminating evidence possessed by the state.
Prosecutors, in return, agreed to drop 11 related charges against Moats, including reckless endangerment and neglect of a child. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a criminal case involving a preventable fire caused by unsafe living conditions, leading to a child's death. This directly relates to public safety due to the hazards and legal consequences. While health and neglect aspects are present, the primary context is the safety failure and criminal justice outcome.

title: Tornado touches down in Dorchester Friday
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Tornado touches down in Dorchester Friday

 May 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 218
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DORCHESTER — According to the National Weather Service, an EF-1 tornado originated in Dorchester County at 6:52 p.m. on Friday, May 16.Serious damage occurred to a line of trees along Rhodesdale Vienna Road, where the tornado formed. Several trees were uprooted and snapped at the trunk.
"There was really extensive damage in multiple areas in Northern Dorchester and I'm told in Delaware as well," said Dorchester County Council Vice President Mike Detmer.
The tornado continued along Indiantown Road, where it left little damage, until reaching Eldorado Sharptown Road, where the storm continued to damage trees.
The most destruction occurred in Galestown, where the tornado reached its peak width of 600 yards, lifting an elongated farm building completely off of its foundation. Trees were uprooted, snapped and twisted from their foundation, damaging homes and power lines.
"Miraculously, there were no injuries," Detmer said.
The storm then crossed over into Sussex County, Delaware damaging more trees and destroying the roofs of two commercial structures in Laurel.
Detmer was impressed with how the Dorchester County community responded to the disaster. "I mean Public Works worked until 3 that night and hit it again the next morning," he said.
Residents lost power until the following afternoon and are continuing to work with the county, the volunteer fire service and utility companies to fix damages and clean up debris.

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man pleaded guilty earlier this month to third-degree sexual offense of a child.Trevor Holland, 22, entered a guilty plea for the sexual offense charge on May 5. Judge Karen Dean handed down a 10-year sentence with all but 18 months suspended.
According to a Cambridge Police Department press release after his arrest last October, police determined Holland had a sexual relationship with a 13 year old.
Holland had previously faced eight total charges: two counts of second-degree rape, two counts of sexual solicitation of a minor and two counts each of third- and fourth-degree sex offense. The state entered nolle prosequi for seven of those charges, meaning the state will not prosecute for them.
According to court records, the victim's mother provided an impact statement as a state exhibit. Holland and others provided character statements as defense exhibits.
Holland will be registered as a Tier II sex offender and placed on five years probation. He is conditioned not to have any contact with the victim or the victim's family, among a list of other conditions.

title: Solar panel fire damages Chestertown home
author: STAFF REPORTS
content:
Solar panel fire damages Chestertown home

 May 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORTS | Section: Local News 
 
 292
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — A fire originating from roof-mounted solar panels damaged a two-story home in Chestertown in early May, according to fire officials.The Chestertown Volunteer Fire Company responded to a structure fire in the 22000 block of Great Oak Landing Road around 5:30 p.m. on May 2, finding flames visible from the roof area surrounding solar panels, the department reported.
"Due to the location and timing of the incident, there was a delayed response," said Chestertown Volunteer Fire Company Chief J. Darling, who arrived at the scene with Kent EMS Paramedic 11.
First responders initially used garden hoses from the property and a neighboring home to combat the flames before additional units arrived. A second alarm was called due to staffing needs and the size of the house, bringing in additional resources including a tanker task force, though some were later deemed unnecessary, according to fire officials.
Fire crews deployed two hand lines upon arrival, with one targeting the roof fire and another addressing flames in the attic. The fire was contained to the second-floor attic and the section of roof containing the solar panels, the fire department said.
The Maryland State Fire Marshal's Office determined the cause was related to the solar panels. Tesla, the apparent manufacturer of the system, was notified, and representatives met with homeowners at the scene.
No injuries to civilians or firefighters were reported.
Eight volunteer fire companies and emergency services from Kent and Queen Anne's counties responded to the incident.
Officials from the fire department advised, "As more homes install solar panels, it's important for homeowners to understand the potential fire risks and how to reduce them. While solar panels are generally safe and highly regulated, like any electrical system, they can pose hazards if improperly installed, damaged or affected by environmental factors." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 16-year-old charged with attempted murder for incident in Federalsburg
author: Konner Metz
content:
16-year-old charged with attempted murder for incident in Federalsburg

 May 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Caroline

 FEDERALSBURG — A 16-year-old is being charged with attempted murder after allegedly stabbing a woman in a Federalsburg parking lot, according to police.The incident occurred just before noon on Monday, the Caroline County Sheriff's Office said in a press release. The juvenile allegedly stabbed the woman multiple times during an altercation.
The 16-year-old suspect, who was not publicly named, is charged as an adult with attempted first- and second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment, and possession of a dangerous weapon with intent to injure.
Police also arrested Franky Florestal, 29, and charged him with two counts of accessory after the fact to attempted first-degree murder.
Florestal, a Federalsburg resident, posted $5,000 unsecured bond following a bail review Thursday, according to court records. A preliminary hearing is scheduled for June 16.
The juvenile is being held without bond at the Caroline County Detention Center, police said.
The woman, 20, sustained life-threatening injuries but is now in stable condition, police said.
According to the Sheriff's Office, police in Seaford, Delaware responded to a local hospital where the woman was dropped off with multiple stab wounds. Per investigators, Florestal and the 16-year-old "transported the victim to the hospital before fleeing the scene."
The Caroline County Sheriff's Office, at the request of the Federalsburg Police Department, is actively investigating the incident. Anyone with information is asked to contact 410-479-2515 or info@carolinesheriff.net.

title: Cambridge looks to implement traffic safety pilot programs
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Cambridge looks to implement traffic safety pilot programs

 May 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 260
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — During a Cambridge City Council meeting May 19, the council agreed to implement more traffic safety pilot programs this year.After an inordinate number of resident complaints this year regarding speeding and pedestrian safety, commissioners plan to address the problem by installing temporary safety measures that Commissioner Brian Roche says he'd like to eventually make permanent.
Some of these measures include changing intersections to four-way stops rather than stop lights and installing raised crosswalks.
Cambridge created the Traffic and Safety Committee in 2021, and the city ran its first traffic safety pilot program in 2022.
According to Roche, who is also a member of the Cambridge Traffic and Safety Committee, pedestrian crashes increased significantly in 2020 while people were staying home as a result of Covid-19.
"People were caught going 80 miles per hour in neighborhoods," Roche said.
After the city implemented its first traffic safety pilot program at the intersection of High and Church streets, external consultants verified that the program reduced speeding and other traffic concerns.
"Data's important, but in most cases, people have to see it," Roche said.
Between now and the next City Council meeting, commissioners will select one or two areas in their wards they would like to address. Then, city staff will begin implementing traffic safety measures.
Roche says he is anxious to get residents' feedback on this year's pilot programs and that he understands it will be a transition for some.
Roche says they have the resources for the program and are ready to get underway as soon as possible. "Summer is the perfect time to do it," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
