title: Local K-9 units work to overcome retirements from cannabis law
author: Konner Metz
content:
Local K-9 units work to overcome retirements from cannabis law

 May 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 917
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In just a handful of months, K-9 Knox is making an impact at the Easton Police Department.The nearly 2-year-old black lab completed training in January. In 2025's first quarter alone, she was deployed 17 times, making six drug arrests alongside her handler, Pfc. Mark Schinault.
"She has that drive for her reward, her toy after she does a good scan," Schinault said. "That means the world to her, so she's very driven to work."
Knox is part of Easton's new guard of K-9s. Last year, three dogs trained in marijuana detection were forced into early retirement due to the legalization of recreational cannabis use legalization in Maryland, which took effect July 2023.
Easton is not the only agency looking to rebuild its K-9 team in the wake of the legislation. Across the state, law enforcement agencies are working to fund and fill their K-9 units, which serve crucial roles not only in deterring crime, but also in connecting with the community.
Police officers largely agree that dogs trained to sniff marijuana can't be used to detect drug offenses any longer, nor does the dogs' expertise hold up in court.
"I really didn't want to go down the road because I didn't want to be challenged in the courtroom," Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said.
Knox joined K-9 Waylon in Easton, and soon two other young dogs not imprinted on marijuana will fill out the town's K-9 unit. Lt. Tim Larrimore said it has been a "complete rebuild" for the unit since the law passed.
Trained dogs can sometimes cost around $14,000, Larrimore said. Younger, untrained pups are significantly less, though they require major time commitments for training and certification.
Across the state, the work of K-9 dogs — depending on their training — often includes drug sniffing, tracking of suspects or missing subjects, and explosives detection. Knox is certified in drug detection and on her way to certification in tracking.
Schinault and Knox completed more than 60 hours of one-on-one training before she was certified in drug detection. Easton opted to go with untrained dogs to save costs and build rapport between K-9s and officers.
While Maryland K-9s are no longer sniffing for marijuana, Larrimore says their work is more important than ever in combating drug offenses.
"This odor of marijuana was enough before 2023 to give us probable cause to search. Now that's out," Larrimore said. "So now you need the ability to smell something that the human nose isn't necessarily good at detecting. It's the dog that gets you there."
PLAYING CATCH UP
Kent County Sgt. Scott Lockerman has a passion for not just his K-9 partner, Khari, but for all police dogs across the state. He is president of the Maryland Police K9 Foundation, a nonprofit that helps police agencies buy, train and protect their four-legged workers. The foundation paid for one of Easton's new dogs.
Lockerman said that after the legalization of cannabis, there was roughly a 60-40 split of agencies that could quickly get their K-9 units back on track versus those that were more affected by unexpected retirements. But he said progress is being made across all departments.
"Most of the agencies were able to replenish the dogs," Lockerman said.
At the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office, one K-9 retired early after the cannabis law was passed, while multiple dogs retired shortly before. The agency worked ahead to bring in replacement dogs not trained to detect marijuana so the state legislation didn't present too many challenges.
"We saw it coming," Sheriff James Phillips said. "It was on the horizon."
Six K-9s currently work for the Dorchester Sheriff's Office. Three can assist in patrols and narcotic detection, two work in narcotics only, and one bloodhound specializes in tracking. Phillips said the office has adequate funding to fill its seventh and final spot for a K-9 trained in detecting explosives.
Funding often comes from grants, local donations, organizations such as the K9 Foundation and county councils. Phillips said it's "mind-boggling" how generous people have been in donating dogs to the Sheriff's Office.
In addition to purchasing the dogs, agencies pay for safety equipment (like bulletproof vests) and health payments. Departments are also on the hook for vet costs incurred by retired dogs, per state law. For a retired K-9, departments could pay up to as much as $2,500 a year, capped at $10,000 per dog.
Larrimore, the Easton lieutenant, says that hasn't yet presented a major funding challenge, though it could down the road.
"It hasn't hit us yet," he said. "These dogs are just retired last year. They're young, they're healthy."
COMMUNITY IMPACT
When the highly-skilled dogs aren't working a case, they're often out in the community showing more of their friendly side.
In Dorchester County, Sgt. Steve Twilley says the K-9 unit bridges the gap between the Sheriff's Office and the community. The dogs especially help police build trust with kids.
"Next thing you know, that kid's come to you for help instead of lashing out or doing something at school," Twilley said.
Schinault and Knox attended a recent Coffee with a Cop event this spring. Schinault said they're very involved with community policing efforts.
Phillips and Twilley say the same is true in Dorchester County. Whatever dollar amount is spent on police dogs, Phillips says, comes back to the Sheriff's Office "10 times over because of the relationships that we build with the kids and the people."
"I think an agency that's trying to do today's police work and doesn't have the K-9 ability out there, I don't think they're a full police agency," Phillips said. "I think it completes the police agency by having the K-9s." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on local law enforcement's K-9 units adapting to cannabis legalization, emphasizing their role in public safety, drug detection, and community policing. While local government aspects are mentioned, the core theme revolves around law enforcement operations and public safety initiatives.

title: K-9 Murph adjusts to retirement after cannabis legalization
author: Konner Metz
content:
K-9 Murph adjusts to retirement after cannabis legalization

 May 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 297
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Cpl. Joseph Schinault still remembers the first time his K-9 partner Murph tracked down a suspect.The Belgian malinois and German shepherd mix located a residence in the Doverbrook Apartments an unarmed robbery suspect ran to with stolen items. It was the dog's first tracking mission and far from his last.
Starting in 2018, Murph served as an integral part of vehicle searches and the Easton Police Department's crisis response unit.
But Maryland's legalization of recreational cannabis use put an end to Murph's career in 2024, Schinault said. Two other Easton K-9s trained to detect marijuana also retired.
"It was a huge hit to our unit," Schinault said.
The police department is filling its K-9 spots with a new guard of police dogs. Meanwhile, Schinault has moved up the ranks and is no longer a K-9 handler. But he still looks fondly on his time working alongside Murph.
"It is truly an honor to work with them," Schinault said of the skilled dogs.
Murph, 7, still lives with Schinault and his family. He's become the "best of friends" with Schinault's son, who is just six months younger than Murph.
Schinault said it took a while for Murph to adapt to staying home instead of jumping in the police car when it started. "He lives to have a purpose," Schinault said.
Schinault's younger brother and fellow Easton police officer, Mark, is the handler of one of Easton's new K-9s, Knox. Joseph Schinault says it's amazing what K-9s can do, emphasizing the importance of police dogs in solving crime.
"Who's to say we (would've) ever solved that?" he said of Murph's first tracking.
For the Easton police officer, having a partner like Murph was a source of daily motivation.
"There's not a day that you bring a K-9 to work that they don't want to work," Schinault said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Man gets five years for Thanksgiving Day stabbing of stepson
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Man gets five years for Thanksgiving Day stabbing of stepson

 May 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 548
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A man who stabbed his adult stepson following Thanksgiving dinner in November 2023 at a residence near Elkton received a five-year prison term on Thursday, according to Cecil County Circuit Court records.Cecil County Circuit Court Judge Cameron A. Brown imposed a maximum 10-year sentence on the defendant — Ernest Anthony Vuocolo, 64 — for second-degree assault and then suspended all but four years of the penalty, court records show.
In addition, Brown imposed a consecutive one-year sentence on Vuocolo for carrying a dangerous weapon with intent to injure.
The judge also imposed a concurrent four-year sentence on Vuocolo for reckless endangerment.
Brown ordered Vuocolo to serve three years of supervised probation after completing his five-year term in a Maryland Department of Corrections prison.
A jury convicted Vuocolo of those three charges in March after a two-day-long trial. The jury, however, acquitted Vuocolo of the criminal case's most serious charge, first-degree assault, a felony offense that carries a maximum 25-year sentence.
Assistant State's Attorney Gavin Patashnick prosecuted Vuocolo, who was represented by Elkton-based defense lawyers Tina Harris Schlecker and C. Thomas Brown, and Brown presided over the trial.
The defense maintained that Vuocolo acted in self-defense and that he was at a disadvantage during the confrontation with his stepson because Vuocolo has a history of medical issues, including suffering multiple heart attacks, and that he is 20 years older than his stepson. Vuocolo testified in his own defense.
The incident leading to Vuocolo's convictions and five-year prison term occurred at approximately 10 p.m. on Nov. 23, 2023 at his residence in the unit block of Stirrup Drive after a family Thanksgiving dinner, police reported.
Vuocolo assaulted his 41-year-old stepson when the stepson confronted Vuocolo regarding "sexual comments" that Vuocolo purportedly had made about his stepson's wife, according to court records.
An ambulance crew drove the victim to Christiana Hospital in Delaware, where doctors treated him for a stab wound to one side of his chest, court records show.
Cecil County Sheriff's Office deputies rushed to the Stirrup Drive residence at 10:14 p.m. Nov. 23, 2023, after receiving a complaint regarding a "physical domestic involving a knife," police said. Deputies found the victim "bleeding heavily" from his left side, police added.
Family members who witnessed the incident told investigators that Vuocolo assaulted the victim with a knife during an argument, according to court records. At the scene, deputies recovered the knife, which investigators described as being about six inches long with a "thick blade," court records show. (At trial, the term "field clever" was used to describe the knife.)
Because Vuocolo complained of chest pain at the scene, an ambulance crew drove him to ChristianaCare's Union Hospital in Elkton, where doctors treated him before releasing him back into direct custody of police, according to court records.
During an interview conducted by CCSO Det. Joseph Laspina at Christiana Hospital, the victim alleged that Vuocolo had made sexual comments about his wife on Nov. 21, 2023 — two days before the stabbing occurred, according to court records.
The victim told investigators that he confronted Voucolo about those purported comments after Thanksgiving dinner and that he requested an apology from him, court records show. The victim told investigators that, at that point, Vuocolo attacked him with a knife, stabbing him in the side of his chest while holding him in a headlock, according to court records. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Altair Apartments residents chained in Friday
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Altair Apartments residents chained in Friday

 May 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 399
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Friday, residents of the Altair Apartments were given a notice that strict parking and gate access measures would be in place beginning at 4 p.m.Altair management chained and bolted the fencing at the complex, preventing residents from entering or leaving and causing concern among residents and emergency officials.
"The concern was that there was not an emergency exit or an evacuation route for the residents," said Cambridge Commissioner Shay Lewis-Sisco, who represents the ward where Altair is located.
Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd said he had no prior knowledge that the complex would take these measures and gave management 30 minutes to remove the chains. Altair staff complied and removed the chains but kept the gates closed, according to Lewis-Sisco.
Altair Apartment staff did not respond to a request for comment.
According to the notice distributed to residents, the measures were put in place for an unauthorized "Freaknik" event scheduled to take place in the area.
Eight arrests were made at a Freaknik event held at the same location last year. Police said in a news release following the 2024 event that officers deployed pepper spray and departmental-issued tasers "to affect arrest and to keep hostile crowds back from officers."
Though this year's event was cancelled, police maintained a heavy presence in the area for the next few days. Todd said the increased presence was due to social media rumblings of a large crowd for the "Freaknik" event. He said the department wanted to ensure the safety of residents and visitors.
"You know, our main goal and our presence, which we always try to keep our presence in all of our higher crime areas or where we've experienced major crimes to keep our residents safe and that's our number one goal and our number one priority," Todd said.
However, Lewis-Sisco said many Ward 2 residents felt differently about the police presence. "The increased police presence and safety precautions that were put in place and implemented on Saturday definitely made residents feel inferior," she said.
Traffic diversions and police presence made navigating the area difficult, Lewis-Sisco said. Some residents informed Lewis-Sisco that they went the entire weekend without medication or aid because health care workers could not reach them due to the gates being closed.
"I think the other part was that residents were infuriated that these precautions were taken for an event when there has been unresponsiveness about complaints that regard their living conditions," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: HOMICIDE: Fatal shooting under investigation in Queen Anne's
author: Staff Writer
content:
HOMICIDE: Fatal shooting under investigation in Queen Anne's

 June 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 379
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEENSTOWN — Route 213 (Centerville Road) John Brown Road and Lloyds Meadow Lane has reopened following an ongoing fatal shooting investigation.At approximately 1:15 a.m. on June 1, deputies from the Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff responded to reports of gunfire in the 1500 block of Centreville Road. Prior to law enforcement arrival, a large party had been held at a residence in the area.
According to a statement released by the sheriff's office, witnesses reported that upon hearing gunshots, attendees fled the scene. Deputies located three individuals suffering from gunshot wounds. One victim was pronounced deceased, and the other two victims were transported to area hospitals, where they remain hospitalized.
Mid-day Sunday, police confirmed Christopher Parsley, 19, of Centreville is the deceased victim. Police said they would not release the names of the other two gunshot victims at this point in the investigation.
Through witness interviews, investigators believe the suspect or suspects were present at the party before the shooting occurred.
Dispatch reports indicated that at 1:19 a.m., emergency medical teams, including units from Talbot and Caroline counties and two Maryland State Police helicopters, were dispatched to the scene. At 1:35 a.m., EMS personnel advised a Mass Casualty Incident response. By 2:06 a.m., the incident was placed under control, with EMS and fire units clearing the scene shortly afterward.
Sheriff Gary Hofmann expressed his condolences: "Our thoughts and prayers are with the family of the victim whose life was tragically taken, as well as with those who were injured. This kind of violence has no place in our community. We are working diligently to identify and apprehend those responsible. I encourage anyone with information to come forward, your help could make all the difference in delivering justice for these families."
There is no suspect in custody at this time, Public Information Officer Kaitlyn Briselli said.
The Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office is leading the investigation. Anyone with information related to this incident or the identity of those involved is urged to contact the Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff at Sheriff-Info@qac.org or by calling the Anonymous Tip Line at 410-758-6666.
Further updates will be provided when released by the investigating authorities.
This story was updated at 10:10 a.m., June 1. This story was updated again at 2:11 p.m. with the name of the deceased.

title: Trial begins for Cambridge man charged in fatal shooting last October
author: Konner Metz
content:
Trial begins for Cambridge man charged in fatal shooting last October

 June 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 491
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Testimony began Monday afternoon in the jury trial for a Cambridge man charged in the shooting death of a 26-year-old man last year.Jo'Mir Norman, 18, is charged with first- and second-degree murder, among other offenses, in the fatal shooting of Virgil Simms on Oct. 20, 2024.
On Monday, the jury heard opening statements from Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard, the lead prosecutor, and defense attorney Margaret Fox, as well as testimony from witnesses.
Norman sat at the right of Fox dressed in an all-gray suit. He faces nine total charges, three of which are felony charges — the first- and second-degree murder counts and a count of first-degree assault.
Leonard recounted the "senseless killing" in which she said Norman and another shooter acted together to murder Simms on Pine Street, firing many rounds at Simms before fleeing the scene. She said no matter who landed the fatal shot, they are both responsible for the crime.
"One doesn't get exonerated because they had better or worse aim," she said.
Leonard told jurors to expect lots of video evidence and expert testimony about how surveillance cameras work. Prosecutors are also expected to bring forward "distinctive clothing" worn by Norman on the day of the murder as evidence.
Fox argued the state will present no forensic evidence nor an eyewitness placing Norman at the scene.
"The state's case is not resting upon direct evidence. ... It's completely circumstantial," Fox said. "This case comes down to what you can see with your eyes," the defense attorney added.
Leonard and Fox's arguments to the jury both acknowledged a hiccup in the early days of the murder investigation — the misidentification of the other main suspect. Initially, police charged then-15-year-old Brian Wongus Jr. in connection to the murder.
Maryland State Police announced the arrests of Norman and Wongus in an Oct. 28 press release. But Wongus was misidentified by police, the attorneys said.
An MSP spokesperson said Tuesday that "in consultation with the Office of the State's Attorney in Dorchester County," charges against Wongus were dropped in late October or early November.
In the courtroom Monday, Fox looked to poke a hole in the state's case, telling the jury that prosecutors are depending upon "the same video evidence that led to the misidentification of somebody."
Leonard said "police readily and quickly" discovered the misidentification. Surveillance cameras linking Norman to the crime stand true, she said.
"All of the evidence always pointed at Jo'Mir Norman," Leonard said.
Prosecutors brought three witnesses to the stand Monday afternoon: a police officer and EMT who responded to the shooting, as well as Simms' mother Yolanda Hernandez.
Hernandez provided a brief but emotional testimony as prosecutors asked her about her son.
Hernandez said she and Simms had grown closer since he had two young children. She said he liked to cook, grill and joke around. "He was a decent guy," Hernandez said.
Jurors are expected to hear from a number of expert witnesses in the coming days. The trial is scheduled to run through Thursday.

title: Transcript reveals final words from Dali crew before Key Bridge collapse
author: LIV BARRY obarry@chespub.com
content:
Transcript reveals final words from Dali crew before Key Bridge collapse

 June 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LIV BARRY obarry@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 887
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Just five minutes prior to the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge on March 26, 2024, crewmen aboard the Dali ship were conducting business as usual.At 1:06 a.m., the ship's pilot communicated to one of the Dali's tugboats: "I like my chances if you want to take off."
"Alright — all done here. (Have) safe trip," the tugboat Bridget McAllister responded.
Less than 20 minutes later, around 1:25 a.m., the Dali's command center was sent into chaos as the vessel lost power.
A transcript released by the National Transportation Safety Board in April, which was first reported by The Baltimore Banner on Monday, notes the first 25 minutes of the Dali's voyage as unremarkable.
However, the initial power outage, signified in the transcript by a sound "similar to Automatic Power Change Over Circuit" and multiple blaring alarms that continued throughout the collision, threw the crew into a state of alarm.
What followed the power outage is a series of internal and external communications between Dali crew members, the Dali's tugboats, the Maryland Transportation Authority Command Center. To better lay out the events leading to the collision, The Dundalk Eagle has organized the communications between calls for external help, attempts to lower the anchor and attempts to use bow thrusters.
CALLS FOR HELP
Immediately upon losing power, the pilot asked the second officer and helmsman if they had steering, to which both responded yes.
As the crew attempted to maneuver the ship away from the Key Bridge, the pilot communicated to the second officer and helmsman again at 1:25:24 p.m.
"(Just) let me know if you can't steer," the pilot said.
Seconds after the pilot's command, another sound similar to an automatic power change is noted in the transcript. The pilot then communicated with the AMP Pilot Command Center.
"@[AMP Pilot Dispatcher] have them shut down the Bay Bridge. I just lost steering — not the Bay Bridge — the, uh ... Key Bridge," the pilot said.
At 1:26:10 a.m., the helmsman reported that they were "swinging to starboard." Soon after, the pilot can be heard asking for a "mac boat," referring to the Dali's two tugboats, the Bridget McAllister and Eric McAllister.
"Calling the Mac boats — anybody out there?" the pilot asked at 1:26:38 a.m. Just seven seconds later, the Eric McAllister responded.
"Hey Eric [IMO 9707413] it's the Dali — I need ya over here quick. I've uh just lost power (heading to the Key Bridge)," the pilot said.
Simultaneously, as the pilot called the Eric McAllister, the pilot's command center contacted the MDTA.
"No there's a vessel — I'm calling for the pilot. There's a ship heading toward the Key Bridge. He lost steering. We need to stop all traffic on the Key Bridge," the pilot's command center said to the MDTA Command Center at 1:26:57 a.m.
As the captain attempted to lower the anchors, the training pilot made a call over very high frequency (VHF) radio to alert other ships at 1:27:25 a.m.
"Security call. Security call. Container ship Dali has lost power. Approaching the Key Bridge — I repeat — the container ship Dali has lost all power approaching the Key Bridge — Dali," the training pilot said.
This was the final external warning call.
ATTEMPTS TO LOWER ANCHOR
After the pilot's command center asked to close traffic on the bridge, the captain can be heard asking the forward crewman to let go of the port anchor.
"Sir I cannot * * *," the forward said. According to the NTSB, the rest of the forward's response could not be made out over shouting on the ship's bridge, marking the obscuring with asterisks.
The captain again called for the anchor to be lowered at 1:27:14 a.m., shouting, "Fast, fast let go port anchor."
As the pilot attempted to use the bow thrusters, the captain continued to command the forward to lower the anchor, imploring the crewman until he received another response at 1:27:55 a.m.
"I tried to open the break. Break is not able to open up," the forward said.
At 1:28:42, the frontman told the captain that he opened the break.
"Let go. Let go," the captain said in response.
After not receiving a response, the captain checked back in with the forward at 1:29 a.m. exactly before delivering what would be the final words before the crash is marked on the transcript: "Let go, yes."
LAST-RESORT ATTEMPTS
The pilot made one final attempt to prevent the ship from colliding with the Key Bridge.
At 1:27:42, the pilot asked the crew if the ship had bow thrusters. According to The Baltimore Banner, the device helps guide ships laterally while docking.
After the crew confirmed to the pilot that the ship had bow thrusters, the second officer delivered devastating news: "No. It's not working."
"Not working #," the pilot said, with an expletive marked by a pound sign in the transcript. These would be the pilot's final words before the collision, which is estimated by the transcript to have occurred at 1:29:06 a.m.
What followed was a story that Dundalk knows well: six construction workers dead and a span that connected Baltimore left twisted in spirals of steel.
As the collision is still under investigation, around 12 Dali crewmen remain in Baltimore. This June marks a year since the crew was allowed to leave the ship, as cleanup efforts, expired visas and maritime law complicated their departure.
To read the full transcript, including the events before and after the Dali lost power, visit the docket at ntsb.gov/investigations/Pages/DCA24MM031.aspx 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details the tragic bridge collapse involving the Dali ship, focusing on the crew's final communications and the safety failures leading to the accident. While it involves local events, the primary emphasis is on public safety concerns, investigative transcripts, and the broader implications for maritime safety, aligning most closely with 'Public Safety' rather than localized government or news topics.

title: Cambridge City Council talks traffic safety
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Cambridge City Council talks traffic safety

 June 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 241
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — City Council member Brian Roche is on a mission to make the streets of Cambridge safer with a new roll-out of traffic safety pilot programs.The city introduced the pilot programs in 2021. The programs effectively curbed traffic hazards in targeted areas through raised crosswalks, four-way stop signs and bump-outs also known as curb extensions.
After continued complaints regarding traffic concerns, council members plan on tackling the issue through another round temporary pilot programs that may become permanent if effective.
"A majority of our emails are about traffic calming needs," said council member Brett Summers.
Each council member identified two to three areas of concern in their ward at the council's meeting Monday. Roche then compiled the information from council members and residents into a spreadsheet that lists the streets and intersections of concern along with a map that pinpoints those locations.
Some of the areas identified by the City Council include Robin Street at the intersection of Pine and Center streets, Stone Boundary Road and Route 16, and a multiple others.
Council members expressed major concern over lighting issues on Route 16, which is owned and maintained by the state. The council has provided the state with a resolution to this issue, but has not received a response. The council did not say what that resolution is.
At the next regular City Council meeting on June 9, council members will vote to determine which areas will be the best candidates for the pilot program. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Sheriff Hofmann addresses homicide investigation as community offers support for family
author: HANNAH COMBS
content:
Sheriff Hofmann addresses homicide investigation as community offers support for family

 June 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS | Section: Crime 
 
 375
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — In a Wednesday interview, Queen Anne's County Sheriff Gary Hofmann emphasized that the homicide investigation into the shooting death of 19-year-old Christopher Parsley remains the department's primary focus.Parsley was shot and killed on Sunday, June 1, near a residence on Centreville Road while attending a bonfire with friends.
"We're dealing with a homicide here, and that's going to take precedence," Hofmann said. He noted that many attendees at the party have not come forward, and some individuals may be hesitant to share information out of fear of legal consequences related to underage drinking or drug use. "Let us be clear: We are not seeking to prosecute anyone for those actions," he said.
Hofmann encouraged the public to provide any information, stressing that failing to do so could hinder the investigation. "This shouldn't happen here," Hofmann stressed, "We're not going tolerate this happening here."
Having information that could aid in the investigation and withholding it, is definitely not helpful to the family of individual that you were friends with, Hofmann reiterated. It is hope that the person/s involved in this incident will soon be held accountable.
The Sheriff also warned that social media platforms like Instagram and Snapchat have exacerbated the problem, with parties being posted online drawing unwanted attention.
In addition to the ongoing investigation, Metro Crime Stoppers of Maryland is offering a cash reward for information leading to the arrest of the person or persons responsible for Parsley's death. All tips submitted through Metro Crime Stoppers are anonymous and eligible for a reward. Anyone with information is encouraged to call 1-866-7LOCKUP or submit an anonymous tip online at www.metrocrimestoppers.org.
"Christopher wasn't just a 'good kid' — he was the best," said friends of the family. "He was the kind of young man who would drop everything to help a friend, offer a smile to a stranger, and light up every room he walked into." A GoFundMe page has been created to help with funeral expenses, help support his family during this tragic time, and to pay off his truck loan, a symbol of something Christopher was proud of.
The Sheriff's Office continues to work diligently to solve the case and bring those responsible to justice. "We're very hopeful and committed to finding closure for this family," Hofmann said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Delaware park closed due to safety concerns, hazardous conditions
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Delaware park closed due to safety concerns, hazardous conditions

 June 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 262
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A Newark park will be closed for the foreseeable future after a recent inspection found "significant safety concerns and hazardous conditions," city officials said.One of the city's lesser-known parks, Coleman Park is located near the Maryland border, bounded by Valley Road and the Country Hills and Briarcreek neighborhoods. The main entrance is in Country Hills.
The 8.5-acre park contains walking trails but otherwise is preserved in its natural state.
The inspection found that the tree canopy near the entrance to the park consists of many black locust trees that are structurally compromised by fungal decay and pose a significant risk of falling.
The walking paths are eroded and surrounded by dense thickets of greenbrier, multiflora rose and poison ivy.
"These thorny species have overgrown the area and become entangled with large woody debris from fallen trees and limbs," City Manager Tom Coleman wrote in a memo to city council. "Significant land clearing and tree removal must be completed before we can reopen the park."
The city does not have funding for such work in the 2025 budget, according to Coleman, who did not provide any indication as to when the park might reopen.
The city's five-year capital improvement plan includes plans for broader improvements to Coleman Park, such as building a turf/meadow area, planting new trees and possibly paving the trails. However that $50,000 in funding, which is dependent on a state grant, is not budgeted until 2027.
Coleman Park was created in 1993 when Newark purchased the land for $180,000 and annexed it into the city. It is named for the family that previously owned the property. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cambridge man found not guilty of murder in shooting last year
author: Konner Metz
content:
Cambridge man found not guilty of murder in shooting last year

 June 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 775
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — After just over an hour of jury deliberation Thursday afternoon, a Cambridge man was acquitted of charges in connection to the fatal shooting of 26-year-old Virgil Simms last year.Jo'Mir Norman, 18, was found not guilty on all counts, including first-degree murder, assault charges, and firearm and handgun charges. Family and friends of Norman embraced outside the court room. Norman's father, Joseph Norman, said his son was wrongly accused and said it was relieving to hear the not guilty verdict.
During the trial, Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard relied on video evidence to piece together Norman's whereabouts and the clothes she said he wore the day of the murder.
On Oct. 20, 2024, Cambridge Police Department officers responded to the area of Pine Street just after 7 p.m. for reports of a shooting. Investigators determined 19 rounds were fired by two different shooters. Simms was pronounced dead on the scene, sustaining a gunshot wound to the chest.
On Thursday, jurors rewatched videos that had been closely examined during the four-day trial. Leonard argued camera evidence showed Norman and the other shooter flee from the scene and enter a house on Camelia Street, where clothes allegedly worn by Norman the day of the murder were found by investigators.
But defense attorney Molly Fox told jurors that prosectors relied too heavily on circumstantial evidence and had glaring holes in their arguments, such as the fact that surveillance video meant to bolster clothing and vehicle evidence jumped from a 1 p.m. convenience store video to a 6 p.m. video an hour before the shooting.
Fox called the state's case against Norman "a circus" like she's never seen before.
"There was a lot they didn't even try and present," Fox said in an interview after the verdict was announced. "It just seemed like it was thrown together last second."
Fox cited a lack of direct witness testimony, missing videos and issues during the discovery process leading up to the trial as reasons why "the evidence did not point toward my client."
Prosecutors encountered some specific challenges during witness testimony.
On Monday, an EMT who responded to the scene testified that she saw Simms with a gunshot wound to the head, though it was established during trial that he sustained a chest wound. And during the trial, a state's witness who allegedly dropped off the two shooters the day of the murder did not confirm that Norman was one of the men she drove that day. Leonard called that witness "young" and dealing with a "very packed court room."
"Don't be fooled by the shaved head here today," Leonard noted to jurors, referencing Norman's buzz cut Thursday compared to longer hair he had when arrested.
Fox also reminded jurors of a key mistake in the early days of the murder investigation: Maryland State Police wrongly arrested then-15-year-old Brian Wongus Jr. at the same time they charged Norman in October.
Attorneys on both sides acknowledged police misidentified Wongus as one of the shooters. An MSP spokesperson said Tuesday that charges against Wongus were dropped in late October or early November.
Leonard said the evidence investigators used when wrongly charging Wongus was "very different" from the evidence presented against Norman at the trial. She said jurors received "no testimony at any time that Jo'Mir Norman was misidentified."
Fox said while video evidence can be useful, it can also lead to wrong identifications.
"You have nothing more than what they had when Brian Wongus was arrested," Fox told the jury.
The lead-up to Thursday's verdict and the reaction afterward was emotional but civil on both sides, with family of both Simms and Norman attending. When the trial began Monday, Simms' mother Yolanda Hernandez took the witness stand.
Hernandez provided a brief but emotional testimony as prosecutors asked her about her son.
Hernandez said she and Simms had grown closer since he had two young children. She said he liked to cook, grill and joke around. "He was a decent guy," Hernandez said.
Leonard told The Star Democrat after the verdict that she respects the jury but was "disappointed" in the outcome. She declined to comment further, citing an active case against the man police arrested after misidentifying Wongus, 19-year-old Jahmere Bryan.
Bryan, from Cambridge, faces the following charges in connection to the Simms shooting: first- and second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, use of a firearm while committing a felony, and three other firearm and handgun charges.
A May 19 hearing for Bryan in the Dorchester County Circuit Court was postponed. A jury trial is scheduled for next month, but Leonard said Thursday that trial is expected to be pushed back due to a change of Bryan's defense attorney.
This report has been updated to correct the date of the fatal shooting. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Man pleads guilty to 2021 murder of Trappe woman
author: Konner Metz
content:
Man pleads guilty to 2021 murder of Trappe woman

 June 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 302
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A man has pleaded guilty to the murder of a Trappe woman that took place on Christmas Eve in 2021.Mauricio Ibarra Juarez, 33, entered an Alford plea on May 23 for a first-degree murder charge in connection to the killing of Marta Merina over three years ago.
Judge Philip Cronan handed down a life sentence with all but 75 years suspended.
"I am confident that Mr. Juarez will spend the rest of his life in prison for this heinous crime," said Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale in a press release.
An Alford plea allows a person to maintain their innocence while acknowledging the state had enough evidence to obtain a conviction. Five other counts levied against Juarez — including second-degree murder and first-degree assault charges — will not be prosecuted.
The morning of the murder, police responded to Howell Point Road in Trappe for a reported shooting. Merina, 33, was found outside her home and pronounced dead on the scene.
A few days later, following an investigation, Maryland State Police issued a warrant for Juarez in connection to the murder.
Per the recent state's attorney's office press release, investigators traced a phone found at the scene to Juarez. They also worked with police in Virginia — where Juarez lived at the time — to match a vehicle driven by Juarez to what was found on nearby security footage the night of the murder, according to court documents.
Juarez was located by Mexican authorities for an unrelated crime in Oaxaca, Mexico in 2022. The U.S. Department of Justice's Office of International Affairs worked with Mexican prosecutors to request Juarez's provisional arrest. Extradition was granted later that year, but was deferred pending completion of Juarez's sentence in Mexico.
Last October, Juarez was extradited to Maryland. His 75-year sentence will credit back to February 2023. Juarez is being held without bond. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cambridge man faces murder charges for 2024 shooting
author: Konner Metz
content:
Cambridge man faces murder charges for 2024 shooting

 June 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 340
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man is facing charges including first-degree murder in connection to the fatal shooting of 26-year-old Virgil Simms last year.Jahmere Bryan, 19, is charged with first- and second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, use of a firearm while committing a felony, and three other firearm and handgun charges.
Bryan is one of two shooters police allege are responsible for the death of Simms on Oct. 20, 2024, in the area of Pine Street. Nineteen rounds were fired and Simms sustained a fatal gunshot wound to the chest.
On Thursday, though, a jury acquitted the other main suspect, 18-year-old Jo'Mir Norman, of all charges in relation to the case. Prosecutors relied heavily on video evidence and clothing in trial, but dealt with challenges during witness testimony and the fact that the murder investigation started off with a significant mistake.
Bryan was arrested by police last November, but it came after police misidentified 15-year-old Brian Wongus Jr. as one of the two suspects. Maryland State Police wrongly arrested Wongus and charged him with first-degree murder, among other offenses. Charges were dropped in late October or early November, according to an MSP spokesperson.
The misidentification of Wongus as one of the two shooters came up in Norman's trial this week. Attorneys on both sides acknowledged the error, though offered different opinions on how the evidence leading to the misidentification compared to the evidence presented against Norman.
As for Bryan, a jury trial previously slated for mid-July was postponed. A future trial date has not yet been released.
Charging documents allege Bryan fled from the shooting scene just after 7 p.m. on Oct. 20, 2024. Investigators reviewed surveillance video and allege clothing worn by Bryan earlier that day was found in a house on Camelia Street where the suspects allegedly fled to after the shooting.
According to court documents, investigators interviewed a witness who identified Bryan and provided his street name, "Krunch." The witness saw Bryan on Camelia Street before the murder, per court documents.
Bryan is being held without bond at the Dorchester County Department of Corrections.

title: UPDATE: Man killed in Cambridge shooting on Sunday
author: Konner Metz
content:
UPDATE: Man killed in Cambridge shooting on Sunday

 June 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 232
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Police are investigating a shooting that killed a Delaware man Sunday night in Cambridge.Just after 8:30 p.m. Sunday, officers responded to the 900 block of Camelia Street and found the man lying outside of a vehicle in a driveway with a gunshot wound to his head, according to a press release from the Cambridge Police Department.
Alyson Elien, 23, of Seaford, was identified as the victim. Police attempted life-saving measures. Elien was later transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center in Cambridge, where he was pronounced dead, police said.
According to the press release, detectives identified a suspect using video surveillance. Authorities also recovered a handgun at the scene.
"Criminal charges are being applied for at this time and the suspect is actively being sought after," the department stated.
The suspect's name was not released as of Monday afternoon. Per the release, police are attempting to identify others involved in the incident.
Police said video footage shows a "large amount of community members" around the victim but not rendering aid to him. Video shows people took items from the victim's vehicle and "appeared to be taking items off of the victim as he laid there with nobody attempting to help," the release said.
Sunday's fatal shooting was the first homicide in Cambridge this year.
The Cambridge Police Department is asking anyone with information regarding the shooting to call (410) 228-3333.
This report has been updated.

title: St. Michaels suspends Zoom meetings after 2nd security incident this year
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
St. Michaels suspends Zoom meetings after 2nd security incident this year

 June 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 341
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — St. Michaels commissioners announced live Zoom meetings for the town government would be "discontinued for the foreseeable future" after second security incident in 2025.Both incidents involved disruptions caused by meeting attendees, town officials said.
"Both the February and June incidents were the same or similar with intentions of disrupting the open format forum," Town Manager Don Richardson said in a email to the Star Democrat on Tuesday. "A Zoom attendee took control of the screen and displaying an indecent video clip along with hate text. They also took control of audio playing loud sounds and noises. Staff caught this quickly, shut down the online display, and the Historic District Commission completed the meeting as schedule.
"On Friday, the town issued the Constant Contact to notify the public that meeting participation would be changing to keep our town meeting safe and accessible."
The announcement came after the June 5 meeting, where the Zoom feed was interrupted. Commissioners President Alfred Mercier described the contents of the video displayed by the person disrupting the meeting as "propaganda associated with foreign countries and explicit graphic presentations of individuals."
"This came with a lot of thought because we certainly want full transparency in what we present and how we present to the town, and we certainly want to be cognizant of the fact that everything that we present and the information that we display out there needs to be communicated effectively to our to our residents," Mercier said to the Star Democrat on Tuesday.
St. Michaels is not the only town that have stopped Zoom meetings, the Town of Greensboro also stopped recording meetings via Zoom after an incident in February.
"These graphic obscenities that have have been occurring not only in St. Michaels, but in many towns throughout the U.S., have presented a challenge for a lot of these towns," Mercier said.
St. Michaels plans to record the meetings as they occur and to have a question and answer session for residents to ask questions. Town officials are currently looking for more secure softwares to conduct town meetings. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Video of presumed ICE arrest sparks confusion, fear in Cambridge
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Video of presumed ICE arrest sparks confusion, fear in Cambridge

 June 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 705
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Immigrant communities are living in fear after arrests of immigrants have taken a new shape under the Trump administration.A Facebook video of unmarked vehicles with federal agents in bulletproof vests and ski masks arresting four men on Maryland Avenue off Route 50 in Cambridge has been circulating throughout the community.
"You know, it's definitely something we knew was coming, but we didn't know it was gonna be handled this way," said Julie Martinez, who recorded and uploaded the video to Facebook.
Residents and commenters of the video believe these agents to be Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials. The Department of Homeland Security has not responded to The Star Democrat's request for details about the incident.
Since President Donald Trump's inauguration, ICE raids have looked different. Washington, D.C., immigration attorney of over 25 years Matthew Famiglietti said the legal gray area has grown significantly due to rapid policy changes such as getting rid of safe spaces like churches, courts, hospitals and schools.
"Talking about what's legal and what's not legal, that's changed quite a bit since Trump," Famiglietti said.
Trump campaigned on stepping up immigration enforcement, promising to deliver the largest mass deportation in American history. ICE arrests have increased by 25% since he took office, according to the most recent ICE detention data.
To make this possible Trump signed five immigration-based executive orders on his first day, instated enforcement and structural changes within federal agencies like Customs and Border Control and ICE, conducted mass arrests including in safe spaces, and enacted travel bans from 12 countries, according to the White House's website.
Famiglietti said ICE agents and the Department of Homeland Security are under no legal obligation to let local law enforcement agencies know of their actions.
Cambridge police Capt. Antoine Patton and Dorchester County Sheriff Jimmy Phillips both said they were not aware of the arrests made on June 4.
The Cambridge Maryland Police Department's official Facebook made a post regarding the arrests saying, "We have received several phone calls and inquiries regarding photos passed through social media showing subjects being detained/arrested within the city limits by law enforcement. The law enforcement in the pictures is not anyone associated with the Cambridge Police Department, and we have no knowledge of the incident(s) that took place."
Martinez said around 7:15 a.m. June 4, four unmarked cars surrounded a work truck and began making what she called "unclear" announcements through a speaker while arresting the four individuals on Maryland Avenue.
"As you can see in the video, they didn't even give them time at all to even explain or say why you're getting pulled over," Martinez said. "It was very quick, so when I saw it, my first thing was 'oh my gosh, there's no way this is happening.'"
Famiglietti said ICE agents do not have to show their faces or ride in marked cars, but they have to wear some sort of identifying detail. Martinez said the agents' bulletproof vests said "Police," but that was the only identifying mark.
Martinez said she immediately pulled out her phone and began recording. She said she's always recording because "you never know what could happen, especially right now."
The video quickly caught traction, with 554 shares, 176 reactions and 135 comments on Facebook. The post made its way to the family members of the detained individuals, who, according to Martinez, were not aware of the arrests before the video.
Out of the 135 comments on Martinez's post, multiple alluded to further ICE actions around Cambridge. However, those actions were not verified.
Famiglietti said concerned residents and those looking for family members who may be detained should call their senators and representatives for information.
"That's the No. 1 thing," he said.
On June 14, demonstrations will be held across the nation on what protesters are calling "No King Day" in response to the administration's immigration policies and the actions of ICE agents. Protests are planned in Easton and Cambridge on that day, according to posts made on social media.
Martinez said the immigrant community has to be especially careful right now.
"Drive at the speed limit. Do everything you're supposed to be doing," she said. "You know we contribute to this country a lot, and unfortunately, we can't stay home. We can't do much but to keep going forward, but definitely stay more on the low."

While federal immigration policies are discussed, the immediate impact on local residents' safety and the role of law enforcement align most directly with 'Public Safety.' title: North East mom, boyfriend charged in murder of toddler
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content:
North East mom, boyfriend charged in murder of toddler

 June 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: News 
 
 498
 Words 

 Read News Document

 NORTH EAST — Maryland State Police have charged Darrian Lynelle Randle of North East with first and second degree murder in the death of her 3-year-old daughter, Nola Dinkins.Her boyfriend, Cedrick Antoine Britten, 44, from North East, is charged as an accessory. He's being held in the Cecil County Detention Center on a $75,000 bond.
Dinkins body — described in charging documents released Thursday as "consistent with an emaciated child and were completely wrapped in saran (sic) wrap" — was found in the unit block of Dune Drive in North East inside a blue suitcase.
Randle and Dinkins were living in Britten's home when the alleged crime took place, according to police. The pair shared a room in the home on Elk Nest Road
Charging documents indicate Randle beat the child 15-20 times Monday with a belt. When the child fell to the ground, she noticed the child was no longer breathing.
"Randle stated that Britten attempted CPR ... but eventually realized (Nola Dinkins) was deceased," the documents filed in Cecil County District Court of Maryland read.
Becoming upset, Randle told police that the body was placed in Britten's vehicle — a BMW — and the couple drove around for awhile.
"Randle stated that once they returned to the residence she placed (the body) in a dark blue suitcase belonging to Britten," the court documents read. The suitcase was placed on the third step of the basement stairs overnight. She checked on the suitcase one time, then asked Britten to take it from the house.
Britten told investigators he took the suitcase away, later sending Randle a photo of a park.
On Tuesday, Randle told New Castle County Police the child had been kidnapped from her vehicle at gunpoint; a story later determined to be false. While searching for Dinkins, police questioned Britten, who was described as having "little to no reaction" to word that the child had been reported missing.
At the home, investigators noticed a distinct odor of bleach. Blue nitrile gloves were found during a search; one pair in a downstairs trash can and another pair in the room that Randle and Dinkins shared.
Investigators searched Perryville Community Park in response to the photo of a park, but ultimately located Dinkins' body — still in the suitcase — on a vacant lot near Britten's home.
Randle, being held by New Castle County Police on a $1 million bond for a charge of filing a false police report, is now facing numerous charged in Maryland including first- and second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment, child abuse resulting in death, neglect, failure to report a child death and unauthorized disposal of a body.
Britten is charged with eight counts including accessory after the fact to first- and second-degree murder, neglect of a minor, unauthorized disposal of a body, and failure to report a child's death.
The body has been taken to the Office of the Medical Examiner for an autopsy and positive identification.
Police officials have yet to say when Randle will be extradited from Delaware to Maryland. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Attorney general visits Easton to honor first responders at annual celebration
author: Konner Metz
content:
Attorney general visits Easton to honor first responders at annual celebration

 June 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 433
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — First responders across different Talbot County agencies were honored Thursday in Easton by local residents, business leaders and Maryland Attorney General Anthony Brown.Bluepoint Hospitality Group hosted the fifth annual First Responders Celebration, closing down North Washington Street temporarily on Thursday afternoon to pay thanks to the county's police officers, firefighters, EMTs and other first responders.
"These people put their lives on the line so that we can live in a civil and safe community," said Bluepoint Hospitality owner Paul Prager.
The event was headlined by Maryland Attorney General Anthony Brown, who called the Talbot County first responders — paid or volunteers — "heroes."
"When others run away from danger, you run toward it," Brown said. "From volunteers who respond to dangerous house fires in the middle of the night, to police officers who take drugs, and guns and bad people off our streets, to emergency medical service personnel who rush people to the hospital for life-saving care, our first responders are the backbone of public safety and the cornerstone of our communities."
During the brief ceremonies, Ed Forte, vice president of the Friends of Easton Volunteer Fire Department, revealed a new rendering of an in-construction training campus to Easton Fire Chief J.R. Dobson.
The A. James Clark Emergency Services Training Campus, located on Mistletoe Drive, will be 7,200 square feet and provide state-of-the-art training opportunities for all first responders.
As the rendering showed, a building on the training campus will be named after Paul Prager and his wife, Joanne. The Pragers donated $500,000 to the project.
Forte said Thursday that $4.5 million has been raised in the last two-and-a-half years, nearly all of the project's $5 million goal. Project leaders hope for the campus to open by the end of this year.
"(It's) taken many, many years; many, many people; many hours; many ideas," Forte said. " … Raising the money was the hardest thing."
After the event, Brown said in an interview he's impressed with the coordination between the different first responder agencies in Talbot County.
"Often people think small, rural community on the Eastern Shore, 'how busy does it get?'" Brown said. "But clearly the numbers show that they're busy. It's important to stand ready. The facility that is going to be built is going to help them do that."
When asked afterward if the First Responders Celebration is becoming a tradition, Prager had no hesitation.
"It's gotta be, absolutely," Prager said. "These people do thankless jobs. And there's not a whole lot you can do to enable them to make their lives better. So I think if you at least just say thank you, that goes a long way." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Police arrest 3 in connection to Easton bank robbery
author: Konner Metz
content:
Police arrest 3 in connection to Easton bank robbery

 June 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 335
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Police have arrested two Cambridge men and an Easton woman in connection to a bank robbery earlier this month.On June 2, Easton police asked for assistance identifying a man suspected of robbing BayVanguard Bank on Idlewild Avenue. Police on Wednesday announced the arrest of 31-year-old Deondre Williams, of Cambridge, along with two others alleged to be involved — 21-year-old Makhyla Jenkins, of Easton, and 20-year-old Jeremiah Carter, of Cambridge.
All three are charged with first- and second-degree assault, armed robbery, firearm use in a violent crime, handgun on person, reckless endangerment, theft and conspiracy. Williams and Jenkins face handgun in vehicle charges, while Jenkins and Carter are charged with neglect of a minor.
Police say around 2:30 p.m. on June 2, officers reported to BayVanguard Bank for a robbery. According to a press release, employees provided police with a description of a man who investigators later identified as Williams.
Williams demanded money from a bank teller and brandished a firearm, police said. He allegedly took a sum of money then fled on foot toward Idlewild Park. No employees were injured.
Easton police worked with the FBI to gather surveillance footage that allegedly shows Jenkins, the Easton woman, driving the two Cambridge men to Idlewild Park. Police say Williams left the vehicle, later returned with the money and was driven by Jenkins to Kelley Gibson Street, where he and Carter exited the vehicle.
Investigators obtained a search warrant for a residence on Kelley Gibson Street they say is linked to the two Cambridge men. Police found "further evidence of their involvement in the bank robbery," a press release states.
Carter was apprehended on Monday in Easton after a foot chase, police said. Williams and Jenkins were arrested Wednesday in Cambridge and Easton, respectively.
All three were taken to the Talbot County Detention Center and are listed as being held without bond. Carter had a bond hearing Tuesday and has a preliminary hearing slated for July 7. Williams and Jenkins have bond hearings on Friday and preliminary hearings on July 14.

title: Knocking on people's doors at night is bad idea
author: GLENN MOLLETTE
content:
Knocking on people's doors at night is bad idea

 June 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GLENN MOLLETTE | Section: Columns 
 
 552
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The recent murder of Minnesota state Rep. Melissa Hortman and her husband, Mark, has dropped jaws across the country. The couple was gunned down in their home by someone masquerading as a police officer. Obviously, he was able to fool them long enough to kill them. Moments before and only five miles away he had visited the home of Minnesota state Sen. John Hoffman and his wife, Yvette, shooting them multiple times, most likely thinking he was leaving them for dead.At this writing they are expected to survive.
Such an intrusion scares people because criminals copy the acts of other criminals. How do we know if a legitimate policer officer is knocking on our door whether it's the middle of the night or the middle of the day?
Two officers should make the visit and announce themselves as police loud and clear. They should clearly state the reason for the visit before entering a home. Flashlights or outside lighting should be on to help with visibility and identification. Uniforms should be visible with badges and IDs. The knock pattern should be a firm knock or doorbell press then they should announce themselves as police again. There should be a 30-second to one-minute wait for a response from the resident before knocking or ringing the doorbell again. For a search warrant, the warrant should be shown before entry. Your local sheriff or city chief of police may have a different protocol, and it needs to be made known.
Unfortunately, this still doesn't keep a criminal from copying the protocol to achieve their criminal endeavor.
I believe 99 percent of Americans are good law-abiding people. However, no one wants to be caught off guard by a criminal invasion. Rep. Hortman would not have wanted to mistakenly shoot a real policer officer who might have been doing his job to protect her. Sadly, the man was there to kill her and her husband. He succeeded. This is why door knocking after dusk is a bad idea unless you have a pre-arranged appointment, and everyone knows who everyone is and the reason for the visit.
When I was 12 years old, I was home alone while my parents were at church. About 8 o'clock it was pitch black with darkness and a man started knocking on our front door. He then went to the back door and started knocking. He then came back to the front door and continued pounding the door. I was terrified. I didn't know who it could be. I loaded our 12-gauge shotgun and aimed it at the front door in fear he would soon be coming through.
Like a fool, I opened the door but knew the outer storm door was locked. I had the shot gun close by. The man asked if my dad was home to which I replied, "No. he's gone to church." The man then inquired if my father still had hogs for sale to which I replied, "Yes, but you'll need to speak to him about that." The man said he would come back later.
To this day I don't know who that man was, but I'm glad I didn't shoot him. It's too bad Rep. Hortman or Sen. Hoffman didn't shoot the man knocking on their door in the middle of the night.
Knocking on doors at night is a bad idea. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on safety protocols for home security, discusses a criminal act involving police impersonation, and provides guidance on verifying official visits. These elements directly relate to public safety concerns and crime prevention measures.

title: Firefighters handle major town house blaze in St. Michaels
author: Konner Metz
content:
Firefighters handle major town house blaze in St. Michaels

 June 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 291
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Firefighters across the Mid-Shore worked together to put out a large town house fire in St. Michaels on Saturday. No injuries were reported.Around 1:20 p.m. Saturday, the St. Michaels Fire Department responded to a fire at a six-unit town house complex on Martingham Circle. Assistant Chief Phil Jones said a second alarm was requested. Agencies from Talbot, Caroline, Dorchester and Queen Anne's counties assisted, with at least 70 people on the scene.
The fire was caused by an electrical failure with an HVAC system in the attic, according to the Maryland Office of the State Fire Marshal.
Jones said two of the six units will be "displaced for some time." A third unit incurred small fire damage, a fourth unit sustained water damage and the other two units were unharmed, he said.
The fire marshal's office estimates $1 million in damages to the structure and contents.
First responders were able to extinguish most of the fire in the first hour of efforts. Jones said firefighters were on scene for over four hours Saturday to fully handle the blaze. They had to be mindful of the hot conditions.
"With the heat, it makes it twice as hard for us," Jones said. "Usually a firefighter can only work five to 15 minutes in the heat" without taking a break, he added.
All firefighters were required to receive a medical check on their vitals, Jones said. Crews went through over 20 cases of bottled waters.
Jones emphasized that the firefighters on scene were all volunteers. He expressed appreciation for the responding units from surrounding counties, as the additional manpower was necessary for such a hot day. Jones said there was good cooperation with the homeowners and between fire agencies.
"We all work together to complete everything," Jones said.

title: Maryland's new standards on worker safety bring added protection amid heat wave
author: Konner Metz
content:
Maryland's new standards on worker safety bring added protection amid heat wave

 June 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 571
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — With a major heat wave in full swing, Maryland's new heat safety standards for workers are being put to the test, including in Easton.Dustin Otto, construction division manager for the Town of Easton, helped create a health safety and prevention plan for Easton's public works employees. It outlines the steps the town will take to protect its outdoor workers during periods of extreme heat, incorporating the state's new standards.
Otto says whether it's the use of 32-ounce water bottles, additional breaks or monitoring heat indices more, the added layers of protection work toward a common goal.
"It's all about safety," he said.
Last September, new heat stress rules from Maryland Occupational Safety and Health, which operates under the Department of Labor, went into effect for all workplaces with a heat index of 80 degrees or higher.
Statewide discussion of heat safety peaked last summer when Baltimore Department of Public Works employee Ronald Silver died from heat illness on the job.
The new state standards require employers to develop heat-related illness prevention and management plans. Those plans must detail how employers will protect workers in 80 degree heat or higher and how employees will receive proper training and preventative measures.
Department of Labor Secretary Portia Wu said the new regulations stem from legislation passed by the General Assembly a couple years ago.
"These are common sense. They rely on tools we all know about," Wu said. "But having a written plan and making sure you're training everyone on it is really important."
In addition to shade and hydration requirements, the following rules are in effect for outdoor workers:
In a heat index above 90 degrees and below 100 degrees, workers must rest at least 10 minutes every two hours.
In a heat index above 100 degrees, workers must rest at least 15 minutes every hour.
Easton officials say they're used to observing best practices regarding hydration, shaded areas and rest times.
"We've always had that in place," Otto said.
But the town's new heat illness safety plan spells it out more clearly and makes sure employees receive the proper training and education on working in the heat.
The town builds on the state standards by requiring the 15-minutes-per-hour rest at at heat index of 98 degrees or higher, along with providing water to employees.
Otto emphasized that the town's public works and construction employees perform work critical for Easton residents. He noted the toughest days come when asphalt paving happens and that the department leaders take extra precautions on those days to protect staff.
The state standards also place an emphasis on acclimating employees not previously exposed to heat, or those who spent a period of time away from working in high temperatures.
Employers must monitor acclimating employees through regular checks as well as create a schedule of "gradual introduction and alternative cooling" measures.
"You really need to ramp up people's exposure to heat," Wu said.
Wu added that the state is providing guidance to industry leaders with specific questions for areas of work that may be unique. The MOSH rules don't apply to "emergency operations and essential services."
Wu said the state also provides a template of a plan for businesses, especially helpful to smaller operations who may not have dedicated staff to put together the required heat illness prevention plan.
"I think businesses want to do the right thing. Hopefully it's helpful to them to have these tools now," Wu said. " ... We thought giving really concrete guidelines actually makes it easier to know what to do." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Body sits in Greensboro yard for hours due to traffic delay, town says
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Body sits in Greensboro yard for hours due to traffic delay, town says

 June 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 237
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — On June 22 at about 1:57 p.m., the Greensboro Police Department were dispatched to an apartment on Maple Avenue in Greensboro in reference to an unattended death.According to a statement from the Town of Greensboro, a male was found lying face up on the stairs of his apartment.
When emergency personnel arrived, they moved the man, who was not identified by the town, from the residence and stairs to a front yard area near the driveway so they could conduct a full analysis. He was pronounced dead at about 2:06 p.m., the town said.
Greensboro Police Department requested dispatch to notify a forensic investigator and have them respond to the location.
EMS then placed two sheets over the man, preventing him from being viewed by the public. The forensic investigator arrived on the scene at about 4:30 p.m., then they consulted the medical examiner's office in Baltimore that an autopsy would be needed.
The forensic investigator contacted Springbok to transport the body to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner in Baltimore. The estimated time of arrival was initially an hour and a half, but due to a 16-mile Bay Bridge back-up, the transport was delayed and didn't arrive until 7 p.m.
EMS, the forensic investigator and the Greensboro Police Department offered to moved the man out of the environment, back inside the residence or place him in a body bag. The family declined all options, the town said.

title: Easton fire department takes home awards from firefighters convention
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Easton fire department takes home awards from firefighters convention

 June 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 405
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTERN SHORE — Representing the spirit of Maryland fire departments, Eastern Shore volunteers brought numerous home recognitions from the 133rd Maryland State Firefighters Association annual convention and conference in Ocean City June 18.Each June, the association gathers for its annual convention and conference to conduct business and provide training and educational sessions. In addition to the convention, a parade of apparatus took to the streets of Ocean City.
Easton Volunteer Fire Department was the fire company with the most uniformed fire service personnel attending the event. The department took home awards after the parade, including Best Appearing Fire Service Color Guard, Best Appearing Pumper Tanker, Best Appearing Ambulance, Second Best Appearing Tower and Third Best Appearing Rescue.
Easton volunteers were also awarded the Chief A. Marvin Gibbons Award for the Maryland company with the best appearance overall.
"I am truly honored and proud of the men and women of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department. Preparation for the Maryland State Firemen's Association Parade in Ocean City begins months in advance to ensure that we display our apparatus with pride, professionalism, and a strong representation of our department, the Town of Easton, and Talbot County," said Easton Volunteer Fire Department Chief J.R. Dobson in a statement. "Being presented with the Chief A. Marvin Gibbons Trophy for Best Overall Appearance is an achievement we strive for every year, dating back to 1992, when the award was established in honor of Chief Gibbons. We are proud to announce that this year marks the thirteenth time we have received this prestigious recognition."
Federalsburg firefighters took home the Second Best Appearance Tanker award, and Cordova firefighters won the Fire Prevention Entry Making Best Appearance award.
Sudlersville Volunteer Fire Company brought home awards including Best Appearing Engine, Best Appearing Rescue, and Third Best Appearing Brush Truck. The convention also saw Sudlersville's William "Billy" Faust elected as 1st vice president of the association.
Stevensville's United Communities Volunteer Fire Department Safety Officer Dave Reid received the Smith N. Stathem, Jr., P.P., Memorial Safety Award, which recognizes an individual's contributions toward firefighter and EMS safety. United Communities member Sierra Hawkins was named Miss Fire Prevention Queen.
Organized in 1893, the Maryland State Firefighters Association is a cumulation of the volunteer fire, rescue and EMS companies of the state that seeks to ensure adequate training and education, as well as standards in leadership and equipment.
More information about the MSFA can be found at msfa.org.
Star Democrat reporter Konner Metz contributed to this report.
