title: Sheriff warns of rising scams targeting local businesses, residents
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Sheriff warns of rising scams targeting local businesses, residents

 August 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Headlines 
 
 510
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — The Queen Anne's County Chamber of Commerce welcomed Sheriff Gary Hofmann on July 30 as part of its ongoing seminar series, where he provided an in-depth look at the latest scams affecting businesses and individuals — and the steps they can take to protect themselves.Speaking at the Kent Island Library, Hofmann emphasized the importance of awareness and vigilance in a county he described as "very trusting and generous," where numerous worthwhile charities and nonprofits operate.
"Benefactors should always verify the legitimacy of an organization before donating," he said.
Hofmann outlined how small businesses, which often lack training and robust IT resources, are frequently targeted. Scammers may use stolen credit cards to place large orders, leaving businesses unaware until it is too late. To reduce risk, Hofmann recommended printing invoices and verifying identification when fulfilling pickup orders.
He also warned of phishing emails and fake invoices that can appear legitimate but include malicious links or fraudulent payment requests.
"If you find something out of the ordinary or that looks suspicious, take a breath," Hofmann said. "Scammers often use fear or urgency tactics — like threatening to cut off power — to compel quick action. It's important to slow down."
One common scam involves demands for payment via prepaid gift cards. In other cases, scammers impersonate tech support, offering to fix nonexisting issues in exchange for access to personal data.
Hofmann said data harvesting can occur almost anywhere. Fake job postings often request personal information or payment for background checks. "Check washing" is also on the rise — criminals steal checks from mailboxes and alter them to commit fraud. Hofmann advised residents to walk checks directly into the post office to minimize risk.
"Using secure payment methods and monitoring accounts regularly is key," he said. "Set up alerts for check clearances and large withdrawals, and implement internal controls like requiring two signatures."
When writing checks, Hofmann recommended pressing firmly into the paper to make alterations more difficult. He also urged residents to shred sensitive documents before disposal to avoid "dumpster identity theft."
"We don't think about how much information we're putting out there when we throw things away," he said.
With the rise of contactless payments, Hofmann encouraged people to cover the front of their credit cards at checkout to prevent nearby cameras from capturing card numbers. He also warned about credit card skimmers — devices that mimic real readers and can steal information from magnetic strips using hidden cameras or overlays.
Other scams include:
Overpayment scams, where fraudsters send more than the owed amount and request a refund before the original check bounces.Malicious QR codes that direct users to phishing sites or install malware.Tax scammers impersonating government agencies.Ransomware attacks that encrypt a victim's data until payment is made.
Hofmann stressed that education and prevention are the best tools to stay ahead of increasingly sophisticated criminals. Staff training, multi-factor authentication, and careful scrutiny of digital communications are essential.
"Taking the extra time to assess and validate links is imperative," he said. "Multi-factor authentication might be inconvenient, but it can save you a lot of headaches down the line."
He also encouraged reporting suspicious activity. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on sheriff warnings about scams targeting residents and businesses, emphasizing crime prevention and community safety. While business aspects are mentioned, the core theme is public safety through fraud awareness and security measures.

title: CPS staff under investigation in Caroline County
author: Lily Tierney
content:
CPS staff under investigation in Caroline County

 August 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Caroline 
 
 746
 Words 

 Read News Document

 An investigation into the work of Caroline County Child Protective Services is long overdue, county Sheriff Donnie Baker said.The internal investigation into CPS staff was prompted by an incident on July 13, where a social worker never arrived to a home where child abuse and neglect was reported, according to Baker.
He said the agency has been "lacking in their responses," including showing up over an hour after being called or not responding to calls of abuse or neglect until law enforcement has already handled the situation.
"There are some issues that the local Caroline County Department of Social Services needs to work out, and we have been working with them for quite some time to work out," Baker said.
The state Department of Human Services is conducting the internal investigation. Maryland State Police are investigating the report of abuse and neglect.
Baker and Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin met with the secretary of Human Services about a year ago to address long CPS response times.
"We were promised a lot of changes, and unfortunately, those changes have not come to fruition," Baker said.
The Caroline County Department of Social Services, which oversees CPS, did not respond to requests for comment.
Ben Shnider, director of communications for the state Department of Human Services, which oversees the Caroline County department, wrote in an email to the Star Democrat, "The safety and well-being of Maryland's children is our highest priority, and local departments of social services respond to every report of alleged child abuse or neglect."
According to Department of Human Services policy, the Caroline County Child Protective Services response times fall within the guidelines for responding to reports for the examples that Baker cited.
The policy calls for:
Answering calls of physical or sexual abuse within 24 hours.Answering calls for reports of neglect within five calendar days.Answering calls for cases of substance-exposed newborns within 48 hours.
But Baker and Franklin said this policy leaves law enforcement to act as a middle man, but addressing the problem is complicated.
The Caroline County Department of Social Services is a state-run agency over which the county has no control, making it difficult for local agencies and officials to affect change, Franklin said.
"I have no power to enforce changes, I can only make recommendations," Franklin said.
Baker and Franklin said there have been unfulfilled promises of solutions since the problems began during the pandemic but were vague as to what those problems and promises were, saying they wanted to preserve their working relationships with CPS.
Both said they want a better working relationship with Child Protective Services. State law mandates law enforcement agencies working with CPS.
After-hours reports of child neglect or abuse can be handled in a few different ways. In cases involving high or even moderate risks, a Child Protective Services case worker should be automatically dispatched, but if they cannot respond, law enforcement, generally the sheriff's office, will be sent.
Because of the mandated joint investigations, Baker said law enforcement officers have been picking up the slack when the case workers do not arrive, leading to increased frustration by the officers on the scene.
Part of the problem may be vacancies in the state Department of Human Services, where there is a 7% vacancy rate, although Baker said he thinks the root cause stems from procedural and cultural issues that start with upper management.
"I would say that everything starts from upper management and works its way down as far as a cultural issue," he said. "And I think that there are some procedural issues within the agency itself."
Baker spent a majority of his career working in child abuse investigations and said they are near and dear to his heart.
"I know how hard that is, so it's very disheartening to me when we do not have good partners," Baker said.
Shnider, the Department of Human Services communications director, said his agency "is committed to holding ourselves accountable." His email statement said the department will address any systemic issues that are identified through the investigation.
"Any failure to respond to a report of abuse or neglect in a timely manner is unacceptable," Shnider said. "When mistakes are made, we hold ourselves accountable and take action to ensure we do better moving forward."
In the meantime, Baker and Franklin hope the investigation will bring systemic change that will enhance their partnerships and the safety of the children in Caroline County.
"I hope that some accountability and changes will come to better protect the kids," Franklin said.
This report has been updated to clarify that MSP and DHS are conducting separate investigations. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

This directly relates to public safety concerns. title: Surging ICE arrests raising community concerns
author: Konner Metz
content:
Surging ICE arrests raising community concerns

 August 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: News 
 
 903
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Matthew Peters noticed a stark change at last week's annual National Night Out mixer between residents and police officers from years prior. The immigrant community was largely missing."A lot of our community right now is feeling scared, not wanting to come here," said Peters, executive director of the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center. "If you were here last year and the year before, our community looked different."
Speaking to families at Moton Park in Easton, Peters asked them to keep the local immigrant community in their minds. His appeal comes amid a ramp-up in U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement activity on the Eastern Shore, which has spurred similar calls to action by local governments in Easton and Cambridge.
Feelings of fear and uncertainty have been vocalized early this week by many Eastern Shore residents on social media, who have shared hundreds of posts containing photos, videos and reports of unconfirmed ICE arrests.
"ICE was here today and made some arrests. I mean, it seems like they're here more often than ever," Easton Councilmember the Rev. Elmer Davis said at last week's Town Council meeting.
"It's deeply troubling that such actions have caused young immigrants to fear attending school, worried that their parents might be taken away," Davis said. "No one should live in fear in Easton or in this country, and every person deserves safety and opportunity and a chance to live without the shadow of oppression."
As local officials speak out on residents' concerns, it's still unclear just how many arrests immigration agents are making day-to-day. ICE's Baltimore field office did not respond to a request for comment in time for publication.
Nationwide, immigration arrests have surged since President Donald Trump took office in January. Trump campaigned on stepping up immigration enforcement, promising a mass deportation that targeted criminals.
"Across the country, arrests of criminal illegal immigrants have soared as President Donald Trump makes good on his promise to rid our communities of these threats to public safety," the White House said in a press release on July 22.
According to the press release, ICE arrests in Maryland have jumped 290% since Trump took office. U.S. Customs and Immigration data from June 29 shows a recent shift from focusing mainly on those with criminal records to arresting those without a record. Out of 57,861 people detained by ICE, 41,495 had no criminal convictions.
Members of the Trump administration maintain that targeting criminals remains the administration's priority.
INCREASED ICE ACTIVITY
Cambridge Mayor Lajan Cephas and Cambridge Police Department Chief Justin Todd each issued statements indicating increased ICE activity in city limits.
Cephas said in a statement the city was made aware of last week's activity "after the fact." In an interview, she added that she's contacted Gov. Wes Moore (D), Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.), and Sen. Angela Alsobrooks (D-Md.). Cephas said they have been in communication and are collecting information on whether constitutional rights may have been violated in interactions with ICE.
"You don't have to be a U.S. citizen to have constitutional rights," Cephas said. "It's for everybody that has stepped foot anywhere in the U.S. territories."
Todd said in an interview last Wednesday that Cambridge police have received phone calls and video footage from residents of the unconfirmed ICE activity. The department wasn't previously aware of the activity, he said.
Easton police have indicated they're aware of ICE activity. But Deputy Chief Greg Wright said the department hasn't been involved in arrests and cannot provide specific details.
Cephas urged residents not to engage with immigration agents. In a statement, she asked residents to send her photos or videos of "perceived inappropriate actions" by immigration agents, details she plans to forward to Congress members.
Elected officials in Easton shared similar thoughts at Monday's meeting. Town Council President Don Abbatiello encouraged residents to reach out to Harris, Alsobrooks and Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.).
FEARS
Fears from the immigrant and Hispanic communities in Easton have gained national attention since the arrest of Honduras-born Daniel Fuentes Espinal, a longtime pastor of Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama, on July 21.
ICE confirmed Espinal, who came to Easton in 2001, was arrested for overstaying a six-month visa. He is being detained in Louisiana, his daughter Clarissa Fuentes Diaz said. A hearing for Espinal had not been scheduled as of Tuesday, she said.
Protesters calling for Espinal's return have gathered in Easton the last two Fridays, many of them appealing to Harris, whose congressional district includes the Eastern Shore, to take action.
Harris maintained on Wednesday that his office is in the process of determining what power U.S. Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem holds "in stopping deportations."
"Once we figure out exactly what the secretary can do, (Espinal's) will be one of a number of cases where we will ask the secretary to exert the discretion we think she has," Harris said after an unrelated press conference in Tilghman Island. "But we're going to determine that first before she makes her ask."
At recent protests, residents have expressed fear and anger that the pastor was taken from the community. Now, those sentiments are spreading among residents across the Eastern Shore.
At the National Night Out in Easton on Tuesday, Peters said it's key to continue supporting immigrant communities, especially at events including local officials like police and first responders.
"A lot of people are scared right now," he said. "And I think at events like this, we got to keep these going to show the solidarity we have with our entire community."
Reporter Lily Tierney contributed to this story. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on ICE enforcement activities, community fears, and local government responses, all tied to public safety concerns. While local government and immigration diversity are relevant, the core issue revolves around safety and security impacts on residents.

title: ‘It’s how people should be’: Man credited with rescuing woman, dogs from house fire
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
‘It’s how people should be’: Man credited with rescuing woman, dogs from house fire

 August 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 437
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A Brookside man is being praised for his courage and selflessness after helping a woman and her dogs escape from a house fire last week.Jose Mercado, 34, was leaving his Merry Road house to go to work on the morning of July 28 when he saw a nearby house on fire. He drove the short distance to the burning house and banged on the door to alert the woman inside to the fire.
After assisting her and one of her dogs out of the house, Mercado ran into the burning home in search of the woman's other dog.
"I thought, go to the worst part of the house first, because that's where the dog might be," he said. "So I went upstairs. It was pitch black. I couldn't see in the room, there was so much smoke. I had my shirt over my face."
He could hear the dog barking and finally located it.
"I saw the dog downstairs when I was looking around, and I threw a blanket over him, and I wrapped him up, and I took him outside," he said.
Mercado went back into the house to look for the resident's car keys in an attempt to move the vehicle so it wasn't damaged by the fire, but he was unsuccessful in finding them.
"We are grateful for his courage and selfless act during this situation — and the positive outcome for both the resident and Mr. Mercado," said Lawrence Tan, spokesman for Aetna Hose, Hook and Ladder Company.
Mercado left the scene without seeking recognition, and the fire department only learned of his actions after being notified by another neighbor, Tan said.
Mercado said he was just in the right place at the right time.
"Thankfully, I was there to see," he said. "No one else saw it. It was just wild. It's perfect timing for me."
Mercado said he has young kids and would hope someone else would do the same thing to help them.
"It's how people should be," he said.
While Tan praised Mercado's actions, he made sure to note that the fire department does not encourage witnesses to enter burning buildings.
"Entering a burning structure places an individual into an environment that is immediately dangerous to life and health," he said. "It only takes seconds for someone to become overwhelmed by smoke or heat and lose consciousness — making the situation worse. Persons entering a burning structure without the appropriate training and protective equipment can actually further endanger someone who is trapped, since firefighters would need additional resources and time to find and rescue both the original victim and a well-intentioned bystander that was overcome by smoke, heat and poisonous gases." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a courageous rescue during a house fire, emphasizing safety protocols, bystander intervention, and fire department guidelines. While Local Life could marginally apply due to the community aspect, Public Safety directly addresses the emergency response and life-saving actions described.

title: Fire scorches house, displaces residents; causes $250K in damage
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Fire scorches house, displaces residents; causes $250K in damage

 August 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 191
 Words 

 Read News Document

 An investigation is continuing after a blaze caused an estimated quarter-million dollars in damage to a Perryville home early Friday morning, displacing the residents, according to the Maryland Office of the State Fire Marshal.One of the occupants called 911 at 12:39 a.m. Friday, after discovering the fire at the residence in the 1800 block of Perryville Road (Route 222), prompting area volunteer fire companies to respond, fire officials said. The Community Fire Company of Perryville served as the on-scene command unit, fire officials added.
Approximately 30 firefighters battled the blaze for about 45 minutes before bringing it under control, fire officials reported.
The fire caused an estimated $250,00 in structural damage to the two-story house, according to an MOSFM spokesperson, who further reported that relatives are assisting the family that has been displaced.
No one was injured, the spokesperson said. The home was equipped with smoke detectors; however, the blaze "originated on an unprotected exterior area," the spokesperson added.
During their on-scene investigation, MOSFM detectives determined that the fire started on an exterior porch, according to fire officials. But as late Friday morning, the cause of the blaze remained under investigation, fire officials added.

title: Pittsburgh woman killed in fiery crash in Queen Anne’s County
author: Staff Writer
content:
Pittsburgh woman killed in fiery crash in Queen Anne’s County

 August 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 215
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A serious accident in Queen Anne's County claimed the life of a Pittsburgh woman July 25. Two others were also injured in the two-vehicle crash in Sudlersville, according to Maryland State Police.Lisa Marie Arisman, 56, was pronounced dead at the scene. She was the front-seat passenger in a 2022 Chevrolet Malibu that collided with a 2020 Nissan Frontier shortly before 11 p.m. near the intersection of Sudlersville Road and Duhamel Corner Road.
The Malibu's driver, John Arisman, 58, also of Pittsburgh, was injured and transported to the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore.
The Nissan Frontier was driven by Kyle Wayne Crossly of Sudlersville. He was taken to Christiana Hospital in Delaware for treatment.
According to a preliminary investigation, the Nissan was traveling west on Sudlersville Road when it failed to properly navigate a curve, crossed into the eastbound lane and struck the Malibu head-on.
The Maryland State Police Crash Team is leading the investigation with assistance from the Queen Anne's County State's Attorney's Office. Charges are pending the outcome of the investigation.
Officials from the Church Hill Volunteer Fire Company reported the vehicle carrying the Arismans was engulfed in flames when first responders arrived. Firefighters from Sudlersville and surrounding departments spent about five hours on scene extinguishing the fire, providing EMS care, and assisting state police.

title: Immigrants contributing taxes
author: Staff Writer
content:
Immigrants contributing taxes

 August 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 297
 Words 

 Read News Document

 How does current immigration policy serve America's interests? On several levels, from economic to public safety to morally and ethically, the Trump Administration's aggressive deportation campaign does not serve us well.Over 8 million unauthorized US workers contributed $73 billion in federal, state and local taxes in 2022 through the use of ITIN numbers, a voluntary process since they are not eligible for Social Security numbers. Additionally, these workers paid $33.9 billion in payroll deductions to Medicare, Social Security and unemployment insurance, programs for which they are not eligible to receive benefits. Tracking down unauthorized taxpaying residents for deportation discourages the voluntary payment of taxes and drives otherwise lawful persons underground.
Residents fearful of deportation are less likely to cooperate with law enforcement if they become witnesses to or victims of crime. This allows criminals in our community to flourish as a segment of the population becomes vulnerable to extortion, abuse and human trafficking.
From a moral and ethical standpoint, the U.S. has allowed over 10 million unauthorized immigrants to remain in this country for decades – working, raising families and otherwise contributing to the strength of our communities. For most of these residents there is no path to legal residency and citizenship.
Immigration enforcement has shifted wildly from administration to administration because we lack consistent, rational and comprehensive immigration reform. Recent attempts at bipartisan immigration policy have been scuttled by extremists who see political benefit in the current dysfunctional system. To suddenly snatch long-standing residents off the street as they go about their daily lives, as has happened in this community and many others, is cruel and places us as U.S. citizens in moral jeopardy.
Each of us has an obligation to speak out to our elected leaders and let them know how we feel about this policy.
MARY M. YANCEY
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on how immigration enforcement policies impact public safety by discouraging tax compliance and cooperation with law enforcement. title: Police: Armed neighbor thwarts home invasion attempt
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Police: Armed neighbor thwarts home invasion attempt

 August 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 499
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ELKTON — Investigators are crediting a resident in an Elkton neighborhood with thwarting an attempted home invasion at his neighbor's house by detaining the suspect at gunpoint until officers arrived, according to Cecil County District Court records.The incident occurred at approximately 12:15 a.m. on Saturday, Aug, 9. when a suspect identified as Caleb N. Cline, 23, pounded on a door of a residence in the unit block of Upland Court, which is part of the Buckhill Farms community in eastern Elkton, and repeatedly yelled threats to kill the occupant, police reported.
Court records indicate that the victim does not know Cline and, as of Tuesday, information regarding why Cline allegedly targeted that home and the person inside of that dwelling was unavailable. The charging document also alleges that Cline was attempting to break into the home.
During a lull — before the suspect allegedly started pounding on the door again and screaming threats to kill — the resident inside of the dwelling called his "longtime friend and neighbor" and alerted him to the real-time situation, police reported.
The occupant then opened a second-floor window and looked outside to investigate, police said. At that point, he saw Cline, who allegedly said, "Come out here; I want to kill you" after noticing the occupant peeping out the window, police added.
Moments later, the occupant grabbed a baseball bat for protection and went outside after he saw his neighbor walking toward his targeted home, court records show. The occupant heard his neighbor warn the suspect, "Don't move — I have a gun," police reported.
The neighbor told investigators that he instructed his wife to call 911, after he grabbed his gun, and then headed toward the targeted home to confront the suspect, police said. As officers with the Elkton Police Department rushed to the scene, a dispatcher reported that the suspect was being "detained by a neighbor of the victim at gunpoint," police added.
Court records indicate that, according to his account, the neighbor told the suspect, "I have gun, lay down."
"He reported that Cline complied and even put his hands behind his back at one point. He reported that while they were waiting for the police to respond, Cline was saying all kinds of things that did not make sense. He reported that they tried to talk to him and calm him down. (The neighbor) reported that he held his gun behind his back, out of view of the suspect, to help him remain calm," according to the charging document, which indicates that no physical contact was made during the incident.
Officers arrested Cline after they arrived at the scene, police reported.
Cline is facing six criminal charges, including attempted home invasion, attempted fourth-degree burglary of a dwelling, trespassing and disturbing the peace, court records show.
He spent two nights in the Cecil County Detention Center on no bond, before gaining his pre-trial release Monday on an unsecured $5,000 bond after his bail review hearing in front of Cecil County District Court Judge Denise Winston, according to court records. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Small town on Eastern Shore grapples with increasing ICE presence
author: Konner Metz
content:
Small town on Eastern Shore grapples with increasing ICE presence

 August 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 960
 Words 

 Read News Document

 MARYDEL — Positioned directly on the Maryland-Delaware state line, Marydel is a quiet town. But last Wednesday, its sidewalks and businesses were unusually empty."This morning felt like a ghost town," said Karen Bamaca, 18, of Marydel on Aug. 6.
That morning, social media posts containing photos, videos and reports of unconfirmed immigration arrests in the town were widely shared. Many of the town's residents said people didn't feel safe going to work or nearby gas stations, and some resorted to communicating exclusively through Facebook and texting.
Around 50 people, including Bamaca, gathered on the Maryland side of the border that evening as the dust settled to protest against U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. They marched down Route 311, past local businesses and churches and through a mobile home park, eliciting cheers and claps from the neighborhood largely made up of Hispanic families.
The loud but peaceful display was a stark contrast from that morning's silence.
Protesters, many of whom were young Hispanic residents, said they were motivated to speak out for those they say don't have a voice.
"We're just here for those who can't be," said Ashley Oliver, 24, of Greensboro.
In the days since, the impact of the immigration arrests hasn't evaporated. The town's Hispanic and immigrant communities are afraid, many say, and families and businesses are left to grapple with the effects of the Trump administration's goal to increase ICE arrests.
Nationwide, immigration arrests have surged since President Donald Trump took office in January. Trump campaigned on stepping up immigration enforcement, promising a mass deportation that targeted criminals.
"Across the country, arrests of criminal illegal immigrants have soared as President Donald Trump makes good on his promise to rid our communities of these threats to public safety," the White House said in a press release on July 22.
According to the press release, ICE arrests in Maryland have jumped 290% since Trump took office. U.S. Customs and Immigration data from June 29 shows a recent shift from focusing mainly on those with criminal records to arresting those without a record. Out of 57,861 people detained by ICE, 41,495 had no criminal convictions.
An ICE spokesperson did not respond to questions from The Star Democrat on Tuesday regarding arrest numbers and whether immigration officials have increased enforcement in Caroline County, where Marydel is located.
Marydel, Maryland, operates a small town government. The town is unincorporated on the Delaware side of the border. Census data from 2020 shows Marydel, Maryland's population as 176. Of that mark, 115, or 65%, were Hispanic or Latino.
Many of the town's Hispanic residents or immigrants in the area have been hesitant to work, shop or walk the streets like they're used to doing, business owners and residents say.
"They're scared. They don't know what's gonna happen," said Alfonso Ortiz, owner of a corner store on the Delaware end of town.
VISIBLE IMPACT
A handful of businesses serve as the go-to stops in Marydel. On the Maryland side, there are two gas stations with grocery storefronts, a post office and a popular taco truck. In Delaware, there's a Family Dollar, Marydel Ag Supply and a few restaurants.
In the days after last Wednesday, Ortiz says business at his grocery store, Tienda Frontera Variety, drastically slowed.
"They were scared for a couple days, and they stopped coming," he said on Monday. It's rebounded a bit since, but foot traffic hasn't returned to normal, Ortiz said.
Families are grappling with immigration arrests, too. Adrian, 17, who asked to share only his first name, said four of his family members — his dad, brother, uncle and cousin — were all detained last week.
"I woke up to my mom banging on my door" at 6:30 a.m. on Aug. 6, Adrian said. His family is from Guatemala, and his uncle, dad and cousin had clean criminal records, he said.
Adrian said his dad was on his way to work for a local roofing company before being arrested. Adrian and an uncle retrieved his father's truck, which had been left on the road, as well as several cars for other families.
"To take the dad, to take the mom, what happens to the children?" asked Alex, 35, a neighbor of Adrian's who preferred to only share his first name. Since last week, many in the neighborhood haven't been going to work, he said.
Protesters last Wednesday said they feel immigrants are crucial to Marydel's community and the entire Eastern Shore.
It's "very important, no matter how small their job is," Oliver said.
'SPEAKING FOR THOSE WHO CAN'T'
Many of those protesters aimed to give voice to their family members who were scared to speak out. One sign read, "My parents fought for my future now I will fight for theirs." Another person wrote on a poster, "I'm speaking for those who can't."
Selvin Cordova, 27, of Marydel, helped organize last week's protest. Seeing the fear that developed across the community that day, he was compelled to lead a show of support.
Many who came to protest were young Hispanic residents like Cordova. He said a new wave of immigrant families is driving increased involvement and activism of the local youth.
"Definitely over the last year, our Hispanic community has grown so much more," Cordova said, noting that more Hispanic families are moving to the area.
Last week's protest wasn't just for the families and businesses in Marydel impacted by surging arrests. It was for all of the small towns nestled within Caroline County's rural north corridor, protest leaders said.
Small towns on the north end of Caroline County are home to much of the county's Hispanic population. Per 2020 census data, Templeville and Henderson have Hispanic/Latino population rates at 70% and 65%, respectively.
"Viva la Henderson, viva la Marydel, viva la Templeville, viva la Greensboro," a protester shouted into a megaphone. The crowd cheered and some joined. The chant continued on.
"Viva la Guatemala, viva la Maryland, viva la Delaware." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the impact of increased ICE presence on a small town's community safety, including fear among residents, protests against immigration enforcement, and effects on local businesses. While race and diversity are relevant due to the Hispanic community's experience, the core theme revolves around public safety concerns tied to immigration enforcement actions.

title: Reporting when rumors spread faster than facts
author: Staff Writer
content:
Reporting when rumors spread faster than facts

 August 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Headlines 
 
 168
 Words

 A recent uptick in U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement arrests has posed a challenge for our newsroom.Reports of ICE activity spread quickly on social media, but with little publicly accessible information from official sources, it became difficult to determine the extent of what was happening in Mid-Shore communities. title: Forty years later, the goal was reached
author: Konner Metz
content:
Forty years later, the goal was reached

 August 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Headlines 
 
 184
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sitting around a lunch table at Harrison's Harbour Lights on Wednesday, pioneers of Talbot County's advanced life support program told me about their vision for comprehensive cardiac response efforts.Some surely saw it as a far-fetched goal back in 1985, as people were accustomed to sometimes 20-minute wait times for first responders, even during serious cardiac emergencies.
But a group of five Easton firefighters and select hospital and county partners believed there was a gap to fill in saving lives. They voluntarily manned a life support unit 24/7, 365 days a year.
It slowly grew into a larger effort, a countywide paramedic system and, eventually, today's Talbot County Department of Emergency Services, which includes six full-fledged life support units.
At the end of our conversation, I asked them if four decades later, their aspiration was met. "Goal was reached," they told me without hesitation.
To learn more about Talbot County's "first five" advanced life support visionaries, read my story below. Also in today's newsletter: Easton debates food trucks, local artists design banners for downtown Denton, Chris Van Hollen holds a town hall and more.
Thanks for reading.
— Konner Metz

title: Talbot's advanced life support pioneers reflect on program's 40-year mark
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot's advanced life support pioneers reflect on program's 40-year mark

 August 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 722
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Pioneers in Talbot County's advanced life support services gathered this week to reminisce on the 40-year anniversary of their revolutionary effort to improve emergency response on the Mid-Shore.Five Easton firefighters began volunteering to man a new advanced life support, or ALS, program on Aug. 13, 1985. They had just one vehicle from the fire department. They sacrificed time at home and kept up constant communication to ensure someone was ready to respond to a cardiac emergency at any given moment.
The "first five," as they're often called, were Wayne Dyott, Kevin Knussman, Marc Stockley, Ray Taylor and the late Gary Jones.
Wednesday afternoon inside the Harrison's Harbour Lights restaurant in St. Michaels, the four men shared laughs and memories of the effort they spearheaded four decades ago to the day.
"It was quite a haul," Stockley recalled. "And unfortunately, in the past five years, I've been able to use this (ALS) system several times. And seeing the changes. It's been interesting to see the advancements. The care level is always there."
They were joined by others integral to the early success and soon-to-come expansion of paramedic services in Talbot County: Margie Callahan, then-nurse coordinator at Easton Memorial Hospital, and Buddy Harrison IV, former County Council president and the first director of Talbot County Advanced Life Support.
They all took time to reflect on Jones' integral role in the effort.
Jones, former director of cardiovascular services at the Easton hospital, died in 2021. Dyott said Jones joined the fire company in the 1980s knowing the ALS program was about to kick off.
"Ultimately, he was a good bridge between hospital staff, them accepting us and bringing the whole program together," Stockley said.
'SKEPTICISM AT FIRST'
Jones and others worked to show people the importance of pre-hospital cardiac care and why countywide ALS services were needed.
A half-decade ago, response times for heart emergencies could sometimes be 20 to 30 minutes. First responders typically reported to the fire station, then traveled to the location of the emergency.
Taylor said it was hard at first for fire companies to even accept EMTs back in the 1970s. The five men, certified as cardiac rescue technicians, aimed to change that.
"We kept hearing the same thing: 'you're not doctors, you don't need to play doctor on the ambulance,'" Taylor said.
Fire department and hospital leaders eventually warmed up to the ALS program, Taylor said. It didn't come without questions from the community, Stockley noted.
"I think there was skepticism at first, but I think it came around eventually when they started seeing positive results," he said.
On Wednesday, Taylor recalled what may have been the first of those positive outcomes. In 1985, he and Dyott rode in the ALS vehicle to the scene of an overturned truck and a man lying down. Taylor successfully defibrillated the man, and that began to turn heads in the right direction.
"It's a good feeling," Taylor recalled.
IMPACT FELT TODAY
Since 1985, the modest five-person, volunteer venture in Easton has transformed to a countywide staple. The Talbot County Department of Emergency Services operates six ALS units and one "chase vehicle" for rapid response. Over 50 paramedics and EMTs staff the units, some full-time and others volunteers.
The hard work of the original five was done with the hope of having a comprehensive system like the one that exists today, Dyott said.
"That's what we started. That was our goal, our ambition," he said.
Tina Kintop, Talbot's EMS division chief, said the division's current success and bandwidth wouldn't be possible without those pioneers. Crews responded to around 6,800 calls last year, she noted.
"We are better prepared and educated more than ever in the life-saving business," Kintop wrote. "Thank you to the visionaries 40 years ago and to those advancing ahead today."
Callahan similarly credits the first five for persevering through the doubts and paramedic funding struggles in 1985 and the years after.
"They were a part of seeing this all come to fruition," she said.
Over the last 40 years, it has always been about saving lives, said Talbot County's original ALS leaders. Knussman said all the vehicle swaps and early morning phone calls were well worth it.
"I think all of us would agree that the people on the street today are better trained, better educated, better equipped and better organized," Knussman said. "That's something that all four of us, and Gary if he were here, that's something to be proud of." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the development and impact of Talbot County's advanced life support emergency services, highlighting firefighter-led paramedic programs, emergency response systems, and community safety initiatives. While health aspects are present, the core subject is public safety infrastructure and emergency services.

title: Advice for a common circumstance
author: Staff Writer
content:
Advice for a common circumstance

 August 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 112
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As one of Andy Harris' constituents, I need to ask for his advice about what to do in the following increasingly common circumstance:If I am approached by a group of armed, masked individuals wearing what appear to be uniforms but with no identifying information, and they order me to get into a vehicle with them, should I comply?
In times past the answer to this question was always abundantly clear to me, but it no longer is. I am asking for his advice as my congressional representative and also as a physician.
If the question presents a conundrum to you too, consider supporting HR 4176, the No Secret Police Act of 2025.
MARY YANCEY
Easton

title: Conversation topic: combining police, sheriff
author: STEPHEN RIDEOUT
content:
Conversation topic: combining police, sheriff

 August 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPHEN RIDEOUT | Section: Columns 
 
 496
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In these challenging times, so much has changed and is being uprooted. Much that was familiar and consistent is now gone. I recall years ago being on an airplane going to give a speech in Alabama when I saw a woman wearing a Dilbert sweatshirt. Above Dilbert was written "Change is Good!" and below Dilbert was written "You go first!"While I thought at the time that what was written spoke to me, much of the change that is happening now is not perceived by many as being good, but it is happening anyway. Those who disagree with the change need to think about how they might make change to confront or address the current change that is happening daily if not in some cases hourly.
Years ago, after I moved to Cambridge, I thought that one change that needed to be considered was how the county, Cambridge, and Hurlock address the challenges of crime in Dorchester County with separate police forces and the sheriff's office. There is, of course, the sheriff, who is elected and two cities with police forces that have police chiefs and staff who are hired by the cities. There are in Maryland and elsewhere in the country, countywide police forces that also work within the cities in those counties. There are also sheriffs in those counties who oversee the safety of the courthouse and the local jail as well as serve court process both civil and criminal.
When I was on city council, I learned that Cambridge alone spent more for its police department than the county did for the sheriff's office. At the same time, the residents of Cambridge and Hurlock are paying county taxes, some of which paid for the sheriff and its staff that do not work full-time in the cities, although they do collaborate with the state and local police on some joint task forces.
Given our current times with less federal and state money coming to the counties and cities and the burden on city taxpayers who also pay county taxes, would it not be a good time for the County Council and the city councils of Cambridge and Hurlock to take a look at the cost of these departments, duplication of staff leadership positions and current areas of need to see if there might be a more efficient and less expensive way to protect all of the residents of Dorchester County than currently exists.
If that study were undertaken by the county manager who has expertise in this area and the city managers with a report back to elected leadership, some "change" that could be "good" could be accomplished. By finding a new and separate way to respond locally to the unexpected and significant changes that are coming to counties and cities because of how federal and state monies are being diverted, some new ways to address the needs of local communities might be found in this area and others.
At the very least is it not worth a conversation? 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the structure and efficiency of law enforcement agencies (police and sheriff's office) in Dorchester County, discussing cost-effectiveness, collaboration, and public safety responsibilities. While local government structures are mentioned, the core topic revolves around public safety management and criminal justice systems.

title: Grassroots lobbying derails Maglev train plans
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Grassroots lobbying derails Maglev train plans

 August 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 772
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Until recently, Maglev trains were being considered for passenger service between Washington, D.C., and Baltimore and eventually between Washington, D.C., and New York City.Unlike traditional passenger trains with locomotives pulling steel wheeled cars on steel tracks, Maglev trains use a powerful combination of electromagnets and levitation.
As a result, Maglev trains can run at top speeds between 250 and 300 miles per hour. That is significantly faster than Amtrak's soon to be launched NextGen Acela, a high-speed passenger train between Washington, D.C., and Boston with top speeds of 160 miles per hour.
After seeing and riding Maglev trains on a trade trip to Japan, Gov. Moore expressed great enthusiasm and strong support for Maglev passenger trains in Maryland.
Despite Moore's enthusiasm and support, Maglev trains are not in Maryland's immediate future, and most likely never will be.
Recently, U.S. Department of Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy announced the Federal Railroad Administration is canceling more than $26 million in federal grants to study a Maryland Maglev project.
Duffy noted this project has seen nearly a decade of poor planning, significant public opposition, tremendous costs overruns and nothing to show for it. He noted the project would result in significant unresolvable impacts to federal agencies and federal property, including national security agencies and Fort Meade.
Some will say this decision is comparable to previous Trump administration decisions that negatively impact Maryland such as keeping the FBI headquarters in downtown Washington, D.C., instead of moving it to Maryland and recent news reports about relocating a U. S. Department of Agriculture research center from Maryland.
That is simply not the case with the Maglev decision.
The Maryland Coalition for Responsible Transit (MCRT) has strongly opposed Maglev trains running through Maryland for many years.
The all-volunteer MCRT was formed in January 2020 by a group from Prince George's County and Anne Arundel County to evaluate transportation proposals from a broad array of perspectives, then communicate their findings and recommendations to government decision-makers and also educate the public.
MCRT launched a grassroots lobbying effort with a concise message — stop the proposed Maglev service from being built and operating in Maryland.
Ultimately, their message was heard by and resonated with a wide range of current and previous Maryland Republican and Democratic local, state and national elected officials.
Gov. Hogan, a former and current resident of Anne Arundel County, originally supported the concept. After it generated widespread public opposition, he changed his stance to oppose it.
Members of the Prince George's County Council sent a letter to the Federal Railroad Administration urging rejection of the Maglev proposal.
Angela Alsobrooks, now one of Maryland's U.S. senators, signed that letter when she was a member of that council.
U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen has said: "Concerns about the project and its impact on Maryland communities were long running. While its potential was promising, the devil lay in the details, and those details were never fully fleshed out — including how the project would affect residents, our environment and nearby federal agencies."
Despite his enthusiasm for the Maglev project, even Gov. Moore has accepted the Federal Railroad Administration decision. His spokesperson recently said in part, "… this project had challenges that were insurmountable."
Following the decision, Susan McCutchen, a board member at MCRT said the decision brought her a mixture of excitement and surprise.
Her surprise was based in part on the MCRT prevailing despite an enormous amount of lobbying done on behalf of the company that planned to bring a Maglev project to Maryland.
According to media reviews of the company's disclosure reports filed with the Maryland State Ethics Commission, they spent $575,000 on lobbying in 2023 and $603,000 in 2024.
McCutchen has said humbly, "We worked very, very hard — and all volunteer — but it's for our communities, that's the bottom line."
Affirming that the MCRT effort was the result of "very, very, hard work, Maryland state Sen. Alonzo Washington and Maryland state Dels. Anne Healey, Ashanti Martinez and Nicole Williams issued a joint letter saying, "The outcome did not happen by accident. It is the result of relentless and unified opposition from our community and elected leaders — a coalition of residents, advocates, faith leaders, council members and state legislators who stood together to protect our neighborhoods, homes and environmental legacy. We made it clear: Our communities are not for sale, and infrastructure should uplift communities — not divide them."
MCRT's successful efforts are a case study of the awesome power and effectiveness of grassroots citizen lobbying.
Those efforts confirm that in the legislative arena a group of committed, energized, and mobilized citizens can prevail even when they are engaged in a dealing with an opponent who spends in excess of a million dollars to secure a win for their cause. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the cancellation of a major infrastructure project due to public opposition, federal agency concerns, and potential impacts on communities and national security. While not strictly a safety issue, the emphasis on federal agency conflicts, community protection, and unresolved project risks aligns most closely with 'Public Safety' among the listed topics.

title: Are we spending too much to arrest immigrants?
author: LENA GILL
content:
Are we spending too much to arrest immigrants?

 August 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LENA GILL | Section: Columns 
 
 462
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The tax and spending bill passed by Congress and signed by President Trump on July 4 allocated $45 billion over four years to snatch undocumented migrants and some legal immigrants off the street or from their jobs and to lock them up. This is far more money than any previous president spent on removing undocumented migrants. Those doing the snatching are the masked, unidentified ICE agents, or Trump's new "secret police" who will balloon in numbers.This "secret police" force, reporting to the Department of Homeland Security and, therefore, to the president is bigger than most countries' military force. It is reminiscent of the Brown Shirts under Benito Mussolini in Italy before and during World War II. A police force reporting to the president of a country is out of character for any democracy in modern times.
The new detention centers for the unfortunates snatched up, who seldom have committed a crime, are being deliberately built in the worst locations. We all saw photos of President Trump visiting "Alligator Alcatraz," a tent camp (so far) built on an unused airfield in the middle of the Everglades in Florida. This part of the Everglades is populated by big snakes and alligators.
According to Homeland Security Secretary Kristi L. Noem, the camp will be paid for by FEMA and will cost $450 million per year to maintain. It can so far accommodate 5,000 people, but it can only withstand a Level 2 hurricane. More severe hurricanes occur in this part of Florida occasionally. The disregard for human life and the dehumanization of migrants who only came to the U.S. to build a better life for themselves and their families is extraordinary.
Migrant advocates have raised concerns about the living conditions in tents, but President Trump likes these unsafe structures with poor ventilation, as tents can be erected quickly. (Even the Nazis provided wooden housing in their concentration camps.) Apparently, Homeland Security needs 100,000 beds quickly. They are looking into using old prisons such as Alcatraz in San Francisco. At least 10 migrants died while in ICE custody in the first half of 2025.
The Big Beautiful Bill also includes $46.5 billion for building the famous wall toward Mexico and $6 billion for border technology and surveillance, along with other border security and immigration measures.
Why are we agreeing to spend such a large amount of money on a nearly non-existing problem? Trump has closed the border, so few new migrants are coming into the U.S. According to most experts undocumented and documented immigrants are committing many fewer crimes than U.S. citizens. We also need these people to do jobs that most citizens do not want to do. Here in Maryland the jobs tend to be picking crab meat and harvesting farm products that would otherwise rot on the vine. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on federal immigration enforcement policies, spending on detention centers, and border security measures, which directly relate to public safety and law enforcement. While it touches on national policy and political debates, the core discussion centers on immigration enforcement practices and their implications for public safety.

title: Espinal, Easton pastor arrested by ICE, returns home
author: Konner Metz
content:
Espinal, Easton pastor arrested by ICE, returns home

 August 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 269
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Daniel Fuentes Espinal returned home Friday after nearly a month of being detained by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement.Espinal's daughter, Clarissa Fuentes Diaz, flew to Louisiana last week to bring Espinal home, according to a Facebook post by family friend Len Foxwell on Friday.
"It was an emotional time for me — to see him after almost a month of not seeing him," Diaz told The Baltimore Banner.
Espinal, pastor of Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama since 2015, was arrested the morning of July 21. He was on his way to his construction job, his family said. He was taken to ICE's field office in Salisbury and then transferred to Baltimore, where he spent three nights in Baltimore before being transferred to a detention center in Louisiana.
Espinal was granted bond on Tuesday, family told The Baltimore Banner.
His arrest received regional and national attention. In Easton, it stopped services at his congregation and sparked weekly protests against ICE.
Earlier this month, Easton Town Council members called for Espinal to be returned to his family.
Espinal has been in the country since 2001 and has no criminal record, his family has said. Following his arrest, ICE stated that Espinal was arrested for overstaying his six-month visa.
"Daniel Omar Fuentes Espinal is an illegal alien from Honduras who was arrested by ICE on July 21, in Easton, Maryland," the statement said. "Fuentes entered the United States on a 6-month visa and never left in 24 years. It is a federal crime to overstay the authorized period of time granted under a visitors visa."
This story may be updated.
Reporter Lily Tierney contributed to this story. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 2 arrested on gun charges in Days Inn incident
author: Konner Metz
content:
2 arrested on gun charges in Days Inn incident

 August 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 283
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Police arrested two people last week on firearm charges stemming from an incident at the Days Inn hotel in Easton.Ernest Young Jr., 40, of Federalsburg and Katherine Adkins, 29, of Queen Anne were both arrested on Aug. 12 after an incident that afternoon. Young is charged with first-degree assault, home invasion, reckless endangerment and four firearm charges.
Adkins faces two handgun charges, accessory after the fact to a felony, altering physical evidence and making a false statement to an officer.
Around 1:40 p.m. on Aug. 12, police were dispatched to a first-floor room in the hotel. According to court documents, 58-year-old James Terrell Jr. told police he and Adkins were in the room when Young knocked at the door.
A few minutes later, Young allegedly pointed a gun at his chest, Terrell told police. Terrell grabbed Adkins and left the room before "Young grabbed Adkins and took her back" into the room, per court records.
A woman in a room on the second floor later told police that Adkins "knocked on her door and handed her a handgun." Adkins allegedly told the woman, "'Take this 'cause I don't want to get in trouble,'" court records indicate.
An officer saw Adkins on the second floor and approached her. Adkins told officers "there was no gun" and soon after "doubled down" on that assertion, court records state.
Officers found a gun in the second-floor room, which was allegedly the same one hidden by Adkins and held by Young during the incident on the first floor.
Adkins was released on $25,000 unsecured personal bond on Aug. 14. A preliminary hearing is set for Sept. 2.
Young posted $1,000 cash bond on Aug. 3. His preliminary hearing is set for Sept. 3.

title: Easton pastor reunited with family after ICE detention
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton pastor reunited with family after ICE detention

 August 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 881
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — When Daniel Fuentes Espinal walked out of an ICE detention center in Louisiana on Thursday, his oldest daughter shed tears before hugging him.In an interview with The Star Democrat Sunday afternoon, Clarissa Fuentes Diaz recounted the emotional reunion with her father. It came nearly a month after he was arrested by ICE agents in Easton while heading to work the morning of July 21.
Diaz and her husband flew to New Orleans on Thursday morning after a judge ordered bond and Diaz posted it the day prior. They made a four-hour drive to the ICE detention center southwest of Winnfield, about 160 miles northwest of Baton Rouge.
Around 4:30 p.m., Espinal and his oldest daughter embraced.
"When (the guard) told me he is getting released, I started obviously tearing up," she said. "And then when we finally went in there, I was already crying. This is actually happening, after a month. I'm actually gonna hug my dad again."
They stopped at a restaurant that night for dinner, then flew back to Maryland, where Espinal was reunited with the rest of his family Friday night.
Diaz said her sister and brother, Daniela and Daniel, are holding up well. Daniela will soon move into her dorm at the University of Maryland. Her "worst fear" was her dad not being there, Diaz said, a worry that's now gone.
Espinal's case has garnered national attention in the weeks since his arrest, as have its impacts on the Easton community. Services at the Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama, where Espinal has been pastor since 2015, were temporarily halted. Maryland representatives in Congress, Town Council members and protesters rallying weekly since his arrest called for Espinal's release.
Born in Honduras, the 54-year-old pastor has been in the country since 2001 and has no criminal record, his family has said. Following his arrest, ICE said he was arrested for overstaying his six-month visa.
"Fuentes entered the United States on a 6-month visa and never left in 24 years," ICE wrote in a statement last month. "It is a federal crime to overstay the authorized period of time granted under a visitors visa."
Diaz acknowledged that the family has tried to fix Espinal's status. She said it's been hard to find a "pathway," but this year they had plans to apply for naturalization.
"Whoever says that it's easy, it's not," Diaz said. "It really isn't."
CONTINUING TO PREACH
Returning from Louisiana, Espinal told his family it wasn't all doom-and-gloom. Conditions were "not ideal," Diaz said, but her father had a bed, a private bathroom and received some medications.
The experience led to a medical discovery. His family knew Espinal was pre-diabetic; a nurse at the Winn Correctional Center officially diagnosed him with diabetes.
"He's like, 'I can't say anything bad about Louisiana,'" Diaz said of what Espinal has conveyed. "'They treated me with respect. They gave me what I needed.'"
Espinal told his family about his experience with the detention center's church.
The center's chaplain saw Espinal on the news and invited the pastor to preach and lead Bible studies, Diaz said. Sparsely attended services and studies grew enormously.
"He said that from 13 people that he preached on that first day, the last day that he was there, 85 people started attending," Diaz said. "And he said not just Christians ... Muslims, Hindus, people from Ethiopia, just different ethnicities wanting to hear the gospel."
The chaplain told Espinal "he's never seen anything like this" in around 10 years at the facility, Diaz said.
"Being the light in someone else's darkness during your process is amazing to see, not because he's my dad and not because I'm his daughter," Diaz said on Sunday. "But when God uses you as a vessel, that's when people come at you the most."
WHAT'S NEXT
Espinal appeared at his church on Sunday, though he's not back to leading services. Diaz said this week will include a medical visit given his new diabetes diagnosis.
Espinal's case remains in Louisiana, although Diaz said the family and their attorney are asking to have it moved to Maryland. She said they are waiting to be notified of the next court hearing.
Maryland politicians in Congress have taken mixed stances on Espinal's case, largely along party lines.
In a statement Monday, Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md., 1st) said he views Espinal's bond release as "appropriate" pending a court appearance. The congressman, though, said federal law on overstaying a visa "is clear."
"Under that law Mr. Espinal is subject to deportation," Harris' statement read. "As the process moves forward, I will continue to be in contact with (U.S. Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi) Noem's office about whether an exception to deportation is possible in this case in the event the immigration judge rules against Mr. Espinal."
On Saturday, U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.) called Espinal's return home "an important victory" and said "there are many more like him" in a post on X.
Diaz says "words are not enough" to thank the community, politicians and family friends for their support over the last weeks. Espinal and his oldest daughter released a video statement on Sunday.
"I'm very happy to be home with my family and my community," Espinal said.
"I'm just happy, my heart is full. My dad is home," Diaz said. "Just praying for whatever outcome, or whatever happens. Just keeping our faith. The faith that we had at the beginning won't break." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on ICE detention and deportation proceedings, which relate to federal law enforcement and public safety. While it involves local community reactions and political figures, the core issue centers on immigration enforcement, a subset of public safety. The story also highlights community impact and legal processes, which align with broader public safety themes.

title: Report: Dorchester County K-9 died in hot car
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Report: Dorchester County K-9 died in hot car

 August 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 580
 Words 

 Read News Document

 An investigation into the death of a Dorchester County K-9 revealed the dog died after being left in a hot car.The Dorchester County Sheriff's Office released a statement on June 26 announcing the "untimely" death of 5-year-old K-9 Ender. The statement reported that a full and independent investigation would be handled by the Wicomico County Sheriff's Office.
In an interview Tuesday, Capt. Rich Wiersberg of the Wicomico County Sheriff's Office, who handled the investigation, confirmed that K-9 Ender's death was heat-related due to being left in a car.
The investigation is now in the hands of Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard. Wiersberg said he finished his investigation and handed it over to Leonard on Aug. 11. The state's attorney's office will review the file and decide whether to refer it to another office or keep it.
"We are happy to help Dorchester County Sheriff's Office with the investigation and hope to reach a conclusion soon," Wiersberg said.
The Dorchester County sheriff declined to comment on the open investigation.
The dog's death has left the Throw Away Dog Project, a dog training company that donated Ender to the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office in 2022, with many questions.
"I actually found out from an outside source once Ender passed, which prompted me to call the sheriff's office," founder Carol Skaziak said. "So no phone call from the handler at all, no phone call from the county or the sheriff's office."
The Throw Away Dog Project has placed 70 dogs nationwide, four of them on the Eastern Shore. The organization trains the K-9s, covers the cost of handler training and donates the animals to join the line of duty.
They provide specific instructions on what to do when a K-9 dies.
"As an organization, I said, we have a contract. You signed our contract. And I said, one of the stipulations in the contract is upon the death of the dog, the dog must go to a veterinarian and an autopsy must be done," Skaziak said.
Skaziak said she was told by the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office that Ender's body was taken straight from the handler's house to be cremated.
"You cremated an officer's body without finding out what was wrong because he is an officer of the law," Skaziak said. "No proper ceremony, no honoring this dog that served his county. Why wasn't this done? Why?"
Skaziak said Ender died while his handler was off-duty. She said she was told by the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office that there was a mechanical issue with the vehicle in which the dog was left.
"What I do know is the vehicle was equipped with a Hot-N-Pop system, which is a heat alarm," Skaziak said.
The Hot-N-Pop system is a K-9 heat alarm that is accompanied by an app that notifies the handler of real-time temperature status.
According to Skaziak, if the handler does not respond to a warning or alert, a loud alarm will blare and the windows will automatically be lowered. Skaziak said she was told there was nothing wrong with the heat alarm in the handler's vehicle.
The death of K-9 Ender has prompted Skaziak to advocate for new legislation in his honor. The "K-9 Ender Law" she proposes is state legislation that would mandate working, tested heat alarm systems in all K-9 police vehicles with recorded tests and penalties for non-compliance.
"We're going to hopefully start it in Maryland where every K-9 police car is to have a working heat alarm system that is tested and those tests need to be recorded with their department," Skaziak said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cambridge Police Department presents second quarter report
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Cambridge Police Department presents second quarter report

 August 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Events 
 
 439
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Capt. Shane Hinson of the Cambridge Police Department presented the department's 2025 second quarter report at the Aug. 11 Cambridge City Council meeting.The report presents a snapshot of police data from April to June of this year, which reveals that overall crime has decreased. But there are still concerns regarding homicides, robberies and juvenile violence, Hinson said.
Hinson said during the meeting that adopting the "policing with a purpose" procedure last year has been effective at catching crime quickly or preventing it before it happens.
Policing with a purpose uses "analytics and statistics to determine which areas of the city need more attention," Hinson said. When officers go into these areas, they are encouraged to interact with the community and stay for a minimum of 15 minutes.
"We're able to look at those numbers and say, 'okay, we need an officer to be here at least 15 minutes every two hours,'" said Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd in an interview. "It allows people to be seen, engaged, and I truly believe that that's what's helping."
Because of this procedure, the total cost of services has increased while the number of calls made to the department remained about the same, per the quarterly report.
Homicides, assaults, larceny and motor vehicle theft all increased from the second quarter in 2024. The homicide rate rose 200%, with two homicides that both led to arrests. One of the homicides was committed by a juvenile.
Assaults slightly increased by 2.1% with one more than last year, larceny offenses increased by 78.5% from 14 to 25 cases in the past year, and motor vehicle thefts increased from 12 to 15 over the same time period.
However, the total number of offenses decreased by 5.5% from 109 in the second quarter of 2024 to 103 in the second quarter of 2025.
Cambridge continues to see stable statistics regarding juvenile delinquency, with 42 juvenile charges in the past three months, some of which are serious and violent crimes like homicide, second degree assault and motor vehicle theft, according to the report.
"These are unprecedented times in our community," said Council President Sputty Chephas on the state of juvenile violence in Cambridge.
The Cambridge teen court deals with minor offenses "like if a kid is vaping at school," said Todd. The teen court program was launched in May, and Todd said it is showing early promises of curbing juvenile offenses.
"They have to go before their peers and be judged by a jury. And then they get found in sentence, whether it be guilty, not guilty, and they get a punishment handed down to them, such as community service hours, such things as that," Todd said.

title: Old mill to be demolished
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Old mill to be demolished

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 352
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Following lengthy discussion and community considerations, the Centreville Town Council announced intentions to demolish the old mill building at 2647 Centreville Road.Presenting its findings of fact following a recent public hearing, the council on Aug. 7, identified the structure to be a dangerous building that poses a risk to public safety.
Presenting the demolition order, the council stated the property owner has 10 days from the Aug. 7 meeting to demolish the building and in the event of failing to do so, the town may cause the structure to be demolished.
It was also noted, in the first step to acquiring a search warrant for dangerous buildings, the council unanimously approved an ordinance to add a new related town code chapter.
State law requires a town code chapter be in place in order to get an administrative search warrant from a judge.
The town would then have to go to court and get a search warrant before entering the property. The intention is to allow inspectors onto property the town deems pose a public safety risk.
The now more permanent administrative search warrant ordinance is related to the emergency version issued earlier this year.
The ordinance's initial draft received considerable public outcry but no public comment was presented at the hearing.
"So that feels like a good sign," Council President Ashley Kaiser said.
The council has made significant progress in ordinance developments to make it more palatable but public education will be needed before initiating any type of robust enforcement, she said.
"I think it is a step in the right direction and puts us in line with a lot of towns around us," Kaiser said.
In other business, three applications have been received for the two chairs open in the council's upcoming October election.
The Ethics Board will review applications before considerations are brought to the Board of Supervisors of Elections.
Although currently on the ballot for re-election, Council Member Jim Beauchamp noted he intended to withdraw if both other candidates move forward.
Beauchamp has served off and on the council for 10 years, "It's been a good 10 years," he said.
The Centreville Town Council will next meet Sept. 4 at 7 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: County buys mask testing system to keep firefighters safe
author: Staff Writer
content:
County buys mask testing system to keep firefighters safe

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 302
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Volunteer firefighters across Talbot County will soon benefit from new technology designed to keep them safer on the job.At a recent Fire Chiefs Committee meeting, fire chiefs gathered around their brand new AeroFit testing system, a device that delivers precise, OSHA-compliant fit tests for N95 respirators, elastomeric masks and other protective gear. The equipment, fully funded by the county, was purchased to reduce costs for local stations and increase safety for emergency responders.
Until now, fire companies had to pay for individual fit testing services, which added up in cost and required outside scheduling. With the new AeroFit system, once staff are trained, the tool can be used at any station, as well as other local emergency responders, to test firefighter masks, N95 respirators, gas masks and more.
This flexibility means the system will not only help volunteer fire departments but will strengthen readiness across all county emergency responders.
Properly fitted masks are essential for protecting firefighters and other emergency personnel from hazardous smoke, chemicals and airborne particulates. With AeroFit's advanced technology, firefighters will know their equipment is performing as intended before entering dangerous environments.
"Providing our firefighters with the right tools is critical," stated Jimmy Eason, President of the Talbot County Volunteer Fire & Rescue Association "With the county's support, this system ensures that every responder, whether volunteer, law enforcement, or emergency services staff, can be confident their protective equipment will keep them safe."
The purchase of the AeroFit system is part of Talbot County's ongoing investment in the safety of both residents and first responders. Each year, the county provides funding for the seven volunteer fire companies through its annual budget appropriation. Funding is distributed to each department by the Talbot County Volunteer Fire and Rescue Association.
"This is about taking care of the people who take care of us," said council President Chuck Callahan.
