title: Attorney takes on ICE on Eastern Shore
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Attorney takes on ICE on Eastern Shore

 September 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 933
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Criminal defense attorney Ivette Furneisen has made it her mission to stand between federal agents and some of her clients.From courtrooms to detention centers, she is fighting U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement on behalf of families across the Eastern Shore.
Having gone through the immigration process herself, she understands what it entails. Lately, she said, the road has gotten more difficult under the Trump administration.
"In general, I see that people are being picked up and detained for minor traffic offenses," she said.
This was not so during past administrations, she said. Under other administrations, felonies and misdemeanors such as assault, theft, neglect of a minor and sex crimes would lead to deportation since they are crimes of moral turpitude.
"Under Trump however," she said, "people are being picked up for minor offenses and then targeted by ICE."
That's the distinction.
In a recent case, her client was charged with driving under the influence by local police for having open alcohol containers in the back seat. He was acquitted, she said, but it put a target on her client for ICE.
Furneisen recalled that her client was leaving the hospital between Kent and Talbot counties after his wife's medical checkup when he was stopped by ICE. She said agents busted out the windows while his pregnant wife was in the car and detained him. Furneisen and his loved ones did not know where he was for three days.
She said that level of apprehension is heightened by more ICE presence, including in courtrooms.
In her first case of this happening recently, two undercover ICE agents approached her client in court, asked their name, then hauled them into a van.
"I am seeing a lot of failure to appear in court, especially for minor traffic violations, and that makes things worse for those facing charges," she said. "I tell them they need to show up for court with a lawyer."
It could mean the difference between paying a fine and being detained by ICE.
"That's why I fight so hard for them," she said. "If I can get them out of jail at the bail review, they will have a better chance to stay with their families. If they go to jail, their life in the U.S. is over."
She said these are not isolated incidents.
"I am swamped with work of this nature," she said, noting cases from Kent to Talbot and Queen Anne's counties.
The attorney has built her practice around these kinds of challenges.
Furneisen has worked hard all of her life, immigrating from Spain, establishing herself as a prominent immigration attorney on the Eastern Shore. She is half of the law firm of Campbell and Furneisen, located on Cross Street in Chestertown.
The firm's expertise earned Furneisen the 2024 Women to Watch recognition, an honor sponsored by the Kent County News' parent company, Adams MultiMedia. She is one of the only Spanish-speaking attorneys on the Eastern Shore, dealing with criminal, traffic and immigration cases.
Furneisen received her law degree from the University of Barcelona Law School. After becoming a United States citizen, she received her master's degree in U.S. law from George Mason Law School. She is admitted to practice in both state and federal courts in Maryland, the District of Columbia Court of Appeals and the Executive Office for Immigration Review.
That background and the multiple courts where she is admitted have come in handy in the past year as a criminal attorney that handles some immigration cases.
In the past, anyone could request a bond hearing. Now, she said, the federal government wants to limit or eliminate bond eligibility for many immigrants detained by ICE, particularly those who entered the U.S. illegally.
"The problem is that this will lead to indefinite detention because there is a backlog in immigration court," she said. "These people could be detained for years before they have their immigration hearing."
Furneisen described one client who was told not to plead guilty to theft and he would receive probation before judgment ©, which is not considered a conviction under immigration law. Her client pleaded not guilty and paid full restitution.
The judge ordered the detention center to release her client, but the center did not comply. She filed a writ of habeas corpus to release him, but ICE picked him up and gave him an option: get deported or sign a voluntary departure.
He chose the latter and went back to an area where his brothers and cousins were tortured before being beheaded by a gang.
"That's why I fight so hard to keep them here, but sometimes everything goes against you and you lose those battles," she said.
She said some of her clients, the ones who are undocumented, pay taxes through special IRS rules.
"They work in the county, they pay taxes and they are contributing, but they are still getting deported," she said.
Her view aligns with Maryland Attorney General Anthony G. Brown, who has said that immigration violations are a federal civil matter, not a state-level criminal offense.
Kent County Sheriff Dennis Hickman said his office's stance on ICE has not changed since March.
"In the past ICE has placed a detainer on illegal immigrants who were being held on local charges," Hickman wrote, "but when the sentence was over they were required to come get them. That practice has not changed."
Furneisen sees positive changes happening within the justice system as cases like Kilmar Abrego Garcia, a Maryland man who was deported to El Salvador earlier this year before being brought back, gain national attention.
"Just because you're being charged with a crime doesn't mean you did it," she said. "I love my job in helping those who don't have a voice and being an advocate for them." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on ICE enforcement actions and their impact on individuals, which relates to public safety concerns. While immigration is a federal issue, the story highlights local legal battles and community effects, aligning with 'Public Safety' as the primary topic.

title: Dorchester County K-9's death ruled accident: no criminal charges pending
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Dorchester County K-9's death ruled accident: no criminal charges pending

 September 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 424
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The investigation into Dorchester County Sheriff's Office K-9 Ender's death has concluded and did not find anyone criminally responsible.After the sheriff's office announced Ender's death in June, an independent investigation was handled by the Wicomico County Sheriff's Office. When that investigation concluded last month, findings were turned over to Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard, who said that to avoid conflict of interest she sent the report to the Worcester County State's Attorney's Office so they could do an independent review.
The review concluded that Ender's death was a tragic accident caused by equipment failure and inadequate fleet maintenance, not criminal conduct by the handler.
Dorchester County Sheriff Jimmy Phillips said the handler has been devastated since the death of Ender and has only worked one day since. "To say that he is devastated is an understatement," Phillips said.
The investigation found that the handler, who has not been identified, left Ender kenneled in his patrol vehicle with the engine running, windows closed and air conditioning on while the handler went inside his home and fell asleep. When he returned around 5 p.m., he found Ender dead. The outside temperature that day reached 100 degrees.
Carol Skaziak, CEO and founder of the Throw Away Dogs Project, which donated Ender to Dorchester County, said she is "very distraught with the findings."
Skaziak said the report attributed Ender's death primarily to mechanical car failure and air conditioning issues while overlooking the handler's decision to leave the dog in the car to sleep for three hours.
The vehicle's Hot-n-Pop heat alarm system did not go off during the time Ender's handler was asleep. The Hot-N-Pop system is a K-9 heat alarm that is accompanied by an app that notifies the handler of real-time temperature status.
The investigation revealed that the Hot-N-Pop safety system worked properly when tested after the incident, the air conditioning had only been temporarily repaired weeks earlier and required a new condenser.
Supervisors noted that the handler was visibly distraught when they arrived.
"They blamed it on a faulty car. So I get that, but what if none of it had happened? What if the handler didn't put the dog in the car off duty and then went to sleep? He'd still be alive. But no one brought that to light, and that was a huge mistake, a huge error. And now he's dead, and no one is going to be held accountable for it," Skaziak said.
Skaziak said she plans to have a public memorial for Ender in Dorchester County in the near future to honor and celebrate his life and service. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on an investigation into a K-9 officer's death due to equipment failure and maintenance issues, highlighting safety protocols and accountability. title: Drivers need patience on roadways
author: Staff Writer
content:
Drivers need patience on roadways

 September 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 428
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As a senior driver of 70 years driving experience I have finally reached my frustration point in what I (correctly or incorrectly) perceive as unwarranted impatience, if not absolute rudeness and discourtesy, on the part of drivers in Talbot County.I am a competent, not perfect, operator of a motor vehicle, and I do not understand the needs of many other drivers, younger ones in particular, to honk their horns, pass on the right side, ride your bumper or even pass on a double line when I take a needed extra second or two to double check when I am making a turn, entering an intersection, leaving a stop light, or driving at what I consider a safe 40 mph on the narrow, winding and crowned blacktop roads here, many of which have no shoulders only ditches.
You drivers who are speeding and tailgating in our county — and you, in my experience are many —will get where you are going without putting me or yourselves in danger. An absolutely unneeded honking horn is startling and rather than achieving its likely objective of hurrying me along and making me drive in the manner in which you think I should be driving actually slows me down when I look once more to reassess the situation around me before I move away from that light or stop sign or turn against traffic.
You will be senior drivers someday yourself, and you will understand certain facts — namely your reaction time slows a touch, your hearing and vision, though adequate for the task, are not what they used to be and your trust in your own cognition in discerning what is happening around you is quite naturally slightly diminished.
Talbot County and the town of Easton today present challenging driving conditions. The sheer volume of traffic, the narrow streets in town with double parking, and the plethora of large sized pickups and SUVs plying streets and roadways here that were not designed for these types of vehicles are factors, as well as the presence of some dangerous intersections lacking traffic controls — one of these is one I use daily, the intersection of the Parkway and Tristan Drive. I do not need an accident at my age, whether my fault or not. This is a major reason I (and many others of my age) need that extra moment of time to cope safely and competently with the driving situations already mentioned. And I can cope if I get just a minimum amount of cooperation from all of you others on the road.
JOEL S. STROBECK
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on driver behavior, road hazards, and safety concerns in Talbot County, emphasizing risks to public safety through unsafe driving practices and challenging road conditions.

title: Juveniles injured after chase ends with car hitting house
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Juveniles injured after chase ends with car hitting house

 September 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 368
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Three juveniles were injured, one critically, after a vehicle slammed into an Owings home over the weekend. The vehicle appears to have been stolen, according to police.Shortly before 6 p.m. Sunday (Sept. 14), deputies from the Calvert County Sheriff's Office were alerted to a stolen vehicle entering Calvert County.
According to a sheriff's office release, the vehicle, a Kia Optima, had been reported stolen out of Prince George's County and was detected traveling on Route 260.
Deputy Justin MacWilliams located the vehicle on Route 260 and investigators reported the driver "accelerated at a high rate of speed, passing vehicles on the shoulder and operating recklessly."
Attempts were made to stop the fleeing vehicle and a pursuit was initiated, with additional units responding to assist. The pursuit continued eastbound on Route 260 to westbound on Mt. Harmony Road.
Stop sticks were deployed in an effort to end the pursuit. However, the driver swerved the vehicle toward officers and continued fleeing.
According to the sheriff's office, the pursuit ended when the vehicle failed to negotiate a turn on Mt. Harmony Road near Alyssa Way, left the roadway, struck a telephone pole, traveled through a yard and ultimately crashed into a residence a residence.
The vehicle was occupied by four individuals. Three occupants sustained injuries, while one fled on foot into a wooded area.
Deputies, along with responders from Dunkirk, Huntingtown and North Beach volunteer fire departments, rendered medical aid at the scene and police established a perimeter.
With the assistance of agency personnel, K9 units, and drone resources, the fleeing suspect was located and detained. That individual was uninjured.
All four occupants were determined to be juveniles. No names will be released in accordance with state law.
The driver was airlifted by Maryland State Police helicopter to an area trauma center in critical condition. Two additional occupants were transported by ground to local hospitals with non-life-threatening injuries.
In accordance with Maryland law, the Office of the Attorney General's Independent Investigations Division was notified of the incident but declined to investigate.
The Calvert County Sheriff's Office Crash Reconstruction Unit responded and has assumed the investigation.
Anyone who may have witnessed the crash or the events leading up to it is asked to contact Deputy Jeffrey Hardesty at Jeffrey.Hardesty@calvertcountymd.gov and reference case number 25-76666. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton, other Eastern Shore towns host vigils for Charlie Kirk
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton, other Eastern Shore towns host vigils for Charlie Kirk

 September 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 657
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Communities on the Eastern Shore have been hosting vigils for political activist Charlie Kirk after last week's shooting, including in Easton, where Republican officials organized a gathering in front of the Talbot County Courthouse.Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble, council member Dave Stepp and state Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), among other Republican officials, joined with around 200 people for a vigil late Sunday afternoon.
Gamble said the idea for the vigil came from a conversation he, Stepp and Mautz had on Sept. 11, the day after Kirk was shot and killed while speaking at an event at Utah Valley University.
Gamble and Stepp said Sunday's event drew people from "all walks" of life. Gamble said he saw people attend with "all types of political backgrounds."
"Call for a time of prayer, a time of reflection, a time to try to come together as a community and lower the temperature," Gamble said of the vigil's purpose.
Kirk, founder of the youth conservative organization Turning Point USA and a close ally to President Donald Trump, spoke at the Utah college on Sept. 10. Police have since arrested suspect Tyler Robinson, 22, who is accused of fatally shooting Kirk from a rooftop.
The Kent County Republican Central Committee hosted a vigil earlier Sunday for Kirk in Chestertown. In Denton, the Caroline County Republican Central Committee is hosting a vigil on Thursday at 6:30 p.m. on the courthouse steps, according to the group's Facebook.
Stepp said the recent trend of political violence seen nationwide is "unacceptable." Kirk's death came less than three months after Minnesota Rep. Melissa Hortman, a Democrat, and her husband were assassinated in their home on June 14.
In a statement, Talbot County Democratic Central Committee Chair Phil Jackson said the killings of Kirk and Hortman and her husband "are not only assaults on individuals but on the democratic principles we all share."
"This moment demands that we show it's possible to disagree fiercely without resorting to violence," Jackson wrote. "When leaders exploit and weaponize a tragedy like this, they dishonor the victims, deepen the divide, and fail to solve the problem of political violence. At the same time, gun violence — in our schools, our neighborhoods and in our politics — is a scourge on our nation, that we must confront with honesty, courage and a shared commitment to do better."
Sunday's vigil included a lot of prayer, Stepp said. He said it was successful in bringing people together and that the large gathering was "God's work."
"We are so thankful for the hundreds of Talbot County and other Maryland residents of all ages who, with very short notice, filled the courthouse lawn for the emotional and moving prayer vigil for Charlie Kirk and other victims of violent crime," wrote Shari Wilcoxon, chair of the Talbot County Republican Central Committee, in a statement.
Gamble said the discourse on social media since the shooting has been intense. He released a statement on the Sheriff's Office Facebook page the night of the shooting stating he was "saddened and angry."
In an interview Monday, Gamble said he's a taken "a lot of phone calls" from residents in regard to social media harassment and threats made in recent days. Sunday's vigil had no disruptions, he said, but he's hoping the online chatter tones down.
"We need to lower the temperature. We need to talk more," Gamble said. "We have a history here of hashing out our differences through public debate."
In Ridgely, an employee at The Benedictine School was seemingly fired after making a social media post about the shooting, though the school provided only some details. In a press release Monday morning, the school said the employee "referenced the murder of Charlie Kirk in a repulsive manner."
"This matter has been addressed in accordance with the organization's policies and the employee is no longer associated with Benedictine," the release stated. "No further information be provided."
This story has been updated to include a statement from the Talbot County Democratic Central Committee. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on community vigils following a political shooting, emphasizing public safety concerns, political violence, and local official responses. While local government and national news elements are present, the core theme revolves around public safety and community safety measures.

title: Trial begins for Cambridge man accused of murder, kidnapping of woman
author: Konner Metz
content:
Trial begins for Cambridge man accused of murder, kidnapping of woman

 September 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 615
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Witness testimony began Tuesday in the jury trial for a Cambridge man charged with murdering and kidnapping a woman last year.Kenneth Bradley, 43, is charged with first- and second-degree murder and kidnapping, among other counts, in connection to the disappearance and presumed death of Tiyavauna Britt on Feb. 7, 2024, at the Gerry Boyle Park at Great Marsh in Cambridge.
On Tuesday, prosecutors made their first appeal to the jury, asking for first-degree murder and kidnapping convictions. The defense is vying for not-guilty verdicts on those counts, contending that second-degree murder or manslaughter are more appropriate charges.
Bradley and Britt, a 31-year-old mother of three, had been dating, according to multiple accounts provided during trial Tuesday and prior court documents. They were allegedly together in the parking lot of the park on Feb. 7, 2024, before Britt disappeared.
Easton police put out a missing persons report for Britt six days later. Family had found her car abandoned in an Easton parking lot.
Cambridge police, along with state homicide detectives, assumed the investigation from Easton authorities following the review of cell phone location data placing Britt at the park.
Bradley was initially arrested on kidnapping charges in February 2024. Review of camera footage at the park from Feb. 7 revealed "sounds of loud thuds ... consistent with forceful strikes," police wrote in charging documents. Later that night, footage showed a man "carrying and dragging" a woman's body to a vehicle, police wrote.
Bradley was indicted and arrested on murder charges in March 2024. Britt's body was not found.
Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard, the lead prosecutor, and public defender Matt Connell, who is representing Bradley, provided opening statements Tuesday.
Leonard told the jury the case is full of "rage, control, domestic violence." Evidence shows Britt's relationship with Bradley was "toxic," she said.
Leonard said Bradley's former employer and a close friend will testify later this week. Bradley confided in them, she said, confessing to the murder and the disposing of Britt's body.
"She vanished," Leonard said. "She was never seen or heard from again. No phone calls or text messages."
Leonard said jurors will see video footage from the park. The audio is "chilling," she said, showing Bradley drag Britt and throw her in the trunk of a car.
Before jurors took their seats to listen to openings, Connell objected to some of the audio evidence, arguing that Bradley could have a "reasonable expectation" for privacy during some of the conversations.
"We are fine acknowledging that that was him in the video," Connell said. " ... 90% of the verbal communication occurred inside the vehicle."
Leonard disagreed with the 90% assessment. Connell said, "it's possible I'm mistaken."
While the full video and accompanying audio wasn't admitted as evidence Tuesday, Judge William Jones sided with the prosecution. It's "quite likely" the court will allow its admission during trial, the judge said, especially if the conversations included yelling.
In Connell's opening statement, he acknowledged Bradley's involvement in Britt's death. But he said prosecutors must show Bradley intended to kill Britt in order for the jury to deliver a guilty verdict on first-degree murder.
"He lost it. He hit her too hard, and she died," Connell said, adding that Bradley tried to resuscitate Britt. "He didn't mean to do it."
"Hold him responsible for what he's really guilty of, not above and beyond that," the defense attorney said.
Thirteen witnesses testified Tuesday, including close family of Britt and police detectives who worked the case.
Linda Harris, Britt's mother, recalled Feb. 12, 2024 during an emotional testimony. It was her other daughter's birthday, and Britt didn't show up.
"She wouldn't miss anything," Harris said of birthday parties and holidays. The mother said she last saw Britt a week before she disappeared.
Trial is scheduled to continue through Friday. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal trial involving murder and kidnapping charges, which directly relates to public safety concerns. While the case involves legal proceedings, the core subject is a serious crime impacting community safety. title: Jury finds Cambridge man guilty of murder, kidnapping
author: Konner Metz
content:
Jury finds Cambridge man guilty of murder, kidnapping

 September 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: News 
 
 801
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A jury on Friday declared Kenneth Bradley guilty of murdering and kidnapping 31-year-old Tiyavauna Britt last year in Cambridge.Bradley, 43, was found guilty on all counts, including first-degree murder, kidnapping, false imprisonment and assault, for beating Britt to death at a Cambridge park on Feb. 7, 2024.
Bradley burned and disposed of Britt's body in the days after, according to witness testimony and facts established during the trial. He was arrested by police over a week after the murder, following a missing persons report for Britt in Easton. Police tracked Britt's last known location to the Gerry Boyle Park at Great Marsh in Cambridge and identified Bradley as the suspect.
Britt's remains have not been found.
Friday's verdict came after three consecutive days of witness testimony and evidence. The 12-person jury deliberated for just under two hours before reaching a unanimous decision.
Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard, the lead prosecutor, relied on video footage from the park as well as key witness Adam Kinnamon, Bradley's friend who worked with police to obtain a confession and details about the disposing of Britt's body.
Over an hour of the graphic video was shown during trial. The accompanying audio revealed loud thuds from inside a parked vehicle over the course of around 20 to 30 minutes, during which a female voice can be heard screaming intermittently.
Bradley, who was at the time in a relationship with the victim, yelled at one point, "'B----, you about to die.'"
After the repeated thuds and yelling, video shows a man of Bradley's stature put a small female figure in the trunk of the car before driving away.
On Thursday, Kinnamon recounted the phone calls he had with Bradley in the days following the murder. Four of those calls were recorded by Maryland State Police Sgt. Scott Sears, the case's lead investigator. The calls occurred later that February as Bradley attempted to hide evidence and avoid arrest.
"He said he hit her twice and tried to bring her back but couldn't," Kinnamon said. Bradley became violent that night with Britt due to his accusation that she cheated, according to investigators and witnesses.
In an interview after the verdict was announced, Leonard said the video evidence was crucial, and added that Kinnamon's testimony "pretty much sealed the deal."
Public defender Matt Connell, who represents Bradley, asked the jury to consider the lesser charges of second-degree murder or involuntary manslaughter. Connell said the defendant didn't mean to kill Britt.
"Mr. Bradley was in a zone, he couldn't pull out of it. He was in a rage," Connell said.
The attorney encouraged the jury to choose false imprisonment over the more serious kidnapping charge.
Connell acknowledged Bradley's acts as "horrific" and "awful," and he apologized to the jurors that they had to watch the video of the incident. But he said Bradley exhibited "blind rage" and could not control his behavior, contending the killing wasn't premeditated.
Leonard disputed those points.
"Twenty minutes of beating is more than enough time to rethink your actions," she said during a closing statement to the jury.
Leonard added that repeated texts and calls from Bradley to Britt throughout the day show the escalating nature of his anger at her. Leonard said Bradley had ample time to think about his actions, an argument the jury ultimately backed.
"Tiya can't speak for herself any longer, but the evidence sure does," Leonard said.
Britt's family packed the courtroom on Friday. Close family members took the witness stand earlier in the week. Mother Linda Harris said Britt and her three children had a close relationship and that Britt was "very active in their lives."
An aunt said Britt was always there to support everybody in the family. She checked on everyone "even when she needed people checking on her," the aunt said.
Leonard said the state will seek life without parole at Bradley's sentencing, which is not yet scheduled.
She commended Britt's family for maintaining composure during the jarring week-long trial. Leonard said she'd love to be able to provide the family with information about Britt's body or remains, but she indicated that it's unlikely to happen.
Sears, the lead investigator on Britt's murder, was the final witness to take the stand Thursday afternoon. He recalled extensive searches carried out by police for Britt's body, all of which came up empty.
He said he contacted the FBI to consider bringing the agency in to search local landfills, which had been mentioned by Bradley to Kinnamon during the recorded calls with police. But so many days after the potential disposal, digging up the landfills wasn't feasible, the sergeant said.
"The amount of time that had gone by, that would not be fruitful," Sears said on the stand, noting that police "put every resource" into the case.
During cross-examination, Connell at one point asked Sears if had recovered a body or had any new leads.
"I do not," Sears said. "I wish I did." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal trial involving murder and kidnapping, which directly relates to public safety concerns. While local government and national news could marginally apply, the core focus on a criminal case and judicial process aligns most closely with public safety.

Five injured in hayride crash

title: Maryland State Police investigating two late-night fatal crashes in Queen Anne’s, Kent counties
author: Staff Writer
content:
Maryland State Police investigating two late-night fatal crashes in Queen Anne’s, Kent counties

 September 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 396
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Maryland State Police are investigating two fatal crashes that occurred late Saturday in Queen Anne's and Kent counties, police said.Around 11:22 p.m. Saturday, troopers from the Maryland State Police Centreville Barrack responded to the area of northbound U.S. Route 301 at Hayden Clark Road in Centreville for a report of a two-vehicle crash involving a motorcycle, police said.
The operator of the motorcycle, identified as Marcus Dangerfield, 20, of Dover, Delaware, was pronounced dead at the scene, police said. The driver of a GMC Acadia, a 45-year-old man, was taken by ambulance to the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center. A passenger in the SUV, a 38-year-old woman, was flown by Maryland State Police Aviation Command to the same hospital.
The preliminary investigation indicates the GMC was traveling east on Hayden Clark Road, attempting to cross northbound U.S. Route 301, when it was struck by the motorcycle for unknown reasons, police said.
U.S. Route 301 was closed for more than two hours for the crash investigation. Assistance at the scene was provided by the Church Hill Fire Department, Queen Anne's County emergency medical services and the Maryland Department of Transportation State Highway Administration.
Around 11:55 p.m. Saturday, troopers from the Centreville Barrack responded to Maryland Route 213 and Riley's Mill Road in Chestertown for a report of a single-vehicle crash, police said.
A passenger in a Ford Fusion, a 17-year-old boy, was pronounced dead at the scene, police said. The driver, a 19-year-old woman, was flown by Maryland State Police Aviation Command to the Shock Trauma Center for treatment of her injuries. Three other passengers — a 21-year-old woman, a 17-year-old boy and a 23-year-old woman — were transported by ambulance to University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Chestertown, police said.
As of Sunday morning, police had not released the names of those involved in the Kent County crash.
The preliminary investigation indicates the Ford was traveling south when, for unknown reasons, it left the roadway onto the right shoulder, lost control, struck a telephone pole and overturned, police said. Investigators believe impairment may have been a factor.
Maryland Route 213 was closed for more than two hours. Assistance at the scene was provided by the Chestertown Fire Department, Kent County emergency medical services and the Maryland Department of Transportation State Highway Administration.
The Maryland State Police Crash Team is leading the active and ongoing investigations into both crashes, police said.

title: Caroline County Sheriff's Office welcomes K-9 Ace
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline County Sheriff's Office welcomes K-9 Ace

 September 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 236
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — On Monday, the Caroline County Sheriff's Office introduced K-9 Ace as the newest member of the K-9 Unit.According to a Facebook post, Ace is a 3-year-old German Shorthaired Pointer who specializes in narcotics detection and tracking.
This will be the second K-9 with the sheriff's office. Sheriff Donnie Baker expects another K-9 to be added within the next couple of months.
"Our plan is to add two this year," Baker said. "We are starting with Ace, and then we are planning on in the next couple months adding a third K-9."
Ace will serving alongside his handler, Deputy Logan Miller.
"K-9 Ace has already shown an eager drive to work and a loyal spirit, and we are confident he will be an outstanding asset to our team and community. Together, DFC Miller and Ace will play an important role in keeping Caroline County safe," the Facebook post stated.
Ace was sourced through Delmarva K9, a police dog training vendor the sheriff received four previous K-9s from, including current K-9 Kazi.
"Ultimately there's a whole lot of vendors out there, but we use a local vendor called Delmarva K9," Capt. Rodney Helmer said. "... Very good vendor. We like their training, and we like the dogs that it produces, which is why we still stick with them today."
Baker said that all the county's K-9s are certified through the state police as well as the North American Police Work Dog Association.

title: New Shelter Alliance aims for 24/7 support, year-round housing in Kent County
author: SUBMITTED NEWS
content:
New Shelter Alliance aims for 24/7 support, year-round housing in Kent County

 September 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SUBMITTED NEWS | Section: News 
 
 428
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Some 170 people representing a cross-section of Kent County gathered Monday for The Shelter Alliance's inaugural event, an evening focused on the root causes of homelessness, practical pathways to stability and self-sufficiency, and the organization's new leadership under Executive Director Kimrose Goodall.Chestertown resident and Maryland Planning Secretary Rebecca Flora opened the program by introducing Jake Day, Maryland's secretary of Housing and Community Development, noting their shared commitment to approaches that are data-driven and heart-led.
After touring Kent County earlier in the day, Day said the state is grappling with the compounding effects of not building sufficient affordable housing over the last 16 years. He said the Moore administration believes everyone deserves safe shelter and called for collaboration across all levels of government. Day highlighted the Maryland Shelter and Transitional Facilities Grant Program, which funds improvements to emergency shelters and creation of transitional housing, and said the department will partner with The Shelter Alliance to bring resources to Kent County.
Goodall brought the conversation local, noting Kent County ranks third in Maryland for adolescent homelessness. While single men comprise the largest group experiencing homelessness nationally and locally, she said, many single women, mothers with children and a growing number of older adults are also facing uncertain futures.
Goodall outlined The Shelter Alliance's mission to provide a shelter operating 24 hours a day, year-round, paired with individualized, wraparound support. The organization has an eight-member working board, an executive director and a case manager, and coordinates with partner agencies and community organizations to streamline intake and tailor services to each guest's needs. She said the board plans to expand and invited attendees to apply.
During a Q&A, attendees asked about Goodall's vision for a future facility. She said the ideal site would be an existing structure that can be safely adapted to meet diverse guest needs and is near public services, including substance use and mental health support, partner agencies and everyday amenities. Proximity matters, she said, because transportation challenges in Kent County can hinder access to vital programs and resources.
The evening concluded with a presentation honoring board president Carol Niemand for her role in founding The Shelter Alliance and steering the organization to early milestones.
An annual report summarizing The Shelter Alliance's accomplishments was available at the event and will be posted on Facebook and at shelteralliancemd.org, which is scheduled to launch on World Homeless Awareness Day, Oct. 10.
Follow on Facebook: The Shelter Alliance
Volunteer: contact@shelteralliancemd.org
To contribute: Make checks payable to "Mid-Shore Community Foundation" with "Shelter Alliance" in the memo line and mail to The Shelter Alliance, PO Box 2, Chestertown, MD 21620.

title: St. Michaels Police Chief says salaries need to be raised for officer recruitment, retention
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
St. Michaels Police Chief says salaries need to be raised for officer recruitment, retention

 September 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 424
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — During the St. Michaels Commissioners meeting on Wednesday, St. Michaels Police Chief Jeffrey Oswald said the police department will lose an 18-year veteran officer to another municipality. The officer, he said, is leaving for better pay."I'm coming up on my 24th year here, three as chief, and during this time, I've seen 43 officers come and go in our agency," Oswald said. "Obviously, there are several factors that contribute to some of the turnover, but the prominent and consistent driver from the exit interviews has been paying upward mobility."
Starting on Thursday, the St. Michaels Police Department will be operating with only four officers, excluding Oswald.
Oswald mentioned one of the reasons that officers leave besides salary is opportunities larger departments can provide.
"They have criminal investigation divisions, they have training divisions dedicated solely to ensure officers meet certifications, qualifications and criminal updates… and remember, each of these on their own is a full-time specially trained position," Oswald said. "... Every St. Michaels Police Department (officer) must be able to perform every one of these rules at any given time, and therefore, after a few years, an officer builds a strong resume and they take it to another agency who's more than happy to pay them some extra money."
Oswald suggested potentially hiring a police recruiting firm and raising wages commensurate to officers' total years of service.
"We're a good place to have an opportunity to do a reset because there's only four of us remaining," Oswald said.
According to Town Manager Don Richardson, the police department has four openings with two each at the corporal and sergeant level.
With potential salary raises, the cost would be north of $200,000 for the town to properly recruit and retain officers, Richardson said.
Commissioner Alexis Roiter mentioned accommodation taxes, which are paid by tourists who stay at hotels or rental properties, as a potential revenue source for police department needs. Commissioner David Wojciechowski mentioned allocating funds from town events.
The commissioners agreed to draft legislation allowing for salary amendments so the St. Michaels Police Department can become competitive in hiring and retention. The measure would have to go through the town's typical legislative process, which would include public hearings, before it can be adopted.
"Thank you for supporting this important need for the town of St. Michaels and our community," Richardson said. "It will ultimately require some level of budgeting amendment that will absolutely go through a public comment period and a legislative ordinance."
The town encourages anyone interested in joining the St. Michaels Police Department to contact the town for further instruction. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Ridgely man arrested on 2nd-degree murder, abuse charges
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Ridgely man arrested on 2nd-degree murder, abuse charges

 September 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Caroline 
 
 336
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIGDELY — A man was arrested Monday on second-degree murder and abuse charges for allegedly assaulting a family member, who was found dead by police.Around 9:30 a.m. on Monday, the Caroline County Sheriff's Office and fire officials responded to a house on Maple Avenue in Ridgely for a man in cardiac arrest.
Upon arrival, police said it was immediately apparent the victim was dead and had sustained injuries consistent with an assault. The victim was 65-year-old Robert Daywalt, according to court records.
Tyler Davis, 22, of Ridgely, is accused of physically assaulting Daywalt on or around the night of Sept. 28, according to police. Davis is Daywalt's great-nephew, court records indicate.
Davis was taken into custody without incident and charged with second-degree murder, manslaughter, first- and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment, causing physical injury to a vulnerable adult and other abuse counts.
Police say Davis and Daywalt lived together. Davis was a state-certified care provider for his great uncle, per court records.
In a statement of probable cause, police said Davis admitted to them during an interview that he assaulted Daywalt overnight on Sept. 28 or Sept. 29. Davis told police he "had consumed alcohol and did not recall the event" that night, court records state.
Davis said he made a comment he shouldn't have made to Daywalt, "at which time (Daywalt) punched" him, per court records. Davis told police he grabbed Daywalt's arms and then assaulted him.
"(Davis) advised during the assault, he was pushed into the dresser, at which time he 'blacked out' and the assault" continued, police wrote.
Davis is being held without bond at the Caroline County Detention Center. Online court records show he is set to appear for a preliminary hearing in Caroline County District Court on Oct. 28.
The Maryland State Police Crime Scene Unit and Caroline County State's Attorney's Office assisted the Sheriff's Office during this investigation.
Anyone with information related to this incident is asked to contact the Caroline County Sheriff's Office at 410-479-2515.
This story has been updated to identify the victim and include information from court records.

title: Day care teacher sentenced after assaulting toddlers
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
Day care teacher sentenced after assaulting toddlers

 September 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 438
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — A former day care teacher was sentenced to 18 months in jail after pleading guilty to assaulting three toddlers at a Queen Anne's County day care, authorities said.Wendy Jones, 58, of Easton, was sentenced Sept. 25 after entering a guilty plea in August to three counts of second-degree assault. The sentence was at the high end of Maryland's sentencing guidelines, according to the Queen Anne's County State's Attorney's Office.
Investigators launched a probe in February after receiving a report that a child had been physically assaulted at Kiddie Academy of Kent Island, where Jones had worked for about four years. Surveillance footage revealed Jones had assaulted three children, all under age 2, Deputy State's Attorney Christine Dulla Rickard said.
Day care employee Mandy Pettis first reported concerns to police after witnessing Jones kick and yank a child in the infant room. A search warrant uncovered footage showing Jones pushing and forcefully seating the toddlers, though no injuries were reported, Rickard said.
Under Maryland law, assault includes intentionally frightening someone with a threat of immediate physical contact or making offensive physical contact through an intentional or reckless act that is not accidental, legally justified or consented to. Rickard described the conduct as "assaultive, but not abusive" and said it amounted to "poor treatment of children."
Assault can mean several things from tripping someone, punching someone, attempting to punch someone or hitting someone, Rickard said, explaining that the legal threshold differs from child abuse, which requires a higher standard of harm or injury.
Jones was arrested Feb. 21, one day after the initial report. She received three consecutive 10-year sentences with all but six months suspended on each count. Upon release, she will serve three years of supervised probation and complete 50 hours of community service. A condition of her probation prohibits Jones from engaging with children in a supervisory role.
Parents of all three victims were consulted before Jones entered her plea, Rickard said.
"Parents expect 100 percent care, not 98 percent," Rickard said. "Jones crossed the line, and the court held her accountable."
Separately, day care owner Dana Barnhart was charged with failure to report child abuse or neglect after Jones' actions were brought to her attention. Her case was postponed indefinitely on Sept. 19. Under those terms, Barnhart will continue in administration but cannot be actively involved in caretaking or supervising children at the facility.
Sheriff Gary Hofmann said the case served as a warning that such behavior would not be tolerated.
"Parents place their trust in those who care for our most vulnerable, our children," Hofmann said in a statement. "When that trust is broken, it sends a profound shock through the community." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 2 charged with hindering drug investigation, reporting fake shooting in Easton
author: Konner Metz
content:
2 charged with hindering drug investigation, reporting fake shooting in Easton

 September 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 332
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Police have arrested two people for hindering a drug investigation in April, alleging they made a fake report to 911 that there was a shooting at the Easton Walmart.Elon Black, 38, of Easton, and Lacira Wilson, 39, of Worton, are both facing charges in connection to a drug investigation on April 4.
They were arrested on Sept. 18 and 19 for intent to distribute drugs, obstructing and hindering, and making false statements to police officers.
According to a press release from the Easton Police Department, officers stopped Black's vehicle in the area of U.S. Route 50 and Cecil Drive on April 4. A K-9 search discovered "suspected heroin/fentanyl mix," crack cocaine and ecstasy, police wrote.
During the stop, police said Black was on his phone. Investigators eventually determined that Black called Wilson during that time. Black had Wilson make a call to 911 and report a fake shooting at the Easton Walmart, police said.
Officers went to the Walmart but found no evidence of shots fired.
According to online court records, Black and Wilson both posted $10,000 unsecured personal bond since their arrests, meaning they will only have to pay the full amount if they fail to appear for a court date or break other conditions imposed by the court.
Wilson has a trial scheduled for Nov. 5 in Talbot County District Court. She faces four total charges: obstructing and hindering, making a false statement to officers, and two counts of possession with the intent to distribute a controlled dangerous substance.
Black's trial is scheduled for Nov. 3 in District Court. He faces the same four counts as Wilson.
Black, in a separate case in Talbot County Circuit Court, is also facing two felony, six misdemeanor and 11 traffic counts in connection to the same April 4 traffic stop. A jury trial for those charges is scheduled for Dec. 8.
In that case, he's charged with two felony counts of possession with the intent to distribute narcotics. Black posted $10,000 unsecured bond for those charges back in July.

title: County says new paramedic station in Cordova will reduce wait times for residents
author: Konner Metz
content:
County says new paramedic station in Cordova will reduce wait times for residents

 October 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 347
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CORDOVA — Talbot County officials and first responders broke ground Monday on a new EMS station intended to reduce ambulance wait times in the northern part of the county.The station, located in Cordova across from Chapel District Elementary School, is already taking shape. As site work begins and the station's main structure is erected, officials placed shovels in the dirt for a ceremonial groundbreaking.
Residents in Cordova and across northern Talbot County will reap the benefits of the station once it's completed, said Brian LeCates, director of the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services.
"We always try to make sure that we are to our calls within eight minutes, at least 95% of the time," LeCates said. "And this is an area that was underserved by that.
"The (Talbot County Council), they really took note of that. We gave them information. We gave them data."
Council members fully funded the $2.1 million project, which will be the county's sixth paramedic station. It will include space for a 24/7 paramedic and EMT unit.
Council President Chuck Callahan said the project comes at an important time as renovations are progressing at the elementary school across the street.
"It's kind of the perfect storm here when it comes to having safety, kids," Callahan said. "It makes the whole community feel a little bit safer."
Jimmy Eason, president of the Talbot County Volunteer Fire and Rescue Association, said the station is welcomed "with open arms."
"Unfortunately for us in Cordova, we're facing almost a 100% failure to respond rate," Eason said. "But not to any fault of anybody's, it's just a sign of the times. So this station means so much more to this area than some people might believe."
Callahan thanked the Gannon family for giving a piece of their farmland up for the project. Siblings Greg and Celeste Gannon attended Monday's groundbreaking.
LeCates shouted out their mother, Sylvia Gannon, for her continued loyalty to Talbot County's EMS efforts. Gannon, a former County Council member, was a founding member of the Talbot Paramedic Foundation.
"Every step of the way, she always stepped up and tried to help us," LeCates said.

 QUEEN ANNE'S COUNTY — The Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office announced two arrests in separate child-abuse investigations, including a Stevensville man wanted in Kentucky and an Essex man charged with child pornography.On Sept. 18, the sheriff's office was contacted by the Fulton County Sheriff's Office in Hickman, Kentucky, regarding a full-extradition warrant for Robert Wolfe, 59, of Stevensville, on three counts of first-degree sexual abuse of a child younger than 12, according to the sheriff's office.
Fulton County authorities advised that Wolfe had been entered into the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) database, the sheriff's office said. After confirming the active warrant, deputies arrested Wolfe at his Stevensville residence. He was charged as a fugitive from justice and held pending extradition to Kentucky to face the charges.
"This case highlights the value of interagency cooperation," public information officer Kaitlyn Briselli said in a statement. "By working closely with our partners in other jurisdictions, we were able to locate and apprehend a fugitive whose actions threatened the safety of our community and, most importantly, our children."
In an unrelated case, the sheriff's office said Jamie Lee Overton Jr., 23, of Essex, was arrested on Sept. 24 in Baltimore and held without bond following an investigation into a report received Aug. 30. A county resident alleged an unknown adult male contacted their child, younger than 12, for sexual purposes, according to the sheriff's office.
After reviewing evidence, investigators obtained a warrant Sept. 19 charging Overton with sexual solicitation of a minor, two counts of child pornography and two counts of obscene telephone misuse, the sheriff's office said.
Because the investigation is ongoing, the sheriff's office said it could not release specifics on how the child was contacted. Detectives are reviewing evidence to determine whether additional victims may be involved.
Anyone with information is asked to contact Detective Cpl. Parker at gparker@qac.org or call the anonymous tip line at 410-758-6666.

 CAMBRIDGE — A Federalsburg man is facing assault and false imprisonment charges after allegedly strangling a woman in Cambridge last month.Tyrone Wilmer Jr., 28, was arrested Sept. 7 and charged with first- and second-degree assault, false imprisonment and carrying a dangerous weapon with the intent to injure, among other counts.

title: Mother charged in killing of daughter, 3, extradited back to Maryland
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Mother charged in killing of daughter, 3, extradited back to Maryland

 October 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 694
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A woman charged with murder in the beating death of her 3-year-old daughter inside their North East residence in June remained in the Cecil County Detention Center on Thursday, Sept. 25.— two days after her extradition from Delaware and hours after her bail review hearing.Cecil County Circuit Court Judge Robert Sentman concluded that the defendant — Darrian Lynnelle Randle, 31 — should be held without bond, as recommended by Assistant State's Attorney Gavin Patashnick during Thursday afternoon's proceeding. (From the county jail, Randle appeared in the courtroom on a closed-circuit television screen.)
"The state cannot think of any (allegations) more heinous . . ." Patashnick told the judge.
The prosecutor opined that Randle poses a flight risk because she has no ties to Cecil County, noting that her relatives reside in Indiana and that her boyfriend — Cedrick Antoine Britten, 44 — owns the home in which they were living at the time of killing.
Britten also remains in the county jail on no bond, charged with first-degree child abuse resulting in death of a child under 13 and 10 other offenses relating to his alleged role in the incident.
In addition, Patashnick emphasized that an agreement between the governors of Maryland and Delaware allowed for Randle's extradition to Cecil County from Delaware, where she had been jailed since June on making a false report, and that the State of Maryland must ensure that Randle will be returned to Delaware to face that felony charge.
After allegedly killing her daughter — Nola Dinkins — Randle purportedly reported to Delaware police that the girl had been kidnapped in an attempted carjacking near Newark, to explain why the youngster was missing.
The agreement between the two governors allows the Cecil County State's Attorney's Office to try Randle in the murder case first. And then, regardless of the outcome — even if Randle is acquitted of all charges — the agreement calls for her return to Delaware to be tried in the felony false report case.
"Both governors in Delaware and Maryland signed the agreement. She must go back to Delaware immediately (after the adjudication of her Cecil County murder case)," Patashnick told the judge.
Randle's defense lawyer, Michael Halter, had asked the judge to allow Randle to remain free on home-monitored release until her murder trial. Halter reported in the courtroom that Randle "vehemently denies the allegations" against her and the she "looks forward to her day in court."
On Wednesday, a Cecil County grand jury handed up an 11-count indictment against Randle, charging her with first-degree murder, first-degree child abuse resulting in death and nine related charges, according to court records.
Court records allege that Randle admitted that she beat Nola to death inside their shared bedroom of Britten's residence in the 300 block of Elk Nest Road during the daytime hours on June 9 and then made arrangements to get rid of the girl's body.
Randle told investigators that she struck Nola 15 to 20 times with a belt all over her body, causing the girl to collapse to the floor and to stop breathing — a confession given after she allegedly had falsely reported that her daughter had been kidnapped, triggering an Amber Alert, according to the original charging document.
In addition, Randle told detectives that she asked Britten to get rid of Nola's body, which they had placed inside a dark blue suitcase, police said. She also told investigators that Britten later sent her a photograph of a park, after driving away from the residence with the suitcase inside his car, police added.
Court records further allege that, during an interview at the Maryland State Police North East Barrack on June 11, Britten "produced a map of where he believed that Randle may have disposed of" Nola's body, a statement that appears to allege that Randle got rid of the body.
Based on that map, investigators found human remains "consistent with an emaciated child" inside a suitcase found in a vacant lot in the unit block of Dune Drive near North East, close to Britten's residence, court records show.
The remains were positively identified as those of Nola, based on an autopsy performed by the Maryland Office of the Chief Medical Examiner in Baltimore, police reported. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: State Supreme Court hears arguments on police stops for cell phone use while driving
author: Konner Metz
content:
State Supreme Court hears arguments on police stops for cell phone use while driving

 October 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 510
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Maryland Supreme Court heard arguments Friday on whether police officers have reasonable suspicion to pull over drivers for cell phone use "in a manner that is consistent with sending a text message or initiating a phone call."In State of Maryland v. Michael Eugene Stone, the attorney general's office is asking the high court to overturn a Maryland Appellate Court decision in favor of Stone, a Washington County man found guilty of controlled dangerous substance charges.
The charges stem from a traffic stop police initiated on Stone in May of 2023. Police observed Stone "manipulate a cell phone that was attached to his windshield," which led to a search and discovery of the substances.
Attorneys for Stone filed a motion to suppress before his trial in Washington County Circuit Court, arguing his Fourth Amendment rights were violated. The Circuit Court denied the motion, but the Appellate Court ruled in January that the Circuit Court should've granted the motion.
"There is insufficient evidence in the record from which the trial court could properly conclude that the officers had reasonable suspicion to conduct a traffic stop," a majority opinion from the appeals court read.
In Maryland, handheld cell phone use and texting while driving is illegal. Exceptions include 911 calls and use of a GPS system.
On Friday, the Maryland Supreme Court dug in on the matter. They did so inside the Easton High School auditorium, part of a special off-site oral argument endeavor to reach students in high school and college.
Hundreds of students, as well as members of the public, listened in.
Jillian Chieppor, assistant attorney general, asked the Supreme Court to reverse the Appellate Court's decision. She argued officers had reasonable suspicion to pull Stone over, as they reported he pressed his phone in a manner "consistent" with typing a text message.
She said Maryland law statutes are intended to prevent the dangerous consequences of distracted driving and that forcing officers to wait until the consequence occur goes against the law's purpose.
Justices asked Chieppor if officers would have reasonable suspicion any time a driver touches their cell phone.
"It seems like if we accept the state's position, any time somebody touches a cell phone device, that would constitute reasonable suspicion," Justice Brynja Booth said. "Wouldn't we be casting a really wide scope?"
Stone's public defender, Douglas Nivens II, said the case isn't about texting and driving.
"This is a case about Mr. Stone … reaching up to touch the screen of his cell phone mounted on his dashboard," Nivens said.
"One touch being the grounds for a traffic stop is a bridge too far," he added.
Justices asked Nivens to provide his view of what officers would need to show reasonable suspicion based on the General Assembly's passage of laws to bar dangerous distracted driving.
Nivens said where the phone is located inside the car should matter, as well as how long the officer has looked at the driver's behaviors.
"We don't want officers just stopping people at random because they have a hunch," he said.
A decision from the Maryland Supreme Court on the matter is expected at a later date. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a state supreme court case addressing police procedures for traffic stops related to cell phone use, which directly ties to public safety concerns about distracted driving and law enforcement practices. While involving legal and governmental aspects, the core issue revolves around public safety regulations and officer discretion.

title: Body cam video released of Cambridge officer-involved shooting
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Body cam video released of Cambridge officer-involved shooting

 October 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Dorchester 
 
 455
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE — A man who was shot and killed by a Cambridge police officer asked the officer to shoot him as he charged the officer with a knife.On Thursday evening, the the Maryland Office of the Attorney General released the body-worn camera footage from the fatal officer-involved shooting that occurred Sept. 4 in Cambridge.
The preliminary investigation released in the days following the incident revealed Jacob Weber, a corporal from the Cambridge Police Department, fatally shot 30-year-old Ryan Garcy of Cambridge after Garcy charged at Weber with a knife.
The nine-minute video released by the attorney general's office includes footage from the body-worn cameras of three police officers — Weber and two officers identified only as "witness officer from the Cambridge Police Department."
The footage shows an exchange between Weber and Garcy that lasted under a minute.
During the interaction, Weber repeatedly tells Garcy to drop the knife he is holding and to stay back. Garcy, who was naked, can be seen slowly approaching Weber's police vehicle before pausing and asking Weber, "Will you just f------ shoot me?"
Garcy can then be seen rapidly approaching Weber. Weber is seen deploying a Taser, which is ineffective, then running from Garcy before firing five shots in Garcy's direction.
"I can say that I'm very proud of the officer that, from what I see, with all his training and knowledge of the job, he did what he, unfortunately, had to do to survive, and that's about all I can say about that for now," Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd said Friday.
Garcy was transported by Maryland State Police Aviation to Tidal Health Peninsula Regional Medical Center in Salisbury, where he later died.
Weber, who has been with the police department for six years, has been placed on paid administrative leave until the investigation by the attorney general's office is finished, Todd said.
According to Todd, this is Cambridge's first fatal police shooting in about 15 years.
"I can say my condolences for the family of Mr. Garcy having to go through that and have that video out there. I can't imagine the pain and heartache," Todd said. "Mental health is a real problem."
Todd said he has been in contact with Garcy's family via email since the incident and considers the experience traumatic for both the family and the officers involved.
"We all sign up to do this job, and yes, we know it can come to that, but I don't think anyone can speak for it until you actually have been through something like that," Todd said.
Todd does not know when the investigation from the independent investigations division will conclude, but he said the investigators have been in touch and have been great to work with.
This article was updated to add comments from Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cambridge police ready for National Night Out
author: Lily Tierney

Cambridge police ready for National Night Out

 CAMBRIDGE – Cambridge Police Sgt. Antione Patton was at Walmart purchasing 100 pumpkins Monday afternoon for the following day's National Night Out.This year, the department is switching from its traditional August date and holding the event in October to avoid the heat and broaden participation by providing pumpkin decorating, a hayride, television giveaways and the first-ever CPD pie eating contest.
The event aims to provide opportunities for the community to interact with officers during a positive, non-crisis moment.

"And we want people that are having a good time, to actually have time to talk to police officers about other things than problems and issues."
The Cambridge Police Department is hosting National Night Out on Tuesday, Oct. 7, from 5 to 7 p.m. at Great Marsh Park.

title: Easton man killed in hit-and-run crash
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton man killed in hit-and-run crash

 October 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 240
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A 68-year-old man riding a bike was killed Saturday morning in a hit-and-run crash, according to police.The Easton Police Department said in a press release that a passerby discovered a body next to a bicycle in the area of Route 50 and Woodridge Drive around 7:50 a.m. on Saturday.
Police attempted life-saving measures at the scene, but the man was confirmed dead. On Monday, officials identified the man as Donald Dawson, an Easton resident.
Easton Police Department Deputy Chief Greg Wright said on Monday that police are still searching for the suspect vehicle.
Preliminary investigations by Maryland State Police and Easton police indicated Dawson "was struck by either a tractor trailer or box truck" earlier Saturday morning, according to the press release.
On Monday, Wright said investigators narrowed the timeframe of the hit-and-run to around 2 to 2:30 a.m. that morning. There were no new significant leads as of Monday morning, Wright said.
Police found vehicle debris at the scene, per the press release. The vehicle suspected in the hit-and-run has a missing mirror and damage to the front passenger side.
Woodridge Drive is on the east side of Route 50, south of Easton High School and across the highway and near the Immanuel Lutheran Church. In February, a car struck and killed a 35-year-old man near Route 50 and Woodridge Drive.
Anyone who witnessed the incident or has information is asked to contact the Easton Police Department at 410-822-1111.
This article has been updated.
