title: In wake of fatal hit-and-run, Route 50 safety in Easton a concern
author: Konner Metz
content:
In wake of fatal hit-and-run, Route 50 safety in Easton a concern

 October 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 826
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Safety concerns for pedestrians and bikers using Route 50 in Easton are being raised after a fatal hit-and-run crash Saturday.Donald Dawson, a 68-year-old Easton resident, was killed riding a bike early Saturday morning in what police said was a hit-and-run crash with a box truck or tractor trailer. Police are still searching for the suspect vehicle.
The crash occurred at U.S. Route 50 and Woodridge Drive.
On Monday, Town Council President Don Abbatiello implored residents to drive safely.
"We already have enough people who come through town speeding. We don't need to add to that," Abbatiello said.
The fatal crash occurred just north of the Immanuel Lutheran Church and across from Saints Peter & Paul High School. Slightly north of the crash location is an overhead sign instruction drivers of the traffic light ahead, reading: "urban area stay alert." The speed limit reduces to 45 mph as drivers funnel toward the Route 50 and Dutchmans Lane intersection.
Saturday's crash is the second fatal collision on that stretch of road this year. In February, a car struck and killed a 35-year-old man near Route 50 and Woodridge Drive.
In response to questions about Route 50 safety in Easton, State Highway Administration spokesman Danny Allman said pedestrian activity near Woodridge Drive "is not encouraged as there are no sidewalks nor shoulders" on that side of the highway.
"We always emphasize visibility for pedestrians and cyclists on any road," Allman wrote in an email statement Tuesday. "Pedestrians and cyclists should always wear reflective apparel, especially in areas with no separation or lighting."
Saturday's fatal crash is also raising the question of whether speed cameras should be placed along Route 50 in Easton. Abbatiello said the cameras are needed.
"I also am pleading with the state to consider adding speed cameras on Route 50," he said during Monday's meeting. "We are talking about adding two crosswalks, one at Dover, one at Goldsborough, hopefully within the next year. We're going to have people walking across Route 50. It needs to be safe for them to do so. And so I hope that the state will seriously consider a request for a speed camera on Route 50."
Easton has its own speed enforcement program to deter speeding in school zones. School zone signs with "photo enforced" written under them indicate where the cameras may be active.
Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh said speed cameras on town streets and roads have been successful. There are cameras near the YMCA and The Country School, he said.
"I think that speed cameras help change behavior," Van Emburgh said.
While Saturday's crash didn't occur on a town-operated road, Easton engineers are in communication with their counterparts at the state level, he said.
Allman said SHA doesn't have "enabling legislation" to install speed cameras in non-work zones. Per state law, jurisdictions can install cameras in school zones and sometimes residential and other areas, he said.
For a camera to be placed on a state route, Allman said a jurisdiction would have to submit a request to SHA and receive a permit to place the camera.
Abbatiello said in an interview Tuesday that the next step for the town to consider requesting a speed camera permit for Route 50. The precedent is already set in Salisbury Abbatiello noted, pointing to speed cameras on the highway near Wicomico Middle School.
"It's a real issue in Easton," Abbatiello said of Route 50 safety.
Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said on Wednesday that the police department is working with a speed camera vendor to assess safety on the highway. "There's a lot of work to be done" before officially submitting a speed camera request to SHA, Lowrey said. Work includes gathering crash data.
"The goal is safety, the goal's not revenue," Lowrey said. "That's how the state looks at it, too."
According to SHA, sidewalks and pedestrian crossings are in the works for two Route 50 intersections — Dover and Matthewstown Roads, or Routes 331 and 328, respectively. Construction will begin in early- to mid-2026, Allman said Tuesday.
For roads maintained by the town, a draft comprehensive "Complete Streets" study is expected to be presented to town officials in the coming weeks. It will outline target speed limits, assess the need for sidewalks or bike lanes and, overall, put "safety first," Van Emburgh said.
"It's gonna tell us what we want our roads to look like," he said.
Talbot Thrive, a local nonprofit that advocates for pedestrian and bicycle safety, said in a statement on Monday that the town's Complete Streets study and similar safety efforts by Talbot County officials are important.
"These efforts need to be, at their core, about saving lives," the statement read.
Talbot Thrive's statement also addressed Saturday's fatal crash.
"This tragedy is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of those who travel by foot, bicycle, or wheelchair in our community — and of the urgent need to make Talbot County's roads safer and more connected for everyone, not just for those in cars," the statement read.
This story has been updated to include comment from Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on road safety concerns, a fatal accident, and discussions about speed cameras and infrastructure changes to protect pedestrians and cyclists. While local government actions are mentioned, the core issue revolves around public safety measures and community well-being.

title: ‘High-risk targets’: New normal at churches, houses of worship after deadly attacks
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
‘High-risk targets’: New normal at churches, houses of worship after deadly attacks

 October 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Section: News 
 
 1448
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Security at churches, synagogues and other houses of worship is being increased significantly after recent deadly attacks.Since late August, there has been fatal, targeted violence aimed at a Catholic school during mass in Minneapolis that killed two young kids, a Mormon church in Michigan and a Jewish synagogue in Manchester, England.
The assassination of conservative Christian influencer Charlie Kirk has also raised concerns about political and religiously motivated violence.
"Places of worship are meant to be sanctuaries of peacemaking, prayer and connection," said Doug Andersen, a spokesman for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints after a man shot up and burned down a church in Michigan in September, killing four.
There were 900 "acts of hostility" (including vandalism, arson and gun-related incidents) against U.S. churches in 2023 and 2024, according to the Family Research Council (an Evangelical Group).
Those are up significantly from previous years.
The Anti-Defamation League (ADL) has reported more than 27,000 antisemitic incidents in the U.S. since 2023, in the years after the Oct. 7, 2023 terror attacks and as Israel's two-year war in Gaza against Hamas has drawn significant international criticism.
That includes incidents on college campuses.
A new ADL survey of American Jews shows 55% say they experienced antisemitism over the past 12 months and 57% "believe that antisemitism is now a normal Jewish experience."
"All of the houses of worship should consider themselves to be high-risk targets at this point," said Dan Skoczylas, vice president of CLS Background Investigations and executive director of Hawkeye Active Shooter Response (both based in Illinois.)
He said that should prompt more religious groups to look more proactively at security, including engaging congregations and staff.
'VIGILANCE & SECURITY'
Police across the country have increased their presence and patrols at churches and other houses of worship as well as at higher profile events.
On Sept, 30 in Venice, Florida, police responded to threats against the Jewish Congregation of Venice and determined those to be a hoax or "swatting."
Those types of threats have been increasing nationally.
In nearby Lee County, the local sheriff's office "continues to maintain vigilance and security" at houses of worship after the Sept. 10 killing of Kirk and other attacks.
Kirk, an ally of President Donald Trump who was popular with Evangelical Christians and young conservatives, was shot by a sniper Sept. 10 during a rally at Utah Valley University
"We have hundreds of individual places of worship and religious centers within Lee County. Deputies are familiar with those in their patrol sectors and conduct frequent area checks — this is standard practice," said Julie Sin, public information officer for the Lee County Sheriff's Office.
Sin said deputies receive active shooter training and the agency deploys surveillance towers and increases patrols during religious holidays and large gatherings.
In Madison, Wisconsin, the First Congregationalist Church of Christ had an LGBTQ pride banner vandalized in June. In December 2024 a mass shooting at Abundant Life Christian School in Madison killed three (including the 15-year-old shooter who police said took her own life).
Another shooter targeted a Christian school in Nashville in 2023, killing three young children and three adults before being shot and killed by police.
Anthony Vogel, a spokesman for the Madison Police Department, said local law enforcement has "threat assessment" and "criminal intelligence" to investigate threats and disseminate those leads to officers on patrol.
"The Madison Police Department offers the option of hiring officers for Special Duty to provide police presence and security," Vogel said of options for religious and other groups putting on events.
But Cathal Walsh, vice president and chief security officer for Guidepost Solutions (a New York-based security firm) said increased police presence can be temporary, centered around holidays, weekly services or special events as well as after high-profile incidents or threats.
"The police presence is always temporary," Walsh said, noting law enforcement can't be at churches 24/7.
'VERY SERIOUSLY'
There have also been increased police and security footprints at Jewish synagogues during the recent High Holidays and the anniversary of Hamas' Oct. 7 attacks in Israel (which occurred on the Jewish holiday of Simchat Torah / the Feast of Tabernacles).
"We take security very seriously," said David Holtz, Temple administrator for Temple B'nai Israel in Easton, Maryland, citing "the considerable uptick of anti-Semitic threats violence."
That includes the killing of a couple who worked at the Israeli Embassy in Washington D.C. and the attack on elderly demonstrators at a rally for Oct. 7 hostages in Boulder, Colorado, earlier this year.
"We have a gate that requires a code or approved entry for access to our parking area. We have magnetic locks on both the exterior entrance vestibule doors and the interior doors to our temple's lobby," Holtz said. "We have security cameras throughout the interior and the exterior of the Temple. We have both off-duty sheriff's officers (armed and in uniform with marked vehicles) and private security personnel available for every service, Religious School or gathering event."
Holtz said for the Yom Kippur holiday on Oct. 2 guards were posted both inside and outside the Maryland synagogue "both as deterrent against any malicious actions and as peace of mind for our members and congregants."
'I'M GOING TO BURN IT DOWN'
The Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) has published a best practices guide for mosques and security.
Its recommendations include having a "vigilant" security / usher staff that can give early warnings to congregants, approach suspicious individuals before they enter the house of worship and do their best to keep erratic or violent behavior outside.
"Unknown males with bulky, camouflage, or combat-type clothing, for example, need to be approached and asked if they can be helped, Should the attacker engage persons outside the mosque, every effort must be made to keep the intruder from getting inside the mosque in order to minimize casualties," the CAIR guide reads.
Some of the vandals and shooters have some kind of animus towards a specific faith or church. Others hold some kind of personal grievance or grudge.
On Oct. 1, police in Dearborn Heights, Michigan received a threat from a man in Texas saying he would burn down a local mosque.
'I'm going to burn it down," the caller said, according to Michigan police.
'TARGET NO. 1'
Security experts are seeing houses of worship upping their security efforts via increased staffing, surveillance and physical barriers. Some religious venues are considering or have deployed metal detectors at entrances.
"Many houses of worship are increasing security presence in response to recent shootings, including posting off-duty law enforcement officers, trained volunteers, or professional armed security," said Gene Petrino, CEO of Survival Response LLC, a Florida-based security consulting firm.
"Some facilities are adjusting access points, adding fencing, controlled entrances, or security checkpoints," he said.
Others are adding surveillance cameras, motion detectors and alarm systems.
Skoczylas, a former law enforcement officer, said larger churches and dioceses have more resources and money than smaller congregations to have paid security guards or to buy security cameras and other equipment.
"They're not going to have the funds to hire a security force," Skoczylas said.
He said small churches and other groups can look at training volunteers.
Skoczylas said that can cost in the range of $1,500 for a security training versus hiring off-duty cops or security, which he said can regularly cost thousands of dollars.
He said the reality for security personnel (paid or volunteer) is to be armed.
"A security agent who is unarmed is nothing more than target number one," Skoczylas said.
That can run up against churches and other houses of worship wanting to be welcoming places.
"The goal is a visible deterrent while maintaining a welcoming environment," said Petrino, a former SWAT commander.
Walsh agrees it's a balancing act between security and feeling like a welcoming place.
Roman Catholic churches, for example, have long prided themselves on having sanctuaries open for those who want to come in and pray or meditate.
But Walsh said parishioners now will be concerned if they don't see some security, especially during holidays and big events.
"They kind of get a little bit worried," he said.
ASSESSMENTS & SOLUTIONS
Walsh suggests houses of worship look at entrances and exits and parking lots for vulnerabilities and how they fit into security plans and emergency responses.
He also said religious groups could look at having attendees register in advance for some events.
Walsh also said there are federal grants available through the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and U.S. Department of Homeland Security for nonprofits and religious venues to upgrade their security infrastructure.
"You might receive the funding to install more security cameras," Walsh said. "Those opportunities are out there."
Some houses of worship are looking at how much to advertise events on social media and are looking more at potential threatening individuals making menacing online comments.
That is also a balancing act with social media serving as a primary conduit for religious groups connecting with local communities.
"Social media is very touchy," Skoczylas said. "It's the conduit of all things good and bad." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on increased security measures at houses of worship due to rising threats and violence, emphasizing safety protocols, law enforcement responses, and vulnerability assessments. This directly aligns with 'Public Safety' as the core theme, with secondary relevance to 'National News' due to widespread incidents across the U.S.

title: Three arrested in connection with death of Centreville teen
author: Staff Writer
content:
Three arrested in connection with death of Centreville teen

 October 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 554
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — The Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office has arrested 19-year-old Kamryn Andrews, 20-year-old James Lawson and 27-year-old Travis Lissau in connection with the June 2025 shooting death of 19-year-old Christopher Parsley of Centreville.On June 1, at approximately 1:15 a.m., deputies from the Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office, along with allied emergency services, responded to the 1500 block of Centreville Road in Queenstown for a report of shots fired involving multiple victims.
Responding units discovered Parsley, who had been attending a bonfire with friends, fatally shot. Life-saving measures were initiated; however, Parsley was pronounced dead at the scene.
In a statement issued by the Sheriff's Office Wednesday, Oct. 8, police said detectives from the Sheriff's Office Criminal Investigation Unit immediately launched an investigation, working closely with multiple federal, state and local partners. The investigation was conducted with the collaborative support of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Baltimore-Annapolis Field Office, the Chesapeake Bay Safe Streets Task Force, Homeland Security Investigations' Baltimore Eastern Shore Field Office, the Maryland State Police Centreville Barrack, Centreville Police Department, Delaware State Police, Delaware Information and Analysis Center, Delaware State Police Governor's Task Force, Delaware Probation and Parole, Seaford Police Department and the Queen Anne's County State's Attorney's Office.
After an extensive investigation, the case was brought before a Queen Anne's County grand jury. The grand jury returned indictments, and on Oct. 6, arrest warrants were issued.
Andrews, of Seaford, Delaware, is charged with attempted second-degree murder (two counts), manslaughter, first-degree assault (four counts), second-degree assault (four counts), reckless endangerment (four counts), firearm used in the commission of a crime of violence (four counts), handgun on person (two counts), handgun in vehicle, loaded handgun in vehicle, and possession of a firearm as a minor.
Lawson, of Queenstown, is charged with attempted second-degree murder (four counts), manslaughter, first-degree assault (five counts), second-degree assault (five counts), reckless endangerment (five counts), firearm used in the commission of a crime of violence (five counts), conspiracy to alter physical evidence to avoid criminal prosecution, handgun on person (two counts), loaded handgun on person, possession of a firearm as a minor, and possession of a firearm without a serial number.
Lissau, of Centreville, is charged with attempted second-degree murder (four counts), manslaughter, first-degree assault (five counts), second-degree assault (five counts), reckless endangerment (five counts), firearm used in the commission of a crime of violence (five counts), conspiracy to alter physical evidence to avoid criminal prosecution, loaded handgun on person (two counts), and possession of a firearm without a serial number.
All three were taken into custody and held without bond.
Sheriff Gary Hofmann said, "This has been an incredibly difficult time for Chris' family and for our entire community. The effects of this tragedy have been deeply felt, and our thoughts remain with those who continue to grieve. This investigation reflects the strength of collaboration between our community and our law enforcement partners.
"As the investigation continues, every tip, video, and witness account remains vital to bringing closure for Chris's family and our community. We have zero tolerance for crime in Queen Anne's County and will always stand up for victims who no longer have a voice."
The investigation into the death of Parsley remains ongoing. Investigators continue to seek information from the public and encourage anyone who may have details related to this case to contact the Anonymous Tip Line at 410-758-6666 or email Sheriff-Info@qac.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a criminal investigation, arrests, and law enforcement collaboration surrounding a fatal shooting, directly relating to public safety concerns. While local government agencies are involved, the core focus is on crime prevention and community safety rather than governmental operations or national events.

title: Fire departments 'charge into safety' for National Fire Prevention Week
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Fire departments 'charge into safety' for National Fire Prevention Week

 October 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 405
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Fire companies throughout Mid-Shore made extra efforts to educate the public Oct. 5 to 11, part of National Fire Prevention Week programming.Firefighters visited schools, daycares and even jujutsu studios to teach about fire safety measures.
"In the city of Cambridge, we make a big push to go to all the elementary schools, we get to the preschools, the daycares and just talk a little about fire safety," Cambridge Rescue Fire Company's Chief Brad Walters said.
Easton Volunteer Fire Department Chief J.R. Dobson said they hand out plastic fire hats to the children, and Walters distributes coloring books intended to reach kids' families and reinforce safety messages.
The theme of this year's prevention week is "charge into safety — lithium-ion batteries in your home."
Walters and Dobson said lithium-ion batteries pose a significant fire risk when not handled properly.
The batteries can be found in everyday items like laptops, medical devices such as pacemakers, digital cameras, e-bikes and even some children's toys, according to a press release from the Office of the State Fire Marshal.
According to the press release, in 2023 the fire marshal's office began tracking lithium-ion battery-related fires. So far, 102 incidents have been recorded.
Walters said that in Cambridge, they have had five lithium-ion related incidents within the last six months. Dobson said these incidences in Easton have been "few and far between" but can occur with lithium-ion batteries as small as those that go in hand-held power tools.
The campaign emphasizes three key safety actions when handling lithium-ion batteries: buy safely, charge safely and recycle safely.
The fire marshal's office suggests only purchasing devices and batteries with a safety certification mark, only using manufacturer-approved charging equipment, steering clear of overcharging, and never charging on soft surfaces like couches, beds or pillows.
The office said it is also critical to recycle these batteries at designated recycling centers, which can be found at call2recycle.org.
According to the National Fire Prevention Association, signs there are problems with a lithium-ion battery include an odor, change in color, change in shape, too much heat, odd noises or leaking. If it is safe to do so, the association suggests moving the battery away from anything flammable and calling 911 if necessary.
Walters said beyond lithium-ion safety measures, families should communicate, maintain a home exit plan and practice everyday fire prevention awareness.
"And if you have any questions, reach out to your local fire department, and if you're willing to come volunteer, reach out to your local department," Walters said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

These directly align with 'Public Safety' as the primary topic, with secondary relevance to 'Health' due to safety awareness and 'Environment' only tangentially related to battery disposal.

title: Subcontractor strike causes major sewer line break in Greensboro, town says
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Subcontractor strike causes major sewer line break in Greensboro, town says

 October 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 357
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — At around 3:30 p.m. Friday, the Town of Greensboro received a call about sewage water in the road on Route 313 and Bridgetown Road, town officials said.Upon arrival, Greensboro Public Works found a sewer main pipe break on Bridgetown Road. Greensboro Town Manager Cindy Yost said the sewer line is connected from Greensboro to Goldsboro. Friday evening, she said the town had asked Goldsboro residents to use less water while repairs were underway.
"We've had to go in and shut down the pump station to Goldsboro, and hopefully that'll keep it from coming forward," Yost said. "Then we've got some trucks coming in, too, to help with that load. So, hopefully we can manage that with Goldsboro and not create any issues for them at the current time."
She said the town hoped to have the issue resolved by the morning.
After investigation, the town discovered that a subcontractor from Sure Shot Drilling was boring on the property. Yost said the subcontractor hit the main sewer pipe, then covered the pipe with plywood, put an orange flag around the pipe and left the scene without contacting the town.
According to Yost, the town contacted Sure Shot Drilling after discovering the break, and the company said workers had contacted Miss Utility, the company responsible for marking the location of power lines, sewer lines and water lines ahead of construction work.
The town manager said Sure Shot Drilling officials told her the area was not marked, so the contractor boring in that area was unaware the pipe was there.
Sure Shot Drilling could not be reached for comment due to the office being closed at the time the Star Democrat called.
Yost said the town was not contacted by Miss Utility ahead of Friday's construction work and was unaware of boring being done in the area that day.
"This is a huge sewer main. We should have been contacted. We were not," Yost said. "So, right now we've got emergency crews out here. We've got our local police out here on the road. We've called MDE because of the sewage going into the creek. So, we're hoping that we can get this fixed tonight."

title: Ease up on the gas, make Easton a safer place
author: MEGAN COOK
content:
Ease up on the gas, make Easton a safer place

 October 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MEGAN COOK | Section: Columns 
 
 264
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Easton is an active town — people are out walking, biking, shopping and getting to school or work. That's a big part of what makes our community so vibrant. But it also means we all share a responsibility to keep our streets safe. One of the simplest and most important ways we can do that is by slowing down.The town continues to invest in projects that improve safety for everyone who uses our streets. We've added new sidewalks and crosswalks, updated trail crossing signage, improved lighting and installed electric speed signs in several neighborhoods. We're planning even more improvements in the months ahead — from better pedestrian crossings to infrastructure upgrades that make it easier and safer for everyone to get around.
But no matter how many improvements we make, the truth is that safety ultimately depends on how we drive. Speed and distraction are two of the biggest factors in crashes, and both are within our control. A pedestrian has a significantly better chance of surviving a car collision at lower speeds. When we slow down — especially in residential areas and near schools — we give ourselves more time to react, protect our neighbors and prevent accidents before they happen.
So as we continue working to make Easton safer through careful design and investment, I hope everyone will do their part behind the wheel. Put the phone down. Watch for pedestrians, wheelchairs, cyclists, scooters and skateboarders. Ease up on the gas.
Together, through thoughtful planning and careful driving, we can keep Easton a safe and welcoming place for everyone who calls it home.
Safe travels. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on road safety initiatives in Easton, emphasizing driver behavior, infrastructure improvements, and community responsibility to create a safer environment. These directly align with 'Public Safety' as the primary topic, with secondary relevance to 'Local Government' due to mentioned infrastructure projects.

title: Weekend storm threatens Shore with rain, wind
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Weekend storm threatens Shore with rain, wind

 October 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 237
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Eastern Shore is expected to see escalating coastal storms late Saturday into Monday.Zack Cooper, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service Office in Mount Holly, said while there is a low chance for thunderstorms or tornadoes, the storm will bring one to three inches of rain and 40 mph winds.
"So really starting late in the day Saturday we'll start to see an increase in cloud cover and shower activity, which will ramp up rapidly from there going into Sunday, which is when most of the heavy rainfall will occur, Sunday into Sunday night and going into Monday as well," Cooper said.
Due to the potential costal storm the Maryland Transportation Authority reminded residents and travelers to be prepared for wind warnings, restrictions and the potential for temporary traffic holds at MDTA bridges Sunday into Monday.
If wind exceeds 55 mph, the MDTA could make the decision to hold traffic or close bridges.
Cooper said minor costal flooding is possible.
While Cooper said this storm doesn't look like it will cause a big flooding event, there are some precautions that residents can take to make sure they stay safe.
"It all starts with just preparation and planning," Cooper said. "A lot of times if there's minor flooding or roadway flooding or things like that the best course of action is to just stay off the roadways."
The National Weather Service will continue to monitor the coastal storm throughout the weekend. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Our roads need to be safe for all
author: Staff Writer
content:
Our roads need to be safe for all

 October 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 234
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We are deeply saddened to learn of the tragic loss of life that occurred on Saturday morning, Oct. 4, when a person riding a bicycle was struck and killed on a westbound lane of Route 50 in Easton. Our hearts go out to the victim's family, friends and all those affected by this horrific incident.Every life lost on our roads is one too many. This tragedy is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of those who travel by foot, bicycle or wheelchair in our community — and of the urgent need to make Talbot County's roads safer and more connected for everyone, not just for those in cars.
At Talbot Thrive, we advocate for a future where people can move safely and efficiently — whether they drive, walk, bike or take transit. We believe that investing in complete, connected neighborhoods and better infrastructure for people without cars is essential to building a community that is equitable, healthy and resilient.
This moment underscores the importance of thoughtful implementation of the Town of Easton's Complete Streets Plan and the county's Safety Action Plan, including expanding transit options and designing streets that prioritize safety for all users. These efforts need to be, at their core, about saving lives.
We extend our condolences once again to the victim's loved ones. May this loss strengthen our shared resolve to make Easton and Talbot County safer and more accessible for everyone.
HEATHER GRANT
Easton

title: Greensboro welcomes new officer to police department
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Greensboro welcomes new officer to police department

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — At the Oct. 2 Greensboro Town Council meeting, the town introduced Jeremy Eckel, the town's newest police officer.Going into this year, Chief Lenox Trams was the sole officer at the department. Trams said he has been on a mission to grow the department with solid officers. He believes he has another one in Eckel.
"I was by myself for a while, and then I've recruited a second officer and I'm continuing to want to build, so having a third officer actually feels pretty good," Trams said. "I would only hire the best. I have told the Town Council and the citizens, please be patient with me, I will build the agency but I'll only hire the best and it really feels good to hire the best."
Eckel, 27, is from Edgewater. He served in the Marine Corps from 2015 to 2021, two years in the reserves and four years active, and he is currently in the Army National Guard.
After his service, Eckel joined the Federalsburg Police Department from June 2023 to Oct. 1. After the Federalsburg Police Department was absorbed by the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, Eckel joined the Greensboro Police Department.
Greensboro is one of two towns in Caroline County that still has its own police department. Last year, Ridgely turned over policing duties to the Sheriff's Office after laying off the town's six officers amid an investigation into the police department's chief. The investigation did not find any wrongdoing by the chief.
The Federalsburg Police Department was disbanded this month due to the town's financial constraints.
In Federalsburg, Eckel said he gained experience in small-town policing and learned how to build a relationship with the town's residents.
"When it comes to small-town policing, there's a different mindset you have to have," Eckel said. "It's not Maryland State Police, where you're going to see that person one time out of your 20, 25 years. You're going to be interacting with these people all the time. So getting to know these people, getting to essentially humanize the badge, I learned a lot of that in Federalsburg."
While Eckel mentioned his tactical experience as a plus for the town, Trams said he was most impressed by Eckel's passion and his drive to be out in the community.
"Jeremy is not going to just hang around the office and put his feet up and wait for a call to come in," Trams said. "He did tell me that he likes to be out there and ride around. So, the town is going to go through more gas because he's going to be out there and visible. That's exactly what the residents has asked for."
Eckel said when he interacts with residents, they can expect, "kindness, compassion and definitely some knowledge." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Phone-scam investigation expands to victims in six states
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Phone-scam investigation expands to victims in six states

 October 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 533
 Words 

 Read News Document

 An investigation that led to the arrest of an 81-year-old Perryville man accused of stealing more than $160,000 from an 85-year-old California woman through a protracted telephone scam has continued for the past two and a half months, resulting in the lead detective identifying six more victims and six other states, according to Perryville Police Chief Robert Nitz."The total amount of money stolen is up to about one million dollars now," Nitz told the Cecil Whig on Wednesday. "We've reached out the the U.S. Secret Service and now there is a possibility that it will take over the case and handle the investigation from here."
Nitz applauded Perryville Police Department Det. Anthony Lenzi, lead detective, for conducting the initial three-month-long investigation that led to the arrest of the suspect — Harold Joseph Lahr, of the 1400 block of Perryville Road — and for the continuing probe during the past two and a half months, which resulted in the identification of the six additional victims and six other states. Lenzi reportedly was assisted by fellow officers while serving as the lead investigator.
"These types of investigations are especially complex due to the involvement of multiple financial institutions and jurisdictions," Nitz commented. "This case highlights that crime knows no boundaries. I'm extremely proud of the dedication and persistence shown by our officers in bringing justice to the victim. The Perryville Police Department remains committed to protecting our community and (to) working with partners across the country to hold criminals accountable."
The local investigation leading to Lahr's arrest and the criminal charges against him started in May, when detectives with the Orange County (Cal.) Sheriff's Office contacted the Perryville Police Department regarding an elderly resident in their jurisdiction who had been defrauded by someone in Cecil County, police reported.
That spurred a three-month-long investigation, culminating in the arrest of Lahr on July 30 and the charges against him, according to Nitz, who declined to specify the ruse that Lahr allegedly had used to steal the woman's money, citing the pending trial.
Nitz reported that the woman used cashier checks to pay Lahr and, on one occasion, overnighted $8,000 in cash to Lahr through the U.S. Postal Service.
"The investigation revealed that the victim had been defrauded of approximately $163,000 through a series of financial transactions. Through search and seizure warrants, subpoenas, and multiple interviews, Harold Lahr was identified as the suspect," Nitz explained.
The police chief further outlined, "Investigators gathered transaction logs, video surveillance footage, and other supporting evidence before submitting the case to the Cecil County State's Attorney's Office for review."
Investigators arrested Lahr after the Cecil County State's Attorney's Office filed 11 charges against him on July 16 by way of a criminal information document, Nitz outlined.
The criminal charges against Lahr include four counts each of exploitation of a vulnerable adult to steal more than $25,000 and less than $100,000 and theft of more than $25,000 and less than $100,000, according to Cecil County Circuit Court records. Theft scheme to steal more than $100,000 also is among the charges against Lahr, court records show.
Lahr remained in custody on no bond Wednesday, according to court records, which further show that, on Sept. 5, Lahr was found to be incompetent to stand trial. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Students warned of 'imposters' with offers of 'DoorDash-style' marijuana deliveries
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Students warned of 'imposters' with offers of 'DoorDash-style' marijuana deliveries

 October 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 283
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A fraudulent marijuana operation is targeting University of Delaware students and Newark residents by illegally offering marijuana deliveries, according to state officials.The Delaware Division of Alcohol & Tobacco Enforcement issued an alert to the public on Thursday indicating that the agency is investigating reports of flyers and business cards that are being distributed around Newark. The ads falsely claim to be associated with Fresh Cannabis, the licensed medical and recreational marijuana dispensary on Ogletown Road.
"The impostors are attempting to mislead potential customers into purchasing marijuana products illegally," said Jon Peterson, a spokesman for DATE.
One of the ads includes a cartoon of a marijuana leaf character holding a joint and targeting UD students with the words "UDEL-iver? Yes we do!"
"Quick delivery for on-campus students only! (DoorDash/Uber Eats Style!)," reads the ad, which includes the Fresh Cannabis logo and a promise of a free sample of marijuana for students who sign up.
Another ad also includes the Fresh Cannabis logo and shows a menu of offerings. It notes that the business delivers 24/7.
Peterson emphasized that no licensed marijuana dispensary in Delaware is permitted to deliver marijuana or marijuana products.
"Any business claiming to offer delivery services is operating illegally," he said. "Delaware's adult-use marijuana marketplace includes strict regulations and testing standards designed to ensure consumer safety. Products sold through illegal channels bypass these safeguards and may contain dangerous contaminants such as mold, pesticides or heavy metals."
Though Delaware legalized recreational marijuana, it remains illegal to sell it outside of licensed dispensaries.
Tips about this or similar cases can be sent to Cpl. Tristin Burris at tristin.b.burris@delaware.gov.
"DATE's Marijuana Enforcement Unit is actively investigating this matter and encourages anyone with information about these fraudulent materials to come forward," Peterson said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Kent Samaritan Group nears goal to open emergency shelter in December
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Kent Samaritan Group nears goal to open emergency shelter in December

 October 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 649
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — On Sunday afternoon, the day of its fundraising rally at Presbyterian Church of Chestertown, the Samaritan Group of Kent County had $1,400 toward its goal of $14,000 needed to open the Emergency Winter Shelter, in operation since 2003.Because of Christ First United Methodist Church's $5,000 donation, along with other donations, at the end of the event that afternoon, the group had $12,000.
Shelter Director the Rev. James Diggs said they need donations and are optimistic to reach the goal, but they also need volunteers for the shelter: some cooks, but more importantly they need hosts and sleepers. The host, Diggs explained, meets and greets the guests, ensures they are comfortable and safe while the sleepers stay the whole night.
Diggs announced this year they are aiming to open the shelter in December, a first.
That is up to the amount of volunteers that sign up. Diggs said that they have to have 85% of December filled to accomplish this, with volunteers especially needed Christmas Eve, Christmas, New Year's Eve and New Year's.
"Let's make this month a recruiting month. Help us do it because I think we certainly can. We're excited to be able to add December and maybe next year, add another month."
As winter approaches, the need increases to care for Kent County's homeless population he stated.
As their mission describes, the Samaritan Group of Kent County work with local agencies, churches, businesses and organizations and individuals to keep them warm and also providing financial assistance.
During the rally with refreshments and ice cream served by Marcia Stoltzfus and family, Diggs listed the shelter's accomplishments and gave out certificates and awards to the hardworking, caring volunteers which make it possible each year, adding a fun family event along the fundraising.
In the early winter months of 2025, they served 21 clients, seven women, two children and 12 men, 661 bed nights total. In 2018 they served 21 people as well, 1,033 bed nights and that next year, 28 people and 921 bed nights.
"The number of people we serve is unpredictable. We just don't know from year to year. The point is to be ready and all of you volunteers make that possible."
He thanked some of the volunteers that helped get the shelter ready.
Receiving the Laverne and Shirley Award was dynamic duo Annie Woodall and Andrea Nieman. Top Chef, and also supplying that tasty soft serve ice cream was Marcia Stoltzfus and family. The Host with the Most was Allison Brieske and Volunteer of the Year, who dedicated time cooking/ inspiring her whole church to cook, and hosting, was Anne-Marie Walters.
Many other certificates given as well, some of whom were not in attendance.
"They may not be here, but they were when it counted," joked Diggs.
Giving her testimony about the rewards of volunteering was Melanie Keller, who was recruited by Woodall and Nieman years back and was the volunteer coordinator for a time.
Keller said that after her third child, part of what kept her volunteering was her two children who also volunteer. They play hide-and-seek with guests and see other people's experiences, their suffering and joys and practice reaching out with compassion.
"We are a community and I hope to see some of you as hosts," she told attendees.
Diggs said hosts have a very important role, stay from 5:30-10 p.m. and are in pairs. Diggs personally greets the hosts each night and briefs them on what they need to know, ensuring they are comfortable.
Sleepers stay into the night and see guests off in the morning.
Diggs encouraged the audience to not only sign up but to become recruits, sharing the joys of volunteering at the shelter where Mid-Shore Community Foundation, United Way of Kent County, the Good Neighbor Fund and Kent County Department of Social Services partner in this important mission.
"We need your help," Diggs said to the community. "With it we can open up in December...one month at a time."
To contact them go to: info@samaritangroupofkentcounty.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Man charged with attempted murder for Easton stabbing
author: Konner Metz
content:
Man charged with attempted murder for Easton stabbing

 October 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 306
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A Baltimore man is facing attempted murder charges for allegedly stabbing his roommate outside their apartment last month, according to court documents.Steffon Washington, 34, was arrested Oct. 9 for allegedly stabbing a man multiple times on Sept. 21 around 1:30 a.m. in the area of 600 Dover Rd. Easton police, with help from the U.S. Marshals Capital Area Regional Fugitive Task Force, located Washington at a residence in Ellicott City.
The victim, Kendall Wooten, was transported to Shock Trauma with "at least five stab wounds" on his neck, chest, arm and back, according to court documents. Easton Police Department Deputy Chief Greg Wright said on Thursday that Wooten had since been released from the hospital.
Washington is charged with attempted first- and second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment and use of a dangerous weapon with the intent to injure.
Charging documents indicate that Washington and Wooten shared an apartment inside The Gratitude House, an addiction recovery home on Dover Road. The manager of the home witnessed the stabbing, police said in charging documents.
Prior to the stabbing, the manager told police that Wooten and Washington "got into a verbal altercation that turned physical." The manager prepared to give Wooten a ride to leave the apartment, police said.
While in the parking lot, Washington allegedly approached Wooten and stabbed him multiple time, court records state.
The manager told police he "never saw a knife, so he initially thought that Washington was punching Wooten, until he saw blood spurting from Wooten's neck," court records state.
The manager applied aid to Wooten while Washington left the scene, per court records. Police arrived on scene and observed blood near the vehicle where the stabbing occurred, charging documents state.
Washington is being held without bond at the Talbot County Detention Center. A preliminary hearing in Talbot County District Court is set for Nov. 4. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bikes, scooters need to show caution
author: Staff Writer
content:
Bikes, scooters need to show caution

 October 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 398
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last week, I met and spoke with Easton Police Department Officer Hugo Galan while walking on the Rails to Trails. We talked after he spoke to a man riding a motorized bicycle about keeping safety in mind as he traveled the trails.I told him my concerns about more and more riders of electric bikes, scooters and skateboards whizzing along on the trails with seemingly little regard for pedestrians. If these riders were on the street, the speed probably wouldn't be as noticeable, but when you're walking, it feels really fast as they zip by, startling because you often don't hear them until they're next to you.
And, it happens without warning, like signaling with the ringing of a bicycle bell behind you, or, as some kindly people do, call out to let you know what side they're passing on. Careless riders will zig-zag at top speed between older adults walking dogs, little kids on bikes and scooters, or moms pushing strollers with small children in tow. It's frightening to watch because one misstep could result in something terrible.
The Rails to Trails through Easton is a pedestrian highway for hundreds of people. Some without transportation use it to get to jobs. Schoolchildren use it to get to and from school. And for others, it's a daily exercise routine or a way to simply enjoy the outdoors. But with more motorized bikes, scooters and even skateboards, the safety and peacefulness of walking on the trails has changed. Walkers have to factor in the possibility of being hit, adding a lot more caution to each stroll.
Easton residents have been speaking up about the uptick of speeding on the trails, expressing concerns to the police department and to town officials. Officer Galan said the Easton Police Department has expanded its outreach and patrols to increase safety awareness among riders, urging them to slow down as they approach walkers and runners. I applaud these conversations, the extra patrols and other actions the police take each day, particularly at night when no one should be on the trails or in the parks, to keep all of us safe.
It is reassuring to see officers on the trails engaging with the public in positive ways to increase everyone's awareness. But most importantly, riders need to show more courtesy to walkers and slow down. We all use the trail and we want to enjoy it safely.
BARBARA SAUERS
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on safety concerns for pedestrians due to increasing motorized vehicle use on public trails, emphasizing the need for caution and police outreach to prevent accidents. While local government actions are mentioned, the core issue is public safety.

title: Man who shot co-worker sentenced to 50 years
author: Konner Metz
content:
Man who shot co-worker sentenced to 50 years

 October 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 277
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A man has been sentenced to a combined 50 years in prison for shooting a co-worker outside a Trappe gas station last year.Antonio Bolden, 37, received consecutive 35- and 15-year terms in Talbot and Dorchester counties, respectively, after pleading guilty to attempted first-degree murder and armed carjacking.
Bolden shot a man in the face and arm at the Freedom Fuel gas station and food mart off of U.S. Route 50 on Sept. 17, 2024.
The victim, then-29-year-old Aigner Smith of Salisbury, was identified as Bolden's co-worker. The two were heading to a job site in the same van when Bolden asked the victim to pull over at the gas station.
Smith has since recovered from his injuries after a number of surgeries, according to a press release from the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office.
The day of the shooting was Bolden's second day working for a new company, prosecutors said. Bolden and Smith "did not have any prior history" and there was no "provocation or disagreement" between them before the shooting, the press release stated.
After shooting Smith, Bolden removed him from the car, left him on the ground and fled the scene in the van, according to the press release. He tried carjacking a vehicle in Cambridge before police arrested him. Bolden later pleaded guilty to armed carjacking.
At an Oct. 7 hearing, Talbot County Circuit Court Judge Phil Cronan handed down a life sentence with all but 35 years suspended. Two days later, Dorchester County Circuit Court Judge Karen Dean sentenced Bolden to 15 years for the carjacking.
The two sentences will be served consecutively. Following the 35-year sentence, Bolden will be placed under five years of supervised probation. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton officials weigh in on Complete Streets study, pedestrian safety
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton officials weigh in on Complete Streets study, pedestrian safety

 October 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 640
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Town officials on Monday discussed ongoing efforts to shore up pedestrian and bike safety, including a comprehensive study on the town's roads and streets.In a workshop, Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh updated the Town Council on an ongoing study into street safety conducted by the engineering firm Wallace Montgomery.
The study, known as Complete Streets, aims to create a manual for Easton outlining which types of roads and streets prioritize certain modes of transportation, such as walking, biking and driving. The study itself will not make road safety improvements, though officials see it as a guide to initiating those upgrades.
Those leading the study are in the process of meeting with local businesses and safety stakeholders to gather feedback on how best to define and classify different streets. Larry Marcus, an associate for Wallace Montgomery, said some classifications include residential, collector, commercial urban and commercial industrial streets.
Roads are further defined by land use: downtown, residential, commercial and industrial, Marcus said. The categories roads fall into will determine the study's recommendation on which sidewalk, bike lane or vehicular improvements should be taken.
Van Emburgh added that the manual will make it easier for the town to require certain road safety steps be taken when residential or commercial developers apply for site plan approval. Moving forward, the town will be less likely to give developers breaks or reliefs from ensuring private roads are up to town standards, he said.
"It's a very practical document that I can think of a lot of different ways it will be used," Van Emburgh said of the Complete Streets study. Guidelines will be drafted and applied to a map of town roads in November.
During the nearly hourlong workshop, many specific pressure points in town were raised, including Port Street and North Washington Street.
Council President Don Abbatiello said telephone poles in the middle of sidewalks on Port Street make it difficult for people to walk safely. Council members Maureen Curry and the Rev. Elmer Davis echoed the concern about the street.
"It's gonna (be) awfully difficult to make Port Street pedestrian friendly unless we make some serious improvements," Curry said.
On North Washington Street, sidewalks are expected to be added. Van Emburgh said the town has funds in its budget already for survey and design work for North Washington Street from Easton Hardware (near the Creamery Lane intersection) to Gay's Seafood (close to the stoplight at the Easton Parkway, or Route 322).
The Complete Streets guidance will help determine the specific bike, pedestrian and vehicular safety measures taken for the North Washington Street project.
Pedestrian and bike safety has been an ongoing discussion among town leaders, residents and local advocates. Earlier this month, worries about safety on Route 50 — a state-operated highway — were raised after a man on a bike was struck and killed.
Ward 3 Councilmember David Montgomery shared concerns that the town would sacrifice the efficient flow of vehicular traffic in order to prioritize walking and biking. He said many of the older residents in his ward — including the west side of Easton Parkway — aren't "interested in bicycling to downtown."
"Automobile transportation is pretty much what everybody uses in order to get into the center of town," Montgomery said. "So I'm very concerned about our sacrificing the flow of single-occupancy vehicles, sacrificing it to other things, that for my ward, don't do any good at all by way of mobility."
Heather Grant, executive director of Talbot Thrive, a local nonprofit that advocates for pedestrian and bike safety, refuted Montgomery's stance. In a statement, she said residents who "don't want to drive everywhere" deserve "equal access to safe infrastructure."
"Some council members who mention the difficulties in traveling by car during school drop off and pick up should consider that if we make our streets safer for kids to walk and bike to school, we can reduce vehicle congestion," Grant wrote.
